headline: Custody of Domestic Terror Suspects Extended by Two Weeks
body: The two individuals suspected of planning a domestic terror attack will be held in custody for another two weeks, V√≠sir reports. A defence attorney has called the decision ‚Äúincomprehensible‚Äù in light of a psychiatric assessment that held that the men were neither a danger to themselves nor others. Four Icelandic men were arrested on September 21 suspected of ‚Äúterrorist plots‚Äù against state institutions and civilians. Two of the suspects were immediately released; the other two have remained in custody. According to the police, the suspects had hoarded numerous weapons ‚Äì including dozens of semi-automatic guns and 3D-printed components ‚Äì alongside a considerable amount of ammunition. The men, both of whom are in their twenties, had discussed carrying out attacks against political figures, among them Minister Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r √û√≥r√∞arson and Chairman of Efling, S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir. As noted by V√≠sir yesterday, the two men were initially placed in custody on the basis of investigative interests, but the current extension, as confirmed by the Reykjav√≠k District Court, was predicated on public interest, with the men believed to be a danger to the public. In an interview with V√≠sir yesterday, Sveinn Andri Sveinsson, defence attorney for one of the men, stated that the decision was founded on a threat analysis carried out by the National Police Department. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve criticised the fact that the threat assessment, which actually predated the psychiatric assessment, did not take the psychiatric assessment into account.‚Äù According to Sveinn, the psychiatrist who carried out the assessment at the behest of the police did not believe the men to be a threat to themselves or others. The District Court, however, did not take this assessment into account. Sveinn Andri added that his client would be appealing the District Court‚Äôs decision, which was a big disappointment, to the Court of Appeal. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs always disappointing for individuals who are in custody without good reason to have to remain in custody. But we‚Äôll simply have to deal with it and try to have the decision overturned in the Court of Appeals. That would be ideal.‚Äù In late October, Sveinn Andri Sveinsson dismissed private messages between the suspects as a ‚Äúfailed attempt at humour,‚Äù adding that he did not believe that either of the men would be charged with planning a terrorist attack.

headline: Optimism for Icelandic Language in the Digital Age
body: The integration of the Icelandic language into digital services and devices has improved rapidly over the last few months, with large leaps in speech recognition. Nana Bule, a representative for Microsoft, stated to R√öV: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been fortunate enough to have really high quality data sets on the Icelandic language, which means that we‚Äôve in very short time improved language recognition for Icelandic by 32%. Which may sound small, but is actually a very big improvement that would normally have taken 5 to 10 years.‚Äù Earlier this May, an Icelandic delegation including President Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson and Minister of Culture and Trade Lilja D. Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir met with American tech companies to discuss the further integration of the Icelandic language into digital services and devices. Following the May meetings, representatives from Microsoft have been visiting Iceland this week to report on progress made. Now, the meetings seem to be bearing fruit, with surprisingly fast improvements for the integration of Icelandic into digital services. Mrs. Bule stated that Icelanders will soon be able to speak Icelandic to their devices without a problem. Bule also stated with regard to speech recognition: ‚ÄúWe can already do that today, but my hope is that in the future, we will be able to do it much more fluently. In the future, an interview could be you asking me questions in Icelandic, me answering in English, but listeners could hear it in Icelandic hopefully because we‚Äôll be able to translate it in real time.‚Äù President Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson said with regard to the innovations that it will be essential for the future of the Icelandic language to have a place in the digital sphere as well.

headline: Buster Takes Over from Tindur
body: A new drug dog, Buster, will begin his duties in the Westfjords police force. The dog he will be replacing, named Tindur, will be retiring next year. Steinar Gunnarsson, a police officer in the Westfjords, was responsible for training Buster and handing him over to his new supervisors. Pictured are Tindur and Buster with their supervisors, √û√≥r Gu√∞mundsson and Mar√≠n Elvarsd√≥ttir. According to the announcement, Tindur has served with Westfjords police for many years, but is now in his senior years. In the announcement on Facebook, Westfjords police stated: ‚ÄúWe expect a lot from Buster and believe that he will be just as good as Tindur.‚Äù

headline: Iceland Moves to Reduce Marine Bycatch in Light of New US Import Regulations
body: Icelandic regulators are making moves to conform to new regulations of seafood imports in the United States, according to the latest information from the Ministry of Food, Agriculture, and Fisheries. In an effort to promote more sustainable fishing practices among exporting nations, the US has announced the introduction of new regulations which limit the acceptable amount of marine bycatch produced by fishing. Originally announced in 2016 with a 5-year grace period for nations to conform to the new regulations, the implementation has been delayed in part due to the COVID-19 pandemic, leaving Icelandic fisheries extra time to meet the new rules. Especially important in the Icelandic context is the amount of seabirds and seals affected by lumpfish fishing, a fishery traditionally for small boat fishermen. Some Icelanders have expressed concerns that the new regulations will disproportionately affect small-scale rural fishermen, who are already suffering economically. According to the Ministry of Food, Agriculture, and Fisheries, Iceland has already launched measures in response to the new US regulations. Increased monitoring is being implemented, using ship logs, drones, and geospatial modelling to better understand the distribution of bycatch. In response to the poor state of the seal population in Iceland, the direct hunting of seals has been banned. It is now forbidden to shoot seals to scare them away from fish farms, for instance. Other methods are also being investigated to reduce bycatch, such as the use of sound repellents on fishing gear. By both increasing the monitoring of wild fishing stocks, and also increasingly monitoring registered bycatch, Icelandic authorities hope to gain a fuller picture of their success in implementing these changes. Another concern is that the relatively higher bycatch of smaller fisheries, such as lumpfish, could adversely affect the status of larger, more lucrative fisheries, such as cod. According to the Ministry of Food, Agriculture, and Fisheries, while it is certain that seafood from fisheries with bycatch in excess of US guidelines will be prevented from entering the market, there is as of yet no final word on how seafood from other fisheries will be handled. It is also as of yet unclear whether the steps taken by Icelandic authorities will be considered sufficient to meet the US conditions. The US regulations, after a delay, are now slated to come into effect on January 1, 2024. ¬† ¬†

headline: Mouse Infestation ‚ÄúUnlike Anything‚Äù Exterminator Has Seen
body: In an interview with R√öV, a seasoned exterminator has stated that Iceland is currently experiencing a mouse infestation the likes of which he‚Äôs never seen. He encourages people to take the necessary precautions. Despite their small stature, mice can be an outsized pest for homeowners. √Årni Logi Sigurbj√∂rnsson, an exterminator of 43 years, has been busy over the past days ‚Äì in light of a countrywide mouse infestation. ‚ÄúThe infestation traces its roots to favourable weather conditions,‚Äù √Årni told R√öV. ‚ÄúFlush growth of vegetation last spring has meant plenty of nourishment for mice. Then when you have these long days of rain and the temperature begins to drop ‚Äì hovering around freezing during nights ‚Äì they begin to seek shelter in cars and homes, cottages and bales, because mouseholes aren‚Äôt exactly ideal.‚Äù √Årni recommends that individuals take good care of their possessions by taking the necessary precautions and installing mousetraps; mice can squeeze in through holes as small as ten millimetres. ‚ÄúI encourage people to be on their guard because mice, even though they‚Äôre small, can wreak great damage.‚Äù ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†

headline: Protests in Front of Parliament in Wake of Deportations
body: Protestors last week flocked to Austurv√∂llur square in front of Iceland‚Äôs parliament in response to the recent deportation of Icelandic refugees. The protests took place Thursday, November 3, and Sunday, November 6 with some thousand people in attendance. The recent wave of deportations is the largest in recent history in Iceland, with some refugees being deported as their applications for asylum status were still under consideration by the Directorate of Immigration. Isavia, the company responsible for running Keflav√≠k International Airport, has also come under critique for its involvement in the deportations. The Journalists‚Äô Association of Iceland has accused Isavia of obstructing the work of journalists covering the deportations, turning floodlights against a crowd of reporters. Isavia has published a statement regretting their involvement, saying that they were following police instructions, who requested that Isavia staff prevent filming of the deportations. F√≥lk streymir √° Austurv√∂ll til a√∞ √æess a√∞ m√≥tm√¶la √≥mann√∫√∞legri brottvisun h√¶lisleitenda pic.twitter.com/hmwgcEeMLC The above video from Pirate Party MP G√≠sli √ìlafsson shows a glimpse of the crowd present at the Thursday protests.¬†¬† Icelandic police forces have also faced criticism for their treatment of the deported individuals, with one video showing a refugee man being forcefully removed from his wheelchair. According to Icelandic police, they are now considering having vehicles more suitable for wheelchairs. Further critique has been raised by the confiscation of refugees‚Äô phones. Icelandic police state that the refugees‚Äô phones were taken from them in order to ensure their safety. Helgi Valberg Jensson, Chief Legal Office of the National Police, stated to V√≠sir: ‚ÄúWe had individuals in custody, and it was our duty to ensure their safety.¬† Whether this needs to be revised is something we will consider moving forward.‚Äù Police body cameras were also reported to have been turned off during portions of the raids. Helgi has stated that this for the privacy of individuals who may feel uncomfortable. Among the critics of the recent deportations are the United Nations Children‚Äôs Fund in Iceland, the Icelandic branch of Amnesty International, the Disabled Persons‚Äô Association, the Red Cross in Iceland and the Icelandic Teachers‚Äô Association.

headline: Council of Europe to be Held in Reykjav√≠k
body: The Council of Europe is to be held in Reykjav√≠k in May of next year. The meeting is to be the fourth-ever meeting in the organisation‚Äôs 73-year history, taking place 16-17 May, 2023. The Council of Europe, a distinct organisation from the European Union, is an international body tasked with upholding human rights and rule of law in Europe. Founded after the Second World War, its best-known body is the European Court of Human Rights. Faced with new crises in Europe, from the war in Ukraine and the accompanying energy crisis to the economic disruptions of the global COVID-19 pandemic, the organisation has announced that it is time to redouble efforts to promote democracy and justice in Europe. Some 46 nations are party to the Council of Europe #Breaking @coe Committee of Ministers just adopted decision to hold 4th Summit of Heads of State/Gov in üáÆüá∏Reykjavik in May 2023. Opportunity for leaders of 46 Council of Europe Member States to unite & recommit to the core principles ‚Äì human rights, democracy & rule of law. pic.twitter.com/wp2CuASGMf In a press release from the Council of Europe, Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir stated: ‚ÄúIt is a great honour for Iceland to be the host of the 4th Summit of Heads of State and Government. Iceland is convinced that the Council of Europe ‚Äì the continent‚Äôs oldest and leading pan-European organization ‚Äì has a critical role to play as the region‚Äôs guardian of human rights, democracy, and the rule of law. Together, we must continue to ensure that the Council of Europe is fit for purpose to meet current and future challenges as well as the expectations of future generations. We applaud the Irish presidency for their in-depth work on the role of the Council and look forward to working with all the Council‚Äôs Member States to reaffirm our common commitment to the Council‚Äôs core principles.‚Äù Council of Europe Secretary General Marija Pejƒçinoviƒá Buriƒá also stated: ‚ÄúThe decision to hold a Fourth Summit of Heads of State and Governments is timely and right. I congratulate the Committee of Ministers on taking it. The Summit will be an opportunity for all our member states to recommit to the values that underpin democratic security in our fast-changing continent.‚Äù

headline: Opioid Abuse Among Young People Growing More Common
body: Opioid abuse among individuals 25 years old and younger has grown more common, according to Dr. Valger√∞ur R√∫narsd√≥ttir, the Medical Director of S√Å√Å (the National Centre of Addiction Medicine). Valger√∞ur addressed the audience at a conference at the Hilton Nordica hotel yesterday, Mbl.is reports. Speaking to Iceland Review last month, Dr. Valger√∞ur R√∫narsd√≥ttir, the Medical Director of S√Å√Å (National Centre of Addiction Medicine) stated that talk of a ‚Äúnew opioid crisis‚Äù in Iceland was not an exaggeration. Referring to the data, Valger√∞ur noted that between 2010 and 2022, the percentage of patients being treated for opioid addiction at the Vogur detox centre and rehabilitation hospital rose by approximately 200% (from 10.3% to ca. 30% of the clinic‚Äôs patients). Furthermore, these patients are twice as likely to relapse than others, and thirty-five of those who have sought treatment over the past five years have died. Read More: In Harm‚Äôs Way: Harm Reduction in the Age of Opioids Yesterday, Valger√∞ur addressed the audience at a conference held by S√Å√Å and F√ÅR (the Association of Alcohol and Drug Advisors) at the Hilton Nordica hotel in Reykjav√≠k between November 2 and 3. According to her lecture, prescription opioid abuse ‚Äì including opioids like Contalgin, Oxycontin, and Fentanyl ‚Äì among individuals 25 and younger has grown more common. Although opioid abuse is on the rise, alcohol is still the most commonly abused intoxicant in Iceland. Speaking to Mbl.is, Valger√∞ur noted that the problems were ‚Äúof a different nature‚Äù when individuals are abusing potent prescription drugs. Valger√∞ur also noted that the percentage of working individuals who are admitted to the Vogur rehabilitation centre has declined to 30%. Given this, it was important that the Icelandic Vocational Rehabilitation Fund (VIRK) no longer mandates a 3-6 month sober period as a condition for entering into vocational rehabilitation. The aforementioned conference was the first to be sponsored jointly by S√Å√Å and F√ÅR. Valger√∞ur told Mbl.is that many parties, including VIRK, F√ÅR, S√Å√Å, and municipal authorities, are determined to work together to combat substance abuse in Iceland.

headline: Arrest of Refugee Raises Critique
body: Freyja Haraldsd√≥ttir, an advocate for the disabled in the capital area, said that the rights of a disabled refugee were not respected when he was arrested last night, November 2. A lawyer representing the man is now preparing a complaint to the European Court of Human Rights, according to V√≠sir. The man, originally from Iraq, is in Iceland with a family of five, all of whom were scheduled to be deported to Greece last night. This is alongside several other deportation-related arrests that have been made in the last week, with several refugees and asylum seekers now in police custody. He is also wheelchair-bound and has received important medical treatment during his time in Iceland. His entire family was arrested yesterday and taken to a hotel in Hafnafj√∂r√∞ur for their deportation, but the man was later removed from the hotel by police officers. Freyja Haraldsd√≥ttir has stated to V√≠sir that the man‚Äôs rights were violated when he has not provided with an advocate. As a disabled person, Freyja stated, he was in a particularly vulnerable position: ‚ÄúHe has the right to have a lawyer to support him, both to inform him about what is going on and what the next steps are, to ensure that he understands everything that is going on, make sure that he can speak his mind, and make sure that appropriate accommodations are made so that he does not suffer harm in his situation.‚Äù The incident has sparked controversy on social media, with a photo depicting police officers forcibly removing the man from his wheelchair in wide circulation. ¬†

headline: September Recording-Breaking Month for Tourism
body: In a report by Statistics Iceland, overnight stays in hotel accommodations in Iceland are shown to be 7,144,400 for the year so far. This represents a 2% increase from 2018, the previous record-breaking year before the global pandemic. Should the trend hold, 2022 could be the busiest year ever in the Icelandic tourism industry. In September of this year, some 853,500 overnight stays in hotel accommodations were recorded, representing a 27% increase from September 2021. Approximately 81% of these overnight stays can be accounted for by foreign tourists, or around 691,000 stays. Icelanders and residents of Iceland accounted for the remaining 19%, at around 161,000 overnight stays. Compared with September 2021, this represents a slight decrease in the amount of domestic tourism, when Icelanders were generally more represented during the travel restrictions imposed by COVID-19. ¬† Not surprisingly, the region of Iceland with the largest yearly increase was the capital region, with an 11.8% increase in overnight stays from September 2021 to September 2022. Following the capital region were West Iceland and the West Fjords, with an 8.3% increase in the same period. The region least affected by the recent upswing was East Iceland, with a negligible 0.5% increase in overnight stays year-on-year. The total supply of hotel rooms has also risen since last year. This summer saw an acute shortage of accommodations in Iceland, driving many prices up. Statistics Iceland reports now an 8% increase in hotel capacity, with an average occupancy over the year of around 79%. ¬†

headline: Sixteen Middle Managers at Landsp√≠tali Hospital Dismissed
body: Sixteen middle managers employed at the National University Hospital of Iceland received letters of termination yesterday, R√öV reports. The terminations stem from the adoption of a new organisational chart intended to improve the hospital‚Äôs operations. A new organisational chart will come into effect at the National University Hospital on January 1. According to director Run√≥lfur P√°lsson, the organisational chart is intended to simplify the hospital‚Äôs operations and make them more efficient. ‚ÄúThe main purpose is to get a handle on the hospital‚Äôs management and operations, to strengthen our clinical services, and to harmonise other key services,‚Äù Run√≥lfur remarked in an interview with R√öV. Over the past months, questions concerning the sustainability of the hospital‚Äôs operations have come to the fore. When asked if these changes would be felt by the public, Run√≥lfur replied: ‚ÄúI hope it‚Äôll translate into a stronger hospital, that we‚Äôll be able to improve our service: improve our emergency services, the flow of patients while also strengthening our surgical department. If we‚Äôre successful in this regard, then the public will certainly feel it.‚Äù The hospital‚Äôs organisational chart was introduced to the Minister of Health today. The changes imply a decrease in the number of middle managers and increased responsibility among front-line managers. ‚ÄúSix directorial positions will be cut, but there are two positions that are bound by law, namely the directorship of nurses and medicine ‚Äì but the other six will be cut alongside all of the ten managerial positions,‚Äù Run√≥lfur remarked. As reported by R√öV, the sixteen individuals holding the aforementioned positions received a letter of notice yesterday. Run√≥lfur added that because the organisational chart had yet to be implemented, it remained to be seen whether it would result in increased efficiency. ‚ÄúThese are big changes, and we must be aware that changes to the organisational chart, in themselves, are not enough to improve our output ‚Äì there are other things that must work out as well,‚Äù Run√≥lfur stated. ‚ÄúBut the purpose of these changes is to get a better handle on and harmonise our clinical services. In the near future, we will aim to overhaul all of the clinical organisational units in the front line and strengthen its management affording them greater responsibility.‚Äù

headline: Record Number of Coronavirus Deaths Since Start of 2022
body: Deaths from COVID-19 have hit a record high, V√≠sir reports, with 188 people having died from the coronavirus since the beginning of 2022. According to Chief Epidemiologist Gu√∞r√∫n Aspelund, the effect of COVID-19 far outweighs the effects of other infectious diseases such as influenza. Deaths from COVID-19 have surged since the start of 2022, V√≠sir reports. Thirty-one people died from the coronavirus in 2020 compared to eight in 2021. During the first ten months of 2022, however, that number has risen to 188. According to Chief Epidemiologist Gu√∞r√∫n Aspelund, this upswing in cases owes primarily to the highly infectious Omicron variant and the fact that no social restrictions are in place. Deaths have mainly occurred among individuals seventy years and older. ‚ÄúWhich is why we‚Äôre encouraging older people, everyone sixty years and older, and those who are at risk, to get their booster shots. That‚Äôs the best form of protection,‚Äù Gu√∞r√∫n remarked, adding that protection from vaccines diminishes over a period of a few months. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve also got new vaccines now that offer protection against the original variant of coronavirus and Omicron, which offers better protection. We need to repeat these vaccinations to enter into winter with good protection.‚Äù Read More: Long-form Interview with former chief epidemiologist √û√≥r√≥lfur Gu√∞nason Gu√∞r√∫n observed that Iceland‚Äôs neighbouring countries have also been seeing a rise in cases in 2022. ‚ÄúConfirmed deaths from COVID-19 are believed to be around six and a half million. But there are many who believe that those figures are at least twice as high ‚Äì thousands of people are still dying from coronavirus every week.‚Äù According to Gu√∞r√∫n, deaths from coronavirus are significantly higher than deaths from influenza. Coronavirus deaths in Iceland are, however, lower when compared to other countries, with Iceland having the lowest death toll among the Nordic countries. When asked to speculate why, Gu√∞r√∫n pointed to Iceland‚Äôs speedy vaccination campaign, its social restrictions, and the fact that the healthcare system had responded well. ‚ÄúI think we can chalk up this achievement to these factors along with the participation of the citizenry.‚Äù

headline: Further Animal Abuse from Borgarf√∂r√∞ur Farmer Already Implicated Earlier this Year
body: The Icelandic Food and Veterinary Authority, MAST, is taking action against the same farmer responsible for a case of animal abuse against horses earlier this year. The current case concerns cattle in Borgarfj√∂r√∞ur that have been reportedly abused. According to information from MAST, the livestock are no longer in the farmer‚Äôs custody. According to R√öV, neighbours of the farm have complained about conditions on the farm, saying that the animals have inadequate water and shelter against the elements. According to the neighbours, livestock on the farm are often locked inside for long periods, and the cattle that are seen outside are often malnourished to the point of deformity. The owner of the cattle in question has also been reported as having a difficult relationship with his neighbours in past, with some saying that he has shown threatening behaviour. Now, according to MAST, the livestock are in a better facility. According to the neighbour interviewed by R√öV, the livestock in question had been locked inside for nearly three years.

headline: Emergency Shelters Not Able to Cope with High Numbers of Unhoused People
body: Hrafnhildur √ìl√∂f √ìlafsd√≥ttir, nurse and head of the City of Reykjav√≠k working group on homelessness, has stated in a recent interview with R√öV that following a large increase in the use of homeless shelters in the last two years, the system can no longer cope with the large demand placed on it. According to the latest information from the Welfare Council, some 87 women and 214 men remain unhoused in Reykjav√≠k. 30% of this group use emergency shelters, with around another 50% in residential facilities. Hrafnhildur stated to R√öV that the crisis had many causes: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs connected to many factors, especially the housing and rental market, and reduced access now to guesthouses, hotels, and hostels, which we had access to during the pandemic.‚Äú Emergency shelters in Reykjav√≠k are now consistently at and above their limits, compared with 2021 where utilization of shelters sat between 60-80%, and in 2020, when it sat around 30-50%. Further exacerbating the problem is the fact that around a third of Reykav√≠k‚Äôs unhoused come from other municipalities. Hrafnhildur stated: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not that people are choosing to come to Reykjav√≠k, we are simply the only municipality that offers these services. Other resources need to be developed and allocated elsewhere, too.‚Äù See our Ask Iceland Review on homelessness in Iceland for more information. ¬† ¬†

headline: The Climate Disaster Has ‚ÄúAlready Begun to Materialise‚Äù
body: The international community is ‚Äúfalling far short of the Paris goals,‚Äù a new UN report finds. ‚ÄúThe disaster has already begun to materialise,‚Äù Halld√≥r √ûorgeirsson, Chair of Iceland‚Äôs Climate Council, told R√öV yesterday. Yesterday, October 27, the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) published its 2022 edition of the Emissions Gap report. The report provides an update on the progress towards ‚Äúachieving national mitigation pledges‚Äù and the goals set by the Paris Agreement by taking stock of the so-called ‚Äúemissions gap.‚Äù As noted by a UN press release, the report concludes that the international community is ‚Äúfalling far short of the Paris goals, with no credible pathway to 1.5¬∞C in place.‚Äù The authors state that the only way to avoid climate disaster is via an urgent ‚Äúsystem-wide transformation.‚Äù Read More: The Age of Eco-Anxiety ‚ÄúGlobal and national climate commitments are falling pitifully short,‚Äù Secretary General of the UN Ant√≥nio Guterres stated in a video message during an introduction of the report yesterday. ‚ÄúWe must close the emissions gap before climate catastrophe closes in on us all.‚Äù To address the report‚Äôs findings, R√öV invited the Chair of Iceland‚Äôs Climate Council Halld√≥r √ûorgeirsson (and a retired Senior Director at the UN Climate Change Secretariat) to an interview during yesterday‚Äôs nightly news. Halld√≥r was blunt: ‚ÄúThese disasters have already begun to materialise, and this year, we have seen disasters that are truly man-made. The strongest example being Pakistan, and, just as bad, and nearer to home, Florida. ‚ÄúThese things are already manifesting in such a way that it‚Äôs no longer a question of the future. Our meagre achievements means that the window of opportunity grows ever narrower; there‚Äôs much less time. That‚Äôs why the only feasible path forward is to undertake fast and extensive system-wide transformation.‚Äù The only way to do this, Halld√≥r maintained, was increased investment. ‚ÄúThese are large figures but in reality, it‚Äôs only about 2% of the total budget. So it certainly seems doable. Central banks play a big role, and we need to rethink the economy. That‚Äôs what this is about ‚Äì alongside greater cooperation between nations.‚Äù The 2022 United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP27) will be held from November 6 to 18 in Egypt. It will mark the 27th United Nations Climate Change conference. According to Halld√≥r, no ‚Äúbig decisions‚Äù are expected to be made during the conference. ‚ÄúThis conference will focus more on following through with the agreement,‚Äù Halld√≥r observed. ‚ÄúThe implementation of the Paris Agreement was concluded in Glasgow last year. During the first two days of the conference, global leaders will be present, and the messages that they send matter. All eyes will be on China. They‚Äôve been quite reticent. Then there‚Äôs this very strong undercurrent, connected to those aforementioned disasters because one of the big questions of this conference is how we provide aid to nations who suffer such disasters.‚Äù

headline: Two Thirds of Reykjav√≠k Residents Support Pedestrian Zones
body: The majority of Reykjav√≠k residents view pedestrian districts in downtown positively, according to a recent poll commissioned by the City of Reykjav√≠k from Mask√≠na, a market research group. The recent opinion poll also reports a significant reduction in negative opinions towards pedestrian districts in the last four years. In total, 64.5% of Reykjav√≠k residents view pedestrian districts positively, with 12.3% viewing them negatively. Interestingly, those disposed most positively towards pedestrian districts are generally those who live near and visit pedestrian districts, such as Laugavegur, often. Conversely, negative attitudes towards walking zones were also shown to cluster around those who live away from and visit walking zones less. 88% who visit walking districts weekly or more feel positively towards them. 64% of those who visit one to three times a month felt positively towards them, and only 38% of those who visited walking districts less than once a month felt positively towards them. The neighborhoods most positively disposed towards pedestrian areas were Vesturb√¶r (80%) and downtown (78%). Among key benefits of walking districts residents of Reykjav√≠k highlighted in the poll were positive effects on health, community, restaurants and caf√©s, and shopping. The poll also comes at a time when Reykjav√≠k City is planning to expand the walking district by Austurv√∂llur around D√≥mkirkjan and Al√æingi. The plans for the new walking area, which can be accessed here, will convert Kirkjustr√¶ti and Temparasund into pedestrian-only areas. The area will also receive an extensive redesign. The Mask√≠na survey took place between August 12 and 17 of this year, with a random sample of citizens and residents selected from Registers Iceland. Respondents were 18 years and older, and represent all districts of Reykjav√≠k. ¬† ¬† ¬†

headline: Reykjav√≠k City Proposes New Fee for Winter Tires
body: The Environment Agency of Iceland has introduced a new plan for air quality in the capital region which would advise local authorities to introduce new fees for studded winter tires, reports Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞. According to air quality expert at the Environment Agency, √ûorsteinn J√≥hannsson, there now exists the political will to push through these new regulations, which would aim to both improve air quality by lessening the particulate matter in the air, and also lessen wear on the capital‚Äôs roads. Some, according to √ûorsteinn, have stated that this would amount to a further tax burden on Iceland‚Äôs already-struggling rural communities. Because of the conditions during winter, it is practically a requirement for Iceland‚Äôs rural population to use studded tires. √ûorsteinn, however, has clarified that the fee would apply principally to the capital region, and that visitors with studded tires to the capital would pay a daily fee. In this way, it would function much like a parking fee. According to √ûorsteinn, investigations show that studded tires cause 20 to 40 times as much wear to roads as non-studded. √ûorsteinn also notes that although the legal season for winter tires is from November 1 to April 14, there are already many studded tires on the road in Reykjav√≠k. Alexandra Briem, chairperson of the city council, has also stated her support for such a fee, noting that additional methods to reduce air pollution and wear on roads are needed. More information on car ownership and regulations can be found at the Icelandic Automobile Association.

headline: US Extends Deadline for Marine Mammal Bycatch Regulations
body: In a recent announcement, the United States National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has extended the deadline for the implementation of regulations governing the import of seafood to the US. Aimed at protecting endangered species and limiting the amount of unnecessary bycatch (what is unintentionally caught by net fishing, which can include seabirds, other species of fish, seals, dolphins, and even small whales), the regulations aim to limit the import of marine products from fisheries where marine mammals are caught. This has potentially large consequences for Iceland, the US being a major export market for Icelandic seafood. The regulations were originally introduced in 2016 and gave exporting nations a 5-year period to comply with the new US regulations. However, this grace period was extended by a year, and then further delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Notably, Iceland lost its Marine Stewardship Council (MSC) certification in 2018 due to the large number of bycatch produced by Icelandic lumpfish fishing. Lumpfish generally stick near the shore and are thus safe from larger trawlers. This fish, prized for its roe, is still fished in small boats with nets. However, net fishing also produces large amounts of unwanted bycatch. Although Iceland has taken steps in recent years to minimizing the environmental impact of net fishing, it is a complicated situation for Icelandic fishermen, as it is generally the small boat fishermen who will be under the most pressure from the current regulations. Iceland‚Äôs small boat fishermen have already been sidelined in many ways by the current quota system. Although the bycatch problem is indeed important, it leaves some wondering if the burden of environmental responsibility is being placed excessively on small, independent fishermen. ¬† ¬†

headline: Iceland Ranked World‚Äôs 20th Most Innovative Nation
body: Iceland ranks 20th among the world‚Äôs most innovative nations according to the new global innovation index. Switzerland, the US, and Sweden remain top. The Global Innovation Index is ‚Äúan annual ranking of countries by their capacity for, and success in, innovation.‚Äù The index ‚Äì started in 2007 by INSEAD and World Business ‚Äì is published by the World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO) and is based on both subjective and objective data derived from several sources, including the International Telecommunication Union, the World Bank, and the World Economic Forum. Falling three places from 2021, Iceland ranks 20th according to this year‚Äôs index (the confidence interval indicates that Iceland ranks somewhere between 15th and 20th) and 12th among European countries. Read More: Idea Island (Iceland Is Investing in Innovation) As noted by the government‚Äôs website, Iceland‚Äôs standing may be somewhat skewed by its size and abundance of natural resources: ‚ÄúAs a small country, by international standards, Iceland draws the short straw when it comes to several criteria employed by WIPO during the index‚Äôs calculus; the criteria is not patterned to small nations rich in natural resources.‚Äù To this point, Iceland scores high (14th place) in the categories Institutions and Business Sophistication, and is ranked first when it comes to the use of information and communication technologies, electricity output, share of gross domestic expenditure on research and development (GERD) financed from abroad, number of scientific articles published per capita, national feature films, and online creativity. On the other hand, Iceland scores low when it comes to the ratio of gross-domestic-product (GDP)-to-energy-use (129th), a proxy for energy efficiency; the size of the domestic market (129th); the value of inward direct investment made by non-resident investors (127th); and graduates in science and engineering (85th). As noted in a recent article in Iceland Review magazine, Iceland may have ‚Äúhopped on the startup train a bit later than other countries, but its startup environment has taken huge strides in recent years.‚Äù In 2019, the Icelandic government penned its first-ever comprehensive innovation policy, and at the end of 2020, the newly-elected government established a Ministry of Higher Education, Science, and Innovation, suggesting that policymakers are ‚Äúnot overlooking what startups have to offer the nation.‚Äù

headline: Single-Lane Bridge Replaced with Double-Lane Bridge Near Kirkjub√¶jarklaustur
body: Sigur√∞ur Ingi J√≥hannsson, Minister of Infrastructure, took part in the official opening of the new bridge over J√∂kuls√° on the south coast of Iceland on Friday, October 21. With the appearance of the new bridge, there will no longer be any one-way bridges between Reykjav√≠k and Kirkjub√¶jarklaustur, a town on the south coast of Iceland. The improvement is a major one for the region, meaning that the drive east along the south coast will be all the more navigable. Also present at the opening ceremony were Anton K√°ri Halld√≥rsson, mayor of Rang√°r√æing eystra, and Einar Freyr El√≠narsn, mayor of M√Ωrdalshreppur municipality. After the ceremony, minister Sigur√∞ur was the first to drive over the new bridge, inaugurating this latest addition to Iceland‚Äôs road system. In his address at the ceremony, minister Sigur√∞ur outlined his ministry‚Äôs plans to get rid of single-lane bridges throughout the nation: ‚ÄúToday we move one step closer to that goal.¬†Four years ago, 37 bridges on the Ring Road were single-lane, now there are 32, and there will be 31 when the new bridge opens today.¬†And there is no let up in construction.¬†I am hopeful that we will be able to reduce the number of them to 29 right before the end of the year, with new bridges openings on both Hverfisflj√≥t and N√∫psv√∂tn later in the year. There are also three single-lane bridges that will be diverted around the Ring Road when traffic is allowed over the new bridge over the Hornafj√∂r√∞ur River.‚Äù According to information from the Road Administration, the new bridge is some 163 m [535 ft] long, with a total width of 10 m [33 ft]. The bridge it replaces was built in 1967, part of the construction of Iceland‚Äôs Ring Road.

headline: No Gender Pay Gap in √Årborg
body: For the first time in the municipality‚Äôs history, √Årborg in South Iceland has reported no wage gap for the municipality‚Äôs thousand-some employees. Fj√≥la Kristinsd√≥ttir, mayor of √Årborg, stated to V√≠sir that she was ‚Äúextremely proud of this achievement.‚Äù She noted that it was particularly impressive given the large size of the municipality and their many employees, though she also stated ‚Äúthis is naturally what we have to do according to the law.‚Äù On how the municipality achieved this milestone in social justice, Fj√≥la stated that ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not trying to own this accomplishment. It‚Äôs just our great staff who have been working hard on this.‚Äù There are around 1,000 employees in √Årborg municipality, with women now considerably more represented than men. Now, however, the basic wage for all is the same, something that was not always the case. The news is significant in its timing as well, coming near the anniversary of Women‚Äôs Day Off. On October 24, 1975, women in Iceland staged a historic strike, now known as Women‚Äôs Day Off. With nearly 90% of Iceland‚Äôs women participating in the strike, they walked out of both jobs and domestic labour for the day. The following year, legislation ensuring equal pay was passed. ¬†

headline: The Road to Borgarfj√∂r√∞ur Eystri Now Paved
body: Residents of Borgarfj√∂r√∞ur Eystri, a village in East Iceland, can now drive on paved roads all the way to Egilssta√∞ir. The last section of paved road was completed earlier this month, a 15 km [9.3 mi] stretch near the town of Ei√∞ar was finally paved. H√©ra√∞sverk, the contractor responsible for finishing the road project, reports that it was difficult going. The final section required significant blasting to clear the way. Now, however, a straight and wide road runs where there was previously a winding, gravel road with potholes. The region has seen significant improvements in infrastructure in the last years, with a new road recently finished near Njar√∞v√≠k. Residents also protested in 2018 by paving sections of road themselves to highlight inaction on behalf of the municipality. ¬† With the recent improvements, all towns in the Flj√≥tsdalsh√©ra√∞ municipality are now connected via paved roads, a major milestone for this remote region of Iceland. Ey√æ√≥r Stef√°nsson, a resident of Borgarfj√∂r√∞ur Eystri and representative in M√∫la√æing‚Äôs local council, is quoted as saying: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs amazing what‚Äôs happened in such a short time. We set off to fight to get sections of landslide-prone roads paved, but then this all started to happen incredibly fast.¬† We had hoped to improved the road from Ei√∞ar but it turned out much better than we reckoned. They‚Äôve taken away the blind rises, so now it‚Äôs a properly straight and wide road, practically a motorway.‚Äù

headline: Twice as Many Cockroach Calls This Year
body: While a pervasive and persistent pest in most places, cockroaches are a rarely seen phenomenon in Iceland, but their numbers seem to be on the rise, if recent exterminator callouts are any indication. R√öV reports that exterminators are reporting twice as many callouts to remove roaches this year than last. Cockroaches can‚Äôt survive long outdoors in Iceland, but they manage just fine inside. Exterminator Steinar Sm√°ri Gu√∞bergsson has been responding to roach calls all over the country of late, from Akureyri to Vesturb√¶r, on the west side of Reykjav√≠k. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôve been quite a few calls due to cockroaches in the last six months,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd say they‚Äôve increased considerably.‚Äù Steinar Sm√°ri reminds Icelanders unfamiliar with the scuttling scourge that roaches thrive in warm environments where there‚Äôs plenty of food‚Äîso people should avoid leaving dirty dishes in the sink or leftover food on counters. Indeed, cockroaches are the only insects Steinar Sm√°ri can think of that enjoy filth, and he notes that this is a good encouragement to keep one‚Äôs house clean. (He himself seems relatively unbothered by roaches, but actually became an exterminator because he was afraid of spiders when he used to live in the countryside.) Asked if he thinks cockroaches are here to stay in Iceland, Steinar Sm√°ri said, ‚Äúthey‚Äôve got a foot in door, I‚Äôd say.‚Äù

headline: Domestic-Terror Suspects Engaged in a ‚ÄúFailed Attempt at Humour,‚Äù Attorney Says
body: The defence attorney for one of the two men held in custody suspected of planning a domestic-terror attack has dismissed private messages between the suspects as a ‚Äúfailed attempt at humour.‚Äù He does not believe that either of the men will be charged with planning a terrorist attack, V√≠sir reports. On Tuesday, the Court of Appeal confirmed the further four-week custody of two men arrested last month suspected of planning a domestic-terrorism attack. According to the police, the suspects had hoarded numerous weapons ‚Äì including dozens of semi-automatic guns and 3D-printed components ‚Äì alongside a considerable amount of ammunition. The men had also discussed carrying out attacks against political figures, among them Minister Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r √û√≥r√∞arson and Chairman of Efling, S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir. ‚ÄúHaving spoken with my client, it appears that the police got ahead of itself in their press conferences and the like. It appears as if this is a matter of a firearms violation,‚Äù Sveinn Andri Sveinsson, the new defence attorney for one of the suspects, told V√≠sir. Sveinn Andri stated that his client admits to weapons offences but that the men were not planning a real domestic-terror attack, suggesting that that charge rests solely on the evidence of private messages: ‚ÄúIt was merely a failed attempt at humour by these two boys; the idea that they had been planning an act of terrorism on public chatrooms, that just doesn‚Äôt hold any water.‚Äù ‚ÄúMy client is a harmless wretch who wouldn‚Äôt hurt a fly. He‚Äôs as far from a terrorist as one can imagine. He has no interest in politics, believes that the Pirates are actual buccaneers and not a political party, and so on, and so forth.‚Äù When asked if he believed that the court‚Äôs primary task would be to decide whether or not private messages between the two men were ‚Äúfailed attempts at humour,‚Äù Sveinn replied that he was altogether unsure whether the charge of planning a terrorist attack would be brought against the two suspects. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not sure that it‚Äôll go as far as that; my feeling is that, in the end, they‚Äôll be charged for weapons offences to which they will then admit.‚Äù

headline: Parents, Community Appalled by Brutal Bullying Case
body: S√¶d√≠s Hr√∂nn Sam√∫elsd√≥ttir and her twelve-year-old daughter √çsabella Von S√¶d√≠sard√≥ttir opened up to local media yesterday about the brutal campaign of bullying that the latter has suffered at the hands of classmates. Abusers encouraged √çsabella to ‚Äútry again,‚Äù following a failed suicide attempt. Parents must shoulder greater responsibility, the Chair of Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur‚Äôs City Council has stated. As reported by R√öV yesterday, √çsabella Von is an eighth-grader at the Hraunvallask√≥li primary school in Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur. Having long been bullied by her classmates, she recently attempted suicide by overdosing on her mother‚Äôs prescription drugs. √çsabella notified her mother, who drove her to the Children‚Äôs Hospital for treatment. She returned home yesterday. ‚ÄúI felt like everyone would be happy if I went through with it. That‚Äôs what everyone has told me,‚Äù √çsabella told R√öV. S√¶d√≠s Hr√∂nn Sam√∫elsd√≥ttir, √çsabella‚Äôs mother, maintains that she can name at least 35 children who have sent her daughter hateful messages; although the ones sent anonymously are worse. √çsabella has also been attacked physically twice, once at the Sm√°ralind shopping mall, which was recorded and shared on social media. After the beating, she received the following message: ‚ÄúShe probably began fucking bawling. If there hadn‚Äôt been people around, she probably would have been fucking dead (‚Ä¶) You should have been fucking dead, √çsabella.‚Äù S√¶d√≠s says that psychologists with the National Agency for Children and Family have tried to offer assistance; that they‚Äôve applied for so-called MST intervention, which is a cross-institutional treatment geared towards aiding parents in helping their children cope. ‚ÄúThe school has also tried to help, but she just doesn‚Äôt show up,‚Äù S√¶d√≠s remarked. After news of the bullying broke, the Parents‚Äô Association of Hraunvallask√≥li released a public statement on Facebook. The association was ‚Äúshocked by revelations‚Äù in the media yesterday and has called a meeting with school administrators. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important to tackle such matters with determination and to activate protocols. Also, we, as parents, administrators, and school employees must work together toward constructive solutions that put our children‚Äôs welfare first. The Parents‚Äô Association will try its utmost, circumstances allowing.‚Äù Mayor of Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur R√≥sa Gu√∞bjartsd√≥ttir also weighed in on the matter on Facebook yesterday, encouraging a show of empathy, responsibility, and love. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been heartrending, hearing of the violence that our young girl in Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur has suffered. All of the world‚Äôs specialists [‚Ä¶] will never replace us as custodians and parents. Let us talk to our children, monitor their activities more closely, explain to them the seriousness of their actions and the consequences of treating other people poorly. The simple message: ‚Äòdo unto others as you would have them do unto you.‚Äô It is so important and true.‚Äù Speaking to R√öV yesterday, Valdimar V√≠√∞isson, Chair of Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur‚Äôs City Council, stated that bullying was not endemic to Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur. ‚ÄúBullying in primary school is, unfortunately, our current reality. We must find ways to respond.‚Äù Valdimar says that social media is playing an increasingly larger role. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a reality with which we‚Äôve been unable to adequately deal,‚Äù Valdimar observed, adding that some of the options available are helpful, although uprooting bullying always necessitates the involvement of parents. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs often the case that schools are left screaming into the void because there isn‚Äôt a lot of participation. But parents must take part, as well as society at large.‚Äù If you‚Äôre experiencing suicidal thoughts, reach out to Red Cross Iceland (Phone No. 1717) or the P√≠eta Association (Phone No. 552-2218)

headline: ISK 20 Million to Support E-Sports
body:
Reykjav√≠k City Council approved a grant proposal yesterday to fund sports clubs with e-sports teams. The funding will total some ISK 20 million.
 Bj√∂rn G√≠slason, city councilperson, has stated his support of the proposal to V√≠sir, saying that there are high costs to starting e-sports leagues, and that the government‚Äôs assistance is important. ‚ÄúIt is my dream that electronic sports are implemented in all sports clubs in Reykjav√≠k, especially with the goal of preventing social isolation and increasing the social skills of children and teenagers,‚Äù Bj√∂rn said.
 Perhaps not surprisingly, the proposal has been critiqued by representatives from the Independence Party, with some suggesting that e-sports are not an appropriate or important field for government support. Notably, Iceland already has a relatively established e-sports gaming scene. Local sports clubs have been home to e-sports teams since 2018. Iceland has also hosted several important e-sports tournaments, having an advantage especially during the COVID-19 pandemic, with relatively relaxed restrictions on gatherings. Because e-sports are generally at home in high-tech nations, such as South Korea, Japan, China, and also other Nordics such as Denmark and Sweden, the Icelandic e-sports community has tried to make its mark among these peers. Supporters of the grant for funding also highlight the role that e-sports play in young peoples‚Äô lives. Like traditional sports, they claim, they encourage young people to work together with their peers and form social bonds. Proponents have pointed to the role of e-sports in self discipline, emotional management, responsibility, and other important aspects of childhood development.

headline: Str√¶t√≥ Discontinues Night-Time Service During Weekends
body: Str√¶t√≥ has announced that it will discontinue its night-time bus service in Reykjav√≠k during the weekends, citing low passenger demand during a special trial period. Str√¶t√≥ is facing financial troubles following the pandemic, and recently, the capital area municipalities had to divert extra fund to keep the regional partnership company from insolvency. In early July, Str√¶t√≥ (the public bus service in Iceland) announced that the Reykjav√≠k night bus, N√¶turstr√¶t√≥, would return to service on July 9 following a two-year hiatus in response to low demand during the pandemic. During this hiatus, many capital-area residents had called for its return, arguing that it provided an affordable and safe alternative to taxis. During a trial run between July and October of this year, however ‚Äì when the night bus departed downtown Reykjav√≠k every hour and stopped at the capital area‚Äôs seven suburban neighbourhoods ‚Äì demand once again proved wanting. As noted in a press release from Str√¶t√≥, an average of 15 passengers travelled aboard the night bus during each trip, which amounts to approximately 300 passengers over a weekend. ‚ÄúIn light of this, and given the finances, Str√¶t√≥‚Äôs board has agreed that continuing night-time service during the weekends, now that the trial period has concluded, cannot be justified. The service will, therefore, be discontinued.‚Äù As noted by V√≠sir, transportation options from downtown Reykjav√≠k after the night clubs have closed during the weekend are limited; operating electric scooters while intoxicated is illegal and securing transportation via taxis often proves difficult. ¬†

headline: Would-Be Terrorists Discussed Killing Minister Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r
body: The two men being held in police custody accused of planning a domestic terrorism attack in Iceland had reportedly discussed killing Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r √û√≥r√∞arson ‚Äì Minister of the Environment, Energy, and Climate. Four Icelandic men were arrested on September 21 suspected of ‚Äúterrorist plots‚Äù against state institutions and civilians. Two of the suspects were immediately released; the other two have remained in custody. Last Friday, the District Court of Reykjav√≠k approved the District Attorney‚Äôs request to extend their custody by four weeks. According to the police, the suspects had hoarded numerous weapons ‚Äì including dozens of semi-automatic guns and 3D-printed components ‚Äì alongside a considerable amount of ammunition. The men, both of whom are in their twenties, had reportedly discussed carrying out an attack during the police‚Äôs annual celebration (which was held on October 1). Yesterday, R√öV reported that the suspects had also discussed killing Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r √û√≥r√∞arson, Minister of the Environment, Energy, and Climate. The Chief of Police reportedly notified the Minister of the suspects‚Äô intentions prior to calling the Minister in for questioning. As reported on October 10, the suspects had also discussed targeting Efling chairperson S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir and Gunnar Sm√°ri Egilsson, chairperson of the Socialist Party. The names of current and former Pirate Party politicians were also mentioned as possible targets. The police have asked a psychiatrist to assess the earnestness of the remarks made by the men during private messages, with the suspects‚Äô lawyers contending that the threats were empty. Chief Police Inspector Karl Steinar Valsson has stated that this is the ‚Äúfirst investigation of its kind‚Äù to be launched in Iceland.

headline: Directorate of Education to be Abolished
body: Extensive changes to Iceland‚Äôs education system were announced today in a press release by Minister of Education and Childrens‚Äô Affairs √Åsmundur Einar Da√∞ason. In order to strengthen schools across the nation, a new general framework on education is to be established, replacing the Directorate of Education. The new framework is part of the government‚Äôs outline for an education policy to the year 2030, which seeks to re-organise several offices in order to better assure quality and access to education for children from kindergarten to secondary school. In the press release, √Åsmundur stated: ‚ÄúThere is no comprehensive legislation on school services for nursery, primary and secondary schools and no central organization with a defined role to implement and coordinate these services.¬†Access to services varies, both between and within school levels and municipalities, which leads to inequality. We need to coordinate the systems to ensure a comprehensive, effective, and quality service such as when students move between schools or move between school levels. We also need greater consultation with school staff and support for school work, allowing for faster and more efficient resources for children and young people. Everything we do should be aimed at their success.‚Äù A new organisation will take over the responsibilities of the Directorate of Education. During the transition period, the responsibilities of the Directorate will be placed directly under the Ministry of Education and Childrens‚Äô Affairs. √û√≥rd√≠s J√≥na Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir is the recently-appointed director of the Directorate of Education and will continue in her leadership role at the new organisation, which is yet to be named.

headline: VR to Remain in AS√ç
body: Ragnar √û√≥r Ing√≥lfsson, chairperson of VR, has stated that for the time being, VR‚Äôs position within AS√ç will remain unchanged. VR is Iceland‚Äôs largest trade union, representing some 40,000 workers. There have however been suggestions recently that VR will leave AS√ç, or the Federation of Labour. AS√ç, founded in 1916, is the largest federation of trade unions in Iceland and has historically played an important role in labour organisation in Iceland. However, the most recent AS√ç conference over contract negotiations has proved a turbulent one, with many major trade unions suggesting that they go their separate ways in the future. The upheavals come in the wake of Dr√≠fa Sn√¶dal‚Äôs resignation earlier this year from her leadership position in AS√ç. Citing political hostility, she said that it was no longer possible to perform her duties in her resignation letter. Since her resignation, AS√ç leadership has been in turmoil, with some of Iceland‚Äôs largest trade unions considering leaving during AS√ç‚Äôs 45th conference. Ragnar √û√≥r also withdrew his candidacy for AS√ç leadership at the conference, citing the possibility of a break with the federation. Now, at least for the time being, it seems that VR will remain with AS√ç. The announcement came today before a formal meeting with SA, Iceland‚Äôs leading employers‚Äô union. In a statement from Ragnar √û√≥r, he said that all of the union‚Äôs efforts will now be directed towards the wage negotiations with SA. Regarding the future, however, Ragnar √û√≥r emphasised that nothing can be ruled out.

headline: Court Rules City Not Liable for Rabbit Collision
body: The Reykjav√≠k District Court has ruled that the City of Reykjav√≠k does not have to compensate a local cyclist who was injured when running over a rabbit on a municipally maintained cycling path, R√öV reports. The accident occurred in 2016, after a rabbit ran into the path of the man‚Äôs bicycle. He ran over the animal, fell off his bike, and careened into a tree. He then had to be hospitalized for ten days to recover from the injuries he sustained. See Also: Rabbit Rescue Hops to Rehome Sixty Wild Bunnies In his suit, the man claimed that the conditions of the cycling path were indefensible, and that the lighting at the scene of the accident was particularly bad. He also maintained that the city had been aware of an ongoing wild rabbit epidemic, as well as an increase in cycling accidents involving the wayward hoppers, but had failed to take any action about this until subsequent media coverage of the issue. In its judgement on the case, the District Court agreed that the city would have been aware of the disturbances that rabbits could cause for cyclists on its paths. However, rabbits are wild mammals and therefore, protected by Icelandic law. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs clear that rabbits, like other animals including birds, cats, and rats, can find their way onto the city‚Äôs walking and cycling paths,‚Äù remarked the court, adding that it would be no easy thing for municipal authorities to prevent such encounters. The court also found that better lighting and/or mirrors on the path would have been unlikely to prevent the accident and the city will not be obligated to pay damages to the cyclist.

headline: Custody of Domestic Terror Suspects Extended Four Weeks
body: The two individuals suspected of planning a domestic terror attack will be held in custody for another four weeks. R√öV reports that the District Court of Reykjav√≠k approved the District Attorney‚Äôs request for extended custody on Friday. The suspects‚Äô lawyers have appealed the decision to the National Court. The suspects have been held in isolation for three weeks, a decision that has been criticized by their lawyers. In his petition for extended custody, however, DA √ìlafur √û√≥r Hauksson did not request further isolation. See Also: Judge Grants Extended Custody Over Domestic Terror Suspects Four Icelandic men were arrested on September 21 suspected of ‚Äúterrorist plots‚Äù against state institutions and civilians. Two of the suspects were immediately released; the other two have remained in custody. According to the police, the suspects had hoarded numerous weapons ‚Äì including dozens of semi-automatic guns and 3D-printed components ‚Äì alongside a considerable amount of ammunition. The men, all of whom are in their twenties, had reportedly discussed carrying out an attack during the police‚Äôs annual celebration (which was held on October 1). Chief Police Inspector Karl Steinar Valsson told reporters that this was the ‚Äúfirst investigation of its kind to be launched in Iceland.

headline: No Daytime Shelter for Homeless Men, Despite Protests
body: Emergency shelters for homeless men will remain closed during the day, according to the Director of Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs Welfare Council. The city will continue to focus on the buildup of more permanent housing resources for the homeless. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre literally on the streets, no matter the weather,‚Äù one homeless man told V√≠sir. Yesterday, V√≠sir.is reported on the numerous homeless women who seek refuge at the Konukot emergency shelter. The shelter is overcrowded most nights, too small to meet demand. In an interview with V√≠sir, Hei√∞a Bj√∂rg Hilmisd√≥ttir, Director of Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs Welfare Council, stated that the Council was currently completing an appraisal of Konukot to establish whether more space was required. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre also considering providing more halfway homes, so that individuals would first be allotted a room where they‚Äôre offered necessary support, prior to those individuals moving into dedicated apartments.‚Äù Despite the congestion at Konukot, homeless women can seek shelter at Icelandic Church Aid during the day, while homeless men can only seek shelter at Samhj√°lp between 10 AM and 2 PM. With winter fast approaching, a group of homeless men organised a sit-down strike at an emergency shelter in the Grandi neighbourhood of Reykjav√≠k on Wednesday to protest. V√≠sir spoke to a few protesters, who voiced their indignation at being turned out of emergency shelters during the day, in all kinds of weather and physical states. Among the protesters was Dav√≠√∞ √û√≥r J√≥nsson, one of the founders of Vi√∞m√≥t ‚Äì an organised interest group on the rights of drug users. Dav√≠√∞ was diagnosed with pneumonia last week but has had no choice but to roam the streets in the cold. ‚ÄúOur only refuge during the day is Samhj√°lp, which is open between 10 AM and 2 PM. After that, we‚Äôre literally on the streets, no matter the weather.‚Äù Dav√≠√∞ √û√≥r wants homeless men to be offered comparable shelter as Icelandic Church Aid offers women. ‚ÄúThere are plenty of talented people who are homeless; something good could be made of their talents if they had appropriate shelter.‚Äù Despite such concerns being raised, Hei√∞a Bj√∂rg Hilmisd√≥ttir told V√≠sir that the emergency shelters will remain closed during the day: ‚ÄúThere are always places of refuge for everyone, but the emergency shelters will not be open. The city libraries are always open. People can sit down, have some coffee, and relax,‚Äù Hei√∞a told V√≠sir, explaining that the city conceives of emergency shelters as temporary resources. ‚ÄúThe ideology behind emergency shelters is that you can stay there overnight if you don‚Äôt have a place to stay. But it isn‚Äôt housing. You don‚Äôt live there. This is a temporary option, but we don‚Äôt want people to settle down. We haven‚Äôt emphasised an increased number of emergency shelters, having chosen to focus on providing more permanent housing.‚Äù According to Hei√∞a, the City of Reykjav√≠k has allocated 130 apartments to homeless individuals since the beginning of last year. ‚ÄúWhere you can settle down and make a home for yourself, which is not something you can do at an emergency shelter.‚Äù According to V√≠sir, 61 individuals are on a waiting list for housing in Reykjav√≠k. A third of those who seek out emergency shelters are legal residents of other municipalities, which means that they are not eligible to apply for housing in Reykjav√≠k. As noted by Iceland Review, the City of Reykjav√≠k released a report in 2021 that ‚Äúfound 301 people were experiencing homelessness in the city. This is a decrease of 14% since 2017. According to data from the report, 71% of the individuals were men, 29% were women, and most were between 21 and 49 years of age.‚Äù

headline: Icelandic to Take Precedence on Keflav√≠k Airport Signage
body: The board of directors at Isavia, the national airport and air navigation service provider of Iceland, has decided to renew the signage at Keflav√≠k Airport so as to emphasise the Icelandic language; Isavia will foreground Icelandic on all instructional and informational signs at the airport. The Icelandic Language Council was established in 1964 and operates according to Article 6 of Law No. 61/2011 regarding the status of the Icelandic language and Icelandic sign language: ‚ÄúThe role of the Icelandic Language Council shall be to provide public authorities with academically-informed advice on matters concerning the Icelandic language, and to make proposals to the Minister regarding language policy.‚Äù The law also stipulates that the Council may ‚Äútake the initiative to draw attention to both positive and negative aspects of the ways in which the Icelandic language is used in the public sphere.‚Äù With a view to this provision of the law, the Icelandic Language Council has persistently drawn attention to the conspicuously anglicised signage at the Keflav√≠k National Airport: ‚ÄúEnglish is the primary language on almost all of the signs at the airport,‚Äù a journalist at R√öV writes, ‚Äúwith information in Icelandic playing a secondary role or none at all.‚Äù Eir√≠kur R√∂gnvaldsson, Professor Emeritus at the University of Iceland, brought attention to the issue again after Icelandair announced that it would resume the custom of addressing passengers in Icelandic first, prior to reverting to other languages. Isavia responded with reference to security concerns, but critics pushed back, noting that local languages were foregrounded in many international airports without such a thing being a cause of concern; Gaelic is foregrounded at Irish airports ahead of English. An article on Mbl.is notes that Lilja Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir, Minister of Culture and Business Affairs, emphasised these concerns to the Board of Directors of Isavia, the national airport and air navigation service provider of Iceland. According to Mbl.is, Lilja had ‚Äúcommented on the marginalisation of the Icelandic language at the airport at the time before reemphasising her concerns following Icelandair‚Äôs decision.‚Äù Lilja reached out to former minister Kristj√°n √û√≥r J√∫l√≠usson, the newly-elected Chairman of the Board for Isavia, who then raised the issue at a board meeting (see below entry: ‚ÄúConcerns have been raised, and comments made, in public, by, among other parties, the board of the Icelandic Language Council in 2016 and 2017, regarding the use of language on informational and instructional signs at the Keflav√≠k Airport. Isavia‚Äôs board discussed these issues in 2018. Over the recent days, criticism has resurfaced. In light of this criticism, Isavia‚Äôs board hsa agreed upon the following: ‚ÄòExtensive renovations are currently underway at Keflav√≠k Airport. Alongside the current alterations, Isavia‚Äôs board of directors has decided to devise a plan to renew the airport‚Äôs signage, in phases, in the near future. During this renewal, the principle of ensuring the foregrounding of the Icelandic language on instructional and informational signs will be followed.‚Äô‚Äù

headline: Foreign Nationals to Receive Icelandic Citizenship after Controversial Withholding of Applications
body: R√öV reports that six foreign citizens are to be naturalised as Icelandic citizens following a delay that was caused by the Directorate of Immigration withholding their applications. The six new Icelanders are respectively from Mongolia, Russia, South Africa, Kosovo, and Iran. In addition to the normal process of receiving citizenship through residence and application, parliament can also grant citizenship through decree in Iceland. These special applications are generally for individuals in extenuating circumstances, though some critics such as Bjarni Benediktsson have stated that these special applications constitute too large a proportion of Icelandic naturalisations. These citizenship applications through decree are still processed by the Directorate of Immigration, however, and there was controversy when earlier in the year, the Directorate refused to hand over the relevant application to parliament. Notably, this deliberate withholding was illegal, and caused outcry among politicians who insisted that legal process be followed. Now, the relevant application have finally been submitted and the path has been cleared to Icelandic citizenship for the six. Parliament generally naturalises Icelandic citizens twice a year: at the end of the year and before summer break. ¬† ¬†

headline: Norwegian Crown Prince Visits Iceland
body:
Norwegian Crown Prince Haakon is visiting Iceland for the Nordic Round Table conference. On the docket are Nordic responses to climate change and the war in Ukraine. Trying his hand at Icelandic, he briefly greet the assembly, but continued his talk in English. ‚ÄúWe meet here in Reykjav√≠k during difficult times. In these uncertain times, Norway emphasizes international law and continuing strong international cooperation. It has been going well for nearly thirty years and we must ensure that the Nordic Round Table remains the main forum for cooperation in the Nordics.¬†Norwegians are looking forward to taking over the presidency next year,‚Äù he stated at a breakfast meeting this morning.
 In addition to the conference, Prince Haakon also accompanied President Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson on a hike to the eruption site at Fagradalsfjall. They were accompanied by both a ranger and geologist, who informed them about the geology of the Reykjanes region. After the hike, the Crown Prince was invited to dinner at Bessasta√∞ir, the presidential residence in Iceland.

headline: Never Been More Difficult to Hire Staff: September Unemployment at 2.8%
body: Unemployment rates sat at 2.8% in September, creating tension in the labour market. Although this may sound like a good development, according to the Federation of Trade and Services, hiring new staff has never been more difficult for Icelandic employers. In a statement to R√öV, Landsbankinn economist Una J√≥nsd√≥ttir said that instead of employees competing for jobs, it is now the case that employers are competing for staff. In total, around 5,400 were unemployed in September, largely representing the retail, service, transportation, and restaurant industries. Of these 5,400, 44% are reported to be foreign residents in Iceland. In comparison with the total unemployment rate for Iceland of 2.8%, the unemployment rate for foreigners is double, at 5.6%. Iceland‚Äôs Su√∞urnes region is notable as having an especially high unemployment rate of 4.8%, with the capital region sitting around 3.2%. Icelandic unemployment is lowest in the Northwest, which has only 0.7%. Economists have suggested that the increased demand for labour created by the low unemployment could affect the upcoming wage negotiations.

headline: Two Suspects Released, Murder Not the Case in Laugardalur
body: The two men arrested yesterday for their suspected involvement in a murder in Reykjav√≠k have now been released, Mbl.is reports. The police no longer believe that the victim‚Äôs death was the result of a punishable offence. After a woman was found dead in her car Saturday morning (in the 105 district of Reykjav√≠k, near Laugardalur), two men in their forties were arrested suspected of homicide. The men, both of whom were in their forties, were said to have known the victim. The police withheld details during the initial stages of the investigation, prior to releasing a public statement yesterday evening: ‚ÄúThe forensic pathologist has concluded that the woman‚Äôs injuries did not lead to her death; there is no longer any reason to believe that the woman‚Äôs death was the result of a punishable offence.‚Äù The police clarified that during the initial stages of the investigation, the forensic pathologist and the police were confronted with many ‚Äúquestionable aspects‚Äù that required further examination. For this reason, two men connected to the woman were arrested, and the police intended to keep them in custody until October 13. But they have now been released. The investigation is still ongoing, with the police currently investigating whether someone was responsible for the woman‚Äôs injuries. Updated at 1.37 PM

headline: Domestic Terrorists Targeted S√≥lveig J√≥nsd√≥ttir and Gunnar Egilsson
body: The men being held in police custody for planning a domestic terrorism attack in Iceland are reported to have targeted Efling chairperson S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir and Gunnar Sm√°ri Egilsson, chairperson of the Socialist Party. This was first reported in Samst√∂√∞in, a media platform for leftwing political debate. According to Samst√∂√∞din, individuals named by the suspects as potential targets were brought in by the district prosecutor to testify. S√≥lveig was reportedly shown an exchange in which the suspects vowed to kill her, identifying her as a troublemaker who wanted to start a revolution. Gunnar was also shown a conversation in which one of the suspects reported to have seen Gunnar in a restaurant. The suspect speculated about what would happen if he had killed Gunnar on the spot. S√≥lveig stated to Samst√∂√∞in the following: ‚Äú[o]f course, it is frightening to learn that these men have been collecting weapons and planning to execute me for my political views and work. But I‚Äôve just become so numb from the relentless attacks and accusations over the past few years that I took it like any other attack.‚Äù In response to the planned attacks, Gunnar has highlighted the dangers of rightwing nationalism and hate speech. Gunnar stated to Samst√∂√∞in that ‚Äú[t]he Socialist Party is fighting for the development of social housing, to repeal tax cuts for the rich, for the general public to have power over their resources and other national issues that enjoy the support of a large majority of the public. The right responds to this by associating Socialists with Stalin‚Äôs crimes, violence, subversion and plots to deprive people of their freedom.‚Äù Gunnar also called attention to the unfair ways in which S√≥lveig is portrayed in media, with terms such as ‚Äúpurges‚Äù regarding her recent reorganization of the Efling union office associating her with Soviet dictatorship.

headline: Two Men Held in Custody for Murder in Reykjav√≠k
body: Two men are being held in police custody for their suspected involvement in a murder in Reykjav√≠k. According to the initial police report and Morgunbla√∞i√∞, a woman was found dead in her car Saturday morning in the 105 district of Reykjav√≠k, near Laugardalur. It is not clear how long the woman had been dead in her car until the case was reported, but this question is now under investigation by Reykjav√≠k police. The two men held in custody are in their forties and are said to have known the victim. Because the investigation is still in its initial stage, the police have not provided more details, given the sensitive nature of personal information in such cases. The murder is notable as the fourth murder so far this year in Iceland. Iceland, often cited as one of the safest nations in the world, generally has a low murder rate. This year appears to some as an outlier, with already four murders before year‚Äôs end. However, as Icelandic criminologist Dr. Margr√©t Valdimarsd√≥ttir has noted, such statistics can be somewhat misleading in the case of Iceland. The mean murder incidence between 2001 and 2020 in Iceland sat around two a year. With such small-scale numbers, statistical outliers can also be given too much weight, with an increase of two to four murders representing a 100% increase in murders. Icelandic society has also grown rapidly in recent years, meaning an increase in murders is also inevitable. More details will be reported on the case as it develops. ¬† ¬† ¬†

headline: Multicultural Festival Celebrated as Part of ‚ÄòFriendship Week‚Äô in Vopnafj√∂r√∞ur
body: The East Iceland village of Vopnafj√∂r√∞ur will celebrate its second annual Multicultural Festival on Saturday, with international food, dance exhibitions, games, international cartoons for children, and more. Austurfr√©tt reports that just under 10% of the fishing village‚Äôs population is of foreign extraction, with full-time residents hailing from 20 different countries around the world. As of September, 670 people called Vopnafj√∂r√∞ur home. Sixty of these residents are originally from another country. Poles make up the largest subset of foreign residents, followed by Bulgarians. The village is also home to people from Sweden and Pakistan, among other nations. ‚ÄúPeople have always come here from abroad,‚Äù says √û√≥rhildur Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir, who oversees multicultural and diversity initiatives for the larger municipality. √û√≥rhildur explained that the village has a history of attracting foreign workers, but it‚Äôs only recently that the makeup of the fulltime population has been so diverse. ‚ÄúThere are people with Faroese roots, and then Danish women came to work here. I think one of them is still left. Otherwise, there weren‚Äôt many [other nationalities] here even six years ago. For a long time, it was just one woman from Poland. But that‚Äôs changed completely.‚Äù Vopnafj√∂r√∞ur held its first Multicultural Festival in 2020, at which time, there were people from 22 countries living in the village. The following year, a Children‚Äôs Cultural Festival was held instead, but still with a multicultural focus. During that festival, kids were taught how to count to five in 13 languages and flags were raised for each of the nationalities living there. This year, the Multicultural Festival is just one part of a week-long ‚ÄòFriendship Week,‚Äô sponsored by a local youth club and programmed entirely by teenagers. Friendship Week runs from Friday, October 7 to Sunday, October 16 and will include a variety of events, including a parade, a potluck-style cake buffet, a movie night, a ‚Äògoodwill marathon,‚Äô in which residents are encouraged to do good deeds for one another (such as raking leaves, folding laundry, dog walking, etc), an intergenerational game night, and more.
