Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs four-party governing coalition ‚Äì consisting of the Social-Democratic Alliance, Reform Party, Pirate Party, and Left-Green Movement ‚Äì lost two of its 12 seats in the election, and therefore has lost its majority on the 23-seat Reykjav√≠k City Council. The Social-Democratic Alliance and Reform Party both lost seats, the Left-Green Party held its single seat, while the Pirate Party increased its number of seats from two to three. As elsewhere in the country, the Progressive Party saw great success in Reykjav√≠k, going from zero seats on the City Council to four. The Socialist Party also saw an increase in voters, doubling their seats from one to two. While it received the largest proportion of the vote, or nearly 25%, the Independence Party lost one seat, going from seven to six councillors following the election. Voter turnout decreased in all of the country‚Äôs largest municipalities except Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur, where it increased by 2.4%. The lowest voter turnout was in Reykjanesb√¶r, where less than half of registered voters turned up to the polls. Voter turnout was 63% across the country, a drop from 68% in the last municipal elections. In Reykjav√≠k, voter turnout was 61.1%, or 5.9% lower than in 2018. It bears noting, however, that amendments to election legislation that took effect in January increased the number of registered voters in the city by around 10,000. A total of 61,359 people voted in the city in this year‚Äôs election, while in 2018 that number was 60,417. In light of the weekend results, parties across the country are beginning coalition talks. In Reykjav√≠k, Mayor Dagur B. Eggertsson has announced that his Social-Democratic Alliance has begun negotiations with the Pirate Party and the Reform Party on forming a governing coalition. Progressive Party councillor Einar √ûorsteinsson said he was open to collaborating with all parties with seats on the council. Independence Party councillor Hildur Bj√∂rnsd√≥ttir stated she had had several informal talks with other councillors, while Left-Green Movement councillor Lif Magneud√≥ttir has stated the party will not participate in majority coalition talks this term.

headline: Seaman‚Äôs Association: Government‚Äôs Stalled Negotiations with Coast Guard Pilots ‚ÄúUnacceptable and Disgraceful‚Äù
body: The Icelandic Seaman‚Äôs Association has issued a strongly worded statement in support of Iceland‚Äôs Coast Guard pilots, calling the government‚Äôs delay in negotiations ‚Äúunacceptable and disgraceful,‚Äù Mbl.is reports. The Coast Guard pilots have been without a contract since December 31, 2019. ‚ÄòA hopeless position‚Äô As Iceland‚Äôs Coast Guard pilots have police powers, they are legally prohibited from going on strike, which puts them in ‚Äúa hopeless position‚Äù when it comes to contract bargaining, says Sonja Bjarnad√≥ttir Backman, a lawyer with the Icelandic Airline Pilots‚Äô Association (F√çA). Per a statement issued by F√çA in April, Coast Guard pilots‚Äô ‚Äúlabour agreements have historically been linked to CLAs of comparable professions, for the longest time through a statutory link, or until 2006.‚Äù That arrangement is now under ‚Äúvigorou[s] attack‚Äù by the Ministry of Finance, however, which F√çA says is pushing ‚Äúa clear demand for a new, original wage agreement without links to comparable professions. This will not only affect pilot benefits but will also greatly increase staff turnover among the Coast Guard‚Äôs pilots.‚Äù With ‚Äúhundreds of millions of ISK‚Äù spent on training each pilot, high turnover amongst the Coast Guard‚Äôs pilots is clearly costly to the state monetarily, but also has the associated cost of lost experience and knowledge among the highly trained professionals who oversee rescue operations at sea. ‚ÄúIncreased staff turnover is therefore quick to more than offset the disconnection of wages from comparable professions,‚Äù continues the F√çA statement. The F√çA also takes issue with the Ministry of Finance‚Äôs desire to abolish the pilot‚Äôs seniority list, which it says is ‚Äúone of the cornerstones of safety culture in aviation around the world.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis arrangement has proved successful, as such lists ensure transparency, professionalism, and that pilots can report incidents without fear of punishment. The Ministry has presented no objective arguments to support its position, and in fact the pilots‚Äô negotiation committee has perceived a lack of professional knowledge and understanding of the unique position of the aviation industry in the negotiations.‚Äù (Read the F√çA‚Äôs full ‚ÄúResolution from the Pilots of the Icelandic Coast Guard here, in English.) See Also: Coast Guard Helicopter Unmanned Due to Pilot Shortage ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs happened that there‚Äôs no helicopter available when needed,‚Äù continues to the statement issued by the Seaman‚Äôs Association. Indeed, due to staff illness, there was no helicopter available when a serious traffic accident occurred in South Iceland this week. Since it was not possible to man the helicopter crew, the injured person had to be transported by ambulance ‚Äì making the trip one and a half hours longer than it would have been by helicopter. According to √Åsgeir Erlendsson, communications officer of the Icelandic Coast Guard, for two thirds of the year, the Coast Guard has two crews on call, but for one third of the year, there is just a single crew on duty. In the past, illness or other staffing challenges have been solved by calling in staff who were off duty. That was, however, not possible on the day of the accident in question. This staffing shortage was denounced by the Minister of Justice, who wants to increase the number of helicopter pilots. But despite the Seaman‚Äôs Association‚Äôs later claims, this incident was said to be unrelated to the pilots‚Äô ongoing wage dispute. ‚ÄòAmbulances of the sea‚Äô The Seaman‚Äôs Association statement, which was cosigned by the Association of Ship Captains, the Association of Engineers and Metalworkers, and the Grindav√≠k Seaman and Engineer Association, also drew particular attention to the fact that with only one helicopter on duty, it is not possible to rescue distressed sailors who are more than 20 nautical miles from land. ‚ÄúIf ships are outside the 20 nautical mile-mark,‚Äù reads the statement, ‚Äúthey have to sail to meet a helicopter with their injured or ill. Minutes matter in these cases‚Äîlet alone hours.‚Äù The Seaman‚Äôs Association presses the government to ensure that there are always two helicopters, or ‚Äúambulances of the sea‚Äù available, and concluded by saying that having only one helicopter on duty could have grave consequences for Icelandic and foreign fishermen alike.

headline: Coast Guard Helicopter Unmanned Due to Pilot Shortage
body: For one third of the year, the Icelandic Coast Guard has only one helicopter crew on duty, R√öV reports. Yesterday morning the helicopter could not be manned to respond to a serious accident due to staff illness. Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson says the situation is unacceptable and wants to increase the number of helicopter pilots. A serious traffic accident occurred under the Eyjafj√∂ll mountain range in South Iceland just after 11:00 AM yesterday morning. One person was in the car and they were transported to the National University Hospital in Reykjav√≠k for treatment. Since it was not possible to man the helicopter crew, the injured person had to be transported by ambulance ‚Äì making the trip one and a half hours longer than it would have been by helicopter. √Åsgeir Erlendsson, communications officer of the Icelandic Coast Guard, says that for two thirds of the year, the Coast Guard has two crews on call, but for one third of the year, there is just a single crew on duty. In the past, illness or other staffing challenges have been solved by calling in staff who were off duty. That was, however, not possible yesterday. The situation that occurred yesterday morning is not acceptable, Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson told reporters. ‚ÄúSuch incidents should not occur and we will try to do everything we can to prevent this from happening again,‚Äù he stated. J√≥n pointed out that the government budget outlines an increase in funding to the Coast Guard so that the number of shifts can be increased from six to seven. The government updated the helicopter fleet last year and the number of crews was increased from five to six. ‚ÄúIt is no secret that with more crews it would be possible to increase the response capacity even further,‚Äù √Åsgeir stated. The Coast Guard‚Äôs pilots have been without a valid collective agreement for almost two and a half years. The pilots assert that complying with the Ministry of Finance‚Äôs requirements would impact aviation safety. The Ministry has denied those claims. The manning of the helicopter crew yesterday is unrelated to the wage dispute.

headline: ‚ÄúG√≥√∞an dag, this is Volodymyr from Kyiv‚Äù
body:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy spoke directly to the Icelandic Parliament and nation today in a virtual address broadcast in the chamber of Al√æingi. In his speech, Zelenskyy underlined the centuries-old ties between the two countries and urged Iceland to continue supporting Ukraine in the ongoing conflict, saying that ‚Äúthe size of a country is of no importance when fighting for democracy.‚Äù Before Zelenskyy took the floor, President of Iceland Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson addressed the Ukrainian President in English, commending the Ukrainian nation‚Äôs strength. He added that Iceland and Ukraine share values and that Ukrainian refugees are welcome in Iceland, even adding a few sentences in Ukrainian. Zelenskyy, in turn, began his speech with a few words in Icelandic, saying ‚ÄúHello, this is Volodymyr from Kyiv.‚Äù He emphasised the ancient ties between Iceland and Ukraine: Scandinavians settled the area that is now Ukraine as early as the 8th century. He thanked Iceland for taking part in sanctions against Russia and encouraged the country to continue to put pressure on Russia. The Ukrainian President stated that Icelanders‚Äô expertise in energy could come to good use in rebuilding Ukraine after the war is over. 







 A few dozen Ukrainians and supporters of Ukraine were gathered outside the Parliament building while the event took place, brandishing Ukrainian flags. Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir, Iceland‚Äôs Prime Minister, took the floor following Zelenskyy‚Äôs address. She condemned Russia‚Äôs threats to use nuclear weapons, saying that military action should be resisted and assuring Zelenskyy that the Icelandic government would do everything in its power to help the Ukrainian people. She stated that Iceland wanted in particular to provide special protection for women and children who were survivors of sexual violence due to the conflict. The Prime Minister ended her address by asking those present to rise for a moment of silence on behalf of the Ukrainian nation.

headline: Inflation Response Measures Target Renters, Pensioners, and Families
body: Renters, pensioners, and families with children are the target groups of government measures intended to reduce the impact of inflation on the most vulnerable demographics. The government approved the measures at a cabinet meeting this morning. They include raising social security benefits, income-related child benefits, and housing benefits. Almost half of households on the rental market receive housing benefits, according to estimates from the Housing and Construction Authority. Around 70% of them have index-linked leases. Housing benefits will be increased by 10% from June 1, and the income limit for receiving housing benefits will be raised by 3%. The cost of rent has doubled in Iceland over the past decade. Families receiving income-related child benefits will receive an additional ISK 20,000 per child [$153; ‚Ç¨145], to be paid out by the end of June. The child benefit system is being reviewed ‚Äúwith the aim of addressing various shortcomings in the system,‚Äù in order to better achieve the objectives of reducing child poverty and supporting parents, especially in lower income brackets. From June 1, disability benefits and benefits for old-age pensioners will be increased by 3%. Inflation measured 7.2% in Iceland last month. The Central Bank instituted a sharp 1% hike in interest rates in response. √çslandsbanki analysts have predicted that inflation will continue to rise in Iceland, peaking in June at 7.7%. The notice concludes by stating that the government will ‚Äúfocus on tight fiscal policy to support the Centra Bank‚Äôs monetary policy.‚Äù

headline: Zelenskyy to Address Icelandic Parliament and Nation Today
body: Ukraine‚Äôs President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will address Iceland‚Äôs Parliament and the Icelandic nation virtually at 2:00 PM this afternoon. It is the first time a foreign head of state makes a speech in Al√æingi, according to a notice from the Office of Parliament. The address will be broadcast into Al√æingi in a special ceremony involving the Prime Minister and President of Iceland. Speaker of Parliament Birgir √Årmannsson will preside over the event and will be its first speaker. After Birgir, President of Iceland Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson will say a few words on behalf of the Icelandic nation. Zelenskyy will then speak after Gu√∞ni, followed by Prime Minister of Iceland Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir. Icelandic authorities have condemned the Russian invasion of Ukraine and expressed support for the Ukrainian nation and government in the ongoing conflict. Iceland has participated in international economic sanctions against Russia and received nearly 1,000 refugees from Ukraine. An Icelandic airline has participated in transporting equipment, including military equipment, to Ukraine. The address will be streamed live at althingi.is as well as by Icelandic national broadcaster R√öV.

headline: Advanced Polls Busy as Municipal Elections Approach
body: More residents have voted in advanced polls for the upcoming municipal election than in the last election, in 2018, V√≠sir reports. Amendments to election legislation that took effect this year require all parties to announce their candidacy before advanced polls open. The amendments have had varying effects on the May 14 election, including enabling more foreign residents to vote and making it more difficult to man polling stations. ‚ÄúSo far today we‚Äôve had 421 people vote here at the District Commissioner of Greater Reykjav√≠k and since [advanced polls] opened, 2,800 have voted, and 4,063 across the whole country,‚Äù District Commissioner Sigr√≠√∞ur Kristinsd√≥ttir stated. There have already been more advanced voters in the capital area this election than in the entire country preceding the last election, in 2018. The advanced polling station for the capital area is open daily in the Holtagar√∞ar shopping centre from 10:00 AM to 10:00 PM. On election day, the station will be open between 10:00 AM and 5:00 PM for voters whose registered address is outside the capital area. The new election legislation has made it difficult to staff electoral committees, particularly in smaller municipalities, R√öV reports. A new rule states that committee staff members may not appear as supporters on the election lists of campaigning parties. In many municipalities, this has ruled out a majority of election committee staff, who are scrambling to find replacements. The fact that the election falls on the same day as the 2022 Eurovision Song Contest final has reportedly also made staffing polling stations more difficult. Before this year, most foreign citizens living in Iceland had to wait five years before they could vote in municipal elections. The new legislation has shortened that period to three years, with Danish, Norwegian, Swedish, and Finnish citizens whose legal residence is in Iceland can vote regardless of how long they have lived in the country. The amendment has led to some large shifts in voter demographics, for example in M√Ωrdalshreppur, South Iceland, where 42% of eligible voters are immigrants. The proportion is around one third in Skaft√°rhreppur and S√∫√∞av√≠kurhreppur, and around one quarter in Reykjanesb√¶r, Southwest Iceland. In an effort to reach voters who may not speak Icelandic, more political parties have created materials in English and Polish and held campaign meetings in English. The Multicultural Information Centre provides comprehensive information about municipal elections in English on its website.

headline: Rental Market in ‚ÄúState of Emergency‚Äù, Association Says
body: The upcoming municipal elections revolve mainly around the ‚Äústate of emergency in the housing and rental market,‚Äù a spokesperson for the Icelandic Tenants‚Äô Association has stated. Since 2005, apartments owned by legal entities that own more than one apartment have nearly doubled, R√öV reports. The Icelandic Tenants‚Äô Association held a public meeting at Kex Hostel yesterday. The aim of the meeting was to ‚Äúdemand answers‚Äù from candidates in the upcoming municipal elections on how they intended to ensure housing for tenants in Reykjav√≠k. In an interview with R√öV, Gu√∞mundur Hrafn Arngr√≠msson, a spokesperson for the Icelandic Tenants‚Äô Association, stated that tenants had been made to suffer from the slow development of housing in the capital region through ever-increasing rent, greater uncertainty, and deteriorating social status. The Association maintains that legal entities and wealthy individuals have swept up real estate for the sake of profit and that investors have little or no incentive to speed up development as a slow pace ensures higher rent. In its coverage yesterday, R√öV presented a handful of facts to shed light on the state of the rental market. According to the Tenant‚Äôs Association, individuals above the age of 35 have ‚Äúlittle chance‚Äù of escaping the rental market. 63% of young adults below the age of 24 live at home with their parents (39% of those who are under the age of 29).

headline: ISK 145 Million to Support Icelandic Education for Immigrants
body: The Ministry of Social Affairs and Labour has announced its annual allocation of ISK 145.5 million [$1.1 million; ‚Ç¨1.1 million] in support of Icelandic language education for immigrants. According to the ministry, the aim of the subsidy is to afford ‚Äúeveryone registered with a legal address in Iceland the opportunity to acquire the required proficiency in Icelandic to become active citizens in the country.‚Äù Foreign citizens account for around 15% of Iceland‚Äôs population. Eighteen schools, companies, and institutions will receive grants to conduct courses around the country. The subsidies are afforded to institutions that provide Icelandic language courses that are not part of a general curriculum in the public school system. The Icelandic government shuffled several dossiers when the current government took office last November, including Icelandic language education for immigrants, which was moved from the Ministry of Education to the Ministry of Social Affairs and Labour. Unlike many of its Nordic neighbours, Iceland does not provide free Icelandic language classes for immigrants. Education available to the country‚Äôs newest residents largely falls into two categories: free conversational classes provided by community organisations such as the Red Cross, and paid courses offered by privately-operated schools.¬†An eight-week paid course costs approximately ISK 50,000 [$375; ‚Ç¨340], though union members can usually get 75% of this fee reimbursed. The University of Iceland also offers a diploma and a degree program in Icelandic as a second language. Hjalti √ìmarsson of Retor fr√¶√∞sla, one of the schools that have received funding through the grant, says public funding covers only about 35-40% of the school‚Äôs operating costs. ‚ÄúWhen it comes to public funding, there‚Äôs not enough. The amount of grant money available has not risen since 2009. And whether your company has 10 employees or 100, the amount you can apply for is the same. Workplaces complain to us that they exhaust their grant money very quickly.‚Äù The government did allocate increased funding to Icelandic language education for immigrants as a response to the COVID-19 pandemic, but the measure was only temporary. No one at the Ministry of Social Affairs and Labour was available for comment. Read more about Icelandic language education for immigrants in our latest issue.

headline: Reykjav√≠k Plaza Renamed ‚ÄúKyiv Square‚Äù
body: A small square in central Reykjav√≠k will be renamed Kyiv Square in a show of support to Ukraine, the city‚Äôs authorities have announced. The square will also bear the name K√¶nugar√∞ur in Icelandic, an old Icelandic name for the Ukrainian capital. The square is located on the corner of Gar√∞astr√¶ti and T√∫ngata, amid a row of embassies, including Russia‚Äôs. ‚ÄúReykjav√≠k is sending a clear message of support for the Ukrainian nation here and at the same time referencing the ancient connection between Iceland and K√¶nugar√∞ur [Kyiv],‚Äù stated City Councillor Ey√æ√≥r Arnalds. ‚ÄúThe location at the corner of Gar√∞astr√¶ti and T√∫ngata is appropriate as those streets house the offices and embassies of foreign countries.‚Äù The notice from the City of Reykjav√≠k states that K√¶nugar√∞ur ‚Äúreferences the historic name of the city in Icelandic and emphasised its history that stretches back for millennia.‚Äù Scandinavians settled the area that is now Ukraine as early as the 8th century. The Kristni saga, written around the 13th century, refers to the city that is now Kyiv as K√¶nugar√∞ur. According to V√≠sindavefurinn, the first part of the word, k√¶na, is possibly derived from Kijane, the Old East Slavic name for residents of Kyiv, while gar√∞ur shares the same root as the Old East Slavic word gor√≥d, meaning city. In modern Icelandic, K√¶nugar√∞ur also means ‚ÄúK√¶na Garden,‚Äù an appropriate name for the square, which features greenery. The square will be known as Kyiv Square in English and will have similar names in other languages, in order to reference the city‚Äôs internationally-known name. The square is located amid a strip of embassies and foreign offices, including the Canadian Embassy to Iceland and the offices of the Faroese and Greenlandic delegations. The Russian embassy and Russian ambassador‚Äôs residence, where public protests have been held since the Russian invasion of Ukraine began, are located a short distance up the street. The Ukrainian embassy to Iceland is located in Helsinki, Finland.

headline: Trust in Government Plummets Following Controversial Bank Sale
body: If an election were held today, the current governing coalition would lose 12 of their 38 seats, losing their current majority. The three governing parties: the Left-Green Movement, the Independence Party, and the Progressive Party, would win 26 seats in Al√æingi ‚Äì 32 are needed for a majority government. The data comes from a recent poll Pr√≥sent conducted for news outlet Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞. Seven months since Iceland‚Äôs last parliamentary election and five months to the day since the cabinet was appointed, all three governing parties have lost significant following, according to the poll‚Äôs results. The Independence Party has experienced the biggest drop as compared to last autumn‚Äôs election results: from 24.4% to 17.9%. The Progressive Party now measures 12.4% support, as compared to 17.3% in the last election. Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir‚Äôs party the Left-Green Movement has dropped from 12.9% support in the election to 9.6% in the poll. Among the opposition, both the Pirate Party and the Social-Democratic Alliance have gained significant following when the poll is compared to the election results, and the Reform Party has also seen a slight increase in support, putting them on par with the Left-Green Movement. The People‚Äôs Party and Centre Party have both lost following since last autumn. The Socialist Party, which did not win any seats in the last election, would win three if elections were held today. A recent poll from Mask√≠na shows that trust in government ministers has fallen significantly since last year. The number of respondents that stated they trust Finance Minister Bjarni Benediktsson a lot has fallen by half since last autumn, from 37% to 18%. More than seven out of ten respondents stated they have little or very little trust in Bjarni. Several controversies have emerged since the government took power last autumn, the biggest of which has been last month‚Äôs sale of a 22.5% stake in √çslandsbanki. The government‚Äôs handling of the sale has been harshly criticised by opposition MPs and has led to multiple public protests. A racist comment uttered by Progressive Party Chairman Sigur√∞ur Ingi J√≥hannsson has likely impacted his party‚Äôs following.

headline: Debated √çslandsbanki Sale into the Wee Hours
body: Iceland‚Äôs Parliament debated the recent sale of a 22.5% stake in √çslandsbanki until 2:30 AM this morning. It was the first time Al√æingi had convened since before the Easter break and most of the discussion centred on the controversial sale. The government has received harsh criticism¬†for the share offering‚Äôs lack of transparency, and for the 5% discount buyers received on the shares‚Äô market value, despite high demand for the shares. Many have also criticised the fact that smaller, short-term investments were permitted in the sale, and that staff of the consulting company that managed the sale were among the investors. The sale is being investigated by the Central Bank and reviewed by the National Audit Office. Minister of Finance Bjarni Benediktsson presented an oral report on the sale during yesterday‚Äôs session. While maintaining that the sale had in general been successful, he admitted that it had raised questions regarding three aspects in particular: the possible participation of employees of the consulting company involved in the sale, the possible participation of buyers who did not fulfill the stated requirements of being professional investors, and the dissemination of information to the public. Bjarni stated that the public could have been better informed about the sale. He added that it had taked a long time to access and release information about the sale after the offering and some questions had remained unanswered for too long. Opposition MPs criticised the government‚Äôs decision to dismantle Icelandic State Financial Investments (ISFI) in light of how the sale went. They questioned whether that decision had truly been discussed at a cabinet meeting, as as an announcement from the government stated. Chairman of the Centre Party Sigmundur Dav√≠√∞ Gunlaugsson asked whether government ministers had any plan as to what would replace the ISFI. √çslandsbanki was fully owned by the government until last year, when it¬†sold¬†a 35% stake in the bank, something that had been on the government agenda¬†for years. While that first offering was open to the public, last month‚Äôs offering was solely open to professional investors. The second sale reduced the government‚Äôs stake in the bank from 65% to 42.5%. Two protests have been held where attendees opposed how the sale was handled, calling for Bjarni Benediktsson‚Äôs resignation.

headline: Many Icelandic Residents Unaware of Right to Vote
body: Foreign residents who have lived in Iceland consecutively for three years have the right to vote in municipal elections, but many of them are not aware of that right, says Sara Bj√∂rg Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir, a candidate for the Social-Democratic Alliance in Iceland‚Äôs upcoming municipal elections. Citizens of Denmark, Sweden, Norway, and Finland whose legal residence is in Iceland also have the right to vote in municipal elections, regardless of how long they have lived in the country. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre talking about residents who have been living here for many years, paid taxes and fees, been active users of city services but didn‚Äôt know that they could vote in municipal elections,‚Äù Sara Bj√∂rg told Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞. ‚ÄúAs a society, we need to do better when it comes to informing our residents about what rights they have in our society. One of the most precious ones is the right to vote.‚Äù Amendments to Iceland‚Äôs municipal election laws took effect on January 1 of this year, shortening the period foreign citizens must reside in Iceland before they acquire the right to vote in municipal elections. Municipal elections are held every four years in Iceland, and occur on the same date in all municipalities across the country. The upcoming municipal elections will be held on May 14, and advanced polls are already open.

headline: Iceland Donates ISK 130 Million in Emergency Aid to Ukraine
body: The Icelandic government has decided to send ISK 130 million [just over $1 million; ‚Ç¨929,000] in emergency financial assistance to Ukraine via the World Bank. R√öV reports that Foreign Minister √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n Reykfj√∂r√∞ Gylfad√≥ttir announced the additional funding after attending a meeting last week in Washington, D.C. wherein international leaders met to attend the World Bank‚Äôs roundtable on Ukraine. The meeting was scheduled to coincide with the spring meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. This is Iceland‚Äôs second major emergency aid donation to Ukraine. In February, Iceland committed ‚Ç¨1 million to humanitarian support in Ukraine, and also made a ‚Ç¨200,000 contribution to NATO‚Äôs Trust Fund for the Ukraine Professional Development Programme. Ukraine‚Äôs Prime Minister Denys Smyhal and Minister of Finance Sergei Marchenko were both present at the meeting and emphasized Ukraine‚Äôs urgent need for financial assistance, both in order to maintain basic services and also for reconstruction efforts. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky delivered an address remotely. In her own address, √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n expressed Iceland‚Äôs desire to contribute as much as possible to support Ukraine in its efforts to repel Russia‚Äôs invasion of their country. ‚ÄúThe Ukrainian people are fighting for their lives and freedom,‚Äù she said, reemphasizing that Iceland continues to stand in solidarity with Ukraine.

headline: ‚ÄòOut with Bjarni‚Äô: √çslandsbanki Protesters Continue Calls for Minister of Finance‚Äôs Resignation
body: Protesters gathered in Austurv√∂llur Square in front of parliament once more on Saturday to voice their anger at the government‚Äôs recent sale of shares in √çslandsbanki bank. Hundreds of protesters gathered last week; the exact attendance numbers of Saturday‚Äôs event were not available at time of writing. However, V√≠sir reports that 2,000 people marked themselves as attending on the protest on Facebook, an event entitled ‚ÄúBjarna Burt, Spillinguna Burt,‚Äù or ‚ÄúOut with Bjarni [Benediktsson, Minister of Finance], Out with Corruption.‚Äù The protest was a festive one, and kicked off with a performance by P√°ll √ìskar, and included speeches by former and current MPs, a reading by the ‚Äúpoet of the protest,‚Äù Anton Helgi J√≥nsson, and performances by hip hop acts XXX Rottweiler and Blaffi. Hot chocolate and doughnuts were served before and after the rally itself. See Also: Hundreds Protest Sale of √çslandsbanki Shares √çslandsbanki was fully owned by the government until last year, when it¬†sold a 35% stake in the bank, something that had been on the government agenda for years. While that first offering was open to the public, last month‚Äôs offering was solely open to professional investors. The second sale was successful, reducing the government‚Äôs stake in the bank from 65% to 42.5%. The government has been¬†criticised for the latter share offering‚Äôs lack of transparency, and for the 5% discount buyers received on the shares‚Äô market value. The majority of the investors who purchased shares sold their stakes almost immediately for considerable profit. Days after the first protest at Austurv√∂llur, the Icelandic government announced that it would be introducing a parliamentary bill to abolish Icelandic State Financial Investments (ISFI), the government‚Äôs holding company on the financial market. But protesters are not yet satisfied. Now that the latter demand has been achieved with the dismantling of ISFI all together, protesters remain focused on their first two goals. ‚ÄòOut with the puppets of capitalism in the government‚Äô ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to learn from this,‚Äù said headlining speaker Dav√≠√∞ √û√≥r J√≥nsson, a pastor and actor who has been an outspoken leader in the √çslandsbanki protests. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll learn to never, never, never again trust these people with a single thing. We‚Äôll learn to never, never, never again trust political parties that form a government that would allow this to happen.‚Äù His remarks were met with cheers from the crowd. ‚ÄúOur demands are unambiguous and reasonable,‚Äù Dav√≠√∞ √û√≥r continued. ‚ÄúOut with the psychopaths [amoral people] in our financial system! Out with the puppets of capitalism in the government! Out with an ineffectual, cowardly Al√æingi that doesn‚Äôt have the guts to affirm its lack of confidence in an unfit government that doesn‚Äôt just permit, but rather gives its blessing to the psychopaths plundering their own country!‚Äù

headline: Iceland Would Support Finland Joining NATO, Prime Minister Says
body: Iceland‚Äôs Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir has stated that the country would support Finland and Sweden if they decide to join NATO, R√öV reports. Support for Finland joining NATO has more than doubled among the general public since the Russian invasion of Ukraine began. Katr√≠n stated that Iceland‚Äôs Security Council is updating its risk assessment for Iceland. Katr√≠n stated that the re-evaluation is ‚ÄúBased on both the events in Ukraine and what could possibly follow: that is, the possible accession of Finland and Sweden to the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. So this work is ongoing.‚Äù Katr√≠n travelled to Finland earlier this month, where she met with Finnish Prime Minister Sanna Marin (pictured above). The two leaders discussed ‚ÄúRussia‚Äôs military aggression against Ukraine, the European security situation and deepening Nordic cooperation,‚Äù according to a tweet from the Finnish government. When asked about Russia‚Äôs potential reaction to Finland and Sweden joining NATO, Katr√≠n stated: ‚ÄúWe see that they do not take this well in public discussion. But the way I look at it the Finns and Swedes make their decisions and we will stand with them in their decisions.‚Äù

headline: Calls on Icelandic Authorities to Tackle Hate Speech
body: If hate speech has no consequences for the individuals who spout it in Iceland, that could serve as a certain recognition that it is acceptable, according to Doctor of Anthropology and Assistant Professor of Police Science Eyr√∫n Ey√æ√≥rsd√≥ttir. Eyr√∫n told R√öV it is up to Icelandic authorities to take concrete measures against hate speech. Icelandic media outlet Kjarninn withdrew an interview with deputy MP Lenya R√∫n Taha Karim from online circulation yesterday after the article received a flood of personal attacks against Lenya, including racism and hate speech, on social media. In the interview, Lenya R√∫n describes the disrespect and racism she has had to endure in Iceland as a person of foreign origin in the public sphere. ‚ÄúThe fact that people appear under their own name [on social media] and express themselves in this way, that can perhaps be traced to the fact that there have in fact been few consequences for people in Iceland who have [used hate speech],‚Äù Eyr√∫n explains. ‚ÄúPerhaps a precedent has even been set for hate speech, and if it is left undisturbed, then it creates a certain recognition that it is maybe just OK.‚Äù ‚ÄúNothing has been heard from the authorities, they haven‚Äôt condemned this type of hatred that is put forth against certain members of society, and that‚Äôs a shame,‚Äù Eyr√∫n observes. ‚ÄúIn many countries, authorities have laid down plans, invested money, created hate crime units within the police and other such things, as a strong emphasis is placed on tackling [hate speech].‚Äù Eyr√∫n previously headed such a unit within the Capital Area Police Department, but it has since been dismantled. The authorities themselves have been embroiled in a controversy regarding a racist remark made by Minister of Infrastructure Sigur√∞ur Ingi J√≥hannsson at a conference last month. Sigur√∞ur Ingi has been accused of violating the Parliamentary Code of Ethics by making the comment. Besides publishing an apology on his Facebook page, the minister has refused to discuss the incident. ‚ÄúHate speech is of the nature that the more well-known and powerful the people that use it are, the worse its effect is in society,‚Äù Eyr√∫n says. It can cause others to take up such language, ‚Äúbecause they think that if the nation‚Äôs officials can allow themselves to talk this way then it‚Äôs OK.‚Äù

headline: Government to Dismantle State Investment Company
body: The Icelandic government will introduce a parliamentary bill to abolish Icelandic State Financial Investments, the government‚Äôs holding company on the financial market. The decision is made in response to widespread criticism of how the government handled the sale of 22.5% of √çslandsbanki bank last month. No further sale of the state‚Äôs shares in √çslandsbanki will take place until a new system is in place, a notice from the government states. The sale of 22.5% of formerly state-owned bank √çslandsbanki last month through a private stock offering has been harshly criticised by opposition MPs as well as the general public. Several hundred gathered in Austurv√∂llur square last Friday to protest the way the sale was handled. One of the speakers at the event, Pirate Party MP Halld√≥ra Mogensen, called on Minister of Finance Bjarni Benediktsson to resign. The government has been¬†criticised¬†for the share offering‚Äôs lack of transparency, and for the 5% discount buyers received on the shares‚Äô market value, despite high demand for the shares. Many have also criticised the fact that smaller, short-term investors were permitted to take part in the sale, and that √çslandsbanki staff and staff of the consulting company that managed the sale were among the investors. While the government‚Äôs stated aim for the share offering was to attract long-term investors, shareholder lists revealed that many smaller investors sold their shares in the bank just days after the sale, for a significant profit. The list of purchasers included a holding company owned by the Finance Minister‚Äôs father. Government ministers have refused interview requests from reporters over the past week to discuss the sale of the bank. The government notice released today states that ‚ÄúIt is clear that the implementation of the sale did not fully live up to the government‚Äôs expectations, e.g. on transparency and clear dissemination of information.‚Äù ¬†

headline: Hundreds Protest Sale of √çslandsbanki Shares

headline: Many √çslandsbanki Buyers Have Already Sold for Profit
body: Of the 207 investors who purchased shares in √çslandsbanki bank in a private share offering last month, 132 have already sold some or all of their stake in the formerly state-owned bank, Kjarninn reports. The sellers have made a cumulative profit of ISK 1.6-2.1 billion [$12.3-16.2 million; ‚Ç¨11.4-15 million]. Finance Minister Bjarni Benediktsson had previously stated that the aim of the share offering was to acquire long-term investors in the bank. √çslandsbanki was fully owned by the government until last year, when it¬†sold a 35% stake in the bank, something that had been on the government agenda¬†for years. While that first offering was open to the public, last month‚Äôs offering was solely open to professional investors. The second sale was successful, reducing the government‚Äôs stake in the bank from 65% to 42.5%. The government has been¬†criticised¬†for the latter share offering‚Äôs lack of transparency, and for the 5% discount buyers received on the shares‚Äô market value. Notably, six foreign investment funds that were invited to take part in the offering sold all of their purchased shares in the bank within three days of listing, at a significant profit. These funds also participated in last year‚Äôs public share offering, meaning they have turned quick profits on the sale of the bank‚Äôs shares for a second time. Those funds include Silver Point Capital, Fiera Capital, Lansdowne Partners, and Key Square Partners. According to the shareholder lists Kjarninn has in its possession, most of the ‚Äúsmaller‚Äù investors that took part in last month‚Äôs share offering have already sold their shares in the √çslandsbanki. In total, 59 investors were permitted to buy shares for under ISK 30 million and another 79 for under ISK 50 million. Among the purchasers who are no longer listed as shareholders of √çslandsbanki are employees and owners of the consulting company that was hired to manage the stock offering. Some larger investors who took part in the offering, who bought shares worth several hundred million ISK, have also sold their stake in the bank. This includes Steinn Holding Company, owned by Samherji seafood company CEO √ûorsteinn M√°r Baldvinsson and his ex-wife. One particularly controversial buyer in the offering was the company Hafsilfur, owned by Benedikt Sveinsson, the father of Finance Minister Bjarni Benediktsson. The Finance Minister is responsible for the sale of √çslandsbanki, according to law. Hafsilfur is still listed as a shareholder in √çslandsbanki, and its shares have increased in value by around ISK 5 million since the share offering. Pension funds and other institutional investors have bought up a large part of the shares that smaller investors have sold at profit since the share offering. It was previously reported that pension funds requested to were allotted fewer shares in the offering than they had requested. The Central Bank of Iceland has stated it is investigating the sale.

headline: Central Bank Investigating √çslandsbanki Sale
body: The Central Bank of Iceland confirmed to Stundin that it has opened an investigation into the government‚Äôs March 22 sale of a 22.5% stake in √çslandsbanki bank. However, what specific matters about the sale are under investigation is not clear. ‚ÄúIn light of the Central Bank of Iceland‚Äôs supervisory role, the Bank cannot comment on issues that are directly related to the state‚Äôs sale of a holding in √çslandsbanki,‚Äù a Central Bank spokesperson told Stundin. ‚ÄúThe reason is that individual factors related to the sale may be examined by the Central Bank‚Äôs Financial Supervisory Authority, and an examination of certain aspects related to the sale has already begun.‚Äù As previously reported, √çslandsbanki was entirely state-owned until the government sold a 35% stake in 2021. While last year‚Äôs sale was a public offering, the March 2022 sale was only open to professional investors, who received an invitation to buy shares, which were then sold for 5% less than market value after markets had closed for the day. The blowback to the sale was swift once it came to light that, in addition to pension funds, those who purchased shares in March included J√≥n √Åsgeir J√≥hannesson, the largest shareholder in Glitnir bank before it went bust in Iceland‚Äôs 2008 economic collapse; Samherji CEO and former Glitnir chairman √ûorseinn M√°r Baldvinsson; and Benedikt Sveinsson, the father of Minister of Finance Bjarni Benediktsson. Stundin raised concerns last week about the status of those invited to the recent sale. The offering was meant to be open exclusively to institutional investors, but, Stundin‚Äôs source alleged, some investors who walked away with √çslandsbanki shares were general investors with third party securities firms. Also voicing concerns over how the recent sale was handled is Minister of Tourism, Trade and Culture Lilja D√∂gg Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir, V√≠sir reports. She said Finance Minister Bjarni Benediktsson must be held responsible. What isn‚Äôt clear is whether Lilja is speaking for herself or if her sentiments about the sale and Bjarni are representative of the Progressive Party, of which she is vice-chairperson. Lilja sits on the Council of Ministers for Economic Affairs and the Restructuring of the Financial System along with Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir and the Finance Minister. The Prime Minister said that Lilja had not noted her opposition to the sale in any official minutes.

headline: Minister to Meet with CEO Vigd√≠s H√§sler in Wake of Racist Remark
body: Minister of Infrastructure Sigur√∞ur Ingi J√≥hannsson will meet with CEO of the Icelandic Farmers‚Äô Association Vigd√≠s H√§sler today to discuss a racist remark made by the Minister at the association‚Äôs annual conference last week. Vigd√≠s hopes the meeting will allow her to ‚Äúset the matter aside,‚Äù R√öV reports. Words spoken in a ‚Äúfit of frustration‚Äù As reported by Iceland Review earlier this week, Minister of Infrastructure¬†and Chairman of the Progressive Party Sigur√∞ur Ingi J√≥hannsson attended the annual conference of the Icelandic Farmers‚Äô Association last week.¬† After a night of ‚Äúmuch singing, joy, and entertainment,‚Äù a few employees of the Farmers‚Äô Association approached the Minister, asking him to partake in a photo-op. The photo-op involved lifting CEO Vigd√≠s H√§sler onto a makeshift plank. Finding the act inappropriate, the Minister refused to participate and uttered a racist remark about the CEO. (Vigd√≠s is Icelandic but was originally adopted from Indonesia.) Vigd√≠s published a Facebook post on the incident on Monday, saying that she had ‚Äúnever imagined she would have to write such a statement: I‚Äôve never let the colour of my skin, my race, sex, or anything else define me.‚Äù Vigd√≠s wrote that the Minister had uttered an ‚Äúextremely hurtful remark,‚Äù without getting into the details. Shortly after Vigd√≠s‚Äô post, Sigur√∞ur Ingi published a written apology on Facebook. In an interview with R√öV on Tuesday, the Minister again apologised for his remark, adding that it had been spoken in a ‚Äúfit of frustration.‚Äù According to Sigur√∞ur, he had tried to reach out to Vigd√≠s on the morning after the annual conference and through the Association‚Äôs Chair on the following weekend. While pressed several times to clarify what exactly he had said, the Minister refused to repeat his remark. Hopes to ‚Äúset the matter aside‚Äù As reported by R√öV last night, Sigur√∞ur Ingi will meet with Vigd√≠s H√§sler today. Vigd√≠s hopes that she will be able to ‚Äúset the matter aside‚Äù after the meeting, although closure will depend entirely on Sigur√∞ur Ingi.¬† In a brief interview, Vigd√≠s stated that she had received ‚Äúnumerous messages over the past few days,‚Äù from the parents of adopted children, among others, in which it became clear to her that ‚Äúall types of racism are widely tolerated.‚Äù She did not comment further on the meeting.¬† The Minister has received harsh criticism from the public, many of whom have called on him to resign. Opposition MPs have also criticised Sigur√∞ur Ingi. In a session in Parliament, Pirate Party MP Halld√≥ra Mogensen stated that the Minister‚Äôs remark could be considered ‚Äúa breach of law.‚Äù In response to the opposition, Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir stated that Sigur√∞ur Ingi‚Äôs apology indicated that the remark had been unacceptable and should not have been uttered. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt dispute the words of the CEO of the Icelandic Farmers‚Äô Association in this matter, but we must also be able to accept it when people apologise,‚Äù Katr√≠n stated.

headline: List of √çslandsbanki Buyers Released
body: In the wake of opposition criticism about low share prices and a general lack of transparency around the government‚Äôs March 22 sale of a 22.5% stake in √çslandsbanki bank, the Ministry of Finance has publicly released the list of investors. As Stundin reports, 209 investors participated in the March sale, with a handful of pension funds scooping up a sizeable number of shares. The largest single buyer was Gildi Pension Fund, followed by the Pension Fund for Icelandic State Employees, Br√∫ Pension Fund and the Pension Fund of Commerce. All other investors purchased less than 4% each of the total shares available in this offering. Notable investors include J√≥n √Åsgeir J√≥hannesson, the largest shareholder in Glitnir bank before it went bust in Iceland‚Äôs 2008 economic collapse; Samherji CEO and former Glitnir chairman √ûorseinn M√°r Baldvinsson; and Benedikt Sveinsson, the father of Minister of Finance Bjarni Benediktsson. The full list of investors who participated in this round of sales has been published by Stundin. The investment in √çslandsbanki is paying off for those invited to invest. Share prices are up 11% since the sale. Stundin calculated that the Finance Minister‚Äôs father has already made ISK 6 million profit on his newly acquired shares, while the fishing company Jakob Valgeir ehf. has made ISK 102 million. √çslandsbanki was entirely state-owned until the government sold a 35% stake in 2021. While last year‚Äôs sale was a public offering, the recent sale was only open to professional investors, who received an invitation to buy shares, which were then sold for 5% less than market value after markets had closed for the day. Icelandic State Financial Investments (ISFI) previously said it was not able to publish the data on who purchased shares. ISFI believed it was likely the buyers‚Äô identity falls under bank secrecy regulations. ¬† ¬†

headline: Legal Obstacles to Revealing √çslandsbanki Buyers
body: Icelandic State Financial Investments (ISFI) has stated it is not able to publish the data on who purchased shares in √çslandsbanki during last month‚Äôs stock offering. The government has been criticised for the share offering‚Äôs lack of transparency, and for the 5% discount buyers received on the shares‚Äô market value. Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir has previously stated that if the ISFI is not able to publish information then the Icelandic Parliament should amend legislation to make it possible. √çslandsbanki was fully owned by the government until last year, when it sold a 35% stake in the bank, something that had been on the government agenda for years. While that first offering was open to the public, last month‚Äôs offering was solely open to professional investors. The second sale was successful, reducing the government‚Äôs stake in the bank from 65% to 42.5%. Minister of Finance Bjarni Benediktsson stated yesterday that the information on who the buyers were would be published, if permitted by law. In an interview this morning, Chairman of ISFI‚Äôs board L√°rus Bl√∂ndal stated that ISFI does not consider itself able to publish the data, as it is likely the buyers‚Äô identity falls under bank secrecy regulations. He added that it is virtually unheard of for buyers to be publicly identified when such offerings are conducted abroad. A total of 209 parties bought shares in the March offering. The Finance Minister has previously stated that Icelandic pension funds were the main purchasers. L√°rus stated that all of the buyers could be legally classified as professional investors. Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir has argued that when state property is sold, the Icelandic public is entitled to know who the buyers are. During Al√æingi‚Äôs question period on Monday, she stated that ‚ÄúIf any technical factors cause ISFI to consider ifself unable to publish that information, I believe it is right for Al√æingi to make appropriate changes to the legal framework so that it can be published, anything else is unacceptable.‚Äù Read more about the sale of state-owned banks in Iceland.

headline: Minister Harshly Criticised for Racist Remark
body: Minister of Infrastructure Sigur√∞ur Ingi J√≥hannsson is facing harsh criticism for a racist remark he made at the Icelandic Farmers‚Äô Association annual conference last week. Sigur√∞ur Ingi‚Äôs assistant originally denied the minister had made the comment, calling it ‚Äúutter nonsense.‚Äù After Vigd√≠s published a Facebook post on the incident, however, Sigur√∞ur Ingi also published a written apology for making the remark. Reform Party MP addressed the Prime Minister, asking if she did not consider it obvious that Sigur√∞ur Ingi‚Äôs remark was a breach of MPs and Ministers‚Äô codes of conduct. In her response to the opposition, Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir stated that Sigur√∞ur Ingi‚Äôs apology indicated that the remark had been unacceptable and should not have been said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt dispute the words of the CEO of the Icelandic Farmers‚Äô Association in this matter but we must also be able to accept it when people apologise,‚Äù Katr√≠n stated. When asked about Sigur√∞ur Ingi‚Äôs remark following a cabinet meeting today, Minister of Finance Bjarni Benediktsson referred to it as ‚Äújust a very unfortunate incident.‚Äù Neither he nor Minister of Higher Education, Science, and Innovation √Åslaug Arna Sigurbj√∂rnsd√≥ttir would comment on whether they felt Sigur√∞ur Ingi should resign due to the comment. Sigur√∞ur Ingi declined to answer any questions about the incident, pointing instead to his Facebook post. Vigd√≠s has stated that she will make no further comment on the incident.

headline: Agreement on Long-Awaited New Research Vessel Signed
body: The Marine & Freshwater Research Institute (MFRI) will receive a new research vessel in 2024. Yesterday, the institute‚Äôs director signed an agreement with government ministers and the Spanish contractor Astilleros Arm√≥n. In June 2018, on the centenary of Iceland‚Äôs sovereignty, Parliament approved a bill granting the Minister of Fisheries the authority to initiate preparations for the construction of a new research vessel for the Marine & Freshwater Research Institute (MFRI). The new vessel would replace Bjarni S√¶mundsson HF-030, which was constructed in 1970. The MFRI would continue to use √Årni Fri√∞riksson, a much younger vessel, built in 2000. Yesterday, √ûorsteinn Sigur√∞sson, the Director of the MFRI, signed an agreement with Minister of Finance Bjarni Benediktsson; Minister of Food, Agriculture, and Fisheries Svand√≠s Svavarsd√≥ttir; and an unnamed representative from the Spanish shipbuilding company Astilleros Arm√≥n for the construction of the new research vessel. ‚ÄúThis is a milestone in the history of marine research in Iceland,‚Äù √ûorsteinn stated in an interview with Mbl.is yesterday. According to the director, discussions regarding the construction of a new research vessel began around the turn of the century. At the time, a decision was made to refit Bjarni S√¶mundsson, with the repairs expected to last until 2012. Yesterday, the MFRI signed an agreement for the long-awaited new vessel. Construction is expected to take 30 months. If all goes according to plan, the vessel will arrive in Iceland in the fall of 2024. As noted by Mbl.is, an emphasis will be placed on fuel efficiency and environmentally friendliness in the construction of the new vessel. It will be 70 metres long and 12 metres wide. Skipas√Ωn has spent the past three years designing the ship. It also oversaw the tendering process. The ship will be built by Astilleros Arm√≥n, which made the lowest offer of three Spanish yards that tendered for the build, or ISK 4.8 billion ($37 million / ‚Ç¨33.5 million).

headline: Housing Available for 1,815 Ukrainian Refugees
body: The Multicultural Information Centre (MCC) estimates that accommodation is currently available to house up to 1,815 refugees from Ukraine, V√≠sir reports. Since Russia invaded Ukraine on Feb. 24, housing has been offered by the public, hotels and, notably, Bifr√∂st University. MCC director Nichole Leigh Mosty said the centre has received 363 accommodation offers from 51 municipalities, with the vast majority in the capital area. In the first week after MCC invited people to register available accommodation, the centre received 100 offers per day, with many individuals offering available rooms in their homes. That figure has since slowed to less than 100 offers per week and trended toward full apartments. ‚ÄúThe municipalities are working hard to map services and work with us,‚Äù Nichole told V√≠sir. ‚ÄúNow an interim solution is being launched where people get housing from three weeks to three months. As a result, more sustainable measures will be considered that better take into account the needs of each and every family.‚Äù An average of 18 Ukrainian nationals apply for international protection in Iceland daily, with 124 individuals arriving in the past week. A total of 508 Ukrainian citizens have applied for international protection in Iceland since Feb. 24, and a report from the National Commissioner of Police estimates another 496 individuals will apply for protection over the next four weeks.

headline: Iceland‚Äôs Economic Outlook ‚ÄúImproving,‚Äù Despite Rising Inflation
body: The annual inflation rate hit 6.7% this morning. It hasn‚Äôt been higher since May 2010. In a press conference today, introducing the government‚Äôs fiscal plan, Finance Minister Bjarni Benediktsson maintained that the economic outlook was ‚Äúimproving.‚Äù According to data published on the website of Statistics Iceland this morning, the annual inflation rate in Iceland has hit a near 12-year high: 6.7% ‚Äì an increase of almost a percentage point (0.94%) since last month. The biggest driver for this recent increase has been a rise in the price of housing, gas, and clothing. The price of oil and gas rose by 8.2%, the cost of housing by 2%, and the price of clothing and footwear by 5.3%. As noted by R√öV, the inflation rate has seen a sharp increase over the past few months. The annual inflation rate was 4.3% in August of last year, and it has risen steadily since then. The first three months of this year have seen the steepest increase, or ca. half a percentage point from December. The inflation rate has exceeded the Central Bank‚Äôs target rates (2.5%) for almost two years, R√öV notes. Finance Minister Bjarni Benediktsson introduced the government‚Äôs fiscal plan today. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre exiting a deep economic depression, in which we employed the state finances to safeguard households and companies ‚Ä¶ we‚Äôve been protecting our public services and ensuring that we‚Äôre prepared to recover when the effects of the pandemic began to subside. I think we‚Äôve been very successful in this regard,‚Äù Bjarni stated. A press release on the fiscal plan echoes the Finance Minister‚Äôs statement, stating that ‚Äúthe financial standing of households and companies is strong,‚Äù and that the government‚Äôs debt prospects have ‚Äúimproved considerably:‚Äù ‚ÄúThe government is hopeful that a moderate increase in outlays and continued growth within expanding export industries‚Äù will provide ‚Äúan opportunity to strengthen the (economic) base again and work towards building an even more robust society.‚Äù A few key figures from the press release on the new policy: As noted in the above-mentioned press release, the government will be emphasising several issues in its fiscal plan, among them mental health. The policy area will receive a permanent increase of ISK 500 million ($3.9 million / ‚Ç¨3.5 million) in 2023, and an additional increase of ISK 100 million ($800,000 / ‚Ç¨700,000) each year for the following two years. Other notable issues that the government will be emphasising in its policy are investments in research and innovation (ISK 25 billion); combatting the long-term social and health-related effects of the pandemic (ISK 3 billion); and defence and cyber security (ISK 2.2 billion). 2.6% of government spending will be allocated to environmental issues. There was no mention of a national stadium in the fiscal plan. The fiscal plan will be in effect for the years 2023-2027. ¬† This article was updated at 12:48 PM.

headline: New Hospital Won‚Äôt Meet Bed-Demand, Report Finds
body: A new government report finds that the healthcare system will be significantly short of hospital beds by 2040, even with the new hospital opening on Hringbraut in Reykjav√≠k. The Director of the new hospital hopes that the war in Ukraine won‚Äôt delay construction. On March 18, the Ministry of Health released a report on the future development of the National University Hospital of Iceland (Landsp√≠tali). The report, which was based on data from 2019, was predicated on analytical work done by the management consulting company McKinsey & Company. Among the report‚Äôs main findings was that the need for hospital beds in Iceland is expected to rise by 80% by 2040. This need is driven mainly by demographic changes, with the average age in the country expected to increase by 9% and the total population expected to increase by 18% over the next 18 years. Given these changes, the healthcare system would have only half of the needed hospital beds by 2040 if no significant actions were taken ‚Äì even with the opening of the new hospital on Hringbraut (expected to open in 2026). According to the report, the healthcare system can tackle the shortage by shifting long-term and primary care from Landsp√≠tali to ‚Äúa more (sic) adequate healthcare setting.‚Äù The health authorities would need to create the equivalent of ca. 240 bed capacity in home-based, elderly, and rehabilitation-care facilities. In an interview with R√öV yesterday, Run√≥lfur P√°lsson, Director of the National University Hospital of Iceland, responded to the report by saying that ‚Äútime was of the essence.‚Äù ‚ÄúEverybody is familiar with the current facilities as far as hospital beds are concerned,‚Äù P√°ll observed. ‚ÄúPersonnel shortage is also a growing concern. We should have acted sooner; the preparation time required for the construction of the new hospital was way too long.‚Äù As noted on R√öV yesterday, the current conditions at Landsp√≠tali er still difficult, even with a decline in COVID-19 cases. There is a significant shortage of hospital beds. Every day, almost 30 people must wait in the emergency ward to be admitted into the hospital. Furthermore, illnesses among staff, whether resulting from COVID-19 or influenza, have also made operations difficult. Many employees of the hospital have also gone on sick leave owing to work-related stress. In an interview on Friday, Gunnar Svavarsson, Director of the New University Hospital on Hringbraut, stated that the construction of the new hospital was, for the most part, on schedule. The Russian invasion of Ukraine may cause a delay, however, as the contractors can no longer import steel from Russia. ‚ÄúWe hope there won‚Äôt be any delays,‚Äù Gunnar said. ‚ÄúAs it stands, it‚Äôs looking pretty good. Some areas are behind schedule and others that are ahead of schedule.‚Äù

headline: Iceland to Increase Defence Spending, PM Announces
body: PM Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir attended a NATO meeting in Brussels yesterday. Speaking to R√öV after the meeting, the PM stated that the government would be increasing its defence budget, with special emphasis on cyber security. Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir attended an extraordinary NATO meeting in Brussels yesterday alongside Minister of Foreign Affairs √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n Reykfj√∂r√∞ Gylfad√≥ttir. The aim of the meeting was to discuss NATO‚Äôs short and long-term response to the war in Ukraine. ‚ÄúWe condemn Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine in the strongest possible terms,‚Äù a statement released after the meeting by the Heads of State and Government of the 30 NATO Allies read. ‚ÄúWe call on President Putin to immediately stop this war and withdraw military forces from Ukraine, and call on Belarus to end its complicity, in line with the Aggression Against Ukraine Resolution adopted at the UN General Assembly of 2 March 2022.‚Äù In an interview with R√öV after the meeting, Katr√≠n stated that although Iceland would not be participating directly in NATO operations, it would be offering humanitarian support. ‚ÄúWe have decided to ramp up humanitarian support. That is, to increase our support even more. We‚Äôve tripled our spending since the start of the invasion.‚Äù As noted on the government‚Äôs website, Iceland will be contributing an additional ISK 150 million ($1.1 million / ‚Ç¨ 1 million) to humanitarian aid. The authorities have already spent more than ISK 500 ($3.9 million / ‚Ç¨ 3.5 million) million since the war began. Given that NATO has decided to activate its defence plans, Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir also expects increased traffic above and around Iceland. NATO‚Äôs defence plans involve, among other things, the deployment of ‚Äúsignificant air and naval assets.‚Äù ‚ÄúDefence plans have been activated for all NATO zones,‚Äù Katr√≠n observed, ‚Äúincluding areas to which Iceland and Norway belong. So we can expect increased air and sea traffic.‚Äù Iceland will also be increasing its NATO funding. ‚ÄúWe will increase our spending over the next few years, and that spending will be focused on cyber security, which is also an area of emphasis within NATO,‚Äù Katr√≠n told R√öV.

headline: Icelandic Government to Stop Subsidising Rapid Testing for COVID-19
body: On April 1, Iceland‚Äôs government will stop subsidising rapid COVID-19 testing centres, a notice from the Health Ministry states. The regulation first came into force on September 16, and allowed private parties to offer rapid testing services free of charge. Symptomatic testing will continue to be conducted at primary healthcare centres and health care institutions, free of charge. Testing for travellers who require a COVID-19 test certificate will remain available for a fee. PCR exams at primary healthcare centres and healthcare institutions for those who require a travel certificate will cost ISK 7.000 [$54; ‚Ç¨50], as before. The Icelandic government‚Äôs test and trace policy was key to curbing the spread of COVID-19 during the first waves of the pandemic. It came at a hefty price tag, however: R√öV reported that between the start of the pandemic and the end of last year, the government spent over ISK 9 billion [$70 million; ‚Ç¨63.7 million] on COVID-19 testing. The largest portion of that cost is attributed to PCR testing, followed by border testing, and then rapid testing, which was not introduced in Iceland until mid-2021. Iceland lifted all domestic restrictions due to COVID-19 on February 25, 2022, including mandatory isolation and quarantine. While infection rates remain relatively high, hospitalisation and death rates are dramatically lower than in previous waves of the pandemic.

headline: State Sells 22.5% Stake in √çslandsbanki
body: The Icelandic government sold a 22.5% stake in √çslandsbanki bank last Tuesday in an offering for professional investors. Opposition MPs have criticised the shares‚Äô low price and the sale‚Äôs lack of transparency. Finance Minister Bjarni Benediktsson says the aim was to acquire long-term investors and that Icelandic pension funds were the main purchasers. √çslandsbanki was fully owned by the Icelandic state until last year, when it sold a 35% stake in the bank, something that had been on the government agenda for years. While last year‚Äôs sale was a public offering, this week‚Äôs was only open to professional investors, who received an invitation to buy shares, which were then sold at a 5% discount from their market value. The sale was successful, reducing the government‚Äôs stake in the bank from 65% to 42.5%. According to information from Icelandic State Financial Investments (ISFI), demand for the shares was high. Both Icelandic and foreign investors showed interest in the sale, though the identity of the investors has not been made public. Investors were required to sign a confidentiality agreement, meaning they were temporarily granted access to inside information. Investors had already made a profit yesterday, when shares in the bank rose by ISK 4-5 billion [$31.1-38.9 million; ‚Ç¨28.3-35.4 million] following the sale. MPs criticised the sale‚Äôs lack of transparency in Parliament yesterday, as well as the discount given to investors. Financial expert √Åsgeir Brynjar Torfason told R√öV it is unclear how the investors were selected, and that is a question that ISFI and the Ministry of Finance need to answer. He also called on authorities to answer why such a large discount was given, despite high demand for the shares. In an interview with R√öV, Minister of Finance Bjarni Benediktsson called the discount on the shares a small one, saying that Icelandic pension funds were the main purchasers in the offering. ‚ÄúWe did not go the route of looking for the pension fund or the investor who wanted to offer the highest price and let them have as much as they wanted. We took another route. We wanted to go toward more decentralised ownership and we wanted to consider what the market conditions would be like when the offering ended. That there would be a [financially] healthy group behind the bank.‚Äù

headline: Will Submit a Revised Decriminalisation Bill this Autumn
body: Iceland‚Äôs Health Minister Willum √û√≥r √û√≥rsson says he will submit a revised bill to decriminalise possession of illegal substances in small quantities, R√öV reports. Willum has faced criticism for withdrawing his decriminalisation bill from Parliament‚Äôs spring agenda. He says the bill is now being reviewed by a group that includes specialists on the matter. Read More: Disappointment as Health Minister Shelves Decriminalisation Bill MPs and rights organisations have criticised the Minister‚Äôs decision to drop the bill from Al√æingi‚Äôs spring agenda. Willum says that the working group will collect data, define terminology, and better organise the issue. They are expected to finish their work by the end of this month. He added that while there has not been consensus on the bill within Parliament, he believes the working group will help solve existing disagreements. ‚ÄúI have put the matter into a very broad consultation, which is what is often called for, and then I intend to introduce it in the autumn session, which is only five months away,‚Äù the Health Minister stated.

headline: Disappointment as Health Minister Shelves Decriminalisation Bill
body: Health Minister Willum √û√≥r √û√≥rsson has received criticism for shelving a bill that would have decriminalised possession of illegal drugs in small amounts. Krist√≠n Dav√≠√∞sd√≥ttir, director of the Icelandic Red Cross‚Äô harm reduction team, says the Minister‚Äôs decision to take the bill off Parliament‚Äôs calendar is a big disappointment that will negatively impact at-risk populations. ‚ÄúI have to admit that this somewhat surprised me, I didn‚Äôt expect it. It seemed to us that there was a certain momentum in the whole community in support of decriminalisation,‚Äù Krist√≠n told R√öV. ‚ÄúWe have seen a big change just in the nation‚Äôs opinion. Around 60% of the nation describes itself as supportive of decriminalisation today. So I found it sad, first and foremost.‚Äù Iceland legalised safe injection sites in 2020, but it wasn‚Äôt until earlier this month that the Red Cross opened the country‚Äôs first: a mobile site that is stationed in downtown Reykjav√≠k between 10:00 PM and 4:00 AM, while shelters are closed. The site provides clients 18 years of age and older with sterilised needles, helps them avoid overdosing, and even provides warm socks, hats, and gloves to those who need them. The regulations on safe injection sites permits clients to carry illegal substances in small doses. However, it complicates the site‚Äôs operation if those same clients can be arrested for possession at a certain distance from the safe injection vehicle, Krist√≠n says. ‚ÄúAnd of course it‚Äôs just never good when things are set up in this way. And especially not concerning this group. This is a very broken-down group that has a hard time trusting, has a hard time trusting the system. I think it‚Äôs incredibly important to erase any kind of doubt just in order to foster increased safety and trust in this group.‚Äù

headline: Vote Recount Case Dismissed
body: The Police Commissioner of West Iceland has dismissed a case against the staff of the Northwest Constituency‚Äôs election supervision committee, V√≠sir reports. The staff have received letters informing them of the decision. The letters state that new legislation, which took effect on January 1, makes it unclear whether the staff had broken the law by not resealing ballot boxes between the initial count and a recount of votes. A vote recount in the Northwest Constituency following the Parliamentary election on September 25, 2021 redistributed five of Parliament‚Äôs 63 seats. As a result, several candidates filed charges against election proceedings in the constituency. Evidence showed that the election supervision committee had failed to seal the votes after it had completed its initial count and had left them unattended, actions that constituted breaches of regulation. Police had fined election staff, who had refused to pay the fines. A preparatory Credentials Committee was subsequently established (later succeeded by the actual Credentials Committee¬†after parliament reconvened following a lengthy hiatus) to investigate these claims. Following weeks of discussions and a field trip to Hotel Borgarnes,¬†the committee submitted its findings to Parliament last November. The Parliament then voted to confirm the election results in all constituencies, putting an end to the matter ‚Äì except for the ongoing police investigation. West Iceland Police stated that the new election legislation that took effect this year is not sufficiently clear about the obligation to seal election data, though previous legislation had been. Therefore, the Police Commissioner considers there to be doubts about the criminality of the alleged violation.

headline: Iceland to Open Embassy in Warsaw This Autumn
body: An Icelandic embassy to Poland will be opened in the country‚Äôs capital Warsaw this autumn, Iceland‚Äôs Foreign Minister announced at a cabinet meeting last week. The embassy will also be responsible for servicing Lithuania, Ukraine, and Belarus. Polish nationals account for around 40% of all immigrants living in Iceland. ‚ÄúPolitical, economic, and cultural relations between Iceland and Poland have increased significantly in recent years,‚Äù a government notice on the new embassy reads. ‚ÄúAn ever-increasing number of Icelanders trace their origins to Poland. The countries‚Äô interests converge on important issues, such as security and defence. Increased communication between the two countries, not least due to the large number of Poles living in Iceland, has strengthened trade and cultural ties.‚Äù The Polish government has operated a consulate in Iceland since 2008, which became a full-fledged embassy in 2013. ‚ÄúWith the opening of the Icelandic Embassy in Warsaw, the necessary reciprocity in the political union of the states will finally be achieved, and it is gratifying to be able to take that step and emphasise how valuable the nations‚Äô friendship is to us Icelanders,‚Äù Foreign Minister √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n Reykfj√∂r√∞ Gylfad√≥ttir stated. ‚ÄúThe Polish Embassy in Reykjav√≠k has provided important services to the large group of Poles living in Iceland. In the same way, the Icelandic Embassy in Warsaw can provide services to Icelandic citizens and Poles with close ties to Iceland, and at the same time pave the way for Icelandic companies in these regions and safeguard Icelandic interests, for example in the EEA Development Fund.‚Äù Read more about Iceland‚Äôs Polish community here.

headline: Iceland‚Äôs First Lady Meets Jill Biden in Washington Today
body: Iceland‚Äôs First Lady Eliza Reid will be a guest at the White House in Washington today, where she will have a private meeting with First Lady of the United States Jill Biden. The occasion is a special event marking Equal Pay Day, a day meant to raise awareness of and help eradicate the gender pay gap. Eliza will also take part in the Taste of Iceland Festival in Washington later this week. Eliza is a fitting guest for Equal Pay Day, having recently published a book on gender equality and feminism in Iceland called Secrets of the Sprakkar, about ‚Äúa small island nation, the women who live there, and how they are changing the world,‚Äù according to the book‚Äôs subtitle. Eliza spoke to Iceland Review about feminism and the book in our latest issue.

headline: Directorate of Immigration Broke the Law by Withholding Citizenship Applications
body: Iceland‚Äôs Directorate of Immigration (√öTL) broke the law when it failed to hand over citizenship applications to Iceland‚Äôs Parliament last month, according to a legal opinion received by the Judicial Affairs and Education Committee, R√öV reports. MPs criticised the Minister of Justice for his handling of the issue in Al√æingi yesterday. One MP urged the Speaker of Parliament to follow up on the issue and ensure the documents were delivered to Al√æingi by the end of the week. Along with the standard process of applying for citizenship through the Directorate of Immigration, Icelandic law permits Al√æingi to grant citizenship by decree, which it normally¬†does twice a year. Unlike the standard process, the¬†Al√æingi route¬†is open to applicants who do not meet the conditions for the granting of Icelandic citizenship. Applicants who take this route must submit detailed arguments as to why Al√æingi should grant them an exemption from these requirements. Last December, Parliament could not process the applications submitted, as it never received¬†the necessary application data from √öTL. Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson, who oversees √öTL, defended the decision, stating that those who apply for citizenship via Al√æingi should not get to ‚Äújump the line‚Äù ahead of others. MP Helga Vala Helgad√≥ttir of the Social-Democratic Alliance stated that she was pleased that Al√æingi‚Äôs legal office had taken a clear stance on Al√æingi‚Äôs side in the issue. She added that this stance raised the question of how the Speaker of Al√æingi would follow up on the matter, and asked whether the Parliament would receive the necessary documents before the end of the week. Helga Vala stated that she had heard √öTL had rejected one of the applications in the group as the applicant had reached the age of 18 in the period of nearly one year that had passed since the application was submitted, without a ruling from √öTL. As a result, the basis of the application was no longer valid in the case.

headline: MP Demands Work Permits for Ukrainian Refugees
body: 107 refugees from Ukraine have applied for international protection in Iceland since Russia invaded the country, R√öV reports. Iceland‚Äôs Civil Protection and Emergency Response Department has increased its preparedness at the border to its alert phase, which enables authorities to open a dedicated response centre for refugees, if necessary. Iceland‚Äôs Minister of Justice has triggered an article of law to facilitate the reception of Ukrainian refugees, but the decision will limit their rights, one MP argues.
