Pirate Party MP √û√≥rhildur Sunna √Üvarsd√≥ttir criticised the government for its reception of Ukrainian refugees yesterday, particularly the Minister of Justice‚Äôs decision to trigger an article in Icelandic law providing temporary international protection in the event of mass exodus, which she argues gives refugees fewer rights than if the article had not been triggered. ‚ÄúThe government has decided that they get a residence permit for humanitarian reasons which, as I say, provides inferior legal protection, does not include a work permit, and means that they will have to depend on financial aid from municipalities and will have to somehow find housing on their own once they‚Äôve received this protection. This is a political decision and it does not show that our arms are particularly open, at least not for this year [that the residence permits are valid].‚Äù Icelandic authorities expect between 1,000-1,500 refugees from Ukraine to arrive in the country in the coming weeks.

headline: 76 Ukrainians Have Applied For Asylum in Iceland
body: Since Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine began on February 24, 76 Ukrainians have applied for asylum in Iceland, Border Division Police Chief J√≥n P√©tur J√≥nsson told MBL.is. However, an even higher number of Ukrainian nationals arriving in Iceland recently could indicate that many are exercising their right to reside in the country for up to three months before officially applying for protection. J√≥n P√©tur said border police could not rule out that scenario. He said authorities are considering increasing the preparedness level at the border to better handle the stress of arrivals from Ukraine on the immigration system. Iceland‚Äôs Social Affairs Minister Gu√∞mundur Ingi Gu√∞brandsson will appoint a special response team to coordinate the reception of refugees from Ukraine. ‚ÄúWe are looking holistically at the reception system, from the time an individual arrives in the country until they receive services,‚Äù J√≥n P√©tur said. ‚ÄúThe reception system is resetting itself now that Article 44 of the Foreign Nationals Act is active.‚Äù Article 44 of the Foreign Nationals Act provides for the collective protection of foreign nationals in the event of mass exodus. Justice Minister J√≥n Gunnarsson triggered the article¬†on March 3. Including the recent applicants from Ukraine, 320 individuals have applied for asylum in Iceland so far this year ‚Äî a seven-year high. ¬†

headline: Iceland Appoints Response Team to Assist Ukrainian Refugees
body: Up to 2,000 Ukrainian refugees might come to Iceland to apply for international protection, according to estimates from the country‚Äôs Refugee Committee. Iceland‚Äôs Social Affairs Minister Gu√∞mundur Ingi Gu√∞brandsson will appoint a special response team to coordinate the reception of refugees from Ukraine. Iceland‚Äôs Minister of Justice triggered Article 44 of the Foreign Nationals Act last week to provide immediate, though temporary, protection for Ukrainians fleeing as a result of the Russian invasion. One of the biggest challenges will be finding housing for the refugees, according to the chairman of Al√æingi‚Äôs Refugee Committee, Stef√°n Vagn Stef√°nsson. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs one of the big projects, to find housing for the people, and the problem is that we don‚Äôt know how much will be needed. Finding housing has gone better than we assumed it would. Private parties have contacted us and offered housing. That‚Äôs incredibly important and helps a lot. It‚Äôs also a cause for celebration that the Icelandic Confederation of Labour‚Äôs central committee encouraged labour unions to join the effort last week.‚Äù Stef√°n also expressed his hope that municipal authorities would help in finding housing. While there are currently three municipalities in the country with active government contracts for the reception and resettlement of refugees, he says more will have to be added in order for the project to be successful. A notice from the Icelandic government stated that an electronic portal would be set up as early as today where institutions and others could offer housing for refugees, both shorter and longer term.

headline: ‚ÄúEveryone Loses‚Äù in New Legal Assistance Scheme for Asylum Seekers
body: The Justice Ministry and Directorate of Immigration (√öTL)‚Äôs new legal assistance scheme for applicants for international protection will lead to higher costs, longer processing times, and inferior service, a lawyer at the Icelandic Red Cross has stated. Last month, the Justice Ministry decided not to renew its contract with the Red Cross, which had provided legal assistance to asylum seekers for nearly seven years. According to Red Cross lawyer Gu√∞r√≠√∞ur L√°ra √ûrastard√≥ttir, the new scheme laid out by √öTL is worse for asylum seekers, the government, and the lawyers providing the service. V√≠sir reported first. The Directorate of Immigration published an advertisement last week calling on applications from those who would provide legal assistance to applicants for international protection. In a post on Facebook, Gu√∞r√≠√∞ur stated that the scheme outlined in the advertisement is ‚Äúreally the same as scheme that was in place before the Icelandic Red Cross took over and was considered not good at all.‚Äù She adds that the hourly rate proposed for lawyers has only been raised by ISK 1,000 [$7.48; ‚Ç¨6.88] since 2014, and is ‚Äústill the lowest rate the state pays for lawyers‚Äô services.‚Äù According to Gu√∞r√≠√∞ur, the proposed maximum hours in the scheme ‚Äúdo not in any way reflect the reality, and the Red Cross, which has done this work for nearly 7 years was not contacted when this aforementioned maximum time was calculated.‚Äù The scheme also does not appear to take into account the cost of interpreting services, Gu√∞r√≠√∞ur stated. ‚ÄúThis is a sad turning point,‚Äù Gu√∞r√≠√∞ur wrote. ‚ÄúIn my opinion, this scheme will lead to worse quality, much higher costs, worse service, and longer case processing times. Everyone loses here.‚Äù The changes are implemented as asylum seeker applications reach a seven-year high in Iceland. Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson has stated that more changes to Immigration Law are in the works. The Red Cross and other human rights organisations have criticised a proposed amendment to the Immigration Act from the Minister.

headline: Capelin Quota to Be Increased by 50,000 Tonnes
body: Icelandic fishing companies are likely to be granted an additional quota of ca. 50,000 tonnes‚Äô worth of capelin, V√≠sir reports. The announcement comes as the most valuable phase of capelin season, the processing of roe, commences. As Norwegians vessels were unable to use the full extent of their capelin allowance in Iceland ‚Äì when their season on Icelandic waters concluded ‚Äì the Ministry of Food, Agriculture, and Fisheries is expected to reallocate the remainder of the quota among Icelandic vessels, V√≠sir reports. As reported by Mbl.is, the authorities rejected Norway‚Äôs request for an extension in February. This reallocation, which could comprise around 50,000 tonnes, could come into effect as early as today. If Icelandic vessels manage to fully utilise this additional quota, the value of the catch could be worth between two to three billion ISK (‚Ç¨14-21 million / $15-23 million). The announcement comes as the most valuable phase of the capelin season, the processing of roe, commences. Roe-processing is expected to be in full swing around the country, as companies race against time to catch as much capelin as possible before they spawn. As noted in Iceland Review last year, the Marine and Freshwater Research Institute of Iceland set its new advice for capelin catch quotas at 904,200 tonnes for the 2021/22 season. This quota is nearly sevenfold of last year‚Äôs quota and a dramatic shift from 2019 and 2020 when no capelin quota was issued at all.

headline: Special Article Triggered to Assist Ukrainian Refugees
body:
The Minister of Justice has decided to trigger article 44 of the Foreign Nationals Act in response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, R√öV reports. The article, activated for the first time in history, concerns the collective protection of foreign nationals in the event of mass exodus. Yesterday, the national ministers of EU member states agreed to provide special protection for Ukrainians in mass flight following the Russian invasion. Icelandic Minister of the Interior J√≥n Gunnarsson attended the meeting in Brussels and subsequently spoke to a reporter from R√öV. ‚ÄúEU member states decided to trigger the (temporary protection directive), involving the collective protection of individuals that are party to a mass exodus. There was great solidarity among the European ministers,‚Äù J√≥n Gunnarsson stated. ‚ÄúI have, therefore, decided to trigger article 44 of the Foreign Nationals Act, which concerns collective protection in a mass flight situation. This will expedite our reception of refugees.‚Äù Although Ukraine is not part of the passport-free Schengen Area, Ukrainian nationals are ‚Äúentitled to visa-free travel for up to 90 days.‚Äù¬†The triggering of the directive aims to offer a long-term solution in the event that the 90-day limit is exhausted. As noted on the website of the European Commission, temporary protection is an ‚Äúexceptional measure to provide immediate and temporary protection to displaced persons from non-EU countries and those unable to return to their country of origin.‚Äù The measure applies when the standard asylum system is at risk of not being able to cope with the demand stemming from a mass exodus. When asked if this meant that this would remove all uncertainty for Ukrainians fleeing the invasion ‚Äì as they would receive immediate protection without the delays that often accompany the standard processing of applications ‚Äì minister J√≥n Gunnarsson replied in the affirmative: ‚ÄúYes, on the basis of this legislation, they‚Äôll receive protection without going through the system. This is the first time that this article is triggered in Iceland. It‚Äôs a kind of historic moment. We have opened our borders to these people, and there are a few who have already arrived. This will simplify our work and make the process more efficient.‚Äù The minister‚Äôs decision will be introduced before Parliament today. ¬† (The first two paragraphs of article 44 on the Foreign Nationals Act: ‚ÄúIn a case of mass flight the Minister may decide to apply the provisions of this article. The Minister also decides when authorisation to provide collective protection under paras. 2 and 3 shall cease. A foreign national who is a member of a group which flees a specified region and arrives in Iceland, or is in Iceland when the provisions of the article are applied, may upon application for international protection be granted protection on the basis of a group assessment (collective protection). This entails that the foreign national will be granted a residence permit under art. 74. The permit cannot serve as basis for the issue of a
permanent residence permit.‚Äù)

headline: List of Candidates in Reykjav√≠k Elections Becoming Clearer
body: The list of candidates running for municipal elections in Reykjav√≠k this spring is gradually becoming clearer. Women are set to form the majority of party leaders. With two and a half months until municipal elections ‚Äì and just over a month until the nomination deadline ‚Äì it looks as if a minimum of nine candidates will be vying for the mayoral seat in Reykjav√≠k, R√öV reports. The Social Democratic Alliance and the Pirate Party have already introduced their list of candidates, with Mayor Dagur B. Eggertsson leading the former party and councillor D√≥ra Bj√∂rt Gu√∞j√≥nsd√≥ttir chairing the latter. Two primary elections will be held in Reykjav√≠k next week when the Left-Green Movement and the Reform Party will decide on their list of candidates. Three women will be vying for first place for the Left-Greens: meteorologist El√≠n Bj√∂rk J√≥nasd√≥ttir, councilwoman L√≠f Magneud√≥ttir, and substitute city councillor El√≠n Oddn√Ω Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir. √û√≥rd√≠s J√≥na Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir and √û√≥rd√≠s L√≥a √û√≥rhallsd√≥ttir will hope to lead the Reform Party The Progressive Party will be holding a constituency congress in Reykjav√≠k on March 10 to introduce its list of candidates. It is widely believed that former R√öV anchor and journalist Einar √ûorsteinsson will be leading the party. Handballer Bj√∂rgvin P√°ll G√∫stavsson has announced that he will not be seeking first place. Primary elections for the Independence Party in Reykjav√≠k will be held on March 18 and 19. A new leader will be elected given that Ey√æ√≥r Laxdal Arnalds has decided to step aside. Substitute councilwoman Ragnhildur Alda Mar√≠a Vilhj√°lmsd√≥ttir will be running against councilwoman Hildur Bj√∂rnsd√≥ttir for chair. The Centre Party will hold primary elections on March 26, where members will vote on its top three candidates. Councilwoman Vigd√≠s Hauksd√≥ttir will once again be running for chair. The People‚Äôs Party has not announced when it will reveal its list of candidates. It will not hold primary elections, and councilwoman Kolbr√∫n Baldursd√≥ttir intends to hold onto first place. The same holds for the Socialist Party, where councilwoman Sanna Magdalena M√∂rtud√≥ttir will lead the party. This means that women will be leading seven out of the nine parties running in the municipal elections. (Municipal elections will be held across the country on May 14, 2022. Both citizens of Iceland, as well as residents of Iceland who have lived in the country for five years or longer, can vote in municipal elections.)

headline: Iceland Prepares to Receive Refugees from Ukraine
body: Iceland will receive refugees from Ukraine, as other European countries are doing, stated the chairman of the Icelandic Parliament‚Äôs Refugee Committee. The Directorate of Immigration has removed Ukraine from its list of safe countries, making it possible for Ukrainians to apply for international protection in Iceland, and several dozens have already done so. Authorities have yet to determine how many refugees from the country will be accepted, but preparations to receive them are already underway. ‚ÄúWe have begun the preparations for the project but strongly emphasise monitoring and observing how European countries will assist the tremendous number of people that are now seeking refuge,‚Äù Stef√°n Vagn Stef√°nsson, chairman of the Refugee Committee, told V√≠sir. ‚ÄúWe will try to the best of our ability to be in step with what other European nations are doing. We have initiated dialogue with municipalities to try to find out how much housing is available in the country.‚Äù Stef√°n stated that a number of municipalities in Iceland had already declared that they would like to participate in the resettlement of refugees. He expects more municipalities to do so. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very gratifying to see the solidarity and the willingness from municipalities to take part in the project.‚Äù The committee has not yet determined how many refugees will be taken in from Ukraine. ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt give you a number because it doesn‚Äôt exist. We don‚Äôt have one yet. It‚Äôs very bad to give a number then not be able to honour it. The situation is such that this is very unlike the projects we have had so far,‚Äù Stef√°n stated. ‚ÄúThis is a European country and residents of Ukraine are free to come here and be here for 90 days. Ukraine has been taken off the Directorate of Immigration‚Äôs list of safe countries, so people can apply for international protection. That has already begun, some dozens have applied for it, so the project has begun in some respect.‚Äù The Committee‚Äôs next meeting is scheduled for Friday.

headline: Housing Shortage Won‚Äôt Prohibit Iceland Receiving Ukrainian Refugees
body: Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir said Monday that issues surrounding the Directorate of Immigration‚Äôs housing facilities will not deter or delay Iceland‚Äôs reception of refugees from Ukraine, and preparations are already underway, V√≠sir reports. Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson told V√≠sir last week that ‚Äúthere is a real state of emergency at the Directorate of Immigration (√öTL),‚Äù exacerbated by the unwillingness of asylum seekers in Iceland to undergo PCR testing required as a condition of their deportation from the country. He said the Directorate‚Äôs difficulties in carrying out deportations of some refugees is resulting in less housing and fewer facilities available to welcome other refugees that the government is willing to welcome During question period in Al√æingi Monday, Social Democratic Alliance MP Helga Vala Helgad√≥ttir called the Minister of Justice‚Äôs comments unacceptable and asked the Prime Minister if they were reflective of the government‚Äôs policy. Katr√≠n replied that many people are in very vulnerable positions and it matters how those groups are talked about. Furthermore, she said the status of √öTL‚Äôs housing will not hinder Iceland‚Äôs reception of Ukrainian refugees. Katr√≠n noted that the Minister of Social Affairs had already met with the Refugee Committee and preparations had already begun to receive them. The Prime Minister reminded Al√æingi that half a million Ukrainians have already fled the country since the Russian armed forces began their invasion on Feb. 24, and that figure could increase to four to five million. She said a large proportion of those who have fled will likely want to return to their home country when the situation allows, so both short- and long-term arrangements need to be considered. ‚ÄúI would like to note that it is not long since the situation deteriorated in Afghanistan and the Icelandic government initially decided to receive a certain number of people and then decided to receive a larger number of Afghan refugees because we felt it was important to take responsibility for the global community. In relative terms, we actually welcomed more people than other Nordic countries did on that occasion. So when we look at what has previously been done, we have not shied away from taking responsibility,‚Äù Katr√≠n said.

headline: Iceland Closes Airspace to Russia
body: The Icelandic government has decided to close its airspace to Russian aircraft. R√öV reports that Minister of Foreign Affairs √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n Reykfj√∂r√∞ Gylfad√≥ttir announced the decision via Twitter on Sunday morning, ‚Äúin solidarity with Ukraine.‚Äù Iceland has decided to close its airspace to Russian air traffic, in solidarity with #Ukraine üáÆüá∏ üá∫üá¶ ‚Äî √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n Reykfj√∂r√∞ Gylfad√≥ttir (@thordiskolbrun) February 27, 2022  Iceland was one of several Nordic countries to close its airspace to Russia over the weekend; Denmark, Sweden, and Finland announced that they would be doing the same on Sunday. Britain, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, and Romania have also closed their airspace to Russia and Germany has announced its intention to do so as well. It‚Äôs expected that Russia will face a total EU airspace ban shortly. Iceland condemns Russia‚Äôs ‚Äòbrutal and unprovoked attack‚Äô on Ukraine, sends ‚Ç¨1 million in aid √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n has made a number of public statements condemning Russia‚Äôs assault on Ukraine in recent days. On February 24, the first day of Russia‚Äôs invasion, √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n gave an official statement, stating that Iceland condemned ‚Äúin the strongest possible terms, the brutal and unprovoked attack of Russia on Ukraine.‚Äù She continued: ‚ÄúRussia‚Äôs action is a flagrant violation of international law, including the Charter of the United Nations, and is in full contradiction to the Helsinki Final Act.‚Äù That same day, she tweeted that Iceland would be sending ‚Ç¨1 million [ISK 141.19 million; USD 1.13 million] in humanitarian support to Ukraine. Our thoughts are with the Ukranian people who are under attack. We stand by our allies in strongly condemning Russia's illegal aggression. We will partake in sanctions and I have announced today that Iceland will provide EUR 1 million to humanitarian support in Ukraine. ‚Äî √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n Reykfj√∂r√∞ Gylfad√≥ttir (@thordiskolbrun) February 24, 2022  The next day, she urged the Council of Europe to suspend ‚ÄúRussia‚Äôs right of representation in the Council of Europe with immediate effect.‚Äù  According to information from the Foreign Ministry, Iceland will also be revoking special privileges that have been afforded Russians coming to Iceland via existing bilateral agreements, such as simplified visa processing for Russian diplomats, businesspeople, politicians, and government representatives. The ministry has emphasized, however, that these moves are ‚Äúnot directed at general Russian tourists, students, or others,‚Äù whose visa applications will continue to be reviewed as per usual. Iceland‚Äôs airspace patrolled by NATO Iceland‚Äôs airspace is patrolled by NATO as part of an ongoing mission, called Icelandic Air Policing, which is meant ‚Äúto establish air surveillance and interception coverage over Iceland and maintain the integrity of NATO airspace.‚Äù NATO members maintain a periodic presence of fighter aircraft from the former US military base at Keflav√≠k. Icelandic Air Policing typically involves member nations deploying fighter aircraft to patrol Iceland‚Äôs airspace three times a year, for periods of three to four weeks at a time.

headline: Protesters, Authorities Voice Support for Ukraine
body: Approximately 300 people gathered outside the Russian Embassy yesterday to protest Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine. Additional protests have been scheduled outside the embassy for Sunday. The Icelandic government strongly condemned Russia‚Äôs attack yesterday and iterated its support for Ukraine. Following news of the invasion of Ukraine yesterday, Russian journalist Andrei Menshenin organised a protest outside the Russian Embassy in Reykjav√≠k. Approximately 300 people were in attendance. Speaking to Morgunbla√∞i√∞ before the rally, Andrei stated he knew he spoke for many Russians when he said he was ‚Äúdevastated‚Äù by news of the invasion. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been in contact with my colleagues worldwide today, and they have the same story to tell,‚Äù Andrei remarked. ‚ÄúEveryone is devastated by this course of events and very saddened. Many Russians have posted a black profile picture on social media today to try to express how they feel and to show that they do not at all support this attack by Putin.‚Äù Further protests of the invasion have been scheduled for Sunday. As noted on a Facebook-page for the event ‚Äì organised by Inga Minelgaite, professor at the University of Iceland‚Äôs School of Business: ‚ÄúThere is no excuse for war in 2022. Standing up for peace is (the) responsibility of (each and) every (one) of us. Let‚Äôs meet for a peaceful protest to express our support to Ukraine and the Ukrainian people.‚Äù Protesters are encouraged to light candles and flashlights and display the colours of the Ukrainian flag in a show of solidarity. In a statement yesterday, the offices of the Prime Minister and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs strongly condemned Russia‚Äôs attack on Ukraine. Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir called on Russia to cease its military action and declared that the invasion was ‚Äúa serious violation of international law.‚Äù Minister of Foreign Affairs √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n Reykfj√∂r√∞ Gylfad√≥ttir iterated the government‚Äôs unwavering support for Ukraine: ‚ÄúIceland will continue its support for Ukraine, by taking full part in international sanctions. Iceland will respond to humanitarian needs by providing EUR 1 million for humanitarian support in Ukraine. This is in addition to a EUR 200,000 contribution to NATO‚Äôs Trust Fund for (the) Ukraine Professional Development Programme.‚Äù As noted in the press release, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs summoned the Russian Ambassador to emphasise Iceland‚Äôs position. The Ministry‚Äôs consular services were also in contact with 28 individuals in Ukraine, including 16 Icelandic nationals, stating that it would continue to ‚Äúwork closely‚Äù with the consular services of other Nordic countries.

headline: Iceland Lifts All COVID-19 Restrictions
body: All COVID-19 social restrictions have been lifted as of midnight today. Individuals who test positive for the coronavirus will no longer be required to quarantine, and no disease prevention measures will be in place at the border. Nearly two years after imposing the first social restrictions due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Icelandic authorities have lifted all limitations on public gatherings. Rapid tests will replace PCR tests, and individuals who test positive for COVID-19 will no longer be required to quarantine. According to a statement by Minister of Health Willum √û√≥r √û√≥rsson on Wednesday, the decision to lift social restrictions was unanimous among ministers ‚Äì and in line with the most recent memorandum of Chief Epidemiologist √û√≥r√≥lfur Gu√∞nason. The memo noted that severe illness has not increased over the past few weeks ‚Äì despite over 2,000 infections being recorded daily. √û√≥r√≥lfur believes that the best way to end the pandemic is widespread herd immunity against the virus (ca. 80% of the population is expected to have become infected by mid-March). Approximately 110,000 individuals have been diagnosed with COVID-19 in Iceland. Antibody testing suggests, however, that an equal number of people have already been infected without testing positive. Sixty one individuals have died from COVID-19 in Iceland since the start of the pandemic. ‚ÄúWe can truly rejoice at this turning-point, but I encourage people to be careful, to practice personal infection prevention measures, and not to interact with others if they notice symptoms,‚Äù the Minister of Health stated on Wednesday. Among those who will be celebrating the lifting of restrictions are bar owners, who may now resume normal operations for the first time since July. The nightlife in downtown Reykjav√≠k is expected to be especially busy this weekend. The National University Hospital warns of an increased strain on its operations and encourages partygoers to exercise caution. As noted by meteorologist Haraldur √ìlafsson in an interview with V√≠sir, today‚Äôs forecast is less than ideal. An orange weather alert will be in effect for the capital area between 11 AM and 5 PM. Wind speed is expected to reach up to 25 m/s with sleet and rain. The storm will have mostly subsided by the evening.

headline: Iceland to Take Part in Sanctions Against Russia, Ministers Say
body: Iceland‚Äôs Prime Minister, Foreign Minister, and President publicly condemned Russian military action in Ukraine this morning. Al√æingi, Iceland‚Äôs Parliament, discussed the development during question period today, when opposition MP Helga Vala Helgad√≥ttir urged the Justice Minister to declare Ukraine an unsafe country and accept refugees from the country in Iceland. Foreign Minister √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n Reykfj√∂r√∞ Gylfad√≥ttir stated Iceland would take ‚Äúfull part in international sanctions‚Äù on Russia. Iceland‚Äôs National Security Council will meet today to discuss the Russian attack on Ukraine, R√öV reports. The meeting was scheduled prior to the attack launched by Russia last night. Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir stated that the most pessimistic predictions of events in Russia and Ukraine have come to pass. ‚ÄúThe Icelandic government and I condemn this attack, of course. This is a serious breach of international law and truly looks as if the worst predictions in this matter have come to pass,‚Äù Katr√≠n stated. Asked about Icelandic authorities‚Äô response, she stated that Iceland would collaborate with its allies and NATO, of which it is a founding member. √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n was asked whether authorities would consider deporting Russia‚Äôs ambassador to Iceland. ‚ÄúWe called him to a meeting here yesterday and reviewed our case. Now the priority is really to support what needs to be supported within NATO, monitor closely and review what is happening.¬† As for the Russian embassy here, it will remain to be seen,‚Äù √û√≥rd√≠s stated. The Russian Embassy to Iceland criticised statements from the President of Iceland and the Minister of Foreign Affairs expressing support in Ukraine‚Äôs territorial integrity earlier this month, calling them ‚Äúone-sided‚Äù and ‚Äúsubjective.‚Äù During the Icelandic Parliament‚Äôs question period this morning, opposition MP Helga Vala Helgad√≥ttir urged Justice Minister J√≥n Gunnarsson to declare Ukraine an unsafe country today and ease the arrival of refugees from the country. The Minister answered that the issue ‚Äúshould be reviewed‚Äù at this point, but made no firm declarations, Kjarninn reports. J√≥n‚Äôs recent actions concerning asylum seekers, including proposed amendments to the Immigration Act, have been criticised by human rights organisations and medical professionals in Iceland.

headline: Icelandic Officials Express Support for Ukraine
body: Iceland‚Äôs Prime Minister, Foreign Minister, and President have expressed their support for Ukraine and called on Russia to de-escalate its military advance into the country. Minister for Foreign Affairs √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n Reykfj√∂r√∞ Gylfad√≥ttir met with the UK-led Joint Expeditionary Force (JEF) yesterday, who issued a statement on the matter. The Icelandic government considers Russia‚Äôs actions to be a breach of international law, Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir stated in an interview with R√öV. ‚ÄúThe Icelandic government‚Äôs stance is completely clear. We consider this to be a breach of international law,‚Äù the Prime Minister stated. ‚ÄúThis concerns the border of an independent state and not only have the Russians recognised the independence of these two regions but moreover sent troops over the border which is, of course, a very serious situation.‚Äù Katr√≠n added that she hoped the current situation would not lead to conflict, and that ‚Äúall diplomatic paths would be pursued as far as possible.‚Äù The Prime Minister tweeted along similar lines yesterday, writing that ‚ÄúEscalation and armed conflict is not the solution to current challenges. The door for diplomacy must remain open.‚Äù Iceland‚Äôs President Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson retweeted Katr√≠n‚Äôs statement, adding: ‚ÄúA clear stance by the government of Iceland. Respect for international law is paramount, recourse to violence unacceptable.‚Äù Iceland‚Äôs Minister for Foreign Affairs met with the Partner Nations of the Joint Expeditionary Force (JEF) yesterday, who issued a statement calling out Russia for breaking international law and reiterating their support for Ukraine and its sovereignty. ‚ÄúWe call on Russia to deescalate and encourage them to engage in transparent dialogue, including through the OSCE and the NATO-Russia Council, in order to reduce tensions,‚Äù the statement reads, in part.

headline: Iceland‚Äôs Proposed Legislation Contradicts Code of Ethics, Doctors Say
body: ¬†Doctors in Iceland will be forced to choose between obeying the law or obeying their international code of ethics if the government passes its proposed amendments to the Immigration Act, the chairperson of the Icelandic Medical Association stated in an interview with R√öV. The proposed legislation would grant Icelandic police the authority to force physical examinations on asylum seekers. The legislation was introduced by Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson and has been criticised by human rights organisations in Iceland. ‚ÄúIn this 19th article, as it is worded, the police are given very broad powers to force people to undergo various interventions: testing, physical examination, and more. And also to hand over medical records, which are sensitive, confidential information. This completely contradicts doctors‚Äô code of ethics,‚Äù Steinunn √û√≥r√∞ard√≥ttir, chair of the Icelandic Medical Association stated. ‚ÄúThe World Medical Association‚Äôs Declaration of Geneva [the modern-day Hippocratic Oath] reads as follows: the health and well-being of my patient will be my first consideration. We wonder how these two things can go together and actually see it as a complete impossibility. If this becomes law, we are put in the position of having to choose between complying with national law or the international code of ethics for doctors,‚Äù Steinunn remarked. The Association‚Äôs formal comments on the proposed legislation strongly criticise the proposed changes. ‚ÄúIf a foreigner that is set to be deported is forced to undergo such examination, it can be assumed the person is opposed to being deported. Individuals in this position tend to have complex issues, often due to post-traumatic stress, and are being deported back to situations where they consider their life and health to be at risk. By issuing the aforementioned certificate, a doctor would need to consider that such deportation from the country would be in the best interest of the person in question, according to the aforementioned code of ethics,‚Äù the comments read. The comments continue: ‚ÄúRespect for the patient and mutual trust are the basis of medical practice. An action such as [forcing physical examination] works against patients‚Äô interests and human rights, and we consider it to be in conflict with the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights.‚Äù

headline: Consolidation and Control of Quota Permits Under Scrutiny
body: Minister Svand√≠s Svavarsd√≥ttir has instructed the Directorate of Fisheries to increase its supervision of quota permits. The Minister has also proposed a bill to grant the Directorate of Fisheries greater authority. These measures aim to prevent the consolidation of quota permits and deter non-compliance with laws and regulations within the fishing industry. Ever since Blackport (Verb√∫√∞in) premiered on R√öV in late December, the TV series has inspired nostalgia for the ‚Äô80s while also training the spotlight on the Icelandic fishing industry. The series, whose season finale premiered last Sunday, revolves partly around the transferable quota system, which was introduced in 1984 and allocated Iceland‚Äôs fishing allowance among fishermen-cum-boat-owners. Last Wednesday, Blackport served as a segue into proposed amendments to the supervision of the quota system in a conversation between Minister of Food, Fisheries, and Agriculture, Svand√≠s Svavarsd√≥ttir, and journalist Sigmundur Ernir R√∫narsson on the news programme Fr√©ttavaktin on Hringbraut. Svand√≠s observed that Blackport was an ‚Äúexcellent‚Äù series that had inspired Icelandic society to reflect back upon that ‚Äúdangerous cocktail of business and politics,‚Äù noting that the temptation of corruption remained a real possibility. Later in the conversation, Svand√≠s discussed what she felt were necessary changes to the quota system ‚Äì changes publicised in a press release on the government‚Äôs website yesterday. As noted in the press release, Svand√≠s Svavarsd√≥ttir has entrusted the Directorate of Fisheries to investigate the consolidation and control of quota permits by associated parties within the Icelandic fishing industry. In her instruction to the Directorate, the Minister emphasised that the institution conduct a systematic investigation of the control of quota permits by associated parties and that it inform the Ministry of its findings at regular intervals. The Minister‚Äôs instructions are founded on two reports: a task-force report on the increased supervision of fishery resources, on the one hand, and a report by the auditor general from 2018 on the Fisheries Management Act, on the other hand. (Article 13 of the Fisheries Management Act defines the allowable quota share of individual and associated parties.) The Minister has also proposed a bill to amend specific laws within fisheries management, which the cabinet has approved for discussion before Parliament. The aim of the new legislation, which will grant the Directorate of Fisheries greater authority, is more efficient supervision to deter non-compliance with laws and regulations applicable to the management of fishing quotas. As noted in a press release from the Ministry: ‚ÄúThe government must possess a clear overview of the control and consolidation of quota permits by associated parties in the industry. The systematic management of the Directorate of Fisheries is essential in this regard, and supervision must be improved. Furthermore, changes to the legal definition of ‚Äúassociated parties‚Äù in applicable laws are needed so that it is clear when two parties are considered ‚Äúassociated.‚Äù With these instructions and this parliamentary bill, the first steps are taken to make the necessary amendments in the supervision of the fisheries management system. Efficient supervision on behalf of the government is one of the conditions for engendering trust among the public in the management of the collective natural resource,‚Äù Minister Svand√≠s Svavarsd√≥ttir wrote. According to an article in Kjarninn published yesterday, the ten largest fishing companies in Iceland controlled 53% of the allocated quota in 2020; in November of last year, the aforementioned share had risen to 67%. Parallel to these developments, the profits of fishing companies have increased significantly, with less than 30% of profits being collected by the Icelandic government in the form of income tax, payroll tax, and fishing fees, while 70% of profits settled in the coffers of fishing companies. (This article was updated at 7.36 on February 19, 2022)

headline: Russian Embassy Criticises Foreign Minister‚Äôs, President‚Äôs Tweets
body: The Russian Embassy in Reykjav√≠k has expressed disappointment in Tweets authored by the President of Iceland and the Minister of Foreign Affairs. The Embassy has called the Tweets, which declare support for Ukraine‚Äôs territorial integrity, ‚Äúone-sided‚Äù and ‚Äúsubjective.‚Äù On February 15, Minister of Foreign Affairs √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n Reykfj√∂r√∞ Gylfad√≥ttir took to Twitter to encourage Russia to ‚Äúdeescalate‚Äù and ‚Äúrespect the sovereignty and territorial integrity‚Äù of Ukraine. The Tweets followed the Minister‚Äôs meeting with Secretary-General of NATO Jens Stoltenberg, in which the pair discussed ‚Äúthe serious security situation in Europe.‚Äù President Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson retweeted the Minister‚Äôs message a day later, extending a greeting to President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and the people of Ukraine on the newly declared Unity Day: ‚ÄúIceland is united with (its) NATO Allies to call on Russia to deescalate and respect the sovereignty & territorial integrity of Ukraine.‚Äù As Ukraine observes a Day of Unity on February 16, I send my greetings to President @ZelenskyyUa and all the people of üá∫üá¶ Iceland is united with @NATO Allies to call on Russia to deescalate and respect the sovereignty & territorial integrity of Ukraine‚§µÔ∏è https://t.co/ZcRhti1Z2r ‚Äî President of Iceland (@PresidentISL) February 16, 2022  Yesterday, the Russian Embassy in Reykjav√≠k responded to the President‚Äôs and Minister‚Äôs Tweets, saying that it had been ‚Äúdeeply disappointed with Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs one-sided and subjective comprehension of the real situation in the region.‚Äù The Embassy holds that the escalation at the Ukrainian border is to be traced to the failure of Ukrainian authorities to comply with the Minsk II agreement ‚Äì which has proven difficult to implement, owing in no small part to profound differences in interpretation between Moscow and Kyiv ‚Äì and the ‚Äúactive participation‚Äù of Western countries in the militarisation of Ukraine. The Embassy called on Iceland to take a ‚Äúmore balanced and constructive approach‚Äù towards matters of European security. ‚ùóÔ∏è Comment by the Russian Embassy in Iceland on the statements of Icelandic officials @thordiskolbrun @PresidentISL on Ukraine. üí¨ We are deeply disappointed with Reykjavik‚Äôs one-sided and subjective comprehension of the real situation in the region. https://t.co/9PVKUZw2jU pic.twitter.com/kQTB7OGmxa ‚Äî RusEmbassy Iceland (@RusEmb_Iceland) February 17, 2022  Tensions have been growing between Ukraine and Russia over the past few weeks. According to the US, Russia is believed to have amassed approximately 150,000 troops near the Ukrainian border, demanding that Ukraine be permanently denied membership to NATO and that NATO remove all soldiers and weapons from Eastern Europe. NATO has rejected these demands on the grounds of the principle of self-determination. US President Biden stated yesterday that it was ‚Äúhighly likely‚Äù that Russia would invade Ukraine in the coming days; the Russian authorities have denied that they harbour any such plans. (This article was updated at 9.40 AM)

headline: Arming Police With Tasers Under Consideration
body: Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson will meet with the National Federation of Icelandic Police (Landssamband l√∂greglumanna) and police commissioners to discuss the possibility of arming Icelandic police with tasers, R√öV reports. The Federation says tasers would not be useful in situations where the attacker is armed with a firearm. If tasers were introduced into the force, it would be according to strict regulations, the Minister stated. Two shootings occurred in Reykjav√≠k this month, just days apart, sparking a conversation about whether Icelandic Police‚Äôs standard equipment of pepper spray and clubs is sufficient. Research shows that police officers, the government, and the general public are all of the opinion that firearms are not necessary for police. Still, the number of police cases involving weapons (both knifes and guns) has increased in recent years, leading the force to reconsider what should be included in standard equipment. The National Federation of Icelandic Police stated in a press release that the discussion surrounding tasers is not directly linked to the two shootings, and that tasers would not be used in situations where attackers are armed with firearms. ‚ÄúHowever, such equipment must be investigated thoroughly to ensure police officers‚Äô safety, but it should be borne in mind that such equipment will not be used when firearms are used,‚Äù the press release reads. Read More: Two Shootings Cause Concern Among Reykjav√≠k Residents ‚ÄúThis development is alarming and something we do not want to see continue. We want to try and put an end to this in our society. We enjoy a lot of security here in Iceland and we want to ensure that residents are safe. At the same time, we must ensure that police can respond appropriately, protect themselves and residents,‚Äù the Minister of Justice stated in a radio interview this morning. ‚ÄúWe want to try and put an end to this in our society. We enjoy a lot of security here in Iceland and we want to ensure that residents are safe. At the same time, we must ensure that police can respond appropriately, protect themselves and residents. We are considering whether it might be appropriate to take the step of introducing these electric weapons, which have been used a lot abroad. Including in neighbouring countries.‚Äù The Minister stated that tasers would help police officers avoid conflicts involving clubs, which are more likely to cause physical injury in arrests, according to some studies. The call to consider the use of tasers has come from the ranks of police, according to J√≥n. ‚ÄúI hear that and I am listening. I‚Äôm going to meet with them and afterwards, we will decide whether we take that step. And then we will do that according to very strict regulations.‚Äù

headline: Legal Services for Asylum Seekers Up in the Air
body: All 15 lawyers working for the Icelandic Red Cross were laid off after the Justice Ministry decided not to renew its contract with the organisation ensuring legal assistance to asylum seekers, V√≠sir reports. Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson has stated that many changes to services for foreigners in Iceland are in the works. No decision has been made on how such services will be provided after the contract expires on April 30. The Icelandic Red Cross lawyers currently provide legal assistance and advocacy services for applicants for international protection in Iceland under the provisions of the contract with the Ministry of Justice. The services are intended to ensure that applicants‚Äô cases ‚Äúreceive just and careful treatment,‚Äù according to the Red Cross website. Gu√∞r√≠√∞ur L√°ra √ûrastard√≥ttir, one of the Red Cross‚Äô lawyers and leader of the organisation‚Äôs team on the issues of applicants for international protection, confirmed that the Justice Ministry has decided not to extend the contract past April 30. Gu√∞r√≠√∞ur stated she did not know the Ministry‚Äôs plans for providing such services after that date and stated that any future involvement of the Red Cross would depend on contract stipulations. While the Minister of Justice stated that no decision has been made on whether the services will be put out to tender, Gu√∞r√≠√∞ur L√°ra stated that the Red Cross was informed a tender would be launched. She stated the Red Cross would participate ‚Äúif we possibly can.‚Äù The Minister of Justice stated that major changes are in the works in services connected to foreigners in Iceland, which is the reason the Ministry decided not to extend the contract. ‚ÄúPart of the projects in this contract are moving to another ministry. [The Red Cross] has both provided social services for asylum seekers, which now goes elsewhere, to the Ministry of Social Affairs, and also the advocacy services, which we are responsible for. So it was decided to reconsider the approach now.‚Äù The Ministry recently reintroduced a bill that proposes amendments to immigration law, which has received criticism from human rights organisations, including the Red Cross. Members of Parliament have also levelled criticism at the Ministry of Justice for its recent decision to withhold citizenship applications from Parliament.

headline: Human Rights Organisations Criticise Immigration Bill
body: Several human rights organisations, including the Icelandic Red Cross, Unicef Iceland, and the Icelandic Women‚Äôs Rights Association, have submitted formal letters criticising an immigration bill that was recently introduced in Parliament for the fourth time. Activist Sema Erla Serdar of the humanitarian aid organisation Solaris states the bill is ‚Äúa manifestation of systemic racism in Iceland‚Äù that aims to ‚Äúgrant protection to as few refugees as possible.‚Äù The bill in question was originally drafted in the Ministry of Justice and first introduced in Al√æingi, Iceland‚Äôs parliament, in 2018, but was not passed at that time. It has been criticised by human rights organisations each time it has been introduced. ‚ÄúThis is an attempt by the government to establish a policy that involves significantly constricting refugees, curtailing their human rights, and reducing their possibilities for receiving protection in Iceland,‚Äù Sema Erla Tweeted. ‚ÄúThe bill especially targets children and other people in a particularly vulnerable situation.‚Äù The bill proposes several changes to Iceland‚Äôs current legislation governing asylum seekers, including granting police the authority to force physical examinations of asylum seekers. ‚ÄúThis is a major encroachment of people‚Äôs privacy that does not conform with the law, Iceland‚Äôs constitution, or the Icelandic government‚Äôs international commitments,‚Äù Sema wrote. Along with the above-mentioned organisations, several others have submitted comments on the bill, including No Borders Iceland, the Icelandic division of Amnesty International, the Icelandic Confederation of Labour, the Teachers‚Äô Association of Iceland, and more. In their criticism of the bill, No Borders Iceland point out that the demographic that would be most impacted by the proposed changes does not have the opportunity to read them, as most asylum seekers do not read Icelandic, the only language in which the draft bill has been published. The bill also proposes that the rights of asylum seekers to basic services in Iceland would expire 30 days after a final refusal of international protection is published in their case. The Red Cross criticised this proposal, in particular, stating that it would put asylum seekers in Iceland at increased risk of abuse, human trafficking, and violence. This in turn would increase the burden on police and municipalities, the Red Cross statement asserts. In 2021, Iceland‚Äôs Directorate of Immigration withdrew housing and food allowances from a group of asylum seekers for refusing to undergo COVID-19 testing, a prerequisite for their deportation. The action was later ruled to be illegal.

headline: President Biden Nominates New US Ambassador to Iceland
body: US President Joe Biden has nominated Carrin Patman to be the United States‚Äô ambassador to Iceland, R√öV reports. Patman is a former trial lawyer, currently serves as the chair of the Metropolitan Transit Authority of Harris County, Texas, and was a major donor to Biden‚Äôs presidential campaign. The US‚Äô last three ambassadors to Iceland have all been political appointees and fundraisers for the presidents who have nominated them. Prior to this, Robert C. Barber was appointed by President Barack Obama and Jeffrey Ross Gunter was appointed by President Donald Trump. Over the last few decades, US presidents have generally given the country‚Äôs more comfortable ambassadorial seats to political supporters, says Silja B√°ra √ìmarsd√≥ttir, professor of political science at the University of Iceland. The president‚Äôs ambassadorial nominations must be approved by the senate. ‚ÄúToday, they look at this as something of a sinecure,‚Äù she continued, saying that the opposition party tends to approve political appointees as a sort of quid pro quo. It‚Äôs a system that politicians seem largely satisfied with, but among ‚Äúthose who work within the foreign service and have worked their way up, there‚Äôs a fair amount of criticism,‚Äù said Silja B√°ra, ‚Äúand of course within watchdog organizations as well.‚Äù Critics argue that ‚Äúyou can buy an ambassadorship.‚Äù President Biden has now nominated around 90 ambassadors, 60-70% of whom could be considered political appointees.

headline: Calls on the Banks to ‚ÄúLighten the Load‚Äù of Households
body: The Minister of Culture and Commerce has called on the banks to ‚Äúlighten the load‚Äù of households faced with rising interest rates. The net profit of Iceland‚Äôs three largest commercial banks amounted to approximately 80 billion ISK ($643 million / ‚Ç¨564 million) last year, V√≠sir reports. In an interview published in Morgunbla√∞i√∞ yesterday, Lilja D√∂gg Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir, Minister of Culture and Commerce, called on Iceland‚Äôs three largest commercial banks to ‚Äúlighten the load‚Äù of families faced with rising interest rates. The Central Bank raised key interest rates by 0.75% on Wednesday, which may strain the finances of households who have signed non-indexed mortgages. The inflation rate in January was 5.7% ‚Äì the highest since April of 2012 ‚Äì and the Central Bank predicts an inflation rate of +5% in 2022 (+5.8% in the first quarter), which is double the Bank‚Äôs target. According to Lilja, the three commercial banks have recently reaped ‚Äúsuper profits‚Äù ‚Äì a total of ISK 80 billion ($643 million / ‚Ç¨564 million) last year ‚Äì which puts them in a prime position to assist young people and low-income families. √çslandsbanki announced 2021 profits amounting to ISK 23.7 billion ($190 million / ‚Ç¨116 million) this week. Landsbanki, 95% owned by the government, had previously declared profits of ISK 28.9 billion ($232 million / ‚Ç¨204 million) for 2021, and Arion Bank announced a profit of ISK 28.6 billion ($230 million / ‚Ç¨202 million) for 2021. Speaking to Morgunbla√∞i√∞, Lilja invoked the banks‚Äô ‚Äúcivic duty.‚Äù ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs imperative that certain households, especially that of young people and low-income families, are not left holding the bag. It would be better for the banks to intervene immediately and tend to these households. If the banks don‚Äôt find a solution, I believe that we should reinstate a levy on banks.‚Äù Lilja followed up her comments by referring to a levy imposed by former British PM Margaret Thatcher, which sought to harvest around ¬£400m from the banks, for they were seen to be ‚Äúescaping the pain of that recession‚Äù: ‚ÄúIn 1981, Thatcher instated windfall taxes to deal with precisely such conditions, to level the playing field among the citizenry,‚Äù Lilja remarked. In an article published on Innherji this morning, Gu√∞r√∫n Hafsteinsd√≥ttir, Chair of the Economic and Finance Committee, stated that forcing the banks to spend a portion of their profits to subsidize interest payments would serve to devalue √çslandsbanki shares (the government has yet to sell 65% of its share in the bank). Asked to respond to Lilja‚Äôs comments, Gu√∞r√∫n remarked that they had taken her by surprise. ‚ÄúIf the government intends to alter the banks‚Äô operational conditions, such a thing must, one way or another, influence the price of the remaining shares in √çslandsbanki. It‚Äôs obvious that if the government, as a shareholder, intervenes in such an encumbering manner, the selling price will be affected.‚Äù As noted by Innherji, the government expects to sell its remaining 65% of shares this year and the next. The treasury received ISK 55 billion ($442 million / ‚Ç¨388 million) when it sold its 35% share in a stock offering of √çslandsbanki last year. Since then, stocks have risen considerably. Innherji estimates that, according to the current market valuation, the government stands to receive up to ISK 160 billion ($1.3 billion / ‚Ç¨1.1 billion) for its remaining shares.

headline: Justice Minister Defends Withholding of Citizenship Applications
body: Receiving Icelandic citizenship through an act of Parliament should be the exception, but it appears to be the rule, Justice Minister J√≥n Gunnarsson argued in committee today. MPs have criticised the Minister and the Directorate of Immigration for refusing to hand over applications for citizenship that Al√æingi, Iceland‚Äôs Parliament, was scheduled to process last December. J√≥n stated that those who apply for citizenship via Al√æingi should not get to ‚Äújump the line‚Äù ahead of others, R√öV reports. Along with the standard process of applying for citizenship through the Directorate of Immigration, Icelandic law permits Al√æingi to grant citizenship by decree, which it normally does twice a year. Unlike the standard process, the Al√æingi route is open to applicants who do not meet the conditions for the granting of Icelandic citizenship. Applicants who take this route must submit detailed arguments as to why Al√æingi should grant them an exemption from these requirements. Read More: Citizenship Applications Withheld from Parliament In an address before the Judicial Affairs and Education Committee this morning, the Minister of Justice stressed that citizenship applications should be treated equally regardless of how they are submitted. He criticised that applications submitted through Al√æingi ‚Äújump the line‚Äù ahead of others, asserting that there is nothing in Icelandic law that requires those applications to be processed first. J√≥n stated that the processing time for citizenship applications (submitted through the standard process) had been shortened from 18 months to six, and authorities would work to process dozens of applications in the coming days.

headline: Opposition Abstains from Voting on ‚ÄúM√≠la Bill‚Äù
body: Iceland‚Äôs Parliament passed the so-called ‚ÄúMila bill‚Äù today with 33 votes in favour, R√öV reports. Fifteen MPs abstained from voting, all members of the opposition. The bill is intended to ensure national security in light of the sale of Iceland‚Äôs telecommunications company M√≠la to French fund management company Ardian. M√≠la, which owns and operates nationwide telecommunications systems, was sold to Ardian last year. All of Iceland‚Äôs homes, businesses, and institutions are serviced by M√≠la‚Äôs systems, and many expressed concern that such important infrastructure was being sold to a foreign company. Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir has called telecommunications infrastructure ‚Äúa key issue for public security in every society.‚Äù Read More: Parliament Rushing to Ensure National Security Ardian‚Äôs purchase of M√≠la was discussed in the National Security Council and new legislation was drafted, with the stated goal of strengthening and securing the legal basis for electronic communication with regard to national security. Helga Vala Helgad√≥ttir, MP for the Social-Democratic Alliance, has argued that there were many red flags in the government‚Äôs handling of the case and that the legislation did not ensure consumer security. The newly-passed bill, introduced last term by then-Minister of Justice √Åslaug Arna Sigurbj√∂rnsd√≥ttir, amends the Electronic Communications Act, legislation governing the Electronic Communications Office of Iceland (ECOI), and legislation on foreign investment in business operations.

headline: Hope to Remove R√öV from the Ad Market this Electoral Term
body: Minister of Education, Science, and Culture, Lilja D√∂gg Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir iterated her position yesterday that R√öV should be removed from the advertisement market. In an interview with V√≠sir, the leaders of the Independence Party and the Left-Green Movement concurred with the Minister‚Äôs conviction. The inclusion of R√öV (the Icelandic National Broadcasting Service) on the advertising market has long been contentious. R√öV has a legal commitment to promoting the Icelandic language and Iceland‚Äôs history. It is partly funded by a television license fee, with the rest of its income originating from ad sales. Last year, for example, the government paid out 400 million ISK in grants to 19 privately-owned media outlets, 63% of which went to three major companies. In comparison, government payouts to R√öV increased by 430 million ISK ($3.5 million / ‚Ç¨3 million), or from 4.6 billion ISK ($37 million / ‚Ç¨32 million) to 5.1 billion ISK (($41 million / ‚Ç¨36 million). As reported by V√≠sir, R√öV‚Äôs income currently accounts for approximately a quarter of all earnings by Icelandic media outlets, a figure that hasn‚Äôt been higher since the last century. Yesterday, Lilja D√∂gg Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir ‚Äì Minister of Education, Science, and Culture ‚Äì iterated her intentions of removing R√öV from the advertising market. When asked by a V√≠sir reporter why the citizenry should take these remarks seriously, given that she had made such declarations in the past ‚Äì Lilja D√∂gg announced ambitious plans to remove R√öV from the advertising market in 2019 ‚Äì Lilja turned the journalist‚Äôs logic on its head: ‚ÄúSuch statements point to my perseverance, to how determined I am, as a politician; if I think something needs to be done, I don‚Äôt stop until it‚Äôs done. In those countries to whom we often compare ourselves, the state broadcaster is not on the advertising market.‚Äù Referencing the government‚Äôs renewed mandate, Lilja stated that the government now had the requisite time on its hands to withdraw the state broadcaster from the ad market. ‚ÄúOf course, this means that we need to bolster R√öV‚Äôs operations in some other way, which I‚Äôve previously noted. But it‚Äôs clear that the operational environment of local media is unsustainable. We‚Äôve seen a great many people leave the profession. This isn‚Äôt good for Icelandic democracy, for politics, for business.‚Äù Like Lilja, Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs, Bjarni Benediktsson, is confident that R√öV will be removed from the ad market this electoral term. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs time that we take this step, and we need to find ways of doing it,‚Äù Bjarni stated, acknowledging that the government would need to find a way to ensure R√öV‚Äôs operations. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not saying that we need to make drastic cuts to its budget, for we seem to lack the political consensus to decrease R√öV‚Äôs scope. Personally, however, I think it‚Äôs something that we should be open to reviewing: whether we want R√öV to operate at such a scale for the foreseeable future, as opposed to cutting our coat according to the cloth.‚Äù Bjarni added that he is opposed to raising the television licence fee, which he considers a tax and not a premium. ‚ÄúI believe that we should review, during this electoral term, whether we shouldn‚Äôt abolish this tax ‚Äì to relieve households and legal entities of the tax. We need to face the cost of operating a public broadcaster with an item in the budget that clearly states the price.‚Äù Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir agrees that R√öV should be removed from the ad market. When asked by V√≠sir if she was comfortable with the fact that the state of the media had deteriorated during her tenure, Prime Minister Katr√≠n cited government grants and her agreement with Lilja D√∂gg that the government needed to draw up a long-term, holistic policy for media outlets. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs long been my opinion that we should aim toward removing R√öV from the ad market, with the caveat that we need to ensure its operations. We are all of the same opinion, in my party, that we want a vigorous public broadcaster,‚Äù Katr√≠n stated, who believes that a strong public broadcaster is vital in a small society like Iceland.

headline: Central Bank Raises Key Interest Rate by 0.75%
body: The Central Bank of Iceland has raised interest rates by 0.75 percentage points. The hike takes the Bank‚Äôs key interest rate to 2.75%. In the shadow of rising inflation, the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) of the Central Bank of Iceland has decided to raise the Bank‚Äôs interest rates by 0.75 percentage points. The Bank‚Äôs key interest rate ‚Äì the rate on seven-day term deposits ‚Äì will, therefore, be 2.75%. The inflation rate in January was 5.7% ‚Äì the highest since April of 2012 ‚Äì and the Central Bank predicts an inflation rate of +5% in 2022 (+5.8% in the first quarter), which is double the Bank‚Äôs target. As noted in an announcement this morning, the MPC will not only raise key interest rates but also employ all of its available instruments to ensure that inflation rates subside to target levels within an acceptable timeframe. The increase in interest rates coincides with the publication of the latest edition of the Monetary Bulletin (Peningam√°l). (The Monetary Bulletin, published on a quarterly basis, contains an ‚Äúinflation and macroeconomic forecast along with comprehensive analysis of economic and monetary developments and prospects.‚Äù) As noted in the Bulletin, GDP growth exceeded November forecasts by 1%; GDP growth in 2021 was 4.9%, and the Central Bank predicts similar growth in 2022. ‚ÄúJobs have continued to grow, unemployment has decreased, and the production slack that formed in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic is expected to disappear. There is, however, considerable uncertainty.‚Äù The MPC states that inflation outlooks have worsened considerably since the committee‚Äôs last meeting. The headline inflation rate has risen to an estimated 4%. Furthermore, inflationary expectations have increased according to several indicators, with the rise in housing prices having a considerable effect, in addition to increases in several items of domestic expenditure. As reported by Kjarninn yesterday, Dr√≠fa Sn√¶dal, President of the Icelandic Confederation of Labour, wrote a letter to the MPC yesterday asking it to refrain from raising interest rates. In her letter, Dr√≠fa stated that ‚Äúsharp increases in interest rates have already put many households in a difficult spot. Many households have committed to non-indexed mortgages, owing both to favourable conditions and to indirect encouragement on behalf of the government and the Central Bank.‚Äù The Central Bank will hold a live broadcast at 9.30 AM.

headline: Minister Titles Finalised, Changes to Cost ISK 1.8 Billion
body: Is J√≥n Gunnarsson Iceland‚Äôs Minister of the Interior or Minister of Justice? It has been a difficult question to answer since Iceland‚Äôs newest government took power in November. The government has not only shuffled ministry appointments, but changed the number of ministries as well as their names and assignments, since last term. R√öV reports that the minsters‚Äô titles have now been finalised by presidential ruling, and the changes are expected to cost the treasury ISK 1.8 billion [$14.1 million, ‚Ç¨12.5 million] this term. Six ministers have the same titles as those announced last November. Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir keeps the title of Prime Minister, Bjarni Benediktsson the title of Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs, and Sigur√∞ur Ingi J√≥hannsson the title of Minister of Infrastructure. Willum √û√≥r √û√≥rsson remains the Minister of Health, √Åsmundur Einar Da√∞ason the Minister of Education and Children, and Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r √û√≥r√∞arson the Minister of the Environment, Energy, and Climate. The other six ministers received a new title with the presidential rulings. √Åslaug Arna Sigurbj√∂rnsd√≥ttir, originally announced as the Minister of Science, Industry, and Innovation, will now be the Minister of Higher Education, Industry, and Innovation. Svand√≠s Svavarsd√≥ttir will no longer be known as the Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries, rather the Minister of Food. √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n Reykfj√∂r√∞ Gylfad√≥ttir, originally the Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Development Cooperation, will simply be known as the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Lilja Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir‚Äôs title will also be shortened from Minister of Tourism, Trade, and Culture, to Minister of Trade and Culture. The same goes for Gu√∞mundur Ingi Gu√∞brandsson, who will no longer be the Minister of Social Affairs and the Labour Market, rather simply the Social and Labour Market Minister. J√≥n Gunnarson, who was initially announced as Interior Minister, will be known as the Minister of Justice. According to a recent response in Parliament, the cost of shuffling the ministries and changing the titles could cost up to ISK 1.8 billion [$14.1 million, ‚Ç¨12.5 million] this term.

headline: S√≥lveig Anna Announces Candidacy for Efling Chair
body: S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir, who resigned as Efling‚Äôs Chairperson in October, has decided to resubmit her candidacy for the position, R√öV reports. Elections for a new board and chairperson will begin on February 9 and will end on February 15. In October of last year, Efling Union Chairperson S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir resigned. Her departure followed on the heels of accusations of workplace bullying, as alleged by union staff in letters of no-confidence to her, the union, and Icelandic media. S√≥lveig Anna subsequently denied the allegations, and after her resignation, union members stated, in another letter to the media, that what they had wanted was solutions ‚Äì and not resignations. Following these events, Efling voted in its first chair of foreign origin (on a short-term basis): Agnieszka Ewa Zi√≥≈Çkowska, who previously served as vice-chair of the union. Elections for a new board and chairperson will commence on February 9 and will end on February 15. So far, two other candidates have announced their intentions to run: √ìl√∂f Helga Adolfsd√≥ttir, Efling‚Äôs current vice-chair, and Gu√∞mundur Baldursson, Efling board member. In an interview with¬†R√öV, S√≥lveig Anna remarked that she had decided to submit her candidacy in light of the ‚Äúnumerous encouraging messages‚Äù that she had received from union members. Despite these positive messages, S√≥lveig added that her decision had required careful deliberation: ‚ÄúI still spent a lot of time weighing the prospect, but in the end, having discussed it with good people, we reached this conclusion.‚Äù S√≥lveig Anna will be campaigning under the banner of Bar√°ttulistinn (the Fight List), and states that she is prepared for the campaign: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm certainly ready for the fight. Since I first assumed chair of the union, in 2018, I‚Äôve been prepared to fight. Efling has made tremendous strides; we managed to transform this colossal bureaucracy, which enabled the continuation of low-wage policies, into the most powerful tool wielded by Icelandic workers.‚Äù As noted in an article in Iceland Review last year, Efling is Iceland‚Äôs second-largest labour union, with around 27,000 members working in public service, healthcare, and other industries. S√≥lveig Anna became Efling‚Äôs chair in 2018 and led wage negotiations and strikes among City of Reykjav√≠k employees and hotel workers calling for better wages and working conditions for low earners. More than half of Efling‚Äôs members are of foreign origin.

headline: Icelandic Artist Packs Up Exhibition in Russia
body: Contemporary Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson has put a stop to his exhibition Santa Barbara that was taking place in the newly-opened GEC-2 contemporary art museum in Moscow, Russia, R√öV reports. Kjartan says there was no question that packing up the exhibition was the right thing to do after Russia invaded Ukraine last Thursday. Ragnar is an internationally renowned artist, having exhibited at the Venice Biennale, the Tate Modern, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, among other places. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not possible to exhibit this piece when this horror has begun,‚Äù Ragnar stated. ‚ÄúThe piece is about the beginning of the Russia that came to be after the Soviet Union. And that Russia ended [last Thursday]. Now it‚Äôs just become a full-blown fascist state.‚Äù Ragnar‚Äôs piece Santa Barbara is named after the US soap opera that started being broadcast in Russia one week after the fall of the Soviet Union. The exhibition recreates the series one episode at a time under the direction of √Åsa Helga Hj√∂rleifsd√≥ttir. A team of crew and actors had recreated one episode from the show each day since the beginning of December, until the decision to stop was made last week. The exhibition was originally supposed to run for an additional two weeks.  Read More: Staging Reality Ragnar says Russian artists have told him of being censored or imprisoned due to their art. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just been an incredible experience to make art in this situation, where it‚Äôs almost like being in a thriller,‚Äù Ragnar stated. ‚ÄúYou meet all kinds of people that have been put in prison, experienced bomb threats, censorship and I don‚Äôt know what else.‚Äù A New York Times article from December describes Russian artist Maria V. Alyokhina‚Äôs criticism of the GEC-2 grand opening as ‚Äúhosting a feast during a plague,‚Äù a reference to a play by Alexander Pushkin. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really cool what they are doing, I really like it. It‚Äôs just, we have reality also, not only ‚ÄòSanta Barbara,‚Äô‚Äù Alyokhina said, implying the arts centre was ignoring Russia‚Äôs political reality. Ragnar is also quoted in the article as saying: ‚ÄúMany things can be criticized in this country, but we cannot look away from the fact that the Russian culture is completely awesome.‚Äù

headline: Iceland‚Äôs First Eurovision Semi-Final Today
body: Iceland‚Äôs Eurovision adventure starts today, Saturday, February 26, with the first S√∂ngvakeppnin semi-final. The show will be broadcast live on R√öV at 7:45 pm local time. As in previous years, there are two semi-finals with five songs competing in each round. The public will vote on their favorite songs in each semi-final and the top two songs from each round will advance to the grand final on March 12. The event organizers also have the option of sending a fifth ‚Äòwildcard‚Äô song to compete in the final. The competition will take place in ‚ÄòS√∂ngvakeppnin Hall‚Äô at Trapped director Baltasar K√≥rmakur‚Äôs RVK Studios and be hosted by Bj√∂rg Magn√∫sd√≥ttir, J√≥n J√≥nsson, and Ragnhildur Steinunn J√≥nsd√≥ttir. Is this Iceland‚Äôs Year? Last year, Iceland sent Da√∞i og gangmagni√∞ with their song ‚Äú10 Years‚Äù to Eurovision. The song quickly became a fan favourite and many speculated that it was finally Iceland‚Äôs year to win. The band had already achieved widespread popularity the previous year with their song ‚ÄúThink About Things,‚Äù which was Iceland‚Äôs submission to the 2020 Eurovision contest. That event was, of course, cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Unfortunately, despite a promising outlook for Iceland‚Äôs long-awaited Eurovision triumph, 2021 had other plans in store. A COVID outbreak among band members meant that Da√∞i og gagnamagni√∞ couldn‚Äôt compete in either the semi-final or final. A recording of their second rehearsal in Rotterdam was used instead of a live performance and they placed fourth overall. Iceland‚Äôs 2022 Eurovision Song Contest Playlist All of the songs will be performed in Icelandic during the semi-finals; grand finalists have the option of singing in either Icelandic or English. (Links below include videos of the songs in both languages, as available.) Semi-Final One (February 26) Amarosis: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt You Know‚Äù Haffi Haf: ‚ÄúG√≠a‚Äù (English title: ‚ÄúVolcano‚Äù) Sigga, Beta, & El√≠n: ‚ÄúMe√∞ h√¶kkandi s√≥l‚Äù Stefan√≠a Svavarsd√≥ttir: ‚ÄúHjarta√∞ mitt‚Äù (English title: ‚ÄúHeart of Mine‚Äù) Stef√°n √ìli: ‚ÄúLj√≥si√∞‚Äù (English title: ‚ÄúAll I Know‚Äù) Semi-Final Two (March 5) Hanna Mia and the Astrotourists: ‚ÄúS√©ns me√∞ √æ√©r‚Äù (English title: ‚ÄúGemini‚Äù) Katla: ‚Äú√ûa√∞an af‚Äù (English title: ‚ÄúThen Again‚Äù) Mark√©ta Irglov√°: ‚ÄúM√∂gulegt‚Äù (English title: ‚ÄúPossible‚Äù) Reykjav√≠kurd√¶tur: ‚ÄúT√∂kum af sta√∞‚Äù (English title: ‚ÄúTurn This Around‚Äù) Sun City & Sanna: ‚ÄúH√¶kkum √≠ botn‚Äù (English title: ‚ÄúKeep it Cool‚Äù)

headline: Audiobooks Account for a Third of Books ‚ÄòRead‚Äô in Iceland
body: The popularity of audiobooks in Iceland has exploded in recent years, R√öV reports. A third of books ‚Äòread‚Äô in Iceland are now consumed in audio form. The audiobook boom happened later than anticipated in Iceland, says author and literary scholar Halld√≥r Gu√∞mundsson. When digital music formats became the norm, it was expected that the Icelandic literary world would also naturally shift to digital and audio formats. This didn‚Äôt happen, however, in part simply because audiobooks were not being published in any significant way. The Icelandic Audio Library (previously known as the Library for the Blind) made audiobooks available to Icelanders who were unable to read printed material. But their collection was not accessible by the general public. Leaving the Audio Library‚Äôs collection out of the tally, therefore, a grand total of nine audiobooks were published in 2017. But just a year later, when Swedish audiobook retailer Storytel arrived in Iceland, audiobook publications skyrocketed, with 168 audiobooks published in 2018. This trend has continued apace: 770 audiobooks were published in Iceland in 2020. A side benefit of this audiobook explosion, says Halld√≥r, is that Icelandic books that have gone out of print are now readily available once again, as production costs are much lower than they would be if the books were republished in print format. He also noted that there are now authors who are have begun writing specifically for audio format, creating, in essence, a new literary genre as they go. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs interesting about it is that this could become, and in some cases has already become, its own literary genre: the audiobook. If you‚Äôre writing specifically for audio, you have to do things like introduce characters to the story a bit differently. It‚Äôs an aesthetics called ‚Äòaudio-first.‚Äô‚Äù Audio books are also bringing many authors new audiences, something that Halld√≥r‚Äîwho wrote a celebrated, 824-page biography about Iceland‚Äôs Nobel Prize for Literature winner Halld√≥r Laxness in 2004‚Äîknows from personal experience. ‚Äú‚Ä¶The big plus is that you get new readers. All of a sudden, people who would have never attempted my doorstop [of a biography] about Halld√≥r Laxness are getting in touch with me, and it takes a whole week to listen to that.‚Äù Indeed, the audio version of the biography, read in Icelandic by the author himself, is nine hours and nineteen minutes long. (An English version of the book, translated by Philip Roughton in 2008, was published under the title The Islander: A Biography of Halld√≥r Laxness.) There is still, of course, room for improvement in terms of how authors are remunerated for audiobook publication. It‚Äôs a well-known fact, concedes Halld√≥r, that musicians have not been treated equitably in this new digital streaming world and authors are not faring much better. Storytel, for example, only pays authors a little more in royalties than Spotify, ‚Äúby far the worst‚Äù of the streaming platforms, pays its musicians. The company is up front about its payment rates, however, so while Halld√≥r agrees that ‚Äúauthor remuneration could be higher, no question,‚Äù he notes that there is still payment and the terms are clear from the outset. Platforms like Storytel are pushing Icelandic publishers to release more audiobooks themselves. Looking at the example of Forlagi√∞, the biggest publisher in Iceland, Halld√≥r notes that the company only released a single audiobook in 2017. Whereas last year, Forlagi√∞ published 192 audiobooks. This only makes sense, Halld√≥r concludes: you can‚Äôt look at the figures ‚Äî a third of all books in Iceland being read by audio format ‚Äî and let that sort of opportunity pass by.

headline: Verb√∫√∞in Wins Big at G√∂teborg Film Festival
body: Icelandic TV series Verb√∫√∞in (English title: Blackport) won the 2022 Nordisk Film & TV Fond Prize at the G√∂teborg Film Festival this week, R√öV reports. The award is given for ‚Äúoutstanding writing of a Nordic drama series‚Äù and is accompanied by a prize of NOK 200,000 [ISK 2.85 million; $22,824]. This year‚Äôs nominees included Countrymen (Norway; written by Izer Aliu, Anne Bj√∏rnstad), Transport (Finland; written by Auli Mantila), The Shift (Denmark; written by Lone Scherfig), and Vi i villa (Sweden; written by Tove Eriksen Hillblom). Set in the Westfjords in the 1980s, the story follows a married couple, Harpa and Grimur, as they build a small fishing empire along with their childhood friends. But with the introduction of a new quota system in the country, where the fishing grounds are privatised, the struggle for power results in a feud of jealousy, greed and betrayal. Hailed as the buzziest TV series to come out of Iceland since Trapped, Verb√∫√∞in has indeed already garnered a great deal of international interest, despite the fact that it has not yet been widely broadcast for the international public. Vesturport produced the show for R√öV in Iceland and Arte France, and has production backing from the UK‚Äôs Turbine Studios, the Nordic 12 TV Alliance and the Nordisk Film & TV Fond. Prior to its success at G√∂teborg, it won the Series Mania Award at the Berlinale Co-Pro Series pitching event in 2018 and was also a hit at the Spanish Serielizados TV festival last fall. Verb√∫√∞in has also been extremely popular with audiences at home‚Äî80% audience approval according to some figures. But the positive foreign reception of this particularly Icelandic story has been particularly surprising for the creators, says Mikael Torfason, who co-wrote the script with two members of the Vesturport theatre and film company who also star in the series: N√≠na D√∂gg Filippusd√≥ttir (The Vallhalla Murders, Trapped), Bj√∂rn Hlynur Haraldsson (Trapped, The Witcher), and G√≠sli √ñrn Gar√∞arsson (Ragnarok, Prisoners). ‚ÄúThis is maybe not something you‚Äôd expect. The most popular material has usually been crime dramas.‚Äù ¬† ¬†
