headline: No More One-Metre Distancing Requirement for Seated Events
body: Iceland‚Äôs Health Minister has lifted the requirement of one-metre distancing at seated events, such as concerts and performing arts events. The decision was made in consultation with the Chief Epidemiologist. Event organisers had complained that the rule was unnecessarily cumbersome and stricter than requirements in other types of venues, such as bars and restaurants. ‚ÄúThis is a big and important change,‚Äù Health Minister Willum √û√≥r √û√≥rsson stated. ‚ÄúThis changes the conditions for holding events as it will be possible to utilise all seats at events as long as there are not more than 500 people per compartment.‚Äù As previously, mask use is still required at all seated events. Performing arts venues are still not permitted to sell alcohol during events. Some event organisers have protested that regulation, as alcohol sales are permitted at bars, clubs, and restaurants.

headline: Majority of Icelandic Music Catalogue Sold to Universal Music
body: Iceland‚Äôs largest music label, Alda Music, has been bought by Universal Music/Ingrooves Music Group, the largest music corporation in the world, V√≠sir reports. The head of Iceland‚Äôs Musicians‚Äô Union expects the acquisition to give Icelandic musicians ‚Äúbigger speakers‚Äù and open doors for them abroad. The purchase directly impacts the majority of music released in Iceland as well as the local music industry as a whole. Alda Music was founded in 2016 by musicians S√∂lvi Bl√∂ndal and √ìlafur Arnalds. The label purchased the rights to a large catalogue of Icelandic music previously belonging to Sena, including the music of current and decades-old hit artists. Alda, and now Ingrooves, hold the rights to 80% of all music released in Iceland, according to the company‚Äôs own figures. ‚ÄúIn just a few years, S√∂lvi and his team at Alda have built Iceland‚Äôs most powerful distribution network with an incredible roster of local artists,‚Äù Bob Roback of Ingrooves stated on the purchase. ‚ÄúWe are looking forward to working closely with them as we invest in the local music community and expand opportunities for artists both within Iceland and around the world.‚Äù The purchase could help increase value in the Icelandic music by increasing its reach abroad, according to Gunnar Hrafnsson, chairman of the Musician‚Äôs Union of Iceland (F√çH). ‚ÄúI think [Icelandic music] has got bigger speakers now. There is more capital behind it and a more powerful company.‚Äù Others in the industry may have more reservations about the sale. ‚ÄúImportant to think about and discuss this news of a foreign company‚Äôs purchase of the distribution rights to a large portion of Icelandic music,‚Äù Icelandic musician Logi Pedro Stef√°nsson tweeted today. ‚ÄúAs a small nation with a tiny language we have to stand guard over our cultural wealth and legacy, and how we support the arts as well as possible in the future.‚Äù It is clear the purchase will greatly impact the Icelandic music industry, Bragi Valdimar Sk√∫lason, chairman of the Composer‚Äôs Rights Society of Iceland (STEF), told Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞. ‚ÄúThere are of course huge interests at stake here. There is a remarkable catalogue of Icelandic songs from the very start [of recording].‚Äù Bragi Valdimar points out that musicians still hold the rights to the songs themselves, though Universal has acquired the rights to the masters (or recordings). This could be positive for STEF, as Universal will invest in distributing the recordings. What impact the purchase of Alda will have is yet to be seen, Bragi Valdimar added, but it is just one step of a development that has been ongoing for some time, and not only in Iceland. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been something of a trend that these independent labels have a tendency to merge together in the end.‚Äù

headline: Icelandic Government Raises Artist Salaries
body: Iceland‚Äôs government raised its artist grants known as ‚Äúartist salaries‚Äù to ISK 428,000 [$3,330, ‚Ç¨2,908] per month this January, Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞ reports. The salaries were ISK 409,580 [$3,187, ‚Ç¨2,782] per month last year. Minister of Tourism, Trade, and Culture Lilja Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir has decided to increase funding of artists salaries by a further ISK 100 million [$779,000, ‚Ç¨679,000] this year and says the government is also considering restructuring the artist salary grant system. ‚ÄúThis is not a high figure in my opinion and we aim for it to rise in stages throughout this term because I consider it important for our artists and this system has worked very well,‚Äù Lilja stated. ‚ÄúI would say that the entire government agrees with increasing support to this system.‚Äù In fact, the 2022 artist salary recipients, who were recently announced, will receive ISK 490,920 per month [$3,825, ‚Ç¨3,335]. The government has, however, decreased the number of months granted to artists as compared to 2020 and 2021. An additional 600 months in artist salaries were granted in 2020 and an additional 550 in 2021 in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The artist salaries for 2022 have however decreased back to 1,600 months in total, the same number granted between 2009 and 2019.¬† Lilja says the government is considering restructuring the artist salary system, including by having a special category for young artists. Culture and Trade were brought together under a single ministry this term under Lilja‚Äôs leadership, and she says that presents certain benefits. ‚ÄúEverything that is connected to culture and art is now in one place. The reimbursement system for literature, the reimbursements for film, recording, so now we have for example the Icelandic Film Centre and the big reimbursement system in one place which creates new opporunities.‚Äù Last term, the government abolished sales tax on Icelandic books and increased contributions to writers grants. This term, Lilja says the focus will be on the music and film industries. Lilja says that the government chose to work toward raising artist salaries rather than increasing them in number to ‚Äúsend a message to the entire industry.‚Äù She says there is still a ways to go, as salaries in comparable professions average around ISK 550,000 [$4,285, ‚Ç¨3,736] per month.

headline: International Book Thief Targeted Icelandic Authors, Publishers
body: The mysterious book thief whose five-year stint stealing unpublished manuscripts has sowed mistrust and anxiety among authors, agents, editors, translators and literary professionals of all stripes also specifically targeted Icelanders and went to great lengths to acquire Icelandic language texts. Following the FBI‚Äôs recent arrest of the man suspected of being behind the thefts‚ÄîFilippo Bernardini, a 29-year-old Italian national who works in the foreign-rights department of publisher Simon & Schuster‚Äôs UK office‚ÄîR√öV reports that the thief‚Äôs interactions with Icelandic authors and agents had, in at least one instance, been menacing enough to warrant filing a police report. ‚ÄòThere‚Äôs no apparent reason for it‚Äô The book thief‚Äîdubbed ‚ÄòThe Spine Collector‚Äô by journalists Reeves Wiedeman and Lila Shapiro who spent six months investigating the case‚Äîused intricate means of acquiring, or attempting to acquire, unpublished of big-name novelists (Margaret Atwood, Jennifer Egan, Laila Lailami, and David Lagercrantz, the Swedish author who took over writing Stig Larsen‚Äôs Millennium series), celebrities (Ethan Hawke), and unknown first timers. The thief‚Äôs motives remain unknown and unclear‚Äîas pointed out in a 2020 New York Times article, the manuscripts never appeared on the black market and were never followed by any sort of ransom demand. To make things all the more confusing, the individual also targeted authors who write in a variety of languages other than English. By early 2020, it was clear that the thief had set his sights on adding unpublished, Icelandic-language manuscripts to his collection, and although no one was entirely sure why the person would go to such trouble, it put everyone in the industry on edge. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs totally worthless material, in the sense that it was in a language that at most, 350,000 people speak,‚Äù remarked author Bj√∂rn Halld√≥rsson at the time. Bj√∂rn had been contacted by the thief, who posed as an editor at a respected American publisher and asked for a copy of his as-yet unpublished first novel. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no apparent reason for it,‚Äù Bj√∂rn mused in an interview. ‚ÄúBut after consulting with people who work for big publishers, I think that this is the first phase in some sort of scheme to build trust and relationships, so god only knows what could have happened if I‚Äôd sent the manuscript.‚Äù ‚ÄòI know where you live‚Äô The thief also contacted H√≥lmfr√≠√∞ur Matth√≠asd√≥ttir, publishing director at Forlagi√∞, Iceland‚Äôs largest publishing house. ‚ÄúHe had created email addresses, we‚Äôll call them impostor emails, that mimicked the names of actual people who work in the literary world,‚Äù she recalled in a recent interview. ‚ÄúWell-known translators, agents, and publishers, people we were in touch with.‚Äù (The thief would often employ tricks such as replacing an ‚Äòm‚Äô with ‚Äòrn‚Äô so that a fake email address‚Äî[email¬†protected], for example‚Äîwould look legitimate unless closely scrutinized.) ‚ÄúHe wrote to us using these fake email addresses and asked us to send manuscripts or files for books that we were about to publish,‚Äù H√≥lmfr√≠√∞ur continued. ‚ÄúBecause he was just so excited to read them and wanted to consider publication abroad.‚Äù H√≥lmfr√≠√∞ur saw through the ruse, however, and wrote back to the emailer, suggesting he get in touch with one of the other aliases he‚Äôd been using to solicit Icelandic manuscripts. ‚ÄúI say to him, ‚ÄòNow, be sure to talk to the other [impostor] because that person has just as much interest in Icelandic literature as you do.‚Äù The thief became threatening. ‚ÄúHe explicitly said: ‚ÄòI know where you live and I‚Äôm going to show up there.‚Äô‚Äù After consulting with her colleagues, H√≥lmfr√≠√∞ur decided to report the interaction to the police. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really unsettling when you don‚Äôt know who is behind words like that.‚Äù Thief wrote in Icelandic The thief also impersonated a number of Icelanders in the literary world, H√≥lmfr√≠√∞ur herself included. As she recalled in an interview with Morgunbla√∞i√∞, he wrote to Icelandic author Sj√≥n ‚Äúin good Icelandic,‚Äù pretending to be her. He also emailed Bjartur & Ver√∂ld publisher P√©tur M√°r √ìlafsson, pretending to be author Hallgr√≠mur Helgason. In that exchange, fake Hallgr√≠mur said he was in Denmark and asked for a pdf of a manuscript that he was interested in reviewing. ‚ÄúI knew that the real Hallgr√≠mur had been on a trip to Germany,‚Äù said P√©tur M√°r, ‚Äúand I found it a bit strange,‚Äù not least because Hallgr√≠mur had written a post on Facebook about returning to Iceland. P√©tur M√°r responded to fake Hallgr√≠mur, not letting on that he suspected that something was amiss. He said he‚Äôd seen that the author had come back to Iceland and invited him to come to the publisher‚Äôs office to pick up the book in person. He also suggested a phone call, but in both cases fake Hallgr√≠mur demurred and repeated his request for a pdf. The impostor maintained his impersonation even after P√©tur M√°r responded with well wishes about his sudden COVID infection‚Äîas it happens, the real author had posted on Facebook that very day, saying he‚Äôd caught COVID. P√©tur M√°r included a screenshot of the Facebook post in his message to the impostor and said he‚Äôd send the book to the quarantine hotel in Reykjav√≠k. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt receive any packages,‚Äù wrote fake Hallgr√≠mur. ‚ÄúOnly pdfs.‚Äù But the real Hallgr√≠mur had not only received the book, he‚Äôd called P√©tur M√°r to thank him. Meanwhile, the impostor sent another email: ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt received it‚Ä¶can you send me a pdf?‚Äù ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs strange,‚Äù responded P√©tur M√°r, ‚Äúyou just called me before and thanked me for the package!‚Äù That was the last that P√©tur M√°r heard from fake Hallgr√≠mur. Interestingly, however, when the FBI arrested Bernardini, the publisher recalled having corresponded with the man under his real name. In that instance, Bernardini addressed P√©tur and his colleagues in broken Icelandic. ‚ÄòWe know nothing about what he was doing‚Äô While no material damage seems to have been done to any of the Icelandic authors and agents targeted by the thief, the person‚Äôs campaign of deception has made a real impact on the (Icelandic) publishing industry, which, H√≥lmfr√≠√∞ur pointed out, is one that‚Äôs built on trust. Even more unsettling is the fact that ostensibly knowing who was behind the thefts has done little to explain the thief‚Äôs motives. ‚ÄúThe books, or the manuscripts haven‚Äôt appeared on illegal download sites, and we‚Äôve never seen him take advantage of them in any visible way,‚Äù noted H√≥lmfr√≠√∞ur. ‚ÄúIn reality, we know nothing about what he was doing with these manuscripts.‚Äù

headline: Resturants, Concerts Granted Temporary Slack From New COVID Restrictions
body: Minister of Health Willum √û√≥r √û√≥rsson has decided to exempt restaurants from new infection prevention gathering limits on December 23. Restaurants can accept 50 guests in each compartment instead of 20 as stipulated in the new regulations. Musicians hosting Christmas concerts have also been allowed to host events according to requirements from the previous and milder infection prevention regulation.¬† Aside from the gathering limits, restaurants must uphold, including closing at 9 pm. The exception is made to ensure proportionality in light of the short notice given until the new regulations took effect. Restaurants are encouraged to continue to keep up the utmost infection prevention measures, including providing access to hand sanitisers, making sure mask requirements are upheld, and keeping up the 1-metre social distance between unrelated parties.¬† December 23 is known as √ûorl√°ksmessa and is a popular day for fermented skate parties at home or in restaurants, people-watching, and last-minute shopping in downtown Reykjav√≠k.¬† Musicians such as Bubbi Morthens and Emmsj√© Gauti have also been granted exemptions to host their Christmas Concerts based on the previous infection prevention regulation requirements. Five hundred people are allowed in each compartment, provided they can present a negative antigen test performed by a healthcare professional no less than 48 hours previous.¬† In a conversation with Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞ reporter, Chief Epidemiologist √û√≥r√≥lfur Gu√∞nason has called the exemptions ‚Äúmaybe not the wisest course of action from an epidemiological standpoint.‚Äù

headline: Lamb Shortlisted for the Oscars
body: Lamb, a movie by Icelandic director and screenwriter Valdimar J√≥hansson, has been shortlisted for the 2022 Academy Awards. The movie was selected as Iceland‚Äôs entry for the Best International Feature Film last October. Fifteen movies from fifteen different countries are on the shortlist, which was unveiled yesterday. Lamb is a supernatural drama about an Icelandic farm couple, Mar√≠a (Noomi Rapace) and Ingvar (Hilmir Sn√¶r Gu√∞nason), that takes a human-sheep hybrid into their care after witnessing one of their sheep giving birth to the creature. The movie, which premiered last July, has received international acclaim and has already won some noteworthy awards. It was one of six movies that were awarded by the Un Certain regard jury at the Cannes festival in 2021, receiving the Prize of Originality. It was awarded best film at the Sitges Fantastic Film Festival of Catalonia earlier this year, and the best actress award at the same festival went to Noomi Rapace. The movie is a co-production between three countries: Iceland, Sweden and Poland. The screenplay was jointly written by director J√≥hannsson and Icelandic poet and writer Sj√≥n. The nominations for the 2022 Academy Awards will be announced in early February 2022.

headline: New Church To Be Built In Gr√≠msey This Summer
body: The Mi√∞gar√∞ar parish committee in Gr√≠msey recently signed a contract with carpentry workshop Loftkastalinn to build a new church to replace the one that burnt down earlier this year. Architect Hj√∂rleifur Stef√°nsson has been hired as a construction manager and Arna Bj√∂rg Bjarnad√≥ttir, project manager of Gl√¶√∞um Gr√≠msey ‚Äì a campaign to revitalise habitation in the island ‚Äì has agreed to supervise the project. Everyone involved in the church building has experience with building restoration projects. The new church will reference the old church but will be larger than the old one due to modern requirements. The design will also take into consideration that the church will be used for other events than church ceremonies. Parts of the church will be prepared on the mainland but the structure is set to be constructed in Gr√≠msey next summer. A notice from the parish committee states that building the new church is a communal project and that the islanders are making every effort to raise funds for the projects. Some funds have already been donated and the people of Gr√≠msey have gratitude for everyone who has already contributed to the project. On January 1, Gr√≠msey had a population of 57 but not all residents live on the island all year round. In recent years, efforts have been made to reverse steady emigration from the island but as of yet, they‚Äôve proven unsuccessful. The island lies off the north coast of Iceland and is the northernmost inhabited part of the country, situated on the Arctic Circle.

headline: The Number of Self-Employed Workers in the Cultural Sector Decreases by 19%
body: The number of self-employed workers in the cultural sector in Iceland decreased by 19% in the year of 2020, a report by Statistic Iceland confirms. The number had been growing since 2017, but started falling sharply after the pandemic hit in the beginning of last year. In Iceland, self-employed workers are more common in culture and arts than in any other sector. Currently, 23.6% of those who work in culture are self-employed. In comparison, the rate of independent workers in other sectors in Iceland has been around 10% for the past five years. Erling J√≥hannesson, the president of the Federation of Icelandic Artists states in an interview with Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞, that artists and others who work in culture have found themselves in a precarious situation since the pandemic hit, as these individuals commonly work as freelancers who do not have permanent jobs. ‚ÄúThis group of people faced various bureaucratic hurdles and have not been offered proper solutions‚Äù. He adds that member societies of the federation are unhappy about the new government‚Äôs fiscal policy, in which the government has cut the additional financial support to independent theatre groups which was introduced at the dawn of the pandemic. ‚ÄúWe are still trying to make people aware that the situation is not over yet. We are still just trying to keep afloat. The main issue is to reclaim the additional support funds in order to be able to create something; write music, create art,‚Äù Erling says. In 2020, 12,700 individuals aged 16 to 74 worked within the cultural sector, or around 6.7% of the entire workforce. The number includes permanent employees. The report demonstrates that the decrease in workers does not apply to permanent employees working in the cultural sector. On the contrary, there has been a slight increase in the number of those with permanent job posts in the cultural sector between 2019 and 2020, or 3.7%.

headline: Nordic Clinker Boat Traditions Added to the Unesco Intangible Heritage List
body: The creation and usage of Nordic clinker boats has been inscribed by UNESCO on the Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity.¬†The inscription is shared by five Nordic countries: Iceland, Norway, Finland, Sweden and Denmark. Nordic clinker boats have been built by the people in the region for nearly two millennia. The boats are quite small, between five to ten metres [16‚Äì33 ft] long and are made from wood. Although the craft of making a clinker boat varies slightly from region to region, the boats are built using the same basic techniques, which is explained as following on UNESCO‚Äôs website: ‚ÄúThin planks are fastened to a backbone of the keel and stems, and the overlapping planks are fastened together with metal rivets, treenails or rope. The shell of the boat is strengthened with frames.‚Äù Traditionally, clinker boats were mainly used for fishing and transport. Building a clinker boat required great skill and mastering the craft was a lengthy endeavour. Aspiring craftsmen would commonly start training with a master as young men, sometimes practicing for up to a decade until fully acquiring the skill. The nomination was a result of a joint effort by various Nordic cultural institutions, associations and individuals, which commenced more than five years ago, R√öV reports. Over 200 associations signed the nomination, which was endorsed by all five governments. Sigurbj√∂rg √Årnad√≥ttir, chair of The Icelandic Lighthouse Association, says that the organisation had been preparing the nomination for quite some time. ‚ÄúReaching this milestone is simply wonderful, we are so delighted,‚Äù she says. Sigurbj√∂rg says the idea came into being after a series of annual festivals celebrating Nordic coastal culture. The festivals took place in various locations, such as Norway, the Faroe Islands and the Icelandic coastal town Siglufj√∂r√∞ur. ‚ÄúDuring the festivals we shared our knowledge and expertise with other people and quickly realised that the building of Nordic clinker boats is a shared Nordic tradition that has been sustained for millennia,‚Äù she says. Sigurbj√∂rg admits that throughout the process, she was optimistic that UNESCO would accept the tradition to their list of intangible heritage. ‚ÄúWe prepared the application very well and got many associates on board with us‚Äù. Although the usage of Nordic clinker boats has changed throughout the years, UNESCO reports that the tradition is still of great significance. Today, the boats are mostly used for ceremonial purposes, such as festivities and sporting events. ¬† ¬†

headline: Two New Ice Rinks Set to Open for Christmas
body: Since 2015, the Icelandic telecommunications company Nova has operated an outdoor ice-skating rink during Christmas on Ing√≥lfstorg square in downtown Reykjav√≠k. This year, as part of the festive season, two new skating rinks are set to open in Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur and Reykjanesb√¶r. The town of Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur will open a new synthetic ice-skating rink tomorrow, Saturday, December 11. The rink, which will be known as ‚Äúthe Heart Rink‚Äù (Hjartasvelli√∞), will be situated on the parking lot behind the B√¶jarb√≠√≥ theatre and will span 200 m2. The rink will be open every day between 2 pm and 8 pm, excepting holidays, and tickets to the rink can be booked online. It will be open until January. Writing on V√≠sir.is yesterday, Gu√∞bj√∂rg Oddn√Ω J√≥nasd√≥ttir, Chairperson of Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur‚Äôs Culture and Tourism Commitee, stated that ‚Äúthe rink will be a great addition to the activities available to the town‚Äôs guests, serving to connect the Christmas village, restaurants, shops, and the bright Christmas lights of Hellisger√∞i park.‚Äù The rink is branded as ‚Äúeco-friendly,‚Äù using neither water nor electricity. The town of Reykjanesb√¶r will also be opening a synthetic ice rink next weekend. The rink will be located in the Skr√∫√∞gar√∞ur park in Keflav√≠k.

headline: Cat Calls the Shots for Westfjords Book Publisher
body: ‚ÄúShe makes all the decisions; chooses which books are printed and how and chooses the colours and paper, and I‚Äôm really just her spokesperson and see to all the things that are difficult for cats to do,‚Äù¬†says¬†Birta √ìsmann √û√≥rhallsd√≥ttir about her cat and colleague Skri√∞a. The two manage a book publishing company of the same name based in Patreksfj√∂r√∞ur in the southern Westfjords. ‚ÄúI take care of the VAT number, of course, and the company registration number and all of these practical things having to do with book publishing but I don‚Äôt do anything without consulting [Skri√∞a] and she consults me as well,‚Äù Birta says, admitting that the work is not evenly distributed. ‚ÄúI do most of the dirty work, the accounting. She can‚Äôt be bothered to do it.‚Äù Publishing company Skri√∞a was founded in 2019 and has published eight books. The focus is printing good-quality books that have thoughtful content but are also beautiful objects. All of the books are currently printed in Reykjav√≠k, but Birta hopes one day to set up a printing press in her basement so the books could be made on site. Birta says her working relationship with Skri√∞a is a good one. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs genuinely gratifying and fun. She‚Äôs not ingratiating, she sets down clear guidelines on how things should be done.‚Äù Skri√∞a the cat was present for the interview but made no comment to reporters.

headline: Controlant Receives President‚Äôs Export Award
body: Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson presented the President‚Äôs Export Award to innovation company COntrolant at the Bessasta√∞ir presidential residence yesterday. He also gave an honorary award to director and producer Baltasar Korm√°kur. At a small ceremony at Bessasta√∞ir yesterday, President of Iceland Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson presented Controlant CEO G√≠sli Herj√≥lfsson with the President‚Äôs Export Award. G√≠sli co-founded Controlant, whose real-time supply chain monitoring technology proved very useful when Pfizer used its services to deliver its Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine globally. Gu√∞ni also presented director and producer Baltasar Korm√°kur with an honorary award, acknowledging his cultural impact. On Twitter, Gu√∞ni stated: ‚ÄúThanks to both for invaluable contributions in the fields of technology and culture, in Iceland and beyond.‚Äù Read more: Baltasar Korm√°kur in Iceland Review (subscribers only)

headline: A Third of Icelanders Read Five or More Books in the Past Month
body: It‚Äôs the time of the Christmas book flood, or¬†j√≥lab√≥kafl√≥√∞, in Iceland and it seems that Icelanders are reading just as avidly as ever before. According to new figures published by¬†the Icelandic Literature Center, a third of the nation read five (or more!) books in the past month and 68% gave someone a book in the last 12 months. While interest in literature and reading remain high, however, there is a growing number of Icelanders who read ‚Äúlittle or not at all.‚Äù This is the fifth year in a row that the Icelandic Literature Center has conducted a survey on Icelanders‚Äô reading habits in conjunction with six other literary organisations in the country, including the Reykjav√≠k City Library, Reykjav√≠k UNESCO City of Literature, and the Writers‚Äô Union of Iceland. As last year, this installment also focused on the impact that COVID-19 has had on locals‚Äô interest in literature but found that the pandemic is no longer having a significant impact on Icelanders‚Äô reading habits. Results showed that Icelandic men are reading less this year (1.5 books/month), while women are reading as much as they did before (3.1 books/month). On average, the nation reads an average of 2.3 books a month. People aged 18-24 read significantly less than people in older age brackets. A healthy majority of Icelanders, or 79%, believe that it is important for Icelandic literature to have financial support from the government, which is an increase from last year, when 73% were in agreement about this. Icelanders still read ‚Äòtraditional‚Äô books, with 78% saying that they‚Äôve read a physical book in the last 12 months. This is down somewhat from last year, during the height of the pandemic, when 83% of respondents said they‚Äôd read a physical book. Audiobooks remain as popular as they were last year, with 46% of respondents having listened to one in the last year. Only 31% had read an e-book. Icelanders still mostly prefer to read in Icelandic: 29% only read in Icelandic, while 28.8% read in Icelandic more often than they read in other languages. 19.5% read in other languages just as often as they read in Icelandic, 19.6% read in other languages more often, and 3% only read in other languages. In the same vein, 80.5% of the nation believes that it‚Äôs important for works of foreign literature to be translated into Icelandic. The reading survey was conducted from October 22-31 and was sent to 1,800 individuals aged 18 and older. A total of 992, or 55%, responded.

headline: L√≥kal International Theatre Festival Begins
body: The L√≥kal International Theatre Festival began on Friday and will continue through Monday, December 6. This year‚Äôs program features seven works by local artists, some of which are still in development, as one of the festival‚Äôs emphases is works in progress. The lineup also includes one piece by renowned international theatre-makers 600 Highwaymen. This year‚Äôs festival will also see the publication of Syrpa, a collection of sample scripts by artists based in Reykjav√≠k. Syrpa will be available for sale at Tjarnarb√≠√≥ for the duration of the festival. The program schedule, curated by artistic directors Eva R√∫n Snorrad√≥ttir and J. Vala H√∂skuldsd√≥ttir, is varied in subject matter and approach, and reflects the festival‚Äôs interest in ‚Äúgut feelings‚Äù and giving artists ‚Äúopportunities to try new things.‚Äù It also reflects an imaginative understanding of what theatre and performance actually is and prioritizes active audience participation. Take, for instance, Saturday‚Äôs Botanical Expansion Tour, a 4-hour trip to the Reykjanes peninsula during which participants will develop ‚Äúa plant-oriented worldview that comes in handy when dealing with global warming, midlife crisis and everyday stress.‚Äù Saturday will also stage ‚ÄúThe Festival of Impermanence,‚Äù during which ‚Äúa nurse, a poet, and musicians come together to celebrate and explore the work of healing‚Äù in the home of one of the performers. Another of the festival‚Äôs performances can be experienced from the comfort of the audience‚Äôs homes and will continue for the duration of the festival. As part of ‚ÄúCall Center,‚Äù which begins at 5pm on Sunday, November 28, three short performance pieces will be delivered over the phone. Participants can call whenever they like, as often as they like, from anywhere. The phone number for the performance will be announced on Sunday, see the¬†Facebook event page¬†for details. Most of the performances are in Icelandic, but two will be held in English. On Wednesday, December 1, visual artists Lukas Bury and Weronika Balcerak will present ‚ÄúThey have no pictures on the walls,‚Äù which is ‚Äúan artistic research project that aims at in-depth research of the Polish immigrant community in Iceland.‚Äù The lunchtime lecture is free to attend, but pre-registration is required (more information¬†here). The three-part performance ‚ÄúA Thousand Ways,‚Äù has been performed in phases throughout the world. During L√≥kal, theatre-makers 600 Highwaymen respond to our ‚Äúalready-strained coexistences and interactions,‚Äù which have been ‚Äúfurther fractured and flattened by virtual gatherings‚Äù and offer the audience ‚Äúa new chance at making contact with a stranger.‚Äù This performance requires direct participation: ‚ÄúYou and another person, seated at a table, separated by a pane of glass, a stack of cards between you. A new type of theater emerges.‚Äù (More information and tickets¬†here.) The full program of events can be found on the L√≥kal website, in English,¬†here. Masks are required at all in-person events and attendees at any show held at Tjarnarb√≠√≥ must get a rapid antigen COVID test no more than 48 hours before the event and furnish proof of a negative result at the door.

headline: ‚ÄúEverything About the Immigrant Experience In Iceland In Poetic Form‚Äù
body: Una publishing house recently released¬†P√≥lif√≥n√≠a af erlendum uppruna, a collection of poetry by immigrants to Iceland. The book features fifteen different poets from nine different countries exploring aspects of their immigrant experiences. A press release proclaims that ‚Äúit‚Äôs high time that the voices of immigrants are heard in Icelandic literature and this book is a good start.‚Äù The concept was conceived by editor and one of the featured writers Natasha Stolyarova in collaboration with Una publishing house. After reading the work of Danish-Palestinian poet Yahya Hassan, she wondered about the lack of immigrant voices in Icelandic literature. During times of gathering limitations due to the pandemic, she rounded up some active poets and writers in Iceland ‚Äì all immigrants to Iceland. ‚ÄúI knew around half of the writers already,‚Äù Natasha told Iceland Review. ‚ÄúThe others were recommended to me when I shared the idea for the project.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe first met in the summer of 2020,‚Äù she continues. ‚ÄúSometimes in person and other times over zoom, when the pandemic was raging.‚Äù They passed around notes of open-ended questions about their experiences in Iceland, of the country, the language, the people, and their interactions with them. This inspired some of the poets to write new work, while others submitted older work they felt fit the theme. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs everything they had to say about their experience as an immigrant in Iceland, in poetic form.‚Äù Even though the work is now complete, the group is now working on promoting the book and attending poetry readings and literary events during the so-called Christmas book flood. ‚ÄúSo much has happened since we started this. People have moved away from Iceland and back again. Two of the poets have had children!‚Äù Natasha tells me. The book is intended for Icelandic readers. All the featured poems are in Icelandic, some were written in Icelandic while others appear in the original language as well as Icelandic translations. With writers from 11 countries ‚Äì including Russia, Italy, Colombia, Serbia, Denmark, Finland, India, Poland, the US, and Canada ‚Äì the book has poems in languages such as English, Portuguese, and Finnish, and one poet even writes in their own version of the Icelandic language and developed their own script. The writers of¬†P√≥l√≠f√≥n√≠a af erlendum uppruna¬†are Ana Mjallhv√≠t Drekad√≥ttir, a rawlings, Deepa R. Iyengar, El√≠as Kn√∂rr, Ewa Marcinek, Francesca Cricelli, Giti Chandra, Jakub Stachowiak, Juan Camilo Roman Estrada, Mao Alheimsd√≥ttir, Meg Matich, Natasha Stolyarova, Randi W. Stebbins, Sofie Hermansen Eriksdatter, and Vilja-Tuulia Huotarinen, with translations by A√∞alsteinn √Åsberg Sigur√∞sson, Brynja Hj√°lmsd√≥ttir, Gunnhildur J√≥natansd√≥ttir, Helga Soff√≠a Einarsd√≥ttir, K√°ri Tulinius, Magnea J. Matth√≠asd√≥ttir, and √û√≥rd√≠s Helgad√≥ttir.

headline: √ìlafur Arnalds Nominated For Two Grammy Awards
body: Musician √ìlafur Arnalds has been nominated for two Grammies at the 2022 Grammy Awards, one for best dance/electronic recording and another for Best Arrangement, Instruments and Vocals. √ìlafur is nominated in two out of the Grammies‚Äô 86 categories. Loom by √ìlafur Arnalds featuring Bonobo is nominated in the category of Best Dance/Electronic Recording. He is also nominated for Best Arrangement, Instrument and Vocals for the song The Bottom Line, performed by him and Josin. This is the first time √ìlafur is nominated for a Grammy but he has been nominated for a Bafta and an Emmy before. √ìlafur told R√öV he hadn‚Äôt booked his flight to California yet for the January 31 award ceremony, but that he is very pleased with his nominations.  ¬†

headline: Nordic Noir Author Arnaldur Indri√∞ason Awarded
body: Best-selling Nordic noir author Arnaldur Indri√∞ason was awarded the J√≥nas Hallgr√≠msson Prize yesterday. The award is given annually on November 16, Icelandic Language Day, to individuals whose work has helped the Icelandic language flourish through writing, teaching, or scholarship. Arnaldur‚Äôs books have sold over 14 million copies worldwide and have been translated into 40 languages. Arnaldur is a prolific writer whose crime fiction books are popular in Iceland as well as abroad. In 2006, his novel Jar City was made into a film directed by Baltasar Korm√°kur. On receiving the award yesterday, Arnaldur stated that he was accepting it on behalf of all crime fiction writers in Iceland. ‚ÄúI believe the award is also a recognition of the branch of literature of which I have been a representative for about a quarter of a century and has flourished in our literary flora in recent years,‚Äù he stated. Podcast host Vera Illugad√≥ttir also received special recognition at the ceremony. Vera is the creator of the Icelandic-language podcast series √ç lj√≥si s√∂gunnar, produced by R√öV. The podcast presents global history in a gripping, narrative format, often telling of historic events that have rarely been written about in Icelandic.

headline: Icelandic Language Day Celebrated
body: Today is Icelandic Language Day, celebrated in Iceland annually on November 16. The goal of the day is to remember the importance of the Icelandic language within Icelandic society and celebrate its past, present, and future. Icelandic is an Indo-European language, belonging to the group of Germanic languages. This group also includes Danish, Norwegian, Swedish, and Faroese. Of these languages, Faroese and Norwegian are the most closely related to Icelandic. The Icelandic language is notable for its relative stability over the past millennium: modern Icelandic speakers can read and understand the Icelandic sagas, written around a thousand years ago. Icelandic Language Day will be celebrated today with an official program of events in the National Museum of Iceland in Reykjav√≠k. The events include the presentation of the J√≥nas Hallgr√≠msson Prize and will be streamed live on the government website. November 16 was chosen for the holiday as it is the birth date of J√≥nas Hallgr√≠msson¬†(1807-1845). J√≥nas was an Icelandic poet and translator and a strong advocate for Iceland‚Äôs independence from Denmark. Iceland Review regularly covers stories related to the Icelandic language, including why many foreigners struggle to learn Icelandic and the future of Icelandic language technology. For readers interested in learning the Icelandic language, this list of online resources is a good place to start.

headline: Sigr√∫n P√°lsd√≥ttir Wins 2021 EU Prize for Literature
body: Writer Sigr√∫n P√°lsd√≥ttir was awarded the European Union Prize for Literature (EUPL) on November 9. The EUPL honours a single writer per participating country once every three years. Sigr√∫n P√°lsd√≥ttir is the fourth Icelandic author to receive the prize. The European Union Prize for Literature (EUPL) was established in 2009 and is an annual initiative to recognize the best emerging fiction writers in Europe. The EUPL also aims to ‚Äúpromote the circulation and translation of literature amongst European countries.‚Äù For authors to be eligible for the prize, their country must participate in the Creative Europe Programme, which currently includes over 40 countries: the 28 EU member states, the three EEA countries (including Iceland), the candidate and potential candidate countries for accession to the EU, and the European Neighbourhood Policy countries. The EUPL is organized into three-year cycles. Each year, national juries comprised of experts in literature, publishing, and bookselling are organized into a ‚Äúrotating third of the participating countries.‚Äù After settling on a shortlist of two to five books from their nation‚Äôs most promising writers, each jury selects its national winner. As noted on the EUPL‚Äôs website: ‚Äúall participating countries are thus represented across cycles of three years, with the prize awarding one winning book/author per country.‚Äù The 2021 EUPL award ceremony was held on November 9 at the culture house Flagey in Brussels, Belgium. Thirteen authors from 13 different countries were recognized. This year, the jury selected writer and historian Sigr√∫n P√°lsd√≥ttir as its Icelandic winner (the award had previously been announced in May of this year). Sigr√∫n was honoured for her 2019 novel Embroidery (also been translated as Runaround and the Nonsense Trip), which revolves around a 19th-century Icelandic woman named Sigurl√≠na: ‚ÄúShe disappears from Reykjavik, along with a historical relic from her father‚Äôs collection. Through a series of incredible events, the artefact is unveiled at The Metropolitan Museum of New York.‚Äù As noted in the jury‚Äôs review,¬†‚ÄúEmbroidery is the product of an author who has achieved mastery of both form and style ‚Ä¶ the narrative is concise and lean ‚Ä¶ and the novel is at once original and modern but at the same time incredibly accessible and fun.‚Äù Sigr√∫n P√°lsd√≥ttir is the fourth Icelandic writer to win the EUPL. Previous winners are Halld√≥ra K. Thoroddsen, Oddn√Ω Eir √Üvarsd√≥ttir, and √ìfeigur Sigur√∞sson. According to the EUPL‚Äôs website, each laureate of the EUPL receives 750,000 ISK (‚Ç¨5,000 / 5,700$) and their awarded book is given support for translation and promotion. ‚ÄúA EUPL anthology is also published every year, which features excerpts from all laureates‚Äô awarded books both in the original language and in an English or French translation.‚Äù

headline: Skyr Exhibition Opens in Selfoss
body: The history of skyr production and consumption is the subject of a new exhibition that was just opened in Selfoss, South Iceland. Called Skyrland, the exhibition tells visitors the story behind Iceland‚Äôs characteristic dairy product, from the first settlers to the 21st century. The exhibition is located in Selfoss‚Äô newly built city centre in the same building as a food hall. At Skyrland ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll discover how 40 generations of women passed their skyr-making knowledge down, from mother to daughter, and how the story moved from isolated turf-roofed farms, to the world,‚Äù the exhibition‚Äôs website states. The exhibition features stops for all senses, including a ‚Äústory wall,‚Äù an immersive scent exhibit, and even a tasting session for those who want to try the delicacy. Skyr is a high-protein, low-fat, cultured dairy product. It is technically a cheese but it is consumed like a yogurt. Skyr has a sour flavour and is produced and sold commercially with added flavouring like blueberry or vanilla. It has been a staple of the Icelandic diet for centuries and is even mentioned in a number of Medieval sagas. Cultural historian Hallger√∞ur G√≠slad√≥ttir has suggested that skyr was produced across Scandinavia at the time Iceland was settled, but the tradition was lost elsewhere after that period.

headline: Gl√≠ma: Icelandic Wrestling Applies for UNESCO Status
body: Icelandic wrestling, known as gl√≠ma, could soon be on the UNESCO list of intangible cultural heritage, R√öV reports. The sport involves wrestlers gripping their opponent by the waist and attempting to throw them to the ground. Gl√≠ma was brought to Iceland by Norwegian settlers. Though originally opponents held onto each other‚Äôs trousers, in 1905 a special belt or harness was introduced to the sport, allowing wrestlers to have a better grip on each other. The sport is known for emphasising technique over force and was featured in a demonstration at the 1912 Summer Olympics. Gu√∞mundur Stef√°n Gunnarsson teaches gl√≠ma in Njar√∞v√≠k, Southwest Iceland. He is working to get the sport onto UNESCO‚Äôs official list of intangible cultural heritage. It recently reached the first milestone in that process, which is to be registered as Icelandic cultural heritage. According to Gu√∞mundur Stef√°n, the atmosphere of gl√≠ma is very positive and competitions are characterised by respect among athletes. Hei√∞r√∫n Fj√≥la P√°lsd√≥ttir, an award-winning gl√≠ma competitor who teaches alongside Gu√∞mundur, agrees. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs such incredibly good morale in Icelandic gl√≠ma. Everyone is friends and it‚Äôs always so much fun.‚Äù More information about gl√≠ma is available in English on the website Lifandi hef√∞ir (Living Traditions).

headline: 46 Years Since First Women‚Äôs Day Off in Iceland
body: Yesterday marked 46 years since Iceland‚Äôs first ‚ÄúWomen‚Äôs Day Off,‚Äù when women left their workplaces and took to the streets to protest the gender pay gap. Around 25,000 women attended that first protest in L√¶kjartorg square, which sparked similar movements around the world. Women‚Äôs average salary in Iceland is still just 77.2% of men‚Äôs average salary, according to the newest figures from Statistics Iceland. The first Women‚Äôs Day Off was held in 1975, and five more protests have been organised in Iceland since then: in 1985, 2005, 2010, 2016, and 2018. No public protest was held this year due to the COVID-19 pandemic, though the Women‚Äôs History Archives held a feminist history walk yesterday in downtown Reykjav√≠k. Despite legislation intended to ensure equal pay, Iceland‚Äôs gender pay gap persists. As of last year, women still filled less than 25% of CEO and chair positions in Icelandic businesses and the proportion of women on boards for companies with more than 50 employees was just under 35% in 2019.

headline: The Norse Settled in North America 1,000 Years Ago, Research Shows
body: In an article in Nature published yesterday, researchers claim to have determined the precise date of Nordic settlements in Newfoundland. By employing a novel dating technique, researchers provide evidence that the wood used in the construction of timber-framed buildings in L‚ÄôAnse aux Meadows was cut in AD 1021. It‚Äôs widely accepted that the Norse people arrived in North America long before Christopher Columbus. Despite the general acceptance of this theory, there has been only one confirmed Norse settlement site in the Americas: L‚ÄôAnse aux Meadows, Newfoundland (a UNESCO World Heritage Site). Since the latter half of the 20th century, extensive field campaigns have been conducted at the site, with much knowledge having been gleaned about the settlement and its contemporary environment. The precise age of the site has never been scientifically established; most previous estimates have been based on analysis of architectural remains, artefacts, and interpretations of the Icelandic sagas. According to a new article published in the journal Nature, however, researchers claim to have discovered the precise age of the settlement in L‚ÄôAnse aux Meadows. By employing a novel dating technique ‚Äì which uses a solar storm in 992 as a reference point ‚Äì researchers were able to analyze the tree rings of wood from timber-framed buildings on the site (widely thought to have belonged to Vikings) to determine that the wood was cut in AD 1021. This means that the Norse arrived in North America 471 years before Columbus. As noted in the article: ‚ÄúOur result of AD‚Äâ1021 for the cutting year constitutes the only secure calendar date for the presence of Europeans across the Atlantic before the voyages of Columbus. Moreover, the fact that our results, on three different trees, converge on the same year is notable and unexpected. This coincidence strongly suggests Norse activity at L‚ÄôAnse aux Meadows in AD‚Äâ1021. Further evidence reinforces this conclusion.‚Äù This article was updated at 21:33.

headline: Lamb to Be Iceland‚Äôs 2022 Oscar Submission
body: The Icelandic Film and TV Academy has chosen Lamb to be Iceland‚Äôs submission to the 2022 Academy Awards, or Oscars, R√öV reports. Lamb (titled D√Ωri√∞ in Icelandic) has already snagged two nominations and one award at Cannes and is already the highest-grossing Icelandic film to be screened in the United States. The film is directed by Valdimar J√≥hannsson, who wrote the script alongside Icelandic author Sj√≥n. Lamb stars Noomi Rapace and Hilmir Sn√¶r Gu√∞nason, who play Mar√≠a and Ingvar, a childless couple in the Icelandic countryside who discover a mysterious newborn on their farm. While at first, ‚Äúthe unexpected prospect of family life brings them much joy,‚Äù it ultimately destroys them. The jury of the Icelandic Film and TV Academy praised the film‚Äôs strong imagery and originality. ‚ÄúFrom the first moment, the viewer is captured and hypnotizes through a mysterious and exciting adventure,‚Äù the jury wrote. Their statement called the film a ‚Äúcareful study of human nature, sorrow, and loss.‚Äù Lamb is currently showing in Icelandic theatres.

headline: Trapped Season Three Premieres in Iceland
body: There‚Äôs something for both local and international viewers in the third series of popular Icelandic TV show Trapped, which premiered in Iceland last night. Familiar faces from Iceland‚Äôs music and media scenes will impress Icelanders with their handling of minor roles while beautiful landscape shots will charm Icelandophiles abroad, the guests of a new R√öV podcast on the series argued. √ìlafur Darri √ìlafsson stars as usual in the role of Detective Andri, this time investigating a murder committed on the property of a religious cult in North Iceland. The creators of Trapped began working on the third season of the show as early as December 2018. Filming finally began in Siglufj√∂r√∞ur, North Iceland in September of last year. Shooting was subject to COVID safety protocols: cast and crew had their temperature taken daily when arriving on set, and a COVID safety supervisor was on set at all times to make sure distancing and mask-wearing regulations were followed. Among the musicians featured in the show is former Eurovision singer turned yoga teacher Ingibj√∂rg Stef√°nsd√≥ttir, who is convincing as a meditation guide at the cult. Rock DJ Andrea J√≥nsd√≥ttir, well-known to locals in Iceland, appears in a bar scene, while hip-hop artist Fl√≥ni also appears in the show. It remains to be seen whether the show‚Äôs third series will enjoy as much success as the first two.

headline: Impostor Poets Make Impressive International Debut
body: Fr√≠√∞a √çsberg and √û√≥ra Hj√∂rleifsd√≥ttir, two members of Iceland‚Äôs Impostor Poets collective, are catching the attention of readers around the world. √û√≥ra‚Äôs novel Magma (translated by Meg Matich), was included on Oprah‚Äôs list of the 21 best books in English translation to be published in fall 2021. And translation rights to Fr√≠√∞a‚Äôs Merking (The Mark) were sold to five countries before the book had even been published in Iceland. Narrated in elegantly spare, visceral language, Magma tells the story of 20-year-old Lilja, whose whirlwind love affair with a charismatic, confident, and self-important classmate quickly and almost imperceptibly turns abusive. ‚ÄúIn impressionistic, mesmerizing chapters, Hj√∂sleifsd√≥ttir [sic] dives deep into the fire-rivers of lust,‚Äù Hamilton Cain at Oprah Daily concluded, ‚Äú[and] just how much humiliation we‚Äôre willing to tolerate in the name of love.‚Äù Magma also caught the attention of book reviewer Tammy Tarng, who included it as one of the New York Times‚Äô Globetrotting picks this summer, while reviewers Annabel Gutterman, Cady Lang, and Raisa Bruner at Time named it as one of the ‚Äú36 Books You Need to Read This Summer.‚Äù Merking is a work of speculative fiction that is centered around the Empathy Test. According to its supporters, the test can establish whether the taker is a moral and compassionate person, while its detractors believe that it is an unjust infringement on privacy and autonomy. The novel was only just published in Iceland this week, but prior to its publication, has already found homes in five other countries around the world: Laffont in France, Hoffman & Campe in Germany, Gyldendal in Denmark, Norstedts in Sweden, and De Geus in The Netherlands. Magma and Merking are both √û√≥ra and Fr√≠√∞a‚Äôs first novels. Fr√≠√∞a previously published two poetry collections and a collection of short stories that was nominated for the Nordic Council Literary Prize. Along with the other four members of their Impostor Poets Collective, √û√≥ra and Fr√≠√∞a have also co-authored three books of poetry and a novel, Ol√≠a (Oil) which came out in Iceland this month as well.

headline: New Film Casts Iceland‚Äôs Polish Community in New Light
body: Wolka arrives in Icelandic theatres today, R√öV reports. The Polish-Icelandic production made its debut at this year‚Äôs Reykjav√≠k International Film Festival and is the last film made by director √Årni √ìlafur √Åsgeirsson, who died last spring¬†at the age of 49, just three months after being diagnosed with cancer. Wolka tells the story of a Polish woman who has just finished a 15-year sentence in prison for murder. For reasons known only to herself, she breaks parole and travels to Iceland in search of a woman. The film, √Årni √ìlafur‚Äôs fourth, was in the works for some time‚Äîalmost a decade, in fact. √Årni √ìlafur, who was married to Polish set designer Marta Luiza Macuga, had lived in Poland and wanted to make a movie about Polish society in Iceland. After moving back to Iceland, he met screenwriter Michal Godzic. They began working on the script together and nine years later, the film is finally ready for audiences. In addition to its debut at RIFF, a special screening of Wolka was also held in the Westman Islands. ‚ÄúIt was certainly emotional for my son and I,‚Äù said Marta. ‚ÄúIt was so strange to be there without √Årni. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll ever go back to the Westmans. Wherever I went, I felt like √Årni should be there with us. It was easier here in Reykjav√≠k, the team was with me so it was more bearable. I could enjoy it more and celebrate the movie coming out. It‚Äôs done and people will appreciate it.‚Äù Olga Bo≈ÇƒÖd≈∫, one of Poland‚Äôs most prominent film stars, played the leading role of Anna. ‚ÄúI met √Årni √ìlafur in Poland,‚Äù she recalled. ‚ÄúHe called and asked if I wanted to play Anna. I read the script and fell for it, it was such a beautiful role that offered up so many possibilities. I said yes‚Äîyes, thank you. He was one of the most remarkable directors I‚Äôve ever worked with.‚Äù Filming in the Westmans during the winter was difficult, Olga noted, but she recalled it positively. ‚ÄúIt was hard because of the weather, it was freezing. But Iceland is such a beautiful country and the people friendly and showed me such kindness, especially the Poles because everywhere I went, I met Poles. They were really proud that there was a film being made about Poles who live in Iceland. I hope that they‚Äôll like it.‚Äù Olga believes that Wolka is a story that will have a broad appeal. ‚ÄúThe film is part mystery and part adventure, but it is also a family drama. I think that everyone can relate to family drama.‚Äù And while the story may have particular significance for Poles living in Iceland, Olga believes that it will expand people‚Äôs notions about this community. ‚ÄúThe story is certainly about Polish society [in Iceland], but it shows it in a new light. √Årni wanted to show that Poles are not just a labour force, but also people with feelings, who laugh and cry. We are normal people like all other nations.‚Äù An earlier version of the article falsely stated that √Årni passed away last year.¬†

headline: Arnaldur Turns to History, Not Crime, This Christmas
body: World-famous author Arnaldur Indri√∞ason will not be putting out a new crime novel during this year‚Äôs j√≥lab√≥kafl√≥√∞, or Christmas Book Flood, mbl.is reports. Arnaldur has released a new book every November 1st for the last 24 years, and his crime novels‚Äîwhether they star Detectives Erlendur, Konr√°√∞, or Flovent and Thorson‚Äîare a particularly popular part of the season. This year, however, Arnaldur is trying something new and releasing a work of historical fiction. Many of Arnaldur‚Äôs novels are set in the past, but on top of being distinctly un-criminal in nature, his new book, Sigurverki√∞ (a title which can mean both ‚ÄòWinning Entry‚Äô and ‚ÄòWatchworks‚Äô) moves to an entirely new era. It takes place in the southern part of the Westfjords in Iceland and Copenhagen, Denmark during the 18th century and tells the story of J√≥n S√≠vertsen, an Icelandic watchmaker working in a Danish palace to restore magnificent, old clock. One day, the King himself, Christian VII, comes into the J√≥n‚Äôs workshop. Although still king in name, Christian, who suffers from mental illness, has been sidelined by his son and court. In the course of their conversation, J√≥n tells Christian about his father and foster mother, who were killed at the behest of the previous monarch. In his interview with Morgunbla√∞i√∞, Arnaldur said that the idea for the story ‚Äúcame to me very suddenly. I got the idea for the book last summer and immediately sat down to write and finished it in about six months.‚Äù The book takes inspiration from real people and events, although Arnaldur has combined and refigured details to suit his narrative. And as the era is not one that he‚Äôs written before, he enlisted the assistance of a historian while writing. ‚ÄúIt was a lot of fun for me to write about the 18th century because it is, of course, a new arena for me as an author, but it‚Äôs also an interesting possibly new arena for contemporary Icelandic literature.‚Äù Arnaldur says that he wants to continue to surprise himself as a writer, but that doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean that he‚Äôll be writing a lot more historical fiction from here on out. He‚Äôs not sure what the future holds on that count but will be making a return to crime fiction soon. ‚ÄúKonr√°√∞, the rather skewed protagonist of my last books, will be in full swing next Christmas,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat I can I promise.‚Äù

headline: Bj√∂rk‚Äôs Harpa Concert Series Supports Women‚Äôs Shelter
body: Guests filled Harpa Concert Hall in Reykjav√≠k last night for the first evening of musician Bj√∂rk Gu√∞mundsd√≥ttir‚Äôs four-concert series in support of Kvennaathvarfi√∞ women‚Äôs shelter. The concerts were postponed seven times due to COVID restrictions and are Bj√∂rk‚Äôs first performances in Iceland in three years. Twenty per cent of the profits from the concert series will go to Kvennaathvarfi√∞ women‚Äôs shelter in Reykjav√≠k, specifically to support children ‚Äì the shelter houses on average 11 kids at any given time, R√öV reports. The concerts are acoustic (performed without electronics and beats) and feature the Iceland Symphony Orchestra, Hamrahl√≠√∞ Choir, and other local musicians. Though tickets to the concerts are sold out, those interested can follow along virtually. In Iceland, the concerts are broadcast live on R√öV‚Äôs Channel 2 as well as on via radio on R√°s 1. Those located abroad can also purchase access to the live stream. The remaining concerts will be held on October 24 and 31 and November 15.

headline: Lamb Has Become Highest-Grossing Icelandic Film in US
body: Icelandic film Lamb (D√Ωri√∞) earned over $1 million [‚Ç¨ 864,000; ISK 130 million] in ticket sales in the United States last weekend, according to Box Office Mojo and has grossed $1.13 million worldwide. It was the seventh most popular film in US theatres last weekend. These figures make the film the highest-grossing of any Icelandic film screened in the US. Directed by Valdimar J√≥hannsson, Lamb is a supernatural drama that follows a childless couple, Mar√≠a and Ingvar, as they ‚Äúdiscover a mysterious newborn on their farm in Iceland. The unexpected prospect of family life brings them much joy, before ultimately destroying them,‚Äù a plot summary of the film explains. Valdimar wrote the script alongside Icelandic author Sj√≥n. The film stars Hilmir Sn√¶r Gu√∞nason alongside Swedish actress Noomi Rapace, who learned to deliver a lamb for the role. Lamb had its world premiere at the Cannes film festival earlier this year, where it won the Un Certain Regard prize, granted for originality. It is currently showing in Icelandic theatres.

headline: Iceland‚Äôs Culture Industry Needs More Support
body: The 2008 banking collapse and the coronavirus pandemic have impacted Iceland‚Äôs culture industry more negatively than other industries. There are 25% fewer people working in culture in Iceland today than there were in 2008. The data are from a report published by the Icelandic Confederation of University Graduates (BHM) today. BHM emphasised the importance of a government policy that increases support for the arts in order to avoid permanent damage from the pandemic. According to the report, there has been a sharp decline in wage payments and the number of people working in the creative industries in Iceland in recent years. There are 25% fewer people working in the culture industry now than in 2008, while the total decline in wage payments amounts to 40%. The creative industries began to decline significantly after 2013, and the contraction increased significantly after 2017. While COVID-19 is an obvious factor, the development in Iceland‚Äôs culture industry precedes the pandemic. In the last four years, total salary payments in the media industry have decreased by around 45%; in the film industry by 41%; and in the music sector by 26%. While the development began earlier, the economic shock of the pandemic made the situation go from bad to worse, the report states. BHM points out that most artists have a university degree under their belt. Despite their education, however, artists‚Äô salaries were considerably lower than the average salaries of others working full time in 2020. Artists‚Äô salaries have fallen far behind the general wage trend and now compare to the lowest salaries on the Icelandic job market. While the wage index has risen by 96% in recent years, artists‚Äô salaries have risen by 49%. Low wages could explain contraction in individual sectors, such as in the publishing industry. While in 2011, 5.2 books were published in Iceland per 1,000 inhabitants, that number fell to 3.4 in 2019. BHM says Iceland‚Äôs government can look to the Nordic countries as an example of how to increase support for the arts in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic. ‚ÄúOtherwise,‚Äù the report states, ‚Äúthere is a risk that cultural industries will suffer permanent damage from the pandemic.‚Äù

headline: The Garden Sweeps Up at Iceland‚Äôs Edda Awards
body: Iceland‚Äôs Edda Awards ceremony took place last night, handing out accolades to the best film and television produced last year. Ragnar Bragason‚Äôs film The Garden (Gullregn) swept up at the ceremony, taking home 9 awards from its 12 nominations. The film won in the categories Best Film, Best Director, Best Script, and Best Actress. The Garden tells the story of Ind√≠ana (Sigr√∫n Edda Bj√∂rnsd√≥ttir), who lives in a council estate, where she tends to an award-winning tree. Her world is turned on its head when her son J√≥nas (Ey√æ√≥r Gunnlaugsson) turns up with a foreign girlfriend (Karolina Gruszka). Another notable winner was the St√∂√∞ 2 TV series RAX Augnablik, focusing on the career of photographer Ragnar Axelsson. √ìlafur Darri √ìlafsson of Trapped fame took home the Best Actor award for the leading role in The Minister (R√°√∞herrann). Comedian Ari Eldj√°rn‚Äôs Netflix special Pardon My Icelandic took home the award for Best Comedy Show. The Icelandic trailer for The Garden can be seen below.

headline: N√≠na Tryggvad√≥ttir Museum Founded After Generous Donation
body: The Mayor of Reykjav√≠k Dagur B. Eggertsson and Una D√≥ra Copley ‚Äì daughter of artist N√≠na Tryggvad√≥ttir ‚Äì have signed an agreement for the establishment of the N√≠na Tryggvad√≥ttir Art Museum. It will be the first art museum dedicated to a woman artist in Reykjav√≠k. For the past months, work has been done to finalize contracts, register museum assets, compose a charter, and to settle inheritance issues in preparation for the founding of the N√≠na Tryggvad√≥ttir Art Museum. Last Thursday, Mayor Dagur B. Eggertsson, on behalf of the City of Reykjav√≠k, and Una D√≥ra Copley, N√≠na Tryggvad√≥ttir‚Äôs only daughter, signed a formal agreement at the H√∂f√∞i House in Reykjav√≠k. The museum will be housed in the eastern part of Hafnarh√∫si√∞. As the western half of the building houses the Reykjav√≠k Art Museum, the entire building will now be dedicated to the arts. The agreement provides that Una D√≥ra Copley will donate over a thousand works of art by N√≠na Tryggvad√≥ttir that reflect the artist‚Äôs entire career. The art in question includes paintings, drawings, glass art, and watercolours. Additionally, Una D√≥ra will bequeath real estate in Manhattan and Reykjav√≠k to the City of Reykjav√≠k, along with other works of art, a library, and more. N√≠na Tryggvad√≥ttir (1913-1968) was known primarily as a painter, although she also composed and illustrated children‚Äôs books. She was born on March 16, 1913 in Sey√∞isfj√∂r√∞ur and died on June 18, 1968. As a young artist, she studied drawing under the tutelage √Åsgr√≠mur J√≥nsson. Alongside her studies at the Reykjav√≠k Women‚Äôs Gymnasium, N√≠na studied art at the Academy of Finnur J√≥nsson and J√≥hann Briem. She later studied painting at Det Kongelige Akadmi for de Sk√∏nne Kunsten in Copenhagen. N√≠na lived in Paris, London, and New York but always maintained a close connection to Iceland, where she held many private exhibitions. She was an active member of the abstract expressionist movement in New York, and her art can be found in museums and private collections around the world. On Thursday, the City Board of Reykjav√≠k announced that it would call for ideas and perspectives on a design competition to renovate Hafnarh√∫s to house the N√≠na Tryggvad√≥ttir Art Museum, to expand the premises of the Reykjav√≠k Art Museum, and to create space within the building to be dedicated to painting and other art-related activity. The City will call for diverse voices ranging from artists; residents, of all ages; the Reykjav√≠k Art Museum; sponsors of the N√≠na Tryggvad√≥ttir Art Museum; the Err√≥ Museum; the Iceland University of the Arts; the Harpa Conference Hall; and other interested parties.

headline: Gr√≠msey Residents Turn Down Offer of Church from Keflav√≠k
body: The residents of Gr√≠msey island, North Iceland, have turned down the offer of a church building from the Keflav√≠k Airport Firefighting Staff Association, Morgunbla√∞i√∞ reports. Residents are instead fundraising to build a new church after the island‚Äôs historic church burned down on September 21. The staff association offered to give Gr√≠msey residents a church building that is currently located beside the fire station at Keflav√≠k Airport. Alfre√∞ Gar√∞arson, parish council director on Gr√≠msey told Morgunbla√∞i√∞ that while the offer was very generous, residents had decided at a meeting that the church building from Keflav√≠k did not suit the island‚Äôs needs. Gr√≠msey island is the northernmost point of Iceland and has 67 inhabitants. Named Mi√∞gar√∞akirkja, the church that burned down on the island was built out of driftwood in 1867. The cause of the fire is being investigated, but it is believed to have started from an old electrical panel. The Bishop of Iceland has stated that the National Church will assist Gr√≠msey residents to the best of its ability in rebuilding the destroyed church.

headline: COVID-19 in Iceland: Free Rapid Tests Possible Key to Looser Restrictions
body: Public health insurance will cover the cost of rapid antigen tests as of September 20, including those required by private organisations such as concert venues. The aim is to increase the public‚Äôs access to rapid antigen tests and enable more parties to offer testing free of charge. Current domestic COVID regulations allow events of up to 1,500 guests provided attendees undergo rapid testing. Iceland‚Äôs Chief Epidemiologist √û√≥r√≥lfur Gu√∞nason told Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞ that rapid tests could be the key to a more open society in the coming weeks. When the pandemic began, Icelandic health authorities at first used exclusively PCR tests to screen for the SARS-CoV-2 virus. Rapid antigen tests were approved for use much later and have only come into general use in recent weeks for border testing and for individuals who are not required to quarantine but may have been exposed to the virus. New domestic regulations came into effect on September 15, raising the general gathering limit from 200 to 500 people. Events with up to 1,500 guests are permitted if all guests supply negative rapid test results. ‚ÄúIn order for the introduction of rapid tests to serve its purpose of increasing people‚Äôs opportunities to attend a variety of events and pursue cultural activities, it is important to have easy access to rapid tests and that their cost is not cumbersome,‚Äù a government notice states. The capital area healthcare service has offered rapid testing at Su√∞urlandsbraut 34 in Reykjav√≠k, and other public healthcare centres offer rapid testing in various regions of the country. Private providers currently offer rapid tests at BS√ç, Kringlan, and Kleppsm√Ωrarvegur in Reykjav√≠k; A√∞algata 60 in Reykjanesb√¶r; and the University of Akureyri in North Iceland. The regulation comes into effect on September 20 and is valid until the end of this year.

headline: ‚ÄúThe story continues:‚Äù Historic I√∞n√≥ Reopens Tomorrow
body: One of Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs most historic buildings, theatre and event space I√∞n√≥, will reopen tomorrow, putting an end to a closure that lasted nearly one and a half years. The venue‚Äôs new managers promise it will stay open from morning till night and welcome locals and visitors of all ages. The venue was forced to close in May 2020, around two months after the COVID-19 pandemic reached Iceland. I√∞n√≥ reopens with a bang tomorrow, September 18, offering a full program of children‚Äôs events during the afternoon and live music in the evening. I√∞n√≥ (or I√∞na√∞armannah√∫si√∞ as it is rarely called), was built in 1896 and was first home to the Reykjav√≠k Theatre Company, one of the country‚Äôs oldest cultural organisations still in operation. The building has been a hub of cultural activities for decades and has housed many a historic event, including a party for Christian X, King of Denmark, when he visited Iceland in 1921. The venue‚Äôs new management has freshened up the building, including removing carpets to reveal original flooring and putting on a fresh coat of paint. Gu√∞finnur Karlsson of Priki√∞, I√∞n√≥‚Äôs head manager, told V√≠sir the venue‚Äôs doors will be open to all. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not just for members of Parliament. This is the house of the people, and never more so than now.‚Äù

headline: The Reykjav√≠k International Literary Festival Begins Today
body: The Reykjav√≠k International Literary Festival (RILF) begins today, Wednesday, September 8 and continues through Saturday, September 11. International authors Chimamanda Ngozi Adiche, Sa≈°a Stani≈°iƒá, and Le√Øla Slimani will be among the attendees, as will some of the most exciting emerging and established voices on the Icelandic literary scene. RILF has been held every two years since it began in 1985‚Äîthis is its 15th installment. It brings local literati together with authors, agents, and publishers from all over the world. This year‚Äôs opening remarks will be given by American journalist and writer Barbara Demick, who will address the subject of writers combating authoritarianism. Chimamanda Ngozi Adiche will give the Keynote Address on Friday. On the last day of programming, First Lady Eliza Reid will take part in a conversation on ‚ÄúIcelanders‚Äô Self-image in Literature and a Different Perspective.‚Äù All programs are free and open to the public; most are in English. See the full schedule of events on the RILF website here.

headline: Icelandic Thriller Blackport Takes Grand Prize at Series Mania 2021
body: The Icelandic TV series Blackport won the Grand Prize at the 2021 Series Mania festival yesterday. Blackport will premiere on R√öV on December 26 and is produced by Vesturport in collaboration with R√öV, ARTE France, and Turbine Studios. Based in Lille since 2018, Series Mania is a festival dedicated solely to European TV shows. This year marked the first in-person iteration of the festival since 2019. During the festival‚Äôs award ceremony yesterday, the Icelandic TV series Blackport (Verb√∫√∞) was honoured with the Grand Prize in the International Competition. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre on cloud nine,‚Äù actress N√≠na D√∂gg Filippusd√≥ttir remarked, speaking to Iceland Review from her home in Reykjav√≠k this morning. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre incredibly happy to have been accepted to the festival; we were competing with big productions, from the likes of HBO, so we weren‚Äôt exactly expecting to win. Being honoured with the grand prize far exceeded our expectations.‚Äù As noted by Screen Daily, Blackport is a ‚Äúpolitical thriller set in a once-thriving fishing port hit by quota restrictions in the mid-1980s.‚Äù Created by N√≠na D√∂gg Filippusd√≥ttir, G√≠sli √ñrn Gar√∞arson, and Bj√∂rn Hlynur Haraldsson, the series ‚Äì mainly shot in Su√∞ureyri and the Greater Reykjav√≠k area ‚Äì entered into production last summer and wrapped in August. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a long road, complicated by COVID-19; we shot part of the series in Hull and Grimsby, but travelling there last winter proved difficult in light of the pandemic,‚Äù N√≠na D√∂gg stated. The actress plays the lead role in the series along with Bj√∂rn Hlynur Haraldsson. Blackport also features G√≠sli √ñrn Gar√∞arsson, Unnur √ñsp Stef√°nsd√≥ttir, Hilmir Sn√¶r Gu√∞nason, Ingvar E. Sigur√∞sson, Steinunn √ìl√≠na √ûorsteinsd√≥ttir, and Selma Bj√∂rnsd√≥ttir. Blackport is produced by Vesturport in partnership with R√öV, ARTE France, and Turbine Studios. The series comprises eight episodes and will premiere on R√öV on December 26. ‚ÄúBefore the premiere, we‚Äôll be taking it to Mipcom in October and to another festival in Barcelona. From there, the ball will start rolling,‚Äù N√≠na D√∂gg stated.

headline: Iceland Airwaves Postponed Until 2022
body: The Iceland Airwaves music festival has been postponed until 2022 due to ongoing social restrictions in light of the COVID-19 pandemic. The festival will take place November 2-5 2022. Since the Delta variant reaches Iceland, social restrictions limiting gatherings of more than a couple of hundred people have been in place. According to a press release from Sena Live, which operates the festival, these restrictions make festivals such as Iceland Airwaves ‚ÄúEverything concerning rapid tests and festival guest‚Äôs access to them is still unclear. Other events (standing room and without rapid tests) continue to be limited to 200 people or fewer in each compartment. Read More: What‚Äôs the Status Of COVID-19 In Iceland? The most recent relaxations of the social restrictions due to the pandemic allow for 500 people to gather but they must remain in numbered seats, can‚Äôt face each other and have to wear masks until they sit down. Additionally, they must be able to present the results of a rapid test taken no less than 48 hours before the start of the event. ‚Äúraising the gathering limits to 500 people in numbered seats on the condition of rapid tests is a step in the right directions,‚Äù the notice reads, ‚Äúbut these limitations are still too restrictive to larger, standing events, and make it impossible to host events such as the Iceland Airwaves.‚Äù The notice states that ticketholders who want to attend Iceland Airwaves next year won‚Äôt need to take any action, their tickets will still be valid. Those who wish to be refunded can contact TIX by Friday, September 17. ‚ÄúWe encourage ticket holders to keep their tickets. This postponement doesn‚Äôt only affect Iceland Airwaves but all of Iceland‚Äôs music industry. By keeping your ticket, you support Icelandic music, which is hurting these days, the notice reads. Sena CEO √çsleifur √û√≥rhallsson told V√≠sir he considered this a tragedy for Iceland‚Äôs music industry and placed the blame squarely on authorities lack of will to The last Iceland Airwaves festival took place in 2019 as the 2020 festival was also postponed. The 2020 festival was replaced with Live From Reykjav√≠k ‚Äì a two-night online music festival celebrating Icelandic artists.

headline: Alma Nominated for Nordic Council Film Prize
body: Icelandic film Alma, written and directed by Krist√≠n J√≥hannesd√≥ttir, is Iceland‚Äôs nominee for the 2021 Nordic Council Film Prize. The award is accompanied by a prize of DKK 300,000 [ISK 5.9 million; $47,471] to be split equally among the screenwriter, director, and producer, and is given annually to a film from one of the five Nordic nations. The winner will be announced in an awards ceremony in Copenhagen on November 2. Per the Icelandic Film Centre, Alma is ‚Äúthe story of a young woman who is serving time in a psych ward for murdering her boyfriend, a crime she can‚Äôt remember. But when she discovers [he] is still alive, she decides to escape and kill him after all.‚Äù Rather than repeating typical tropes, however, the Icelandic selection committee noted that Alma allows its protagonist space for growth and healing. As they wrote in their nomination, ‚ÄúWhat starts out as a noirish revenge fable becomes a beautiful love story that centers around the process through which a victim of abuse finds her way through trauma and grief to finally rediscover her roots and her distinctive voice.‚Äù ‚ÄúEmploying biting humor as well as striking visual imagery, Alma deftly combines an intense poetic vision and a socially critical feminist angle.‚Äù Alma is Krist√≠n J√≥hannesd√≥ttir‚Äôs third feature (Rainbow‚Äôs End and As in Heaven) and was produced by Gudr√∫n Edda Th√≥rhannesd√≥ttir, Fridrik Th√≥r Fridriksson, and Egil √òdeg√•rd. It stars Sn√¶fr√≠dur Ingvarsd√≥ttir, Kristbj√∂rg Kjeld, Emmanuelle Riva, and Hilmir Sn√¶r Gudnason. Iceland has won the Nordic Council Film Prize three times since it started being awarded in 2002. Director Benedikt Erlingsson has won twice, for Of Horses and Men in 2014 and Woman at War in 2018, and Dagur K√°ri won for Virgin Mountain in 2015. B√≠√≥ Parad√≠s will be showing all of this year‚Äôs nominated films during its Nordic Film Festival, which will run from September 23 ‚Äì 26. All of the films will be shown with English subtitles.

headline: Czech Artist Converts Ship‚Äôs Wheelhouse into ‚ÄòCultural Kiosk‚Äô in Sey√∞isfj√∂r√∞ur
body: A ship‚Äôs wheelhouse dating back to 1969 is getting a new life as a piece of public art cum snack stand in the East Iceland village of Sey√∞isfj√∂r√∞ur, R√öV reports. The project, dubbed KIOSK 108, is the brainchild of Czech artist Monika Fryƒçov√°, who decided to turn her attentions outward during lockdown and find a way to make a meaningful contribution to the local community. The plan? To take an abandoned ship‚Äôs wheelhouse and convert it into a ‚Äòcultural kiosk.‚Äô ‚ÄúWhen the COVID situation came, I thought it‚Äôs very useless for me to sit behind [my] computer and wait [to get] sick,‚Äù Monika explained. ‚ÄúSo, I start[ed] to think about how I can make public art for outsiders and local people, to make something meaningful with this object.‚Äù Monika plans to serve light meals and drinks from the converted wheelhouse, including fish soup, hot dogs, coffee, and beer. She‚Äôs using old timber to build a small bar inside the cabin where people can sit and look out the window onto the fjord. She‚Äôs also plans to create a kid‚Äôs corner for children to play in and have a stage on the roof where musicians and artists can perform. Monika is selling KIOSK 108 stickers and t-shirts to raise money for the project, which has also received a grant from Uppbyggingarsj√≥√∞ur Austurlands, the East Iceland Development Fund.
