Watch Monika‚Äôs interview with R√öV (in English) here; and another video she made about KIOSK 108, here.

headline: Oscar-Winner Hildur Gu√∞nad√≥ttir Composes for Video Game
body: Composer and cellist Hildur Gu√∞nad√≥ttir is composing the music for the video game Battlefield 2042, R√öV reports. Hildur, who won both an Oscar and a Grammy for her score for the film Joker, is writing the soundtrack in collaboration with her husband, the English composer and sound artist Sam Slater. This is the first time she‚Äôs composed for a video game. Battlefield 2042 is a massively multiplayer first-person shooter game and the seventeenth installment in Swedish developer Dice‚Äôs popular Battlefield series. It is published by Electronic Arts. ‚ÄúWe are thrilled to be writing our first video game score for Battlefield 2042 and teaming with Electronic Arts,‚Äù Hildur and Sam wrote in a prepared statement. ‚ÄúIt was such a deeply creative experience to dive into this world and create a truly unique and disruptive musical environment for the game.‚Äù Battlefield 2042 comes out on October 22 on PC, PlayStation, and Xbox. The game score will be released on the same day on both vinyl and via leading streaming services.

headline: Cat Power Covers ‚ÄúI Think of Angels‚Äù for New Sean Penn Film
body: Today, August 20, marks the release of Sean Penn‚Äôs new film Flag Day. The soundtrack to the film comprises 13 songs, among them a cover of ‚ÄúI Think of Angels‚Äù ‚Äì originally composed by Icelandic musician KK ‚Äì as performed by American singer-songwriter Cat Power (Chan Marshall). Flag Day,¬†written by Jez and John-Henry Butterworth (Edge of Tomorrow), premiered at the Cannes Film Festival earlier this summer. The film stars Sean Penn, who also directs the film, and his daughter, Dylan. The film has received mixed reviews. As noted by Pitchfork, the film‚Äôs soundtrack features eight songs composed by Eddie Vedder (Pearl Jam) and Glen Hansard (The Frames, the Swell Season), in addition to a cover of the Icelandic ‚ÄúI Think of Angels‚Äù by Cat Power (Chan Marshall). ‚ÄúI Think of Angels‚Äù was composed by KK and performed in collaboration with his sister, Ellen Kristj√°nsd√≥ttir. The song pays tribute to the siblings‚Äô late sister, Inger, who died in a car crash in America in 1992. ‚ÄúI Think of Angels‚Äù was officially released in 1995 on the album Gle√∞if√≥lki√∞.¬†The song is often performed at funerals in Iceland. In an interview with Mbl.is, KK revealed that the producers of Flag Day reached out to him about two years ago: ‚ÄúI just said Yes, and then there were a few twists along the way, before, finally, it was decided that Cat Power would perform a cover of the song.‚Äù According to KK, Vald√≠s √ìskarsd√≥ttir ‚Äì who edited the film in collaboration with Michelle Tesoro ‚Äì suggested ‚ÄúI Think of Angels‚Äù to Sean Penn, and the director fell for the song immediately. KK is over the moon with Cat Power‚Äôs performance, sung an octave lower than the original, which he calls ‚Äúdivine.‚Äù Readers can listen to the song below.

headline: Iceland University of the Arts to Receive Permanent Home
body: The Iceland University of the Arts (Listah√°sk√≥li √çslands, or LH√ç), will be uniting all of its departments in a single, specially-designed facility in the Tollh√∫si√∞ building in downtown Reykjav√≠k, Iceland‚Äôs cabinet announced in a press conference this week. LH√ç has operated its departments in several disparate facilities since its inception in 1998. A design competition will be launched this autumn where participants will aim to show how all of the university‚Äôs operations can be consolidated under a single roof in Tollh√∫si√∞. Minister of Finance Bjarni Benediktsson announced the decision at a press conference on the Su√∞urnes peninsula last Tuesday, where the cabinet also presented several other measures in support of the arts. The initiatives include establishing a research centre for the creative industries at Bifr√∂st University and the Creative Iceland project, which would work on advancement within the creative industries in Iceland as well as their export. At the conference, Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir pointed to research showing that Iceland‚Äôs creative industries make a significant economic contribution to Iceland, while also stating they have immeasurable value toward forming the nation‚Äôs identity. Located near Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs Old Harbour, Tollh√∫si√∞ was designed by G√≠sli Halld√≥rsson and completed in 1970. Its original design included a harbour warehouse on the ground floor and a customs office for cruise ship passengers arriving in the harbour. After Sundah√∂fn harbour came into operation, however, activities at the old harbour decreased. The building features a mosaic by Ger√∞ur Helgad√≥ttir from 1973 depicting the harbour activities before the construction of Tollh√∫si√∞. The street below the mural is now under construction to transform a parking area into a pedestrian square.

headline: Stolen Artefacts Returned to Icelandic Museum 50 Years Later
body: Three artefacts have been returned to Glaumb√¶r Museum in North Iceland by post more than 50 years after they were stolen, R√öV reports. The museum staff was at first perplexed by the package, which contained no letter or explanation. They eventually contacted the sender in Germany, who had a strange explanation for the return of the items. Last week Glaumb√¶r Farm and Museum received a package from Germany in the post. The museum, a preserved turf farmhouse from the 18th and 19th centuries, often receives gifts in the post, though they are usually accompanied by letters explaining the origin and significance of the items enclosed. ‚ÄúThere were three things in the package: a creamer, a butter tub, and a small backgammon checker, which is like a chip for backgammon. There was no explanation with them, no letter or memo,‚Äù stated Inga Katr√≠n D. Magn√∫sd√≥ttir, project manager at Bygg√∞asafn Skagfir√∞inga (e. The Skagafj√∂r√∞ur Settlement Museum), to which Glaumb√¶r belongs. ‚Äú[‚Ä¶W]e didn‚Äôt understand a thing but the more we thought about it and the more information we found here at the museum, the more exciting it became.‚Äù A search in a database revealed more information about the objects. ‚ÄúThe creamer, it was so familiar that we started to suspect that maybe it was possibly from here and then we went into our database, sarpur.is, and searched for the items we thought it resembled and then it came to light that there was an entry for this creamer and a comment had been written under it: ‚ÄòDisappeared from the museum July 23, 1970‚Äô.‚Äù The museum staff decided to contact the sender who offered an interesting explanation for the items‚Äô return. ‚ÄúHe told us this story, that he had found these artefacts at a flea market many years ago and with the explanation that they were from Glaumb√¶r in Skagafj√∂r√∞ur. And now he was getting old and his descendants didn‚Äôt want to have them so he had decided to send them back now.‚Äù Asked whether it was likely the man had stolen the items himself and returned them out of guilt, Inga Katr√≠n stated only: ‚ÄúThat may very well be.‚Äù

headline: Reykjav√≠k Pride Festival Begins Today
body: Reykjav√≠k Pride will hold an opening ceremony at noon today on Ing√≥lfsstr√¶ti. The city‚Äôs pride parade has been cancelled for the second year in a row due to COVID restrictions. Nevertheless, festival board member Ragnar Veigar Gu√∞mundsson says there will be a variety of pride events this year that will offer a little something for everyone. ‚ÄúThe week will be full of queerness wherever there‚Äôs room for it,‚Äù Ragnar Veigar stated in a radio interview this morning. ‚ÄúOf course the festival has a slightly different format compared to a normal year but we know how it has to be done in order to fall within the pandemic restrictions.‚Äù The festival programme features everything from educational events that will be streamed online to drag performances and a drag brunch held in Gamla B√≠√≥ theatre. ‚ÄúFor example, there‚Äôs a very interesting educational event this afternoon, a conversation between generations, in M√°l og menning bookstore. Three individuals of different ages will be there talking about their queer experience around the age of 20. It‚Äôs just going to be a relaxed event with a good discussion,‚Äù Ragnar Veigar says. Preparation for this year‚Äôs pride parade was in full swing when COVID restrictions were reimposed on July 24. Ragnar Veigar says that there are plans in the works for some form of pride celebrations in the city centre on Saturday. He stresses that all are welcome, whether they belong to the LGBT+ community or not.

headline: Westmans Postpone √ûj√≥√∞h√°t√≠√∞
body: √ûj√≥√∞h√°t√≠√∞, the festival held in the Westman Islands every Merchant‚Äôs Weekend and one of Iceland‚Äôs biggest multi-day events, has been postponed, although organizers still hope to hold it later this summer. This was announced by festival committee chair H√∂r√∞ur Orri Grettisson on the √ûj√≥√∞h√°t√≠√∞ website on Monday. The postponement comes as a result of tightening restrictions aimed at stemming the exponential rise of recent COVID-19 infections, including a ban on gatherings of more than 200 people. Previous √ûj√≥√∞h√°t√≠√∞s have drawn as many as 16,000 attendees‚Äînearly four times the population of Heimey, the island the festival takes place on. As recently as last week, organizers said they had no intention of cancelling the festival, and that ‚Äúprecautions with personal infection control‚Äù and regular sanitation would be sufficient. See Also: Domestic Restrictions Reimposed in Iceland Organizers have asserted that the festival, funds from which support √çBV [the Westman Islands football club] is vital to not only √çBV‚Äôs youth programming but also the Westmans‚Äô local economy. They have, as such, not given up on the idea of holding the festival this year. ‚ÄúIt is our belief that it will be possible to hold the festival in some form later this summer. A decision will be made no later than August 14.‚Äù In the meantime, those who bought tickets have three options: they can receive a refund in August, donate the price of their ticket to √çBV, or transfer their ticket to next year‚Äôs festival in 2022. A slimmed-down and virtual version of the festival will also take place. The Sunday night program, which includes performances by the band Albatross and a performance of this year‚Äôs official festival song, will be streamed online and viewable from anywhere in the world. Tickets for the online event are being sold on tix.is. ¬†

headline: No Plans to Cancel √ûj√≥√∞h√°t√≠√∞
body: There are no plans to cancel this year‚Äôs √ûj√≥√∞h√°t√≠√∞, a festival held annually on Merchant‚Äôs Weekend on Heimey Island in the Westman Islands, R√öV reports. In spite of a recent uptick in positive COVID-19 cases around Iceland and tightening measures to prevent a more serious outbreak, authorities have yet to impose any gathering bans that would prevent organizers from holding the festival, which is one of the biggest multi-day events in Iceland. In past years, it‚Äôs drawn as many as 16,000 attendees‚Äînearly four times the population of Heimey. ‚ÄúWe are determined to put on this √ûj√≥√∞h√°t√≠√∞,‚Äù said chair of the festival committee H√∂r√∞ur Orri Grettisson. ‚ÄúFrom here out, just as up until now, this all depends on us. We have to take precautions with personal infection control, sanitize often, and do it well. This is how we‚Äôre going to prevent ourselves from getting infected.‚Äù H√∂r√∞ur says that ticket sales and planning, which have been underway since the start of the year, have been successful thus far. Organizers are assessing the situation on a day-by-day basis in meetings with Westman Island police and civil defense authorities, he continued. But if the festival had to be cancelled for the second year in a row, it would have serious economic consequences for Westman residents and businesses, H√∂r√∞ur said. ‚ÄúIt would, naturally, be a devastating blow, particularly for √çBV [the Westman Islands football club]. This is by far their biggest fundraiser. All their work with children and teens depends on this festival going well.‚Äù The financial consequences would also extend to companies based in other places around Iceland, H√∂r√∞ur continued. (Indeed, among other things, the weekend necessitates an uptick in both ferry crossings to the Westmans and short flights booked with tour companies to the island.) ‚ÄúTourism, restaurants, etc‚Äîmany of them live or die with this weekend. People have probably booked in for the weekend and such. So [cancelling] would just be a devastating blow.‚Äù

headline: Icelandic Film ‚ÄúLamb‚Äù Double-Nominated in Cannes
body: An Icelandic supernatural drama directed by Valdimar J√≥hannsson, Lamb (D√Ωri√∞), received its world premiere yesterday at the Cannes Film Festival in France. The film has been nominated for the festival‚Äôs Golden Camera Award as well as the Un Certain Regard Award. It is Valdimar‚Äôs first feature film as a director and he told R√öV it is a dream and an honour that the film was chosen for the festival. Lamb follows a childless couple, Mar√≠a and Ingvar, as they ‚Äúdiscover a mysterious newborn on their farm in Iceland. The unexpected prospect of family life brings them much joy, before ultimately destroying them,‚Äù according to the film‚Äôs plot summary on IMDb. Along with directing, Valdimar wrote the script for the film in collaboration with Icelandic author Sj√≥n. The film stars Swede Noomi Rapace and Icelander Hilmir Sn√¶r Gu√∞nason in the leading roles. Noomi lived in Iceland as a child but this is her first role in Icelandic. The actress revealed that she learned to deliver a lamb for the role. ‚ÄúI was taught by an Icelandic farmer but he went quite fast,‚Äù Noomi stated in an interview with France24. ‚ÄúI got a knock, he was like, ‚ÄòThere‚Äôs a lamb coming!‚Äô And I had to run down to the farmhouse and basically put my hands inside of the sheep and pull out a baby lamb.‚Äù She called the experience ‚Äúamazing. I saw life begin and how this amazing, beautiful creature stood up for the first time and started drinking after two or three minutes.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just finding our footing after this wonderful reception that the film received,‚Äù stated Sara Nassim, one of the film‚Äôs producers, after the premiere. ‚ÄúThere was a full house and a standing ovation at the end of the screening. We hope people liked the film. All of the responses so far have been very good, there‚Äôs been a lot of talk about the film.‚Äù Lamb‚Äôs Icelandic premiere is expected this fall.

headline: West Iceland‚Äôs First Pride Celebration Draws Crowds
body: Borgarnes, West Iceland was blanketed by rainbows ‚Äì and crowds ‚Äì last Saturday at the region‚Äôs first-ever pride celebrations. The event was one of the first projects of the region‚Äôs newly-minted LGBT+ association Hinsegin Vesturland. The organisers say they are overjoyed with the turnout and hope to change the discourse on LGBT+ issues in the Icelandic countryside. The sister Gu√∞r√∫n Steinunn and Bjargey Anna Gu√∞brandsd√≥ttir are among the finders of the association and organisers of the local pride festival. ‚ÄúThis is so, so much bigger than we ever expected,‚Äù Bjargey told R√öV. ‚ÄúWhen [Gu√∞r√∫n] started talking about this idea a few years ago we imagined one float and walking with our family on the float. I don‚Äôt even know how many people are here, it‚Äôs wonderful.‚Äù Alexander Aron Gu√∞j√≥nsson is another one of the event‚Äôs organisers. Asked about the importance of holding an LGBT+ festival in the countryside, he answered: ‚ÄúThere is a slightly different rhetoric here in the countryside about LGBT+ people. So it‚Äôs very positive to do this in as many places as possible so that there is an open discussion about everything and everyone, everywhere.‚Äù The West Iceland LGBT+ Association (Hinsegin Vesturland) was founded in February of this year. North Iceland and East Iceland also have regional LGBT+ associations. Samt√∂kin ‚Äô78 is Iceland‚Äôs National Queer Organisation as was the first association of its kind in Iceland.

headline: Puff-Inn Welcomes Seabirds for Five-Star Stay
body: A new hotel is opening by the small town of Borgarfj√∂r√∞ur eystri, East Iceland, but if you‚Äôre reading this article, its lodgings are probably not available in your size. The Lundah√≥tel, or Puff-Inn, is a project hatched by illustrators El√≠n El√≠sabet Einarsd√≥ttir and R√°n Flygenring, offering luxury accommodations to Iceland‚Äôs most beloved birds. Iceland Review spoke to the artists as they were putting the finishing touches on the facilities, located at the farmstead H√∂fn, just east of the town. The two artists opened a puffin shop last year at the same location, an answer to Iceland‚Äòs many tourist shops filled with puffin-themed tchotchkes. ‚ÄúWe made all sorts of puffin-related merchandise that was not for sale and were thinking a lot about the relationship between puffins, people, and puffin stores,‚Äù R√°n told Iceland Review over the phone. ‚ÄúOpening a hotel is a logical continuation of that.‚Äù  A post shared by NyÃÅlundabuÃÅ√∞in (@nylundabudin)  ‚ÄúThe puffin is the symbol of tourism in Iceland but it‚Äôs in danger,‚Äù El√≠n says, explaining that human-caused global warming is pushing the bird‚Äôs food source north and the puffins are following. ‚ÄúA hotel would be a good way to provide them with refuge.‚Äù Early birds can dine on the hotel‚Äôs breakfast buffet, complete with sardines and herring (humans are also welcome), and guests will enjoy all the usual offerings of luxury lodgings: ‚ÄúBathrobes and postcards.‚Äù The Puff-Inn is located by the town harbour across the road from a puffin colony, and the artists admit their new facilities are more of a ‚Äústaycation‚Äù for the birds. Their feathered neighbours are nevertheless are showing interest in the hotel on their doorstep, say the two illustrators, as are the local townsfolk. While there are currently no rooms available for human guests, R√°n says they‚Äôre welcome to make a booking for a friend of the puffin persuasion. Rather than the traditional rooms, the Puff-Inn offers burrows to its guests. ‚ÄúWe plan to offer burrows of various sizes so birds of all kinds can come and stay,‚Äù El√≠n adds. ‚ÄúAll birds are facing difficult circumstances due to human causes, so we hope they all stop by for a visit.‚Äù Interested people and avians can follow the hotel on Instagram.

headline: Vigd√≠s Finnbogad√≥ttir Exhibition to Be Opened Next Year
body: According to a letter of intent signed at the University of Iceland yesterday, an exhibition on the presidency of Vigd√≠s Finnbogad√≥ttir will be opened next year at Loftskeytast√∂√∞in. Vigd√≠s Finnbogad√≥ttir was the first woman to be democratically elected head of state, in office from 1980 to 1996. At a commemorative ceremony yesterday, marking the University of Iceland‚Äôs 110th anniversary, Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir, Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs Bjarni Benediktsson, Minister of Transport and Local Government Sigur√∞ur Ingi J√≥hannsson, and President of the University of Iceland J√≥n Atli Benediktsson signed a joint letter of intent to open an exhibition on the presidency of Vigd√≠s Finnbogad√≥ttir next year. According to the agreement, the government will aid in preparatory efforts for the exhibition, which will be housed at Loftskeytast√∂√∞in ‚Äì Iceland‚Äôs first radio station, inaugurated on June 17, 1918. Loftskeytast√∂√∞in, which is located next to Ver√∂ld ‚Äì the House of Vigd√≠s, will also accommodate research and academic facilities. The agreement stipulates that the exhibition receive an annual subsidy from the treasury. The University of Iceland will manage the exhibition and related scholarly activities, both of which will be integrated within the operations of Ver√∂ld. The signees hope to inaugurate the exhibition next year. ‚ÄúVigd√≠s‚Äô influence on Icelandic society, especially on those who grew up during her presidency, can hardly be overstated: waking up, one morning in June of 1980, as the first nation in history to have democratically elected a woman as head of state. In an incredibly brief time, Vigd√≠s managed to unite the nation. The prevailing attitude at the time was that a president should be a symbol of unity, and in Vigd√≠s the nation quickly found such a symbol,‚Äù PM Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir stated in a speech during the ceremony. Having wished Icelanders happy National Day, and congratulated the University on its anniversary, Vigd√≠s announced that she would be donating various keepsakes from her presidency to the University of Iceland, including letters, gifts from foreign heads of states, and clothing. These items will serve as the basis for the exhibition at Loftskeytast√∂√∞in. As noted in an interview with Iceland Review in 2019, Vigd√≠s Finnbogad√≥ttir always considered herself ‚Äúone of the people.‚Äù Even after being elected president, Vigd√≠s continued visiting the public pool in West Reykjav√≠k, where she would join fellow swimmers in a regimen of quaint exercises invented by the former Danish gymnastics educator J. P. M√ºller. Click here for an excerpt to the article.

headline: Icelandic Series Katla Premieres on Netflix Today
body: Just ten years ago it was unthinkable that a foreign company as big as Netflix would be interested in producing an Icelandic TV series for the global market, according to director Baltasar Korm√°kur. Icelandic series Katla, co-written and co-directed by Baltasar, premieres on the streaming platform today. The fictional drama takes place in V√≠k √≠ M√Ωrdal, South Iceland, during a volcanic eruption so intense it starts melting a glacier from which ‚Äúmysterious elements‚Äù start to emerge ‚Äúwith consequences no one could ever have foreseen.‚Äù Katla is the first Icelandic television series produced by Netflix in collaboration with Reykjav√≠k Studios. Containing ten episodes, the series was written by Baltasar along with Sigurj√≥n Kjartansson, Dav√≠√∞ M√°r Stef√°nsson and Lilja Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir. Lilja and Baltasar also directed the series alongside B√∂rkur Sig√æ√≥rsson. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an idea I got quite a long time ago and was playing around with,‚Äù Baltasar told R√öV. ‚ÄúWhat if the glaciers would melt and we have no idea what‚Äôs under them. Then it developed. I knew it wouldn‚Äôt be easy because it‚Äôs heavy in production.‚Äù Then Baltasar received a call from Netflix and the idea suddenly became a real possibility. Baltasar describes Katla as a combination of folktale, science fiction, and psychological ‚Äúnoir mystery,‚Äù a form he says provided lots of freedom. ‚ÄúWe stuck to a certain realism in terms of what the situation would be like after one year of a volcanic eruption. But then we let go of the reins and it was as if the team filled with energy, it was a lot of fun.‚Äù

headline: Aladdin, Elsa, and Moana Speak Icelandic Again
body:
Streaming service Disney+ has made some popular Disney films available with Icelandic dubbing, V√≠sir reports. Earlier this year, Education Minister Lilja Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir and actor J√≥hannes Haukur J√≥hannesson¬†called for the company‚Äôs films to be made available with Icelandic dubbing and now, films like Aladd√≠n (Aladdin), √çs√∂ld (Ice Age) and Herk√∫les (Hercules) are available in Icelandic. J√≥hannes Haukur criticised Disney+ on Twitter earlier this year for making the content available in Iceland but only in English, despite the existence of Icelandic dubbing. Hey @disneyplus why would you sell subscriptions in a region (Iceland to be specific) without making the subtitles and audio for that region available? Why oh why? Iceland has dubbed Disney features and TV shows for decades. You own it, you have it. Please make it available. ‚Äî J√≥hannes Haukur (@johanneshaukur) January 30, 2021 
Minister for Education and Culture Lilja Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir responded to the subsequent discussion by reaching out to Walt Disney Company CEO Bob Chapek, challenging them to make the films available in Icelandic. The company responded positively, stating that in a few months‚Äô time, popular films such as The Lion King, Toy Story, Frozen, Wall-E, Cars, and Coco would be available with Icelandic dubbing. Today, at least ten Disney films are available in Icelandic: Aladd√≠n, √çs√∂ld, Vaiana, Hin √ìtr√∫legu (the Incredibles), Zootropolis, B√≠lar, R√≠√≥ 2 og Epic as well as Soul, which for a long time was the only film on the streaming service available in Icelandic.

headline: Sigur R√≥s Members Acquitted in Tax Fraud Case
body: All members of the Icelandic band Sigur R√≥s were acquitted this morning by the Reykjav√≠k District Court in an extensive tax evasion case, R√öV reports. J√≥n √û√≥r Birgisson, the bands lead singer, was also acquitted on charges of tax evasion in connection with his company Frakkur. The band‚Äôs legal costs amounting to ISK 56 million ($463,000/‚Ç¨378,000) will be paid by the State Treasury. All of Sigur R√≥s‚Äô band members except Kjartan Sveinsson were charged with committing major tax fraud by submitting incorrect tax returns between 2011-2014. Kjartan, who left the band in 2013, was charged with submitting incorrect tax returns in 2012 and 2014. J√≥n √û√≥r (J√≥nsi) was also charged for tax evasion via his company Frakkur. Throughout the case, the band members have maintained their innocence and said that they had, in good faith, left their financial affairs to an accountant who mishandled them.¬†The band fully co-operated with the tax investigation and paid all charges and fines, yet still faced additional punishment through the District Prosecutor, who has now acquitted them. The band released a statement in October last year decrying the injustice of Iceland‚Äôs legal system, which allows for parties to be charged and tried twice for the same offence. Sigur R√≥s received this year‚Äôs Honourary Award at the Icelandic Music Awards for their contribution to Icelandic music over the past 17 years. The band was established in 1994 and is one of the most internationally successful Icelandic music acts of all time.

headline: Iceland Lands Fourth in 2021 Eurovision Song Contest
body: Iceland‚Äôs representatives in the 2021 Eurovision Song Contest, Da√∞i og gagnamagni√∞, landed in fourth place at the competition despite a COVID-19 infection in the band that prevented its members from performing live. A second member of the band tested positive for COVID-19 upon arriving home in Iceland: √Årn√Ω Fj√≥la √Åsmundsd√≥ttir. Iceland has only twice done better in the Eurovision Song Contest: the country won second place in 1999 with the song All Out of Luck performed by Selma Bj√∂rns, and also in 2009 with the song Is It True, performed by J√≥hanna Gu√∞r√∫n. Iceland also reached fourth place on one previous occasion: in 1990 with the song Eitt lag enn, performed by Stj√≥rnin. After a COVID-19 infection came up in the Icelandic delegation early last week, the entire group was put into quarantine. The first infection was diagnosed in a crew member, but a band member later tested positive that week. Da√∞i og gagnamagni√∞ decided to use the recording from their dress rehearsal as their submission in the semi-finals of the competition last Thursday, and qualified for the finals, held on Saturday night. Iceland landed in fourth place, with 378 points: 198 from the jury and 180 from the public. Most of the Icelandic delegation arrived home in Iceland on Sunday, when a second member of the band tested positive for COVID-19: √Årn√Ω Fj√≥la, frontman Da√∞i Freyr‚Äôs wife. Da√∞i and √Årn√Ω are now in isolation together and have announced they plan to use the time to make a music video. Fans can vote on which song they‚Äôd like to see realised on Da√∞i‚Äôs Twitter page. Thank you for @Eurovision Now on to the next thing pic.twitter.com/GqOvm26Mal ‚Äî Da√∞i Freyr ü•ë (@dadimakesmusic) May 23, 2021

headline: Second COVID-19 Infection in Iceland‚Äôs Eurovision Delegation
body: Update May 19, 12:54: The EBU has released a statement confirming that Da√∞i og gagnamagni√∞ will neither perform at the Thursday semi-finals nor the Saturday finals of the 2021 Eurovision Songcontest. A recording of their second rehearsal in Rotterdam will be used as their entry. One of the members of Da√∞i og gagnamagni√∞, Iceland‚Äôs representatives in the 2021 Eurovision Song Contest, has tested positive for COVID-19. Da√∞i himself announced the development this morning on Twitter. The band will consequently not perform in the Eurovision semi-finals tomorrow night and a recording from their second rehearsal will instead be used as their entry. In a tearful video posted in Gagnamagni√∞‚Äôs Instagram stories, band member J√≥hann Sigur√∞ur J√≥hannsson came forward to tell fans he is the member who tested positive. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really shocked and disappointed and generally just really sad about the whole situation,‚Äù J√≥hann stated, adding that he did everything he could to stay safe. The Icelandic delegation entered quarantine and underwent testing earlier this week after an infection arose in the Polish Eurovision team. J√≥hann is the second member of the Icelandic group to test positive ‚Äì the first is a crew member and not a performer. J√≥hann assured supporters that he was healthy but disappointed as the group had worked so hard and the performance had been ‚Äúso long in the making.‚Äù In a Twitter thread from this morning announcing the development, Da√∞i Freyr stated that the band was ‚Äúvery happy‚Äù with the taped performance that will be used on Thursday night and ‚Äúsuper excited‚Äù for supporters to watch it. A member of Gagnamagni√∞ got a positive test result this morning. Unfortunately this probably means that we will not take part in the rehearsal today or live show tomorrow and a recording from our second rehearsal will be used in stead. pic.twitter.com/93yravOHSY ‚Äî Da√∞i Freyr ü•ë (@dadimakesmusic) May 19, 2021  The Eurovision finals take place on Saturday. It is unclear whether Iceland will be able to perform live at the event.

headline: No Further Infections Detected With the Icelandic Eurovision Delegation
body: No further members of the Icelandic delegation for the 2021 Eurovision Song Contest in Rotterdam tested positive for the coronavirus yesterday, R√öV reports. The whole group was tested for the virus after a member of the Icelandic crew tested positive the previous day. The infected individual is not a member of the on-stage group. The Icelandic delegation will be tested again on Wednesday and Thursday morning and if no further infections are detected, Da√∞i and Gagnamagni√∞ will perform at the jury show on Wednesday evening and the second semi-finals on Thursday night. Head of the Icelandic delegation Felix Bergsson stated that the infection is a reminder to continue to be careful despite their vaccinations but the whole delegation was vaccinated before departing for the Netherlands. Chief Epidemiologist √û√≥r√≥lfur Gu√∞nason has stated that the infection despite the vaccination does not surprise him, it occurred only 10 days after the individual in question received his shot of the Jansen vaccine but it takes two or three weeks for the vaccine to reach full efficacy.

headline: Da√∞i to Compete Despite Eurovision COVID-19 Outbreak
body: Da√∞i og gagnamagni√∞, Iceland‚Äôs representatives in the 2021 Eurovision Song Contest, will compete in the competition‚Äôs semi-finals in Rotterdam this Thursday despite a COVID-19 outbreak in which members of the Polish and Icelandic teams have tested positive for the novel coronavirus, R√öV reports. One member of the Icelandic crew tested positive for COVID-19 and the others are quarantining as they await their test results. If the band is unable to perform live, a recording from their dress rehearsal will be used as their semi-final entry. The competition is taking place in the Netherlands, currently a high-risk area for COVID-19 according to the European Centre for Disease Control. V√≠sir reports that Icelandic national broadcaster R√öV, who sponsors Iceland‚Äôs participation in the competition, requested that the crew be vaccinated before departure to the Netherlands. ‚ÄúAnd we granted that,‚Äù Chief Epidemiologist √û√≥r√≥lfur Gu√∞nason told the outlet. ‚ÄúPeople are being sent out there on behalf of the Icelandic state where [the virus is widespread]. We have been reluctant to grant such requests but we did so in this instance.‚Äù Just under 40% of Icelandic residents have received one or both shots of COVID-19 vaccine, and authorities are still administering the jab to priority groups including school staff and people with underlying illnesses. √û√≥r√≥lfur admitted that some might consider it unfair to let the group jump the line due to the Eurovision trip. The Icelandic Eurovision crew received the Janssen (Johnson & Johnson) single-dose vaccine around ten days ago, shortly before departing for Rotterdam. One member of the crew has now tested positive for the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which does not surprise √û√≥r√≥lfur. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only been ten days since the vaccination. We know it takes two to three weeks for the vaccine to reach full efficacy.‚Äù The infected individual is not part of the on-stage group but has been in contact with them. Their identity has not been revealed for privacy reasons.

headline: Da√∞i Rises on Eurovision Charts After First Rotterdam Rehearsal
body: Iceland‚Äôs representatives at the 2021 Eurovision Song Contest, Da√∞i og gagnamagni√∞, rose two spots in bookies‚Äô charts after their first rehearsal in the Netherlands, R√öV reports. Da√∞i and gagnamagni√∞‚Äôs song 10 Years was in sixth place before the group took the stage at Rotterdam‚Äôs Ahoy Convention Centre but had risen to fourth only a few hours later. Da√∞i Freyr and his band won fans across the world in 2020 with their song Think About Things, Iceland‚Äôs submission to the 2020 Eurovision contest, which was eventually cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. At the rehearsal, the band premiered new costumes, graphics, and instruments ‚Äì the latter designed by band member √Årn√Ω Fj√≥la (also Da√∞i‚Äôs wife and the subject of the song), and constructed by √Årn√Ω, Da√∞i, and Da√∞i‚Äôs father. The band‚Äôs graphics reference previous Eurovision performances, including that of Icelander J√≥hanna Gu√∞r√∫n, who represented the country at the 2009 contest, and Ukrainian artist Ruslana‚Äôs 2004 contest-winning song Wild Dances. Read More: Da√∞i‚Äôs Eurovision is 20/20 The group‚Äôs next rehearsal takes place this Thursday and their official performance will be next Thursday, May 20 in the Eurovision semi-finals in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.

headline: First Day of Summer in Iceland Today
body: Today, April 22, is a national holiday in Iceland known as the First Day of Summer (Sumardagurinn fyrsti). In the old Icelandic calendar, this holiday likely marked the beginning of a new year and was celebrated by giving presents. Despite its name, it doesn‚Äôt always bring Icelanders warm weather. While winter is officially over according to the old Icelandic calendar, it is not uncommon to have snow, hail, or freezing temperatures across Iceland on the First Day of Summer. In 1949, the highest recorded temperature in the country on the day of the holiday was -0.2¬∞C (31.6¬∞F), and Reykjav√≠k was blanketed with 4cm (1.6in) of snow. This year‚Äôs weather forecast for the holiday includes precipitation across West Iceland ‚Äì rain in lowland areas and snow at higher elevations in the region. Temperatures will reach a high of around 10¬∞C [50¬∞F] during the day and around freezing at night. ‚ÄúWe are the only nation in the world that‚Äôs celebrated its own particular first day of summer for 1,000 years,‚Äù ethnologist Dr. √Årni Bj√∂rnsson told Iceland Review. ‚ÄúOur ancestors created their own calendar before they knew of the Roman calendar. They split it into two halves: summer and winter.‚Äù¬†There are clues suggesting that the First Day of Summer was considered the first day of the year. Ancient Icelanders calculated people‚Äôs age by the number of winters they had lived through, a practice that is still upheld in the countryside with horses and other domestic animals.

headline: Fagrahraun or Fagradalshraun: New Reykjanes Lava Field Awaits a Name
body: The town council of Grindav√≠k, Southwest Iceland has narrowed down around 339 name suggestions for the new lava field at Fagradalsfjall to just two: Fagrahraun and Fagradalshraun. R√öV reports that both options have been submitted to the authority that approves new place names in Iceland. The many craters at the eruption site, which has been active for over a month, will also be named F√∂grug√≠gar or Fagradalsg√≠gar, depending on which name is chosen for the field. Grindav√≠k authorities organised a competition between March 31 and April 9, 2021 where the public was allowed to submit suggestions for what to name the new lava field. ‚ÄúThe conclusion was that after reviewing the ideas that were received, which were 339, evaluating and weighing it, that the lava field should be called either Fagradalshraun or Fagrahraun,‚Äù stated Grindav√≠k Mayor Fannar J√≥nasson. The two names are similar in meaning. While Fagrahraun translates as ‚Äúbeautiful lava‚Äù or ‚Äúbeautiful lava field,‚Äù Fagradalshraun references Fagradalsfjall, literally ‚Äúbeautiful valley mountain,‚Äù located at the site. The name also references the volcanic system Fagradalsfjallskerfi, one of the volcanic systems beneath the Reykjanes peninsula. Dalahraun (E. valley lava field), Geldingadalshraun (E. Geldingadalur lava field), and √çs√≥lfshraun (E. √çs√≥lfur‚Äôs lava field; after an early settler once believed to be buried there) were among the most popular suggestions for the field, which continues to grow one month after the eruption began. Some name suggestions referenced the ongoing pandemic, including K√≥r√≥nahraun and Covidhraun, while the suggestion √ñlmuhraun was intended as a tribute to Iceland‚Äôs Director of Health Alma M√∂ller. None of those suggestions made it past the town council‚Äôs deliberations. The town council is now waiting on an official opinion on both place name suggestions.

headline: H√∫sav√≠k, Iceland Rolls Out the Red Carpet for Oscars Ceremony

headline: 50 Years Since First Icelandic Manuscripts Were Returned from Denmark
body: Today marks 50 years since the repatriation of two of Iceland‚Äôs most important medieval manuscripts. The Codex Regius of the Poetic Edda (Konungsb√≥k Eddukv√¶√∞a) and the Codex Flateyensis (Flateyjarb√≥k) were returned to Iceland from Denmark on this day in 1971, a remarkable and symbolic event in Iceland‚Äôs history. Now a state-of-the-art building is under construction in Reykjav√≠k that will be a new home for Iceland‚Äôs most valuable manuscripts. President of Iceland Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson and Minister of Education and Culture Lilja Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir will lay the cornerstone of the building today, which will be named the House of Icelandic Studies, in honour of the momentous anniversary. The Codex Regius of the Poetic Edda is widely regarded as the most remarkable of all old Icelandic manuscripts. It is the sole source for most of the poems it contains, many of which are important sources for the worldview and religious beliefs of pre-Christian Scandinavians. The codex was discovered in 1643 and sent as a gift to King Frederick III of Denmark in 1662. It was kept in the Royal Library in Copenhagen until 1971, when it was brought back to Reykjav√≠k by ship. It was accompanied by the Flateyjarb√≥k, the largest medieval Icelandic manuscript, containing mostly sagas of the Norse kings as well as accounts relating to the Vinland colony, the Orkney Islands and the Faroe Islands. Read More: Medieval Icelandic Manuscripts Soon Housed in New Facility ‚ÄúIt is a pleasure to commemorate this milestone in light of the fact that now the wheels are turning, the construction of the House of Icelandic Studies is going faster than hoped for and we are considering increased collaboration with Denmark on the future of √Årni Magn√∫sson‚Äôs manuscript collection. We all have a shared duty to preserve, research, and distribute these national treasures to new generations,‚Äù stated Lilja Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir, Minister of Education and Culture. The House of Icelandic Studies is expected to reach completion on August 1, 2022. Below is a video of the construction process so far.

headline: Iceland Symphony Orchestra Accompanies COVID-19 Vaccination Today
body: Some 5,000 people who will receive a dose of COVID-19 vaccine in Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs mass vaccination centre today will be serenaded by the Iceland Symphony Orchestra while they get their jab, V√≠sir reports. The ISO contacted vaccination officials and asked if they could play a concert at the centre, and the offer was readily accepted. People of all ages with underlying chronic illnesses are being vaccinated in Reykjav√≠k today. Around 8% of Iceland‚Äôs population has been fully vaccinated while a total of 19% have received at least one shot. The first priority groups to be offered vaccination were frontline workers and nursing home residents, followed by the oldest demographics. Now over 95% of residents over 80 have been vaccinated and most residents over 70 have received at least one dose. This week authorities are vaccinating residents with underlying chronic illnesses in all age groups. Iceland is administering COVID-19 vaccines from three manufacturers: Pfizer, AstraZeneca, and Moderna. ‚ÄúThis is a very large group overall, but we have started on the lists of people with the most serious illnesses, this is about 30,000 people in the Reykjav√≠k Capital Area so it will take us a few weeks or the next few weeks to work through this group,‚Äù stated Ragnhei√∞ur √ìsk Erlendsd√≥ttir, Director of Nursing at Capital Area Healthcare Centres. While those vaccinated today will receive the Pfizer vaccine, others with chronic illnesses that are scheduled to get the jab tomorrow will receive the Moderna vaccine. The 60-70 year old demographic (without underlying illnesses) will be offered vaccination starting next week, Ragnhei√∞ur says. Read More: What‚Äôs the Status of COVID-19 Vaccination in Iceland? It is standard procedure for all individuals to remain at the vaccination centre for 15 minutes after receiving their dose. This allows healthcare staff to monitor them and provide medical care in the rare case they exhibit allergic reactions to the drug. ‚ÄúIt was great that the Symphony Orchestra contacted us and asked whether they could come and play for people, because everyone has to wait 15 minutes until they can leave,‚Äù Ragnhei√∞ur explained. A little bit of music should certainly help soothe nerves and pass the time for today‚Äôs vaccine recipients. Icelandic authorities have stated that they are on track to reach their goal of vaccinating 75% of the population by the end of July.

headline: MAST Reviewing Footage of Mistreated Mares in Youtube Doc
body: The Icelandic Food and Veterinary Authority is currently reviewing footage from a Youtube documentary that features clips of Icelandic mares being mistreated during blood-collection procedures. The conditions and conduct caught on camera are ‚Äúutterly unacceptable,‚Äù says the Chairman of the Horse Breeders Association of Iceland. On November 19, Tierschutzbund Z√ºrich (TSB, Switzerland) and the Animal Welfare Foundation (AWF, Germany) posted¬†a documentary to Youtube¬†under the heading ‚ÄúIceland ‚Äì Land of the 5,000 Blood Mares.‚Äù The documentary reports on the activities within so-called ‚Äúblood farms‚Äù in Iceland, where blood is drawn from mares in early pregnancy to extract¬†ECG¬†(previously known as pregnant mare‚Äôs serum gonadotropin or PMSG): a hormone commonly used in concert with progestogens to induce ovulation in livestock prior to artificial insemination. The documentary features footage from hidden cameras showing workers beating and shouting at horses. The filmmakers claim to have discovered ‚Äúwidespread animal-welfare violations‚Äù in Iceland, which run counter to claims made by pharmaceutical companies on the nature of blood-collection procedures in the country. As noted by MAST, the extraction of ECG from pregnant mares is a growing industry in Iceland; blood from almost 5,400 mares, on 119 farms, has been drawn in 2021. Following coverage of the documentary in the media, various parties connected to blood-collection farms in Iceland have commented publicly. In a press release on Sunday,¬†√çsteka¬†‚Äì which manufactures pharmaceuticals from the blood of mares ‚Äì denounced the treatment of the animals in the documentary: ‚Äú√çsteka disapproves strongly of sourcing practices that do not comply with the high animal welfare standards we work by and that we recommend to our customers and colleagues. We have immediately started an internal supplier review to investigate the allegations and cannot comment any further on this at this time.‚Äù In¬†an interview with V√≠sir, farmer S√¶unn √û√≥rarinsd√≥ttir criticized the footage recorded on her property on the grounds that it lacked context. ‚ÄúNone of my operations have anything to do with what is seen in that video,‚Äù she stated.¬† S√¶unn further alleged that the documentarians misrepresented reality on several occasions. (Early on in the video, for example, the documentarians say that they‚Äôre being followed by a veterinarian driving a grey jeep. ‚ÄúThe veterinarian in question was simply on his way home,‚Äù S√¶unn told V√≠sir.) ‚ÄúThe footage is horrible to watch and not at all an accurate depiction of our operations. We have a complete ban on violence; I would personally beat anyone who laid a finger on my horses,‚Äù S√¶unn remarked. In¬†a public statement released yesterday, the Icelandic Food and Veterinary Authority (MAST) announced that it was reviewing the footage seen in the documentary. ‚ÄúThe procedures caught on film appear to violate operational conditions, which stipulate the horses‚Äô welfare be ensured.‚Äù In the statement, MAST stressed that the supervision of blood-collection procedures is a priority. ‚ÄúSince the regulation on the welfare of horses came into effect in 2014, MAST has established clear conditions for blood-extraction procedures performed on pregnant mares, and we have gradually ramped up supervision.‚Äù According to the statement, MAST inspectors pay annual visits to a fifth of blood-collecting farms in Iceland during the time that procedures are being performed. ‚ÄúIf, during inspections, serious deviations from protocol are noted, operations are stopped; the operations of five facilities has been halted since 2014.‚Äù In¬†an interview with the radio station R√°s 2 this morning, Sveinn Steinarsson, Chairman of¬†the Horse Breeders Association of Iceland, stated that it was clear that the horses in the video had been mistreated: blood-collection is a sensitive procedure that demands great care. ‚ÄúThe extraction of blood from pregnant mares has been practiced for almost 40 years and the fact that the operating conditions are, after all this time ‚Äì and given especially how extensive these operations have become ‚Äì so unsatisfactory is utterly unacceptable,‚Äù Sveinn remarked in the interview. While he condemned the mistreatment of mares in the documentary, Sveinn warned against generalization: ‚ÄúI expect that conditions are acceptable in most places, but, as it stands, our discussion is beginning with the lowest-common denominator.‚Äù Sveinn concluded by stating that those who were charged with the supervision of blood-collection procedures in Iceland had many questions to answer. ‚ÄúAs far as what is depicted in the documentary, I expect no stone to be left unturned.‚Äù This article was updated at 15:17.

headline: Record Proportion of First-Time Buyers on Capital Area Housing Market
body: The proportion of first-time buyers in the Reykjav√≠k capital area housing market has increased significantly over the past year. First-time buyers are younger than before and purchase smaller properties. The average purchase price of properties in this demographic is around ISK 50 million [$382,000; ‚Ç¨338,000]. These figures come from a¬†report¬†published by the Economic Division of Landsbankinn bank today. In the third quarter of 2021, the proportion of all buyers on the property market that were first-time buyers reached a record 33.8%. The average age of first-time buyers has also fallen. It dropped to 29 in the second quarter, its lowest since 2006, rising slightly to 29.2 in the third quarter. The total number of first-time buyers was 983, a decrease from a record 1,354 in the first quarter of this year. Read More: Iceland‚Äôs Housing Market As the average age of first-time buyers has dropped, so has the average size of the properties they purchase. The average size of apartments purchased by first-time buyers was 94 square metres [1,011 square feet], around 38 square metres [409 sq ft] smaller than the average of other demographics. The Landsbankinn report concludes by stating that rising prices have not prevented many buyers from entering the property market. Lowered¬†interest rates¬†and construction of new apartments have increased access to housing, according to the report. Now that interest rates are¬†rising¬†again and the Central Bank has¬†tightened mortgage requirements, demand for housing is expected to decrease. While conditions on the market have benefited many middle-class buyers, there are indications that the pandemic recession has had the opposite impact on low-income residents of Iceland. A¬†report¬†published earlier this year found between 5,000 and 7,000 people in Iceland were living in properties classified as commercial or industrial buildings and not residential buildings. The largest group among them were people who had lost their jobs as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.

headline: Iceland‚Äôs First Self-Checkout Tool Library Opens in the K√≥pavogur Library
body: Patrons of the K√≥pavogur Library are now able to borrow tools and equipment, just like they borrow books and media. This weekend, the Munsafn RVK Tool Library opened Iceland‚Äôs first self-checkout tool library, called Hringr√°sarsafn. According to the press release, the initiative is ‚Äúbased on a Circular Economy approach to consumption, which tackles¬†UN Goal 12.‚Äù Patrons will be able to borrow tools and equipment for a biannual or annual fee and ‚Äúcan then take tools/things home for repairs, projects, and hobbies.‚Äù Per the Munasafn¬†RVK Tool Library website, six-month memberships cost ISK 7,000 [$54; ‚Ç¨42] and full-year memberships ISK 12,000 [$91; ‚Ç¨81], but¬†discounted memberships are currently available¬†given that the library extensions are in a launch phase. Items listed in the website inventory undoubtedly vary from that at the much smaller K√≥pavogur branch, but are indicative of the kinds of things that patrons will likely be able to borrow: tools like a circular saw set, wire strippers, an impact drill set, a car battery charger, and crowbar, as well as protective gear (a hard hat), and more unexpected items like a digital projector, camping equipment, and even a Nintendo system. The Hringr√°sarsafn in the K√≥pavogur Library is the only one of its kind at present, but organizers have received a grant from the Ministry of the Environment to open more tool libraries in locations of the Reykjav√≠k City Library in the future. As the press release continues: ‚ÄúWith more self-checkout libraries available in the future, members can save money, storage space, and resources which helps the planet and aligns with Iceland‚Äôs 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.‚Äù The launch of Hringr√°sarsafn also coincides with the European Week of Waste Reduction. Learn more about the Munasafn RVK Tool Library on their website,¬†here, or on¬†Instagram.

headline: Central Bank Raises Key Interest Rate to 2%
body: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) of the Central Bank of Iceland has decided to raise the Bank‚Äôs interest rates by 0.5 percentage points. The Bank‚Äôs key interest rate will therefore be 2%. This is the Bank‚Äôs fourth interest rate hike since May, indicating a change in direction as the economic forecast has improved. The Central Bank‚Äôs key interest rate reached a¬†historic low¬†of 0.75% in November 2020. In comparison, rates in January 2020 stood at 3% and in January 2019 at 4.5%. According to the Bank‚Äôs new macroeconomic forecast, GDP growth is expected to measure about 4% in 2021. Better prospects for exports result in an improved outlook for GDP growth compared to projections from last August. GDP growth next year is expected to measure just over 5%. The Central Bank nevertheless states that ‚Äúsignificant uncertainty remains, and as before, economic developments will depend on the path the pandemic takes.‚Äù Inflation rose to 4.5% in October, according to the Central Bank‚Äôs statement, and is expected to continue rising in the coming months but then start to ease. Global price increases, a more rapid rebound in domestic economic activity, and rising wage costs are some of the factors behind the rise.

headline: B√≥nus Lengthens Opening Hours, Gives Mascot Controversial Makeover
body: As of Friday, B√≥nus will have longer opening hours. V√≠sir reports that the extension was announced to customers at the same time that the discount grocery chain unveiled that its mascot, the iconic B√≥nus pig‚Äîan off-kilter, droopy-eyed swine that appeared to be recovering from a hard night out‚Äîhad undergone a makeover. But while the later shopping hours will undoubtedly be welcomed, not all locals are equally enthused about the popular porker‚Äôs facelift. B√≥nus CEO Gu√∞mundur Marteinsson says the chain extended its hours in response to calls from consumers. ‚ÄúThis is the complaint we receive most often,‚Äù he explained. ‚ÄúBut we‚Äôre cost-conservative and opening hours are part of the cost. But by keeping the opening hours within reasonable limits‚Äîwe‚Äôre not extending them by much‚Äîwe believe we can implement this without increasing the cost too much. Prices won‚Äôt change because of this adjustment.‚Äù Previously, B√≥nus closed at 6:30 pm. From now on, however, seven B√≥nus locations will be open until 8:00 pm every day: in the capital area, Sm√°ratorg, Skeifan, Sp√∂ngin, Fiskisl√≥√∞, and Mosfellsb√¶r, as well as Helluhraun in Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur and Langholt in Akureyri. The remaining locations will be open until 7:00 pm. In addition, B√≥nus will open an hour earlier on Sundays, or 10:00 am. ‚ÄòHe was always a bit cockeyed‚Äô Remarking on the controversial mascot transformation, Gu√∞mundur said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve just streamlined him a little‚Äîit isn‚Äôt that big a change. We took out one or two lines that it‚Äôs always looked like we forgot to erase when he was initially designed,‚Äù he continued, pointing to a crinkle on the B√≥nus pig‚Äôs nose and an extra line on his back. More dramatic, however, is the adjustment of the pig‚Äôs left eye. ‚ÄúHe was always a bit cockeyed,‚Äù Gu√∞mundur said. ‚ÄúBut as I see it, this is part of our evolution.‚Äù The brand‚Äôs font has also been adjusted, moving from a blocky serif font to a cleaner sans serif. ‚ÄòLong live the B√≥nus pig!‚Äô Change does not always come easy, though, and some locals took to social media to mourn the mascot. ‚ÄúWhat kind of sick joke is this?‚Äù wrote Hrafn J√≥nsson on Facebook. ‚ÄúYou take one of the most iconic pigs of all time and mess with it? [‚Ä¶] What kind of personality-less impostor is this?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhy can‚Äôt *anything* be left alone in this country?‚Äù tweeted @siggiodds. ‚ÄúWhat is the point/goal? Take the nuance, the history, and the humor away so you‚Äôre left with just an empty, generic shell?‚Äù The transformation has also already inspired several memes. ‚ÄúLong live the B√≥nus pig!‚Äù proclaimed Rex Beckett on Facebook, screen-capping the messages she sent directly to the company. ‚ÄúI just wanted to say that I am extremely sad about the decision to change the B√≥nus Piggy‚Äôs look,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúHe was a delightful little weirdo with such a fun personality and his wonky eye made everyone happy. [‚Ä¶] Please let us hang onto our old friend.‚Äù

headline: Fine of ISK 6.5 Million for Smuggled Roses
body: The Reykjav√≠k District Court has sentenced a flower wholesaler to two months‚Äô probation and a fine of ISK 6.5 million [$50,077; ‚Ç¨43,244] for smuggling roses and bouquets into the country, R√öV reports. An employee of the wholesaler was also fined ISK 1 million [$7,704; ‚Ç¨6,653]. The accused, who pleaded guilty, were charged with smuggling four shipments of cut roses and mixed bouquets into Iceland between 2016 and 2018, although the oldest of the charges was dropped. According to the indictment, the wholesaler provided customs with inaccurate and/or misleading information about the types and quantities of flowers that they were importing from the Netherlands.

headline: Reykjav√≠k Ramps Up
body: In March of this year, a project called Ramp Up Reykjav√≠k launched with the intention of helping local businesses install wheelchair ramps to improve accessibility for people with disabilities. Per an press release on the City of Reykjav√≠k website, the organization not only met its initial goal of installing 100 ramps around the capital four months ahead of schedule, it also has a surplus of funds‚ÄîISK 15 million [$115,517; ‚Ç¨99,876], to be exact‚Äîwhich will be placed in an Access Fund to assist in funding additional ramp access. Ramp Up Reykjav√≠k is a collaborative venture undertaken by local businesses, labour unions, government ministries, associations, banks, and city officials. It was launched by entrepreneur Haraldur Ingi √ûorleifsson after finding himself stuck outside downtown shops and restaurants on numerous occasions. He recalls a recent summer night during which he had to sit outside a shop while his family all went inside because there was only one step at the entrance and it was too tall for his wheelchair to go over. ‚ÄúThat wasn‚Äôt the first step,‚Äù he writes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve sat outside before and often. I‚Äôve not gone to coffeehouses because of that step. I‚Äôve not met friends out. I‚Äôve not gone downtown on √ûorl√°ksmessa with my family. All because of that step.‚Äù Haraldur isn‚Äôt the only person in his position, he continues, noting that thousands of Icelanders use wheelchairs, and thousands of tourists, too. This is what inspired him to start Ramp Up Reykjav√≠k, soliciting donations to fund 100 ramps to start with. Under the terms of the funding, restaurant owners can be reimbursed for up to 80% of the cost of installing a wheelchair ramp on their premises. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs amazing how easy it actually was,‚Äù Haraldur says. ‚ÄúAll the founding members, planning authorities, restaurants, and shops in the area really pushed the boat out to get the ramps set up and we had a lot of support from the start.‚Äù Mayor Dagur B. Eggertsson praised the project and said the city was prepared to continue funding for it. Ramp Up Reykjav√≠k will continue to improve access around the capital but is also set to move further afield. Akureyri mayor √Åsthildur Sturlud√≥ttir said she‚Äôd support the project in her town and both Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir and Minister for Social Affairs and children √Åsmundur Einar Da√∞ason said that they‚Äôd support the initiative in the countryside, having seen how successful it‚Äôs already been in the capital.

headline: 400 Small Businesses Form New Association
body: Around 400 small and medium-sized businesses have registered in a new association that was formed yesterday, R√öV reports. The association, called Atvinnufjelag, will take part in contract negotiations separately from the Confederation of Iceland Enterprise (SA) in order to give a voice to smaller businessses. ‚ÄúOver 99% of associations in Iceland are small and medium-size businesses and independent workers,‚Äù stated Arna √ûorsteinsd√≥ttir, one of the founders of the new association and co-owner of ad agency Sahara. The new association‚Äôs preparatory board says smaller businesses need a bigger seat at the table. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs not working with SA is the voting system. The bigger a business is, the more votes you have, the more weight you have. So it‚Äôs more likely that bigger businesses call the shots.‚Äù The premise of the new association is that each company will have one vote, regardless of its size, setting up a majority rule. Arna says smaller companies have felt they do not have enough of a voice within SA. ‚ÄúEspecially during COVID, certain response measures were requested for small and medium-size businesses that did not get support.‚Äù The association‚Äôs founding statement asserts that Iceland‚Äôs taxation system is unequal and should take into account the size and scope of businesses‚Äô operations. The association states it will negotiate contracts on behalf of its members and do so independently from SA. Arna hopes, however, ‚Äúthat there will be an open discussion and talks. We recognise that we are sort of gatecrashers here but we just want to get to the table.‚Äù

headline: Purchase of Icelandic Telecommunications System is Long-Term Investment, Says French Company
body: French fund management company Ardian, which has signed an agreement to buy Icelandic telecommunications company M√≠la, says the purchase is a long-term investment. Speaking to R√öV reporters, Ardian‚Äôs CEO of Infrastructure Investments Daniel Graf von der Schulenburg stated he expects the company to hold onto M√≠la for decades. Icelandic politicians have expressed concern that selling the telecommunications company abroad could pose a threat to Iceland‚Äôs national security. All of Iceland‚Äôs homes, businesses, and institutions are serviced by M√≠la‚Äôs nationwide telecommunications infrastructure, which includes copper wire, fibreoptic, and microwave systems. The company is therefore the basis of all telecommunications and electronic communications systems throughout the country. Ardian‚Äôs purchase of M√≠la is the largest foreign investment in Iceland in the past decade. The influx of foreign currency the purchase entails could cause short-term deviations in the exchange rate of the Icelandic kr√≥na, the Central Bank has stated. The sale is, however, expected to lead to an appreciation of the kr√≥na. M√≠la has been sold to Ardian for ISK 78 billion ($603 million/‚Ç¨520 million). The French company took over the debts of M√≠la‚Äôs previous owner, S√≠minn ehf., which will make a profit of ISK 46 billion from the sale. Icelandic pension funds are expected to acquire shares in the company amounting to 20%, with a price tag of ISK 10-12 billion. Von der Schulenburg says negotiations with pension funds are going well. The Icelandic government has set some requirements for M√≠la‚Äôs sale, including that the equipment remains in Icelandic jurisdiction and that authorities are informed of who the real owners of the company are at all times. Opposition MP √ûorger√∞ur Katr√≠n Gunnarsd√≥ttir, chairperson of the Reform Party, has criticised these requirements as being too little, too late. VR Union Chairman Ragnar √û√≥r Ing√≥lfsson has harshly criticised the sale, fearing it will lead to price hikes for users. He expressed disappointment that pension funds, who hold a majority in S√≠minn ehf., did not prevent the sale in the first place. Von der Schulenburg described Iceland as an attractive country to invest in due to its wealth, educated population, and bright future of its economy. ‚ÄúWe like that stability and good outlook as a place to invest in,‚Äù he stated. According to von der Schulenburg, M√≠la is an exciting investment opportunity because ‚Äúthere‚Äôs still opportunities to improve. He stated that Ardian would place emphasis on extending fibreoptic lines to more sparsely populated areas and continue developing the 5G cellular network. Prices will not rise, according to von der Schulenburg, as Ardian will aim to get more cost-efficient usage out of M√≠la‚Äôs infrastructure. Asked whether Ardian would consider selling the company to Russia or China in the future, von der Schulenburg stated: ‚ÄúNo, that is not going to happen. We are a very long-term investor and there‚Äôs two reasons for that. One is that almost all of our investors are insurance companies, pension funds, and sovereign wealth funds. The majority of the funds are coming from Europe. And these investors have a very long-term perspective.‚Äù Von der Schulenburg added infrastructure investing is long-term in general as it takes time to get a return on your investment. ‚ÄúMost likely you will be seeing us for decades.‚Äù

headline: √ûorl√°ksh√∂fn Harbour Now Fifth Busiest in Iceland
body: There was a 23% increase in transport through √ûorl√°ksh√∂fn harbour in Southwest Iceland between 2019 and 2020, according to newly released figures from Statistics Iceland. The ports of Reykjav√≠k, Grundartangi, Straumsv√≠k and Mj√≥eyri in Rey√∞arfj√∂r√∞ur maintained their positions as the four busiest ports in Iceland in 2020. The rankings are based on tonnes loaded and unloaded at the ports. Local authorities in √ûorl√°ksh√∂fn are planning an ISK 3 billion [$23.3 million; ‚Ç¨20 million] expansion of the harbour that would allow it to accommodate ships up to 180 metres long and 30 metres wide. The renovation would take three years to complete but the new harbour would be usable within two years, according to Elli√∞i Vignisson, mayor of √ñlfus municipality. By docking in √ûorl√°ksh√∂fn instead of Reykjav√≠k, cargo ships would shorten their journey between Iceland and Europe by up to 24 hours, which would lessen the carbon footprint of transport, Elli√∞i stated. A larger harbour in the town could also prove beneficial for the tourism industry, the mayor argued.

headline: The Pandemic Has Reshaped Unemployment in Iceland
body: While unemployment in Iceland has dropped to pre-pandemic rates, the lay of the land has changed both on the job market and among those who still remain jobless. Thousands are working on temporary contracts and 44% of workers on the unemployment register have been without work for a year or longer, Kjarninn reports. Iceland‚Äôs unemployment rate has dropped to 5% and is equivalent to the rate in February 2020, before the COVID-19 pandemic reached the country. It has more than halved since April of this year, when it measured 10.4%. During the height of the pandemic, Iceland‚Äôs government implemented several economic response packages that included partial unemployment benefits for workers on reduced hours as well as financial aid for businesses. Despite the drop in unemployment, two notable changes are apparent in Iceland‚Äôs labour market as the country embarks on a path toward economic recovery. Rates of long-term unemployment have more than doubled among those who are out of work; and among those who are working, many are on temporary contracts subsidised by the state treasury. The subsidies that allowed many businesses to rehire laid-off workers are scheduled to end in the coming weeks. These subsidies were heavily utilised by tourism-related businesses, which tend to wind down over the quieter fall and winter seasons. It remains to be seen whether tourism companies have recovered sufficiently to retain employees once government subsidies run out. In February 2020, right before the pandemic broke out in Iceland, there were 9,162 people on the unemployment register. Of those people, 1,893 had been without work for 12 months or more, or 21%. In September 2021, the number of people who had been unemployed for a year or longer had jumped to 4,598, or 44% of all those unemployed. The Directorate of Labour is aware of this shift and its director Unnur Sverrisd√≥ttir stated it would focus on tackling long-term unemployment this winter. As has often been the case in recent years, unemployment rates are highest on the Su√∞urnes peninsula, in Southwest Iceland. The peninsula‚Äôs proximity to the airport has led to a high dependence on tourism as a source of jobs. Foreign citizens are more likely to be unemployed than Icelandic citizens, and research shows that they were hit harder by the pandemic recession in Iceland. Foreign citizens‚Äô rates of unemployment have, however, returned to pre-pandemic figures.

headline: Bank Subsidiary to Build Wellness Community in Capital Area
body: The capital-area municipality of Gar√∞ab√¶r has signed a contract with Arnarland ehf, a subsidiary of Arion Bank, to build a new wellness community, Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞ reports. The community will ‚Äúemphasize quality of life, nature, and health-promoting services‚Äù and be open to residents who are 50 years and older. Per its website, Arnarland be designed with the United Nation‚Äôs sustainable development goals in mind and feature an on-site center for companies that ‚Äúspecialize in healthcare services, development, and innovation.‚Äù The pharmaceutical and medical supply concern √ìsar, as well as its subsidiaries Icepharma and Parlogis, will be building their future headquarters within the neighborhood. ‚ÄúThe companies and the residences will benefit from one another‚Äôs presence and increase the health-related services that are available to nearby communities,‚Äù remarked Parlogis CEO H√°lfdan Gunnarsson. Arnarland, which will be approximately 10 ha [24 acres] in size, will be built on a plot of land that has been owned by Landey, an Arion Bank subsidiary, since 2016. Landey recently changed its name to Arnarland ehf. Arion bank holds a 51% share in the neighborhood. The real estate company Fasteignaf√©lagi√∞ Akurey, holds the other 49%. The real estate company is owned by father and son Kristj√°n J√≥hannsson and J√≥hann Ingi Kristj√°nsson, who together, own a combined majority, or 64%, in Icepharma and Parlogis. Arnarland ehf CEO √ûorger√∞ur Anna Einarsd√≥ttir says the community will fill a real niche in the capital-area housing market. ‚ÄúIn our opinion, there‚Äôs a real shortage of high quality and spacious apartments for people who want to downsize when their chicks leave the nest. This neighborhood will place an emphasis on allowing residents to cultivate body and soul in a beautiful and nourishing environment.‚Äù

headline: Arion Bank to Ensure 80% of Staff Salaries During Parental Leave
body: Arion Bank has announced that it will guarantee employees up to 80% of their wages during parental leave. The bank promises to pay employees with salaries upwards of 600,000 ISK per month (‚Ç¨4,015 / $4,643) ‚Äì which is the salary cap, before taxes, of the Parental-Leave Benefit Fund ‚Äì an additional benefit so that they can take home close to 80% of their regular wages. In a statement published on the bank‚Äôs website on Wednesday, Arion Bank declared that it would henceforth guarantee employees up to 80% of their wages during parental leave. The benefit will be granted in addition to payments from the Parental-Leave Benefit Fund and other compensation negotiated through collective-wage agreements. The statement further encouraged employees to make full use of their right to parental leave. The salaries of bank employees vary. As reported by Kjarninn, the monthly wages of individuals employed as consultants and brokers, including those working for Arion Bank, exceeded ISK 1.7 million (‚Ç¨11,377 / $13,158) last year. According to the bank‚Äôs new parental-compensation package, the average Arion broker would earn approximately ISK 1,360,000 (‚Ç¨9,103 / $10,528) during up to six months of parental leave, or ISK 760,000 (‚Ç¨5,087 / $5,882) more than the expected payment from the Parental-Leave Benefit Fund. Employees with salaries of ISK 1 million (‚Ç¨6,693 / $7,740) a month receive an additional ISK 200,000 (‚Ç¨1,339 / $1,547) and employees earning ISK 800,000 (‚Ç¨5,355 / $6,192) receive an additional ISK 40,000 (‚Ç¨268 / $310). The parental-leave package forms a part of Arion Bank‚Äôs endeavour toward gender equality. ‚ÄúThe average wages of men, whether in Arion Bank or in society at large, exceed those of women,‚Äù the statement from the bank reads ‚Äì ‚Äúand fathers are less likely to use their parental leaves than mothers.‚Äù ‚ÄúGuaranteeing employees 80% of their wages during parental leave, regardless of gender or position,‚Äù the statement continues, ‚Äúmakes it easier for them to take time off. In this way, this initiative aims to encourage more fathers to make use of their rights. In the future, this step may prove beneficial in ensuring equality of wages between men and women, on the one hand, and increasing the number of women in managerial positions and other positions, on the other hand. Today, women form 44% of the bank‚Äôs management.‚Äù The statement ends with a quote from Director Benedikt G√≠slason: ‚ÄúWe hope to make the bank a more desirable place of employment in the eyes of young and talented people.‚Äù

headline: Central Bank Continues Raising Interest Rates
body: A 0.25% to the Central Bank‚Äôs key interest rate has now brought it up to 1.5%. The bank‚Äôs Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) announced the decision to raise the rate in a press release today. The MPC consistently lowered interest rates throughout last year in response to the pandemic recession but now says it expects the domestic economic recovery to continue. The Central Bank‚Äôs key interest rate reached a historic low of 0.75% in November last year. In comparison, rates in January 2020 stood at 3% and in January 2019 at 4.5%. This is the Bank‚Äôs third interest rate hike since May, indicating a change in direction as the economic forecast has improved. The Central Bank also tightened mortgage regulations at the end of last month, stating that rising real estate prices had ‚Äúgone hand-in-hand with increased household debt.‚Äù The move, which entails instituting a maximum debt-to-service ratio of 35% for borrowers (40% for first-time buyers) is intended to support stability on the housing market. Today‚Äôs press release says, however, that housing accounted for ‚Äúa large share of headline inflation in September.‚Äù Although underlying inflation is declining, the bank states ‚Äúthere is cause for concern in that inflation expectations appear to have begun rising again.‚Äù¬†The bank states it will apply tools to ensure that inflation eases back to target.

headline: MFRI Advises Greatly Increased Capelin Catch Quota for 2021-22
body: The Marine and Freshwater Research Institute of Iceland has set its new advice for capelin catch quotas for the 2021/22 season at 904,200 tonnes following this autumn‚Äôs research expeditions. This is close to sevenfold last year‚Äôs quota and a dramatic shift from 2019 and 2020 when no capelin quota was issued at all. The capelin catch will have a positive impact on the economy, states Finance Minister Bjarni Benediktsson. The MFRI‚Äôs advice is based on the autumn‚Äôs acoustic measurements but the final catch quota will be issued early in 2022, following further research expeditions in January-February. ¬†Minister of Finance Bjarni Benediktsson told 200 M√≠lur that the news creates opportunities for fishing towns around the country and that it‚Äôs a positive for Iceland‚Äôs economy, which is still recovering from the effects of the global pandemic. ‚ÄúThis increase in capelin quota would mean that we see an increase in export revenue and more economic growth next year than expected,‚Äù Bjarni stated. According to the most recent acoustic survey, the capelin‚Äôs spawning stock biomass is estimated at 1,833,000 tonnes. The harvest control rule (HCR) aims at leaving at least 150,000 tonnes of mature capelin at the time of spawning in March with a 95% probability. The index of immature capelin (age 1 and 2) was the third-highest since 1980. While the autumn‚Äôs research expeditions were extensive, weather delays caused less coverage in the southwestern parts of the survey area where immature capelin dominated. There was also limited coverage north of Iceland. The estimate of mature capelin has a higher uncertainty than before but acoustic measurements this winter might clarify this issue. The total landings of the 2020/2021 fishing year amounted to about 128 600 tonnes, which is among the lowest catches since 1980. No capelin was caught in Icelandic waters during summer and autumn 2020. The 2021 winter fishery took place from January until March. Despite relatively low catch, last year‚Äôs export value of capelin amounted to 20 billion ISK [$154,500,000, ‚Ç¨133,140,000]. If it fetches similar prices this year, the export value could be seven times as much.

headline: Apartment Construction Hits 4.5-Year Low
body: There have not been fewer apartments under construction in the Reykjav√≠k capital area since February 2017, R√öV reports. If the trend continues, housing prices will continue to rise in the region. The main reason is a lack of plots, according to the Federation of Icelandic Industries (Samt√∂k I√∞na√∞arins, or SI). There are currently just under 3,400 apartments being built in the capital area. This is an 18% drop compared to the same time last year, when there were 4,100 apartments under construction. The biggest contraction is in Reykjav√≠k, where apartment construction has dropped by 24%, and the smallest in K√≥pavogur, where it has contracted by 10%. Three out of every four apartments under construction in the capital area are in these two municipalities. Read More: Iceland‚Äôs Housing Market The combination of high demand and low supply pushes housing prices upward, which can be dangerous for the housing market. Ing√≥lfur Bender, SI‚Äôs chief economist, stated the lack of building plots is the main issue. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs where the bottleneck is, as we have been pointing out for a long time. The municipal authorities have been twiddling their thumbs on this issue.‚Äù Ing√≥lfur says the Central Bank‚Äôs decision to tighten mortgage regulations will lower demand, but supply is the root of the problem.

headline: Central Bank of Iceland Tightens Mortgage Regulations
body: In an effort to minimise long-term risk as well as household debt, the Central Bank of Iceland has adopted a maximum debt sevice-to-income ratio of 35% for borrowers and 40% for first-time buyers. The Central Bank lowered interest rates throughout last year in response to the pandemic recession, allowing many homeowners to refinance their debt or purchase more real estate. House prices rose as a result, and that ‚Äúhas gone hand-in-hand with increased household debt,‚Äù according to a statement from the Bank‚Äôs Financial Stability Committee. Read More: Iceland‚Äôs Housing Market The statement says that Iceland‚Äôs economic recovery over recent months has ‚Äúsupported household and businesses. On the other hand, asset prices ‚Äì equity securities and real estate prices in particular ‚Äì have risen markedly.‚Äù The position of Iceland‚Äôs three main banks is strong, with their capital and liquidity ‚Äúwell above regulatory minima,‚Äù making them resilient, the Central Bank says.

headline: Icelandic Sheep Fetch Handsome Prices at First-Ever Online Auction
body: Icelandic sheep were auctioned in the UK‚Äôs first-ever online auction, B√¶ndabla√∞i√∞ reports. The auction was handled by the Scottish ‚Äúlivestock marketing company‚Äù Harrison & Hetherington. Twenty-six animals were auctioned in the two-day auction in early September. The highest-earning sheep was the only ewe on offer, Alfifa, who, according to the auction catalog, ‚Äúhad a single ram in 2020 and twin ewe lambs in 2021.‚Äù Alfifa fetched ISK 56,000 [¬£317; $438; ‚Ç¨371].
