body: State mediator A√∞alsteinn Leifsson presented his mediation proposal in the wage dispute between Efling and SA at a press conference yesterday. The proposal met with criticism from both SA and the Efling Union. The state mediator believes that he is well within his legal rights. Yesterday, State mediator A√∞alsteinn Leifsson presented a special mediating proposal (i.e. mi√∞lunartillaga) to resolve the dispute between the Efling Union and the Confederation of Icelandic Enterprise (SA). Negotiations between the two parties have devolved into a sort of Gordian knot, with the last meeting between Efling and SA lasting only a minute. The proposal means that members of the Efling union will have to vote on the same contract previously agreed upon by other unions. S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir, Chair of Efling, told R√öV yesterday that she believed the state mediator had broken the law with his proposal: he had not consulted with Efling. Halld√≥r Benjam√≠n √ûorbergsson, Director of SA, struck a similar note, arguing that it was ‚Äúthe right of the disputing parties‚Äù to bring the case to a conclusion. Following the response from Efling and SA, A√∞alsteinn sent out a press release yesterday in which he rejected any claims about the illegality of the proposal. A mediating proposal was one of the resources available to the state mediator to try to ensure peace in the labour market. ‚ÄúGiven the state of the dispute between SA and Efling, it was my assessment, the office‚Äôs assessment, that it was inevitable to try this remedy.‚Äù A√∞alsteinn admitted that the labour legislation imposes the duty on the state mediator to consult with the parties to a wage dispute before submitting such a proposal: this applies to the content of the proposal and the procedure for voting. ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs why I called representatives of both parties to a meeting with me today for this purpose. I discussed it with them before the proposal was made public. This obligation to consult the parties, however, does not imply that they have the right to intervene or veto the proposal.‚Äù As noted by R√öV, A√∞alsteinn denies that the way in which the proposal was presented was illegal in any way. When asked if the parties to a dispute should be familiar with the content of the legislation, he replied that the law was very clear as regards the authorisation of a mediating proposal. ‚ÄúIt is also very clear in the labour legislation that when a mediation proposal has been submitted, a vote must take place.‚Äù S√≥lveig Anna went on to describe the proposal as a ‚Äúmonstrosity‚Äù (i.e. √≥skapna√∞ur) that failed to mediate anything. Efling‚Äôs point of view had not been taken into account: the state mediator was simply imposing SA‚Äôs offer on the Efling Union. A√∞alsteinn replied that this was far from the case. He was not proposing an agreement from SA but rather one that the Federation of General and Special workers in Iceland (SGS) had negotiated with SA. ‚ÄúAfter very difficult and demanding wage negotiations ‚Äì where an agreement was struck. This agreement has since been approved by an overwhelming majority of votes in all of the eighteen unions within SGS. It should also be noted that this agreement includes the highest proportional increases that have been settled in this round of wage negotiations, within the general labour market, over the past weeks and months.‚Äù At the time of writing, the Efling union had not submitted its membership list to the state mediator; the deadline was 8 PM yesterday. As noted by R√öV, Efling is thereby shirking its statutory duty, given that the office of the state mediator has the right to receive the membership list. El√≠sabet S. √ìlafsd√≥ttir, Chief of Staff at the State Mediator‚Äô office, told R√öV yesterday that the office would have to consider its next steps: ‚ÄúAt this stage, we can send Efling another notice. If the notice proves ineffective, it may eventually be necessary to obtain a ruling from the district court to force delivery.‚Äù The proposal will be put to a vote by the members of Efling and voting will begin at 12 noon on Saturday and continue until 5 PM on Tuesday. This article will be updated

headline: No Agreement Between SA and Efling After Minute-Long Meeting
body: In a final push to avert a strike, the state mediator called a meeting between representatives from the Confederation of Icelandic Enterprise (SA) and the Efling Union; the meeting, which is reportedly the shortest ever to be held at the state mediator‚Äôs facilities, was unsuccessful, R√öV reports. As Efling members began to vote on strike action, the state mediator invited Efling‚Äôs negotiating committee back to the negotiating table alongside the Confederation of Icelandic Enterprise (SA) today. The meeting did not go well, lasting ‚Äúall of about a minute,‚Äù according to R√öV. In an interview following the meeting, Halld√≥r Benjam√≠n √ûorbergsson, Chair of SA, told R√öV that S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir, Chair of the Efling Union, was preventing agreements from being reached, and by calling a strike ‚Äì forfeiting the possibility of retroactive wage agreements. The Deep North Podcast: Wage Negotiations ‚ÄúWith the intransigence that she displayed today, S√≥lveig Anna is preventing union members from contractual wage improvements,‚Äù Halld√≥r remarked. S√≥lveig Anna responded bluntly to SA‚Äôs criticism. ‚ÄúDo people really think it‚Äôs normal, acceptable, that while you can criticise the dress code and behaviour of Efling members, you can‚Äôt pay those same people, who produce the profits, which find their way into other people‚Äôs pockets, decent wages?‚Äù S√≥lveig Anna iterated her conviction that Efling members were prepared to go on strike in order to push for decent wages. ‚ÄúIt is a characteristic of civilised societies that people can provide for themselves with the work they do. In the case of many Efling members, this is simply not the case. I find it disgusting. Unacceptable. And we are fighting for this to be changed,‚Äù S√≥lveig Anna told R√öV.

headline: Government Signs Agreement to Bolster Elite Sports in Iceland
body: This weekend, the government signed an agreement with the National Olympic and Sports Association of Iceland (√çS√ç) on the formulation of policy concerning elite sports. Former Olympian and coach V√©steinn Hafsteinsson has been hired to oversee the project. During a press conference in Gothenburg, Sweden, last Saturday, January 21, the Ministry of Education and Children‚Äôs Affairs and the National Olympic and Sports Association of Iceland signed an agreement on the formulation of policy concerning elite sports in Iceland. As part of the agreement, V√©steinn Hafsteinsson ‚Äì former Olympic athlete and coach ‚Äì will relocate to Iceland to collaborate with the government to formulate measures on how best to improve the status and rights of elite athletes in Iceland. Minister √Åsmundur Einar Da√∞ason has also appointed a special working group comprised of interested parties to collaborate on the project, which V√©steinn Hafsteinsson will lead. The aim is to create ‚Äúthe best possible framework for elite sports in Iceland‚Äù and to put ‚Äúhigh-performance athletes on equal footing with their competitors on an international level.‚Äù The government‚Äôs press release notes that V√©steinn, as a coach and former top-ranked discus thrower, is ‚Äúfamiliar with the conditions required to shape and sustain elite athletic performance.‚Äù Last year, V√©steinn was chosen Coach of the Year in Sweden, having helped Swedish discus throwers Daniel Stahl and Simon Pettersson secure gold and silver medals respectively at the Tokyo Olympics. V√©steinn has been involved in a wide variety of sports over the years, both in Iceland and abroad, and ‚Äúknows the environment and the athletes well.‚Äù V√©steinn has been hired for the next five years to formulate policy changes with the government and, in the future, follow up on the implementation of this policy in cooperation with the Ministry of Education and Children‚Äôs Affairs and √çS√ç. V√©steinn will also assume the role of √çS√ç‚Äôs Performance Manager where he will, among other things, supervise √çS√ç‚Äôs Achievement Strategy (Afreksstefnu) and aid Icelandic competitors in preparation for the Olympics. ‚ÄúIt is very pleasing to cooperate with V√©steinn on this important project,‚Äù √Åsmundur Einar Da√∞ason, Minister of Education and Children‚Äôs Affairs, stated at the press conference. ‚ÄúElite athletes are role models. They inspire and motivate us. They prove that we can achieve excellent results, despite our smallness. This initiative will serve to strengthen sports across the board, while at the same time stimulating recreation and solidarity. Our top athletes do not enjoy the same support as their foreign counterparts. Nor do they have access to the same facilities. They also do not enjoy the same civil liberties as the rest of us. This needs to be fixed. With a new national stadium, we improve our facilities. And now begins a review of our entire framework for elite sports in Iceland as stipulated in the government agreement.‚Äù As noted on the government‚Äôs website, the aim of the work, going forward, is to review and propose changes to the framework, legislation, and other aspects deemed necessary to provide support for elite athletes in Iceland. The working group is tasked with examining, in particular, the cost of participation in national-team activities for competitors and their families, as well as examining the civil liberties of accomplished athletes within the state‚Äôs different social support systems.

headline: S√≥lveig Anna Confident That Strikes Will Be Approved
body: 300 employees at √çslandsh√≥tel hotels are set to go on strike if action is approved by the Efling union. Efling‚Äôs Chairperson is confident that the strike will be approved. Tourism advocates are surprised that the strikes are being directed towards a single employer, R√öV reports. Efling union members will begin voting on strike action today. If the first wave of action is approved, three hundred employees of √çslandsh√≥tel hotels (i.e. custodial staff) will go on strike. S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir, Chairperson of Efling, told R√öV yesterday that, based on conversations with hotel workers, she expected union members to approve strike action. ‚ÄúA strike notice has been accepted, and voting will begin tomorrow at noon. The strike action applies to union members employed by √çslandsh√≥tel hotels. These are approximately three hundred people, custodial staff, who have the opportunity to vote on whether they are prepared to strike in order to push for better contracts: Efling contracts for Efling people.‚Äù ‚ÄúAnd you expect union members to approve of the action?‚Äù a reporter with R√öV inquired. ‚ÄúYes, I expect that the action will be met with approval. The results of a very extensive wage survey conducted by Efling indicate that a very large group of Efling members are prepared to quit their jobs to fight for better conditions. Representatives from our negotiating committee have also been visiting these hotels to speak with union members. It‚Äôs gone very well, and we had a meeting here yesterday, which also went very well,‚Äù S√≥lveig Anna observed yesterday. Tourism advocates are surprised that the strike action is being directed at a single employer. Krist√≥fer Oliversson, the Director of the Association of Companies in Hotel and Accommodation Services (FHG), told R√öV that it was ‚Äúunbelievable‚Äù that these strikes were being directed against almost ‚Äúa single ID number, a single hotel owner.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been just over six months since we were properly up and running, and now another setback. And it‚Äôs always the same custodial staff that‚Äôs being asked to strike. This is about five per cent of Efling members here in Reykjav√≠k who are being asked to take up the fight, again and again. I find it quite incredible,‚Äù Krist√≥fer stated yesterday. S√≥lveig Anna added that this was only the first step. ‚ÄúAt the same time, we‚Äôve been working on a bigger and more comprehensive plan, which will then go to a strike vote if no wage agreement is negotiated in the near future,‚Äù S√≥lveig Anna observed. Krist√≥fer told R√öV yesterday that the tourism industry was in ‚Äúa tight spot‚Äù after a difficult time during the pandemic.‚Äù There are good months ahead; February has now become a good time to visit Iceland. When the views of tourism advocates were put to S√≥lveig Anna, the Efling Chair stated that she did buy the argument. ‚ÄúI find it incredible that people who are willing to keep these companies going, to profit from the work of others, lack the decency to pay those same people a living wage.‚Äù When asked if she expected that further action by Efling would be directed against the tourism industry, S√≥lveig refused to answer. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to answer that at this time. Ultimately, this is for the negotiating committee to decide. We make all our decisions during meetings with the committee, and I discuss them when they‚Äôve been made,‚Äù S√≥lveig Anna remarked. When asked if any specific groups within the union had refused to strike, S√≥lveig responded thusly: ‚ÄúNo, no groups have refused to go on strike, not at all.‚Äù

headline: Electroshock Weapons to Be Employed by Middle of the Year
body: The Minister of Justice hopes that the police will be able to put the first electroshock weapons to use this year, R√öV reports. The minister‚Äôs decision to grant this authority to the police should not come as a surprise. In an interview with R√öV yesterday, Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson affirmed that his decision to authorise the police to carry electroshock weapons will stand ‚Äì despite the criticism. He hopes that the first weapons will be in use by the middle of the year. An amendment to existing regulations is expected to take effect next week. Electroshock weapons will only be assigned to police officers who have received the necessary training, and such weapons may only be used if other, milder measures are not deemed sufficient. ‚ÄúThis will, of course, take some time. I expect that the implementation will take approximately one to two years. My hope is that the first officers will begin carrying these electroshock weapons in the middle of the year or so,‚Äù J√≥n observed. J√≥n has been criticised for not giving Parliament sufficient opportunity to discuss the amendment. During a radio interview yesterday, Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir remarked that it would have been more appropriate to discuss the matter more thoroughly in Parliament. ‚ÄúShe said that more of a discussion needed to take place, and I have submitted a memorandum to Parliament; the matter has received a certain amount of discussion at that level,‚Äù J√≥n added. When asked if the matter had not been discussed thoroughly enough, J√≥n replied that it was not for him to judge. ‚ÄúUltimately, it‚Äôs the PM‚Äôs decision. This change to the regulation has been carefully prepared, and it has been repeatedly discussed, as I‚Äôve told the media previously; it has not provoked any special reactions or given rise to any special discussion, these reactions that have been expressed,‚Äù J√≥n explained. J√≥n plans on attending a meeting with the Judicial Affairs and Education Committee next week so as to answer the committee members‚Äô questions. He says that the decision to introduce electroshock weapons was made with the safety of police officers in mind. ‚ÄúI am prepared for any discussion about this and thoroughly present my reasoning behind the decision. A decision has been made based on the information I have and it stands,‚Äù J√≥n concluded.

headline: Samherji Tax Audit Concludes with Settlement
body: Samherji has reached an ISK 230 million ($1.6 million / ‚Ç¨1.5 million) settlement with the Directorate of Tax Investigations in Iceland, R√öV reports. The audit into the company‚Äôs books is, therefore, considered complete, although another investigation into alleged bribery and money laundering in Namibia is still undergoing. In a press release published last week, Samherji announced that an investigation launched by the Directorate of Tax Investigations (DTI) in Iceland into two companies within the Samherji Group has concluded with a settlement. The investigation was opened following revelations made by the investigative news programme Kveikur in 2019, R√öV notes. According to the settlement, Samherji and another related company, S√¶b√≥l, have been made to pay approximately ISK 214 million ($1.5 million / ‚Ç¨1.4 million) plus interest and penal interest as a result of the DTI‚Äôs reassessment. Samherji will also pay a non-criminal fine of ISK 15 million ($105,000 / ‚Ç¨97,000). Experts interviewed by R√öV stated that a settlement means that the case will remain a private matter between Samherji and the Directorate of Tax Investigations and will not go to court, where additional facts concerning the audit could become public. In the aforementioned press release, Samherji noted that the district attorney‚Äôs office has dropped criminal charges against the companies and their employees and confirmed that neither the managers nor the employees of the group have been guilty of criminal offences in relation to the audit. District Prosecutor √ìlafur √û√≥r Hauksson confirmed to R√öV that the tax side of the office‚Äôs investigation into Samherji had been transferred to the tax authorities, which is why the district prosecutor‚Äôs investigation into Samherji‚Äôs books has been completed. He noted, however, that the office‚Äôs investigation into alleged bribery and money laundering by Samherji in Namibia is still under investigation and that that investigation is well advanced. R√öV was unable to reach √ûorstein M√°r Baldvinsson, CEO of Samherji, following the company‚Äôs press release, and when the media outlet requested numerical data concerning the case, a representative for the company referred to the press release. Brynd√≠s Kristj√°nsd√≥ttir, Director of Tax Investigations, has yet to respond to R√öV‚Äôs requests for an interview. Samherji‚Äôs press release quotes CEO √ûorsteinn M√°r Baldvinsson, who maintains that the DTI took the initiative to conclude the investigation with a settlement: ‚ÄúIn these cases, a thorough investigation was carried out on all operations within the Samherji group. The company collaborated with integrity with the tax authorities and provided all requested documents. It should be noted that the Director of Tax Investigations took the initiative to end the cases amicably. There has been an unusually heated discussion about our company and our people, both in the media and in Parliament. It is, therefore, a great relief to be able to clear away serious accusations with the confirmation of official institutions. The key point here is that the cases are now over without any lawsuits being filed against the company or any individual.‚Äù

headline: Legislation Still Pending on the Taxation of Facebook and Google
body: Imposing a tax on ad revenue collected by foreign tech companies such as Facebook and Google is urgent, the Minister of Culture and Business Affairs told R√öV yesterday. Ad payments to foreign companies totalled approximately ISK 369 million ($2.6 million / ‚Ç¨2.4 million) in 2009 and have gradually increased to total nearly ISK 9.5 billion ($67 million / ‚Ç¨62 million) in 2021. Efforts have long been made to impose a tax on foreign tech giants such as Facebook and Google, which collect a large share of domestic ad revenue ‚Äì but pay no taxes in Iceland. This creates something of a void in the operation of Icelandic media companies, as well as the state treasury, R√öV notes. In September 2018, then Minister of Education Lilja Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir, called a press conference to discuss plans to strengthen the Icelandic media environment by reducing R√öV‚Äôs activities in the advertising market and by imposing taxes on foreign tech companies. ‚ÄúThis is precisely why we‚Äôre proposing a uniform tax on national and foreign online media because a lot of this ad revenue is leaving the country. It‚Äôs not just us who are facing this challenge but our neighbouring countries, too,‚Äù Lilja observed just over four years ago. R√öV echoed these statements to Lilja Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir ‚Äì who now serves as the Minister of Culture and Business Affairs ‚Äì in an interview yesterday. The minister responded thusly: ‚ÄúWe decided to provide operational support to private media companies in Iceland, which was an important step. We‚Äôre currently reviewing the tax environment of media companies and taking into account developments abroad. But as I stated in 2018: the time is now, and we‚Äôre still working according to that plan.‚Äù As noted by R√öV, Statistics Iceland has compiled an overview of the distribution of advertising funds between domestic and foreign media. In 2013, the ad revenue of foreign media increased significantly at the expense of domestic companies. That trend has continued. In 2021, for example, when profits were expected to rebound following COVID, domestic ad revenue increased by 14%, while the ad revenue of foreign companies increased by 34%. Statistics Iceland has also monitored ad payments to foreign companies, which in 2009 were approximately ISK 369 million ($2.6 million / ‚Ç¨2.4 million) but increased to almost ISK 9.5 billion ($67 million / ‚Ç¨62 million) in 2021. The institution honed in on ad payments made via credit cards, usually originating from smaller companies, or smaller ad campaigns, where foreign tech giants like Facebook and Google play a significant role. Their share of ad revenues has increased from 29% in 2009 when the total revenue was ISK 153 million ($1.1 million / ‚Ç¨991,000); to 89% in 2011, when the total revenue was ISK 371 million ($2.6 million / ‚Ç¨2.4 million). In 2021, their share of ad revenue was 95%, when total payments amounted to ISK 4.6 billion ($32 million / ‚Ç¨30 million). The two companies paid no taxes in Iceland. Given the global nature of the issue, R√öV notes, the government has collaborated with other countries within the OECD on how to tax this revenue. ‚ÄúI hope that we‚Äôll find a solution because there are many domestic companies that rely on a fair competitive position against these international giants,‚Äù Finance Minister Bjarni Benediktsson told R√öV in 2021. Lilja Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir stated that resolving the issue was an urgent matter but was unwilling to promise that such legislation would be passed this year. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs difficult to say. I hoped it would see the light of day in 2019, and then the year after. But then, of course, the attention of most governments shifted to the pandemic. But I feel like there‚Äôs a greater understanding of how urgent this is today.‚Äù

headline: Government to Establish Independent Human Rights Office
body: The Icelandic government hopes to soon establish an independent Human Rights Agency, a watchdog organization that will have the broad mandate of monitoring, promoting, and protecting human rights in Iceland, R√öV reports. It will also develop a national plan on human rights issues, which will be used as the basis for future policymaking. This was announced in the newly published draft of the so-called Green Book on Human Rights. Once the purview of the Ministry of Justice, human rights issues were transferred to the Office of the Prime Minister last year. It was then that Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir decided that a Green Book on human rights should be prepared. As it notes in its introduction, the Green Book ‚Äúdeals with the status and development of human rights in Iceland and gives an overview of key issues ahead and the best solutions for [‚Ä¶] resolving them.‚Äù An independent agency was one such proffered solution. New agency will operate alongside existing Human Rights Centre The new agency will be separate from the existing Icelandic Human Rights Centre, which was founded in 1995, receives ISK 41.1 million [$289,000; ‚Ç¨266,427] in government funding each year, and includes sixteen different member organizations, each of which ‚Äúdeals with human rights in one way or another.‚Äù These members include Samt√∂kin ‚Äô78, the national LGBTQIA+ organization of Iceland, the Icelandic Women‚Äôs Rights Association, Red Cross Iceland, the Icelandic chapters of Amnesty International and Save the Children, among others. The Centre‚Äôs goal is to ‚Äúwork towards the advancement of human rights by collecting information on domestic human rights issues, providing information to the public, supporting research and education, and promoting discussion and raising awareness about human rights in Iceland,‚Äù and in this way, it already ‚Äúoperates to a large extent like a national human rights office.‚Äù However, as it does not have a legal basis, the office doesn‚Äôt meet the Paris-aligned benchmarks, thereby necessitating the establishment of a new agency. The existing Human Rights Centre will continue its work alongside the new agency. Building on solid ground  As part of the Green Book drafting process, the government conducted a survey in which it asked Icelanders if they believe that human rights are effectively monitored in Iceland. Just under half of respondents, or 45.2%, said that current human rights‚Äô oversight in Iceland is average, while 26.1% said that the current oversight is handled ‚Äúpretty well,‚Äù 19% responded ‚Äúpretty poorly.‚Äù Four percent of respondents said current oversight is handled ‚Äúvery well,‚Äù 4.6% said ‚Äúvery poorly,‚Äù and 1% responded ‚Äúnot at all.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre building on really good and solid ground,‚Äù said Katr√≠n, remarking on the results of the survey. ‚ÄúIn recent years, which I want to include in this, a lot has been done, for instance, in regards to the rights of LGBTQIA+ people. We‚Äôve also made extensive legislative changes to ensure equal treatment and prevent discrimination. So there‚Äôs been a lot going on, but what we‚Äôve been trying to do is map the overall situation, which hadn‚Äôt been done before.‚Äù Katr√≠n also said that she believed the establishment of an independent human rights agency was ‚Äúdefinitely a prerequisite if we‚Äôre ever going to legislate the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which has been in the works for a long time. So we look at this work as a solid foundation for everything that is to come.‚Äù Asked when Icelanders could expect the new Human Rights Office to start its work, Katr√≠n said that she would probably present a bill about it in parliament‚Äôs upcoming winter session. ‚ÄúSo I hope that it would be able to get started shortly after, probably in 2024.‚Äù

headline: Efling Union Prepares Strikes Amid Failed Negotiations
body: The Efling Union will present proposals for strike action shortly after the weekend, V√≠sir reports. If the measures are approved in a vote among the members, the first strikes could be implemented by the end of the month. Three days ago, S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir, Chair of the Efling Union, broke off negotiations with the Confederation of Icelandic Enterprise (SA) and left a meeting with the state mediator. Strike actions are being prepared. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve begun preparations, but, of course, these are complicated measures, which need to be carefully executed. That‚Äôs the role of the negotiating committee. It will meet this weekend and continue its work. As far as when the strike notices will be ready, I can‚Äôt say at this time ‚Äì but likely sometime next week,‚Äù S√≥lveig Anna told V√≠sir. Once the committee has taken the matter into consideration, proposals for strike action will be put to a vote by Efling members. S√≥lveig Anna told V√≠sir that it was not clear how the measures would be implemented. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs for the negotiation committee to decide. Like all of our decisions, we make them together in a democratic fashion. It‚Äôs too early for me to discuss.‚Äù S√≥lveig Anna added that she had not heard from the state mediator since the talks ended, although, she had read in the media that the state mediator ‚Äúsaw no point in calling a meeting.‚Äù ‚ÄúPerhaps you should ask him why he sees no point in meeting again, but the answer would no doubt be that SA ‚Äì as everyone knows ‚Äì completely refused to accommodate us in any way. Whether something opens up: I hope so, of course.‚Äù When asked if strikes could begin by the end of the month, S√≥lveig stated that that was certainly a possibility. In an interview with V√≠sir yesterday, Halld√≥ra Sigr√≠√∞ur Sveinsd√≥ttir, Chairman of the B√°ran Union, stated that dozens of Efling members had contacted B√°ran on Wednesday and Thursday seeking to transfer their membership from Efling to B√°ran.

headline: FME Believes √çslandsbanki Broke the Law During March Sale
body: √çslandsbanki has started a conciliation process with the Central Bank‚Äôs Financial Supervisory Authority due to the bank‚Äôs possible violations of the law, R√öV reports. The bank‚Äôs employees were among the buyers in a closed bidding arrangement last March when the government sold a 22.5% stake in the bank. The Central Bank‚Äôs Financial Supervisory Authority (FME) believes that √çslandsbanki may have violated the provisions of laws and regulations, regarding the bank and its operations, during the sale of the government‚Äôs 22.5% stake in the bank last March, R√öV reports. This is the result of a preliminary assessment that √çslandsbanki has received. The preliminary assessment states that the Financial Supervisory Authority has the authority to impose administrative fines for the violations. The agency is also authorised to conclude cases through a settlement in the event that the offender admits to the offences and submits to sanctions. √çslandsbanki‚Äôs announcement to the Icelandic Stock Exchange states that a conciliation process has begun and that the bank‚Äôs management takes FME‚Äôs initial assessment seriously: ‚ÄúA conciliation process has begun, and in the coming weeks, the bank will present its explanations and views on FME‚Äôs initial assessment. The bank‚Äôs management takes FME‚Äôs initial assessment seriously. As previously reported, the bank has already made changes to internal rules and processes and will continue such work during the reconciliation process.‚Äù Edda Hermannsd√≥ttir, Director of Communication for √çslandsbanki, told R√öV that Birna Einarsd√≥ttir, √çslandsbanki‚Äôs Director, could not comment on the conciliation while it was ongoing. As insinuated by R√öV, among the rules violated by √çslandsbanki was allowing employees to buy shares in what was a closed sales process; the bank announced in May that it would be changing its rules regarding its employees‚Äô securities transactions: ‚ÄúThere has been a lot of discussion about the sales process and the arrangement employed. Among other things, the participation of the bank‚Äôs employees in the sale has been criticised. We take this criticism seriously and are currently working on changes to the bank‚Äôs rules regarding employees‚Äô securities transactions,‚Äù Birna Einarsd√≥ttir was quoted as saying in an article on Mbl.is last May. R√öV states that the nature of the bank‚Äôs other possible violations has not been revealed. Sigmar Gu√∞mundsson, MP for the Liberal Reform Party, called √çslandsbanki‚Äôs press release ‚Äúpitiful‚Äù in a post on Facebook yesterday. ‚ÄúThe bank‚Äôs offences are committed during the sale of public property, and the bank could have shown more initiative in providing information to this same public.‚Äù The director of the bank prefers to remain silent during this so-called conciliation process, Sigmar noted, a prerogative not available to other criminal offenders.

headline: A Fisherman by Any Other Name: Terminology in New Law Sparks Debate
body: A new law regarding ships‚Äô crews that went into effect at the beginning of the month is sparking considerable debate throughout Iceland, but not because of the content of the law. Rather, critics have taken issue with the choice of wording in it, namely the use of the word fiskari, most easily translatable as ‚Äòfisher,‚Äô in lieu of the term fiskima√∞ur, which literally means ‚Äòfisher+man.‚Äô Mbl.is, R√öV, and V√≠sir have all reported. Critics, including some in the industry and current or former politicians, have called the word choice an example of the sterilization of Icelandic, or even an example of the language‚Äôs slide into n√Ωlenska, or Orwellian Newspeak. Eir√≠kur R√∂gnvaldsson, Professor emeritus in Icelandic Language and Linguistics at the University of Iceland, takes a different view, however, noting that the word fiskari is actually a centuries-old Icelandic word and one that was in use long before modern debates about gender neutrality in language. Law aims to ‚Äòpromote equal access of the sexes to education, training, and jobs aboard Icelandic ships‚Äô According to the text of the ‚ÄúLaw concerning ships‚Äô crews,‚Äù 2022 nr. 82, its aim is to ‚Äúensure the safety of crews, passengers, and ships, and increase protections against the pollution of the seas. These goals will be achieved by making certain mandates about the education and training, age, sailing time, health, vision, and hearing of those who work onboard and in so doing ensure the professional competence of crews based on the size of the ship, its role, and its area of operation.‚Äù This overview goes on to say that the law ‚Äúis intended to promote equal access of the sexes to education, training, and jobs aboard Icelandic ships.‚Äù It then includes an extensive¬† definition of terms, in which it defines a fiskari as ‚Äúhe or she who works or is hired to work on a fishing vessel‚Ä¶harbour pilots, law enforcement officers, other parties in staff positions working with the public, employees on land who perform work onboard fishing vessels, or fishing inspectors are not considered to be fishers.‚Äù It is worth noting that while the word fiskari is being interpreted by critics as inherently gender-neutral because it does not make use of the suffix ‚Äìma√∞ur, meaning ‚Äòman‚Äô (-menn in the plural), fiskari is still a masculine-gendered word in Icelandic. [Note: Icelandic has three grammatical genders: masculine, feminine, and neuter.] It is also worth noting that in the Icelandic, the above-quoted definition also includes the use of three additional masculine-gendered terms for different roles/jobs: hafns√∂gumenn (harbour pilots); starfsmenn (employees); eftirlitsmenn (inspectors). ‚ÄòThe most ‚Äòwoke‚Äô government in the history of Iceland‚Äô Critics, some of whom work within the industry, were quick to voice their dissatisfaction with the word choice. ‚ÄúFiskari is a malaprop in my opinion,‚Äù said Valmundur Valmundsson, the chair of the Icelandic Seamen‚Äôs Association. ‚ÄúSj√≥mannadagurinn [Fishermen‚Äôs Day] is never going to be called Fiskaradagurinn [Fishers‚Äô Day].‚Äù Eir√≠kur √ìli Dagbjartsson, fishing manager of the Grindav√≠k-based fishing company √ûorbj√∂rn hf. felt similarly, telling Morgunbla√∞i√∞ that he thought the shift to the word fiskari was ‚Äúpreposterous.‚Äù Current and former politicians have also taken to social media to voice their dissatisfaction. Former Prime Minister and chair of the Centre Party Sigmundur Dav√≠√∞ Gunnlaugsson wrote a Facebook post in which he said the use of the word fiskari was part of the ‚ÄúPC-powers‚Äô ongoing attempt to turn Icelandic into Newspeak, in the manner of Orwell‚Äù and fretted that ‚Äúthe most ‚Äòwoke‚Äô government in the history of Iceland will hardly stop with this.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt used to be common knowledge that women were also -menn [the plural form of ma√∞ur, men],‚Äù Sigmundur Dav√≠√∞ continued. ‚ÄúThat knowledge seems to be getting lost now, as can be observed from the strange explanations of those who think the change [i.e. removing the suffix -ma√∞ur] is an important step in equality issues.‚Äù Sigmundur Dav√≠√∞ then concluded his post by listing off a number of job titles that incorporate the suffix -ma√∞ur [-man] and which he said were at risk of falling victim next, i.e. that talsma√∞ur [spokesman] might be converted to talari [speaker/spokesperson]. ‚ÄòIt is important to respect their origin and traditional usage‚Äô In a post on Facebook, former Social Democratic Alliance MP, now a professor in the Department of Social Sciences at Bifr√∂st University, √ìlina Kjer√∫lf √ûorvar√∞ard√≥ttir said she could hardly formulate a response. ‚ÄúThe words that we use are something other, something more, than just sterile units of meaning, cut and dried,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúIf that were the case, we couldn‚Äôt talk about a living language, about creative manners of expression. Our words are laden with feeling, the way we see life, our circumstances, our history and culture. ‚ÄúThe word ‚Äòsj√≥ma√∞ur‚Äô has deep-seated emotional implications for many Icelanders, who are familiar with our nation‚Äôs struggle for survival over the centuries. Some job titles are compound words using the word ‚Äòma√∞ur‚Äô [-man]‚Äîflugma√∞ur [pilot], herma√∞ur [soldier], etc‚Äîand others aren‚Äôt‚Äîkennari [teacher], l√¶knir [doctor], prestur [pastor]. It‚Äôs well and good that words aren‚Äôt all formed in the same way. It is more important, I think, to respect their origin and traditional usage, instead of bending and buckling‚Ä¶the language [according to] some puritanical policy about how words should be created.‚Äù √ìlina continued: ‚ÄúSterlization in linguistics is, at best, indifference and incomprehension, and at worst, hostility: to creation, history, and emotion.‚Äù The word fiskari dates back to the 16th century What the overriding criticism belies, however, is the word fiskari enjoys a long history and centuries-old usage in Iceland. ‚ÄúThis word dates back to the 16th century at least,‚Äù says Eir√≠kur R√∂gnvaldsson, Professor emeritus in Icelandic Language and Linguistics at the University of Iceland. ‚ÄúIt was in the first book that was printed in Iceland, Oddur Gottsk√°lksson‚Äôs translation of the New Testament.‚Äù ‚ÄúAccording to the sources I‚Äôve looked at, it seems that from the 16th century to the 19th century, this was the primary word used for [people who fish], much more common than the word fiskima√∞ur.‚Äù Eir√≠kur points out that in the census from 1845, which recorded Icelanders‚Äô occupations, around 150 people called themselves a fiskari, while only seven called themselves a fiskima√∞ur. ‚ÄúFiskari is used up until the 20th century,‚Äù says Eir√≠kur. After that, the word fell out of common use and the word fiskima√∞ur became more prevalent. The most common useage, however, is the word sj√≥ma√∞ur [seaman].‚Äù (As an interesting corollary to Eir√≠kur‚Äôs points, one might consider these words‚Äô frequency in the work of Halld√≥r Laxness, the country‚Äôs sole Nobel Prize winner and a passionate advocate for the Icelandic language who is still considered one of its preeminent stylists and practitioners. Per data compiled in the comprehensive online Icelandic dictionary Snara, fiskari appears 20 times in his writings and fiskima√∞ur¬†appears with the exact same frequency: 20 times. The word sj√≥ma√∞ur, on the other hand, appears some 65 times.) Returning to the text of the law itself, Eir√≠kur points to the section where various terms are defined. ‚ÄúA number of words that are used in the law are clarified. In legal texts, it‚Äôs important that the meaning of words are clear. It is clear [in the text] that fiskari is a word for people who work on fishing vessels. This is to say, it‚Äôs a special term. It is common for legal texts and regulations to use words that have specific and set meanings, where other words are frequently used in everyday speech.‚Äù Speaking to concerns related to the fate of other Icelandic words that end in ‚Äìma√∞ur [-man], Eir√≠kur continues: ‚ÄúWords that end in ‚Äìma√∞ur have an undeniably strong connection to men in many people‚Äôs minds. In old rural society, there was a clear difference between male and female laborers,‚Äù he explains, giving the examples of the gender-specific words vinnuma√∞ur [working man] and vinnukona [working woman] and kaupama√∞ur [merchant-man] and kaupakona [merchant-woman]. ‚ÄúFor people who want to demasculinize the language, these words that end in ‚Äìma√∞ur are much more masculine than other words that are grammatically masculine. People ask: why just this one? Why won‚Äôt other words that end in ‚Äìma√∞ur be taken? The answer to this is maybe, first and foremost, that this word, fiskari, already existed. In this instance, there was an existing word that could be utilized, a synonym. There is no similar word for sj√≥ma√∞ur [seaman] and farma√∞ur [merchant sailor]. We have the word sj√≥ari [seafarer, grammatically masculine but formed in the same way that fiskari is formed; more implicitly gender-neutral], but it‚Äôs completely different [in meaning] than the word sj√≥ma√∞ur.‚Äù [Note: the word sj√≥ari implies that the individual in question is a very experienced sailor, comparable to ‚Äòold salt‚Äô in English.] By using the word fiskari in the text of the new law, lawmakers are reviving an old, existing Icelandic word, says Eir√≠kur, something that can‚Äôt fairly be considered malapropism or ‚Äòincorrect‚Äô language. Language necessarily changes and morphs over time, he says, through common use. ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt that the very definition of ‚Äòcorrect‚Äô language?‚Äù he asks. ‚ÄúThat it‚Äôs the language people speak?‚Äù

headline: Work Group to Submit Report on Reykjanesbraut Closure
body: A work group appointed by Minister Sigur√∞ur Ingi J√≥hannsson to review the closure of Reykjanesbraut in December is expected to submit a draft plan to the Ministry of Infrastructure next week, Mbl.is reports. The closure of Reykjanesbraut led to numerous flight cancellations and delays. Following heavy snow in the capital area during the days leading up to Christmas, Reykjanesbraut ‚Äì the road leading to Keflav√≠k Airport ‚Äì became impassable. The closure led to numerous flight delays and cancellations, with many travellers expressing their criticism of the Icelandic authorities. Speaking to Mbl.is in December, Minister of Infrastructure Sigur√∞ur Ingi J√≥hannson stated that the situation was unacceptable: ‚ÄúI have to say, right now, we have to get over this and ensure, as far as that‚Äôs possible, that Reykjanesbraut is not closed while the airport is open.‚Äù Sigur√∞ur Ingi subsequently appointed a work group composed of representatives from the Icelandic Road and Coastal Administration, the National Police Commissioner, and the Su√∞urnes police chief. The work group was tasked with reviewing the events in December and drafting a plan on how best to deal with similar situations. ‚ÄúWe are working hard on the report in collaboration with these groups,‚Äù Hj√∂rd√≠s Gu√∞mundsd√≥ttir, Director of Communications for the Department of Civil Protection and Emergency Management, told Mbl.is this morning. The work group is expected to submit its report on Tuesday, January 10. ‚ÄúWe scrutinise everything we do, so it‚Äôs natural for us to scrutinise this,‚Äù she added.

headline: Taxi Drivers Demand Hearing with the Government
body: Dozens of taxi drivers stopped work yesterday in protest of the newly approved taxi bill submitted by the Minister of Infrastructure. The drivers have serious concerns about the changes included in the bill and are demanding a hearing with the government, V√≠sir reports. As reported last Friday, taxi drivers staged a protest outside the Minister‚Äôs Residence in Reykjav√≠k; expressing their strong objecting to a new bill on taxi services, drivers drove down the street and honked their horns in front of the residence. The bill, which was approved by Parliament later in the day, loosens requirements for operating a taxi and removes of restrictions on the number of work permits, among other things. Taxi drivers‚Äô interest groups strongly opposed the bill, citing concerns that the changes may incite violence against drivers and result in a decline in service quality for the public, and dozens of drivers went on strike yesterday, V√≠sir reports. In the capital area, there have been unusually long wait times for taxis in recent days. Approximately 150 cars from the company Hreyfill were on the streets of the city at 3 PM yesterday, while there are typically around 200. However, the company claimed that the reduced number of available vehicles was due to weather conditions, rather than the strike by drivers, the article by V√≠sir explained. ‚ÄúA hundred of our members went on strike today in protest of the recently approved bill,‚Äù Dan√≠el Einarsson, Chairperson of the Federation of Icelandic Taxi Drivers, told V√≠sir yesterday. The association counts approximately 400 members. When asked what they were trying to achieve with these protests, given that the bill had been approved on Friday, Dan√≠el responded thusly: ‚ÄúWe tried to get the government to speak with us and consider our concerns, but the bill was rushed through parliament without giving us a chance to voice our opposition,‚Äù Dan√≠el stated. He was speaking from inside Hreyfill‚Äôs offices, where several taxi drivers had gathered to show their solidarity and express their frustration with how they have been treated by the government. While the protest took place, coffee and donuts were offered to those in attendance. Gunnlaugur Ingvarsson, a taxi driver, added, ‚Äúit‚Äôs not every day that taxi drivers take action like this, but we feel overwhelmed by how we have been treated and how the government has ignored our concerns. We are here to make our voices heard.‚Äù

headline: Taxi Drivers Stage Protest in Reykjav√≠k
body: A heated meeting took place among taxi drivers in Reykjav√≠k and Su√∞urnes yesterday evening to discuss a bill on taxi services sponsored by the Ministry of Infrastructure, R√öV reports. This morning, taxi drivers staged a protest outside the Minister‚Äôs Residence in Reykjav√≠k. Outside the Minister‚Äôs Residence in Reykjav√≠k this morning, numerous taxi drivers staged a protest, which was eventually stopped by the police; expressing their strong objecting to a new bill on taxi services, taxi drivers drove down the street and honked their horns in front of the residence. Drivers were not allowed to enter the government meeting inside the minister‚Äôs residence, however, but Dan√≠el O. Einarsson ‚Äì the Chairman of the Federation of Icelandic Taxi Drivers (Bandalag √≠slenskra leigub√≠lstj√≥ra) ‚Äì took the time to read out a special appeal, Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞ reports. He requested that the processing of the bill be postponed. ‚ÄúThe Federation asks the government to grant working taxi drivers a hearing as regards the bill on taxi services,‚Äù Dan√≠el stated. Approval of the bill would open up the door for ride-share services like Uber, which have gained a foothold abroad. The Ministry of Infrastructure posted the bill to the government‚Äôs consultation portal (Samr√°√∞sg√°tt) in July. As noted on the website, the draft of the proposed law is similar to former bills that have previously failed to pass through Parliament. Among other things, the bill proposes the abolition of designated taxi zones and removal of restrictions on the number of work permits. It also removes the obligation for taxis to operate through designated stations and proposes alterations to requirements for those who intend to work as taxi drivers. In an interview with R√öV, Gu√∞mundur B√∂rkur Thorarensen, Managing Director of BSR Taxi, stated that the association was dissatisfied with the bill: ‚ÄúWe are concerned that a large part of the drivers‚Äô income, 30%, will leave the country in the form of foreign currency; that it will reduce income among drivers; and make the service that we have been offering, over the past few years, much worse,‚Äù Gu√∞mundur remarked. Gu√∞mundur maintained that BSR had repeatedly pointed out that more work permits were needed: ‚ÄúBut the idea that we should just completely open it up and that there would be no filter as far as quality standards are concerned or the number of drivers, that‚Äôs never been on the table.‚Äù

headline: VR and SA Agree on Contract
body: VR Union and SA, the Federation of Icelandic Employers, have settled on a short-term contract that will be valid through next year. The agreement will retroactively cover November of this year, and includes a 6.75% wage increase, in addition to increased holiday bonuses and adjusted wage tables for hourly workers. Some have noted similarities between the recent VR contract and that recently reached between SGS and SA. The signing was a rather chaotic affair with representatives from throughout the country present. Official statements were relatively brief, given the long and tiring process it has been so far. Kristj√°n √û√≥r√∞ur Sn√¶bjarnarson, chairman of the Electrical Industry Association of Iceland, stated to R√öV. ‚ÄúWe were trying to press these negotiations as far as possible. I think this is the best outcome under the circumstances.‚Äù Notably, Ragnar √û√≥r Ing√≥lfsson, chairperson of VR union, gave no interview after the signing. After the signing, representatives from both the trade unions, SA, and state mediators sat down to celebrate over waffles, a tradition in Icelandic labour contracts.

headline: Possible End in Sight for VR, SA Negotiations
body: After a late night of fruitless negotiations between VR and SA, the Federation of Icelandic Employers, an end to bargaining may be in sight. The Assistant State Mediator confirmed that negotiations will resume at 13:00 today, when a final contract will be signed. The details of the final contract are not yet public, but an increased living wage in the face of inflation and rising interest rates has been talked about for some time now. The current negotiations between VR and SA have been ongoing since November 14, but the last 24 hours have been under a media embargo, given the potentially sensitive nature of the details. Efling Trade Union has also had a long and contentious negotiation process. Other unions have also agreed to shorter-term contracts as a compromise in a difficult negotiating climate. A press conference will be held later today a 14:30 in which Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir, Minister of Finance Bjarni Benediktsson, and Minister of Infrastructure Sigur√∞ur Ingi J√≥hannsson will give their statements on the importance of the agreement for the labour market. While the content of the agreement is not yet known, in addition to basic wage increases, sources suspect increased measures in child and housing benefits.

headline: Charges to Be Brought Against Domestic-Terror Plot Suspects
body: The District Prosecutor will push for continued custody over two men suspected of planning a domestic terror attack earlier this year. Formal charges are expected to be brought against the men at the District Court of Reykjav√≠k today. Four Icelandic men were arrested on September 21 suspected of ‚Äúterrorist plots‚Äù against state institutions and civilians. Two of the suspects were immediately released; the other two have remained in custody. Speaking to R√öV today, district attorney Karl Ingi Vilbergsson stated that the District Prosecutor has decided to charge the two suspects for violating Article No. 100 of Iceland‚Äôs General Penal Code. The charges are expected to be introduced when prosecutors motion for extended custody over the two men at the District Court of Reykjav√≠k today. R√öV notes that this is likely the first time that such a charge is brought in Iceland. In an interview with Mbl.is, however, Karl Ingi stated that the District Prosecutor had ‚Äúnever considered‚Äù charging the suspects on the basis of Article No. 100 of Iceland‚Äôs General Penal Code. He was not willing to offer further detail on the content of the charges at this time. As previously noted, the two suspects arrested in September had hoarded numerous weapons ‚Äì including dozens of semi-automatic guns and 3D-printed components ‚Äì alongside a considerable amount of ammunition. The men, both of whom are in their twenties, had also discussed carrying out attacks against various political figures, among them Minister Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r √û√≥r√∞arson and Chairman of Efling, S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir. Article 100 of Iceland‚Äôs Penal Code: [Art. 100 a [Punishment of up to lifelong imprisonment shall be imposed on any person committing one or more of the following acts of terrorism with the intention of causing the public serious fear or unlawfully compelling the Icelandic or foreign authorities, or international institutions, to take action or refrain from taking action with a view to weakening or damaging the constitutional structure or the political, economic or social basis of the state or international institution:]1) Article 20 of the General Penal Code states that for ‚Äúan attempted offence, a more lenient punishment may be imposed than for a completed offence.‚Äù This article will be updated.

headline: Deported Asylum Seekers Have Right to Reevaluation, Appeals Board Rules
body: The Immigration and Asylum Appeals Board has ruled that a group of asylum seekers have a right to a reevaluation of their applications, R√öV reports. As many from the group have already been deported to Greece, however, a lawyer for the appellants has stated that it might prove difficult for his clients to reappear before the Directorate of Immigration. In October, Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs District Court ruled in favour of Palestinian Suleiman Al Masr in his case against the government. The court concluded, among other things, that Al Masr could not be blamed for the delay in the government‚Äôs processing of his application, which resulted in his not being deported to Greece (while social restrictions were in effect and travellers were obligated to submit a negative COVID test). Following the decision, Suleiman‚Äôs lawyer, Helgi √ûorsteinsson Silva, asked the Appeals Board to rule in similar cases. The Appeals Board published the rulings this morning. ‚ÄúThere are over twenty rulings and over ten individuals whose applications have been reopened because the premises were similar to Al Masr‚Äôs case. For many of them, the decision means that it‚Äôs rather likely that they will be granted asylum in Iceland,‚Äù Helgi told R√öV. All in all, Helgi believes that there are approximately 100 asylum seekers who have the same cause for appeal. ‚ÄúBut what‚Äôs interesting is that many of the asylum seekers have already been deported and some of them were arrested and put into custody not so long ago,‚Äù Helgi observed, adding that many of those dwelling in refugee camps in Greece would find it difficult to return to Iceland and appear before the Directorate of Immigration. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not uncommon for individuals,‚Äù Helgi explained, ‚Äúwho‚Äôve been asylum seekers in Greece for some time, and who don‚Äôt have valid visas, for example, to have arrived in Iceland on the basis of Greek travel documents. In some instances, those documents are now expired. It could take a long time to renew those papers,‚Äù Helgi remarked, while also noting that the Greek asylum system was on the verge of collapse, as had been widely reported.

headline: SGS Signs New Contract with SA, Causing Controversy
body: A new short-term contract has been reached between SGS, one of Iceland‚Äôs larger trade unions and SA, the Federation of Icelandic Employers. The agreement was reached on Saturday, December 3, between 17 of SGS‚Äôs member organisations and SA. Notably, Efling, SGS‚Äôs largest member organisation, was not a signatory to the agreement. Rising interest rates have complicated wage negotiations between many of Iceland‚Äôs trade unions and SA, with short-term contracts seen as a compromise to cope with the immediate impact of inflation and interest rates, without locking unions and employers into longer-term contracts that may not be suited to economic conditions in the traditional three-year period. The short-term contract will be valid from November 2022 to the end of January 2024. It includes a flat minimum raise, as well as more holidays and adjustments for inflation. However, the recent SGS contract has come under heavy criticism. Kristj√°n √û√≥r√∞ur Sn√¶bjarnarson, acting chairperson of the Confederation of Iceland Labour after Dr√≠fa Sn√¶dal‚Äôs resignation earlier this year, stated that the agreement was not suitable for craftsmen. He expressed his wish that the trade unions would stand together during the negotiating process, but that the inconclusive Confederation of Labour Congress earlier this year caused many fault lines to form within the Icelandic labour movement. ‚ÄúAs I said after the congress,‚Äù stated Kristj√°n to R√öV, ‚ÄúI believed that we could take positive steps forward to strengthen the union. Just like our congressional elections are supposed to do. But it didn‚Äôt work, so this is what it‚Äôs come to. What we need to do is work on our internal issues and find a way forward.‚Äù¬† In light of difficult labour market conditions, the current round of wage negotiations was seen by many in the labour movement as a time for solidarity in applying pressure against SA, the employer‚Äôs union. The recent agreement between SGS and SA is seen by some as a betrayal of labour solidarity at a time when workers hold more power over their employers than usual. S√≥lveig Anna, chairperson of the Efling union, has also been critical of the contract. She stated to R√öV: ‚ÄúWe, of course, do not agree to take part in some deception where what people have already won is being simply repackaged and sold back to them.‚Äù Efling is notable as having gone into their negotiations with very ambitious demands. Along with S√≥lveig Anna, Vilhj√°lmur Birgisson, chairperson of SGS, and Ragnar √û√≥r Ing√≥lfsson, chairperson of VR, together represent some of the largest labour organisations in Iceland. The SGS contract, however, has driven a divide between these figures. In a post on social media, Vilhj√°lmur stated his side of the case, saying that he was ‚Äúsaddened to see people he considered friends stab him in the back.‚Äù He also accused other members of the labour movement of leaking details of the contract to complicate the agreement, and of treating the recent agreement ‚Äúas if a crime had been committed.‚Äù ¬† ¬†

headline: Reykjav√≠k City Council Approves Extensive Budgetary Measures
body: At a meeting yesterday, Reykjav√≠k City Council approved measures intended to save over ISK 1 billion in operational costs over the coming year, R√öV reports. Among the measures are the expansion of paid-parking zones and decreased subsidies for electric-vehicle charging stations located by apartment buildings. At a City Council meeting yesterday, the majority submitted an amendment to Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs 2023 budget. The amendment comprises a total of 92 items, which are expected to save over ISK 1 billion ($7.1 million / ‚Ç¨6.7 million) over the coming year. As noted in the meeting‚Äôs minutes, City Council deems that the measures reflect ‚Äúsensible financial management,‚Äù noting that the pandemic has impacted municipalities all over the country. ‚ÄúThe reaction is natural and befitting the occasion, serving to protect front-line services and vulnerable groups.‚Äù Among the measures are amendments to meal purchases for preschools; reduced opening hours for youth centres (which will close at 9.45 PM as opposed to 10 PM), museums, and swimming pools (during holidays); expansion of paid parking zones; and decreased subsidies for electric-vehicle charging stations near apartment buildings; among other things. In an interview with R√öV on Wednesday, Einar √ûorsteinsson, Chair of City Council, stated that the residents would ‚Äúfeel these changes.‚Äù These budgetary cuts were not fun but necessary in order to improve Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs finances. During its meeting yesterday, the City Council also reviewed an interim financial statement for the city‚Äôs operations during the first nine months of the year. The statement revealed that the city‚Äôs ‚ÄúA Section‚Äù ‚Äì primarily funded by taxpayer money ‚Äì was operated at an ISK 11.1 billion ($7.1 million / ‚Ç¨6.7 million) deficit. In a press release published yesterday, City Council stated that numerous factors had impacted its finances: ‚ÄúA new variant of COVID-19 at the beginning of the year put temporary pressure on operations, especially on the school and welfare system. The war in Ukraine, in addition to the pandemic, led to a shortage of raw goods and slowed down production time, which has negatively impacted global markets and led to increased inflation among our trading partners. The Central Bank, owing to rising real-estate prices, high inflation, and overheating of the domestic economy, raised key interest rates; all of this has had an impact.‚Äù As noted in a press release on the City‚Äôs interim financial statement, however, the City‚Äôs A and B sections ‚Äì the ‚ÄúB‚Äù section includes businesses in part or whole ownership of the city, such as Reykjav√≠k Energy (OR), Associated Icelandic Ports (Faxafl√≥ahafnir), Sopra bs. and Str√¶t√≥ bs., among others ‚Äì produced a surplus of ISK 6.8 billion ($48 million / ‚Ç¨46 million). This article was updated at 11 AM.

headline: Str√¶t√≥‚Äôs Reykjav√≠k Night-Time Service Could Resume Next Year
body: Mayor Dagur B. Eggertsson has proposed allocating an extra ISK 51 million ($361,000 / ‚Ç¨343,000) of next year‚Äôs budget to the operations of Str√¶t√≥ (Iceland‚Äôs public bus service), R√öV reports. The increased allotment is intended to cover Str√¶t√≥‚Äôs night-time bus service in Reykjav√≠k during the weekends. In early July, Str√¶t√≥ announced that the Reykjav√≠k night bus, N√¶turstr√¶t√≥, would return to service on July 9 following a two-year hiatus in response to low demand during the pandemic. During this hiatus, many capital-area residents had called for its return, arguing that it provided an affordable and safe alternative to taxis. During a trial run between July and October of this year, however ‚Äì when the night bus departed downtown Reykjav√≠k every hour and stopped at the capital area‚Äôs seven suburban neighbourhoods ‚Äì demand once again proved wanting. As noted in a press release from Str√¶t√≥ in October, an average of 15 passengers travelled aboard the night bus during each trip, which amounts to approximately 300 passengers over a weekend: ‚ÄúIn light of this, and given the finances, Str√¶t√≥‚Äôs board has agreed that continuing night-time service during the weekends, now that the trial period has concluded, cannot be justified. The service will, therefore, be discontinued.‚Äù At a city council meeting yesterday, however ‚Äì roughly six weeks after Str√¶t√≥ announced that it would be discontinuing its night-time service ‚Äì Mayor Dagur B. Eggertsson proposed allocating an extra ISK 51 million ($361,000 / ‚Ç¨343,000) of next year‚Äôs budget to cover Str√¶t√≥‚Äôs night-time bus service. As noted by R√öV, Str√¶t√≥‚Äôs night-time bus service was a key campaign issue for the Progressive Party, which went on to form a majority coalition, during municipal elections last spring.

headline: Iceland Opens Embassy in Poland
body: Foreign Minister √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n Reykfj√∂r√∞ Gylfad√≥ttir is in Warsaw today for the opening of Iceland‚Äôs embassy there. In a statement to Morgunbla√∞i√∞, the minster said: ‚Äú‚ÄùThe deep respect and friendship that exist between Iceland and Poland is of great value to Iceland, and it is with pride that I take part in opening our embassy in Warsaw on the day of Icelandic Sovereignty.‚Äù In her statement, she also pointed out that Poland has had an embassy in Iceland since 2013, and that some 20,000 Polish citizens reside in Iceland, accounting for 40% of all immigrants in Iceland. The minister also stated: ‚ÄúToday the Icelandic embassy in Warsaw will be opened, on the day Icelanders celebrate their sovereignty in 1918. Around the same time, at the end of 1918, an independent and sovereign Poland was rising from the ruins of the First World War. Iceland recognized the Republic of Poland in January 1922 ‚Äì exactly a century ago ‚Äì and diplomatic relations officially began in 1946. Since the end of the Second World War, the relations between the countries have been strong and growing in many areas.¬†The most important thing in my mind is that a large number of people from Poland and of Polish origin have enriched Icelandic society by settling here for a longer or shorter period of time. [‚Ä¶] Poland has had an embassy in Iceland since 2013, and our relations on many joint platforms are exemplary.¬†However, it is not just to maintain reciprocal relations I made the decision to open an embassy in Warsaw, but I recognize the fact that Poland is one of the leading countries in Europe in cultural, political, scientific and economic terms.‚Äù ¬†

headline: Zelenskyy Gifted Icelandic Lopapeysa from Foreign Minister
body: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy was gifted an Icelandic sweater (i.e. lopapeysa) by Iceland‚Äôs Minister for Foreign Affairs on Sunday. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm proud and honoured,‚Äù the designer of the sweater told Iceland Review this morning. Writing on Facebook yesterday, Icelandic singer Salka S√≥l described an unusual phone call that she received from the Assistant to the Minister for Foreign Affairs recently: ‚ÄúI was asked to knit, for the President of Ukraine, an Icelandic lopapeysa, which the President would receive as a gift from the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I couldn‚Äôt say no to such a request. I called my collaborator Sj√∂fn Kristj√°nsd√≥ttir, and together we knitted two lopapeysur over the space of five days with good help from Eygl√≥ (G√≠slad√≥ttir). Zelenskyy received the sweaters on Sunday ‚Ä¶ we hope that he‚Äôll be spotted wearing them soon; most of all, however, we hope that the war will end.‚Äù In an interview with Iceland Review this morning, designer Sj√∂fn Kristj√°nsd√≥ttir echoed Salka‚Äôs sentiments: it was the most unusual request that she had received. ‚ÄúWe were very surprised, but at the same time, incredibly proud and honoured to be handed this assignment. Zelenskyy is an incredible person, whom we have watched ‚Äì like the rest of the world ‚Äì from the sidelines. To be able to contribute, on behalf of the Icelandic nation, is amazing; it‚Äôs something that I‚Äôll never forget.‚Äù As noted by Sj√∂fn, the Icelandic lopapeysa is a legally protected product, having received a Designation of Origin status from the Icelandic Food and Veterinary Authority in 2020; sweaters with the traditional decorative pattern can only be labelled as ‚ÄúIcelandic sweaters‚Äù if they are knitted by hand in Iceland using Icelandic wool. ‚ÄúThis sweater meets all the criteria,‚Äù Sj√∂fn observed, adding that producing two sweaters in the space of just five days was a lot of work. ‚ÄúOf course, when two hyperactive women come together ‚Äì they decide to make two sweaters. We knitted incessantly. I had a sick child at home; I made good use of sleepless nights.‚Äù As noted in an article on Mbl.is, Foreign Minister √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n, alongside other foreign ministers from the Nordic and Baltic countries, met with Volodymyr Zelenskyy and other Ukrainian ministers on Sunday. The ministers discussed the situation in Ukraine, with representatives from the latter country calling for continued support. The ministers from the Nordic and Baltic countries also acquainted themselves firsthand with the damages wrought by the Russian military and laid a wreath of flowers in honour of the victims of The Holodomor (the Great Famine), which cost millions of Ukrainians their lives between 1932-1933. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important to witness the conditions of the Ukrainian capital with one‚Äôs own eyes,‚Äù √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n was quoted as saying in a press release on the government‚Äôs website, ‚Äúeven if our visit was brief. One is, first and foremost, faced with the terrible consequences of Russia‚Äôs incessant attacks on the country‚Äôs infrastructure. Keeping the electricity on, during the intense and tangible winter cold, is a constant battle: everything is covered in snow and the frost is biting.‚Äù

headline: Over 60 Prison Sentences Expired Due to Lack of Cell Space
body: Roughly sixty prison sentences have expired over the past three years owing to shortage of prison cells, R√öV reports. At a session before Parliament yesterday, members of the opposition expressed concern over the state of the country‚Äôs prison system. Yesterday, Helga Vala Helgad√≥ttir, MP for the Social Democratic Alliance, opened the discussion on prison affairs before Parliament. Roughly 300 people, of which 279 men, are on prison wait lists. According to Helga Vala, the state of affairs is unacceptable, both for victims and perpetrators: ‚ÄúThe aim of legislation on the enforcement of sentences is that sentences be served safely and efficiently in order to deter, whether by particular or general means, criminal offences; however, such a thing can hardly be effective when prisoners cannot begin serving their sentences and when victims must watch perpetrators walk the streets as if they had done nothing wrong. Furthermore, convicted individuals cannot begin to rebuild their lives or must simply trust that their prison sentences expire so that they don‚Äôt need to serve time. These are terrible messages to send to society,‚Äù Helga Vala stated. Sigmundur Dav√≠√∞ Gunnlaugsson, Chair of the Centre Party, echoed Helga‚Äôs sentiments: ‚ÄúAlthough we sometimes use the phrase human-rights violation rather freely, I would categorise it in these terms: that someone has been sentenced ‚Äì with all the subsequent consequences on the individual ‚Äì but must wait in uncertainty as to when that sentence begins,‚Äù Sigmundur remarked. As noted by R√öV, since the start of 2020, 64 prison sentences have expired owing to a shortage of cell space. The COVID pandemic played a significant role but also a lack of government funding. The prison system will receive an increase of ISK 250 million ($1.8 million / ‚Ç¨1.7 million) according to a bill to amend next year‚Äôs budget as proposed by the Minister of Finance. Just Minister J√≥n Gunnar states that this will completely alter the state of affairs: ‚ÄúOne must also consider what the prison authorities are dealing with, namely longer sentences, a greater number of sentences, and a significant increase in the number of individuals being kept in police custody, which wasn‚Äôt entirely expected, and which has served to complicate matters. A working group was appointed to review operations and to offer proposals on how to shorten waiting lists. They‚Äôre working on it, and once that work is finished, we‚Äôll have a foundation from which to increase the budget and the number of prison guards, and also to operate our prisons more efficiently. This will, of course, be of great help,‚Äù J√≥n stated.

headline: Hope that Efling Contract Will be Accepted
body: S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir, chairperson of Efling trade union, has expressed her optimism that wage negotiations with SA, the Federation of Icelandic Employers, may be reaching an acceptable conclusion. The most recent round of contract negotiations has been complicated by changes in AS√ç (The Confederation of Icelandic Labour) leadership and rising interest rates in the face of high inflation. Normally negotiated for longer terms, a shorter-term contract has been suggested as a stopgap to help what has been a difficult negotiation process. Efling has now agreed to make an offer to SA that will include an ISK 56,700 annual raise (USD EUR), in addition to other cost-of-living allowances. The contract as offered will be valid until January 31, 2024. Cost of living has been a pressing issue in the recent renegotiations, and Efling‚Äôs current offer represents a much more humble demand than some of their previous suggestions. However, a statement by the union highlights that the current offer represents what would have been the gains in the first year of a normal three-year contract: ‚ÄúIn the opinion of the negotiating committee of Efling, the agreed increases need to protect the households of low- and middle-income earners from the effects of inflation and guarantee them a fair share in economic growth and the profits of the company. [‚Ä¶] The bargaining committee of Efling believes that other unions have made a mistake by agreeing to percentage increases in negotiations with SA. There have been proposals for discussion where high-income groups are expected to benefit twice as much as low-wage earners.‚Äù Here, Efling refers to a debate within trade unions on whether to go to the bargaining table with demands for flat wage increases, or percentage-based wage increases. Percentage-based wage increases favour higher earners, and such demands have been a cornerstone of BHM‚Äôs demands (The Icelandic Confederation of University Graduates). However, for lower wage earners, flat increases to wage generally tend to increase buying power more directly. Efling submitted their offer to SA yesterday. Previously, they had submitted similar terms, but SA rejected them on grounds of the length of the contract. Now, Efling is hoping that the new, shorter contract will be accepted. In a statement, S√≥lveig Anna said: ‚ÄúWe will see how this shapes up. I‚Äôm not ready to say that we‚Äôve reached the finish line. I know it‚Äôs a complicated game we‚Äôre playing [‚Ä¶] I think it‚Äôs likely that we need to do something more, but the message to us was clear and meaningful.‚Äù ¬†

headline: VR Leaves Negotiating Table, Finance Minister Denies Blame
body: The Prime Minister has expressed disappointment in VR‚Äôs decision to break off wage negotiations with SA Thursday evening. The Minister of Finance does not believe his comments on the Central Bank‚Äôs interest-rate hike were ‚Äúthe deciding factor,‚Äù R√öV reports. This morning, Ragnar √û√≥r Ing√≥lfsson, Chair of VR (the Store and Office Workers‚Äô Union) confirmed to R√öV that he had walked out of negotiations with SA (the Confederation of Icelandic Enterprise) last night, which had recently been referred to the state mediator. The reasons, Ragnar stated, were ‚Äúnumerous,‚Äù although the incongruous messaging of Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir and Finance Minister Bjarni Benediktson concerning the Central Bank‚Äôs interest-rate hikes ‚Äúplayed a role.‚Äù Prior to the Central Bank announcing that it would be raising interest rates, VR and SA had been aiming toward an agreement predicated on less inflation and a lower interest rate: ‚ÄúBut then the Central Bank announced a hike, which, in reality, altered the premises from which we had hoped to proceed,‚Äù Ragnar √û√≥r told R√öV. ‚ÄúThe PM subsequently invited us to a meeting yesterday morning, in which she attempted to reset the parties‚Äô expectations. It was a pretty good meeting.‚Äù Ragnar observed that the parties proceeded to Karph√∫si√∞ (the facilities of the state negotiator) where they hoped to continue their negotiations at noon. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve hardly taken our seats when an announcement is made by the Minister of Finance in which he echoes the Governor‚Äôs (the Central Bank) message, which is completely at odds with what the PM had told us. After that, the negotiations became quite difficult. And when it became clear the kind of ideas that SA were entertaining regarding a 14-month contract, which we had been discussing, it was obvious that there was no ground to continue negotiating.‚Äù Following a cabinet meeting this morning, Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir discussed Thursday‚Äôs wage-negotiation collapse with R√öV. Asked if she had wished that the Central Bank had not raised interest rates, Katr√≠n responded thusly: ‚ÄúThe Central Bank makes its own decisions in accordance with the statutory aims under which it operates. It‚Äôs not my place to comment on those decisions, but it is clear that this decision led to the collapse of negotiations.‚Äù ‚ÄúI regret the fact that VR decided that it was appropriate to leave the negotiating table at this time, but I hope that we can find some kind of opening,‚Äù Katr√≠n added. This morning, Bjarni Benediktsson was asked to respond to Ragnar √û√≥r‚Äôs claim that his comments, justifying the Central Bank‚Äôs actions, had been a deciding factor in the collapse of negotiations. ‚ÄúNo, I think it‚Äôs always best to be completely honest about things,‚Äù Bjarni remarked. ‚ÄúAnd I just saw an announcement from VR where no mention is made of my comments; it‚Äôs likely that the premises had changed following the Central Bank‚Äôs decisions, premises which likely were the basis for the parties‚Äô negotiations.‚Äù Bjarni told R√öV that it was clear that inflation would rise and that it was only natural for the Central Bank to employ those tools at its disposal to keep inflation in check: ‚ÄúBut the truth is that the inflation forecasts have worsened, and the ghost of inflation is set to follow us a bit longer, and inflation will be higher next year than we had hoped just a few months ago. The tension in the economy runs high. We‚Äôre nearing maximum production capacity and the level of employment is very high. Consumption is high, which is one of the factors to which the Central Bank has pointed. It doesn‚Äôt really surprise me that the Central Bank continues to send these clear messages, that it will continue to fight inflation, and it‚Äôs desirable that all of us cooperate to do the same.‚Äù VR is Iceland‚Äôs largest trade union, representing some 40,000 workers. ¬†

headline: Prison Guards to Receive Stab-Resistant Vests, Possibly Tasers
body: The Minister of Justice will answer the call from prison guards regarding increased training and protective equipment, Mbl.is reports. The Director General of Prison and Probation Administration notes a worrying trend of violence and weapons use within Icelandic prisons. As noted in an article published on Mbl.is yesterday morning, violence and weapons use among Icelandic prisoners have greatly increased over the past years. In light of this trend, prison guards have called for better protective equipment, stab-resistant vests, and, in some instances, access to tasers. P√°ll Winkel, Director General of Prison and Probation Administration, told Mbl.is that the prison system was facing a ‚Äúnew reality,‚Äù with weapons now being confiscated from cells and common areas on a regular basis. ‚ÄúThis was almost unheard of, a couple of years ago. It‚Äôs my responsibility, first and foremost, to ensure the safety of my employees. We‚Äôre not enthusiastic about carrying weapons within our prisons, but we obviously need to reassess our protocols. And we may need to reconsider how we interact with certain groups of inmates, i.e. those who create and carry makeshift weapons,‚Äù P√°ll stated, adding that these weapons were improvised from shards of plexiglass, saw-blades, screwdrivers, screws, and nails. Speaking to V√≠sir.is yesterday, prison guard Sigur√∞ur R√∫nar Hafli√∞ason stated that he‚Äôd experienced these trends first-hand: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got this much tougher, more violent core of prisoners, who are also abusing drugs to a greater extent. And so there‚Äôs a big difference in how we‚Äôre managing prisoners today, compared to when I was starting.‚Äù As noted by the article, three serious assaults have been perpetrated against prison guards this year. According to Sigur√∞ur, the younger generation of prisoners commonly carries knives and post-traumatic stress has increased among prison guards.
