Sigur√∞ur R√∫nar doesn‚Äôt necessarily believe that tasers are necessary, arguing that stab-resistant vests and improved training is vital. ‚ÄúWe need to improve safety ‚Ä¶ we need training so that people feel safe while they‚Äôre at work.‚Äù Mass arrests and budgetary constraints have also put pressure on an already strained system. In an article published in Morgunbla√∞i√∞ this morning, Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson stated that the safety of prison guards and police officers was ‚Äúa priority.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs happening inside prison walls reflects broader trends within our society,‚Äù J√≥n remarked. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve had extensive conversations with the prison authorities, and it‚Äôs clear that we must respond on many different levels.‚Äù According to J√≥n, this response will, among other things, include stab-resistant vests. The Ministry is also considering equipping prison guards with tasers. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve repeatedly witnessed serious incidents within the country‚Äôs prisons. It‚Äôs clear that it‚Äôs necessary to equip our people in such a way that their safety is ensured at their places of employment. And we do that by providing better protective equipment. Additionally, we need to consider structural organisation; we can‚Äôt allow things to develop in such a manner within our prisons.‚Äù Physical altercations involving knives have been in the news lately, with a knife attack at the Bankastr√¶ti Club nightclub last weekend and a fifteen-year old boy being stabbed in the Garfarvogur neighbourhood of Reykjav√≠k earlier this week.

headline: Number of Apartments Sold in Capital Area Hits Two-Year Low
body: 331 apartments were sold in the capital area in October, a 22% decline compared to the previous month. The number of apartments sold in the capital area has hit a two-year low, Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞ reports. This week, the Central Bank announced that it was raising key interest rates by an additional 0.25%. Short-term interest rates (seven-day term deposits) would thereby reach 6%. The increase, which serve to complicate wage negotiations, came in response to a month-on-month rise in inflation, which rose from 9.3% in September to 9.4% in October. In an interview with Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞, √ùmir √ñrn Finnbogason, an analyst at Deloitte, explained that rising interest rates had led to a cooling real-estate market; an update to Deloitte‚Äôs real-estate dashboard, based on statistics from Registers Iceland, showed a 22% decline in the sale of apartments in the capital area in October when compared to September. As noted by Deloitte‚Äôs report, even though sales have declined, prices have remained almost unchanged between the months: the average price of a square metre for an apartment was ISK 709,000 ($5,000 / ‚Ç¨4,800) October, ISK 2,000 ($14 / in ‚Ç¨14) higher than in September. ‚ÄúRising interest rates and economic uncertainty have an obvious effect,‚Äù √ùmir √ñrn told Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞. √ùmir expects the real-estate market to continue cooling over the coming months, in light of growing tensions in the economy and wage negotiations. As noted by Deloitte, single-family homes and apartments have followed the same trend, with fewer properties being sold in both categories: the number of single-family homes sold in October compared to September declined by 16%. The average price of a square metre also declined from ISK 647,000 ($4,600 / ‚Ç¨4,400) to ISK 624,000 ($4,400 / ‚Ç¨4,300). ‚ÄúReal-estate prices reflect consumers‚Äô investment power, which is primarily affected by the cost of borrowing money, i.e. interest rates. And rising interest rates obviously lead to a cooling market,‚Äù √ùmir √ñrn stated. As noted by Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞, the price of apartments and multi-family homes have risen in North and East Iceland but fallen in South and West Iceland.

headline: Rising Interest Rates Complicate Upcoming Wage Negotiations
body: The recent hike in interest rates has complicated the upcoming wage negotiations, with government involvement now a possibility to bring the negotiations to a conclusion. Now, Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir has invited leaders from both sides of the bargaining table to a meeting to find a path forward. This fall, around 1/3 of labour contracts are expiring and need to be renegotiated. Matters have been further complicated by turmoil at the 45th AS√ç congress (The Icelandic Federation of Labour, Iceland‚Äôs largest federation of trade unions), which have left the leadership of this organisation unclear. Individual unions have begun renegotiating their contracts, mostly with SA (The Confederation of Icelandic Employers). Recent increases to the interest rate in Iceland have complicated negotiations, with talks with VR and several other unions and SA breaking down yesterday. The rate increases came in the wake of inflation numbers for October being higher than expected. The 0.25% increase to 6% interest (seven-day term deposit rate) is intended to bring inflation back into an acceptable range. √Åsgeir J√≥nsson, Governor of the Central Bank of Iceland, has previously called on the labour market to help in the fight against inflation, as wage demands at the bargaining table could have an exacerbating effect on inflation. Alongside the rate increases, the Central Bank of Iceland‚Äôs Monetary Policy Committee released a statement that inflation forecasts could turn out to be too optimistic if the ongoing wage negotiations lead to wages rising in excess of the Central Bank‚Äôs predictions. Consumer spending in September and October has proved higher than expected, and some fear that wage demands may drive up consumer spending and therefore prices. V√≠sir quotes √Åsgeir as stating ‚ÄúOur task is to ensure price stability and we believe by doing this, we are supporting the wage negotiations. It would be futile to negotiate such wage increases only to have them burn up in inflation. The Central Bank is therefore of the opinion that it is contributing to the process by ensuring this does not happen.‚Äù Finance Minister Bjarni Benediktsson stated regarding the rate hikes that although the increase had been a ‚Äúsplash of cold water‚Äù for many, it nevertheless sent ‚Äúa necessary message to leaders in the labour market.‚Äù The Central Bank of Iceland‚Äôs Monetary Policy Committee has a set inflation target of 2.5%. Inflation currently sits at 9.4%. The rate hike has, however, drawn critique from both sides of the bargaining table. Ragnar √û√≥r Ing√≥lfsson, the chairperson of VR trade union, said that because of this, the negotiations between VR and SA will be terminated and, as a result, harsh measures will have to be taken. Halld√≥r Benjam√≠n √ûorbergsson, director of SA, also said he disagreed with the Central Bank‚Äôs interest rate decision. The decision, according to Halld√≥r, put the wage negotiations in ‚Äúupheaval‚Äù and the bank‚Äôs credibility has been ‚Äúdamaged‚Äù by this interest rate increase. Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir has stated that the government supports a quick conclusion to the negotiations, suggesting the possibility of shorter-term contracts as a solution: ‚ÄúI think that all parties understand that events have not been particularly favourable for us. First an epidemic, then a war, inflation and the consequences of Russia‚Äôs war in Ukraine. So, of course, we all realize that there is considerable uncertainty, which may make a short-term contract a more viable option.¬†But it is of course entirely in the hands of those sitting at the negotiating table to make that decision.‚Äù Katr√≠n continued, saying that it would be bad for all parties involved if negotiations were to break down: ‚ÄúOf course that would be bad.¬†It is in the interest of all in our society that there is peace in the labour market. That workers can live on their wages.¬†That business can continue.¬†It‚Äôs in all of our interests.‚Äù ¬†

headline: Finnish PM Sanna Marin on Official Visit to Iceland
body: Finnish PM Sanna Marin is on an official state visit to Iceland. On the agenda for her meetings with Icelandic PM Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir are the energy transition, climate change, Nordic cooperation, and the War in Ukraine. Finland, in the wake of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, has applied for membership in NATO, to which Iceland has belonged since its 1949 foundation. Previously neutral, the invasion has forced Finland to reassess its security situation, which will now be the topic of talks between the two PMs. Among the several events and roundtables the Finnish PM has attended include a talk at the Nordic House and a ‚Äúlunch-time chat‚Äù at the National Museum of Iceland. Though Finland has remained officially neutral for decades, it has in the past cooperated with NATO exercises and projects. This past May, it officially announced its intention to apply for NATO membership, alongside fellow Nordic nation Sweden, which had also been neutral. PM Sanna Marin also spoke about the importance of women in positions of power, calling it a great need. Even in Europe, few women are in leadership positions, but she identified the Nordic nations as leading forces in this regard. Icelandic PM Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir likewise spoke to the importance of having people with diverse backgrounds in leadership positions, and for people with different experiences to be heard and recognised. Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir also highlighted the common commitment shared by the Nordic nations to social-democratic ideals: ‚ÄúWe have open debates and we have strong national assemblies in our communities.¬†This is not least important because we are seeing certain democratic setbacks. Not only in distant countries, but in Europe as well.¬†These values of the Nordic countries are more important than ever.‚Äù Agreeing that the Nordics share much in terms of history and culture, the Finnish PM stated that Iceland and Finland stand to learn much from one another. Joking, she also stated: ‚ÄúOf course, even though Iceland isn‚Äôt a part of the EU, it‚Äôs always welcome.‚Äù Building on the strong history of cooperation, Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir cited research, development, and education as fields to be further improved between the nations. Notably, Iceland was one of he first nations to openly support Finland and Sweden‚Äôs NATO applications, which are still pending approval.

headline: Minister of Justice‚Äôs Police Bill Approved by Cabinet
body: A new bill on policing, sponsored by the Minister of Justice, was approved by the coalition government this morning, V√≠sir reports. The Minister expects the bill ‚Äì which will, among other things, authorise proactive investigations ‚Äì to be enacted shortly after the new year. A day after Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson announced his intention to ‚Äúwage war on organised crime in Iceland,‚Äù his proposed amendment to the Police Act has been approved by the cabinet. The bill, which was been in the works by the Ministry of Justice for some time, was submitted for public review and commentary in March of this year. Speaking to V√≠sir, Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson stated that he expected the bill to be distributed among the parliamentary parties tomorrow. The purpose of the bill is to grant greater authority to the police in its effort to deter crime, especially in relation to organised crime and national security. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre trying to move closer to those police protocols that have been adopted by our neighbouring countries,‚Äù J√≥n stated. The bill will authorise proactive investigations and enshrine in law regulations concerning the use of weapons among police. ‚ÄúWe refer to it as crime deterrence, allowing the police to begin investigating individuals who although not suspected of committing a crime are believed to be associated with organised crime, or other operations that pose a risk to national safety. Such investigations would, however, always be launched by the Chief of Police or other senior officers. We will also establish an office of internal affairs, which will always be notified in the event of such investigations. A supervisory committee will also be notified as early as possible.‚Äù J√≥n hopes that the bill will be enacted quickly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm hoping that the bill passes through parliamentary review tomorrow and that I‚Äôll be able to address Parliament next week. Then it‚Äôs, of course, up to the parliamentary committee to discuss. I know that the general committee has been quite busy recently, so we‚Äôll have to see how quickly things progress. I think it‚Äôs realistic to hope that the bill would be enacted shortly after the new year, that is, if it‚Äôs not been enacted before Christmas.‚Äù

headline: Mass Arrests Put Pressure on Already-Strained Prison System
body: Iceland‚Äôs prison system is operating at near maximum capacity. Three times as many individuals are being kept in police custody than usual, the Director General of Prison and Probation Administration has stated. The police arrested 27 people following a knife attack at the Bankastr√¶ti Club in Reykjav√≠k last Thursday. Twelve suspects have been kept in custody, with the police having yet to decide whether they will request custody over five additional suspects. Four other individuals connected to the attack remain on the lam, some of whom are believed to have fled the country. P√°ll Winkel, the Director General of Prison and Probation Administration, told Mbl.is that a total of 60 people are currently being held in police custody ‚Äì three times the usual number. Aside from the many arrests made in relation to the Bankastr√¶ti Club attack, there have also been numerous arrests made in connection with drug busts and violent crimes. ‚ÄúIt does, of course, put tremendous pressure on the system,‚Äù P√°ll observed, ‚Äúdetaining 15 prisoners in isolation. It calls for greater manpower and organisation; you need to safeguard investigative interests, that the prisoners don‚Äôt meet, while, at the same time, ensuring that their rights are being respected.‚Äù ‚ÄúThese are people aged 19 and up. These are Icelanders and foreigners, men and women, non-disabled and disabled persons, including one individual who‚Äôs blind.‚Äù Most of the prisoners are being detained in the H√≥lmshei√∞i prison, although some have been transferred to Litla-Hraun. According to P√°ll, the design of H√≥lmshei√∞i has proven advantageous, as there are spaces equally suited to regular confinement and isolation. P√°ll predicts that the situation will remain unchanged for a few more days but hopes that that will be the extent of it. ‚ÄúIt puts tremendous strain on the system. Also because it happens to coincide with our effort to temporarily decrease the number of prisoners so as to operate within budget constraints.‚Äù Speaking to R√öV, Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson stated that the government had already taken steps to deal with the pressure on the prison system, with extensive renovations at the Litla-Hraun prison expected to be completed next year. According to J√≥n Gunnarsson, there have been instances where prison sentences lapse owing to a lack of cells. ‚ÄúWe must respond, and we are doing our best,‚Äù he stated, admitting that increasing the number of prison cells would take time and that bridging the gap could prove tricky. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not quite sure how; this additional pressure means additional operational costs, and we‚Äôve even been in the position where we‚Äôve been unable to fully use all of the prison cells because of budgetary constraints ‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre working on it.‚Äù

headline: Minister of Justice to Declare War on Organised Crime
body: Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson has announced his intention to wage war against organised crime following the knife attacks in a Reykjav√≠k club last week, which have been taken as signs of gang warfare. On Thursday night, November 17, a group of masked and armed men stormed a Reykjav√≠k nightclub, stabbing three men, who were since transported to the ER. Of the nearly 30 men involved in the attack, already some 14 have been apprehended by the police. Two are suspected to have fled the country, with the police now searching for the remaining suspects. According to Minister J√≥n Gunnarsson, the incident reveals a problem with organised crime in a nation generally upheld for its security. In response to the minister‚Äôs call for a ‚Äúwar on crime,‚Äù efforts are now being prepared to attack the root causes of organised criminality in Iceland. The Minister has also expressed his desire to strengthen police powers, with what J√≥n Gunnarsson calls ‚Äúpreventative warrants,‚Äù allowing for ‚Äúproactive investigation.‚Äù Such measures have been controversial in Al√æingi, but J√≥n Gunnarsson has stated that his proposals would be ‚Äúharmless.‚Äù Such warrants would allow police to monitor individuals associated with known criminals and criminal activity, without themselves being found guilty of any crime. The proposed measures would also add tasers to the police arsenal. Currently, Icelandic police officers only carry batons and pepper spray in the field. In a statement to V√≠sir, the Minister said: ‚ÄúThe steps we take may prove to be controversial, I have no doubt about that. Both of these new authorisations, for preventative warrants and weapons for the police, may be controversial, but we have to do it.‚Äù ¬†

headline: Report on √çslandsbanki Sale Highlights Lack of Transparency, Reliance on Outside Consultants
body: State regulators have released a report on the controversial sale of √çslandsbanki shares that took place this March. Among the considerations of the report are details on the dissemination of information of the sale, the determination of its sale price, and the selection process for determining the qualified investors. After the 2008 banking collapse, the insolvent banks were restructured, leading to the partial socialisation of Iceland‚Äôs three major banks, Landsbankinn, Arion, and √çslandsbanki. Landsbankinn continues to be held by the state with a majority share. However, √çslandsbanki has been gradually privatized since the restructuring, with an initial 35% of √çslandsbanki shares being sold in June 2021. After a sharp rise in share prices after the sale, some claimed that the shares were undervalued. In March 2022, a second round of sales was slated, with 22.5% of √çslandsbanki shares to be sold off. This second offering, however, was not a public offering like the first, but was limited to a group of ‚Äúqualified investors.‚Äù Among the qualified investors were the usual suspects, including foreign and domestic investors, and pension funds. However, the list also included some notable individuals such as Benedikt Sveinsson, father of Bjarni Benediktsson, Minister of Finance and the individual legally responsible for the sale. The revelations caused widespread critique of Bjarni, the oversight committee, and the coalition government in power. There were also claims of insider trading, as significant numbers of investors sold off their holdings within days and weeks after a climb in price. In total, the sale involved 450 million shares in the bank to 207 investors. The selling price was ISK 117 per share and the sale proceeds amounted to ISK 52.7 billion (USD 361,000,000; EUR 351,000,000).¬†The state‚Äôs share in √çslandsbanki is now 42.5%. Now, the Icelandic National Audit Office is trying to determine the nature of the sale, how the investors were selected, and how the √çslandsbanki share were valued. The official report can be seen here. According to the report, the sale could have been better prepared and executed. Outside the scope of the report are the legitimacy and legality of the sale, which are left to the Financial Supervision Authority of the Central Bank of Iceland. Instead, the report focuses on the technical execution of the sale and its valuation of the shares. According to the report, ‚Äúthe language used in the documents submitted by the Icelandic State Financial Investments (ISFI) to parliament was not suitable for drawing a clear picture of the arrangement of the sale process. Despite the experience and knowledge of the employees and the board of the Banking Authority in the field of administration and sale of the state‚Äôs holdings in financial companies, the institution did not have experience in bidding arrangements in the run-up to the sale [‚Ä¶] Adequate conditions were not given to supervisors, sales consultants and dealers, and due to shortcomings in the implementation, demand was underestimated when deciding on the indicative final price. Sufficient consideration was not given to possible reputational risks, nor were the principles of transparency observed. As the bidding system was implemented, it could not guarantee full equality for the investors to whom it was directed.‚Äù The report also identifies an over-reliance on external consultants in the private sector. ¬† ¬† ¬†

headline: Protests in Front of Parliament in Wake of Deportations
body: Protestors last week flocked to Austurv√∂llur square in front of Iceland‚Äôs parliament in response to the recent deportation of Icelandic refugees. The protests took place Thursday, November 3, and Sunday, November 6 with some thousand people in attendance. The recent wave of deportations is the largest in recent history in Iceland, with some refugees being deported as their applications for asylum status were still under consideration by the Directorate of Immigration. Isavia, the company responsible for running Keflav√≠k International Airport, has also come under critique for its involvement in the deportations. The Journalists‚Äô Association of Iceland has accused Isavia of obstructing the work of journalists covering the deportations, turning floodlights against a crowd of reporters. Isavia has published a statement regretting their involvement, saying that they were following police instructions, who requested that Isavia staff prevent filming of the deportations. F√≥lk streymir √° Austurv√∂ll til a√∞ √æess a√∞ m√≥tm√¶la √≥mann√∫√∞legri brottvisun h√¶lisleitenda pic.twitter.com/hmwgcEeMLC The above video from Pirate Party MP G√≠sli √ìlafsson shows a glimpse of the crowd present at the Thursday protests.¬†¬† Icelandic police forces have also faced criticism for their treatment of the deported individuals, with one video showing a refugee man being forcefully removed from his wheelchair. According to Icelandic police, they are now considering having vehicles more suitable for wheelchairs. Further critique has been raised by the confiscation of refugees‚Äô phones. Icelandic police state that the refugees‚Äô phones were taken from them in order to ensure their safety. Helgi Valberg Jensson, Chief Legal Office of the National Police, stated to V√≠sir: ‚ÄúWe had individuals in custody, and it was our duty to ensure their safety.¬† Whether this needs to be revised is something we will consider moving forward.‚Äù Police body cameras were also reported to have been turned off during portions of the raids. Helgi has stated that this for the privacy of individuals who may feel uncomfortable. Among the critics of the recent deportations are the United Nations Children‚Äôs Fund in Iceland, the Icelandic branch of Amnesty International, the Disabled Persons‚Äô Association, the Red Cross in Iceland and the Icelandic Teachers‚Äô Association.

headline: Council of Europe to be Held in Reykjav√≠k
body: The Council of Europe is to be held in Reykjav√≠k in May of next year. The meeting is to be the fourth-ever meeting in the organisation‚Äôs 73-year history, taking place 16-17 May, 2023. The Council of Europe, a distinct organisation from the European Union, is an international body tasked with upholding human rights and rule of law in Europe. Founded after the Second World War, its best-known body is the European Court of Human Rights. Faced with new crises in Europe, from the war in Ukraine and the accompanying energy crisis to the economic disruptions of the global COVID-19 pandemic, the organisation has announced that it is time to redouble efforts to promote democracy and justice in Europe. Some 46 nations are party to the Council of Europe #Breaking @coe Committee of Ministers just adopted decision to hold 4th Summit of Heads of State/Gov in üáÆüá∏Reykjavik in May 2023. Opportunity for leaders of 46 Council of Europe Member States to unite & recommit to the core principles ‚Äì human rights, democracy & rule of law. pic.twitter.com/wp2CuASGMf In a press release from the Council of Europe, Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir stated: ‚ÄúIt is a great honour for Iceland to be the host of the 4th Summit of Heads of State and Government. Iceland is convinced that the Council of Europe ‚Äì the continent‚Äôs oldest and leading pan-European organization ‚Äì has a critical role to play as the region‚Äôs guardian of human rights, democracy, and the rule of law. Together, we must continue to ensure that the Council of Europe is fit for purpose to meet current and future challenges as well as the expectations of future generations. We applaud the Irish presidency for their in-depth work on the role of the Council and look forward to working with all the Council‚Äôs Member States to reaffirm our common commitment to the Council‚Äôs core principles.‚Äù Council of Europe Secretary General Marija Pejƒçinoviƒá Buriƒá also stated: ‚ÄúThe decision to hold a Fourth Summit of Heads of State and Governments is timely and right. I congratulate the Committee of Ministers on taking it. The Summit will be an opportunity for all our member states to recommit to the values that underpin democratic security in our fast-changing continent.‚Äù

headline: Bjarni Benediktsson Reelected as Independence Party Chair
body: Bjarni Benediktsson has been reelected as the chair of the Independence Party on Sunday. His leadership, which many have come to see as an embodiment of establishment politics, was challenged by Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r √û√≥r√∞arson, the current Minister of the Environment, Energy, and Climate. R√öV reports that Bjarni won the election with 59.4% of the vote, versus the 40.4% earned by Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r. The Independence Party‚Äôs National Convention is generally held every two years. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, it has not been held for four and a half years. Gu√∞laugur‚Äôs challenge is perhaps a sign of needed change in a party whose leadership has remained frozen by recent events. In the wake of the vote, both Bjarni and Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r emphasized the importance of party unity and both anticipate that Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r will retain his ministerial position. It had previously been suggested that losing the election would have political ramifications for Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r. ‚ÄúWe have to stand together to push the party through the rebuilding phase,‚Äù said Bjarni. Bjarni has been active in politics since 2003, when he was elected as a representative in Al√æingi, Iceland‚Äôs parliament. Since then, he has also served as Iceland‚Äôs prime minister and is now both chairperson of the Independence Party, Iceland‚Äôs centre-right party, and Minister of Finance. His tenure as Minister of Finance has been punctuated by several major corruption scandals, the most recent of which revolved around the sale of √çslandsbanki shares. √û√≥rd√≠s Kolbr√∫n Reykfj√∂r√∞ Gylfad√≥ttir, current Minister of Foreign Affairs, will continue to serve as the party‚Äôs vice chair. MP Vilhj√°lmur √Årnason was elected party secretary.

headline: Commissioner‚Äôs Father Unable to Account for Dozens of Firearms
body: The father of Police Commissioner Sigr√≠√∞ur Bj√∂rk Gu√∞j√≥nsd√≥ttir was unable to account for dozens of firearms discovered at his home during an investigation of a domestic-terror plot. No investigation was opened into his actions, despite his admission that he had sold illegally modified weapons in exchange for cash payment, R√öV reports. As reported in late September, National Police Commissioner Sigr√≠√∞ur Bj√∂rk Gu√∞j√≥nsd√≥ttir recused herself from an investigation into a domestic-terror plot after the home of her father, Gu√∞j√≥n Valdimarsson ‚Äì a well-known weapons collector and vendor ‚Äì was searched during the investigation. According to R√öV, a search of Gu√∞j√≥n‚Äôs home revealed nearly forty unlicensed firearms, for which Gu√∞j√≥n was unable to adequately account. Gu√∞j√≥n was not arrested, however, and the police have not divulged his legal status in relation to the investigation. This is not the first time that Sigr√≠√∞ur Bj√∂rk has been forced to recuse herself from an investigation. In 2018, Sigr√≠√∞ur‚Äôs father was also entangled in an investigation involving the alleged offence of an individual in possession of a DPMS rifle that had been modified to function as semi-automatic. ‚ÄúIn that case, the sole aim of the investigation was whether the buyer ‚Äì who did not have the knowledge, the tools, nor the access to spare parts ‚Äì had modified the weapon himself. The individual who sold the rifle, however, was only interrogated as a witness,‚Äù Einar Gautur Steingr√≠msson, attorney for the man who was charged with the weapons offence, told R√öV. As noted by R√öV, the accused was acquitted before the Court of Appeal (Landsr√©ttur) as the prosecution failed to prove that he had modified the weapon. The case was thereby closed, without any investigation being opened into whether Gu√∞j√≥n Valdimarsson, or someone else, had modified the weapon. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs completely mind-boggling that someone who sells a firearm, which has been modified, is not the subject of the investigation alongside the buyer; the person who modified the weapon is not investigated but rather the person who couldn‚Äôt,‚Äù Einar Gautur added. Gu√∞j√≥n was, however, interrogated, although the interrogation was conducted at his home in Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur and not at the police station. Police reports do not indicate why the interrogation took place at his home. R√öV also notes that it possesses documents proving that the defendant in the aforementioned case had paid Gu√∞j√≥n ISK 1.5 million ($10,00 / ‚Ç¨10,000) for the weapon, in cash. No receipt or invoice changed hands during the time of the transaction (i.e. no tax was paid). During his interrogation, Gu√∞j√≥n partially confirmed that the transaction had been conducted with cash for ISK 700,000 ($5,000 / ‚Ç¨5,00). In an interview with V√≠sir published this morning, Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson maintained that the police had not protected the Police Commissioner‚Äôs father. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve no information to indicate that such a thing happened,‚Äù J√≥n remarked. ‚ÄúAs far as that older case (from 2018) is concerned, during a time when the Police Commissioner was employed as the Chief of the Capital Area Police, she declared her conflict of interest and recused herself. The investigation was subsequently transferred to someone else.‚Äù J√≥n went on to suggest that he wasn‚Äôt adequately familiar with the details of the current investigation to comment but that the Police Commissioner appeared to have comported herself ethically. When asked whether it wasn‚Äôt clear that the legislation on firearms needed to be amended ‚Äì to prevent individuals from hoarding firearms, among them semi-automatic weapons ‚Äì J√≥n stated that he hoped such amendments would be concluded before the end of the year. ‚ÄúWhen I arrived at the Ministry, I realised that this legislation would need to be reviewed. We‚Äôre in the process of doing so now, as I‚Äôve previously announced.‚Äù

headline: Sj√≥n Withdraws from Literary Festival Due to PM‚Äôs Participation
body: The Icelandic writer Sj√≥n has announced his withdrawal from this year‚Äôs Iceland Noir Festival owing to the participation of Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir. Writing on Twitter yesterday, Sj√≥n cited ‚Äúthe cruel treatment of asylum seekers‚Äù by Katr√≠n‚Äôs cabinet. Iceland Noir is a literary festival held in Reykjav√≠k celebrating ‚Äúdarkness in all its forms.‚Äù Founded in 2013 by authors Ragnar J√≥nasson and Yrsa Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir, Iceland Noir began as a celebration of crime fiction but has gradually evolved to welcome writers outside the genre while also including television and film screenings alongside panels. This year‚Äôs festival will be held between November 16 and 19 and will be headlined by Bernardine Evaristo and Richard Osman alongside Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir. Other notable guests include First Lady of Iceland Eliza Reid, English novelist Mark Billingham ‚Äì and Icelandic writer Sj√≥n. Yesterday, however, Sj√≥n announced that he was withdrawing from the festival due to the participation of PM Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir: I am pulling out of the Iceland Noir 2022 Festival as I can not take part in the culture washing of the Prime Minister of Iceland, @katrinjak. @icelandnoir will allow her to pose as a person of culture while her government's cruel treatment of asylum seekers goes unquestioned. ‚Äî Sj√≥n üá∫üá¶üè≥Ô∏è‚Äç‚ößÔ∏èüè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà (@Sjonorama) November 3, 2022  Sj√≥n‚Äôs announcement follows on the heels of fifteen asylum seekers being deported from Iceland. Among those deported was a disabled Iraqi, in Iceland with a family of five, whose lawyer has told the media that he is preparing a complaint to the European Court of Human Rights. The treatment of the man inspired public outcry and a protest was held on Austurv√∂llur Square, in front of Parliament, at 5.15 PM yesterday. The protest was organised by No Borders Iceland and Solaris (an aid organisation providing assistance to asylum seekers and refugees in Iceland) and was ‚Äúwell attended‚Äù according to V√≠sir. Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir spoke to V√≠sir in response to the public outcry yesterday, maintaining that it was ‚Äúonly natural for people to become upset‚Äù whenever force was applied in cases such as these: ‚ÄúBut what we must look into, in particular ‚Äì and I think that I speak for everyone ‚Äì is the treatment of the disabled person, who was among those asylum seekers who were deported. It‚Äôs extremely important that we take great pains when it comes to vulnerable groups of people and that we ensure that his rights were fully respected.‚Äù Isavia, Iceland‚Äôs national airport and air navigation service provider, apologised for hindering the work of photojournalists during the deportations at Keflav√≠k Airport.

headline: Sixteen Middle Managers at Landsp√≠tali Hospital Dismissed
body: Sixteen middle managers employed at the National University Hospital of Iceland received letters of termination yesterday, R√öV reports. The terminations stem from the adoption of a new organisational chart intended to improve the hospital‚Äôs operations. A new organisational chart will come into effect at the National University Hospital on January 1. According to director Run√≥lfur P√°lsson, the organisational chart is intended to simplify the hospital‚Äôs operations and make them more efficient. ‚ÄúThe main purpose is to get a handle on the hospital‚Äôs management and operations, to strengthen our clinical services, and to harmonise other key services,‚Äù Run√≥lfur remarked in an interview with R√öV. Over the past months, questions concerning the sustainability of the hospital‚Äôs operations have come to the fore. When asked if these changes would be felt by the public, Run√≥lfur replied: ‚ÄúI hope it‚Äôll translate into a stronger hospital, that we‚Äôll be able to improve our service: improve our emergency services, the flow of patients while also strengthening our surgical department. If we‚Äôre successful in this regard, then the public will certainly feel it.‚Äù The hospital‚Äôs organisational chart was introduced to the Minister of Health today. The changes imply a decrease in the number of middle managers and increased responsibility among front-line managers. ‚ÄúSix directorial positions will be cut, but there are two positions that are bound by law, namely the directorship of nurses and medicine ‚Äì but the other six will be cut alongside all of the ten managerial positions,‚Äù Run√≥lfur remarked. As reported by R√öV, the sixteen individuals holding the aforementioned positions received a letter of notice yesterday. Run√≥lfur added that because the organisational chart had yet to be implemented, it remained to be seen whether it would result in increased efficiency. ‚ÄúThese are big changes, and we must be aware that changes to the organisational chart, in themselves, are not enough to improve our output ‚Äì there are other things that must work out as well,‚Äù Run√≥lfur stated. ‚ÄúBut the purpose of these changes is to get a better handle on and harmonise our clinical services. In the near future, we will aim to overhaul all of the clinical organisational units in the front line and strengthen its management affording them greater responsibility.‚Äù

headline: Bjarni Benediktsson to Resign from Politics if Successfully Challenged
body: In a recent interview with R√öV, Independence Party chairperson Bjarni Benediktsson claimed that he will retire from political life if he loses the contest for party leadership. The statements come in light of Minister of the Environment, Energy, and Climate Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r √û√≥r√∞arsson‚Äôs recently announced intentions to seek Bjarni‚Äôs position. The Independence Party‚Äôs National Convention is generally held every two years. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, it has not been held for four and a half years. Gu√∞laugur‚Äôs challenge is perhaps a sign of needed change in a party whose leadership has remained frozen by recent events. Gu√∞laugur himself has stated that very little separates his and Bjarni‚Äôs platforms. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs primarily about the personalities,‚Äù he stated to R√öV, which could be a reference to discontent over Bjarni‚Äôs involvement in several corruption scandals, the most recent of which involved him in his role as Minister of Finance in the sale of √çslandsbanki shares. Bjarni has been active in politics since 2003, when he was elected as a representative in Al√æingi, Iceland‚Äôs parliament. Since then, he has also served as Iceland‚Äôs prime minister and is now both chairperson of the Independence Party, Iceland‚Äôs centre-right party, and Minister of Finance. In his long political career, he has become something of the embodiment of establishment politics. Some see Gu√∞laugur‚Äôs challenge as a chance for reform within the party. If Gu√∞laugur is to lose his attempt at seizing party leadership, there has been talk of political consequences for him and the party, with some suggesting the possibility that he be removed from his current ministerial seat. Eva Hei√∞a √ñnnud√≥ttir, a political scientist, has stated to Morgunbla√∞i√∞ that ‚Äú[i]t would be very controversial and very difficult.¬†If it had not come to this contest for leadership, then I would think that it would have been almost impossible. Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r has such strong support in the party that I believe that there would be severe political consequences to remove-ing him as a minister.‚Äù¬† The Independence Party National Convention will convene next Saturday, November 5. ¬†

headline: Reykjav√≠k City Announces Expansion of Paid Parking Zones
body: Changes will soon be made to paid parking zones in Reykjav√≠k, the City announced yesterday. A recent tally indicates that parking spaces just outside paid-parking zones are heavily used. Yesterday, the City announced that it will be expanding paid parking zones in Reykjav√≠k. According to a press release, a recent tally has indicated that spaces just beyond paid parking zones are heavily used. This gives ‚Äúoccasion to expand paid-parking zones in specific areas‚Äù and in accordance with regulations. The expansion will mainly apply to Zone 2 parking spaces but also to Zone 1 and 3. At a meeting on Wednesday, the City‚Äôs Environment and Planning Branch (Umhverfis- og skipulagsr√°√∞) approved a proposal, which has subsequently been referred to City Council. The proposal has also been put to the capital area police where it met with approval. The proposal will, however, not come into effect prior to approval and publication by City Council. Appropriate signage and metres must also be installed within new paid-parking zones. The following parking zones will be expanded: As noted by the press release, residents within paid parking zones can apply for residential cards. Conditions being met, holders of residential cards are allowed to park within applicable parking zones for free.

headline: Leadership of Independence Party to be Contested?
body: This week, Minister Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r √û√≥r√∞arson confirmed that he is considering his candidacy for Chair of Iceland‚Äôs Independence Party ‚Äì at the party‚Äôs National Convention next weekend. Minister Bjarni Benediktsson, who has served as the leader of the Icelandic Independence Party since 2009, has stated that it would be ‚Äúunusual to change the party leadership‚Äù when so little time has elapsed since the formation of a new coalition government. Iceland‚Äôs Independence Party was formed in 1929 through a merger of the Conservative Party and the Liberal Party. The party has won the largest share of the vote in every election except 2009 (when it fell behind the Social Democratic Alliance). Furthermore, every Independence Party leader has at some point held the office of Prime Minister. Bjarni Benediktsson, Minister of Finance and Economic Affairs, has served as the leader of the Icelandic Independence Party since 2009. The party commonly hosts its National Convention every two years. Owing to the pandemic, however, the Independence Party has not held a National Convention for four and a half years. In the run-up to this year‚Äôs convention, Minister of the Environment, Energy and Climate Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r √û√≥r√∞arson ‚Äì who first became involved with the Independence Party in 1987 when he was elected to the board of the National Youth Organisation ‚Äì surprised not a few party members, and ordinary citizens alike, by confirming that he was considering running against Chairman Bjarni. Speaking to R√öV yesterday, Gu√∞laugur voiced his concern for the state of the party: ‚ÄúMany have encouraged me to run. Their message is always the same: they‚Äôre worried about the state of the party. They ‚Äì and this goes for me, too ‚Äì don‚Äôt accept our current position ‚Ä¶ and without the necessary support, it will be more difficult for us to implement our policy and our ideals.‚Äù According to R√öV‚Äôs sources, Gu√∞laugur has entertained the notion of running for Chairman ‚Äúfor some time ‚Ä¶ having privately and publicly laid the foundation for his candidacy by ensuring that his supporters hold the reins in certain key positions that allocate seats at the National Convention. Meanwhile, Bjarni has focused his attention on the state finances during troubling times.‚Äù Approximately 2,000 party members will be offered seats at the Convention, who would then be eligible to vote in the event that Gu√∞laugur decided to throw his hat in the ring. Writing for R√öV, reporter Mar√≠a Sigr√∫n Hilmarsd√≥ttir, citing aforementioned sources, states that Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r is aware that he‚Äôs got ‚Äúone shot in the gun,‚Äù so to speak, and that now may be the time; Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r defeated Minister √Åslaug Arna Sigurbj√∂rnsd√≥ttir during the Independence Party‚Äôs primary elections in Reykjav√≠k last summer, and if Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r fails to announce now, it would be ‚Äúa sign of weakness and a lack of courage.‚Äù Supporters of Chairman Bjarni Benediktsson are ‚Äúprepared for the fight,‚Äù according to R√öV‚Äôs sources. Some of them are, however, surprised that Gu√∞laugur hadn‚Äôt taken ‚Äúmore conventional routes‚Äù in declaring his candidacy: announcing his intentions sooner and embarking on a ‚Äúnationwide campaign of meetings to gather support and shore up his position.‚Äù Bjarni‚Äôs supporters also maintain that the current Chairman has yet to reach his prime ‚Äì and that his best years are still ahead of him. They also note that ‚Äúany talk of loss of popular support is empty given that the political landscape has altered beyond recognition over the past years ‚Ä¶ given that 10 parties are now in the running.‚Äù Bjarni‚Äôs supporters also note ‚Äì as Bjarni himself has noted ‚Äì that the Chairman enjoys much greater support among his constituency compared to Gu√∞laugur.

headline: The Climate Disaster Has ‚ÄúAlready Begun to Materialise‚Äù
body: The international community is ‚Äúfalling far short of the Paris goals,‚Äù a new UN report finds. ‚ÄúThe disaster has already begun to materialise,‚Äù Halld√≥r √ûorgeirsson, Chair of Iceland‚Äôs Climate Council, told R√öV yesterday. Yesterday, October 27, the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) published its 2022 edition of the Emissions Gap report. The report provides an update on the progress towards ‚Äúachieving national mitigation pledges‚Äù and the goals set by the Paris Agreement by taking stock of the so-called ‚Äúemissions gap.‚Äù As noted by a UN press release, the report concludes that the international community is ‚Äúfalling far short of the Paris goals, with no credible pathway to 1.5¬∞C in place.‚Äù The authors state that the only way to avoid climate disaster is via an urgent ‚Äúsystem-wide transformation.‚Äù Read More: The Age of Eco-Anxiety ‚ÄúGlobal and national climate commitments are falling pitifully short,‚Äù Secretary General of the UN Ant√≥nio Guterres stated in a video message during an introduction of the report yesterday. ‚ÄúWe must close the emissions gap before climate catastrophe closes in on us all.‚Äù To address the report‚Äôs findings, R√öV invited the Chair of Iceland‚Äôs Climate Council Halld√≥r √ûorgeirsson (and a retired Senior Director at the UN Climate Change Secretariat) to an interview during yesterday‚Äôs nightly news. Halld√≥r was blunt: ‚ÄúThese disasters have already begun to materialise, and this year, we have seen disasters that are truly man-made. The strongest example being Pakistan, and, just as bad, and nearer to home, Florida. ‚ÄúThese things are already manifesting in such a way that it‚Äôs no longer a question of the future. Our meagre achievements means that the window of opportunity grows ever narrower; there‚Äôs much less time. That‚Äôs why the only feasible path forward is to undertake fast and extensive system-wide transformation.‚Äù The only way to do this, Halld√≥r maintained, was increased investment. ‚ÄúThese are large figures but in reality, it‚Äôs only about 2% of the total budget. So it certainly seems doable. Central banks play a big role, and we need to rethink the economy. That‚Äôs what this is about ‚Äì alongside greater cooperation between nations.‚Äù The 2022 United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP27) will be held from November 6 to 18 in Egypt. It will mark the 27th United Nations Climate Change conference. According to Halld√≥r, no ‚Äúbig decisions‚Äù are expected to be made during the conference. ‚ÄúThis conference will focus more on following through with the agreement,‚Äù Halld√≥r observed. ‚ÄúThe implementation of the Paris Agreement was concluded in Glasgow last year. During the first two days of the conference, global leaders will be present, and the messages that they send matter. All eyes will be on China. They‚Äôve been quite reticent. Then there‚Äôs this very strong undercurrent, connected to those aforementioned disasters because one of the big questions of this conference is how we provide aid to nations who suffer such disasters.‚Äù

headline: Iceland Among Nations to Boycott Vote on South Atlantic Whale Sanctuary
body:
Iceland‚Äôs delegation to a meeting of the International Whaling Commission (IWC) joined 14 other nations in walking out on a vote on whether to establish a whale sanctuary in the South Atlantic, V√≠sir reports. The mass walkout took place at the end of Friday‚Äôs session and meant that there were not enough member nations present to vote on the initiative. The Icelandic government has since commented on the walkout, saying that it objected to the vote on grounds of protocol and fairness to absent member states. A proposal to establish a whale sanctuary in the South Atlantic has been circulating amongst members of the IWC for years‚Äî20 years, according to a representative of Whale and Dolphin Conservation (WDC) Germany. The #IWC68 chair has closed the discussion on the proposal for the South Atlantic Whale Sanctuary to #IWC69 in 2024. This is a huge shame considering that the Sanctuary was proposed 20 years ago.#StopWhaling #SaveTheWhaleSaveTheWorld pic.twitter.com/I5DQWuByQe ‚Äî Whale and Dolphin Conservation (Deutschland) (@WDC_Deutschland) October 20, 2022  A simple majority of the IWC member states has already voted in support of the proposal, but a 3/4 majority is needed to ratify it. ‚ÄúPro-whaling nations‚Ä¶holding Commission hostage‚Äù Iceland‚Äôs delegation to the IWC consists of four delegates, including one representative each from the Ministry of Food, Agriculture, and Fisheries; the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; and the Marine and Freshwater Research Institute. The fourth representative is Kristj√°n Loftsson, CEO of the whaling company, Hvalur, hf. A recap of the Friday meeting on the IWC website described it as ‚Äúchallenging,‚Äù starting, on a more positive note, with the fact that it ‚Äúended with a consensus Resolution on Marine Plastics‚Äù which ‚Äúhighlights the transboundary nature of the threat and need for collaboration at international and multi-disciplinary levels.‚Äù Transboundary collaboration was stymied at the next agenda item, however, although the IWC recap struck a rather diplomatic tone when describing it: ‚ÄúAbsence of some governments from the room and subsequent debate regarding quorum and handling of the Schedule Amendment on the South Atlantic Sanctuary prevented a vote taking place and resulted in Commission agreement to develop proposals to clarify the rules related to quorum and attendance. This will be the first agenda item at the next meeting in 2024 and will be discussed before the Commission is asked to take any decisions.‚Äù Matt Collins, the president of the International Fund for Animal Welfare (IFAW), was more vocal in his critique of the proceedings, however, tweeting: breaking news: pro-whaling nations at #IWC68 refuse to join sessions, breaking quorum required for any decision-making. This is all because they fear losing a vote on establishing a South Atlantic Whale Sanctuary (where none of them hunt or want to hunt whales) ‚Äî Matt Collis (@MattCollisIFAW) October 20, 2022  ‚Äúbreaking news: pro-whaling nations at #IWC68 refuse to join sessions, breaking quorum required for any decision-making. This is all because they fear losing a vote on establishing a South Atlantic Whale Sanctuary (where none of them hunt or want to hunt whales)‚Äù According to Collins‚Äô later tweets, Iceland joined 14 other nations in the walkout: Antigua & Barbuda, Benin, Cambodia, Cote D‚ÄôIvoire, Ghana, Iceland, Kiribati, Laos, Liberia, Mauritania, Morocco, Nauru Palau, St. Lucia, and the Solomon Islands. The meeting chair elected to adjourn for lunch to see if the absent nations would return, but none of them did. ‚ÄúSame countries still absent, holding the Commission hostage‚Ä¶‚Äù tweeted Collins, a state of affairs that continued even after a second adjournment and ‚Äúpassionate pleas from Latin American countries for those absent to show respect to those who have remained.‚Äù we're back in session at#IWC68 but no change in status. Same countries still absent, holding the Commission hostage‚Ä¶ ‚Äî Matt Collis (@MattCollisIFAW) October 20, 2022  Ministry says Iceland objected out of fairness to absent members, protocol
 D√∫i Landmark, the PR officer for the Ministry of Food, Agriculture, and Fisheries, confirmed that the Icelandic delegation walked out of the South Atlantic Whale Sanctuary vote. In a written statement issued to the media about the incident, the Ministry stated that fewer than two out of three IWC member states were present at this year‚Äôs meeting in Portoroz, Slovenia, for a variety of reasons. The statement noted that it was the opinion of representatives of developing nations in Africa and island nations in the Caribbean that a vote should not be held under such circumstances. A number of present nations tried to proceed with the vote, but the Icelandic government agreed with the objectors, saying that holding a vote would be a breach of protocol according to the IWC‚Äôs Articles of Association. ‚ÄúConsequently, Iceland believes that it would be irregular to vote on such a proposal when the requirements of the [IWC‚Äôs] Articles of Association have not been fulfilled and a number of member states are unable to substantively comment on the proposal in question through participation in, and discussions at the annual meeting,‚Äù concluded the Ministry‚Äôs response. The vote on the South Atlantic Whale Sanctuary will be the first agenda item at next year‚Äôs meeting of the International Whaling Commission.

headline: Bill to Amend Foreign Nationals Act Distributed Among MP‚Äôs
body: Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson distributed his bill to amend the Foreign Nationals Act¬†among members of Parliament today. If passed into law, the bill would, among other things, strip asylum seekers of their rights 30 days after their applications have been rejected. Last spring, Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson announced his intention of submitting a bill to Parliament that would amend the Foreign Nationals Act. The Foreign National Act concerns the ‚Äúauthorisation of foreign nationals to enter Iceland, their stay in the country, and their right to international protection.‚Äù Earlier this month, J√≥n observed that the government was facing a ‚Äúdifficult situation‚Äù when it came to asylum seekers in Iceland. He maintained that the welfare system was unable to cope with increased demand and that it was his hope that the new bill would help to solve ‚Äúcertain problems.‚Äù As noted by R√öV, a record number of individuals (2,500) have applied for international protection in Iceland this year. Speaking to R√öV, J√≥n maintained that it was the ‚Äúgovernment‚Äôs duty‚Äù to establish a closed facility for asylum seekers whose applications for international protection had been rejected. ‚ÄúThis means that individuals are placed in particular housing, with limited access, limited freedom to travel, while they wait to be deported.‚Äù J√≥n added: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre dealing with a specific problem when it comes to deportations, namely that we‚Äôre unable to reach certain individuals, we don‚Äôt know where they are, or whether they‚Äôve left the country.‚Äù The minister‚Äôs rhetoric inspired immediate criticism from members of the Pirate and Reform parties, among others, who accused J√≥n of stoking fear with ‚Äúvague claims and assertions‚Äù about asylum seekers. PM Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir, who leads the cabinet to which J√≥n Gunnarsson belongs, stated that she disagreed with the Minister of Justice‚Äôs assertion that ‚Äúchaos reigned‚Äù in matters relating to asylum seekers in Iceland. Addressing Parliament, Katr√≠n remarked that the situation in Iceland was merely a reflection of unprecedented times and the offshoot of two governmental decisions in Iceland, namely to receive a greater number of refugees from Ukraine and Venezuela. This morning, the Minister‚Äôs bill was distributed among members of Parliament. It marked the fifth time that such an amendment was submitted to Parliament. As noted by R√öV, the bill stipulates that the rights of a foreign national (the right to housing, healthcare, etc.) whose application for international protection has been rejected be stripped 30 days after said rejection. This would, according to the authors‚Äô rationale, prevent individuals from seeking services, even for years on end, after they‚Äôve been made to leave the country. If passed into law, asylum seekers would ‚Äúno longer have access to healthcare or schools; however, the rights of children; parents or custodians; pregnant women; or disabled individuals with long-term support needs cannot be revoked.‚Äù To review the bill in Icelandic, click here.

headline: Str√¶t√≥ Discontinues Night-Time Service During Weekends
body: Str√¶t√≥ has announced that it will discontinue its night-time bus service in Reykjav√≠k during the weekends, citing low passenger demand during a special trial period. Str√¶t√≥ is facing financial troubles following the pandemic, and recently, the capital area municipalities had to divert extra fund to keep the regional partnership company from insolvency. In early July, Str√¶t√≥ (the public bus service in Iceland) announced that the Reykjav√≠k night bus, N√¶turstr√¶t√≥, would return to service on July 9 following a two-year hiatus in response to low demand during the pandemic. During this hiatus, many capital-area residents had called for its return, arguing that it provided an affordable and safe alternative to taxis. During a trial run between July and October of this year, however ‚Äì when the night bus departed downtown Reykjav√≠k every hour and stopped at the capital area‚Äôs seven suburban neighbourhoods ‚Äì demand once again proved wanting. As noted in a press release from Str√¶t√≥, an average of 15 passengers travelled aboard the night bus during each trip, which amounts to approximately 300 passengers over a weekend. ‚ÄúIn light of this, and given the finances, Str√¶t√≥‚Äôs board has agreed that continuing night-time service during the weekends, now that the trial period has concluded, cannot be justified. The service will, therefore, be discontinued.‚Äù As noted by V√≠sir, transportation options from downtown Reykjav√≠k after the night clubs have closed during the weekend are limited; operating electric scooters while intoxicated is illegal and securing transportation via taxis often proves difficult. ¬†

headline: Would-Be Terrorists Discussed Killing Minister Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r
body: The two men being held in police custody accused of planning a domestic terrorism attack in Iceland had reportedly discussed killing Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r √û√≥r√∞arson ‚Äì Minister of the Environment, Energy, and Climate. Four Icelandic men were arrested on September 21 suspected of ‚Äúterrorist plots‚Äù against state institutions and civilians. Two of the suspects were immediately released; the other two have remained in custody. Last Friday, the District Court of Reykjav√≠k approved the District Attorney‚Äôs request to extend their custody by four weeks. According to the police, the suspects had hoarded numerous weapons ‚Äì including dozens of semi-automatic guns and 3D-printed components ‚Äì alongside a considerable amount of ammunition. The men, both of whom are in their twenties, had reportedly discussed carrying out an attack during the police‚Äôs annual celebration (which was held on October 1). Yesterday, R√öV reported that the suspects had also discussed killing Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r √û√≥r√∞arson, Minister of the Environment, Energy, and Climate. The Chief of Police reportedly notified the Minister of the suspects‚Äô intentions prior to calling the Minister in for questioning. As reported on October 10, the suspects had also discussed targeting Efling chairperson S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir and Gunnar Sm√°ri Egilsson, chairperson of the Socialist Party. The names of current and former Pirate Party politicians were also mentioned as possible targets. The police have asked a psychiatrist to assess the earnestness of the remarks made by the men during private messages, with the suspects‚Äô lawyers contending that the threats were empty. Chief Police Inspector Karl Steinar Valsson has stated that this is the ‚Äúfirst investigation of its kind‚Äù to be launched in Iceland.

headline: VR to Remain in AS√ç
body: Ragnar √û√≥r Ing√≥lfsson, chairperson of VR, has stated that for the time being, VR‚Äôs position within AS√ç will remain unchanged. VR is Iceland‚Äôs largest trade union, representing some 40,000 workers. There have however been suggestions recently that VR will leave AS√ç, or the Federation of Labour. AS√ç, founded in 1916, is the largest federation of trade unions in Iceland and has historically played an important role in labour organisation in Iceland. However, the most recent AS√ç conference over contract negotiations has proved a turbulent one, with many major trade unions suggesting that they go their separate ways in the future. The upheavals come in the wake of Dr√≠fa Sn√¶dal‚Äôs resignation earlier this year from her leadership position in AS√ç. Citing political hostility, she said that it was no longer possible to perform her duties in her resignation letter. Since her resignation, AS√ç leadership has been in turmoil, with some of Iceland‚Äôs largest trade unions considering leaving during AS√ç‚Äôs 45th conference. Ragnar √û√≥r also withdrew his candidacy for AS√ç leadership at the conference, citing the possibility of a break with the federation. Now, at least for the time being, it seems that VR will remain with AS√ç. The announcement came today before a formal meeting with SA, Iceland‚Äôs leading employers‚Äô union. In a statement from Ragnar √û√≥r, he said that all of the union‚Äôs efforts will now be directed towards the wage negotiations with SA. Regarding the future, however, Ragnar √û√≥r emphasised that nothing can be ruled out.

headline: ‚ÄúThe task is massive,‚Äù PM Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir tells Arctic Council
body: Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir addressed the audience at the Arctic Circle conference yesterday. In her speech, Katr√≠n warned that if sufficient action wasn‚Äôt taken today, the arctic could ‚Äúbecome unrecognisable‚Äù in the future. The Arctic Circle is a nonprofit and nonpartisan organisation founded by former President of Iceland √ìlafur Ragnar Gr√≠msson, former publisher Alice Rogoff, and former Premier of Greenland Kuupik Kleist, among others. The organisation aims to facilitate dialogue between governments, organisations, corporations, universities, think tanks, environmental associations, indigenous communities, concerned citizens, and other stakeholders to address issues facing the Arctic as a result of climate change and melting sea ice. During the opening of the 2022 Arctic Circle Assembly yesterday, October 13, at the Harpa Conference Hall in Reykjav√≠k, Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir addressed the audience. Katr√≠n began her speech on a note of positivity, acknowledging the ‚Äúbroad political determination‚Äù to protect the Arctic and capitalise on present opportunities: ‚ÄúOn the positive side, we see expanding scientific networks, greater knowledge with both the public and businesses and growing skills, there is more investment in green technology, and we are witnessing various green solutions emerging.‚Äù However, Katr√≠n noted, the Arctic could become ‚Äúunrecognisable in a few decades‚Äù if further decisive action was not taken. ‚ÄúEverything is changing ‚Äì we see more extreme weathers around the globe ‚Äì only in the last two weeks we saw hundreds of trees here in Iceland being ripped up by their roots because of extreme storms in the eastern part of the country. We see glaciers receding, permafrost is melting, heat records are beaten and forests are burning. And all this is happening much faster in the Arctic ‚Äì where the ecosystem is sensitive and the resources are great.‚Äù Some of these resources, Katr√≠n noted, should not be meddled with: ‚ÄúWe see big business and big countries showing more and more interest in the Arctic ‚Äì not least because of its rich resources which should not all be harnessed. I applaud the decision of the government of Greenland not to drill for oil ‚Äì my government has also declared that we will not issue licences for oil exploration in Iceland‚Äôs exclusive economic zone and this will be put into legislation.‚Äù Alongside addressing climate-related issues in the Arctic, Katr√≠n also turned her attention to the war in Ukraine and the exclusion of Russia from the Council: ‚ÄúOur region is directly affected as the aggressor is an important player in the Arctic with legitimate interests. But Russia‚Äôs illegitimate actions made it impossible for us not to respond and they were rightly excluded from the Arctic Council. From day one Iceland has condemned Russia‚Äôs aggression in the strongest possible way. Iceland has solidly supported Ukraine, and we will continue to do so, together with our Nordic, European, US, and Canadian friends.‚Äù Katr√≠n concluded her speech with a nod to the massiveness of the task lying ahead: ‚ÄúThis room is full of hope and concerns for the future of the Arctic. We represent different interests, different politics, different ideas. But we should all be united in the will to protect the Arctic and provide a sustainable future for the local populations in the area, as well as for our ecosystems. The task is massive, but the solutions exist, it is ours to get the job done.‚Äù

headline: Foreign Nationals to Receive Icelandic Citizenship after Controversial Withholding of Applications
body: R√öV reports that six foreign citizens are to be naturalised as Icelandic citizens following a delay that was caused by the Directorate of Immigration withholding their applications. The six new Icelanders are respectively from Mongolia, Russia, South Africa, Kosovo, and Iran. In addition to the normal process of receiving citizenship through residence and application, parliament can also grant citizenship through decree in Iceland. These special applications are generally for individuals in extenuating circumstances, though some critics such as Bjarni Benediktsson have stated that these special applications constitute too large a proportion of Icelandic naturalisations. These citizenship applications through decree are still processed by the Directorate of Immigration, however, and there was controversy when earlier in the year, the Directorate refused to hand over the relevant application to parliament. Notably, this deliberate withholding was illegal, and caused outcry among politicians who insisted that legal process be followed. Now, the relevant application have finally been submitted and the path has been cleared to Icelandic citizenship for the six. Parliament generally naturalises Icelandic citizens twice a year: at the end of the year and before summer break. ¬† ¬†

headline: AS√ç Leadership and Future Up in the Air as Three Candidates Withdraw
body: Ragnar √û√≥r Ing√≥lfsson, chairperson of VR, S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir, chairperson of Efling, and Vilhj√°lmur Birgisson, chairperson of the Association of Trade Unions, have all withdrawn their candidacy for the central board of AS√ç. At the 45th conference of AS√ç, Iceland‚Äôs Federation of Labour, tensions have run high, with accusations of personal attacks and more leading to uncertainty for the future of AS√ç‚Äôs leadership. The tensions take place in the wake of Dr√≠fa Sn√¶dal‚Äôs, former chairperson of the AS√ç board, resignation earlier this year. Among the reasons for her resignation she cited that personal conflicts had escalated to the point where it was no longer possible for her to perform her job. In addition to their candidacies for leadership being withdrawn, they have also stated that they are now considering withdrawing their unions from AS√ç itself. Both S√≥lveig and Ragnar have stressed in statements that the final decision will be decided among the unions themselves. The Federation of Labour, founded in 1916, has been the major power in organised labour in Iceland since its founding. Should Efling and VR, Iceland‚Äôs two largest trade unions, leave AS√ç, it would represent a historic change in Icelandic labour relations. √ìl√∂f Helga Adolfsd√≥ttir, secretary of the board of Efling, had previously announced her candidacy against Ragnar √û√≥r for AS√ç president. She is the presumptive candidate for AS√ç president. ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†

headline: Deep North Episode 11: One Night in Gufunes
body: It is honesty, full-throated and vulnerable, which elevates Birnir‚Äôs music above that of other contemporary rappers in Iceland. That and some excellent production. Bushido, Birnir‚Äôs latest work, is a culmination of certain developments in contemporary hip-hop in Iceland; one is inclined to agree. To put one‚Äôs finger on the appeal of the album requires, perhaps, some basic theorising on the phenomenon of music ‚Äì and the power it exercises over a person‚Äôs emotions. In episode 11 of Deep North, we talk about hip-hop, family, and what makes Birnir tick. Read the full story here. ¬†

headline: Iceland‚Äôs 2023 Eurovision Contenders Revealed
body: The ten songs that will compete to become Iceland‚Äôs 2023 Eurovision submission have been released by Iceland‚Äôs National Broadcaster R√öV. The songs will compete for the privilege to represent Iceland in Liverpool this May in the 67th edition of the upcoming Eurovision Song Contest. The songs will first have to make it through one of two Icelandic semi-finals, on February 18 or February 25, and the final held on March 4. See also: Will this be Iceland‚Äôs Year? The submissions are diverse as usual, ranging from powerful ballads to catchy electro-dance tunes and even a rock and roll-inspired number. All of the songs can be heard on a Spotify playlist featuring both the Icelandic- and English-language versions of each song. S√∂ngvakeppnin, the Icelandic Eurovision pre-competition, requires all submissions to be sung in Icelandic, but many of the artists write an English version as well, intended for the international audience and potential Eurovision performance.

headline: Icelandic Animated Short Nominated for Oscar
body: Icelandic director Sara Gunnarsd√≥ttir‚Äôs animated short, ‚ÄúMy Year of Dicks,‚Äù was nominated for an Academy Award under the category Best Animated Short Film. The nominations were announced at a ceremony last night, January 24, where the title of the film was occasion for some humour.¬† The animated short is based on the comedic memoirs of Pamela Ribon, and centres around an American teenager‚Äôs coming of age. Also nominated for best short film were The Boy, the Mole, the Fox and the Horse; The Flying Sailor; Ice Merchants; and An Ostrich Told me the World Is Fake and I Think I Believe it. The final selection will be announced at the Academy Awards ceremony, hosted this March in Los Angeles.

headline: Pedro Gunnlaugur Garcia Gets the Icelandic Literary Prize
body: The Icelandic Literary Prize was awarded last night, January 24, at a ceremony in Bessasta√∞ir. President Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson awarded the Icelandic Literary Prize, as well as the prize for best crime thriller, known as the ‚ÄúBlood Drop‚Äù award, the best non-fiction, and the best youth literature. This year‚Äôs recipient of the Icelandic Literary Prize is Pedro Gunnlaugur Garcia for his novel,¬†Lungu¬†(Lungs), published by Bjartur. According to the verdict by the award panel, ‚ÄúLungu is a sweeping family history of many generations from different corners of the world, which plays out in contemporary Iceland, but also stretches far into the future, culminating in a virtual reality where these generations mingle. Here, a new tone is struck in Icelandic fiction writing with a magical narrative that effortlessly and smoothly moves between the deepest emotions and conflicts to adventurous moments of joy with a mythical twist ‚Äì so that even the greatest tragedies benefit from the joy. Relationships between lovers and generations are broken and damaged, but stories and memories illuminate fateful moments in their lives, showing the reader the very spark of life, and capturing the essence of a long life,‚Äù says the jury‚Äôs review. At the ceremony, Pedro Gunnlaugur Garcia stated: ‚ÄúIt is gratifying, strange, and frankly overwhelming that the book has reached readers, touched some people, and now won an award. I didn‚Äôt expect this at all; it was a distant dream at best.‚Äù Other recipients this year included Sk√∫li Sigur√∞sson for his crime thriller¬†St√≥ri Br√≥√∞ir¬†(Big Brother), Arnd√≠s √û√≥rarinsd√≥ttir for her children‚Äôs book¬†Kollhn√≠s¬†(Somersault), and Ragnar Stef√°nsson for his non-fiction¬†Hven√¶r kemur s√° st√≥ri: A√∞ sp√° fyrir um jar√∞skj√°lfta (When Is the Big One Coming: Predicting Earthquakes). The Icelandic Literary Prize was founded in 1989 on the 100-year anniversary of the Association of Icelandic Book Publishers. Recipients of the award receive ISK 1 million [$6,930; ¬†‚Ç¨6,360], provided by the Association of Icelandic Book Publishers. ¬† ¬† ¬†

headline: Will This Be Iceland‚Äôs Year? Ten Songs Chosen as 2023‚Äôs Eurovision Contenders
body: Ten songs have been selected to take part in this year‚Äôs S√∂ngvakeppnin, the three-part competition that will decide the act that will represent Iceland in the 2023 Eurovision Song Contest in Liverpool in May, R√öV reports. The ten songs, along with their songwriters and the musicians who will perform them, will be announced during a TV special on R√öV on Saturday, January 28. Of the 137 songs were submitted for consideration, six were chosen by a selection committee comprised of representatives from the Association of Icelandic Musicians (F√çH), the Icelandic Society of Composers and Lyricists (FTT), and R√öV. The remaining four slots were filled by performers who the selection committee specifically invited to take part. Will 2023 finally be Iceland‚Äôs year? Since its debut in 1986, Iceland has achieved seven Top 10 placements in Eurovision, including, most recently, Hatari‚Äôs 10th place in 2019 with their art-industro anthem ‚ÄúHatri√∞ mun sigra,‚Äù (‚ÄúHate Will Prevail‚Äú) and Da√∞i og Gagnamagni√∞‚Äôs much-beloved ‚Äú10 Years,‚Äù which placed fourth. Iceland has come this close to winning twice, placing second in 1999 and 2009. 1999: 2009: National song contest to begin in February; winning song selected in March The first semi-final will take place on February 18; the second will take place on February 25. Five songs compete for two spots in the final. The selection committee also has the ability to advance a fifth song. So the national final will include either or four or five songs, depending on whether the committee sees fit to nominate a wild card. Either way, the final will be held on March 4. The festivities will be hosted by actress, presenter, and assistant director of R√öV, Ragnhildur Steinunn J√≥nsd√≥ttir, alongside musician Unnstein Manuel Stef√°nsson, and radio station R√°s 2‚Äôs Director of Music, Sigur√∞ur √ûorri Gunnarsson. Following the TV special on January 28th, the songs will be available to listen to alongside their lyrics on the website songvakeppnin.is. They will also be published on Spotify the same night.

headline: F√öSK Art Collective Looks for New Home
body: DIY art collective, F√öSK, is on the look for a new home.  Gufunes, a former industrial area near the capital, has for some years been the location of film production company Reykjav√≠k Studios, in addition to several other art projects and collectives. The City of Reykjav√≠k has offered abandoned industrial facilities at the site to artists and creative workers who would like to develop them into studios and workspaces. However, despite the initial welcome art projects have received in this area, many are now being forced to relocate. F√öSK leases a de-commissioned fertilizer factory from the City of Reykav√≠k. In a public statement on social media, F√öSK members pointed out unfavourable leasing conditions from the City of Reykjav√≠k, in addition to increasing restrictions. F√öSK has, for instance, been restricted from working with the film industry and from holding further events. Elsa J√≥nsd√≥ttir, a co-founder of F√öSK, stated: ‚ÄúWe went into F√öSK not having anything, water, electricity, or plumbing. It made every 100 per cent harder, but we also learned a lot. I became so invested in some of the projects we had in Gufunes, I just hope the city fights to keep some of them alive.‚Äù Elsa also praised the city for some of its support for artists during the COVID-19 pandemic but suggested a lack of planning. ‚ÄúWe saw all this support for artists during COVID,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut once it was over, they just pulled out the rug from under us. I don‚Äôt think there was a very long-term plan. Even though the city has tried to support youth culture and the arts through initiatives, we don‚Äôt always see it in practice.‚Äù The future of F√öSK is still very much up in the air, but organizers have stated their openness to many different possibilities, including a possible relocation to the countryside. The Gufunes area is slated for an urban renewal project, with plans to construct a swimming pool, a preschool, steam baths, and an underwater restaurant.

headline: √ûorrabl√≥t Feasts Return After Two-Year Hiatus
body: After a two-year hiatus during COVID, 2023 marks the return of √ûorrabl√≥t, a midwinter feast inspired by the food traditions and pagan celebrations of medieval Iceland. Demand is expected to be high over the coming weeks and local food producers are scrambling to prepare. R√öV reports that Icelanders are projected to eat some 60 tons of traditional √æorrabl√≥t fare, which ranges, on the more appetizing end of the spectrum, from hangikj√∂t, or smoked lamb, to soured meats that have been pickled in whey. A not-so-ancient festival √ûorrabl√≥t coincides with the old Norse month of √ûorri, which this year, begins on January 21 and continues through February 18. But while the feast does have its roots in ancient tradition, ‚Äú‚Ä¶there is really nothing that connects [that tradition] to the present-day feasts of the same name,‚Äù food historian Nanna R√∂gnvaldad√≥ttir writes in Icelandic Food and Cookery. Instead, Nanna explains, the festival was largely the creation of ‚Äú‚Ä¶a restaurant owner in Reykjav√≠k in the late 1950s‚Äîhe thought there might be a market for the disappearing traditional Icelandic foods that had never been served in restaurants before.‚Äù A traditional √ûorrabl√≥t spread includes hangokj√∂t, or smoked lamb, as well as a variety of preserved sour dishes, or s√∫rmatur. S√∫rmatur, as Eygl√≥ Svala Arnarsd√≥ttir explains, ‚Äúincludes soured blood and liver pudding, ram testicles, sheep-head jelly, brisket and lundabaggi, a roll of secondary meats. Also eaten at √ûorrabl√≥t is putrefied shark and buttered dried fish. A traditional type of bread served alongside the √ûorri dinner is flatkaka, a special Icelandic rye flatbread.‚Äù Pickling prep started in August √ûorrabl√≥t is typically celebrated with large, buffet-style feasts. Workplaces, cultural associations, and villages all host their own, well-attended festivities, something that was obviously not possible during COVID. This changed the way that √æorramatur (food for √æorrabl√≥t) was packaged and sold over the last few years, namely that stores began selling single-serving, pre-portioned √æorrabl√≥t plates that could be eaten at home. These TV-dinner-style plates proved popular and will still be sold this year, but there‚Äôs also a resurgence in demand for √æorramatur in banquet-ready quantities. This means that local meat processing companies like Nor√∞lenska have their hands full for the next few weeks. Andr√©s Vilhj√°lmsson, marketing director for Nor√∞lenska, says that he fully expects that some popular √æorrabl√≥t products will sell out this year. √ûorrabl√≥t is a feast of all the food that survived the winter, primarily meat and fish that has been dried, salted, smoked, soured, pickled, or cured.
