headline: Rising Prices Likely to Affect Christmas Book Market
body: Inflation and the energy crisis in Europe are driving up prices for many consumer goods, and Christmas books are likely to be no exception this year. Books are a traditional and popular Christmas gift in Iceland, so much so that the months preceding Christmas see a ‚Äúj√≥lab√≥kafl√≥√∞,‚Äù or flood of Christmas books. The tradition is said to have originated during the Second World War, when products from Europe became scarcer. Books were largely printed locally and were seen as cheap and easily available Christmas gifts. In a statement to R√öV, chairman of the Association of Icelandic Book Publishers Hei√∞ar Ingi Svansson stated that the industry hopes to avoid price increases as much as possible, but that some increases will be inevitable. Hei√∞ar outlined the factors contributing to rising costs: ‚Äúthe main ones are that the energy crisis in Europe is causing an increase in energy prices for the production of paper. In recent years, the supply of paper for book printing has also decreased due to the greater focus of paper manufacturers on producing paper for packaging production, due to the increase in online sales.‚Äù Despite the energy crisis and rising costs, Hei√∞ar says that the Icelandic publishing industry must still largely rely on Northern Europe for its needs. ‚ÄúThe increase in transportation costs around the world and the fact that the state‚Äôs reimbursement of part of the production costs is limited to printing in Europe means that it is not possible for publishers to print books elsewhere in the world,‚Äù Hei√∞ar stated. ‚ÄúAlso, environmental considerations, including the carbon footprint, play a major role.‚Äù Another factor keeping Icelandic publishing in Europe, and especially Germany, is the increasing time frame for printing books. Years ago, when paper was cheaper, publishers kept large stocks of paper. Now with increasing shift in logistics to ‚Äújust in time‚Äù manufacturing, publishers tend to keep increasingly small stocks of paper, meaning that supplies have to be specially ordered for each print run. This means increased time between when the book is sent off to print and when it hits shelves. As a result of this, Icelandic book publishers are keen to keep the printing process as close to Iceland as possible to ensure on-time delivery. Despite the bleak holiday forecast, Hei√∞ar stated that ‚Äúwe are going to do everything in our power to hold back price increases on books before Christmas. The Christmas book is by far the most popular Christmas gift for Icelanders, and we plan to do everything we can to ensure that it remains so.‚Äù ¬†

headline: New Gr√≠msey Church Hosts First Service After Fire
body: The first service was celebrated in the new Gr√≠msey church this Sunday, in a major milestone for the reconstruction. The historic church, built out of driftwood in 1867 and relocated in 1932, burned to the ground last year in a fire. Although no one was injured, the destruction of the church was a significant loss for the small community. The new church has been designed to reference the historical structure, but also to accommodate the modern needs of the community, including use as an event space for the Gr√≠msey islanders. In an interview with R√öV, Reverend Oddur Bjarni √ûorkelsson, parish priest of Gr√≠msey said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a huge moment. I am not often speechless, but that‚Äôs exactly how it was. This is the first time I‚Äôve seen the building after its construction began. It‚Äôs so similar to the old church but completely different too. And to see the power of the community and the joy of everyone who came to help, this is a great moment.‚Äù The reconstruction of the church has cost an estimated ISK 120 million, with the original structure being insured for ISK 30 million. Another ISK 20 million has been funded by the state, but much of the remaining amount has had to be collected by the community themselves.

headline: Supreme Court Takes Up Slayer Suit Against Secret Solstice Festival
body: Iceland‚Äôs Supreme Court has accepted an appeal by American thrash metal band Slayer against the organisers of the Secret Solstice festival. Slayer performed at the 2018 festival and allege that they were never paid for their performance. In a 2020 ruling, organisers of Secret Solstice were ordered by a Reykjav√≠k district court to pay a sum of ISK 20 million (USD 138,900; EUR 143,800) to Slayer. Despite some ambiguity in communications regarding the payment, it was determined that Slayer should be compensated with the personal assets of the organisers. However, earlier this year, the decision was revisited by the National Court, which then acquitted Live Events, the former organisers. With the former organisers in bankruptcy, representatives from Slayer have claimed that assets were misused during the bankruptcy, and that there is precedent for payment obligation in such cases. After the festival‚Äôs bankruptcy, it was sold to several different legal entities. Confusion arose after public statements by one of the directors of Live Events, which claimed that all debts would be settled.¬†Now, the Supreme Court of Iceland is taking up the case. Central to the case is whether the statement in question was general in nature, or whether it constituted a binding contract. The Supreme Court has taken up the case partly because it believes that the case will have broader importance in setting precedent in cases of payment obligation with multiple debtors.

headline: Polish Deputy Minister: Support Language Learning in Both Nations
body: While on an official visit to Iceland, Polish deputy minister Szymon Szynkowski vel Sek voiced his approval for mutual language learning in both nations. According to the deputy minister, Polish children should be able to learn their mother tongue in Iceland, but Icelandic should also be offered at a university level in Poland. Poles constitute a large portion of the immigrant population in Iceland. According to Statistics Iceland, some 20,500 Poles claimed residency in Iceland in 2021, comprising nearly 40% of the immigrant population and over 5% of the total population. As such, Poland and Iceland have a very important relationship. There are, however, fears that not all Polish immigrants have had the opportunity to properly integrate into Icelandic society. Increased language education in both countries could be a way to better integrate Polish immigrants into Icelandic society. In a public address, the deputy minister stated that Icelandic was already offered at Jagiellonian University in Krak√≥w, and that there were plans to extend Icelandic education to the University of Gda≈Ñsk. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs one of the things we‚Äôve done to show that we take our relationship with Iceland very seriously,‚Äù he stated. Mr. Szynkowski vel Sek also noted the need for more Polish-Icelandic translators, saying that as the connection between the two nations has become so significant, it is important to have specialists with good command of both languages.

headline: Valdimar J√≥hannsson‚Äôs Lamb Sweeps Edda Awards
body: Valdimar J√≥hansson‚Äôs 2021 film, Lamb, swept the Edda awards, which took place this Sunday September 18. Nominated in 13 categories, the folk horror film took home a total a 12 awards, including film of the year, director of the year (Valdimar J√≥hannsson) and screenplay of the year (Valdimar J√≥hannsson and Sj√≥n). The Edda Prize is awarded annually by the Icelandic Film and Television Academy since 1999. Under consideration this year were 154 television works, 10 films, 13 documentaries, and 15 entries for youth media. Icelandic filmmaker √ûr√°inn Bertelsson was also recognized for his work in cinema. √ûr√°inn is best known for his films¬†J√≥n Oddur & J√≥n Bjarni (1981), Dalal√≠f (1984), Skammdegi (1985), and Magn√∫s¬†(1989). He has since been active in journalism and politics. At the award ceremony, √ûr√°inn stated: ‚ÄúI am extremely grateful that I somehow managed to work only on things that I was interested in. Everything I do, I do for fun and hopefully for someone else too.‚Äù Iceland‚Äôs contribution to the 2022 Oscars was also selected at the award ceremony,¬†Berdreymi¬†(Beautiful Beings), by director Gu√∞mundur Arnar Gu√∞mundsson. The film concerns a troubled teenage boy with a difficult home who befriends a bullied child at school. According to the jury, the film ‚Äúis a haunting story that is presented with calmness and consideration [‚Ä¶] The tone, spirit, and feel of the narrative exploits the potential of the form in a remarkable way, resulting in a raw and powerful cinematic experience.‚Äù Gu√∞mundur is also known for his 2016 film, Hjartasteinn¬†(Heartstone). Read more: Of Lamb and Legends (for subscribers) ¬†

headline: Against the Ice Receives Half a Billion in Production Rebate
body: The State Treasury reimbursed ISK 500,000,000 [$3.58 million; ‚Ç¨3.58 million] in production costs for Against the Ice, an historical survival epic produced for Netflix by Icelandic director Baltasar Korm√°kur. R√öV reports that this is one of the largest film and television production reimbursements that the government has ever made‚Äîon par with the ISK 500,000,000 received by Fast 8 in 2017. Two other productions, the TV series Washington Black and Stella Blomkvist, also received substantial reimbursements: ISK 217 million [$1.55 million; ‚Ç¨1.55 million] and ISK 170 million [$1.22 million; ‚Ç¨1.22 million], respectively. See Also: True Detective Series Will Be Largest-Ever Foreign Investment in Icelandic Culture All of these reimbursements pale in comparison, however, to the one that will be made for the production of the fourth season of HBO‚Äôs True Detective, which will film over nine months in Iceland with a budget of around ISK 9 billion [$64.8 million; ‚Ç¨63.9 million]. Per the Icelandic Film Center‚Äôs reimbursement scheme, ‚ÄúProducers can apply for reimbursements from the State Treasury of 25% of the costs incurred in the production of films and television programs in Iceland, or 35% for production projects that meet given conditions.‚Äù Based on a true story, Against the Ice is set in 1909 and follows two men‚Äôs trek across the Greenland ice cap to recover the records of the ill-fated Denmark expedition, which set out years before to chart the geography of Greenland. Beset by troubles of their own, the pair must survive in the Arctic while waiting for rescue that may never come. The film was directed by Peter Flinth, and stars Nikolaj Coster-Waldau (Game of Thrones) and Joe Cole (Peaky Blinders). The film was shot predominantly in Iceland, although some filming was done in Greenland as well.

headline: Reykjav√≠k International Film Festival Launches Despite Decrease in Funding
body: The Reykjav√≠k International Film Festival (RIFF) will be beginning its 19th season this September 29th. However, the scope of the event will be slightly pulled back this year, given recent cuts in public funding to the arts. RIFF has become a centre of the film scene in Iceland is recent years, spotlighting lesser-known international directors. Despite the decline in funding, some 70 films will be featured from 59 nations. Especially prevalent this year will be short-form films, with some 207 short films featured. Additionally, a special emphasis is being placed this year on women in filmmaking, with a majority of the featured films directed by female directors. In a drive to reduce the environmental impact of RIFF, the use of printed materials such as programmes and posters will be reduced. Instead of programmes, RIFF is launching an app this year to help reduce paper waste. Movie-goers will be able to access the programme schedule, in addition to buy tickets and find other information about the screenings. Several films will be making their world premiere at this year‚Äôs RIFF, such as Icelandic director Sigurj√≥n Sighvatsson‚Äôs Exxtinction Emergency, a documentary about the Extinction Rebellion environmental movement. RIFF has also been known for untraditional screenings, including drive-in car screenings and pool screening at Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs swimming facilities. This year RIFF will also feature a glacial screening inside Langj√∂kull, where Lars Ostenfeld‚Äôs documentary Into the Ice will be shown. According to a press release from RIFF, this represents ‚Äúa unique opportunity to understand and perceive the power of filmmaking in the natural setting of the film‚Äôs subject.‚Äù ¬†

headline: True Detective Series Will Be Largest-Ever Foreign Investment in Icelandic Culture
body: The upcoming series of HBO Max television show True Detective will be filmed in Iceland over a 9-month period for a budget of around ISK 9 billion [$64.8 million; ‚Ç¨63.9 million]. The project entails the largest-ever foreign investment in culture in Iceland‚Äôs history. Minister of Culture Lilja D√∂gg Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir says the project is proof that government initiatives are helping put Iceland‚Äôs film industry on the map. While it will be filmed in Iceland, the fourth season of True Detective is in fact set in Alaska, where the story follows detectives Liz Danvers (played by Jodie Foster) and Evangeline Navarro (Kali Reis) as they investigate the disappearance of six men from a research station. True Detective has received praise from critics and audiences ‚Äì and won five Emmy Awards. Iceland‚Äôs government recently raised the repayment for production costs for films and TV series shot in the country from 25% to 35%. Iceland‚Äôs Culture Minister Lilja Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir presented this and other initiatives to members of the film and music industry on a recent trip to Los Angeles. ‚ÄúI feel a lot of support here in Los Angeles with the initiatives we have been implementing in the last year or so to promote creative industries in Iceland,‚Äù Lilja stated. ‚ÄúThe True Detective project is the largest foreign investment in the field of culture in Iceland‚Äôs history. With a clear vision and multifaceted actions, we are succeeding in making our country a highly respected partner in the world of cinema. International film companies are ready to invest in bigger, longer-term projects than they did. It is a huge victory for Icelandic culture and economy and confirmation that what the government is doing matters.‚Äù

headline: Prime Minister Pens Crime Novel with Ragnar J√≥nasson
body: Best-selling author Ragnar J√≥nasson and Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir have co-authored a crime novel together, R√öV reports. The book will be called Reykjav√≠k. This may seem an unlikely detour for the Prime Minister, but Katr√≠n actually wrote her undergraduate thesis on Icelandic crime novels. She and Ragnar have, moreover, been planning their collaboration for some time. Two years ago, Katr√≠n mentioned that the pair would be co-authoring a book together, but COVID scuppered those plans‚Äîat least temporarily. A year ago, however, Ragnar confirmed that they‚Äôd started writing. Reykjav√≠k is set in 1986 and deals with the disappearance of a young girl named L√°ra Marteinsd√≥ttir from V√≠√∞ey, a small island located in Kollafj√∂r√∞ur Bay just off the capital‚Äôs coastline, some 30 years previous. For decades, L√°ra‚Äôs disappearance has weighed heavily on the Icelandic nation, but no concrete explanation of her disappearance has ever been furnished. That is, until a young reporter starts digging into the cold case with startling consequences. ‚ÄúIn this story, Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir and I are going to invite readers on a journey back to the summer when Reykjav√≠k celebrated its 200th birthday, when Bylgjan and St√∂√∞ 2 [Iceland‚Äôs first privately-owned radio and TV stations] first started broadcasting, and Reagan and Gorbachev‚Äôs Reykjav√≠k Summit was just around the corner,‚Äù wrote Ragnar in a Facebook post about the book on Friday. ‚ÄúAnd that summer is also when unexpected clues about L√°ra‚Äôs fate come to light.‚Äù Reykjav√≠k is set to be released in Iceland on October 25.

headline: Reykjav√≠k Art Shows Cancelled Over Noise Complaints
body: An art and concert venue in Skerjafj√∂r√∞ur has been forced by city authorities to cease holding events after persistent noise complaints from local residents, reports V√≠sir. The venue, called T√≥ma R√Ωmi√∞, or Empty Space, is managed by the art collective, Kl√∫bburinn. The collective leased the space from the City of Reykjav√≠k through the art initiative Skapandi Borg, which seeks to promote the arts in Reykjav√≠k. According to the group, it was understood at the time of signing that the space would be used for concerts. As such, they claim it is unfair for the city to prevent them from using the space as it was intended. In the last two years, the old bar as hosted numerous shows, raves, and theater productions, and members of Kl√∫bburinn are fighting to keep the venue alive. In a statement to V√≠sir, Diego Manatrizio, event manager for the collective, said: ‚ÄúI think this is a unique place in the art scene.¬†We provide a space for many projects that could probably not find a place anywhere else, projects that are first presented here.‚Äù However, not all agree, and the City of Reykjav√≠k also claims that the art group never applied for the necessary permits to hold events. Local residents are also unhappy with the venue, saying that the shows last too late into the night and are far too noisy. The art collective, however, has expressed the desire to improve conditions to be able to continue using the space. Birnir J√≥n Sigur√∞sson, a member of the collective, stated that they took the complaints seriously and were ready to make changes. However, he said, ‚ÄúIf we don‚Äôt get help from the city, we‚Äôll have to close the business.‚Äù

headline: Professor Emeritus Speaks to Need for Better Icelandic Education
body: Eir√≠kur R√∂gnvaldsson, Professor Emeritus at H√°sk√≥li √çslands, has recently expressed the need for better Icelandic education in an interview with V√≠sir. Eir√≠kur stated that foreign labour is projected to play a larger role in Iceland‚Äôs economy in the coming years, and that it is imperative to provide immigrants with more opportunities to learn Icelandic. Specifically, he fears that Iceland‚Äôs workforce may split into an Icelandic-speaking overclass with an English-speaking underclass in the service, restaurant, and hotel industries. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs quite clear that if we want to continue the Icelandic language, then we have to do something,‚Äù Eir√≠kur stated. Additionally, he called for more and better teaching materials and courses to be offered to foreign workers. ‚ÄúIt must be possible for people to study Icelandic during working hours and so on,‚Äù he said. He has been critical of Icelandic prescriptivists in the past, saying that an image of a pristine Icelandic language that does not change with the times and Iceland‚Äôs shifting demographics cannot be continued. Eir√≠kur has also called for the need for more openness in the Icelandic language community, saying that it is too easy for foreigners to revert to English, and not integrate themselves into life in Iceland. Eir√≠kur is also active as the moderator of a popular Facebook page, M√°lspjall, in which Icelanders discuss grammar, innovation, and other current issues with the Icelandic language and its evolution. On Icelandic language education and policy, read more of our coverage here.

headline: Nammigate: Danish Neocolonists Appropriate Beloved Icelandic Liquorice
body: The Danes are at it again: not content with centuries of exploitation, trade domination, and the impoverishment of the Icelandic people, the Danes have perhaps committed their greatest crime against our island nation in recent weeks by claiming a beloved Icelandic tradition as their own. ‚ÄúThey were told that it couldn‚Äôt be done‚Äù hahahahEins og einhver v√≠sindama√∞ur hafi arka√∞ inn sveittur og stressa√∞ur ‚ÄúNEI EKKI BLANDA √û√Å TVO SAMAN √ûA√ê ER EINFALDLEGA EKKI H√ÜGT‚Äù https://t.co/50XOcVCGZO The controversy came to light when actor and comedian Vilhelm Neto brought the above post to light from Danish company, Lakrids by B√ºlow. The original post claimed that despite the limits of modern confectionary technology, Danish researchers were nevertheless able to combine the two sweets to make something entirely new: chocolate-coated liquorice. Stating that he was ‚Äúall in‚Äù to ‚Äústart drama‚Äù with Denmark, Vilhelm Neto critiqued the Danish confectioners: ‚ÄúAs if¬† some scientist barged in, sweaty and nervous, and said: ‚ÄòNo, you can‚Äôt put the two together! It‚Äôs simply not possible!'‚Äù¬† As most visitors to Iceland will know, liquorice is a mainstay in most sweets, with chocolate-covered liquorice being especially beloved. P√©tur Thor Gunnarsson, managing director of the Icelandic confectioner Freyja,¬†set the record straight in a statement to V√≠sir. ‚ÄúThese Danes are taking our honour,‚Äù he stated. ‚ÄúAlready in 1984, our product called Draumur was on the market. This was the first of its kind.‚Äù Draumur is one of Freyja‚Äôs most popular candy bars, consisting of two parallel straws of liquorice covered in milk chocolate.¬† Since the release of Draumur, numerous other liquorce-chocolate sweets have been introduced to the market in Iceland. According to original research by Iceland Review‚Äôs reporters, the Icelandic confections required relatively little research and development before hitting the market.

headline: Sixteen-Year-Old Admitted to Prestigious San Francisco Ballet School
body: Sixteen-year-old ballet dancer Logi Gu√∞mundsson has been admitted to the prestigious San Francisco Ballet School in the US this fall. R√öV reports that Logi has been offered a full scholarship to attend the school. Logi was inspired to start dancing ballet after seeing a production of Billy Elliott at the Reykjav√≠k City Theatre when he was eight years old. He‚Äôs dedicated himself to his craft ever since, practicing six days a week, doing intense stretches every night, and focusing, in particular, on agility. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really demanding. You‚Äôre always practicing, always [trying to] do better than last time,‚Äù he told an interviewer before demonstrating a front split. (He uses a block under his front ankle, he said, to help him be able to stretch even more.) Intense as his practice is, however, Logi always saves Sundays to spend time with friends and enjoy non-dance-related activities. Logi was offered a place at the school after Helgi T√≥masson, the artistic director and principal choreographer for the San Francisco Ballet, invited him to participate in a course there this summer. ‚ÄúThe San Francisco Ballet School is one of the best in the world,‚Äù said Gu√∞mundur Helgason, principal of the Icelandic Ballet Academy. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really hard to get into a school like that. I‚Äôm incredibly proud of [Logi] and look forward to see what comes of this.‚Äù

headline: Of Time and Water Longlisted for National Translation Award in the US
body: Of Time and Water, written by Andri Sn√¶r Magnason and translated by Lytton Smith, has been longlisted for the National Translation Award (NTA) in the US. The NTA is awarded for English translations of both prose and poetry and is administered by the American Literary Translators Association (ALTA). Per the press release, it ‚Äúthe only is the only national award for translated fiction, poetry, and literary nonfiction that includes a rigorous examination of both the source text and its relation to the finished English work.‚Äù The NTA has been awarded for 24 years, with separate awards for prose and poetry given for the last eight. The winning translators in each category will each receive a $2,500 cash prize. Of Time and Water is one of 12 titles to be nominated for this year‚Äôs NTA in prose. Other nominees include The Morning Star by Karl Ove Knausgaard and translated from Norwegian by Martin Aitken, Billy Wilder on Assignment: Dispatches from Weimar Berlin and Interwar Vienna by Billy Wilder and translated from German by Shelley Frisch, In Case of Emergency by Mahsa Mohebali and translated from Persian/Farsi by Mariam Rahmani, and Harsh Times by Mario Vargas Llosa translated from Spanish by Adrian Nathan West. Of Time and Water captured the judges‚Äô attention for its ability to make the enormity of the climate crisis seem both tangible and tackleable. In their nomination, they write: ‚ÄúWhile the devastations of our climate crisis are measurable, statistics have failed to adequately motivate change. An acclaimed writer and environmental activist makes its scale and scope tangible by sharing tales of his grandparents, Icelandic citizen scientists whose honeymoon was spent surveying the Vatnajokull glacier, when ‚Äúglaciers were a symbol of something great and eternal, like oceans, mountains, and clouds.‚Äù Now Vatnajokull is dying. Weaving together family history, folklore, and glaciology, the book attempts a ‚Äòmythology of the present‚Äô that might inspire the action required to deflect the most horrific Anthropocene destruction. Ably translated by Lytton Smith, Magnason follows his role models, the Dalai Lama and conservationist John Thorbjarnarson, in communicating perilous urgency with unflagging friendliness.‚Äù Translator Lytton Smith is a professor of English and Creative Writing at SUNY Geneseo in New York, as well as poet. He has translated numerous works from Icelandic, including Children of the Reindeer Woods by Krist√≠n √ìmarsd√≥ttir, The Ambassador by Bragi √ìlafsson, History. A Mess. by Sigr√∫n P√°lsd√≥ttir, T√≥mas J√≥nsson, Bestseller by Gu√∞bergur Bergsson, and J√≥n Gnarr‚Äôs three-part autobiography, The Indian, The Pirate, and The Outlaw. In 2019, he received a Translation Fellowship from the National Endowment for the Arts. A former candidate for president and an outspoken environmental activist, Andri Sn√¶r Magnason is the author of numerous books, including fiction for children and adults, long-form nonfiction, and poetry. Of Time and Water was shortlisted for the 2021 Nordic Council Literature Prize. The NTA winners will be announced in a virtual ceremony on October 6.

headline: ‚ÄúIceland‚Äôs Settlers Were Not Vikings‚Äù
body: ‚ÄúVikings were never anything more than gangs, just like the criminal gangs of today,‚Äù stated Ethnologist √Årni Bj√∂rnsson in a recent TV interview for St√∂√∞ 2. √Årni criticised the National Museum of Iceland, his former workplace, for hosting ‚ÄúViking battles‚Äù as part of Reykjav√≠k Culture Night earlier this month, saying Iceland‚Äôs historical ties to Vikings are limited at best ‚Äì and that Vikings are nothing worth glorifying. ‚ÄúFor over 100 years, it has been trendy in the European and North American entertainment industries to refer to everyone who lived in the Nordic countries in the High Middle Ages as Vikings. That is of course far from the truth. Residents of the Nordic countries were of course first and foremost farmers and fishermen,‚Äù √Årni explained. Vikings are, however, mentioned more often in sources, ‚Äújust like international news today is more likely to mention terrorist acts.‚Äù Both the National Museum and the Settlement Exhibition hosted Viking-themed events for Reykjav√≠k Culture Night. √Årni explains that the idea that Icelanders are the descendants of Vikings is largely the product of 19th-century foreign authors, who romanticised this idea in their work: the idea has no historical basis. ‚ÄúViolence has always held a certain charm. People enjoy reading crime novels, and they enjoy making up Viking stories. But I think that a public institution that wants to be taken seriously shouldn‚Äôt take part in that. I find that unacceptable, because what is Iceland‚Äôs connection to Vikings? Iceland‚Äôs settlers were not Vikings. Vikings didn‚Äôt come to Iceland, except a few elderly, exhausted ones.‚Äù One of Iceland‚Äôs most respected ethnologists, √Årni was the Director of the National Museum‚Äôs Ethnology Department between 1969 and 2002. He has written and published some 20 books, as well as countless articles and radio segments on Icelandic traditions and cultural history and holds a PhD in Ethnology from the University of Iceland.

headline: Andrey Kurkov Wins the Halld√≥r Laxness International Literature Prize
body: Ukrainian author Andrey Kurkov is the recipient of the 2022 Halld√≥r Laxness International Literature Prize, R√öV reports. The prize, which includes a purse of ‚Ç¨15,000 [ISK 2.1 million; $ 14,946] is awarded to internationally recognized authors who have contributed to ‚Äúa renewal of the narrative tradition,‚Äù which were the grounds for Halld√≥r Laxness receiving the Nobel Prize himself in 1955. One of Ukraine‚Äôs best-known novelists and the president of PEN Ukraine, Kurkov will receive the award in person at the University of Iceland on September 7. The award will be presented by Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir, after which, the author will deliver a lecture in English. The award ceremony will be followed by a reading with other authors at I√∞n√≥ in the evening. Kurkov is the author of 19 novels, including the wildly successful and satirical Death and the Penguin, which has been translated into more than 30 languages, and 2020‚Äôs Grey Bees, which is set in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine and details ‚Äúhis country‚Äôs past struggles with Russia.‚Äù This year, he‚Äôll publish a book of his own personal diary entries, which he started writing on the eve of the Russian invasion. He‚Äôs also written nine books for children, numerous documentary and TV scripts, and recorded an eight-part audio series for the BBC called ‚ÄúLetter from Ukraine,‚Äù detailing life in the country during the current war. The Halld√≥r Laxness International Literature Prize has been awarded since 2019. English novelist Ian McEwan was the first recipient, followed by Turkish novelist and activist Elif Shafak. Shafak was part of the selection committee for this year‚Äôs award, along with journalist Egill Helgason, of the books and literary criticism TV programme Kiljan, and director of the Reykjav√≠k International Literature Festival Stella Soff√≠a J√≥hannesd√≥ttir.

headline: Pussy Riot to Perform at National Theatre
body: The Russian protest and performance art group Pussy Riot will perform at Iceland‚Äôs National Theatre in November, R√öV reports. Theatre director Magn√∫s Geir √û√≥r√∞arson said the piece will be part play, part art exhibition, and part concert, and is being staged in conjunction with the group‚Äôs first retrospective, which will also open in November at Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs Kling & Bang exhibition space. ‚ÄúThis is, of course, a remarkable group that we all know and have followed in the media in recent years. This is a band and a performance art group, a political force, that came here in the spring and worked at the National Theatre to prepare a show that they‚Äôve been touring around Europe this summer and which has been very well-received, with great reviews,‚Äù said Magn√∫s Geir. Co-founder disguised herself as a food courier to escape house arrest Staunch critics of Russian President Vladimir Putin and feminists who have called for the liberation and equality of women and the LGBTQIA+ community, the members of Pussy Riot have endured significant political persecution. Three of the founding members served jail time for performing their ‚ÄúPunk Prayer‚Äù in Moscow‚Äôs Cathedral of Christ the Saviour, in protest of the Russian Orthodox Church‚Äôs close ties to Putin. Placed under house arrest, co-founder Maria (Masha) Alyokhina disguised herself as a food courier and fled both her home and the country in May of this year. Having had her passport confiscated and been placed on Russia‚Äôs ‚ÄúWanted‚Äù list, Alyokhina initially had trouble crossing the Russian border, but Deutsche Welle reports that with the help of Icelandic performance artist Ragnar Kjartansson, she was ‚Äúable to obtain European documents, allowing her to enter Lithuania.‚Äù Ragnar has been an effusive supporter of the group and their work. ‚ÄúPussy Riot‚Äôs performances are, without a doubt, some of the most important political art works of the 21st century,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf ever there were artists who gave everything for their art, it‚Äôs these badasses. The exhibition is centered around Masha‚Äôs story and her description of the hell that is Putin‚Äôs Russia.‚Äù

headline: Sail from Sweden to Iceland to Mark 250th Anniversary of Scientific Expedition
body: The year 2022 marks 250 years since the Swedish botanist Daniel Solander made a scientific expedition to Iceland. To commemorate the expedition, the Embassy of Sweden has collaborated with Icelandic partners to organise a sailing trip, an art exhibition, workshops, nature walks, and other projects that will be held at over 30 locations across Iceland over the next one and a half years. ‚ÄúTogether Iceland and Sweden continue a dialogue on history, biology, geology, anthropology and culture which has spanned over many centuries. The project deals with our common past, present and future,‚Äù Sweden‚Äôs Ambassador to Iceland P√§r Ahlberger told Iceland Review. ‚ÄúI am very grateful to the Government of Iceland and our more than 30 Icelandic partners for the very generous support to this, the most comprehensive Swedish ‚Äì Icelandic project ever.‚Äù Daniel Solander (1733-1782) was a Swedish naturalist who studied under celebrated professor of botany Carl Linnaeus. He travelled as far as Australia and New Zealand for scientific expeditions, where he helped make and describe collections of plants from various regions. Solander visited Iceland in 1772. A travelogue from the expedition, Letters on Iceland, first published in 1777, is available in full on the Icelandic National Library website. One of the cornerstones of the commemorative project is the art exhibition Solander 250: Br√©f fr√° √çslandi (e. Solander 250: Letters from Iceland), which features the work of ten Icelandic artists who contribute with their perspectives of Daniel Solander‚Äôs expedition to Iceland. The exhibition opens in Hafnarborg gallery in the town of Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur on August 27, but will travel to nine other locations in Iceland over the coming 18 months. The exhibition Paradise Lost ‚Äì Daniel Solander‚Äôs Legacy, first exhibited in New Zealand and Australia in 2019-2021 and focusing on the first encounter between Sweden and the Pacific Region, will be shown across Iceland alongside Br√©f fr√° √çslandi. Other events that will be part of the commemorative project include musical performances and educational events.

headline: MATEY Seafood Fest Serves Up the Best of the Westman Islands
body: A new festival seeks to celebrate the produce and producers of Iceland‚Äôs Westman Islands. The MATEY Seafood Festival is a collaborative project between the island‚Äôs restaurateurs and food producers¬†and will take place from September 8-10. Restaurants, fish factories, food producers and other food industry service partners collaborate to highlight the food of the islands. With the MATEY festival, islanders hope to spotlight ‚Äúone of the best culinary destinations in Iceland,‚Äù and give guests a taste of ‚Äúa variety of stunning dishes‚Äù that are made solely with ingredients sourced in and around the Westmans. Leading chefs from neighbouring Nordic nations will also take part in the festival, offering their own twists on ‚Äúauthentic local dishes.‚Äù Restaurants Gott, Slippurinn, Einsi Kaldi, and N√¶s will host menus from guest chefs Chris Golding, Leif S√∏rensen, Ron McKinlay, and Fj√∂lla Sheholli and Junaid Juman, respectively, serving up local ingredients. In addition to serving up local cuisine in Heimaey‚Äôs restaurants, the festival will also feature events in which businesses in seafood industry open their doors, give some insight into their operations, and discuss the ‚Äúblue economy‚Äù that is so vital to the Westmans‚Äô way of life.

headline: Bj√∂rk Announces New Album: Fossora
body: Bj√∂rk has announced that she will be releasing a new album, her tenth, this fall. The revelation comes via a wide-ranging interview in The Guardian. The album will be called Fossora, ‚Äúthe feminine version of the Latin word for digger,‚Äù and anchored by the two ‚Äúlodestones‚Äù of bass clarinet and gabber, a style of Dutch techno that came out of The Netherlands in the 90s. Interviewer Chal Ravens describes Fossora as a reaction to 2017‚Äôs Utopia and says the album features ‚Äúmoments of astonishing virtuosity and bewildering complexity, and, like much of her recent music, a resistance to easy melody.‚Äù The new album is, in a way, a product of the COVID and the space and time that lockdown gave Bj√∂rk to explore and develop new songs and sounds. But it‚Äôs also reflective of ‚Äúa transitional time,‚Äù in the singer‚Äôs life, says Ravens, with songs that in one instance, honour the passing of her mother and in another, serve as a kind of farewell to her youngest child, √çsad√≥ra, who recently moved out of her home. (Both √çsad√≥ra and Bj√∂rk‚Äôs son Sindri provide backing vocals on that track, called ‚ÄúHer Mother‚Äôs House.‚Äù) There will be a fantastical quality to Fossora, Bj√∂rk explained, but also an earthiness. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs see what it‚Äôs like when you walk into this fantasy and, you know, have a lunch and fart and do normal things, like meet your friends,‚Äù she said to Ravens, while also describing Fossora in an email to the Indonesian duo of Gabber Modus Operandi as her ‚Äúmushroom album.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like digging a hole in the ground,‚Äù she wrote to the pair. ‚ÄúThis time, I‚Äôm living with moles and really grounding myself.‚Äù Fossora will be out on One Little Independent Records this fall. Read Bj√∂rk‚Äôs full interview in The Guardian here.

headline: No Deadline for Decision on Whether Gylfi √û√≥r Sigur√∞sson Will Be Prosecuted in UK
body: The Office of the Crown Prosecutor in the UK is currently reviewing evidence against Icelandic footballer Gylfi √û√≥r Sigur√∞sson and deciding whether it will pursue prosecution against the former Everton midfielder or drop the matter entirely, R√öV reports. Gylfi √û√≥r has been accused of ‚Äúmultiple sexual offenses‚Äù and has been subject to a travel ban that has prevented him from leaving the UK since being arrested at his home in Manchester in July 2021. Responding to an inquiry from R√öV, Nazia Dewji, a spokesperson for the Office of the Crown Prosecutor, said that there was no set deadline by which a decision on the matter must be made. Dewji said that the evidence from the police investigation had been received by the prosecutor at the end of January. Gylfi √û√≥r was released on bail shortly after his arrest, but has not played in a professional football match since then. He was taken off the active roster for the Premier League team Everton and his contract was not renewed when it ran out last summer. He has not played with the Icelandic Men‚Äôs National Team since then either. In October 2022, Gylfi √û√≥r‚Äôs father Sigur√∞ur A√∞alsteinsson, gave an interview in which he called on the Icelandic government to come to his son‚Äôs assistance. The case had been dragged on for far longer than legally reasonable, he argued. ‚ÄúIf someone is detained in some [other] country for some hypothetical offense, you can‚Äôt just let him languish there for a year, year and a half just endlessly waiting,‚Äù he said. At the time, the footballer‚Äôs family hoped to change Gylfi √û√≥r‚Äôs legal domicile to Iceland so as to make it harder for the British judiciary to extend his travel ban. It was the first time that anyone close to Gylfi √û√≥r had confirmed that any such travel ban existed.

headline: Deep North Episode 10: First Among Equals
body: Every weekday morning at the public pool in West Reykjav√≠k (Vesturb√¶jarlaug), Halld√≥r Bergmann ‚Äì called D√≥ri ‚Äì slips into his grey, square leg suit and declares that he shall swim 1,800 metres (1.1 miles). He is 68 years old, and, also, a great mangler of the truth. He swims only 200 metres (660 feet), on a good day, but does not like the facts getting in the way of a good time ‚Äì and this may be his best quality: his penchant for childlike embellishment. It‚Äôs this trait, above any else, perhaps, that has won over a troop of loyal followers, and why those followers have, in the spirit of his own whimsy, taken to calling him ‚Äúthe Commander.‚Äù In the latest episode of Deep North, we consider Icelandic swimming pool culture and ask: is the public swimming pool a wellspring of social democracy?

headline: Iceland Leaves 2023 Handball Championship with a Victory
body: The Iceland Men‚Äôs National Handball team went out in style yesterday with a 41-37 victory over Brazil. Unfortunately, Iceland will not be moving past Group II, where it won a place after its initial seeding into Group D. Iceland will be leaving this world championship with a total of three victories and two losses, and a total goal difference of +11.  Brazil led the way in the first half of the final match, with the score standing at 22-18 at halftime. However, the Icelanders managed to make up the difference in the final 10 minutes of the game, with Bjarki M√°r, Janus Da√∞i, and Kristj√°n √ñrn leading in goals. In an interview with R√öV, Icelandic Men‚Äôs Nation coach Gu√∞mundur Gu√∞mundsson said: ‚ÄúWe took a good long look at how we were doing and had to really zero in on the goal and make a comeback with that old Icelandic pride. [‚Ä¶] The second half will be remembered for a long time since we won it 23-15. It was really just fantastically well played.‚Äù

headline: Icelandic Handball Fans Banned from Using Drums
body: Supports of the Icelandic team at the 2023 World Men‚Äôs Handball Championship in Sweden have been banned from using drums in the Gautaborg stadium, Morgunbla√∞i√∞ reports. In a statement to Morgunbla√∞i√∞, Gauti Sigurgeirsson, a member of the Icelandic national team fan club, said: ‚ÄúThe Swedish handball association won‚Äôt let us have drums in the stands at the stadium [‚Ä¶] But we‚Äôre sticking to our plan. We‚Äôre going to the stadium and doing everything we can to support the Icelandic national team, with or without our drums. It just doesn‚Äôt make sense that all of a sudden we‚Äôre not allowed to have any instruments.‚Äù Icelandic fans have so far been happy with the accommodations at the 2023 World Men‚Äôs Handball Championship. The championship is being hosted in nine cities throughout both Poland and Sweden. Matches hosted in the Swedish city of Kristianstad, such as the opening match between Iceland and Portugal, allowed fans to support their team with instruments.  Now, fans of the national team are disappointed but determined to continue rooting for ‚Äúour boys,‚Äù as they are affectionately known. While instruments are not allowed in the general stands, however, a special balcony is reserved in the Gautaborg stadium, where the Icelandic fans can drum to their hearts‚Äô content. Gauti continued to say to Morgunbla√∞i√∞: ‚ÄúIt was just great in Kristianstad. It‚Äôs a great town. We got to do everything we wanted and it went really went, but everything changed in Gautaborg. We weren‚Äôt allowed to bring any of our instruments when we played Sweden, which definitely has an effect on the support. But we just used our hands and voices instead.‚Äù ¬† ¬†

headline: Former National Team Captain Sara Bj√∂rk Wins Maternity Rights Case
body: Sara Bj√∂rk Gunnarsd√≥ttir, recently retired captain of the Women‚Äôs National Football Team, has won her maternity case against former club and employer Olympique Lyonnais. During her time at the prestigious French football club, she became the first Icelander to score in the finals of a Champions League match, among other achievements. After becoming pregnant in 2021, however, she ran up against cultural expectations within professional sports that discourage athletes from having children during the height of their careers.¬† Sara Bj√∂rk arranged with her club to return to Iceland for the duration of her pregnancy, with the understanding that she would return to the team after giving birth. However, Lyon soon began withholding her pay. When it became clear the withheld pay was part of a pattern, Sara Bj√∂rk pressed claims against Lyon. Now, she has been awarded the back pay, plus interest, in a landmark case of maternity rights in professional sports. Sara Bjork Gunnarsdottir‚Äôs landmark ruling against former club Olympique Lyonnais sends a clear message to clubs and footballers worldwide:The strict application of maternity rights is enforceable.üîó https://t.co/SmInzY0xBs pic.twitter.com/aXd4zbazFm Sara Bj√∂rk now plays for the Italian club Juventus.¬† A full account of her pregnancy and subsequent battle with Lyon can be read here. In a statement on social media, Sara Bj√∂rk said: ‚ÄúThis is not ‚Äòjust business.‚Äô This is about my rights as a worker, as a woman and as a human being.‚Äù¬†

headline: New National Stadium to Cost ISK 14.2 Billion
body: It will cost an estimated ISK 14.2 billion [$99.8 million; ‚Ç¨92.1 million] to build Iceland‚Äôs new national stadium, R√öV reports. The overall cost of the project is to be split between the state and the City of Reykjav√≠k, but it has yet to be determined how the expense will be divided. See Also: Location Chosen for New National Stadium The new stadium, intended to be ready for use by 2025, will be 19,000 sq m and accommodate 8,600 people for sporting events and 12,000 people for concerts. It will have facilities for handball and volleyball matches, basketball and football games, and more.

headline: Captain Sara Bj√∂rk Retires from Iceland‚Äôs National Team
body: Footballer Sara Bj√∂rk Gunnarsd√≥ttir has decided to retire from the women‚Äôs national football team. Sara Bj√∂rk, who‚Äôs served as captain for nearly a decade, made the announcement on social media this morning. In a post on her Instagram page this morning, footballer Sara Bj√∂rk Gunnarsd√≥ttir announced that she was retiring from the women‚Äôs national football team. As noted by V√≠sir, Sara Bj√∂rk has played for the national team for sixteen years and holds the record for most games (145); she played her first match with the national team against Slovenia in August of 2007 ‚Äì when she had yet to celebrate her seventeenth birthday. Read More: Iceland Review Profiles Sara Bj√∂rk in 2021 Sara Bj√∂rk took over the captain‚Äôs armband from Katr√≠n J√≥nsd√≥ttir almost a decade ago and is the only Icelander to have scored in a Champion‚Äôs League final ‚Äì and the only Icelandic woman to have lifted the trophy. Sara Bj√∂rk is a four-time Swedish league and cup champion with FC Roseng√•rd (formerly FC Malm√∂), a four-time German league and cup champion with FC Wolfsburg, and Iceland‚Äôs Athlete of the Year in 2018 and 2020 (the only woman to have won twice). Sara does not cite a specific reason why she has decided to leave the national team but states that it has been ‚Äúan absolute pleasure and an honour.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut I know, at this point in my career, that it‚Äôs time to say goodbye. It‚Äôs been a hell of a journey!‚Äù Sara, who has participated in all four European competitions with the Icelandic national team, concluded her announcement by thanking the Icelandic Football Association (√çS√ç) for their cooperation and by wishing the association and the women‚Äôs national team ‚Äúa bright future.‚Äù The announcement in full: ‚ÄúAfter 16 years playing for my country I have decided to stop. For me it‚Äôs been an absolute pleasure and honor but I know at this point in my career it‚Äôs time to say goodbye. It‚Äôs been a hell of a journey! I have always been very proud putting on the blue jersey from day one. Being part of the team that qualified first time in in history for the women‚Äôs euros in 2009 and taking part in four women‚Äôs euros tournaments is something I‚Äôm very proud of! I want to thanks KS√ç , all the coaches, staff members , players and volunteers that shared this journey with me, along with all those great memories during my time!‚Äù

headline: Iceland Beats Portugal in Opening Game of World Championship
body: The men‚Äôs national handball team defeated Portugal in their opening game of the 2023 World Men‚Äôs Handball Championship. Left winger Bjarki M√°r El√≠sson was chosen man of the match by the IHF. The men‚Äôs national handball team took the stage for the World Men‚Äôs Handball Championship, held in Poland and Sweden from 11 to 29 January 2023, yesterday. Iceland started well, gaining a four-goal lead during the 12th minute of the game. Portugal showed spirit, however, and fought back to even the score right before halftime. Read More: Iceland Review Speaks to Gu√∞j√≥n Valur, One of Iceland‚Äôs Most Enduring Handball Stars The second half was similarly tight. The two teams were neck and neck, until the game appeared to swing in Iceland‚Äôs favour during the 42nd minute of the game. Left back F√°bio Magalhaes was shown a red card for a cynical foul against Iceland‚Äôs √ìmar Ingi Magn√∫sson (who was chosen Iceland‚Äôs Athlete of the Year in late December). But Portugal kept pushing. They reduced the deficit to zero goals during the 52nd minute ‚Äì before Iceland pulled away over the final minutes of the game. Final score: 30-26. Iceland‚Äôs players weren‚Äôt the only ones who put in a star performance; the team‚Äôs supporters, who seemed to outnumber the Portuguese, were especially vocal during the game. After the win, the crowd stood up to sing √âg er kominn heim; the players were visibly moved. Iceland will play its second match of the tournament against Hungary tomorrow. Hungary also won their first game of the Championship. Iceland‚Äôs team is predicted to go far in the tournament.

headline: √ìmar Ingi Magn√∫sson Voted Athlete of the Year
body:
Handball player √ìmar Ingi Magn√∫sson has been voted Athlete of the Year for the second year running, R√öV reports. √ìmar Ingi led his team Magdeburg to a German Championship in 2022 and also played a key role for the Icelandic national team at this year‚Äôs European Handball Championships. Each year, the Association of Icelandic Sports Journalists presents its Athlete of the Year award. Yesterday, the honorary title was bestowed upon handballer √ìmar Ingi Magn√∫sson for the second year running. √ìmar Ingi was the top scorer at this year‚Äôs 2022 European Men‚Äôs Handball Championship, which took place between January 13 and January 30. Iceland finished sixth in the tournament, and √ìmar scored 59 goals, twelve more than Denmark‚Äôs Mikkel Hansen. √ìmar Ingi plays right back (right winger) for the German team Magdeburg. This year, he led the team to their first Handball-Bundesliga (HBL) title in 21 years. During the campaign, √ìmar Ingi became the second-highest scoring player in the German league and was voted the league‚Äôs best player by a wide margin. This fall, √ìmar Ingi also helped Magdeburg win the IHF Men‚Äôs Super Globe. Magdeburg currently sits in fourth place in the German league. G√≠sli √ûorgeir Kristj√°nsson, who also plays for the team, received the third most votes in this year‚Äôs selection. As noted by R√öV, this is the eleventh time that a handball player has been voted Athlete of the Year. Aron P√°lmarsson was the last handballer to receive the honorary award in 2012. headline: Location Chosen for New National Sporting Arena
body: The working committee for Iceland‚Äôs new national sporting arena has selected a location for the facility and it‚Äôs hoped that construction will begin at the end of 2023, R√öV reports. If everything goes to plan, the new arena will be ready for use some time in 2025. The new national arena will be built between Laugardalsv√∂llur, the existing arena on the east side of Reykjav√≠k, and Su√∞urlandsbraut. The working committee is currently writing a land-use plan that they expect to complete by March or April. The committee intends to present a detailed justification for the site selection and a report on the scope of construction in mid-December. The next major step for the committee is to determine what the exact dimensions of the facility need to be in order to meet international requirements for hosting national sporting events. Once the square meterage has been established, the committee will be able to provide a reasonably accurate estimate for how much the arena will cost. The expense will be shared by both the city and the national government, although in what proportion is not yet clear.

headline: Ticket to the World Cup Up for Grabs Tonight (Women‚Äôs Football)
body: The women‚Äôs national football team could qualify for the World Cup for the first time in its history. The team faces Portugal in the second round of the qualifying play-offs tonight in Pa√ßos de Ferreira, Portugal It was heartbreak in Utrecht on September 6; aware that a draw would suffice for its first-ever ticket to the World Cup, the women‚Äôs national football team fought hard to keep the score line at 0-0 after regulation time had elapsed ‚Äì despite the patent superiority of the Dutch. During the 91st minute, Dutch forward Esmee Brugts delivered a bullet pass into Iceland‚Äôs box, which sailed past her teammate Stefanie van der Gragt and Icelandic defender Gl√≥d√≠s Perla Vigg√≥sd√≥ttir ‚Äì before winding in the far corner of Iceland‚Äôs goal. It was a painful defeat ‚Äì but all hope wasn‚Äôt lost. The women‚Äôs national team will face off against Portugal in the second and final World-Cup qualifying round at the Estadio Capital do Movel in Pa√ßos de Ferreira, Portugal at 5 PM tonight. A win will secure a historic ticket to the 2023 FIFA World Cup. Speaking to V√≠sir, midfield Dagn√Ω Brynjarsd√≥ttir stated that this would be the team‚Äôs third ‚Äúbig match‚Äù of the year. ‚ÄúWe played against France and the Netherlands and neither of those games went our way. But hopefully, this third game will be different.‚Äù Dagn√Ω hopes that she and her teammates will harness the feeling of losing against France and the Netherlands. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a feeling that we don‚Äôt want to experience again. It‚Äôs up to us to do everything in our power to transform that feeling into something better and more fun.‚Äù Iceland is currently ranked 14th according to FIFA; Portugal is ranked 27th. Nevertheless, Portugal has been in fine form, beating Belgium (ranked 19th) in early October; Turkey and Serbia in September. The 2023 FIFA World Cup will be jointly hosted by Australia and New Zealand: the first time that the tournament will have two host nations. It is scheduled to take place from July 20 to August 20 2023.

headline: Men‚Äôs National Football Team Announced, Captain Reinstated
body:
At a press conference today, Arnar √û√≥r Vi√∞arsson, head coach of the men‚Äôs national football team, introduced his squad for the upcoming fixtures. Former team captain Aron Einar Gunnarsson has been handed the armband again, having not been selected to the team since 2021, R√öV reports, following accusations of sexual misconduct. At a press conference at KS√ç (Football Association of Iceland) headquarters today, Arnar √û√≥r Vi√∞arsson, head coach of the men‚Äôs national football team, announced the squad for the team‚Äôs upcoming fixtures. The team will play a friendly against Venezuela on September 22 before facing off against Albania five days later, in what will be an important match in the Nation‚Äôs League. Notable inclusions in the squad include former captain Aron Einar Gunnarsson, who returns to the team after accusations of sexual assault surfaced in the summer of 2021. The police opened an investigation into the matter September of that year, and when he was left out of the squad a month later, Aron Einar released a public statement accusing KS√ç‚Äôs board of directors of yielding to ‚Äúcancel culture.‚Äù As reported by R√öV, coach Arnar √û√≥r subsequently called for KS√ç and √çS√ç (the National Olympic and Sports Association of Iceland) to set clear rules for which players could be selected to the team. New rules were later established, R√öV notes, which stipulate that players cannot be selected for the national team if they are under police investigation. Aron Einar Gunnarsson is currently eligible for selection as his case was dropped in May. Forward Alfre√∞ Finnbogason, who plays with Lyngby in Denmark, also returns to the team after a near two-year hiatus, following prolonged injury, as do defender Gu√∞laugur Victor P√°lsson and goalkeeper El√≠as Rafn √ìlafsson. Perhaps the most notable exclusion from the team is Albert Gu√∞mundsson; during the press conference, coach Arnar √û√≥r expressed disappointment with Albert‚Äôs attitude during the last international break. ‚ÄúTo me, it‚Äôs a great honour to play for the national team, and that calls for 100% focus, every day, always. You‚Äôre either 100% with us or you‚Äôre not,‚Äù Arnar explained. Brynjar Ingi Bjarnason was also left out of the team; Sverrir Ingi Ingason and Arn√≥r Ingvi Traustason announced that they were unavailable, owing to personal reasons; and J√≥hann Berg Gu√∞mundsson is recovering from a minor injury. headline: Foreign Fisherman Electrocuted by Eystri-Rang√° River
body: South Iceland‚Äôs police report that yeterday, September 6, a foreign fisherman was electrocuted while fishing in the Eystri-Rang√° river. The fisherman was taken to Hvolsv√∂llur for medical care, and has since been transferred to Reykjav√≠k. The man, reported to be in his 60‚Äôs, survived the incident with severe burns, but further details regarding his condition are not known at this time. The original police report can be seen below in a public Facebook post from the South Iceland police. The cause of the incident is attributed to longer-than average fishing gear, which is said to have hit a power line. The fisherman is said to be experienced, but was using a style of telescoping pole that can reach 8-10m in length. This style of rod is uncommon in Iceland, but relatively popular in Spain. As of this time, the origin of the fisherman is unclear. Such incidents are nearly-unheard of in Iceland. Nevertheless. R√öV reports that the power lines in questions may be buried next year to avoid such an incident.

headline: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs the worst country I‚Äôve ever been to‚Äô: Polish Football Player Leaves Iceland, Cites Xenophobia, Discrimination
body: Polish football player Chris Jastrzembski, formerly of UMF Selfoss in South Iceland, joined the team prior to the start of the current season and made 13 league and cup appearances before transferring to Prey Veng in Cambodia last month. V√≠sir reports that Jastrzembski endured repeated xenophobic comments and discrimination on the basis of his nationality while living and working in Iceland. The 25-year-old defender opened up about his experience in Iceland in an interview with the Polish paper Gazeta on Thursday. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the worst country I‚Äôve ever been to,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI will never go back. Many Poles live there and they‚Äôre fine, but my experience of Icelanders is terrible. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend it to anyone. People are sorted into categories there.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe club treated me worse because I have a Polish passport. From day one, those people had no respect for me.‚Äù In the interview, Jastrzembski recalled an incident in which he was putting up scaffolding at the stadium in Selfoss. He was doing so from a ladder that an Icelandic woman was holding for him. ‚ÄúThen the boss came and told her to stop helping me because the wind wasn‚Äôt that strong, and I‚Äôd be fine. The woman left and I fell,‚Äù Jastrzembski said, adding that the woman had felt bad about the accident and he‚Äôd told her not to worry. The supervisor then began speaking to her in Icelandic and she translated what he said for Jastrzembski. According to the woman, what the Icelandic man said was: ‚ÄúTo hell with him. He‚Äôs just a Pole. If he dies, there are plenty of Poles who can take his place.‚Äù ‚ÄòRequested to be released from his contract for personal reasons‚Äô In a Facebook post about Jastrzembski‚Äôs departure from the team in July, the team wrote: ‚ÄúDefender Chris Jastrzembski has played his last game for Selfoss. The player requested to be released from his contract with the club for personal reasons and the club has granted that request. Chris joined the team in the winter and played 13 games this summer and scored one goal. We thank Chris for his time here in Selfoss and wish him the best in his future endeavors.‚Äù Prior to playing for UMF Selfoss, Jastrzembski played in the Faroe Islands, Germany, and for Poland‚Äôs national youth football team.

headline: Organizers Shovel Snow from Mountain Path in Advance of Summer Trail Running Event
body: The S√∫lur Vertical trail-running event will take place on mountain slopes outside of Akureyri, North Iceland this weekend. R√öV reports that organizers and volunteers have been hard at work preparing the trails, even manually shovelling snow on the uppermost slopes of Mt. Hl√≠√∞arfjall in order to carve out a running path for the longest race. This is the seventh time S√∫lur Vertical has been held and participation is higher than ever been before, with 556 people registered to take part in three races of increasing distances: 18 km [11 mi], 28 km [17 mi], and 55 km [34 mi]. The longest race includes a section on Mt. Hl√≠√∞arfjall and a 3000-m [1.86-mi] elevation gain (earning 3 points with the International Trail Running Association). ‚ÄúThis section has been impassable due to snow since the winter,‚Äù read a Facebook post about the organizers‚Äô trail-clearing efforts on Tuesday. ‚ÄúBut many hands, shovels, ( and chainsaws!) made for light work and [this stretch] shouldn‚Äôt be much of an obstacle this weekend.‚Äù S√∫lur Vertical director √ûorbergur Ingi J√≥nsson later clarified that the chainsaws were used to break through hard-packed ice along the trail and said the whole process took only a few hours. ‚ÄúWhen you have such a powerful group, projects like this one are no problem.‚Äù ‚ÄúThis also opens one of the most popular mountain trails around Akureyri to the general public and we welcome that,‚Äù he wrote in Tuesday‚Äôs post, ‚Äúas one of the goals of the S√∫lur Vertical organization is to promote outdoor activity and physical activity in the area.‚Äù The weather forecast isn‚Äôt looking promising for the coming weekend, and there‚Äôs even the possibility of snow in the mountains. But √ûorbergur isn‚Äôt discouraged. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll just make the best of the conditions and we‚Äôve got plenty of hot cocoa and things like that.‚Äù Learn more about S√∫lur Vertical (in English) here.

headline: Open Water Swimmer Takes to the Sea for a Good Cause
body: Open water swimmer Sigurgeir Svanbergsson took to the sea on Friday for a good cause. R√öV reports that the self-trained sea swimming enthusiast set out on his odyssey from the Westman Islands to Landeyjasandur on the mainland at 3:45 pm and was expected to complete the 12-km [7.5 mi] journey in five to six hours, arriving between 9:00 and 10:00 pm. Sigurgeir is swimming on behalf of Save the Children Iceland. (Donate here.) All the money he collects for his monumental undertaking will be donated. He considers this a truly pressing issue, noting that one in every six children in the world‚Äîor 450 million total‚Äîlive in conflict zones, which is a 5% increase from last year. ‚ÄòI always have to go a little further and try something a little harder‚Äô This isn‚Äôt Sigurgeir‚Äôs first open water plunge‚Äînor his first for charity‚Äîalthough he is still relatively new to the pursuit. Last year, with very little prior swimming experience, he swam across Kollafj√∂r√∞ur from Kjalarnes to Reykjav√≠k. (In that instance, he swam for Unique Children in Iceland, a support group for children with rare diseases.) Sea swimming was a pursuit he took up during the COVID lockdown years, unable to practice or compete in his first sport, Lethwei, a particularly strenuous, full-contact form of boxing practiced in Myanmar. ‚ÄúI was supposed to be competing in the world championship, but COVID spoiled that. [‚Ä¶] So I had to find something else to do.‚Äù Sigurgeir had no particular background in swimming and had only really practiced when he was in school. But that was part of the appeal for him. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really interested in putting myself in situations that are really challenging. It‚Äôs so interesting to see where your head goes when you find yourself in a situation that‚Äôs actually kind of impossible.‚Äù And he learned a lot during the course of that first journey, even if it wasn‚Äôt all smooth swimming. ‚ÄúIt went well, I finished it, but with all kinds of complications,‚Äù he recalled in a recent radio interview. For one thing, the engine went out on his escort boat and Sigurgeir ended up having to swim around it for an hour and a half while he waited for a new one. During that break, the currents in the fjord changed direction and so Sigurgeir had to complete his journey swimming against a strong current. The swim took nine hours. ‚ÄúIt was hard and I almost failed,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut then I always have to go a little further and try something a little harder.‚Äù ¬†Learning from experience Sigurgeir has certainly found something ‚Äúa little harder‚Äù with his current swim. The distance of the Kollafj√∂r√∞ur swim was just the same, 12 km, but the swim from the Westman Islands will be much more difficult. ‚ÄúSo, this is the open sea, of course,‚Äù Sigurgeir noted. ‚ÄúI really have no idea what I‚Äôm getting into, in a way.‚Äù He‚Äôs learned from previous experience, however, and in addition to training extensively in advance of Friday‚Äôs swim‚Äîboth physical preparation in the form of cold training and mental preparation for better stress management‚ÄîSigurgeir has made some adjustments. He said he‚Äôd be more mindful of the change currents and planned to bring a kayak with him where he could eat mid-swim. He was also going to practice better feeding methods. Sigurgeir said he didn‚Äôt do this very well last year and as a result, ended up vomiting for the last three hours of his swim. ‚ÄúThere was actually a trail of vomit behind me the whole way.‚Äù Outlook good At time of writing, Sigurgeir hadn‚Äôt completed his swim from the Westmans to Iceland‚Äôs mainland, but the conditions were good when he set out. The currents were favourable, and the weather on Heimey, the only inhabited island in the Westmans from where he set out, was good: 10¬∞C [50¬∞F], with just a slight breeze, a bit of fog, and scattered showers. Sigurgeir was in high spirits before setting out on Friday afternoon, saying: ‚ÄúIn the first place, I just think it‚Äôs exciting. Just such an exciting idea to give this a try. And then there‚Äôs a good cause, too.‚Äù Check Sigurgeir‚Äôs Facebook page, Synt fr√° Vestmannaeyjum (‚ÄòSwam from the Westman Islands‚Äô), to see how his saga ended on Friday night.

headline: Unbeaten Iceland Out of European Championships
body: Iceland is out of the 2022 UEFA European Women‚Äôs Football Championship after a tie game against France. Iceland landed in third place in their group after all three of their matches ‚Äì against Belgium, Italy, and France ‚Äì ended in 1-1 ties. Team captain Sara Bj√∂rk Gunnarsd√≥ttir told R√öV she is proud of the team‚Äôs efforts, though the result is disappointing. Iceland‚Äôs women‚Äôs team gave their all during last night‚Äôs match against France. Though they did not win, the tie result was nevertheless impressive, as the French team had won their last 17 matches, and only lost one of their last 33 games. ‚ÄúWe showed character and gave the French a proper match today,‚Äù Sara Bj√∂rk stated in an interview after the game. ‚ÄúWe were playing against one of the best national teams in the world and we have a damn good chance. It was a great game. Our best one in the championship. Unbelievably proud of the team and the group.‚Äù The result, though disappointing, can still be seen as an improvement from the last UEFA Championship, in 2017, when Iceland lost all of its matches.

headline: Record Numbers of Pink Salmon Caught
body: Iceland‚Äôs Marine Research Institute has issued a report on salmon and trout catches in 2021. 339 pink salmon were reported, an all-time record. Pink salmon, also called humpback salmon for the prominent bump males develop during their spawn migration, is native to the Pacific ocean and is considered an invasive species in Iceland. Some 323 pink salmon were caught by anglers, and 16 were caught in nets. In total, 36,461 salmon catches were registered last year, with 53.7% of them released and 46.3% of them landed. The total catch is recorded as 46,832kg. In the second half of the 20th century, the fish was stocked in Russian streams. After this introduction, the pink salmon has made its way around the arctic region to the North Atlantic, and the species has been recorded not just in Iceland, but also throughout the UK and Ireland as an invasive species. Environmentalists are concerned that the fish may disrupt native habits and compete with other species for food.

headline: Family Requests Body of Mountaineer John Snorri Be Buried with Companions
body: In a recent public announcement on Facebook, L√≠na M√≥ey, wife of the Icelandic mountaineer John Snorri Sigurj√≥nsson, expressed her wishes for the burial of her husband. John Snorri was a respected mountaineer and the first Icelander to summit several major peaks, including Lhotse and K2. He and his climbing companions Ali Sadpara and Juan Pablo Mohr went missing in February of last year and were officially presumed dead. Their bodies were found in July on the slopes above Camp 4. In her statement, L√≠na M√≥ey clarified that the death of John Snorri had ‚Äúturned their world upside down.‚Äù She and her family needed some time to come to a decision that would be both be good for them, but also consider the safety of those offering to help them. As there are currently several teams attempting a K2 summit, it is unclear which team will come across John Snorri‚Äôs remains first. L√≠na M√≥ey stated that her first choice is that John Snorri‚Äôs body be moved to his climbing companions and given a suitable burial. If this is not possible, then she desires him to be moved off the trail and placed out of sight. In her statement, she also requested that no photographs or videos be taken of his body without permission. L√≠na M√≥ey will be travelling to Pakistan at the end of July and staying there for some two weeks to finalize her affairs. In her statement, she thanked all who had helped her family so far and expressed both her gratitude and concern for the safety of all. Read our profile on John Snorri here.

headline: Icelandic National Women‚Äôs Team Starts EM with Draw
body: The Icelandic Women‚Äôs national team drew a tie in their opening match against Belgium last night, with both teams scoring one point. The Icelanders kept up the pressure on the Belgian goal for some time, and the Icelandic goal came shortly into the second half of the match, with a header by Berglind Bj√∂rg. However, the Belgians soon equalized the score with a penalty shot on the Icelandic goal. Some 2,000 Icelandic fans were in attendance to show support for the team, including the Prime Minister. In honour of the famous T√≥lfan fan club, the popular Viking Clap was performed at the twelve-minute mark. Notably, the girls played the match in their old kit. Although the new uniforms for the team are ready, the Icelanders were obliged to wear white as the away team. France currently leads Group D, with Iceland and Belgium tied for second and third, and Italy in fourth place. At the moment, France holds three points after its victory over Italy, while both Iceland and Belgium hold one point each. Italy currently stands with zero points. Iceland‚Äôs next match will be this Thursday at 16.00 against Italy.

headline: Sailing Competitors Seek Safe Harbour in East Iceland
body: Twenty-three of the competitors in France‚Äôs Vend√©e Artique sailing competition are seeking shelter in F√°kr√∫√∞sfj√∂r√∞ur Bay in East Iceland due to dangerous weather conditions on the Atlantic Ocean, R√öV reports. This is the first time that skippers participating in the race were supposed to have crossed the Arctic Circle north of Iceland, but given the current weather conditions on the course, race organizers have elected to end the race in F√°kr√∫√∞sfj√∂r√∞ur. Three of the skippers had already arrived in F√°skr√∫√∞sfj√∂r√∞ur as of Friday night, with the rest expected in the early hours of Saturday morning. Roughly a third of the sailboats were known to have been damaged in the difficult weather on the way to Iceland, where the East Iceland Sailing Club was preparing to receive them. Route designed to be difficult The newly-extended 3,500-nautical-mile Vend√©e Artique begins and ends in Les Sables d‚ÄôOlonne in France and circumnavigates Iceland. It is the first qualifying race for the Vend√©e Globe, a single-handed, non-stop, round-the-world yacht race. As it is intended to help participating skippers test their boats and get a feel for the Vend√©e Globe, the course was designed to be difficult, with purposefully difficult weather conditions. Sailing from north to south ‚Äúis a particular technical exercise,‚Äù explains the competition website, ‚Äúrequiring numerous manoeuvres and sail changes [‚Ä¶] when rounding Iceland.‚Äù ¬† In its explanation for why the race was suspended, the organizers wrote that ‚Äúa low pressure system is threatening the fleet. The skippers are likely to face tough conditions and the back of the fleet already have more than 40kts at times and gusts to 60kts.‚Äù Given the fact that the race ‚Äúis quite isolated,‚Äù there was also the additional risk that rescue would be complicated in the event it was necessary. The next Vend√©e Globe will take place in 2024; in order to be entered in the race, skippers must take place in at least two of five qualifying races. The next qualifying race is the Route du Rhum in November, which sales from Saint Malo, in Brittany, France, to Pointe-√°-Pitre, Guadelopue.

headline: Six Icelandic Women Complete Relay Swim Across English Channel
body: Sea swimming group B√°rurnar (the Waves) reached the coast of France yesterday after completing their relay swim across the English Channel. The trip took the six women 16 hours and four minutes in total, and its last part was against the clock and in choppy waters, as the weather was turning. B√°rurnar consists of Gu√∞munda El√≠asd√≥ttir, Elsa Valsd√≥ttir, Sigr√≠√∞ur L√°rusd√≥ttir, Harpa leifsd√≥ttir, J√≥runn Atlad√≥ttir, and Bjarn√æ√≥ra Egilsd√≥ttir. ‚ÄúWe are just regular women, mothers and grandmothers,‚Äù Gu√∞munda told Iceland Review. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre no athletes or elite swimmers, just a group of middle-aged women.‚Äù While the idea to swim across the English Channel was first sparked some years ago, the group only started regular training last autumn. ‚ÄúSome of us had a solid background in swimming,‚Äù Gu√∞munda noted. ‚ÄúWhile others were just starting to learn the front crawl stroke in August of last year!‚Äù Being regular women with regular lives, the group has its ups and downs, and last year, during preparations for the swim, one of its members got an ostomy bag. She did not let it interrupt her practices and became the first ostomate to cross the Channel. The group also includes two surgeons. With their relay swim, they want to raise awareness for the condition, inviting those who followed their travails to support the Icelandic Ostomy Association. The shortest distance between the coasts of the UK and France is 34 km, but their route was a little longer as they had to swim with the heavy Channel currents amid high waves. The women swam 54 km in total, taking turns swimming for an hour at a time. The group had its doubts about whether they would set off for their swim yesterday morning due to the bad weather forecast and their accompanying boat captain‚Äôs pessimism. Still, as it was the only feasible day in the seven-day window they had planned, they set off anyway. The six swimmers took turns swimming for one hour at a time while the other five tried to keep warm in the boat. The temperature of the water was about 13.5¬∞c.

headline: New National Sporting Arena to be Built in Laugardalur
body: The Icelandic government and City of Reykjav√≠k have agreed to build a new, national sporting arena in Laugardalur. The arena will fulfill the requirements for international competition in indoor sports and greatly improve the available facilities for schools and sports associations in Laugardalur. Construction is expected to be completed by 2025. This was announced in a joint press release issued by the Prime Minister‚Äôs Office, the Ministry of Education and Children, and the City of Reykjav√≠k. The state and the City of Reykjav√≠k have agreed to guarantee funding for the arena‚Äôs initial costs in their long-term budgets. A full cost estimate will be available after the final design and a feasibility study are both completed. The division of the total project cost will depend on the utilization of the arena and the needs of each party‚Äîthe state with an eye to the requirements for international competitions that national sports teams compete in, and the city with an eye to the needs of local sports clubs and sports education. A special committee will be established to oversee the feasibility study and construction preparations, not least how the financing will be handled. The Icelandic government and City of Reykjav√≠k will hold a joint competition to determine the arena‚Äôs design and overall appearance. Preparations for a national stadium for track-and-field in Laugardalur and a national football stadium will continue. A market survey will be carried out to lay out clear options for how to proceed with the development of the national football stadium.

headline: Women‚Äôs Euro Stadium Choices ‚ÄòDisrespectful to Women‚Äôs Football‚Äô
body: Sara Bj√∂rk Gunnarsd√≥ttir, the captain of Iceland‚Äôs national women‚Äôs football team, had strong words this week for the stadiums that have been chosen for the women‚Äôs European Championship, which will take place in England this summer, ESPN reports. The choice of several low-capacity arenas are ‚Äúembarrassing,‚Äù Sara Bj√∂rk remarked, and ‚Äúnot the respect we deserve. They haven‚Äôt prepared for the fact that we can sell more than 4,000, it is disrespectful to women‚Äôs football.‚Äù Sara Bj√∂rk made the remarks while speaking to the podcast Their Pitch and was particularly referring to the 5,000-seat Manchester City Academy stadium, where two of Iceland‚Äôs games will be played. ‚ÄúI am disappointed with the arenas we have been given,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt is shocking‚Äîwe play a tournament in England with several large arenas, and we get to play at a training facility that takes around 5,000 spectators.‚Äù A Euro 2022 spokesperson responded to Sara Bj√∂rk‚Äôs critiques saying, ‚ÄúManchester City Academy is not a training ground.
