It is the official home stadium of Manchester City Women‚Äôs Football Club‚Ä¶We believe that with two of the biggest football stadiums in England [Old Trafford and Wembley], four venues with a capacity of 30,000 or more, two venues over 10,000 and two stadiums under 10,000, the right mix of stadiums has been chosen to provide the tournament with a platform to fulfil its potential.‚Äù FA‚Äôs stadium choices ‚Äòfelt hugely unambitious then and looks almost ludicrously low-key now,‚Äô says Guardian football writer In a piece for The Guardian, however, football writer Suzanne Wrack called Sara Bj√∂rk‚Äôs frustrations ‚Äúunderstandable,‚Äù saying ‚Äúher remarks highlighted a number of important questions, chiefly among them whether the Football Association was ambitious enough in its choice of venues and whether it has done enough to adapt to the accelerating growth of the game? Arguably, the answer to both questions is no.‚Äù Wrack goes on to point out that while women‚Äôs football, and the public‚Äôs interest in it, was in a much different place four years ago when England‚Äôs Football Association (FA) made its bid to host the tournament, ‚Äúthe signs of potentially rapid growth were already there and were either overlooked, ignored or woefully underestimated.‚Äù She continued by saying that ‚Äú[i]t was, and always has been, clear that major international competitions qualitatively impact the growth of the women‚Äôs game.‚Äù Preceded then as it was by the launching of the Women‚Äôs Super League as a full-time professional league in 2018, the 2019 World Cup, and a broader, stated goal of doubling the fanbase by 2020, the FA‚Äôs choice of stadiums ‚Äúfelt hugely unambitious then and looks almost ludicrously low-key now.‚Äù ‚ÄòThey should 100% reconsider‚Äô Responding to the FA‚Äôs claim that they‚Äôve chosen ‚Äúthe right mix of stadiums‚Ä¶to provide the tournament with a platform to fulfil its potential,‚Äù Sara Bj√∂rk noted that both of Iceland‚Äôs matches at the academy have already sold out, and she believes that these sales, as well as sell-outs across the group phases, speak for themselves. ‚ÄúBut matches will be played in larger arenas that I‚Äôm sure will sell out,‚Äù she continued. ‚ÄúWomen‚Äôs football explodes, and you start to get the respect you deserve. It‚Äôs getting better‚Äîmore money is being pumped in now and it‚Äôs going in the right direction. But there are still things that need to improve.‚Äù ‚ÄúThey should 100% reconsider [changing the stadiums],‚Äù Sara Bj√∂rk concluded. ‚ÄúBecause if you look at the reactions and how many people buy tickets and how popular it has become, then you have to reconsider.‚Äù The Women‚Äôs Euro 2022 will be held from July 6 ‚Äì 31; Iceland will play July 10 (vs. Belgium); July 14 (vs Italy); and July 18 (vs France). You can listen to Sara Bj√∂rk‚Äôs full interview with Their Pitch (in English) here.

headline: Olympian in ‚ÄúRace Against Time‚Äù Even Before Race Day
body: Icelandic skier Sturla Sn√¶r Snorrason is in the midst of a nail-biting race‚Äîbut not the kind he was hoping to take part in during the Winter 2022 Olympics in Beijing, China. V√≠sir reports that Olympian was just released from isolation after having been diagnosed with COVID last Saturday. This means that Sturla Sn√¶r can begin training again but will not be able to actually compete unless he receives a negative PCR test result prior to his events, one of which is this weekend. See Also: Five Icelanders Compete in 2022 Winter Olympics Sturla, who competed in the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, was one of Iceland‚Äôs flagbearers during the opening ceremonies last Friday, along with cross-country skier Kristr√∫n Gu√∞nad√≥ttir. Following the ceremony, he began to experience COVID symptoms and was taken to a hospital in Beijing and put in isolation. After a few days, Sturla began to feel better, but he also began to get bored. ‚ÄúThere was no coffee or anything like that,‚Äù he remarked in an interview. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt possible to go on any social media that we use at home. [‚Ä¶] There wasn‚Äôt even a table and chair to sit at. You had to eat in bed and lie there all day. Not much in the way of entertainment, so I had to make my own.‚Äù To while away the time, therefore, Sturla decided to create a website for the road-marking company he runs with his father. As of Friday, Sturla was still in quarantine and still testing positive for COVID. If all goes well, however, he will compete in Men‚Äôs Giant Slalom late Sunday night/early Monday morning (GMT/Iceland time) this weekend and Men‚Äôs Slalom in the early hours of February 16. ¬†

headline: Five Icelanders Compete in 2022 Winter Olympics
body: The Beijing Winter Olympics begin today, and five Icelanders are among the competitors. They are H√≥lmfr√≠√∞ur D√≥ra Fri√∞geirsd√≥ttir, Isak Stianson Pedersen, Kristr√∫n Gu√∞nad√≥ttir, Snorri Einarsson, and Sturla Sn√¶r Snorrason. Two will be competing in their first Olympic games. H√≥lmfr√≠√∞ur is competing in women‚Äôs Alpine skiing, in the slalom, giant slalom, and Super-G events. Kristr√∫n will compete in cross-country skiing, in the women‚Äôs sprint freestyle event. Snorri will compete in the 15km cross-country skiing event, Men‚Äôs 15km+15km Skiathlon, the 50km mass start freestyle event, and the Men‚Äôs Team Sprint Classic event. Isak will compete in the cross-country sprint and the Team Sprint Classic events. Sturla Sn√¶r, Snorri, and Isak all competed in the 2018 Winter Olympics in PyeongChang. Holmfr√≠√∞ur and Kristr√∫n will be competing in the Olympics for the first time. Kristr√∫n and Sturla Sn√¶r will be Iceland‚Äôs flagbearers at the opening ceremony today.

headline: Iceland Must Beat Montenegro to Advance to Handball Semifinal
body: Iceland‚Äôs men‚Äôs national handball team must win their match against Montenegro tomorrow in order to advance to the semi-finals of the 2022 European Handball Championships. Yet victory alone will not ensure their advance in the tournament: it is also dependent on Denmark beating France. Iceland‚Äôs team is currently in third place in Group I, with four points. The men‚Äôs handball team started the tournament on a high note, winning all three of their matches in the preliminary round and advancing to the main round at the top of their group. The streak was interrupted by a COVID outbreak on the team just before Iceland‚Äôs match against world champion Denmark, which they lost 24-28. That was followed by a 29-21 victory against Olympic champions France on January 22 and a disappointing 22-23 loss to Croatia last night. Iceland plays Montenegro tomorrow at 2:30 PM UTC.

headline: COVID-hit Iceland loses to Denmark at European Handball Championship
body: The Icelandic men‚Äôs national handball team suffered a defeat at the hands of Denmark last night. Six Icelandic players tested positive for COVID-19 the night before the game, the first match of the European Handball Championship‚Äôs main round.¬† Rough news following a smooth start Following a positive start to the European Handball Championship, which saw the Icelandic men‚Äôs national handball team win all three of its matches in the preliminary round, the squad suffered a four-point defeat to Denmark last night. The match was the first game of the tournament‚Äôs main round.¬†¬† On the evening before the game, news broke that three Icelandic players had tested positive for COVID-19: goalkeeper Bj√∂rgvin P√°ll G√∫stavsson, centre-back Elvar √ñrn J√≥nsson, and left back √ìlafur Andr√©s Gu√∞mundsson. More bad news broke on the following morning when it was revealed that captain Aron P√°lmarson and winger Bjarki M√°r El√≠sson had also tested positive. The final blow arrived just a few hours before the game against Denmark; centre-back G√≠sli √ûorgeir Kristj√°nsson also tested positive.¬† The players have little to no symptoms, according to reports. Critical of tournament organisers In an interview with V√≠sir yesterday, Bjarki M√°r El√≠sson criticised the tournament organisers for not doing enough to minimise the risk of infection:¬†¬† ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been doing everything in our power to avoid infection; we‚Äôve been holed up in our hotels since January 2,‚Äù who added that the team had been prepared for the worst after the first three players tested positive.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe conditions at the hotel are such that there are tourists and other guests staying alongside us, which, personally, I find absurd. But, of course, there are fans in the stadiums, and we‚Äôre doing interviews, so you‚Äôre always at some risk. Perhaps it was to be expected,‚Äù Bjarki continued.¬† ‚ÄúI suppose what‚Äôs most disappointing, however, is that tournament organisers didn‚Äôt provide better conditions. Ensure that we were more isolated, that there aren‚Äôt other people staying at the hotels; all of the teams are eating in the same places, too. This allows infection to spread, and it was expected, but it is also extremely disappointing.‚Äù A tough schedule ahead Iceland will play its second match of the main round tomorrow, Saturday, January 22. The team will face off against France, the reigning Olympic Champions, with Iceland‚Äôs President Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson expected to be in the stands. The following two games are against Croatia on Monday (January 24) and Montenegro on Wednesday (January 26).¬†

headline: COVID Outbreak Interrupts Iceland‚Äôs Winning Streak at European Handball Championship
body: Five players on the Icelandic men‚Äôs national handball team will not be able to play in the team‚Äôs European Handball Championship match tonight, as they have tested positive for COVID-19. It is a huge blow to the team, which finished at the top of their group in the preliminary round of the tournament. One of the two Icelandic referees in the tournament has also tested positive for COVID-19. Iceland‚Äôs handball team is set to play its first match in the main round of the European Handball Championships tonight, against Denmark. The Icelandic team won all three of their matches in the preliminary round, which they finished off with a 31-30 victory over Hungary in Budapest last Tuesday. Yesterday evening, the Icelandic Handball Association reported that three players had tested positive for COVID-19: Bj√∂rgvin P√°ll G√∫stavsson, Elvar √ñrn J√≥nsson, and √ìlafur Andr√©s Gu√∞mundsson. This morning, the association reported another two COVID-19 cases within the team, those of Aron P√°lmarsson and Bjarki M√°r El√≠sson. One of the Icelandic referees at the competition, Anton Gylfi P√°lsson, also tested positive for COVID. The players have little to no symptoms, according to reports. Iceland‚Äôs President Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson is on his way to Hungary to attend tonight‚Äôs match against Denmark, as well as the handball team‚Äôs match against France on January 22.

headline: Iceland Proceeds to Main Round in 2022 Handball Championships
body: The Icelandic men‚Äôs national handball team will proceed to the main round of the 2022 European Handball Championships after winning all three of their matches in the preliminary round. They beat the Hungarian national team 31-30 in an exciting game in Budapest last night. The Iceland team finished the preliminary round at the top of its group with six points, and carries over two points to the main round thanks to their victory over the Netherlands. The 20,000-seat handball stadium in Budapest was packed for last night‚Äôs Iceland-Hungary match. While Iceland supporters numbered just around 500, the Icelandic Handball Association reports that they made themselves heard throughout the match. The match itself was tense, with Iceland only leading by one point throughout most of the first half and Hungary equalising at 17-17 in the last few seconds before halftime. The score was equal 15 minutes before the end of the match, but Iceland‚Äôs tight defences in the second half eventually helped ensure the 31-30 victory. Iceland plays its first match in the main round against Denmark tomorrow, January 20. On January 22, the team will play France, followed by Croatia on January 24, and Montenegro on January 26.

headline: Iceland European Champion in Group Gymnastics
body: Iceland became the European group gymnastics champion in Portugal on Saturday when the women‚Äôs team won gold with a score of 57,250 points, narrowly beating the Swedish team. The team won the competition‚Äôs highest score in floor exercises in the women‚Äôs category with 22,300 points. This was the first year Iceland also sent a men‚Äôs team to the competition, and they took home silver medals for their performance. The Icelandic youth team also won silver and bronze in the competition. Bj√∂rn Bj√∂rnsson, one of the team‚Äôs coaches, told R√öV he hopes the men‚Äôs silver award encourages young men to train in gymnastics. ‚ÄúI think it can do nothing but increase the number of great boys in gymnastics. The next competition is coming up, in nine months, and we need more great boys.‚Äù

headline: New Report: Football Association Urged to ‚ÄúShoulder Responsibility‚Äù
body: A workgroup established by the Icelandic Football Association (KS√ç) has submitted proposals on how the association could better handle allegations of violence and sexual assault. The report, which tackles issues of ‚Äúprocedure, attitude, and culture,‚Äù encourages the association to shoulder increased responsibility. Following resignations by Director Gu√∞ni Bergsson and the board of directors earlier this year, the Icelandic Football Association established a workgroup to examine procedures relating to allegations of violence and sexual assault. The group‚Äôs mandate was to review responses to sexual and violent assaults within Icelandic football ‚Äúin collaboration with outside professionals.‚Äù A few days ago, the workgroup submitted its report, which was subsequently published on the association‚Äôs website. On the first page of the report, the authors urge the leadership to assert their opposition to all kinds of violence publicly: ‚ÄúThis summary report contains the workgroup‚Äôs proposals alongside an encouragement to the leadership to make good use of the present opportunity to take a clear stance against violence of any kind ‚Äì especially sexual violence ‚Äì and, thereby, improve the culture and attitude of individuals connected to the association.‚Äù The report is predicated on four proposals. First, the workgroup advises that the association update its code of ethics, adding provisions relating to allegations of violence and creating channels for individuals to report misconduct and bring charges. The Icelandic Football Association is encouraged to sign contracts with members of national teams in which the code of conduct is explicitly referenced. Furthermore, the report advises that these contracts include provisions regarding violent misconduct, wherein ‚Äì among other conditions ‚Äì athletes commit to declaring any charges of violent or sexual misconduct. Finally, the authors counsel that employees who occupy positions of confidentiality within the association be made to confirm the code of ethics with their signatures. Second, the workgroup stresses the need to create clear channels and response protocols for instances of violence within the Football Association and its member societies. The Director of the Football Association is to be designated as a ‚Äúspecial liaison‚Äù to communication consultants within sports and youth clubs. Furthermore, instructions on how to report violence are to be made accessible on the association‚Äôs website and on all member societies‚Äô websites. Third, the association is encouraged to take a ‚Äúclear stance‚Äù against violence and to coordinate the messaging of its member societies. The workgroup also advises that leadership attend seminars on equality and violence each year following the annual meeting. Fourth, the workgroup advises that the association assume a leading role in equality within sports in Iceland, that it adopt an ‚Äúequality plan,‚Äù and that it work to ensure gender balance within all of its internal committees and councils. The report concludes with further encouragement in which the association is urged to welcome its responsibility while at the same time taking it seriously: ‚ÄúThe association cannot, by itself, change society; however, it does occupy a unique position in terms of effecting significant and positive change. The association‚Äôs messaging and policies matter. By acting on these four proposals, and by leaning on the insights of professionals in the field of equality and violence, the association can become a role model and demonstrate that it is intent on shouldering responsibility.‚Äù

headline: Out of National Horse-Riding Team Due to Sexual Assault Conviction
body: Veteran jockey J√≥hann R√∫nar Sk√∫lason has been removed from Iceland‚Äôs national equestrian team due to a sexual assault conviction. Mannl√≠f reports that in 1994, J√≥hann R√∫nar was convicted for raping a 13-year-old girl the previous year, when he was 24 years old. The jockey was also recently convicted for domestic violence in Denmark, his country of residence. Gu√∞ni Halld√≥rsson, chairman of the Icelandic Horse Association (Landssamband hestamannaf√©laga, or LH) told V√≠sir it was a difficult decision to remove Iceland‚Äôs ‚Äúbiggest competitor and biggest name‚Äù in the sport from the national team, but added that ‚Äúsexual offences, especially involving children, cannot and will not be tolerated on our watch.‚Äù Gu√∞ni stated that he first heard of the conviction when Mannl√≠f reported on it late last month and that he is not aware of any other sexual assault cases coming up within the association previously. Sexual violence within sport has been a big topic in Icelandic media lately after several cases of sexual violence emerged connected to the national men‚Äôs football team. The Football Association was accused of silencing victims of violence and sexual assault in cases involving team members. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a different discussion and a different way of dealing with issues today than it was five years ago,‚Äù Gu√∞ni stated in reference to the cases involving football players. ‚ÄúThis decision was made based on the environment and the situation today and we stand by it.‚Äù In 2019, J√≥hann R√∫nar was a triple world champion in horse riding and was also nominated for Iceland‚Äôs Athlete of the Year award.

headline: Record-Breaking Weightlifter Works Day Job as Flight Attendant
body: Anna Gu√∞r√∫n Halld√≥rsd√≥ttir set three European records and two world records in her weight class at the European Masters Weightlifting Championships in the Netherlands earlier this month, V√≠sir reports. If that isn‚Äôt impressive enough, the 52-year-old resident of Hverager√∞i, South Iceland managed to achieve these results while still holding down a job as part of Icelandair‚Äôs cabin crew. She even worked a six-hour flight to Chicago the day after the competition. ‚ÄúIt was awesome,‚Äù Anna said. ‚ÄúI got first place in my weight class and set world records and European records and I‚Äôm just so happy about all of it, just over the moon. It‚Äôs been a bit hard to practice alongside work, but it works.‚Äù  Anna Gu√∞r√∫n trains at least five times a week at her local CrossFit. She took up weightlifting at the gym shortly after moving to Hverager√∞i and it was quickly apparent that she had real potential. ‚ÄúWe saw right away that she‚Äôs really strong,‚Äù said Anna‚Äôs trainer, Mar√≠a R√∫n √ûorsteinsd√≥ttir. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a former handball champion. We knew for sure that she had a chance at these world records [‚Ä¶].‚Äù Anna Gu√∞r√∫n hasn‚Äôt let her world champion status go to her head, though, and doesn‚Äôt have plans to stop working as a flight attendant any time soon‚Äîher weightlifting skills come in handy all the time. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs great,‚Äù she laughed. ‚ÄúI can help everyone with their hand luggage and other things, so that‚Äôs something.‚Äù ¬†

headline: Gl√≠ma: Icelandic Wrestling Applies for UNESCO Status
body: Icelandic wrestling, known as gl√≠ma, could soon be on the UNESCO list of intangible cultural heritage, R√öV reports. The sport involves wrestlers gripping their opponent by the waist and attempting to throw them to the ground. Gl√≠ma was brought to Iceland by Norwegian settlers. Though originally opponents held onto each other‚Äôs trousers, in 1905 a special belt or harness was introduced to the sport, allowing wrestlers to have a better grip on each other. The sport is known for emphasising technique over force and was featured in a demonstration at the 1912 Summer Olympics. Gu√∞mundur Stef√°n Gunnarsson teaches gl√≠ma in Njar√∞v√≠k, Southwest Iceland. He is working to get the sport onto UNESCO‚Äôs official list of intangible cultural heritage. It recently reached the first milestone in that process, which is to be registered as Icelandic cultural heritage. According to Gu√∞mundur Stef√°n, the atmosphere of gl√≠ma is very positive and competitions are characterised by respect among athletes. Hei√∞r√∫n Fj√≥la P√°lsd√≥ttir, an award-winning gl√≠ma competitor who teaches alongside Gu√∞mundur, agrees. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs such incredibly good morale in Icelandic gl√≠ma. Everyone is friends and it‚Äôs always so much fun.‚Äù More information about gl√≠ma is available in English on the website Lifandi hef√∞ir (Living Traditions).

headline: Six National Team Players Accused of Violence and Sexual Assault
body: Six members of Iceland‚Äôs men‚Äôs national football team have been accused of sexual assault. The board of the Football Association of Iceland received a confidential email from activist group √ñfgar naming six members of the team and dates of their alleged violent and sexual offences, according to mbl.is sources. The national team coach was also accused of belittling the alleged victims in the wording of his statements to media. Aron Einar Gunnarsson, Kolbeinn Sig√æ√≥rsson, and Gylfi √û√≥r Sigur√∞sson have all been named in Icelandic media in relation to violent or sexual offences. The other three players remain unnamed. The players will not play on the national team while the cases are being investigated. Read More: Football Association Accused of Silencing Sexual Assault Sigurbj√∂rg Sigurp√°lsd√≥ttir, Sports and Youth Activities Communication Counselor is overseeing the investigation. Her position was created last spring under the auspices of the Ministry of Education and Culture to address bullying and violence in sports and youth activities and to ‚Äúcontribute to a safe environment within sports and youth activities‚Äù as per the position‚Äôs official website. Editor‚Äôs note: This article has been updated with a more accurate photo.

headline: Aron Einar Not Selected to the National Team Despite Availability
body: Aron Einar Gunnarsson, captain of the men‚Äôs national football team, has not been selected to the squad for upcoming games against Armenia and Liechtenstein for the World Cup qualifiers. While the team‚Äôs head coach Arnar √û√≥r Vi√∞arsson stated that he was not asked to exclude any players, and board members have denied any interference, Aron Einar maintains that the exclusion stems from the incoming board of directors yielding to ‚Äúcancel culture.‚Äù The footballer contends that he was not selected to the squad because of rumours of sexual misconduct that he allegedly perpetrated in 2010. According to R√öV‚Äôs sources, police are reinvestigating the 2010 incident at the victim‚Äôs request. Yesterday, Arnar √û√≥r Vi√∞arsson, head coach of the men‚Äôs national football team, announced a squad of 25 footballers for the upcoming matches against Armenia and Liechtenstein for the World Cup Qualifiers. Among the names missing from the squad was Aron Einar Gunnarsson, captain of the team for the past decade and who was presumed to be fit. Before the team‚Äôs press conference yesterday, rumours spread that the Football Association‚Äôs board of directors had prohibited Arnar √û√≥r Vi√∞arsson from selecting Aron Einar to the squad on account of the latter being implicated, without being named, in an incident of sexual violence occurring eleven years ago. According to mbl.is, who reached out for a statement, outgoing and incoming board members denied these allegations. Arnar √û√≥r Vi√∞arsson has also stated that he was not asked to exclude any players. After the squad was officially announced, Aron Einar Gunnarsson released a statement to the Icelandic media accusing the Football Association‚Äôs incoming board of directors of excluding him from the team. In the statement, Aron Einar explains that he had informed the Association that he was available, in shape, and had fully recovered from an illness. Furthermore, he had notified the Association that he was innocent of all accusations, referring to an incident of alleged sexual violence that occurred in Copenhagen in 2010. Given that the team has performed poorly over the past weeks, Aron Einar says that he was forced to surmise that his exclusion was not tactical but that the Association had decided to submit to the demands of cancel culture. Aron Einar concluded his statement asking the police to allow him to give a formal statement regarding the incident in 2010. Mbl.is reported yesterday evening that the police authorities had decided to reopen the case; according to R√öV, charges had been brought against Aron Einar in 2010, but those charges were subsequently dropped. ¬† Here is Aron Einar‚Äôs statement in full: ‚ÄúAs reported today, I was not among those players selected by coach Arnar √û√≥r Vi√∞arsson for the national team‚Äôs upcoming games. This exclusion follows my announcement to the Football Association that I was available, in shape, and fully convalesced following an illness. Furthermore, I had informed them that I had done nothing wrong, in reference to the alleged culture of violence within the Football Association, which has been widely discussed recently. During the press conference, however, the reasons behind said squad selection were hardly discussed. I can only draw the conclusion that the incoming board of directors, whose election was not contested, had, without a mandate, exerted itself to cancel me, as reported on DV.is; the team‚Äôs recent results hardly suggest that sidelining the team‚Äôs most experiences players would be wise, which cannot be the reason for my exclusion. I have also not asked Arnar √û√≥r to remain quiet about the reasons for his not selecting me. For me, my family, and those friends who know me, it is deeply hurtful that the National Football Association, for whom I have given my all, for the past 97 national games, has decided to yield to demands founded on vague rumours about members of the national team. It puts one into an indefensible position. On social media, an event that occurred in Copenhagen in 2010 has been widely discussed. I have not had the opportunity to discuss that event formally with the Football Association, have not been allowed to defend myself against these misdeameanours (sic), which is why I am hurt by this unceremonious dismissal. Furthermore, the police has never contacted me in relation to any investigation. I have never been notified that I was suspected of a crime and neither have I at any point been called into interrogation. As a captain, I have long since learned to shoulder responsibility; cancel culture has recently been tolerated, but it should not be. And so while I reject all violence I declare that I have not been violated any person or woman. I refuse to play a codependent role toward the street justice, regarding an incident that supposedly occurred eleven years ago. If anyone has any criticism to level in my direction, I ask that same person not to show me any mercy, to accuse me by name, and give me the opportunity to defend myself. That‚Äôs honest.¬† In light of all of this, I have decided to ask the police to allow me to give a formal statement about that night eleven years ago.‚Äù Aron Einar Gunnarsson

headline: Uncontested Election for Football Association‚Äôs New Chair
body: Vanda Sigurgeirsd√≥ttir, a former member of the women‚Äôs national football team, is the only candidate in the running for the position of Chair of the Icelandic Football Association‚Äôs interim Board of Directors. As the deadline for candidacies expired last Saturday, Vanda is set to be appointed without election. On August 30 ‚Äì following criticism for its handling of revelations of sexual violence by members of the Icelandic football league ‚Äì the Icelandic Football Association‚Äôs Board of Directors resigned. The resignation came just a few days after the Association‚Äôs Director, Gu√∞ni Bergsson, stepped aside. (Gu√∞ni stated in an interview with R√öV in August that the Association ‚Äúhad no knowledge‚Äù of accusations of sexual violence that were circulating online.) In a press release announcing its resignation, the Board of Directors also stated that it would be holding an extraordinary meeting in four weeks‚Äô time to elect an interim board. Given that aspirants were required to announce their candidacy no later than a week before the extraordinary meeting (to be held next Saturday, October 2), it is apparent that Vanda Sigurgeirsd√≥ttir will be chosen without election. Vanda Sigurgeirsd√≥ttir (full name Halld√≥ra Vanda Sigurgeirsd√≥ttir) is a former multi-sport athlete who played both for the women‚Äôs national football team and the national basketball team. In 2001, Vanda became the first woman in Iceland to coach a men‚Äôs football team (Neisti from Hofs√≥s). Besides Vanda, eight individuals have announced their candidacy for the eight available positions on the Association‚Äôs interim Board of Directors. Likewise, three individuals have announced their candidacy to the three available positions on the Football Association‚Äôs auxiliary board. As reported by Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞, given the few candidacies, there will be little ado as far as elections are concerned. The interim Board of Directors will be in office until the Association‚Äôs next annual meeting, which will be held in February of next year.

headline: Iceland Loses 4-0 to Germany in World Cup Qualifer
body:
The Iceland men‚Äôs national football team lost its world cup qualifier match in Reykjav√≠k against Germany on Wednesday night, V√≠sir reports. This is Iceland‚Äôs fourth loss in six qualifying matches thus far. The team has lost five home matches in a row. Germany took the lead in the fourth minute of the first half, with a goal by Serges Gnabry. Mark Antonios R√ºdiger scored a second goal for Germany in the 23rd minute. Germany got its third goal after halftime, courtesy of Leroy San√©, and Timo Werner pounded the final nail in the coffin about a minute before the match ended. Iceland remains, therefore, in the fifth seat with four points in the J-group, which includes Armenia, Germany, Liechtenstein, North Macedonia, and Romania. Iceland has four remaining qualifying matches: two home matches in October and two away matches in November. Changes in starting lineup, Hannes retires
 Head coach Arnar √û√≥r Vi√∞arsson and Assistant Coach Ei√∞ur Sm√°ri Gu√∞johnsen made six changes to the starting lineup ahead of Wednesday‚Äôs match. Hannes √û√≥r Halld√≥rsson started as goalie in place of R√∫nar Alex R√∫narsson, who began the last two games. J√≥n Gu√∞ni Fj√≥luson and Ari Freyr Sk√∫lason started as defenders in place of K√°ri √Årnason and Gu√∞mundur √û√≥rarinsson. Gu√∞laugur Victor P√°lsson was substituted in midfield for Andri Fannar Baldursson. J√≥hann Berg Gu√∞mundsson came in on the right wing and √û√≥rir J√≥hann Helgason on the left. After the match, Hannes √û√≥r Halld√≥rsson announced that it was his last as part of the Icelandic National Men‚Äôs Football team. All together, Hannes played in 77 matches for Iceland‚Äîmore matches than any other goalie in the history of Icelandic football. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve played for the Men‚Äôs National Team for ten years now, almost to the day,‚Äù he said in an interview after the match. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really proud of that and have had some incredible moments in this jersey‚Äîmany of my best memories. But we‚Äôve come to a generational changeover and we have so many great goalies, so I think this is the right time for me to step aside now and let them take the reins without me breathing down their necks. So this was my last game on the national team tonight‚Äîthank you all.‚Äù Hannes might be leaving football, but that doesn‚Äôt mean he‚Äôs resting on his laurels. In 2021, he made his debut as a film director, with Cop Secret, which received positive advance reviews. Hannes directed and co-wrote (with N√≠na Pedersen and Sverrir √û√≥r Sverrisson) the ‚Äúraucously entertaining‚Äù spoof on the cop film genre. See Also: Icelandic Football Requests Space To Enact Improvements The Men‚Äôs National Football Team has been shaken of late by accounts of sexual assault. This has led to the resignation of director Gu√∞ni Bergsson and the entire board of the Icelandic Football Association. The Association‚Äôs CEO Klara Bjartmarz has taken an indefinite leave. Meanwhile, a joint statement from The National Olympic and Sports Association of Iceland, √çslenskur Toppf√≥tbolti, and the Icelandic Football Association asked that Icelandic football be given room to follow through on the work they‚Äôre preparing to combat the issues raised in the past few weeks. The plan includes electing a new temporary board and organising a workgroup that will work on creating and reviewing the necessary work procedures to ensure the right reactions to reports of sensitive matters. The workgroup will cooperate with the communications advisor of sports and youth issues. According to the statement, the reviewed work procedures will be implemented into all associated institutions of the National Olympic and Sports Association of Iceland, making the association as a whole more prepared to handle such issues professionally. They note that while Icelandic football‚Äôs reputation has been damaged, it also has the strength, ability, opportunity and powerful members to improve and meet the challenges together.

headline: Icelandic Football Requests Space To Enact Improvements
body: As preparation continues for the Icelandic national men‚Äôs football team‚Äôs three upcoming qualifying matches for the World cup, the Icelandic Football Association‚Äôs CEO Klara Bjartmarz is on temporary leave in addition to resignations from the association‚Äôs director and the entire board. The association has been accused of sweeping allegations of violence and sexual assault perpetrated by members of the national team under the rug but now requests space to follow through on an action plan against sexual assault and violence. Read More: Icelandic Football Shaken By Allegations of Sexual Assault Read More: Icelandic Football Association Board Resigns As More Allegations Of Sexual Assault Come To Light Following continued pressure to resign along with the former director and board of the Icelandic Football Association, CEO Klara Bjartmarz is now on leave for an indefinite period, V√≠sir reports. One of the Association‚Äôs deputy directors told V√≠sir that if the entire board resigned, FIFA might consider the Association incapacitated and take over under emergency protocols. That has occurred twice before, in Bosnia during times of war, and in Greece during the economic crisis. A joint statement from The National Olympic and Sports Association of Iceland, √çslenskur Toppf√≥tbolti, and the Icelandic Football Association asked that Icelandic football be given room to follow through on the work they‚Äôre preparing to combat the issues raised in the past few weeks. The plan includes electing a new temporary board and organising a workgroup that will work on creating and reviewing the necessary work procedures to ensure the right reactions to reports of sensitive matters. The workgroup will cooperate with the communications advisor of sports and youth issues. According to the statement, the reviewed work procedures will be implemented into all associated institutions of the National Olympic and Sports Association of Iceland, making the association as a whole more prepared to handle such issues professionally. They note that while Icelandic football‚Äôs reputation has been damaged, it also has the strength, ability, opportunity and powerful members to improve and meet the challenges together. The workgroup on sexual assault and violence within Icelandic football led by Kolbr√∫n Hrund Sigurgeirsd√≥ttir intends to work hard and professionally. Kolbr√∫n stated to Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞ that the group will inspect the culture down to the youngest players. Hanna Bj√∂rg Vilhj√°lmsd√≥ttir who wrote an article challenging the Association to deal with allegations of violence has been offered a position in the group, as well as Steinunn Gy√∞u- og Gu√∞j√≥nsd√≥ttir, St√≠gam√≥t representative. Other members are yet to be announced but Kolbr√∫n has said that the group will likely include a lawyer as well as someone from the Association. Kolbr√∫n added that she had received several phone calls from staff and managers of football clubs over rumours of players within their ranks who might have committed violence. The staff don‚Äôt have confirmation that the rumours are true and they don‚Äôt know how to react in such a situation. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a tough job and this won‚Äôt be accomplished in one day. It‚Äôs clear that we need to cover everything down to the youngest kids in football to change certain attitudes and to create a better atmosphere of safety and equality,‚Äù Kolbr√∫n stated. She told V√≠sir that their role is to ‚Äúfigure out how we can make sure that there‚Äôs followthrough on such reports, and ensure that such cases won‚Äôt be let slide or solved in secrecy. We need to make sure that all reports receive a reaction. Icelandic football has a prime opportunity to change the toxic masculinity that has been allowed to fester, stated football fan and Iceland‚Äôs Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥tti, according to V√≠sir. ‚ÄúI think Icelandic football has the opportunity to handle this in a new way and make some radical changes. It‚Äôs important and I say this as the mother of a junior football player, not just as prime minister,‚Äù she stated. √ûorsteinn V. Einarsson hosts a podcast on masculinity and played football in the past. He has pointed out that the issue is so deep-rooted that footballers might not know how to react. ‚ÄúI really think that footballers don‚Äôt know what to say, how to react or what they can do. The fear of losing social standing, respect and power in the locker room breeds a certain kind of powerlessness,‚Äù he told V√≠sir ‚Äúbeing a feminist isn‚Äôt the most popular thing to do in football, or to interfere with equality issues or taking a stand on uncomfortable subjects.‚Äù √ûorsteinn added that players might fear repercussions from ‚Äúold-school‚Äù coaches or teammates when returning to practice after speaking out on sensitive topics. ‚Äúto state the obvious, not all football players are jackasses. But they can all take responsibility for the change that‚Äôs necessary.‚Äù T√≥lfan, the national teams‚Äô fan support group has issued a statement condemning all violence. They declare their support for victims of violence and will be showing it symbolically during the upcoming matches, staying silent until minute 12 of every match. The group also encourages its members to wear hats and insignia supporting women against violence such as the UN Women fuck violence campaign. Their statement notes that their key phrase has always been ‚Äúdon‚Äôt be a jackass,‚Äù and that violence is jackassery in its every form. Kolbeinn Sig√æ√≥rsson is one of the players removed from the national team following the past weeks‚Äô events. He plays for Sweden‚Äôs IFK G√∂teborg. While he wasn‚Äôt named by the victim who came forward following KS√ç‚Äôs original denial of reports of violence, Kolbeinn has stated the matter. While admitting that he ‚Äúbehaved less than perfectly,‚Äù and apologising for his behaviour, he denied harassing or assaulting them. ¬†‚ÄúI repented and took responsibility and was ready to make amends. They had requests for an apology and payments which I agreed to. Additionally, I donated 3 million ISK to St√≠gam√≥t [a centre for survivors of sexual violence] and in that way supported their important fight against sexual violence,‚Äù Kolbeinn stated. ‚ÄúThe Icelandic Football Association was informed of the settlement process but their public denial of violence led to √û√≥rhildur Gy√∞a feeling robbed of that settlement. I have an understanding of that. I regret my behaviour at that time and am fiercely against the violence of any kind. I am still systematically working on my issues.‚Äù √û√≥rhildur was surprised by his statement, stating that she had not named him as she didn‚Äôt want to pull focus from what she believes is the main issue, the culture within the football association. She told V√≠sir that following her interview, she has been contacted by others telling her stories of sexual assault or violence by six or seven former or current members of the men‚Äôs national team. Kolbeinn‚Äôs Swedish team has issued a statement condemning his behaviour but recently stated that they will not be terminating his contract, V√≠sir reports. Kolbeinn joined G√∂teborg‚Äôs team from AIK, whose manager now states that the Icelandic Football Association kept information from them when signing Kolbeinn. Henrik Juerlius told Aftonbladet that they contacted the Icelandic national team and Kolbeinn‚Äôs former clubs to find out if there was anything in his past that they needed to know about but received no such information. Kolbeinn signed with AIK in March 2019, two years after the Icelandic Football Association was notified of the incident. At a press briefing for the upcoming national team match against Romania, veteran team member K√°ri √Årnason states that it‚Äôs tough to enter a project by the national team under the current circumstances. ‚Äúit‚Äôs a sensitive issue and what can I say? I can‚Äôt really touch the subject without throwing someone in front of a train, whoever it is, and I think it‚Äôs best that I don‚Äôt.‚Äù Iceland is playing Romania tonight in Laugardalsv√∂llur, followed by matches against North Macedonia, and Germany. The team‚Äôs coach Arnar √û√≥r Vi√∞arsson has stated that it‚Äôs hard to prepare for a match under the circumstances but they‚Äôre doing their very best to stay focused on the game. K√°ri added that the upcoming project is tough and feels for young players entering the group under these circumstances. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs different this time and the focus outwards hasn‚Äôt really been on the football but that‚Äôs everything we‚Äôre focusing on. I don‚Äôt envy them entering into these discussions. It‚Äôs so sensitive that it‚Äôs hard to focus on something else but we‚Äôll try to keep their minds on the project at hand. It‚Äôs not the most fun position to be in to enter the national team when people aren‚Äôt talking about young and exciting players but something totally different. They‚Äôll just have to show what they got on the field and hopefully, they‚Äôll start talking about them,‚Äù K√°ri stated. The Iceland-Romania match tonight is sold out but tickets for the Iceland-North Macedonia match on Sunday are still available.

headline: Icelandic Football Association Board Resigns As More Allegations of Sexual Assault Come To Light
body: The Icelandic Football Association had knowledge of more allegations of sexual offences than the one reported over the weekend, R√öV reports. They received reports of an alleged gang rape this summer and another incident was brought to their attention over the weekend. In addition to the Association‚Äôs director, the entire board has now resigned but the Association‚Äôs CEO told R√öV she did not intend to resign despite pressure to do so. Read more: Icelandic Football Association shaken by accounts of sexual assault Reports of sexual assaults by members of Icelandic football, including members of the men‚Äôs national team shook Iceland over the past weekend. Following marathon meetings and coming under fire in the media, Director Gu√∞ni Bergsson resigned. The Association‚Äôs board did not intend to resign at first, with one of the Association‚Äôs Deputy Directors Borghildur Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir stating that the entire board resigning would render the Association incapacitated. The result was unsatisfactory according to √çslenskur Toppf√≥tbolti, an organised interest group of Iceland‚Äôs top football leagues, including both men‚Äôs and women‚Äôs teams. An √çslenskur toppf√≥tbolti board member stated to V√≠sir that ‚Äúby and large, people don‚Äôt think enough is being done and are unsatisfied with the Icelandic Football Association over the weekend. People think more needs to be done. The leadership is stripped of trust and [‚Ä¶] Gu√∞ni alone can‚Äôt carry that cross.‚Äù The board of √çslenskur Toppf√≥tbolti later issued a statement demanding that Klara Bjartmarz, the Icelandic Football Association‚Äôs CEO and the entire board resign. The statement also included demands that an extraordinary annual meeting be held to elect a temporary board, as per the Association‚Äôs laws, to regain trust within the football leagues and the public. The statement notes: ‚ÄúThe Association‚Äôs CEO and part of the board have held office for a long time and in light of their position they are responsible for the issues that have been discussed for the past few days. Football in Iceland can‚Äôt accept that the current board of the Icelandic Football Association and the Association‚Äôs CEO will lead the effort to fix things that have been broken and to scrutinise the current culture from the ground up.‚Äù Following √çslenskur Toppf√≥tbolti‚Äôs statement, nine football clubs issued demands that the Icelandic Football Association calls an annual meeting immediately to elect a new board. The clubs are Einherji, √çR, Magni, Leiknir F. Hamar, V√∂lsungur, V√≠√∞ir, Njar√∞v√≠k, and KV. Their statement reads that the reputation of Icelandic football has been greatly damaged, making it necessary to call an annual meeting and shape reactions that for the future will earn the trust of all of the Associated clubs as well as the community as a whole. Longtime KS√ç sponsors such as Coca-cola Iceland, Landsbankinn Bank, and Icelandair have also been in touch with the association requesting more information. A press release from Icelandic Football Association stated that their representatives will be in touch with all major sponsors to respond to ‚Äúloud demands from major sponsors that real change will be effected within the Icelandic football and the association.‚Äù They added that they appreciate the ‚Äúclear message‚Äù they have received that believable steps towards change must be taken. The board had another meeting yesterday, which lasted into the night. Following that meeting, it was announced that the entire board would be resigning and calling for an extraordinary meeting of the Association in four weeks. Invites with information on the date, schedule and organisation of the meeting will be sent out to associated clubs within the next few days, the notice states. It is also noted that the board would like to express that a workgroup‚Äôs efforts to reexamine reactions to sexual offences and violence within the association, and how victims have been supported and will be supported moving forward, will remain a priority. This is in tune with challenges from √çslenskur toppf√≥tbolti and the wishes of Associated Clubs, as well as societal pressure to call for an extraordinary meeting. The board will also meet with UEFA and FIFA representatives to reassure them that no interference with the Icelandic Football Association will be necessary. While the Board and Director of the Icelandic Football Association have now resigned, the Association‚Äôs CEO Klara Bjartmarz has no intentions of resigning. In yesterday‚Äôs 10 o‚Äôclock news, Klara told R√öV: ‚ÄúI am an employee of the football association and have been working here for 27 years, which is a long time. I‚Äôm ready to keep going and will work with a new board when that time comes.‚Äù √çslenskur Toppf√≥tbolti has also called for Klara‚Äôs resignation in order to regain the public and the football leagues‚Äô trust in the Association. As the Director has resigned, the power to lay Klara off as an employee of the Association lies with the board but according to one of the acting directors of the association G√≠sli G√≠slason, they do not intend to use it. He stated to V√≠sir that: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important that the CEO‚Äôs work will be handled fairly.‚Äù When asked if √û√≥rhildur‚Äôs case was the only one reported to the Association, Klara revealed that the Icelandic Football Association also had knowledge of an incident of group rape. She stated that she had heard of the case this summer and that it was currently ‚Äúin process‚Äù within the Association. She added that another incident of the sexual offence had been reported to a board member this weekend. She does not know if the new incident also involves a member of the national team. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt ask about specifics but I know that a board member was notified, passed it along immediately, and started the process. Sexual offences are a sensitive subject and shouldn‚Äôt be passed around. We should make sure that they are treated but we shouldn‚Äôt discuss them if it‚Äôs not needed.‚Äù V√≠sir reports that it‚Äôs likely that the group rape in question concerns a woman around thirty who stated on Instagram this May that two Icelandic men had raped her in another country in 2010. They were well known then and one is quite famous today. They have both been members of the national team and one of them is one of the biggest stars of the men‚Äôs national team. *content warning* In her post, the woman states: ‚ÄúI had drunk some alcohol but I suspect something was put in my drink, could have been anything. To make a long story short, I threw up over one of them in the taxi on the way to their hotel, and again in the hotel bed, but they didn‚Äôt let that stop them and took turns raping me where I lay in the bed naked from the waist down with vomit in my hair, face, and clothes,‚Äù the post read. The woman was around 20 when the incident occurred. She added that not a day passes in the eleven years that have passed that she wasn‚Äôt reminded of it. She intended to press charges, hired a lawyer and was deposed with the police. Everywhere, she was told that the case would be difficult to pursue as it had happened in another country and there were two against one. She was asked over and over again if she wanted to go through that. ‚ÄúAfter months of waiting, I decided not to pursue it any further, I wasn‚Äôt strong enough, I couldn‚Äôt go through more emotionally.‚Äù She posted her story under her own name and reposted it this weekend, tagging the Icelandic Football Association. Footballer Gar√∞ar Gunnlaugsson weighed in on Twitter yesterday, saying that it would take more than new leadership to fix the toxic football culture. He asks boys in football to take part in the fight to create a healthier environment within football where misogyny and racism is a thing of the past. ‚Äúwell boys,‚Äù Gar√∞ar wrote. ‚ÄúThe least part of the problem has been laid off, the board of the Icelandic Football Association. That‚Äôs not where the problem lies, the problem is largely rooted in this toxic culture we‚Äôve grown up in as athletes, be it amateurs or professional players. We have the opportunity to change the culture and make sure young footballers grow up in a healthier environment where misogyny and minority prejudice is a thing of the past. It‚Äôs not an overnight change, it will take time but let‚Äôs make it start with us! Let‚Äôs be role models!‚Äù Gar√∞ar called increased education for players and increased training for coaches ‚Äúa minimum requirement.‚Äù Gar√∞ar still plays football professionally in Iceland but has also played in Scotland, Sweden, Bulgaria, Austria and Germany over the course of his career. He was also a member of the men‚Äôs national team.

headline: Icelandic Football Shaken By Accounts of Sexual Assault
body: Director of the Football Association of Iceland Gu√∞ni Bergsson is resigning following criticism on the Association‚Äôs behaviour concerning revelations on sexual violence by members of the Icelandic football league, including national team players. The Association‚Äôs board has issued an apology but does not intend to resign. Two members of the national football team have been taken out of the line-up in three upcoming qualifying matches for the World Cup. On August 13, Hanna Bj√∂rg Vilhj√°lmsd√≥ttir penned an article calling for an end to the silence surrounding sexual assaults and domestic violence committed by Icelandic football players, citing stories revealed on social media in response to a different high-profile sexual assault case. The Icelandic football association was pressed to respond, finally stating that they dealt with all incidents of violence through appropriate channels and denying accusation of silencing. Gu√∞ni Bergsson stated in an interview with R√öV that but they couldn‚Äôt react unless they were officially notified and that they had received no such notifications. In an interview with R√öV¬†last Friday, √û√≥rhildur Gy√∞a Arnarsd√≥ttir revealed that in 2017, she was sexually and physically assaulted by a member of the national football team. She and another woman who was assaulted that same night reported the incidents to the police. Months later, her father was going to attend a national team match when he realised that the man who had assaulted his daughter was in the line-up. He contacted the Director of the Icelandic Football Association, Gu√∞ni Bergsson, and notified him of the incident. Gu√∞ni contacted both of √û√≥rhildur‚Äôs parents and stated that this was a serious matter and there would be consequences. He then removed the player from the national team for a time. When contacting the Football association director, √û√≥rhildur‚Äôs father also contacted the President of Iceland, who replied to his letter, stating that he had discussed the matter with Gu√∞ni himself, but on account of his office, he could not become directly involved in the matter. √û√≥rhildur noted that Gu√∞ni should have thus been well aware that a member of the national football team had been accused of violence. Following this communication, √û√≥rhildur states she was contacted by the Football Association‚Äôs lawyers, who offered her financial compensation in exchange for signing a non-disclosure agreement. √û√≥rhildur turned down the offer and was then contacted by another lawyer on behalf of the football player who had assaulted her. The player confessed to his actions and paid her damages. √û√≥rhildur states that she has no grievances with the football player but she wasn‚Äôt expecting him to be chosen for the national team when the Football Association knew of his violent actions. Gu√∞ni Bergsson later admitted that it was a mistake to state that no reports of violence had reached the ears of the football association, claiming that he misremembered the incident, believing it to have been only a physical assault, not a sexual assault. The Football Association issued a statement that the lawyers offering the non-disclosure agreement had not been working for them directly but √û√≥rhildur disputed that statement. The first lawyer who contacted her had introduced himself as the football player‚Äôs lawyer but following that conversation, she contacted a legal representative who did some research and then told her that the lawyer was working for KS√ç. Later, when another lawyer working for the football player contacted her, the matter was resolved. The interview caused an uproar on social media, especially as the case comes on the heels of another high-profile sexual assault case which shook the nation. In that case, popular media personality and podcaster S√∂lvi Tryggvason was accused of sexual assault. Another recent high-profile case of a football player accused of sexual assault is the case of Everton-player Gylfi √û√≥r Sigur√∞sson, accused of sexual abuse offended in the UK. Stakeholders within the football industry as well as ministers in Iceland‚Äôs government have expressed concern and requested clarification from the football association. The board of the Icelandic Football Association met on Saturday for a meeting that lasted long into the night, but was ultimately inconclusive. Another meeting began at 10:00 AM on Sunday, and the two women in the boardmet with a representative from St√≠gam√≥t women‚Äôs shelter, as well as Hanna Bj√∂rg Vilhj√°lmsd√≥ttir, who recently penned an article condemning the football association for silencing discussion on reports of sexual violence on behalf of national team members. At 4:00 PM, Football Association staff were called into a meeting. Just before 5:00 PM, the Football Association of Iceland issued a short notice on Twitter, stating that Gu√∞ni Bergsson was resigning as Director of the Football Association and more information would be released shortly. Later that day, the Football Association issued a formal apology, translated in full below. Two players who were slated to play with the national team for the three World Cup qualifying matches have been pulled from the line-up: Kolbeinn Sig√æ√≥rsson and R√∫nar M√°r Sigurj√≥nsson. They will be replaced by Vi√∞ar √ñrn Kjartansson and G√≠sli Eyj√≥lfsson. The Icelandic Football Association‚Äôs website stated that Kolbeinn will not be participating on grounds of the decision made by the Association board whereas R√∫nar M√°r withdrew due to injuries and personal reasons. According to visir.is, Kolbeinn is the football player who assaulted √û√≥rhildur in 2017. √û√≥rhildur Gy√∞a called this development a good start but said more action was needed, stating: ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt blame the protection of perpetrators within the Icelandic Football Association on one guy. A new board is needed, not just a new director.‚Äù The Board of the Icelandic Football Association‚Äôs Statement in full:  Dear victims. We, the board of the Icelandic Football Association believe you and apologise wholeheartedly. We know that we as the parties responsible have let you down and we intend to do better. The board has met over the past few days concerning the serious allegations that have been brought against the association recently on silencing sexual assault cases. We take the matter very seriously. Right now, we will start to work with outside professionals on reviewing all responses to sexual assault and violence within the association and how we have and will support victims. A group of professionals will be established and the Board of the Icelandic Football Association resolves to deal with these matters fully and completely and follow the advice of the group. Additionally, we would like to ask victims or others who have information on serious violence within the association to come forward. We will welcome you with open arms. We want the cases to be handled appropriately and we want to ensure that the responsibility of the violence will be placed on the shoulders of perpetrators, not victims.  We intend to fix things that have been broken and inspect the culture that exists within the football movement from the ground up in order to make sure everyone working within the industry experiences welfare and safety, while listening to victims and taking their interests into consideration.  On account of the statement the board issued on August 17 in response to accusations of violence on behalf of the men‚Äôs national team, it should be noted that the statement was based on the limited information the board had at the time, lacking data and further information that have later come to light. We apologise to Hanna Bj√∂rg Vilhj√°lmsd√≥ttir and others who stood at the front lines pointing out the violence within the Icelandic Football Association for the statement which belittled their accusations and assumed no responsibility nor sincerity.  It has already been revealed that the Director of the Football Association has resigned and accepted responsibility for how matters were handled. Until further decisions have been made, the Deputy Director will take over his work. All board members have considered their position. In order to ensure the uninterrupted operation of the association, the board‚Äôs conclusion is that it is reasonable that they keep their positions until the association‚Äôs next annual meeting in February of next year when board members are voted on.  We want to reiterate that the general staff of the Football Association has performed their duties with care and loyalty and holds no responsibility for the events that are unfolding.  This great wave that has been crashing for the past weeks has touched us all. A part of the largest volunteer movement in Iceland, what KS√ç does and says, matters. We have never been as aware of that as we are now and will seek the help of the community to make radical changes, support victims and be a part of the solution. This project will take time but we will begin right away.  The football movement is part of the community and we as a community all need to do better to support victims and fight sexual violence.  The Board of the Football Association: √Åsgeir √Åsgeirsson, Bjarni √ìlafur Birkisson, Bj√∂rn Fri√∞√æj√≥fsson, Borghildur Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir, G√≠sli G√≠slason, Gu√∞j√≥n Bjarni H√°lfd√°narson, Ingi Sigur√∞sson, Jakob Sk√∫lason, J√≥hann Torfason, Magn√∫s Gylfason, Orri Vignir Hl√∂√∞versson, Ragnhildur Sk√∫lad√≥ttir, T√≥mas √û√≥roddsson, Valgeir Sigur√∞sson, √ûorsteinn Gunnarsson and √û√≥roddur Hjaltal√≠n.

headline: Cycling Race a Rare Opportunity for Riders
body: More than 100 cyclists took part in a socially distanced group ride on Thursday from Siglufj√∂r√∞ur to Akureyri in North Iceland, R√öV reports. The event was part of the Akureyri Cycling Festival, which started last Saturday and will end on Sunday. Competitors were organized into different race groups according to distance, the shortest of which, for adults, was 78 km [48 mi] and the longest of which was 102.8 km [639 mi]. The longest route took cyclists through the H√©√∞insfj√∂r√∞ur and M√∫lag√∂ng tunnels. And although climate conditions aren‚Äôt ideal in the tunnels, festival chair √Årni F. Sigur√∞sson admits, being able to cycle through them is a unique opportunity. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs humid and cool,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúand M√∫lag√∂ng tunnel is one-way and very narrow, which makes it a bit of a struggle. But there‚Äôs no other opportunity to bike a route like that in a competition.‚Äù √Årni said that some people withdrew from the race because of the current rise in COVID infections, but assured that organizers were conscientious about safety measures. Riders were split into smaller groups, some of which never had reason to cross paths with one another. The award competition was also split between two locations and top prizes were given out before all competitors finished the race. ‚ÄúWe gave [winners the awards] right away so that people wouldn‚Äôt gather together and wait.‚Äù This is the fifth or sixth time the Akureyri Cycling Festival has been held, said √Årni, and he encouraged people to take a look at the remaining schedule of events (here) as all events are open to the public spectators and take place outside over a large area, in compliance with current COVID guidelines.

headline: John Snorri and Companions Likely Reached K2 Summit
body: Icelandic mountaineer John Snorri Sigurj√≥nsson and his two companions likely reached the summit of K2 before perishing in a storm on the way down. The trio set out to summit the mountain, the world‚Äôs second-highest after Everest, last winter but lost contact with base camp on February 5, 2021. Search and rescue efforts in the following days were unsuccessful and their bodies were only found on the mountain earlier this week. A tweet from ‚ÄúTeam Ali Sadpara,‚Äù the Twitter account previously belonging to John Snorri‚Äôs climbing companion of the same name, revealed that Ali‚Äôs son Sajid and other climbers were transporting the three bodies further down the mountain to where they would hopefully be retrieved by helicopter at a later date. ‚ÄúAt the moment, immediate retrieval efforts can harm the bodies as well as pose great risks to people involved,‚Äù the Tweet stated. Sajid Sadpara is securing the bodies of fallen climbers to a safe place. At the moment, immediate retrieval efforts can harm the bodies as well as pose great risks to people involved. A consensual course of action will be made for final retrieval. We are proud of Sajid & team 1/2 pic.twitter.com/ub2uFuUd0R ‚Äî Team Ali Sadpara (@ali_sadpara) July 28, 2021  The team states that ‚Äúas per instruments and presence of fig8 it is now confirmed that climbers had summited K2 in winters [sic] and were frozen to death due to storm on their way back.‚Äù A memorial plaque for John Snorri has been placed at the mountain‚Äôs Gilkey Memorial. In a statement sent to media, his widow L√≠na M√≥ey wrote: ‚ÄúJohn‚Äôs family wants to thank you for the warmth, support, and care that we have been shown over the past months and we would like to reiterate our sincere thanks to everyone who has taken part in the search for John Snorri, Ali, and J Pablo.‚Äù

headline: Reykjav√≠k Marathon Hasn‚Äôt Run Out of Hope for 2021 Race
body: Organizers are considering what, if any, options they have for holding the Reykjav√≠k Marathon this year in a way that abides by current COVID control measures, V√≠sir reports. The marathon was not held last year because of the pandemic. The Reykjav√≠k Marathon is the biggest race of the year in Iceland and is currently set to take place on August 21. About 15,000 people take part every year. However, current gathering restrictions are set at a maximum of 200 people. Current COVID control measures will be in effect until August 13 and there‚Äôs a fair amount of uncertainty about what will happen after that. Silja √ölfarsd√≥ttir, information officer for the Reykjav√≠k Sports Association (√çBR), says that organizers haven‚Äôt given up hope of holding the race in some form this year. Staff is currently assessing the situation in consultation with civil defense authorities. ‚ÄúWe were pretty optimistic about being able to hold the race this year, but we‚Äôre taking a closer look at it. We‚Äôre still relatively optimistic, though.‚Äù A number of socially distanced running initiatives were launched last year when the marathon was cancelled and gyms had to be closed. One was ‚ÄòRun Your Way!‚Äô which encouraged would-be marathoners to run on their own and collect money for charity. Another was ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs Run Around the World,‚Äô which allowed participants to participate in a virtual relay race around the world. Silja says that there are a lot of ideas on the table, but can‚Äôt comment on which direction race organizers are leaning just yet. ‚ÄúThe dream, of course, is to be able to hold the marathon, because the [donations collected] are so important for all the charities.‚Äù She says that participating runners have been understanding about the uncertainty: ‚ÄúI think people have just gotten pretty used to this and know that people just need a little time to make decisions about these things.‚Äù √çBR will announce its decision about this year‚Äôs Reykjav√≠k Marathon in the coming days.

headline: Broke Her Own Icelandic Record at Tokyo Olympics
body: Icelandic swimmer Sn√¶fr√≠√∞ur S√≥l J√≥runnard√≥ttir broke her own Icelandic 200-metre freestyle record at her first-ever Olympic event in Tokyo today. She completed the event in 2:00.20, beating her previous record of 2:00.50 by 30/100 of a second. Despite the impressive personal success, Sn√¶fr√≠√∞ur was the last of eight swimmers in Heat 3 and therefore will not proceed to the semifinals for the event. The swimmer will, however, compete in the 100-metre freestyle on Wednesday. Sn√¶fr√≠√∞ur is one of four Icelanders competing in the Olympics this month and was one of Iceland‚Äôs two flagbearers in the opening ceremony last Friday. She is from Hverager√∞i, South Iceland and now lives in Denmark.

headline: Two Bodies Found on K2: One May Be John Snorri
body: Update July 26, 2:49 PM: A third body has been found on K2 and it is thus exceedingly likely the two unidentified bodies belong to John Snorri Sigurj√≥nsson and Juan Pablo Mohr. The remains of two climbers have been found on K2, ExplorersWeb reports. One of the bodies has been identified as Ali Sadpara, and the other is believed to be his expedition companion, Icelandic mountaineer John Snorri Sigurj√≥nsson. The two were last heard from on February 5 some 400 metres from the top of the mountain, which is Earth‚Äôs second-highest after Mt. Everest. Search and rescue teams were unsuccessful in finding the men. A Sherpa team found the remains of two climbers on the mountain earlier today. One was identified as Pakistani climber Ali Sadpara while the other was face down and covered in ice, making it difficult to identify. The body was dressed in a yellow and black suit: both John Snorri and Chilean Juan Pablo Mohr were wearing those colours when they were last seen heading up the mountain. However, an ExplorersWeb source stated that the Sherpa team believed the body was John Snorri‚Äôs. At 8,611m [28,251ft], K2 is the second-highest mountain on Earth and is considered a much more challenging climb than Mt. Everest. In 2017, John Snorri became the first Icelander to top the mountain, which is located on the China-Pakistan border. He then set his sights on being the first person ever to ascend the peak during winter but was beaten to that goal by a team of Nepalese mountaineers in January 2021. Last February, John Snorri was making his second attempt to ascend K2 in winter when he and his expedition lost contact with base camp. There has been speculation that John Snorri and Ali did in fact reach the summit of K2 after they lost contact on February 5 and landed in trouble on their way back down the mountain.

headline: Two Swimmers to Carry Icelandic Flag During Olympic Opening Ceremony
body: Swimmers Sn√¶fr√≠√∞ur S√≥l J√≥runnard√≥ttir and Anton Sveinn McKee will carry the Icelandic flag during today‚Äôs Opening Ceremony for the 2020 Olympics, R√öV reports. This will be the first time that participating countries will have two flag-bearers, one man and one woman. Team Iceland is made up of four athletes including Gu√∞ni Valur Gu√∞nason, who will compete in discus throw, and √Åsgeir Sigurgeirsson, who will compete in 10-metre air pistol shooting. Anton Sveinn will swim in the 200-metre breaststroke, while Sn√¶fr√≠√∞ur S√≥l will swim in two events: the 100- and 200-metre freestyle. Iceland will be first team to enter the arena after the Team Greece, which always enters first, and the IOC Refugee Olympic team. The procession will proceed according to Japanese alphabetization, making Iceland ‚Äì which is called aisurando („Ç¢„Ç§„Çπ„É©„É≥„Éâ) in Japanese ‚Äì first in line. The Opening Ceremony will begin at 8:00 PM in Japan, which is 11:00 AM in Iceland. R√öV will broadcast the ceremony live.

headline: Four Icelanders Compete in Olympics this Month
body: Swimmer Sn√¶fr√≠√∞ur S√≥l J√≥runnard√≥ttir will be the only Icelandic woman competing in this year‚Äôs Olympics in Tokyo, mbl.is reports. There will be four Icelandic competitors at the games this year. This is the smallest Icelandic team to attend the Summer Olympics since 1964, when they were also held in the Japanese capital. Sn√¶fr√≠√∞ur was allocated a quota place in the Olympic swimming competition where she will compete in both the 100-metre and 200-metre freestyle. She reached the B qualifying standard before the games in March this year. These are her first Olympic games. Sn√¶fr√≠√∞ur will swim in the preliminary rounds in the 200-metre freestyle on July 26 and the preliminary rounds in the 100-metre freestyle on July 28. The other three Icelanders competing in the games are swimmer Anton Sveinn McKee, who qualified for the games last year, and marksman √Åsgeir Sigurgeirsson and discus thrower Gu√∞ni Valur Gu√∞nason, who were allocated quota seats.

headline: Ultra Marathon in Icelandic Highland This Summer
body: The Environment Agency of Iceland has granted Arctic Yeti Ltd. permission to hold a so-called ‚ÄúUltra Marathon‚Äù in Iceland‚Äôs highland this summer. It‚Äôs the first time such a run has been held in Iceland: participants will have six days to traverse 280 kilometres (174 miles) between June 26 and July 3. Arctic Yeti CEO Javi G√°lves told mbl.is the company hopes to make the marathon an annual event. It is estimated that there will be about 50 participants in the marathon, which will partly take place around Fjallabak and √ûj√≥rs√°rdalur, protected areas in Iceland‚Äôs highland. The running route contains a mixture of main roads in the area, dirt roads, and highland hiking trails. Marathon participants will stay at campsites within √ûj√≥rs√°rdalur valley for the duration of the run. The campsites will be set up by Arctic Yeti, who will provide tents and other necessities to runners. Participants will be required to carry organic waste bags for their personal use, which will be disposed of in designated areas. Arctic Yeti is a Spanish travel agency that specialises in trips to the Nordic countries. They have previously held an Ultra Marathon in Costa Rica.

headline: League of Legends Tournament Attracts 600 People to Reykjav√≠k
body:
One of the world‚Äôs largest e-sporting events went underway in Reykjav√≠k yesterday, R√öV reports. An estimated 600 people have traveled to Iceland in connection to the event, which pits competitors against each other in two different tournaments. Strict social restrictions are in effect in the Laugardalsh√∂ll sporting arena. Last year, Riot Games‚Äîone of the largest video game companies in the world‚Äîwas forced to cancel its League of Legends Mid-Season Invitational (or MSI for short) in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.¬† This year, as countries across the world ramped up their vaccination campaigns, Riot Games announced that the tournament would go ahead in May and that it would be held in Reykjav√≠k. In addition to the MSI, Riot Games also announced that a second tournament, the so-called Valorant Champions Tour (VCT) Masters Reykjavik, would be held alongside the first. The VCT is the first live international tournament for the Valorant video game.
 According to event organizers, Iceland was chosen as a venue for the tournament as it ‚Äúranked first‚Äù with regard to relevant criteria, ranging from the state of the working environment to stability, in its broadest context. In an interview with R√öV yesterday, Nick Troop‚Äîdirector of the tournament‚Äîexplained that Riot Games had approached Business Iceland (√çslandsstofa) with the idea of hosting a tournament in Iceland: ‚ÄúIt was a win-win for everyone. Iceland is a wonderful country that has responded extremely effectively to¬†the pandemic. We are grateful to be here.‚Äù This week, Troop and his cohort traveled to Iceland alongside 11 professional teams from all over the world, in addition to personnel comprising approximately 400 people. ‚ÄúWe reach many millions of people from all over the world, across forty different media platforms,‚Äù Troop stated. Asked how many people would attend the event, Troop estimated that somewhere¬†between 500-600 people, including professional players and personnel, would be in attendance.¬† Strict social restrictions will be in effect at the tournament. No one is allowed to enter the Laugardalsh√∂ll arena without submitting a negative PCR test. ‚ÄúIn collaboration with Business Iceland and the Icelandic health authorities, we decided that every traveler, whether or not they were vaccinated, would self isolate for five days,‚Äù Troop explained. ‚ÄúOnly after this period of isolation, and only after having received a second negative PCR test, would they be allowed to attend the tournament.‚Äù Event organizers will also be taking the temperatures of attendees and tracking the interactions between personnel to ensure effective tracking in the event of an infection.¬† The tournament goes underway as 17 passenger planes are expected to arrive at Keflav√≠k Airport this weekend. The arrivals make for the busiest travel weekend in Iceland this year, with eight passenger planes expected to arrive on Saturday and nine on Sunday. There are currently three quarantine hotels in operation in the Greater Reykjav√≠k Area, capable of receiving approximately 500 guests.¬† In early April, Iceland‚Äôs Court of Appeal confirmed the district court‚Äôs ruling that authorities cannot require people to spend their quarantine at quarantine hotels when arriving in the country. The ruling mandated clearer requirements for home quarantine, regarding, for example, housing and rules of conduct. However, those travelers who are unable to stay in a home quarantine that fulfills the requirements will need to stay at a quarantine facility. No fee shall be collected for the stay.

headline: Unemployed Icelanders Offered Training and Jobs as eSports Coaches
body: Unemployed Icelanders will be able to access free training in eSports coaching, thanks to a new collaboration between the Social Affairs Ministry and the Icelandic eSports Association. Iceland‚Äôs government has invested ISK 10 million ($78,000/‚Ç¨64,000) in developing and implementing the coaching course specifically for locals who are currently between jobs. Participants will receive a six-month work contract upon completion of training. One goal of the project is to create permanent jobs in the growing eSports industry. ‚ÄúI am very excited about this collaboration with the Icelandic eSports Association, where we are hitting two birds with one stone,‚Äù stated √Åsmundur Einar Da√∞ason, Minister of Social Affairs and Children. ‚ÄúCreate exciting opportunities for unemployed individuals and at the same time strengthen eSports infrastructure. There is a lot of strength and growth in eSports in Iceland, but the industry is young and therefore the infrastructure in clubs is often lacking. There has also been a lack of individuals who have experience in training young people, and it is very important that we get individuals with skills and experience into [the eSports industry].‚Äù √ìlafur Hrafn Steinarsson, chairman of the Icelandic eSports Association, celebrated the initiative. ‚ÄúThis project is extremely important for eSports in Iceland and a great recognition of the excellent work that has been done for eSports in recent years.‚Äù Esports are a form of organised video game competitions, played both individually and in teams. The industry has been growing globally as well as within Iceland, which boasts over 20 eSports clubs that provide eSport activities and training for over 600 children. ‚ÄúThis project enables us to be at the forefront of developments in this field globally,‚Äù √ìlafur Hrafn stated of the initiative. ‚ÄúThere are exciting times ahead in this new field.‚Äù Iceland‚Äôs government put together a task force last December to write a policy concerning the eSports industry. The group is expected to finish their work at the end of this month.

headline: No Traces of Icelandic Mountaineer on K2
