The imported sandwiches, which are sold under the brand name Food on Foot, caught the attention of Fri√∞rik √Årnason, the owner of H√≥tel Brei√∞dalsv√≠k in East Iceland. ‚ÄúWe import all sorts of things to Iceland, but it never occurred to me that I‚Äôd see imported premade sandwiches from Lithuania in a shop in South Iceland,‚Äù Fri√∞rik wrote in a post on his Facebook page. ‚ÄúTo be honest, I was disappointed to see this, thinking about the environment, carbon footprints, and sustainability. I was even more shocked when I saw that the imported sandwiches are half the price of the sandwiches that are made here, with the same ingredients. It‚Äôs a head-scratcher for me.‚Äù The sandwiches, which are shipped frozen to Iceland, are imported by the Reykjav√≠k-based company Dan√≥l. Managing director Mar√≠a J√≥na Sam√∫¬≠els¬≠d√≥tt¬≠ir provided a written response to Mbl after being contacted about the new product and said that the sandwiches are high-quality and have received a good response on the Icelandic market. When asked how a sandwich made in and shipped all the way from Lithuania could be cheaper than a sandwich made in Iceland, Mar√≠a J√≥na wrote: ‚ÄúOf course we can‚Äôt speak to other parties‚Äô price points, but Dan√≥l has a good business relationship with the supplier, which of course, is also producing for a much larger market than the one in Iceland. And as a result, consumers here in Iceland enjoy economies of scale.‚Äù Mar√≠a J√≥na ended by saying that the primary purchasers of the Lithuanian sandwiches are caf√©s in rural areas (‚Äúoften remote villages‚Äù) that ‚Äúsee that favorable prices, product quality, and ease of service go hand in hand.‚Äù

headline: Smi√∞jan Brewery First to Sell Directly to Customers
body: Smi√∞jan Brewery in V√≠k was the first to sell alcohol directly to customers when it officially got its license on Wednesday, July 13. In a statement to Morgunbla√∞i√∞, Sveinn Sigur√∞sson, one of the founders of Smi√∞jan, stated that it was important for the brewery to finally be able to sell directly. A majority of the customers that visit the brewery are foreign tourists and beer enthusiasts, and now they will be able to take beer home with them more easily. At the moment, Smi√∞jan just has a restaurant and bar, but they are planning to significantly increase their production to meet the rising demand of direct sales. Smi√∞jan has been offering brewery tours but expressed frustration that up until now, they were not allowed to sell alcohol directly to their customers after these tours. Smi√∞jan has also been frustrated that getting their product onto V√≠nb√∫√∞in shelves also takes several weeks, meaning that customers are not getting the freshest product possible. Iceland has, up until now, had a state monopoly on alcohol. All alcohol must be purchased at V√≠nb√∫√∞in, the state alcohol distributor, except for some light beer which is available in grocery stores. Al√æingi recently relaxed these restrictions, leading to a boom in online alcohol sales by private retailers. ¬† ¬†

headline: Six Icelandic Firms on Yale‚Äôs List of Companies Doing Business in Russia, Three Shouldn‚Äôt Be
body: The Yale School of Management names six Icelandic businesses on its list of companies still doing business in Russia, but R√öV reports that three of them have no presence or operations in Russia at all, and one never did in the first place. Attempts have been made to contact the manager of the Yale list, a professor and dean at the university, to make appropriate corrections, but these attempts have not been successful. Failing grades  The list, simply dubbed ‚ÄúYale CELI List of Companies‚Äù (CELI stands for Chief Executive Leadership Institute‚Äù) was started on February 28, days after Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine. Since then, the responses of over 1,200 companies regarding their presence and business activities in Russia have been tracked by Professor Jeffrey Sonnenfeld and the Yale Research Team. ‚ÄúOriginally a simple ‚Äòwithdraw‚Äô vs. ‚Äòremain‚Äô list,‚Äù reads the preface, ‚Äúour list of companies now consists of five categories‚Äîgraded on a school-style letter grade scale of A-F for the completeness of withdrawal.‚Äù The CELI list is said to be ‚Äúupdated continuously.‚Äù As of July 8, 2022, its headline read ‚ÄúOver 1,000 Companies Have Curtailed Operations in Russia‚ÄîBut Some Remain.‚Äù As of that time, six Icelandic companies were included on the list. Three of these‚ÄîHampi√∞jan, Knarr Maritime, and S√¶plast‚Äîwere given a grade of F, ‚ÄúDigging In: Defying Demands for Exit or Reduction of Activities.‚Äù Two other Icelandic companies‚ÄîMarel and Naust Marine‚Äîwere graded D, ‚ÄúBuying Time: Holding Off New Investments/Development‚Äù and one, Eimskip, was graded C, ‚ÄúScaling Back: Reducing Current Operations.‚Äù No operations in Russia, but still on the list R√öV contacted the public relations officer for the shipping company Eimskip, who said the company had ceased sailing to Russia right after the invasion and moreover, had not had any operations in the country since 2019, when it closed its Russian office. The PR officer said that Eimskip has attempted to contact Prof. Sonnenfeld to correct its record without success. According to the Yale list, Knarr Maritime, has ‚Äúmembers still operating in Russia.‚Äù R√öV reports, however, that the company closed its office in Russia two years ago and no longer has any operations there. S√¶plast, a company that designs and manufactures insulated tubs and pallets for use in the fishing industry, issued a statement on its website on Thursday, saying that it has no operations in Russia, and never has. ‚ÄúThe company has no office in Russia and no employee works there,‚Äù reads the statement. ‚ÄúS√¶plast sold tubs to Russia for many years, either directly or through agents and/or independent distributors, but since Russia invaded Ukraine, no products have been sold there or delivered from S√¶plast to the Russian market. Allegations about S√¶plast‚Äôs operations and trade with Russia are therefore incorrect.‚Äù According to S√¶plast general manager Da√∞i Valdimarsson, the company has attempted to convey this information to the managers of the Yale list but has had no success. S√¶plast has also been in touch with the Embassy of Ukraine to Iceland (located in Finland) via the Iceland Chamber of Commerce. Still have offices in Russia Naust Marine is one of two Icelandic companies given a D grade, meaning that they‚Äôve paused but not ceased operations in Russia. Four years ago, Naust Marine signed a major deal to sell electric winches to Russia for use on its trawlers. General Manager Bjarni √û√≥r Gunnlaugsson told R√öV the deal is at a complete standstill, but it‚Äôs unclear what that means for future operations. Fellow D recipient Marel, a food processing company, published a statement on its website on March 9, saying that it ‚Äústrongly condemns the military actions of the Russian government in Ukraine‚Äù and that it had ‚Äútaken the decision to pause all new projects in Russia.‚Äù The statement continued by saying that Marel has a sales and service operation in Russia, and employees 70 people. It will ‚Äúcontinue to prioritize the safety and wellbeing of our employees‚Äù and ‚Äúmaintain our dedicated teams in the Ukraine and Russia and our office in Russia, despite expected lower utilization in the near future.‚Äù The statement also added that ‚ÄúMarel‚Äôs annual revenues and order book in Russia and Ukraine amount to approximately 4% of total.‚Äù R√öV was unable to speak to management at fishing manufacturer Hampi√∞jan, as they were apparently all attending a meeting on Friday. The company has an office in Murmansk, Russia. At time of writing, there was no information on Hampi√∞jan‚Äôs website indicating whether the Murmansk office is still operational, or if the its business activities in Russia have changed at all since the invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Sharp Rise In Demand and Price of Hotel Accomodation
body: The Statistics Office of Iceland reports that overnight stays in Icelandic hotels have nearly tripled since the same time in the previous year. The primary driver of this increased demand came from the tourism industry, with tourists making up some 79% of overnight stays. The largest increase has been recorded in the capital region. Increased prices have accompanied the increased demand for accommodation. In a recent article in Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞, Icelandic traveller √ûorsteinn Gunnarsson stated that just a three-night stay in Akureyri would have cost him some ISK 263,000 ($1,974 / ‚Ç¨1,888). √ûorsteinn claims that these prices raise questions of ethics and greed, and he regrets that Icelanders cannot tour their own country, choosing instead to vacation in Tenerife, for example. Snorri P√©tur Eggertson, managing director of Kea Hotel‚Äôs sales and marketing division, did not dispute √ûorsteinn‚Äôs claims but attributed the rise in price to the global pandemic, supply chain shocks, inflation, and increased numbers in tourism. According to the Statistics Office, there were already 558,000 overnight stays in Iceland in May, with more projected for the coming summer months.

headline: New Collaboration May Make It Possible to Hopp from Bus to E-Scooter in Same Trip
body: A new collaboration between electric scooter company Hopp and the Str√¶t√≥ bus service could make it possible for commuters to easily transfer from bus to scooter using the same app, V√≠sir reports. When Hopp launched in Reykjav√≠k in 2019, many observers thought it was a death knell for Str√¶t√≥‚Äîthat given the option of jumping on an e-scooter, many riders would stop taking the bus entirely. This hasn‚Äôt proven to be the case, though. In fact, the two transport modes seem to complement one another, as evidenced by the e-scooters often strewn around city bus shelters. Two modes of transit, one app Hopp was started by software developers and so it only makes sense that they‚Äôd be thinking about new ways to integrate their own software and app with Str√¶t√≥‚Äôs. Hopp CEO S√¶unn √ìsk Unnsteinsd√≥ttir says she believes it should be possible, for instance, for the company‚Äôs e-scooters to pop up on the bus map in the Str√¶t√≥ app. ‚ÄúThis is, of course, super important, because we know people are starting to pick up the Hopp app to look for scooters when they‚Äôre on the bus and coming into the city, for instance,‚Äù she explained. Both Hopp and Str√¶t√≥ would also like it to be possible to use the same app to pay for a trip that is split between bus and scooter. The technology exists ‚ÄúWhether it‚Äôs a credit with Hopp or [the Str√¶t√≥ app] redirects you to the Hopp app, these are just technical implementations that need to happen when the conversation gets underway,‚Äù continued S√¶unn. Str√¶t√≥ CEO J√≥hannes R√∫narsson agrees. The technology exists, he says, it‚Äôs just a matter of kick-starting the process. Other e-scooters have entered the Icelandic market, but Hopp is still the scooter of choice in Reykjav√≠k, and in Iceland more generally. Outside of the capital, the company also has fleets in Akranes, Akureyri, Egilssta√∞ir, Hverager√∞i, Reykjanesb√¶r, Selfoss, and the Westman Islands. Abroad, it has e-scooters in three cities in Spain, as well as Norway, Greece, and the Faroe Islands. Hopp records some 6,000 trips a day on its scooters and S√¶unn foresees a day where there are e-scooter docks next to every bus station in the city. The company now employs 50 people and is growing its fleet from 1,000 scooters around the capital to 3,000. It is also looking to expand into nearby √Årb√¶r and Grafarvogur, as well as a number of other towns in Iceland and abroad (Poland, Hungary, Italy) in the coming year.

headline: Icelandic Breweries Can Now Sell Directly to Customers
body: Starting tomorrow, July 1, breweries in Iceland will be permitted to sell their alcoholic products directly to customers. The change is thanks to a parliamentary bill passed on June 15 that somewhat relaxes the state monopoly on alcohol sales. While some say it‚Äôs high time alcohol was available for sale outside of state-run stores, others are wary increased availability will lead to higher rates of alcoholism. The changes are long overdue, according to √ìlafur Stephensen, CEO of the Icelandic Federation of Trade. He told R√öV that he hopes to see legislation concerning alcohol sales relaxed even further. See Also: Business Booming for Online Alcohol Retailers ‚ÄúThe goal of the bill was, among other things, to strengthen culture-related tourism around breweries in the countryside. The result is that one or two breweries are excluded, both in Eyjafj√∂r√∞ur [North Iceland]. And one producer of spirits in Borgarnes. There is no logic to that,‚Äù √ìlafur stated, adding that there is no reason producers of spirits shouldn‚Äôt also be allowed to sell their products on site. ‚ÄúThese are companies that have the same criteria and have been building up tourism around their operations and production. These breweries produce too much and are therefore too big to fall under these legal amendments.‚Äù The lack of alcoholic beverages in Icelandic grocery stores catches many foreign tourists by surprise. The state-run liquor store, V√≠nb√∫√∞in, is expensive, and opening hours can be sporadic during holidays and in more rural parts of the country. V√≠nb√∫√∞in stores are always closed on Sundays. While some have argued that increased access to alcohol will lead to increased alcohol abuse, a recent survey shows that almost half of Icelanders want beer and wine to be available in supermarkets.

headline: Alvotech Completes Dual Icelandic and US listing
body: Biotech company Alvotech became the first dual-listed Icelandic company in Iceland and the US when it completed its listing in Iceland‚Äôs stock market yesterday. The company‚Äôs founder R√≥bert Wessman expects a fast growth and that the company will become leading in its field. Biotech company Alvotech‚Äôs ordinary shares were admitted to trading on the Nasdaq First North Growth Market in Iceland (‚ÄúNasdaq First North‚Äù) a week after its debut on the Nasdaq stock market. R√≥bert Wessman, founder and chair of the Alvotech Board, rang the closing bell at the Nasdaq First North market in Iceland yesterday. In a speech celebrating the occasion, President of Nasdaq Iceland Magn√∫s Har√∞arson stated that Alvotech was now the second most valuable company in Nasdaq Iceland. R√≥bert noted that the company‚Äôs primary goal was to develop and manufacture biosimilar medicines more cost-effectively than before so that as many people who needed them as possible could afford them. R√≥bert told R√öV that the company‚Äôs recent milestones feel like a fairytale. ‚ÄúBeing there on the grand stage in New York last week was very fun, and we had key managers who joined us in ringing the bell that morning. To experience it again here is so great. We‚Äôre very excited to list the company in Iceland.‚Äù R√≥bert maintains that Alvotech‚Äôs main operations are in Iceland and that they invested over a hundred billion ISK here. He expects that the company will grow fast in the near future. ‚ÄúWe expect our company to be one of the leaders in our field.‚Äù ¬†

headline: Whaling Restarts in Iceland Following Four-Year Hiatus
body: Two whaling ships owned by the company Hvalur hf. set off from Reykjav√≠k harbour yesterday to begin the whaling season, R√öV reports. No commercial whaling has taken place in Iceland for four years, though a single minke whale was hunted in 2021. The whaling licence held by Hvalur hf. expires next year, and Iceland‚Äôs Minister of Fisheries has indicated that the practice of whaling may be discontinued in Iceland afterwards. The whale hunting quota issued by Iceland‚Äôs Marine and Freshwater Research Institute for this season is 161 fin whales and 217 minke whales. The quota is based on appraisals from the North Atlantic Marine Mammal Commission and the International Whaling Commission. According to R√öV, the number of fin whales in Icelandic waters has increased steadily since counting began in 1987. Its conservation status is nevertheless listed as ‚Äúvulnerable‚Äù according to the CITES Appendix. As of 2018, the IUCN Red List places minke whales in the ‚Äúleast concern‚Äù category. The whale hunting season lasts from June until late September, and some 150 employees are expected to staff Hvalur hf.‚Äôs whaling ships, whaling station in Hvalfj√∂r√∞ur, West Iceland, and their processing plant in Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur, in the capital area. Hvalur hf.‚Äôs CEO Kristj√°n Loftsson has stated that the main reason for the company‚Äôs lack of activity since 2018 is conflict with Iceland‚Äôs Food and Veterinary Authority concerning the company‚Äôs whaling station. He has also previously cited poor market conditions for whale products and the COVID-19 pandemic as factors. Whaling company Hvalur hf. has been embroiled in several controversies in recent years. Public outcries followed when the company¬†killed¬†a pregnant fin whale and a¬†rare hybrid whale¬†in 2018. Hvalur hf. was at risk of¬†losing their whaling licence¬†after¬†failing to submit¬†captains‚Äô logs for the 2014, 2015, and 2018 seasons. The company has been¬†sued¬†by three of its shareholders as well as by¬†activists. Earlier this year, Iceland‚Äôs Minister of Fisheries Svand√≠s Svavarsd√≥ttir stated she sees little reason to permit whaling after Hvalur hf.‚Äôs current licence expires in 2023. In an op-ed published in Morgunbla√∞i√∞ newspaper, Svand√≠s wrote that there is little evidence that whaling is economically beneficial to Iceland. She also pointed out that the controversial nature of the practice has a negative impact on Iceland, though it may be hard to measure. Svand√≠s stated that the government would carry out an assessment on the potential economic and social impact of whaling this year.

headline: New Technology for Prawn Fishing Uses Light to Reduce Emissions
body: An Icelandic company has developed a technology for prawn fishing that uses light to herd prawn up from the sea floor. This allows the fishing equipment to remain off the sea floor, leading to less disturbance of the environment and lower emissions than conventional trawling. The technology is set to be put on the market soon. ‚ÄúWe are developing the next generation of fishing equipment. Fishing equipment that can fly close to the bottom without touching the bottom. Then we have a light that herds,‚Äù Halla J√≥nsd√≥ttir, founder of Optitog, told R√öV reporters. Optitog has named this patented light beam technology ‚ÄúVirtual Trawl‚Äù and has data that shows that it results in higher yields, compared to using the equipment with the light off. ‚ÄúWe have a special light that forms a sort of wall or line in the sea and we see that it works to herd [the prawn].‚Äù The prawn swims ahead of the light, up off the sea floor and into the nets. It‚Äôs possible to set the equipment so that it travels a consistent distance above the sea floor, for example 30 centimetres [11.8 inches]. Because Optitog‚Äôs equipment does not trawl along the sea floor, it encounters 30% less resistance than conventional trawling, meaning the method drastically reduces fuel consumption. By leaving the sea floor largely undisturbed, the new technology also reduces CO2 emissions caused by disturbing organic material on the bottom of the ocean. Halla says that a Norwegian party is working to put Optitog on the market as an environmentally-friendly fishing technology. Halla believes the technology could be applied to fishing other species.

headline: Refugee Man and Family Previously Deported Win Case
body: The District Court of Reykjav√≠k has decided that the November deportation of Hussein Hussein and his family was illegal. Now, following the decision, Hussein and his family are back in Iceland after they were deported to Greece. In a statement from Albert Bj√∂rn L√∫√∞v√≠ksson, a lawyer at Claudia & Partners law firm, the firm representing the refugee family, the ‚Äúlegal basis for the deportation was not justified.‚Äù Additionally, he stated that: ‚Äúthe Immigration and Asylum Appeals Board judged their case to have been overdue. This remains unproven, and even if true, it is insignificant, as the Icelandic State stills bears responsibility for the procedure and any delays that have occurred.‚Äù Hussein Hussein is a refugee from Iraq who uses a wheelchair. His deportation in November of this year caused widespread outrage when footage surfaced on social media of authorities forcefully removing him from his wheelchair. The incident also caused controversy, as airport authorities attempted to suppress media coverage of the deportations. At the time of the deportation, many expressed concern that Greece lacked facilities and resources for refugees with disabilities. Although Hussein and his family have won their suit against the Immigration and Asylum Appeals Board, it is still possible for state representatives to appeal the case to the Court of Appeals. At this time, state representatives have made no comments with regard to this possibility. Claudia Wilson, the family‚Äôs lawyer, has stated that the family arrived in Iceland over the weekend. In statements to R√öV, the family has thanked everyone who has helped them so far in the case. They state that Hussein‚Äôs sisters intend to be back in school as soon as possible. ¬†

headline: Continued Cold Spell: Three Pools in South Iceland Closed
body: Three public pools in South Iceland will be closed indefinitely today to save hot water, R√öV reports. Iceland‚Äôs national utility company does not expect rationing to affect households. Temperatures around the country are expected to drop further this week. Temperatures in Iceland have barely risen above 0¬∞C over the past days ‚Äì and the weather is expected to get colder as the week progresses. As noted by R√öV, households in Iceland have been kept warm by an abundance of geothermal energy, and according to information from Veitur ‚Äì Iceland‚Äôs national utility company ‚Äì the country‚Äôs hot-water system is well equipped to handle the cold spell; the system has yet to reach its limit, although Veitur will continue to assess the state of the system on a daily basis. Even though the country‚Äôs hot-water supply is expected to handle the coming cold without incident, Rang√°rveitur, which manages the hot-water supply in three municipalities in South Iceland,¬†is nearing its limit, a press release from Veitur notes. In light of the cold weather, the local authorities have decided to close three public pools in the area ‚Äì in Hvolsv√∂llur, Hella, and Laugaland ‚Äì starting today. The authorities hope that the pools will only be closed for a few days, or over the coldest period. As far as additional reductions to the hot-water supply are concerned, a Veitur spokesperson told R√öV that cuts were always made first among large users ‚Äì bathing lagoons, public pools, and butcheries, e.g. In the event of forced rationing, Veitur screens for ‚Äúessential services‚Äù while also assessing whether relevant water conduits were capable of withstanding closures. As it stands, there is enough hot water to keep Icelandic households warm, although Veitur could be forced to make brief reductions (as in the case of the public pools in the Rang√°rvellir municipality). Veitur recommends that homeowners keep their hot-water usage within reasonable limits. Ideally, radiator valves are to be set at 3 (20¬∞C), allowing the thermostatic valve to detect the temperature in the room and adjust accordingly. Windows should be kept closed.

headline: Government Announces Increased Child and Housing Benefits
body: In the wake of the recently-concluded contract negotiations between VR and SA, the government has announced a series of measures aimed at supporting low- and middle-income households. At a press conference at 14:30 today, Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir, alongside Minister of Finance Bjarni Benediktsson and Minister of Infrastructure Sigur√∞ur Ingi J√≥hannsson, announced the new policies, which aim to support the buying-power of households, while keeping inflation rates down. The child benefit system is to be simplified, while also increasing support for the system, allowing more to qualify for child benefits. The improved child benefits will represent a total increase of ISK 5 billion from the current system over the next two years. Additionally, the system is to be streamlined to reduce the waiting time for child benefits, which are not to exceed four months after the birth of a child. The government also plans to increase the housing supply by incentivizing the development of new real estate throughout the nation. Increased access to social housing will also be a priority, with some ISK 4 billion to be allotted in 2023 to the expansion of affordable housing in Iceland. Housing benefits for tenants will also be increased. Additional reforms include improved pensions for the elderly and disabled, increased funding for workplace training, and reforms to pension funds. Bundled along these concessions to Iceland‚Äôs cost-of-living crisis will also be a large increase to police funding. Read the full announcement here.

headline: VR and SA Agree on Contract
body: VR Union and SA, the Federation of Icelandic Employers, have settled on a short-term contract that will be valid through next year. The agreement will retroactively cover November of this year, and includes a 6.75% wage increase, in addition to increased holiday bonuses and adjusted wage tables for hourly workers. Some have noted similarities between the recent VR contract and that recently reached between SGS and SA. The signing was a rather chaotic affair with representatives from throughout the country present. Official statements were relatively brief, given the long and tiring process it has been so far. Kristj√°n √û√≥r√∞ur Sn√¶bjarnarson, chairman of the Electrical Industry Association of Iceland, stated to R√öV. ‚ÄúWe were trying to press these negotiations as far as possible. I think this is the best outcome under the circumstances.‚Äù Notably, Ragnar √û√≥r Ing√≥lfsson, chairperson of VR union, gave no interview after the signing. After the signing, representatives from both the trade unions, SA, and state mediators sat down to celebrate over waffles, a tradition in Icelandic labour contracts.

headline: Possible End in Sight for VR, SA Negotiations
body: After a late night of fruitless negotiations between VR and SA, the Federation of Icelandic Employers, an end to bargaining may be in sight. The Assistant State Mediator confirmed that negotiations will resume at 13:00 today, when a final contract will be signed. The details of the final contract are not yet public, but an increased living wage in the face of inflation and rising interest rates has been talked about for some time now. The current negotiations between VR and SA have been ongoing since November 14, but the last 24 hours have been under a media embargo, given the potentially sensitive nature of the details. Efling Trade Union has also had a long and contentious negotiation process. Other unions have also agreed to shorter-term contracts as a compromise in a difficult negotiating climate. A press conference will be held later today a 14:30 in which Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir, Minister of Finance Bjarni Benediktsson, and Minister of Infrastructure Sigur√∞ur Ingi J√≥hannsson will give their statements on the importance of the agreement for the labour market. While the content of the agreement is not yet known, in addition to basic wage increases, sources suspect increased measures in child and housing benefits.

headline: Volunteer Organisation Throws Christmas Ball for Ukrainian Children
body:
Ukrainian families living in Iceland were treated to a Christmas Ball on Saturday. The party was the culmination of a year of events and relief efforts led by the volunteer-run organization Flottaf√≥lk and included a banquet and a visit from Iceland‚Äôs Yule Lads. Iceland Review spoke to one of the event organisers, Mark√∫s M√°r Efraim, about the festive event. 







 Also known as the Ukrainian Refugee Center in Iceland, Flottaf√≥lk (whose name in Icelandic, Great People, is a pun on the word fl√≥ttaf√≥lk, which means refugee), ‚Äúwas founded by likeminded volunteers at the start of the war to provide relief for the Ukrainian refugees coming to Iceland,‚Äù says Mark√∫s. Saturday‚Äôs Christmas Ball was the organization‚Äôs biggest event of the year and was made possible thanks to volunteers, ‚Äúboth local and Ukrainian, and the goodwill of the local community,‚Äù individuals and businesses alike, who donated gifts for the children. 







 The ball treated 400 guests‚Äîmostly Ukrainian children and their families‚Äîto a delicious holiday banquet including everything from traditional Icelandic Christmas fare such as hangikj√∂t to pizza, laughs Mark√∫s, ‚Äúfor those whose tastebuds are not made for smoked lamb.‚Äù 







 After eating their fill, the children got to dance around a giant Christmas tree with some visiting Yule Lads, who then handed out gifts. Members of the Ukrainian community also staged a dance performance. A home away from home ‚ÄúOur hearts are full of pure gratitude to those who have been taking care of us for many months already!‚Äù wrote attendee and teacher Tanya Korolenko in the Facebook group ‚Äú√çsland fyrir √ökra√≠nu‚Äù (‚ÄòIceland for Ukraine‚Äô). ‚ÄúThe spirit of Christmas is everywhere now. It‚Äôs beautiful‚Ä¶And all Ukrainians here, in Reykjavik, are thanking you heartily for allowing us to feel it, to enjoy it ourselves! It means a lot!‚Äù 







 ‚ÄúThanks to Flottafolk and its keen volunteers Ukrainians get a HOME to meet every Tuesday, they have plenty of help with practical issues like clothes and hygiene,‚Äù continued Tanya. ‚ÄúBut what touches me the most is when people take care of other people‚Äôs feelings. Like you did today.‚Äù Indeed, Flottaf√≥lk has been providing relief to the Ukrainian refugee community in Iceland since the beginning of the war, Mark√∫s explains. ‚ÄúRelief has been in the form of food, clothing, jobs, events and field trips for kids, educational programs, psychological support, childcare and basically everything necessary. This winter our biggest focus has been on the distribution of clothes and necessities,‚Äù he continues, noting that these distributions take place twice a week at Neskirkja and the community centre in the Grandi neighbourhood on the west side of Reykjav√≠k. ‚ÄúDuring the open houses we often get visits from local educators and speakers or do something special like concerts, and traditional gingerbread-making and decoration.‚Äù Plans to expand in the New Year Invigorated as the volunteers are by their joyful celebration on Saturday, Flottaf√≥lk has even bigger plans for the new year, says Mark√∫s. ‚ÄúWe would like to expand the educational programs, including various art workshops, but need more space as the community centre we have access to has its own extensive programming.‚Äù 







 ‚ÄúOne of the things we have planned for the new year is a writing workshop for kids,‚Äù says Mark√∫s, which would be co-taught by himself and Tanya Korolenko. ‚ÄúThis would hopefully culminate in a bilingual book with the children‚Äôs writing and illustrated by Ukrainian artists.‚Äù It seems clear that Flottaf√≥lk and its ongoing, collaborative efforts have helped to create a strong sense of kinship between local volunteers and members of the newly arrived Ukrainian community, something that Mark√∫s M√°r is quick to affirm. ‚ÄúI had no connections to Ukraine before the war, but as a volunteer and now, project manager for the community centre and educational programs, I feel strong kinship with the Ukrainian people. The refugee community has shown great gratitude to all of us volunteers and given back in so many ways.‚Äù Photos by Alesia Kovalova (–ê–ª–µ—Å—è –ö–æ–≤–∞–ª—å–æ–≤–∞)

headline: Incident Involving Refugee and Son Ejected from Bus Sparks Outrage
body: An account of a refugee and his son being prevented from boarding a Str√¶t√≥ bus from Reykjav√≠k to Keflav√≠k on Friday evening has invoked a public outcry and garnered a great deal of attention, both on social media and from community leaders, V√≠sir reports. Nichole Leigh Mosty, director of the Multicultural Information Centre, says the story isn‚Äôt surprising, and that cultural sensitivity training is important for people in service jobs who deal with diverse populations. Refused to let another passenger pay fare According to a public Facebook post published by Joana Diminiczak, a man and his young son boarded a Str√¶t√≥ 55 bus at the University of Iceland stop at 6:31 PM on Friday. The man attempted to use the payment card provided for him by the municipality of Reykjanesb√¶r, but the card didn‚Äôt work. The driver told him he had to pay his fare out of pocket and began to berate him in front of the other passengers. The man called someone and handed the phone to the driver, who said that ‚Äú‚Äòthese refugees‚Äô never want to pay,‚Äù wrote Joana in her post, ‚Äúthey bring useless cards and he‚Äôs not a charity, he does his job, and wants to finally go home and have his dinner.‚Äù Joana continued, saying that the driver then turned to the man and said in English, ‚ÄúI live in Njar√∞v√≠k [one of the towns that comprises Reykjanesb√¶r]. I‚Äôll find you.‚Äù At this point, Joana said she attempted to intercede and pay the fare for the man and child, but the bus driver refused, saying he had called the police. ‚ÄúI ask him to call the police [back] and say the matter is resolved because I will pay for them, but he didn‚Äôt want to do it. When I say that I can call so he doesn‚Äôt have to, he still doesn‚Äôt want to let me pay!!! The man gives up, takes his son, and they get out. He looks up at the sky, near tears, but still with hope in his eyes of sparing the boy the humiliation, and says, ‚ÄòHe watches us.‚Äô We pull out and the bus driver proudly calls the police and says that he is no longer in need of assistance.‚Äù Joana then concluded her post, writing, ‚ÄúSuch drivers shouldn‚Äôt be driving buses. I hope that Str√¶t√≥ takes this matter seriously.‚Äù At time of writing, the post had received 202 largely sympathetic and outraged comments, many of which called on Str√¶t√≥ to address the situation. It had been also been shared around 1,400 times. ‚ÄòThey need training in how to deal with this diverse group of customers‚Äô When contacted for comment, Nichole Leigh Mosty, director of the Multicultural Information Centre, said the story did not surprise her. ‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt surprised, because I know there have been difficulties implementing the Klappi√∞ app [Str√¶t√≥‚Äôs payment app]. It isn‚Äôt designed for diverse members of society, for foreigners or senior citizens. And we‚Äôve seen this behaviour from employees over and over. It‚Äôs a stressful job, but the fact that they are serving a diverse community means that they need training in how to deal with this diverse group of customers. But don‚Äôt make such prejudicial statements and [provide] poor service.‚Äù Nichole says that cultural sensitivity training is vital. ‚ÄúWhenever we have people in a service position, cultural sensitivity is needed considering that there are all sorts of people who use public transportation. And those who are serving them need to be able to treat everyone who uses that service with respect.‚Äù ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs very clear that we‚Äôll be looking into what went on there‚Äô Str√¶t√≥‚Äôs director J√≥hannes Svavar R√∫narsson told reporters that he wasn‚Äôt familiar with the situation himself, but that the case has been referred to the Icelandic Road Administration, which services bus lines that run outside of the capital area. However, at time of writing, Berg√æ√≥ra Kristinsd√≥ttir, manager of the Road Administration‚Äôs service department, said that she was not familiar with the situation either. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a nice story. It‚Äôs not come across our desk, I‚Äôve not received any other information about this incident. But it‚Äôs very clear that we‚Äôll be looking into what went on there,‚Äù said Berg√æ√≥ra.

headline: Pedestrian Killed in Traffic Accident
body: A pedestrian was killed in a traffic collision in H√∂f√∞abakki on the east side of Reykjav√≠k on Friday evening, V√≠sir reports. The cause of the accident is currently being investigated. See Also: Fatality in Bus and Scooter Collision The collision was reported around 12:30 AM on Saturday morning and occurred not far from the √Åb√¶jarsafn open air museum. The victim was a man in his forties. He was transported to the hospital after being hit by the car but died later that morning.

headline: Couple Who Are Blind Twice Denied Entry Onto Flight, Told to Pay for Escort
body: An Icelandic husband and wife who are blind were twice prevented from boarding an SAS flight to Iceland after being told that they needed to pay for an escort to accompany them onboard. R√öV reports that the couple, who were traveling with their one-year-old daughter at the time, will be pursuing legal action against the airline. Ey√æ√≥r Kamban √ûrastarson and Emil√≠a Pykarinou had a flight booked from Athens, Greece to Copenhagen, Denmark, and then on to Iceland. However, when they tried to board the Scandinavian Airlines flight, they were denied entry. ‚ÄúThe airline insisted that we be accompanied by another person,‚Äù explained Ey√æ√≥r, who said that the couple was also supposed to pay for a third seat for this purpose. They tried to board another flight two days later but were prevented from boarding for the same reason. Ey√æ√≥r believes that the fact that he and his wife were traveling with their young daughter played a part in the airline‚Äôs reluctance to allow them to board, but insisted that they‚Äôd have never booked the flight if they didn‚Äôt feel comfortable looking after their child while flying. In the end, the Ey√æ√≥r and Emil√≠a were only able to board because, a week after they were supposed to have traveled home, they found an Icelandic woman who already had a ticket for the same flight and who agreed to act as their escort. The couple intends to pursue legal action with both Blindraf√©lagi√∞, the Icelandic Association of the Visually Impaired, and the Icelandic consul in Greece, supporting their case. ‚ÄúThis is by no means over,‚Äù said Ey√æ√≥r, pointing out that the airline‚Äôs policy allows for children as young as five to travel unescorted. ‚ÄúWe are in no way okay with the fact that we were ordered to find someone to fly with us, let alone pay for it.‚Äù

headline: Terror Suspect‚Äôs Defence Attorney ‚ÄúAstonished‚Äù by ‚ÄúVague‚Äù Charges
body: Earlier today at the District Court of Reykjav√≠k, formal charges were brought against two men suspected of planning a domestic-terror attack. A defence attorney for one of the suspects has told V√≠sir that he is ‚Äúastonished‚Äù by the charges. As reported earlier today, the District Prosecutor filed a motion for extended custody over two men suspected of planning a domestic terror attack earlier this year. The court approved the motion, and custody was extended for an additional four weeks. Formal charges were also brought against the two suspects. One of the suspects was charged with an act of attempted terrorism and weapons offences. The other suspected was charged as an accomplice to an act of attempted terrorism, weapons offences, and a minor narcotics violation. Speaking to V√≠sir today, Sveinn Andri Sveinsson, defence attorney for one of the suspects, stated that he was ‚Äúastonished‚Äù by the charges: ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre charged with unspecified offences against an unspecified group of people at an unspecified time between May and September. It‚Äôs as hairy as a chimpanzee‚Äôs back.‚Äù According to Sveinn Andri, the police authorities had been too extreme in their initial operations. ‚ÄúThe only attempted offence, in this case, was an attempt to destroy the lives of two young men,‚Äù Sveinn Andri observed. ‚ÄúThe charges are founded on weapons that they had hoarded. My client was not in possession of any weapons. There‚Äôs a reference to weapon production. These are probably the first terrorists who hoard weapons but then sell them before committing an act of terrorism, which must constitute a highly questionable for of preparation,‚Äù Sveinn Andri remarked. Sveinn Andri added that he and his client would have to ‚Äúroll with the punches.‚Äù They would begin by examining a motion for dismissal, given the vague nature of the charges. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs complete nonsense. Terrible. You‚Äôve completely upended the lives of these two young men on the basis of ego. The police jumped the gun in the beginning and everything that they‚Äôve done since has been geared toward justifying that initial jump.‚Äù

headline: Charges to Be Brought Against Domestic-Terror Plot Suspects
body: The District Prosecutor will push for continued custody over two men suspected of planning a domestic terror attack earlier this year. Formal charges are expected to be brought against the men at the District Court of Reykjav√≠k today. Four Icelandic men were arrested on September 21 suspected of ‚Äúterrorist plots‚Äù against state institutions and civilians. Two of the suspects were immediately released; the other two have remained in custody. Speaking to R√öV today, district attorney Karl Ingi Vilbergsson stated that the District Prosecutor has decided to charge the two suspects for violating Article No. 100 of Iceland‚Äôs General Penal Code. The charges are expected to be introduced when prosecutors motion for extended custody over the two men at the District Court of Reykjav√≠k today. R√öV notes that this is likely the first time that such a charge is brought in Iceland. In an interview with Mbl.is, however, Karl Ingi stated that the District Prosecutor had ‚Äúnever considered‚Äù charging the suspects on the basis of Article No. 100 of Iceland‚Äôs General Penal Code. He was not willing to offer further detail on the content of the charges at this time. As previously noted, the two suspects arrested in September had hoarded numerous weapons ‚Äì including dozens of semi-automatic guns and 3D-printed components ‚Äì alongside a considerable amount of ammunition. The men, both of whom are in their twenties, had also discussed carrying out attacks against various political figures, among them Minister Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r √û√≥r√∞arson and Chairman of Efling, S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir. Article 100 of Iceland‚Äôs Penal Code: [Art. 100 a [Punishment of up to lifelong imprisonment shall be imposed on any person committing one or more of the following acts of terrorism with the intention of causing the public serious fear or unlawfully compelling the Icelandic or foreign authorities, or international institutions, to take action or refrain from taking action with a view to weakening or damaging the constitutional structure or the political, economic or social basis of the state or international institution:]1) Article 20 of the General Penal Code states that for ‚Äúan attempted offence, a more lenient punishment may be imposed than for a completed offence.‚Äù This article will be updated.

headline: Hot Water Shortage in Selfoss: Public Pool Closed Indefinitely
body: A fire in an electrical box of the Selfossveitur utility company has led to a hot-water shortage in Selfoss. The √Årborg municipality has encouraged residents to save water and the public swimming pool in Selfoss has been closed indefinitely. As noted in a press release from the √Årborg municipality yesterday, an electrical box in one of the boreholes of the Selfossveitur utility company caught fire on the night before Thursday, December 8. The fire forced a reduction in energy production, leading to a shortage of hot water.¬†¬† Selfossveitur subsequently activated its contingency plan, with residents of the √Årborg municipality being encouraged to use their hot water sparingly. The municipality‚Äôs website offers advice to residents on how best to save water, including ensuring that windows and front doors remain closed and making sure that radiators are not blocked by long curtains or furniture. In light of the shortages, Sundh√∂ll Selfoss, the public swimming pool in the town of Selfoss, has been indefinitely closed. ‚ÄúWhich is why we‚Äôve decided to close the Selfoss public swimming pool indefinitely. We will let you know immediately when we have a more detailed timeline regarding when we‚Äôll open again,‚Äù a press release from the Selfoss swimming pool on Facebook reads. ¬†

headline: The Icelandic Medical Journal Publishes Report on Fireworks-Related Injuries
body: Using data gathered between 2010 and 2022, the Medical Journal of Iceland has released a report on fireworks-related injuries in Iceland. The study searched through medical records between these years for reports of fireworks and information related to the circumstances and severity of the injuries. In total, some 248 people were sent to the hospital during this time for fireworks-related injuries, ranging in age from only 9 months old to 79 years old. A large proportion of injuries, 39%, were also found to have been caused by faulty fireworks. Rockets were found to be the most dangerous, accounting for 23% of all injuries, followed by multishot box fireworks, which accounted for 17% of all injuries. Injuries to hands and eyes were most common, and across the period of the study, individuals were hospitalized for a combined total of 91 days due to their injuries. The report concludes that ‚Äúfirework accidents are a significant problem in Iceland.‚Äù An average of 21 Icelanders end up in the emergency room every year due to fireworks-related accidents. The large majority of these accidents occur on New Year‚Äôs Eve and the first hours of the New Year. Fireworks-related accidents also, perhaps unsurprisingly, show a strong gender bias, with some three out of four affected individuals being male. However, a more serious trend is the number of children affected, with just less than half of all injuries coming from minors. One preschool-aged child, on average, each year ends up in the emergency room, generally due to a lack of supervision. Over the course of the entire study, most injuries were found to be relatively minor cuts and burns, but at least 13 people were identified as having suffered serious injuries. The study suggests an increased emphasis on the correct handling of fireworks, especially the use of safety glasses. Given the relatively high frequency of fireworks-related injuries, the study also suggests ‚Äúconsidering further restrictions on their import, sale, and use.‚Äù The report can be read in its entirety here.

headline: Diego Returns Home After Surgery
body: Diego the cat, a minor celebrity in Iceland, has returned home after a successful surgery. Diego was injured on November 25 in a car accident near Skeifan, the shopping centre he frequents. He is a common sight at both A4, a stationary supply story, and Domino‚Äôs. This was reported recently by Sigr√∫n √ìsk Snorrad√≥ttir, Diego‚Äôs owner, in a post on social media. She stated that he‚Äôs doing very well after a successful surgery, and that all that remains is to let him relax as he recovers from the stressful incident. Many have sent Diego their best wishes during his convalescence, including the A4 and Domino‚Äôs he frequents, which both donated funds to cover the cost of his procedure. His Facebook group has some 10,000 followers.

headline: New Crime Bill Includes Upwards of 1 Billion ISK in Funding, Increased Police Powers
body: Following Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson‚Äôs declaration of a ‚Äúwar on organised crime‚Äù after the recent knife attacks in a Reykjav√≠k nightclub, Icelandic police are set to receive ISK 500 million (3.5 million USD, 3.3 million EUR) in funding for the establishment of special investigation teams. In an interview with R√öV, the minister stated: ‚ÄúIt is absolutely necessary to take drastic measures to stop the development that is taking place in Icelandic society when it comes to organised crime.‚Äù Included in the new crime bill is the ability for Icelandic police to now monitor individuals, not under concrete suspicion of having committed a crime, but merely for connections to known criminals. The police will now also be able to monitor places known to be associated with organised crime, in addition to writing ‚Äúpreventative search warrants.‚Äù Such warrants will lower the standard for probable cause, allowing Icelandic police to issue search warrants on suspicion of criminal activity. According to the budget proposals for the new crime legislation which was submitted to parliament this week, ISK 500 million are expected to go to Icelandic police to strengthen their response to organised crime. Much of the new funding is expected to go to the establishment of special investigation teams against organised crime. The budget committee has also proposed an additional ISK 750 million (5,3 million USD, 5 million EUR) to address ‚Äúweaknesses in police operations‚Äù throughout the country. Of these new funds, ISK 650 million are to be allocated to general operations and training, with another ISK 50 million each going to equipment and investigations. The budget committee stated that the new funds aim to ‚Äúimprove the quality of investigations, shortening case turnover, improving operations in rural areas, and improving equipment in the fields of digital and technical investigations.‚Äù ¬†

headline: Pornographic Film Created in Ambulance Under Investigation
body: A pornographic film is under investigation for having been recorded in an Icelandic ambulance, reports Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞. Authorities state they are taking the matter seriously and that an investigation into the matter has begun. According to Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞, the capital region fire department was alerted to the existence of the video via a confidential tip. The incident is significant as the sale and production of pornography are illegal in Iceland. The incident also raises concerns over security, and how the individuals responsible for the pornographic film were able to gain access to the ambulance in question. The film in question features a woman posing as a patient and a man as an emergency medical technician. Sources report that after an internal investigation, it was concluded that although the ambulance in question is indeed Icelandic, it was not operated by the capital area fire department. Authorities have concluded that the ambulance is either from another municipality, or else an older vehicle that has been sold to a private individual. The incident was an occasion for some moral outrage, with some condemning the use of a vehicle used to treat the sick and dying for such purposes. Despite the outrage, however, there is no indication that the ambulance is currently in service. Spokesperson for the capital area fire department, √Åsd√≠s G√≠slason, stated: ‚ÄúThe issue is being taken very seriously, and we regret having been involved in this matter.‚Äù Update: Video Likely Filmed at Sk√≥garhli√∞ in Reykjav√≠k According to the latest information, the ambulance in question was located in the fire department facility in Sk√≥garhli√∞. Since the matter has been reported in the media, authorities have received numerous tips. Now, they state that several clues from the video indicate that it was indeed recorded at a fire department building in Reykjav√≠k. Birgir Finnsson, assistant fire chief in the capital area, stated that there are no security cameras at Sk√≥garhli√∞, as it had not previously been considered necessary. When asked if other individuals had access to the facility, he stated that although ‚Äúthe building is of course just for use by the fire department, there is something going on that we‚Äôre looking into.‚Äù

headline: Search Area Expanded as Missing Fisherman Still Not Found
body: The Coast Guard has expanded the search area in its effort to find a missing fisherman who fell overboard last Friday. A prayer service was held for the man in Grindav√≠k on Sunday. The search continues for a fisherman who fell overboard just outside Faxafl√≥i Bay on Friday afternoon. The man, a Grindav√≠k resident and father of three, was a fisherman on the longline fishing boat Sighvatur GK-57, which is owned and operated by the Grindav√≠k-based fishing company V√≠sir hf. The police have interviewed the ship‚Äôs captain and have deemed the incident a ‚Äútragic accident,‚Äù V√≠sir reports. Read More: A Brief History of Iceland‚Äôs Maritime Safety and Survival Training Centre The search effort is the most extensive of its kind in years, Gu√∞mundur Birkir Agnarsson, Director of Operations with the Icelandic Coast Guard, told the hosts of the radio programme Morgun√∫tvarpi√∞ yesterday morning. On Saturday, fifteen boats participated in the search ‚Äì among them the patrol ship √û√≥r ‚Äì in addition to two helicopters. Given how many days have passed since the man fell into the sea, the Coast Guard has expanded the search area from 10 x 10 nautical miles to 18 x 18 nautical miles. √Åsgeir Erlendsson, Public Relations Officer for the Icelandic Coast Guard, told Mbl.is yesterday that search conditions have been relatively good, despite not having found the man. A prayer service was held for the fisherman in Grindav√≠k on Sunday. Fannar J√≥nsson, Mayor of Grindav√≠k, told V√≠sir that the community was ‚Äòdeeply saddened‚Äô and that all they could do was wait. According to Fannar, the prayer service was well attended, for an event such as this has an outsized effect on such a small community: ‚ÄúYes, it‚Äôs very hard. You have a big family and friends ‚Ä¶ the crew, the company, and the sailor‚Äôs family, they‚Äôre all hurting. But there‚Äôs a solidarity and a unity among the community, whenever something like this happens.‚Äù

headline: Masked Man Carrying Fake Firearm Raises Alarm Downtown
body: Police were dispatched to the Vesturb√¶r neighborhood on the west side of Reykjav√≠k in the early hours of Sunday morning after receiving reports of a masked man carrying a firearm, R√öV reports. Thankfully, the matter was resolved quickly and the weapon in question turned out to be an imitation. According to police reports, officers, including members of the police‚Äôs armed division, were sent to the area to locate the man and ensure public safety at the time the report was made. Eye witnesses reported the presence of six police cars, including two special forces vehicles, blocking routes into the city centre. See Also: Heightened Police Presence in Reykjav√≠k This Weekend Just after 1:00 am, a car was stopped in Vesturb√¶r, and a fake firearm was confiscated from its occupant, who was taken into custody. At time of writing, police were unable to confirm if the man was intending to present the fake firearm as a real weapon. The case will be reviewed over the weekend and state prosecutors will decide how to proceed.

headline: Search Continues for Fisherman Who Fell Overboard
body: The search continues for a sailor who fell overboard a fishing vessel just outside the Faxafl√≥i Bay on Friday afternoon. R√öV reports that the search and rescue operation is the most extensive of its kind in years, with eight ships and one of the Coast Guard‚Äôs helicopters currently taking part. Ships went out in search of the man as soon as the Coast Guard got word of his accident at around 5:00 pm on Friday. At the time, two helicopters, the Coast Guard‚Äôs patrol ship √û√≥r, and 14 fishing vessels and search and rescue boats joined the search. The majority of the search was paused just before 1:00 am on Saturday morning, although the patrol ship √û√≥r continued to look overnight. The search resumed in full at 10:00 am on Sunday morning; one of the Coast Guard‚Äôs helicopters joined in around 11:00 am. Given the time that had passed since the sailor fell overboard, the search area was expanded to a radius of ten nautical miles to the northwest of the Gar√∞skagi peninsula. Gu√∞mundur Birkir Agnarsson, the Coast Guard‚Äôs operations manager, said that search conditions on Sunday were worse than they were the day before, with stronger winds and waves, and more limited visibility. At time of writing, the sea temperature in Faxafl√≥i Bay was about 5¬∞C [41¬∞F]. Accidents at sea have, thankfully, become far less common than they used to be in Iceland. ‚ÄúOver the last few years, we haven‚Äôt had any fatal accidents at sea, including with people falling overboard,‚Äù said Gu√∞mundur Birkir. ‚ÄúSo this probably the most extensive search we‚Äôve had in recent years.‚Äù Search and rescue efforts will continue until darkness falls, Gu√∞mundur Birkir confirmed, although he did not say how efforts would continue if the missing man had not been found by then. Read more about how Icelandic fishermen are trained to stay safe.

headline: Former Minister J√≥n Baldvin Sentenced in Sexual Harassment Case
body: J√≥n Baldvin Hannibalsson, former government minister and diplomat, has received a suspended sentence of two months‚Äô imprisonment in a sexual harassment case related to an incident that took place at his home in Granada, Spain in 2018, V√≠sir reports. The Landsr√©ttur Court of Appeals also ordered him to pay all court and appeal costs related to the case. J√≥n Baldvin‚Äôs defense attorney has said that an application will be made to the Supreme Court requesting the right to appeal the judgement. An acquittal The sexual harassment charges were first brought against J√≥n Baldvin in 2019, when Carmen J√≥hannsd√≥ttir accused him of having groped her buttocks during a dinner party in Granada the year before. Resolution on the case was long delayed, however, in part because the Reykjav√≠k District Court repeatedly dismissed it because the incident took place in Spain and was therefore not, the court contended, under its jurisdiction. The Court of Appeals overturned this dismissal on technical grounds: over four weeks had passed between the oral presentation of the call to stop the case and the court‚Äôs decision to throw the case out. As such, the District Court was forced to reopen the case. Competing witness testimony also came into play. Carmen‚Äôs mother, Laufey √ìsk Arnorsd√≥ttir, was also in attendance at the party in 2018 and testified that she witnessed J√≥n Baldvin groping her daughter. The District Court rejected Laufey‚Äôs testimony, saying it did not correspond to Carmen‚Äôs version of events. Instead, it accepted the testimony of J√≥n Baldvin‚Äôs wife Brynd√≠s Schram and a neighbor, who corroborated his version of events. The Reykjav√≠k District Court finally ruled on the case in August 2021 and J√≥n Baldvin was acquitted of the charges. A conviction The case was then taken up again by the Court of Appeals, with the District Attorney seeking a suspended sentence of two to three months for J√≥n Baldvin. Carmen J√≥hannsd√≥ttir also sought damages totaling ISK one million [$7,086; ‚Ç¨6,725]. Carmen‚Äôs claim for damages was rejected, but the Court of Appeals granted the DA‚Äôs suspended sentence of two months. In its decision, the Court of Appeals stated that Carmen‚Äôs account of the incident was credible, and was, in fact, supported by that of her mother. It was the Court‚Äôs opinion that these testimonies outweighed J√≥n Baldvin‚Äôs denial. A long history of accusations  J√≥n Baldvin Hannibalsson was an MP for the Social Democratic Party, serving as Minister of Finance from 1987 to 1988 and Foreign Affairs Minister from 1988 to 1995. Following his time in parliament, he served as a diplomat, first to the US and Mexico from 1998 to 2002, and then to the Baltics from 2002 to 2005. He has faced repeated accusations of sexual harassment and impropriety throughout his career, dating all the way back to 1967 when he was a teacher at an elementary school. In 2012, it was revealed that J√≥n Baldvin had sent his wife‚Äôs niece Gu√∞r√∫n Har√∞ard√≥ttir sexually explicit letters starting when she was 14 years old. J√≥n Baldvin denied that he sexually harassed Gu√∞r√∫n, but apologised for what he called a ‚Äúlapse of judgement‚Äù in initiating the correspondence. Gu√∞r√∫n attempted to press charges against J√≥n Baldvin, but police dropped the case. See Also: Former Minister Accused of Sexual Harassment Over 50-Year Period In 2013, J√≥n Baldvin was invited to be a guest lecturer at the University of Iceland. When objections ensued, the university withdrew the invitation. J√≥n Baldvin protested the decision and threatened to take legal action, upon which the university agreed to pay him ISK 500,000 [$3,542; ‚Ç¨3,361] in compensation and publicly apologised for how they handled the matter. In 2019, Stundin published interviews with four women, including Carmen J√≥hannsd√≥ttir, in which each described incidents of sexual harassment by J√≥n Baldvin. A Facebook group called #metoo J√≥n Baldvin Hannibalsson was formed around the same time, and at least 12 women used the platform to share accounts of sexual harassment at the hands of the former politician. In the face of all these incidents, however, J√≥n Baldvin has maintained his utmost innocence. He called Carmen‚Äôs charge ‚Äúpure fabrication‚Äù and stated it was part of ‚Äúa coordinated attack on my reputation.‚Äù ‚ÄòIt hasn‚Äôt been an easy journey, but today, it all became worth it‚Äô Carmen was abroad at the time that the Court of Appeals published its decision, but she spoke to reporters after she‚Äôd had some time to process the news. ‚ÄúThis is very much a cause for celebration,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI know it‚Äôs not a heavy sentence, but it‚Äôs just the fact that he‚Äôs been sentenced at all. I didn‚Äôt expect it, to be perfectly honest, but I‚Äôm really happy about it.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a long process and of course, there‚Äôs already been one ruling on it. But I have to say that I‚Äôm really happy about this. I‚Äôm happy about this victory‚Äînot just for me, but also for everyone who‚Äôs been subjected to abuse at the hands of J√≥n Baldvin.‚Äù ‚ÄúHopefully, this will set a precedent for other judges and lawyers,‚Äù continued Carmen. ‚ÄúAnd also just for people who haven‚Äôt had the desire or ability to claim their rights‚Äîthat it‚Äôs worth it, even if it‚Äôs hard. I‚Äôll absolutely admit that it hasn‚Äôt been an easy journey, but today, it all became worth it.‚Äù

headline: 300,000 Tourists to Visit √çsafj√∂r√∞ur Next Summer Via Cruise Ships
body: Approximately 300,000 tourists are expected to arrive in √çsafj√∂r√∞ur via cruise ships next summer, R√öV reports. Receiving so many tourists is a ‚Äúchallenge,‚Äù the mayor of √çsajf√∂r√∞ur has stated, with many residents keeping entirely out of the downtown area during the busiest periods. √çsafj√∂r√∞ur, located in Iceland‚Äôs Westfjords, is a town of roughly 3,000 residents. Next summer, tourists ‚Äì numbering ten times the town‚Äôs population ‚Äì are expected to arrive in √çsafj√∂r√∞ur via cruise ships. A total of 218 ships, carrying 245,000 passengers (excluding crew members) have announced their arrival. During a 35-day period next summer, R√öV notes, 3,000 visitors are expected to arrive in √çsafj√∂r√∞ur every day. ‚Äú8,200 tourists are expected to arrive in town during one particular day.‚Äù In an interview with R√öV published this morning, Arna L√°ra J√≥nsd√≥ttir, Mayor of √çsafj√∂r√∞ur, added the caveat that experience had shown that there were always a few cancellations. ‚ÄúNonetheless, this is a record number of arrivals, which will greatly test our infrastructure. That much is clear.‚Äù As noted in R√öV‚Äôs article, the port dues paid by cruise ships have become the main source of income for √çsafj√∂r√∞ur harbour, which also comprises the harbours of √ûingeyri, Flateyri, and Su√∞ureyri. (The √çsafjar√∞arb√¶r municipality was founded in 1996 with the merger of six municipalities in the northern Westfjords: the districts of √ûingeyri, M√Ωri, Mosvellir, Flateyri, Su√∞ureyri, and √çsafj√∂r√∞ur). By directing traffic through these four harbours, the municipality would be able to ease the burden. ‚ÄúThose passengers that arrive here, go all the way to Arnarfj√∂r√∞ur, to Dynjandi, or here into Dj√∫pi√∞. So we‚Äôre able to distribute the burden, so to speak,‚Äù Arna L√°ra observed, noting that the numerous arrivals presented an opportunity for the travel industry ‚Äì although it was important not to overdo it. ‚ÄúThere are many residents who monitor arrivals at the harbour; they may decide to avoid the downtown area completely in the event that there are four or five cruise ships arriving.‚Äù Arna L√°ra added that √çsafj√∂r√∞ur was a fishing town and that the fishing industry needed its space: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got to strike a balance. But there are many days in √çsafj√∂r√∞ur where we‚Äôre completely booked.‚Äù

headline: First Female Pilot in Iceland Retires After 38 Years of Flight
body: Sigr√≠√∞ur Einarsd√≥ttir landed today for the last time at Keflav√≠k International Airport. Sigr√≠√∞ur Einarsd√≥ttir was the first female commercial airline pilot in Iceland. Her 38-year career paved the way for many other women in Icelandic aviation. Her Boeing 757, designated Vatnaj√∂kull, her favourite plane to pilot according to V√≠sir, touched down early in the morning yesterday. Passengers reported an ‚Äúexceptionally smooth‚Äù landing. She was greeted by a reception of other female Icelandair pilots who celebrated her long, pioneering career in aviation. Sigr√≠√∞ur‚Äôs career began in 1984 aboard a Fokker F27 turboprop, and three years later, on the airline‚Äôs new jets. In 1996, she became a full captain. At her reception, Sigr√≠√∞ur stated: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that it‚Äôs really sunk in yet that this was the final landing. It was only on the final approach that I really realized that this had been my last flight, on a jet at least.‚Äù Although she‚Äôs retiring, she has no intention to stop flying: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm done. It‚Äôs just so much fun to fly. Now I just need to go renew my private license and get back into smaller planes.‚Äù After her 1984 start, Sigr√≠√∞ur recalls that she was the only female pilot for the first five years of her career. ‚ÄúAfter ten years, there were three of us,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAfter twenty years, the tenth woman was hired.‚Äù Now, she says, there are some 77 altogether. Despite the progress made by Sigr√≠√∞ur, aviation is still largely a male industry in Iceland, with 13% of Icelandic pilots being women. ‚ÄúThis isn‚Äôt a man‚Äôs job anymore,‚Äù she said in her farewell address. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve shown and proved this.‚Äù ¬†

headline: Police Concludes Investigation Into Domestic Terror Plot
body: The police authorities have concluded their investigation into two men suspected of plotting a domestic terror plot, V√≠sir reports. The district attorney‚Äôs office will decide whether or not to bring charges against the two suspects over the coming days. Four Icelandic men were arrested on September 21 suspected of ‚Äúterrorist plots‚Äù against state institutions and civilians. Two of the suspects were immediately released; the other two have remained in custody for the past ten weeks and will remain in custody until next week, at least. Speaking to V√≠sir earlier today, District Attorney √ìlafur √û√≥r Hauksson stated that the police authorities had investigated whether the two men were, on the one hand, guilty of violating the General Penal Code on terrorism and, on the other hand, guilty of perpetrating firearms offences. It is not clear at this time whether the two men will be indicted and, if so, when. According to √ìlafur, a decision will be made before long. Last week, a judge extended custody over the two suspects for two weeks; they had already been held in custody for nine weeks. One of the suspects‚Äô lawyers appealed the decision last week, but the Court of Appeals confirmed the decision, √ìlafur stated. No decision has been made on whether or not a petition for extended custody will be filed. As noted in V√≠sir‚Äôs article, the two men are not the only individuals connected to the case that will possibly be charged with weapons offences. As noted in a police press conference in September, the suspects had hoarded numerous weapons ‚Äì including dozens of semi-automatic guns and 3D-printed components ‚Äì alongside a considerable amount of ammunition. The men, both of whom are in their twenties, had reportedly discussed targeting various political figures. They had also discussed carrying out an attack during the police‚Äôs annual celebration.

headline: Hope that Efling Contract Will be Accepted
body: S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir, chairperson of Efling trade union, has expressed her optimism that wage negotiations with SA, the Federation of Icelandic Employers, may be reaching an acceptable conclusion. The most recent round of contract negotiations has been complicated by changes in AS√ç (The Confederation of Icelandic Labour) leadership and rising interest rates in the face of high inflation. Normally negotiated for longer terms, a shorter-term contract has been suggested as a stopgap to help what has been a difficult negotiation process. Efling has now agreed to make an offer to SA that will include an ISK 56,700 annual raise (USD EUR), in addition to other cost-of-living allowances. The contract as offered will be valid until January 31, 2024. Cost of living has been a pressing issue in the recent renegotiations, and Efling‚Äôs current offer represents a much more humble demand than some of their previous suggestions. However, a statement by the union highlights that the current offer represents what would have been the gains in the first year of a normal three-year contract: ‚ÄúIn the opinion of the negotiating committee of Efling, the agreed increases need to protect the households of low- and middle-income earners from the effects of inflation and guarantee them a fair share in economic growth and the profits of the company. [‚Ä¶] The bargaining committee of Efling believes that other unions have made a mistake by agreeing to percentage increases in negotiations with SA. There have been proposals for discussion where high-income groups are expected to benefit twice as much as low-wage earners.‚Äù Here, Efling refers to a debate within trade unions on whether to go to the bargaining table with demands for flat wage increases, or percentage-based wage increases. Percentage-based wage increases favour higher earners, and such demands have been a cornerstone of BHM‚Äôs demands (The Icelandic Confederation of University Graduates). However, for lower wage earners, flat increases to wage generally tend to increase buying power more directly. Efling submitted their offer to SA yesterday. Previously, they had submitted similar terms, but SA rejected them on grounds of the length of the contract. Now, Efling is hoping that the new, shorter contract will be accepted. In a statement, S√≥lveig Anna said: ‚ÄúWe will see how this shapes up. I‚Äôm not ready to say that we‚Äôve reached the finish line. I know it‚Äôs a complicated game we‚Äôre playing [‚Ä¶] I think it‚Äôs likely that we need to do something more, but the message to us was clear and meaningful.‚Äù ¬†

headline: Dismissed for Distributing Video of Stabbing
body: The individual responsible for distributing video footage of the recent knife attacks in a downtown Reykjav√≠k nightclub has been relieved from their post, reports R√öV. √ìlafur √û√≥r Hauksson, district prosecutor, confirmed this in a statement to R√öV, and stated that it is not believed the employee in question intended for the video to be distributed so widely. However, since its release one week ago, the video has been shared extensively across social media. The video in question showed footage from the security cameras in the downtown Reykjav√≠k club as a group of masked men entered the building and stabbed three individuals. At the time of the leak, there was concern that the leak of the video could potentially hurt the investigation of the case. Now, Reykjav√≠k police have concluded their investigation of the matter and consider the case closed. After the leak, police officer Gr√≠mur Gr√≠msson stated that ‚Äúthe video appears to have been recorded with a phone from the computer screen, and it appears to be a police workstation. I think we can say that this has never happened before, that information on an ongoing investigation has been leaked in this way.‚Äù Presumably, the police were able to trace the workstation back to the relevant employee and conclude the investigation. Several people are reported to have been questioned on the video and its distribution. No further information on the responsible individual has been provided, except that they were an employee of the police force. As of Friday, their employment is reported to have been terminated. ¬†

headline: New Recycling Sorting in Reykjav√≠k Next Year
body: Starting next year, Icelandic households will have four bins to sort recycling into. The changes come in light of new regulations in waste management, which include a restructuring of the collection of waste disposal fees, and a coordinated waste management system for the entire capital region. One of the biggest changes for the average household, however, is that it will now be required for Icelandic households to properly recycle organic waste. A new bin is being introduced, which will be for organic material. Reykjav√≠k households will also need to use biodegradable paper bags for their organic waste instead of plastic. However, households will be receiving a year‚Äôs worth of paper bags. Biodegradable plastic bags have not been found by SORPA to degrade fast enough to be used. Paper and plastic recycling bins will also disappear from communal locations, as these will now be picked up at all households. It has not yet been decided to what extent households will share in the costs of the new system, though it will certainly require some changes. Households will need to have all four bins, but it has been stated that it may be possible for households to use two-part bins, which separate between plastic and paper, for instance.

headline: Too Many Unhoused People Must Rely on Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs Parking Garages for Shelter
body: Harm reduction expert Svala J√≥hannesd√≥ttir stated recently in an interview with R√öV that too many unhoused people in the Reykjav√≠k area are forced to rely on parking garages for shelter. The situation, according to Svala, shows a lack of resources for the homeless in Reykjav√≠k. According to recent statements by experts at the Healthcare Centre for the Capital Area, parking garages have become injection sites for many of Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs unhoused people. One parking garage in particular, by Vesturgata, has been singled out as particularly problematic because it is near a children‚Äôs daycare and also housing for the elderly. A guard was recently hired in the parking garage following an incident where a health centre employee was assaulted in the parking garage. Although many unhoused people have access to some form of shelter, many have no place to go during the day. Unhoused men, in fact, are forced to leave their shelters during the day, a requirement that has led to protests as winter approaches. ‚ÄúThis is a natural manifestation of the lack of options which is the rule for so many unhoused people in the capital area,‚Äù stated Svala to R√öV. Svala has worked advocating for unhoused people with addiction problems for some 15 years and is one of the founders of Matthildur, an association for harm reduction in Iceland. She also stated: ‚ÄúThere has been a large increase in the number of people who are looking for space in the city‚Äôs emergency shelters. The emergency shelters close at 10AM and then open at 5PM. For these seven hours, people have no place to go.¬† We‚Äôve found that for these seven hours, people are simply not in a good place.‚Äù In order to better support people with addiction problems, Svala has called for resources that are available during the day as well. The number of unhoused people has risen significantly in the last years in the capital area, with increased housing prices, drug problems, and other factors driving the trend. The capital region is also the only municipality in Iceland that provides services to the unhoused, meaning an increased burden for social services in Reykjav√≠k. ¬†

headline: Women, Life, Freedom: Candlelight March in Solidarity with Activists in Iran and Afghanistan
body:
UN Women in Iceland hosted a candlelight march against gender-based violence on Friday night. R√öV reports that this is the first time the march has been held since the COVID-19 pandemic began and took place under the slogan ‚ÄúWomen, Life, Freedom,‚Äù echoing the rallying cry that has taken up by feminist activists and protestors in Iran and beyond. The march began at Arnarh√≥ll and ended at Br√≠etartorg, a small square in downtown Reykjav√≠k that commemorates activist and suffragette Br√≠et Bjarnh√©√∞insd√≥ttir (1856 ‚Äì 1940). Harpa concert hall was illuminated in orange during the event, as orange has come to symbolize a better, violence-free future for women and girls around the world. 







 According to a Facebook post about the event, the candlelight march marks the beginning of 16 Days of Activism against gender-based violence, ‚Äúan international campaign that commences on 25 November‚Äîthe International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women‚Äîand ends on 10 December, Human Rights Day.‚Äù This year, the 16 Days of Activism campaign continues with its ongoing mission to end femicide, ‚Äúthe murder of women¬† because they are women.‚Äù Event organizers say that 81,000 women and girls were killed globally in 2020, around 47,000 or 58% of whom died at the hands of an intimate partner or a family member. This equates to a woman or girl being killed every 11 minutes in their home. ‚ÄúBy taking part in UN Women Iceland‚Äôs Candlelight March,‚Äù concluded UN Women in Iceland, ‚Äúwe show solidarity with the brave women and girls of Afghanistan and Iran who are leading the fight against their countries‚Äô regimes‚Äô repressive treatment of women and girls, while being met with brutal and often lethal force.‚Äù ‚ÄòThere‚Äôs no going back because there‚Äôs nothing to go back to‚Äô Friday‚Äôs march was led by activist Zahra Mesbah, an Afghan woman who was born in Iran, Iranian Zoreh Aria, and UN Women in Iceland director Stella Sam√∫elsd√≥ttir. Individuals from both Afghanistan and Iran were invited to walk in front. In her speech, Zahra emphasized unity, saying: ‚ÄúThe only thing that matters is that I am a person, and all people deserve freedom and to live with dignity.‚Äù 







 For her part, Zoreh urged attendees to show their support for the Iranian women who are risking their lives every time they protest. ‚ÄúIn their minds, there‚Äôs only one way forward and there‚Äôs no going back because there‚Äôs nothing to go back to,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey are fighting for freedom and dignity. We ask people to stand with peace, freedom, and the Iranian nation and to ask the government to take action.‚Äù All photos taken by Hei√∞r√∫n Fivelstad on behalf of UN Women in Iceland.

headline: Diego, the ‚ÄòMost Famous Cat in Iceland,‚Äô Injured in Car Accident
body: Diego, the fluffy, much-loved grey-and-white longhair cat who spends his days lounging around various shops in the Skeifan strip mall in Reykjav√≠k, was hit by car on Friday¬† and suffered serious injuries, V√≠sir reports. The unfortunate kitty was taken to a veterinary hospital and underwent surgery that same day.
