Diego has a home and owners, but on most days can be found lolling about atop the printer paper in the stationary store A4, padding through the Hagkaup department store, or even dropping in for a slice at Domino‚Äôs. In a country of dedicated cat lovers, Diego has been said to be Iceland‚Äôs most famous cat. Fans are known to make special trips to Skeifan just to try and spot Diego and a Facebook group in his honor has over 9,500 members. According to a post on the group on Friday, Diego suffered torn muscles and ligaments in the accident, as well as a bag wound on one leg. He underwent surgery and was to be kept in the animal hospital overnight. Shortly after news of his accident went public, A4 started collecting donations to help pay for Diego‚Äôs medical bills. A total of ISK 400,000 [$2,838; ‚Ç¨2,725] was collected for Diego‚Äôs owners, with A4 and Domino‚Äôs both donating ISK 100,000 each [$709; ‚Ç¨681]. This article was updated.

headline: Twenty-Four People Connected to Downtown Knife Attack Released from Custody
body: Police have released twenty-four people who were being held in connection with the knife attack in downtown Reykjav√≠k last weekend, R√öV reports. Six individuals remain in custody. A knife attack at the Bankastr√¶ti Club nightclub in Reykjav√≠k last weekend left three young men hospitalised, following which, there was a spate of retaliatory crime against the suspects‚Äô families. Petrol bombs were thrown into family members‚Äô homes, windows were broken, and the suspects‚Äô families were also subjected to harassment. Three people have now been arrested for throwing the petrol and smoke bombs. See Also: Heightened Police Presence in Reykjav√≠k This Weekend DS Margeir Sveinsson noted that despite the fact that police have released two dozen people connected with the incident, these individuals are still legally considered defendants in the case. ‚ÄúBut there‚Äôs no need or reason to keep them in custody any longer,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve managed to determine what happened there and what everyone‚Äôs part was. Next step is to process all the data we have, that is, phone data etc. to get a handle on the lead-up [to the event]. But we don‚Äôt need to keep people in jail to do that.‚Äù There was initially some fear that the wave of retaliatory crimes would continue, but there was no additional incident on Thursday night, which Margeir said he hoped was a good sign. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs hope that people will come to their senses and quit this nonsense and that things will calm down a bit.‚Äù

headline: Heightened Police Presence in Reykjav√≠k This Weekend
body: Partygoers in downtown Reykjav√≠k this weekend can expect an increased presence among police authorities. The Capital Area‚Äôs Assistant Chief of Police has told R√öV that the police will ‚Äúbe ready‚Äù in the event of retaliatory violence following last weekend‚Äôs knife attack. Following mass arrests in wake of a knife attack at the Bankastr√¶ti Club nightclub in Reykjav√≠k last weekend, which left three young men hospitalised, petrol bombs were thrown into houses, windows broken, and the suspects‚Äô families were subjected to harassment. There were also posts on social media, encouraging retaliation for the attacks. The American and British embassies in Iceland subsequently issued travel advisories to tourists, warning them to avoid large crowds downtown this weekend. Addressing these issues on the radio programme Morgun√∫tvarpi√∞ this morning, √Åsgeir √û√≥r √Åsgeirsson, Assistant Chief of Police for the Capital Area Police, stated that the police would command a much greater presence in downtown Reykjav√≠k this weekend, in the event that further acts of violence were to be perpetrated. ‚ÄúAs far as we‚Äôve gathered, there were, and are, threats of violence this weekend ‚Äì and the operations of certain Reykjav√≠k restaurants are expected to be disturbed,‚Äù √Åsgeir stated. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to protect our city this weekend ‚Äì as we‚Äôve always done.‚Äù When asked if individuals connected to the gang violence last weekend were expected to perpetrate further violence, √Åsgeir replied that he hoped not. ‚ÄúBut law enforcement isn‚Äôt predicated on hope. We have to be ready when we say that we‚Äôll be ready and we‚Äôll be ready this weekend.‚Äù √Åsgeir was unwilling to offer details on the exact meaning of ‚Äúan increased presence‚Äù among police authorities but stated that they would mobilise more equipment and more officers capable of handling ‚Äúdifficult assignments.‚Äù This heightened police presence would not be lost on anyone. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs absolutely clear that the people will feel our presence. We hope that the people involved in these altercations have come to their senses and won‚Äôt be dragging their disputes to downtown Reykjav√≠k. I think that that‚Äôs something all of us, collectively, have been aiming towards,‚Äù √Åsgeir stated.

headline: Prison Guards to Receive Stab-Resistant Vests, Possibly Tasers
body: The Minister of Justice will answer the call from prison guards regarding increased training and protective equipment, Mbl.is reports. The Director General of Prison and Probation Administration notes a worrying trend of violence and weapons use within Icelandic prisons. As noted in an article published on Mbl.is yesterday morning, violence and weapons use among Icelandic prisoners have greatly increased over the past years. In light of this trend, prison guards have called for better protective equipment, stab-resistant vests, and, in some instances, access to tasers. P√°ll Winkel, Director General of Prison and Probation Administration, told Mbl.is that the prison system was facing a ‚Äúnew reality,‚Äù with weapons now being confiscated from cells and common areas on a regular basis. ‚ÄúThis was almost unheard of, a couple of years ago. It‚Äôs my responsibility, first and foremost, to ensure the safety of my employees. We‚Äôre not enthusiastic about carrying weapons within our prisons, but we obviously need to reassess our protocols. And we may need to reconsider how we interact with certain groups of inmates, i.e. those who create and carry makeshift weapons,‚Äù P√°ll stated, adding that these weapons were improvised from shards of plexiglass, saw-blades, screwdrivers, screws, and nails. Speaking to V√≠sir.is yesterday, prison guard Sigur√∞ur R√∫nar Hafli√∞ason stated that he‚Äôd experienced these trends first-hand: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got this much tougher, more violent core of prisoners, who are also abusing drugs to a greater extent. And so there‚Äôs a big difference in how we‚Äôre managing prisoners today, compared to when I was starting.‚Äù As noted by the article, three serious assaults have been perpetrated against prison guards this year. According to Sigur√∞ur, the younger generation of prisoners commonly carries knives and post-traumatic stress has increased among prison guards. Sigur√∞ur R√∫nar doesn‚Äôt necessarily believe that tasers are necessary, arguing that stab-resistant vests and improved training is vital. ‚ÄúWe need to improve safety ‚Ä¶ we need training so that people feel safe while they‚Äôre at work.‚Äù Mass arrests and budgetary constraints have also put pressure on an already strained system. In an article published in Morgunbla√∞i√∞ this morning, Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson stated that the safety of prison guards and police officers was ‚Äúa priority.‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs happening inside prison walls reflects broader trends within our society,‚Äù J√≥n remarked. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve had extensive conversations with the prison authorities, and it‚Äôs clear that we must respond on many different levels.‚Äù According to J√≥n, this response will, among other things, include stab-resistant vests. The Ministry is also considering equipping prison guards with tasers. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve repeatedly witnessed serious incidents within the country‚Äôs prisons. It‚Äôs clear that it‚Äôs necessary to equip our people in such a way that their safety is ensured at their places of employment. And we do that by providing better protective equipment. Additionally, we need to consider structural organisation; we can‚Äôt allow things to develop in such a manner within our prisons.‚Äù Physical altercations involving knives have been in the news lately, with a knife attack at the Bankastr√¶ti Club nightclub last weekend and a fifteen-year old boy being stabbed in the Garfarvogur neighbourhood of Reykjav√≠k earlier this week.

headline: Number of Apartments Sold in Capital Area Hits Two-Year Low
body: 331 apartments were sold in the capital area in October, a 22% decline compared to the previous month. The number of apartments sold in the capital area has hit a two-year low, Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞ reports. This week, the Central Bank announced that it was raising key interest rates by an additional 0.25%. Short-term interest rates (seven-day term deposits) would thereby reach 6%. The increase, which serve to complicate wage negotiations, came in response to a month-on-month rise in inflation, which rose from 9.3% in September to 9.4% in October. In an interview with Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞, √ùmir √ñrn Finnbogason, an analyst at Deloitte, explained that rising interest rates had led to a cooling real-estate market; an update to Deloitte‚Äôs real-estate dashboard, based on statistics from Registers Iceland, showed a 22% decline in the sale of apartments in the capital area in October when compared to September. As noted by Deloitte‚Äôs report, even though sales have declined, prices have remained almost unchanged between the months: the average price of a square metre for an apartment was ISK 709,000 ($5,000 / ‚Ç¨4,800) October, ISK 2,000 ($14 / in ‚Ç¨14) higher than in September. ‚ÄúRising interest rates and economic uncertainty have an obvious effect,‚Äù √ùmir √ñrn told Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞. √ùmir expects the real-estate market to continue cooling over the coming months, in light of growing tensions in the economy and wage negotiations. As noted by Deloitte, single-family homes and apartments have followed the same trend, with fewer properties being sold in both categories: the number of single-family homes sold in October compared to September declined by 16%. The average price of a square metre also declined from ISK 647,000 ($4,600 / ‚Ç¨4,400) to ISK 624,000 ($4,400 / ‚Ç¨4,300). ‚ÄúReal-estate prices reflect consumers‚Äô investment power, which is primarily affected by the cost of borrowing money, i.e. interest rates. And rising interest rates obviously lead to a cooling market,‚Äù √ùmir √ñrn stated. As noted by Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞, the price of apartments and multi-family homes have risen in North and East Iceland but fallen in South and West Iceland.

headline: Bus Scanners Rendered Unusable
body: Str√¶t√≥ has missed payments on its ticketing system, Klapp, leaving the QR code scanners unusable and in need of replacement. Kjartan Magn√∫sson, city representative for the Independence Party, has stated that the situation has led to excessive costs for Str√¶t√≥, which it is not in a position to handle. Serious mistakes have been made in the adoption and implementation of the new payment system, he said. Str√¶t√≥ has now had to postpone payment of its bills due to a lack of funds. According to Kjartan, at an annual meeting of municipal associations, Sorpa, and the Capital Area Fire Department, it came to light that Str√¶t√≥, Iceland‚Äôs public transportation system, is barely operational. Where annual projections forecast an operational deficit of ISK 93 million, Str√¶t√≥ has actually operated at an ISK 1.1 billion loss just in the first nine months of 2022. The gap between projected and actual losses is significant, and Str√¶t√≥‚Äôs equity has subsequently seen a decrease of ISK 22 million. Kjartan is quoted in Morgunbla√∞i√∞ as stating: ‚ÄúFor a whole year, passengers have received the answer that it was just a growing pain, which would soon be a thing of the past. At the meeting, however, it was stated that the scanners used in the buses would be unusable and the only solution would be to replace them all and buy new ones.‚Äù This will represent significant further costs to an already-struggling transportation system.

headline: Explosion and Smoke from a Reykjav√≠k Restaurant Last Night
body: Police and firefighters responded to a call around 2:00 last night at the Dubliner, a bar in downtown Reykjav√≠k. An explosion and smoke were reported as issuing from the bar. No one was reported injured in the incident. According to a statement by an on-duty officer in the fire department, something had been thrown into the bar, but the fire department could not tell the exact nature of the object. When firefighters arrived on the scene, they reported smoke, but no fire. ‚ÄúThere was a window pane that was smashed to bits,‚Äù reported a firefighter to V√≠sir. ‚ÄúOur task was to clear the smoke out of the area, but it‚Äôs the police that are investigating the matter.‚Äù This is notable as the second night in a row that Reykjav√≠k police and firefighters have been called out to respond to firebomb attacks in the Reykjav√≠k area. The previous night, two firebomb attacks were reported in Fossvogur in Reykjav√≠k and in Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur. Reykjav√≠k police have confirmed that the incidents are connected to the recent stabbings at a Reykjav√≠k night club, which authorities believe stems from a gang conflict. ¬† The recent spate of violence has caused both American and British embassies in Iceland to issue travel advisories to tourists, warning them to avoid large crowds downtown this weekend.

headline: President Raises Goal to 1,500 Ramps
body: President of Iceland Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson raised the target goal of Ramp Up Iceland at a press event for the organisation this Monday, November 21, from 1,000 new ramps to 1,500. The president ‚Äúheckled‚Äù Ramp Up founder Haraldur √ûorleifsson, interrupting his presentation by spray-painting over the poster with his new, more ambitious goal.¬† Ramp Up Iceland is an initiative which aims to increase accessibility to people in wheelchairs throughout Iceland. Ramp Up coordinates between businesses, contractors, and state and city authorities to make applying for permits and grants easier. Ramp Up originally had a goal of 1,000 handicap-accessible ramps in Iceland by 2026, but this goal has now been raised to 1,500. As we were celebrating the first 300 ramps, @PresidentISL heckled my speech and announced we are raising our @rampur goal from 1000 to 1500 ramps across all of Iceland.And since he's the president I guess we have to do it. pic.twitter.com/XkcDjsssrB Haraldur √ûorleifsson, a Twitter employee, is notable as one of Iceland‚Äôs highest taxpayers. The founder of the Ramp Up initiative, he has used his income from the sale of his company Ueno to Twitter to fund this philanthropic project, among other things. Haraldur is also noteworthy as an outspoken proponent of Iceland‚Äôs social system, choosing to pay income instead of capital gains tax on the Ueno sale, citing the many advantages he has received through his Icelandic education and healthcare. The Ramp Up press event took place in Mj√≥dd, a bus station, in celebration of the 300th ramp built under the initiative. During the event, the president asked if 1,000 ramps would be enough, and interrupted Haraldur to spraypaint over his previous goal. In response, Haraldur stated: ‚ÄúGu√∞ni is of course the president, so when he says something, we have to listen.‚Äù He continued: ‚ÄúWe all live in a community together, and when people need help, then we all have a responsibility to help out. I am just happy to be able to contribute.‚Äù Many businesses and public places throughout Iceland remain inaccessible to people in wheelchairs, especially older buildings. Haraldur has, however, stated that the overall reaction to his initiative has been very positive.

headline: A Third of Icelanders Read Books Every Day, Study Finds
body: Icelanders read or listen to an average of 2.4 books a month, according to a new survey conducted by the Icelandic Literature Centre. The survey notes an increase in the number of individuals who read five or more books a month and those who report not reading at all. According to a new survey conducted by the Icelandic Literature Centre ‚Äì which has been conducted annually since 2017 ‚Äì the percentage of individuals who ‚Äúnever read‚Äù has increased (from 32.1% last year to 40.4% this year). However, so has the percentage of individuals who read five or more books a month.¬†The survey, which was conducted between October 14 and November 8 of this year, comprised 1,409 respondents (out of 2,800). The survey also found that over a third of Icelanders read or listen to books on a daily basis. The average number of books read per month has risen over the past two years; last year, Icelanders read an average of 2.3 books a month, compared to 2.4 books this year. 65% of respondents stated that they only or mainly read books published in the Icelandic language, which is up from 58% compared to last year. The survey also found significant differences between the genders. According to the results, women read an average of 3 books a month compared to 1.7 among men. The gap between the genders has slightly narrowed between the last two years, however. Here are a few other takeaways from the survey: When it comes to the Icelanders‚Äô taste in reading, most prefer novels, or 59%. Crime fiction was the second most popular genre among respondents. Over a half of respondents, 55%, stated that they received book recommendations from friends and relatives; 35% stated they were influenced by coverage from traditional media; and 31% from social media. Over the past 12 months, just over a third of Icelanders have borrowed books from libraries. The survey found that women borrow books from the library more frequently than men and parents with two or more children at home borrow books from the library most frequently. The results also indicate that fewer people are giving books as gifts when compared to last year. The survey was conducted by the Icelandic Literature Centre in collaboration with the Reykjav√≠k Library, the Association of Icelandic Book Publishers, Hag√æenki, the University Library, Reykjav√≠k UNESCO Literary City, and the Writers‚Äô Association of Iceland.

headline: Mass Arrests Put Pressure on Already-Strained Prison System
body: Iceland‚Äôs prison system is operating at near maximum capacity. Three times as many individuals are being kept in police custody than usual, the Director General of Prison and Probation Administration has stated. The police arrested 27 people following a knife attack at the Bankastr√¶ti Club in Reykjav√≠k last Thursday. Twelve suspects have been kept in custody, with the police having yet to decide whether they will request custody over five additional suspects. Four other individuals connected to the attack remain on the lam, some of whom are believed to have fled the country. P√°ll Winkel, the Director General of Prison and Probation Administration, told Mbl.is that a total of 60 people are currently being held in police custody ‚Äì three times the usual number. Aside from the many arrests made in relation to the Bankastr√¶ti Club attack, there have also been numerous arrests made in connection with drug busts and violent crimes. ‚ÄúIt does, of course, put tremendous pressure on the system,‚Äù P√°ll observed, ‚Äúdetaining 15 prisoners in isolation. It calls for greater manpower and organisation; you need to safeguard investigative interests, that the prisoners don‚Äôt meet, while, at the same time, ensuring that their rights are being respected.‚Äù ‚ÄúThese are people aged 19 and up. These are Icelanders and foreigners, men and women, non-disabled and disabled persons, including one individual who‚Äôs blind.‚Äù Most of the prisoners are being detained in the H√≥lmshei√∞i prison, although some have been transferred to Litla-Hraun. According to P√°ll, the design of H√≥lmshei√∞i has proven advantageous, as there are spaces equally suited to regular confinement and isolation. P√°ll predicts that the situation will remain unchanged for a few more days but hopes that that will be the extent of it. ‚ÄúIt puts tremendous strain on the system. Also because it happens to coincide with our effort to temporarily decrease the number of prisoners so as to operate within budget constraints.‚Äù Speaking to R√öV, Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson stated that the government had already taken steps to deal with the pressure on the prison system, with extensive renovations at the Litla-Hraun prison expected to be completed next year. According to J√≥n Gunnarsson, there have been instances where prison sentences lapse owing to a lack of cells. ‚ÄúWe must respond, and we are doing our best,‚Äù he stated, admitting that increasing the number of prison cells would take time and that bridging the gap could prove tricky. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not quite sure how; this additional pressure means additional operational costs, and we‚Äôve even been in the position where we‚Äôve been unable to fully use all of the prison cells because of budgetary constraints ‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre working on it.‚Äù

headline: Minister of Justice to Declare War on Organised Crime
body: Minister of Justice J√≥n Gunnarsson has announced his intention to wage war against organised crime following the knife attacks in a Reykjav√≠k club last week, which have been taken as signs of gang warfare. On Thursday night, November 17, a group of masked and armed men stormed a Reykjav√≠k nightclub, stabbing three men, who were since transported to the ER. Of the nearly 30 men involved in the attack, already some 14 have been apprehended by the police. Two are suspected to have fled the country, with the police now searching for the remaining suspects. According to Minister J√≥n Gunnarsson, the incident reveals a problem with organised crime in a nation generally upheld for its security. In response to the minister‚Äôs call for a ‚Äúwar on crime,‚Äù efforts are now being prepared to attack the root causes of organised criminality in Iceland. The Minister has also expressed his desire to strengthen police powers, with what J√≥n Gunnarsson calls ‚Äúpreventative warrants,‚Äù allowing for ‚Äúproactive investigation.‚Äù Such measures have been controversial in Al√æingi, but J√≥n Gunnarsson has stated that his proposals would be ‚Äúharmless.‚Äù Such warrants would allow police to monitor individuals associated with known criminals and criminal activity, without themselves being found guilty of any crime. The proposed measures would also add tasers to the police arsenal. Currently, Icelandic police officers only carry batons and pepper spray in the field. In a statement to V√≠sir, the Minister said: ‚ÄúThe steps we take may prove to be controversial, I have no doubt about that. Both of these new authorisations, for preventative warrants and weapons for the police, may be controversial, but we have to do it.‚Äù ¬†

headline: Reykjav√≠k Commits to Accepting 1,500 Refugees Next Year
body: The City of Reykjav√≠k has signed a resolution, committing the city to accept 1,500 refugees next year. Under the leadership of Mayor Dagur B. Eggertsson and Minister of Social Affairs Gu√∞mundur Ingi Gu√∞brandsson, the city has announced its hope that other municipalities make similar plans in cooperation with the state as soon as possible. Such agreements between the state and municipalities were drafted earlier this fall concerning levels of state funding for the municipalities that will be accepting refugees. The funding was outlined in order for the municipalities to be better able to estimate the number of refugees they will be able to accept. Minister of Social Affairs Gu√∞mundur Ingi Gu√∞brandsson is quoted in V√≠sir as saying: ‚ÄúWe are in conversation with quite a few local authorities. I just want to encourage the municipalities, whatever their size, to get involved in this as well. I think that the kind of precedent that is being created by the country‚Äôs largest municipality getting involved now is very positive.‚Äù The City of Reykjav√≠k had previously committed to accepting 500 refugees. The new level represents a threefold increase over the previous figure. Despite the significant increase, Mayor Dagur B. Eggertsson has stressed that this number is only half of what Iceland has so far received this year. ‚ÄúThis number is much higher than previously,‚Äù stated Dagur to V√≠sir. ‚ÄúUnfortunately, I think we have to assume that the War in Ukraine will not be resolved anytime soon and that this will be an ongoing project for some time.‚Äù A pressing concern is to find housing for the incoming refugees. The capital region already faces difficulty in providing affordable housing, although recent initiatives have sought to incentivize further development.¬† ‚ÄúThis is of course a challenge,‚Äù stated Dagur. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no point in hiding that. But the city has been in agreement since the first days of the invasion that we condemn the invasion of Ukraine, and we have shown ourselves ready to work together with both the state and other municipalities in order to accept these refugees.‚Äù ¬†

headline: Petrol Bombs and Threats of Retaliation Following Knife Attack in Downtown Club
body: Reykjav√≠k and capital-area police are investigating a series of crimes believed to be connected to the knife attack that occurred at Bankastr√¶ti Club in downtown Reykjav√≠k on Thursday night. R√öV reports that in the wake of the attack, which left three young men hospitalized, petrol bombs have been thrown into houses, windows broken, and suspects‚Äô families subjected to harassment. There have also been posts on social media, encouraging retaliation for the attacks. Police believe that the incidents possibly herald the beginnings of a gang war, although this but one possible explanation. Police still searching for over ten suspects; two have fled the country A group of almost thirty people, all dressed in dark clothing and masks, barged into Bankastr√¶ti Club on Thursday night and attacked three men, all of whom were in their twenties, stabbing them repeatedly before fleeing the scene. The stabbing victims have since posted on social media, seemingly unruffled by the incident, and two of them were also interviewed on FM957 on Saturday. In the interview, they said that one of them had been stabbed a total of seven times, but was feeling pretty good, all things considered, or ‚Äúlike a king,‚Äù as he put it. As of Saturday, fourteen of those involved in the attack had been arrested and nine had been sentenced to two weeks in police custody. Police were still searching for over ten of the remaining suspects, although their identities were believed to be known. Two suspects have fled the country. Over the weekend, police called for anyone involved in the incident to come forward, but only one person did. A search of suspects‚Äô phone data is also underway, but police say this will be an extensive and intensive process. Stress on prison system The scope of the incident and the number of people remanded into custody is already straining the local prison system‚Äôs capacity, as it is unusual for so many people to be held at once. Halld√≥r Valur P√°lsson, director of the Icelandic prison system, says that while prison officials in no way anticipated an incident of this scope and with this many detainees, Icelandic prisons still have enough capacity to deal with the situation at present. But things could become serious, he says, if a gang war is, in fact, underway. ‚ÄúIt absolutely threatens the safety of the staff and other prisoners as well, if this kind of conflict is going on,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf there are gang conflicts happening out in society, they also find their ways into the prisons in the end.‚Äù The capacity issue is not just a question of being able to hold suspects while the police investigate, however. It also has a knock-on effect for those waiting to serve a prison sentence. New measures have been introduced in recent years that allow convicted individuals to serve their sentences outside of prison walls, for instance by means of electronic surveillance or community service. But there is still a waiting list for those who are actually required to serve their sentences in prison. These individuals must wait to serve their sentences until a facility has room for them. There are currently 317 individuals waiting to serve their prison sentences. Stabbing may be linked to motorcycle fire Police say that the investigation is progressing well, considering its scope. The inciting incident has yet to be confirmed, but it‚Äôs possible that the stabbings were related to two motorcycles that were set on fire in √Ålftam√Ωri on the east side of Reykjav√≠k last Wednesday night.

headline: Fatality in Bus and Scooter Collision
body: A man on an electric scooter died this weekend after colliding with a bus, R√öV reports. The victim, who was a foreign national living in Iceland, was in his twenties. This is the second fatal accident involving an electric scooter in Iceland. The first occurred almost a year ago exactly, in November of 2021, when a man in his 50s collided with a motorcycle. According to police spokesperson Gu√∞mundur P√°ll J√≥nsson, the man seems to have driven his scooter into the side of a group coach about the size of a bus, when it was travelling at low speed. The collision took place at the corner of Bar√≥nst√≠gur and Grettisgata around 9:00 pm on Saturday night. Police are still investigating the circumstances of the accident. The The Red Cross offered trauma support and counseling to seventeen of the passengers, as well as three more witnesses on Sunday. Sunday also happened to be a day of memorial for victims of traffic accidents. Eight people have died in traffic-related accidents in Iceland in 2022. This article has been updated.

headline: Three Wounded Following Knife Attack in Reykjav√≠k Nightclub
body: Four people have been arrested following a physical altercation at a Reykjav√≠k nightclub yesterday, R√öV reports. Three men in their early twenties, all of whom had suffered knife wounds, were transported to the ER. A group of men barged into the nightclub Bankstr√¶ti Club in downtown Reykjav√≠k last night. The group, reportedly dressed in dark clothes, attacked three other men (all of whom are about twenty years old) before absconding from the club. The police were notified at just after 11.30 PM and arrived on the scene quickly, R√öV reports. The police immediately began searching for the assailants, who are believed to have been inside the club briefly. Dozens of police officers were involved in the investigation and a few search warrants have already been executed. The Capital Area Police, assisted by special forces, has stated that the investigation is a priority. Investigators aim to determine whether the assault was an act of revenge or a reckoning, R√öV reports. Most of the involved parties are believed to be Icelandic, although details currently remain unclear. ‚ÄúThe police were armed during yesterday‚Äôs operations, given the seriousness of the attack,‚Äù a statement by the police reads.

headline: Hot-Water Supply Nearing Limit, Rationing to be Considered
body: The nation‚Äôs hot-water supply is nearing its limit, V√≠sir reports. Utility companies may need to begin rationing hot water during long periods of cold weather, a specialist at Samorka has stated. Samorka, a federation of energy and utility companies in Iceland, held an open meeting at the Harpa Conference Hall yesterday. During the meeting, specialists assessed the hot-water supply of the largest utility companies and reviewed forecasts of future demand. In an interview with V√≠sir, Lov√≠sa √Årnad√≥ttir, Samorka‚Äôs public relations officer, stated that the situation at the nation‚Äôs utility companies was serious: hot-water use has outpaced population growth. Utility companies are stretched to the limit trying to meet the current demand ‚Äì not to mention the growing demand in the future. The demand in the capital area is expected to increase by 3% annually. ‚ÄúIf we peer further into the future, to the year 2060, for example, forecasts suggest that the output of the entire heating system would need to be doubled. In terms of relative size: the Hellishei√∞i Power Station, which provides hot water for most of Reykjav√≠k, is approximately twice the size of the K√°rahnj√∫ka Power Station. And so we‚Äôre talking about a lot of energy, and doubling the output is no small task,‚Äù Lov√≠sa told V√≠sir. Approximately 60% of the energy used in Iceland comprises hot water for domestic heating, baths, and other household consumption. This amounts to 43 terawatt hours (a unit of energy equal to outputting one trillion watts for one hour), or twice the amount of energy produced by all of the nation‚Äôs electric power stations. ‚ÄúThe current production areas are already operating at maximum capacity, and so we need to look for ways to make them more efficient. We could do this by, for example, encouraging individuals to use their hot water more frugally,‚Äù Lov√≠sa remarked. This could be accomplished by encouraging individuals to take brief showers instead of baths and by managing sidewalk heating during the summer. Utility companies all over Iceland are considering their next steps. ‚ÄúThe problem is that geothermal exploration takes a long time, which is part of the problem why we‚Äôre struggling to meet demand right now: because increased demand has exceeded forecasts and geothermal exploration can take a decade. Familiarising ourselves with new geothermal systems also takes time.‚Äù Speaking in layman‚Äôs terms, Almar Barja, a specialist at Samorka, stated that utility companies may need to ration hot water, possibly to households, businesses, and service providers ‚Äì in the event of long periods of cold weather this winter or the next. According to Almar, it is not clear how the problem is to be solved, at least in the short term, an article in V√≠sir notes. Almar also noted that consumption patterns were changing, with individuals opting for roomier homes, more people choosing to live alone, and families shrinking. All of this means that an increasingly greater number of square metres need to be heated. Almar added that Samorka was also not seeing frugal use among consumers nor the expected contraction in hot-water use following directives on the insulation of houses, the improved insulation of new houses, e.g. by floor heating.‚Äù

headline: 150 Cattle Taken by Authorities in Abuse Case
body: 150 cattle have been removed from a farm in Borgarfj√∂r√∞ur by the authorities on November 14 and 15. After repeated demands by authorities that their owner improve their conditions, authorities have finally been forced to confiscate the cattle after it became clear the farmer in question would not cooperate. Both police officers and representatives from MAST, the Icelandic Food and Veterinary Authority, were at the scene, reports R√öV. The owner in question is said to have a long history of mistreating his animals. Sheep and horses have been previously taken from the farmer to be slaughtered, as they were too maltreated to be rescued. Some cattle confiscated in the latest episode will likewise be slaughtered, but many of the cows will be allowed to live and given new homes. Ellen Ruth Ingimundsd√≥ttir, district veterinarian for Southwest Iceland, stated that such cases are very difficult for all involved: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a long and difficult story. We decided that it was no longer possible to give deadlines that weren‚Äôt met [‚Ä¶] We don‚Äôt take animals from people just because we want to. We need to follow the law and we need to do this in consultation with locals so that it doesn‚Äôt hurt the animals. That‚Äôs why it has also taken a long time.‚Äù Ellen additionally thanked those farmers who will be receiving the remaining cows, which are headed to barns with better pasture and conditions. ¬†

headline: A Third of Icelanders Read Daily
body: A new report from the Icelandic Literature Center has shed new and interesting light on the reading habits of Icelanders. The annual study has been carried out since 2017. On average, Icelanders listen to 2.4 books per month, with 32% of the nation reading at least once a day. However, Icelandic readership is undergoing a notable shift, with both the groups of those who never read and those who ‚Äúbinge read‚Äù growing. The study also reported a marked difference between the genders, with women reading significantly more than men. The gender gap also correlates with a gap in education, with the college-educated generally reading more than those with a secondary level of education. Older people were found to read on average more than younger people, with the youngest group polled, those between 18 and 24, reading the least out of all groups. In a comparison between the capital region and Iceland‚Äôs countryside, no significant difference was recorded. Some 65% of Icelanders read either exclusively or mostly in Icelandic. This represents a slight change from last year, when the figure sat at 58%. 18% of those polled read equally in Icelandic and another language, with another 14% of residents reading more often in another language than Icelandic. Finally, 3% of those polled read exclusively in another language. The language difference also breaks down along age, with those 34 and younger generally reading in other languages more often than the older groups polled. Usage of public library resources was also recorded, with women again using the library more often than men. Among the top users of public libraries were households with two or more children. The report, which can be read in full here, was authored in cooperation with the Reykjav√≠k City Library, Association of Icelandic Publishers, Hag√æenkir, the National and University Library of Iceland, Reykjav√≠k UNSECO City of Literature, and the Writers‚Äô Union of Iceland.

headline: Dramatic Helicopter Maneuvering Saves Life
body: An Icelandic coast guard helicopter likely saved a man‚Äôs life last Friday when it flew backwards for five kilometres to √çsafj√∂r√∞ur. The dramatic manoeuvre was needed because of weather conditions in √çsafj√∂r√∞ur, and doctors at the National Hospital of Iceland say that the helicopter crew‚Äôs decisive action likely saved the man‚Äôs life. This story was first reported by V√≠sir. Conditions were extreme in √çsafj√∂r√∞ur when the call for help came to Iceland‚Äôs coast guard last Friday, with wind ranging between 35 to 40 m/s, and little to no visibility. Andri J√≥hannesson, helicopter pilot in the coast guard, stated that the mission was one of the most difficult he had been a part of in his 15-year career. Andri stated to V√≠sir that when the crew arrived in the Westfjords, wind conditions were so bad that it was not possible to fly straight into √çsafj√∂r√∞ur like usual. With a strong north-northwest wind, it would have been extremely dangerous to fly into the fjord, but nevertheless, the crew tried twice to fly into the fjord at a low altitude. However, the zero-visibility conditions made this impossible. After these failed attempts, the crew was forced to make a roadside landing in order to assess the situation further. When the crew took stock of the situation, it was clear that they were running low on fuel. The crew had flown in a stiff headwind all the way from Reykjav√≠k, and the multiple attempts at entering the fjord had forced them to spend more time in the air than they had planned. The crew would not be able to make it to Bolungarv√≠k, a village near √çsafj√∂rur, and the location of the patient. The crew would be forced to land in √çsafj√∂r√∞ur to refuel and pick up the patient there. Given the conditions, the crew realised they would not be able to fly the usual way, with the wind at their back, as it would be impossible to turn the helicopter to land in √çsafj√∂r√∞ur. The decision was made to instead fly with ‚Äútheir nose in the wind,‚Äù that is, backwards, for a total of five kilometres. This, however, was not the end of the drama. Given the low visibility, flight mechanic √Årni Freyr had to lead the way. With the back of the helicopter open, √Årni directed the final approach of the helicopter. In a harness and partially hanging out of the helicopter, √Årni led the crew like this for some 20 minutes. Upon landing in √çsafj√∂r√∞ur and taking on the patient, the helicopter was forced to perform a ‚Äúhot refuelling,‚Äù in which the engine stays on. Given the harsh winds, it may have been impossible to start the rotors again if the engine was turned off during the refuelling process. The patient, who had suffered a heart attack, was immediately sent into surgery upon arrival in Reykjav√≠k, and doctors claim he would have died without the crew‚Äôs bravery. The story, dramatic as it is, highlights the critical role played by emergency services in Iceland. Many remote parts of Iceland become largely inaccessible during the winter. Often, there is only one rescue helicopter on call, and there have been calls to increase funding to the coast guard and search and rescue services. ¬† ¬†

headline: Esports Manager Among Suspects of Iceland‚Äôs Biggest Cocaine Bust
body: None of the four individuals arrested during the biggest cocaine bust in Icelandic history has a criminal record, V√≠sir reports. A lumber dealer and a former eSports team manager are among the suspects that were arrested this summer. The case will be filed in court tomorrow. In August of this year, the police confiscated 100 kg of cocaine, which had been hidden inside seven logs included within a timber shipment to Iceland. The drugs were planted inside the logs in Brazil before being shipped to Iceland via the Netherlands. As reported by V√≠sir, the Icelandic police got wind of the shipment in connection to an investigation into organised crime and subsequently notified police authorities in Rotterdam. The Rotterdam police replaced the cocaine with a fake substance before the container was shipped to Iceland. The estimated street value of the drugs is ISK 2 billion ($14 million / ‚Ç¨13 million). The indictment states that the container was shipped from customs to Borgart√∫n in Reykjav√≠k where it stood unmoved for two days. The container was then transported to Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur, where the cocaine were removed, packaged, and delivered to a third party for distribution and sale. The police subsequently seized the cocaine inside a vehicle on Vefarastr√¶ti in Mosfellsb√¶r. The suspects have been charged with engaging in organised criminal activity, attempted large-scale narcotics offences, and money laundering. The case will be filed in the Reykjav√≠k District Court tomorrow.¬† As noted by V√≠sir, none of the suspects possesses a criminal record of note. One of the defendants is a timber dealer in his sixties, whose company, H√∫s og Har√∞vi√∞ur, was used to launder money. The other suspects are in their twenties and thirties, and include a former team manager of Iceland‚Äôs eFootball national team. The district attorney has motioned for several items, believed to have been purchased with ill-gotten gains, to be seized: including a Rolex watch, a Lexus, almost 100 logs of timber, a Volkswagen jeep (believed to have been purchased for the transportation of drugs), and a number of smartphones, among other things. During a raid on the suspects‚Äô homes, the police found quantities of drugs, including MDMA, marijuana, and cannabis. Cash deposits that could not be accounted for All of the four suspects are charged with money laundering and are believed to have, for some time leading up to the arrests on August 4, received, stored, converted, or gained from profits resulting from criminal offences. The police believe that millions of Icelandic kr√≥na were stored in the suspects‚Äô bank accounts, for which they could not account. In most instances, the money was traced to cash deposits. As reported by V√≠sir, the defendants are expected to receive lengthy sentences. Recently, two men received 12-year sentences ‚Äì the maximum punishment for such crimes ‚Äì for extensive drug offences, having imported narcotics to Iceland via a salt spreader.¬† According to Chief Superintendent Gr√≠mur Gr√≠msson, the recent cocaine busts may have led to an increase in drug-trafficking through Keflav√≠k Airport, which have been on the rise over the past weeks and months.

headline: Enrollment in Opioid-Substitution Treatment on the Rise
body: Individuals receiving opioid-substitution treatment have significantly increased over the past years. According to Minister of Health Willum √û√≥r √û√≥rsson, 276 people were enrolled in the treatment in 2019, compared to 438 in 2021. Following a formal enquiry by MP Dilj√° Mist Einarsd√≥ttir ‚Äì on whether doctors would be granted greater authority to prescribe opioids to those struggling with addiction ‚Äì Minister of Health Willum √û√≥r √û√≥rsson gave no indication before Parliament that greater authority would be granted. Read more: In Harm‚Äôs Way: Opioid Addiction in the Age of Harm Reduction Willum √û√≥r explained that opioid-substitution treatment is provided primarily by three institutions in Iceland: S√Å√Å (the National Centre of Addiction Medicine), the University Hospital of Iceland (Landsp√≠talinn), and the Akureyri Hospital in North Iceland. The main drug employed during treatment in Iceland is Buprenorphine, both in tablet and injectable form, which is a licensed drug (‚Äúcostly and/or must be treated with care‚Äù) administered at no cost to patients and supervised by the University Hospital‚Äôs Medicines Advisory Board. The use of Buprenorphine in injectable form, Willum noted, is restricted to healthcare institutions (H-label) while Buprenorphine in tablet form must be prescribed by doctors with knowledge and experience of addiction (Z-label). This means that physicians specialising in addiction treatment, who have secured a license and can demonstrate experience, outnumber psychiatrists when it comes to the prescription of Buprenorphine. Willum also noted that Buprenorphine is primarily administered to patients at Vogur‚Äôs MAT (medication-assisted treatment) clinic in Reykjav√≠k (in accordance with an agreement regarding opioid substitution treatment signed by Icelandic Health Insurance and S√Å√Å) although a number of patients retrieve their drugs in tablet-form at pharmacies. As noted by the National Library of Medicine, opioid-substitution therapy (OST) is an ‚Äúevidence-based intervention‚Äù for opiate-dependent individuals, which replaces ‚Äúillicit drug use with medically prescribed, orally administered opiates such as buprenorphine and methadone.‚Äù As noted in the Minister‚Äôs response before Parliament, individuals receiving opioid-substitution treatment (OST) have ‚Äúincreased significantly over the past years.‚Äù According to the minister, 276 people were enrolled in the treatment in 2019, compared to 438 in 2021. S√Å√Å‚Äôs medication-assisted treatment (MAT) clinic at the Vogur treatment centre has gradually expanded over the years and as of late summer treats 250 patients ‚Äì most of whom have injected opioids or have suffered serious consequences as a result of their addiction. According to Dr Valger√∞ur R√∫narsd√≥ttir, the Medical Director of S√Å√Å, MAT patients receive methadone, buprenorphine pills, or injections, which reduce withdrawal symptoms and cravings for opioids. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a low threshold for participation,‚Äù Valger√∞ur stated. ‚ÄòWe‚Äôd be seeing a much higher overdose rate if it weren‚Äôt for this programme. We also collaborate with other healthcare and social services to help people become sober. If we want to improve the lives of these people, these factors must be entwined.‚Äù Although most of the patients in Vogur‚Äôs MAT are either sober or aspiring toward abstinence, there are also some who are not ready to quit. It is important to provide services to these individuals, and the City of Reykjav√≠k, according to Valger√∞ur, has greatly improved access to housing for this group of people over the past years. ‚ÄúThings are much better today compared to ten years ago,‚Äù she stated, adding that besides offering treatment and other services, removing stigma is also vital.

headline: Results of 2021 Census Reveal Changes in Icelandic Society
body: Statistics Iceland has recently published new data from the 2021 census, revealing a growing nation and shifting demographics. Here, we break down some of the major takeaways. The full report can be found here. As of January 1, 2022, Iceland is home to some 359,122 residents. This represents a 13.8% increase from the last census, taken in 2011. Statistics Iceland reports a discrepancy of some 10,000 inhabitants with the records of Registers Iceland. This population growth is distributed very unevenly across Iceland. Su√∞urnes, the region of the Reykjanes peninsula outside of the capital area, has grown by some 28%, with South Iceland following at 19%, and the capital region at 15%. The slowest growers have been Northwest Iceland, at 0.6%, and the Westfjords, at 1.6%. However, these numbers are not entirely telling the full story. Although no region has experienced a population decline on average, the countryside is still decreasing in residents. In West Iceland, for instance, when the town of Akranes in included, the region saw overall growth. But when Akranes is not accounted for, the region as a whole decreased in population considerably. On average, Iceland has 3.5 inhabitants per square kilometre. Iceland, like many other Western nations, is also an ageing nation. In 2011, the proportion of the population 67 and older was 11%, but this figure now stands at 13%. The gender balance has also shifted slightly since the last census. In 2011, some 49.9% of Icelanders identified as women, but according to the latest figures, that figure now rests at 49%.

headline: Committee on Icelandic Language Established
body: A committee on the Icelandic language has been established in line with Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir‚Äôs previous proposal. The proposal emerged out of the coalition agreement for the current parties, which emphasised the need to support the use of Icelandic among young people, and to support immigrants and their families in Icelandic learning. There has also been increasing dialogue in recent months around language learning for foreigners, with some saying that much still needs to be done to make Icelandic as a second language more accessible. The committee will be headed by the Prime Minister, the Minister of Culture and Trade, the Minister of Education and Children‚Äôs Affairs, and the Minister of Social Affairs and Labour Market. Together, the committee will work to create and implement an action plan to address the shortcomings of Icelandic education and language promotion. ‚ÄúThe Icelandic language is invaluable to Icelandic society. However, the language faces challenges in rapid technological and social changes we must respond to. We must increase access to and dissemination of Icelandic content and promote teaching for diverse social groups, as well as ensure the future of Icelandic in the digital world,‚Äù said Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir in a statement. The Prime Minister will speak further on the matter at the ‚ÄúIcelandic Is for All of Us‚Äù forum today at 16:00, held on the occasion of the Icelandic National Language Day, which takes place this week. For further coverage of this important topic, see Nothing to Speak Of, now open to all readers.

headline: Report on √çslandsbanki Sale Highlights Lack of Transparency, Reliance on Outside Consultants
body: State regulators have released a report on the controversial sale of √çslandsbanki shares that took place this March. Among the considerations of the report are details on the dissemination of information of the sale, the determination of its sale price, and the selection process for determining the qualified investors. After the 2008 banking collapse, the insolvent banks were restructured, leading to the partial socialisation of Iceland‚Äôs three major banks, Landsbankinn, Arion, and √çslandsbanki. Landsbankinn continues to be held by the state with a majority share. However, √çslandsbanki has been gradually privatized since the restructuring, with an initial 35% of √çslandsbanki shares being sold in June 2021. After a sharp rise in share prices after the sale, some claimed that the shares were undervalued. In March 2022, a second round of sales was slated, with 22.5% of √çslandsbanki shares to be sold off. This second offering, however, was not a public offering like the first, but was limited to a group of ‚Äúqualified investors.‚Äù Among the qualified investors were the usual suspects, including foreign and domestic investors, and pension funds. However, the list also included some notable individuals such as Benedikt Sveinsson, father of Bjarni Benediktsson, Minister of Finance and the individual legally responsible for the sale. The revelations caused widespread critique of Bjarni, the oversight committee, and the coalition government in power. There were also claims of insider trading, as significant numbers of investors sold off their holdings within days and weeks after a climb in price. In total, the sale involved 450 million shares in the bank to 207 investors. The selling price was ISK 117 per share and the sale proceeds amounted to ISK 52.7 billion (USD 361,000,000; EUR 351,000,000).¬†The state‚Äôs share in √çslandsbanki is now 42.5%. Now, the Icelandic National Audit Office is trying to determine the nature of the sale, how the investors were selected, and how the √çslandsbanki share were valued. The official report can be seen here. According to the report, the sale could have been better prepared and executed. Outside the scope of the report are the legitimacy and legality of the sale, which are left to the Financial Supervision Authority of the Central Bank of Iceland. Instead, the report focuses on the technical execution of the sale and its valuation of the shares. According to the report, ‚Äúthe language used in the documents submitted by the Icelandic State Financial Investments (ISFI) to parliament was not suitable for drawing a clear picture of the arrangement of the sale process. Despite the experience and knowledge of the employees and the board of the Banking Authority in the field of administration and sale of the state‚Äôs holdings in financial companies, the institution did not have experience in bidding arrangements in the run-up to the sale [‚Ä¶] Adequate conditions were not given to supervisors, sales consultants and dealers, and due to shortcomings in the implementation, demand was underestimated when deciding on the indicative final price. Sufficient consideration was not given to possible reputational risks, nor were the principles of transparency observed. As the bidding system was implemented, it could not guarantee full equality for the investors to whom it was directed.‚Äù The report also identifies an over-reliance on external consultants in the private sector. ¬† ¬† ¬†

headline: Hr√≠sey Island Receives Development Grant of ISK Ten Million
body: Hr√≠sey Island has received a regional development grant of ISK ten million, R√öV reports. The √Åfram Hr√≠sey (‚ÄòOnwards, Hr√≠sey‚Äô) grant is intended to increase available housing and draw new residents to the island. The island of Hr√≠sey is located 35 km [22 mi] north of Akureyri and although small (approx. 7.67¬†km2 or 2.96¬†mi2), is known for its rich bird life. Forty species of birds make their home on Hr√≠sey, with ptarmigans being particularly prolific. It is also home to the largest breeding colony of Arctic terns in Europe. By comparison, however, only 200 people live on the island, and this is something that the grant seeks to address. ‚ÄúRight now, our most pressing issue is housing,‚Äù says resident √Åsr√∫n √ùr Gestsd√≥ttir, who has been hired as the grant‚Äôs project manager. ‚ÄúWe have people who want to move here, but we don‚Äôt have housing for them. We have a lot of houses, but almost half of them are empty for most of the month or the year.‚Äù The grant will make it possible to accelerate the process of building new housing and drawing more people to the island full-time. ‚ÄúUp until now, almost everything has been done by volunteers here‚Ä¶we‚Äôve just been doing it whenever possible, sending news to the media while eating dinner. Right now, there‚Äôs only one person submitting something for us and contacting the planning department in Akureyri and the town council and people we need to call.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe hope that when this project ends in spring 2024, we‚Äôll have seen some progress,‚Äù says √Åsr√∫n √ùr. ‚ÄúThat there will have been some construction and that more people will have moved here with either a permanent presence in our remote work center or even gotten started with something new, new employment opportunities.‚Äù

headline: Hell‚Äôs Angels Expelled from Iceland
body: Twenty-two members of the Hell‚Äôs Angels motorcycle gang were deported from Iceland on Saturday morning. The Hell‚Äôs Angels are one of several motorcycle gangs that are gaining ground in Iceland and the expelled members have suspected ties to organized crime. V√≠sir reported first. The individuals had apparently come to Iceland to attend a gathering in the capital area. Icelandic police have protocols in place to address the arrival of ‚Äúpeople connected to motorcycle clubs‚Äù and were ready and waiting when 15 members of the Hell‚Äôs Angels landed at the airport from Germany. These individuals were detained and questioned while authorities determined whether they would be allowed to enter the country. No arrests were made at the airport, although seven of their fellow club members were stopped and arrested by police on the road to/from the airport on the same day. Those individuals had flown to Iceland from Sweden. R√öV reports that the cases of five other Hell‚Äôs Angels members who arrived from Denmark are still under review, but it is assumed that they came to Iceland to attend the same gathering. This is not the first time this year that members of international motorcycle clubs have been expelled from Iceland upon arrival. In February, a high-ranking member of the Bandidos motorcycle club in Sweden was deported; three members of the Finnish Bandidos club were deported in October 2021. Bandidos MC is another motorcycle with international chapters that is believed to have established a foothold in Iceland.

headline: Herring Era Museum Floods: ‚ÄòThe exhibition area was basically floating‚Äô
body: The award-winning Herring Era Museum in Siglufj√∂r√∞ur in North Iceland flooded on Friday, R√öV reports. Staff were met by 40 cm [15.7 in] of water when they arrived, and two days of heavy rain have only exacerbated the situation. Wellsprings located in the embankment behind the museum tend to collect water underground, and these simply overflowed after days of heavy rainfall. The runoff had no good drainage channel, something that fire chief J√≥hann K. J√≥hannsson says will need to be addressed in the future. ‚Äú[The water] rose really quickly,‚Äù said curator An√≠ta Elefsen. ‚ÄúAround noon, it had reached 77 cm [30 in] and the exhibition area was basically floating, I think that‚Äôs the only word for it.‚Äù Artifacts and cultural relics at risk Located in a former salting station, boathouse, and herring factory in the centre of Siglufj√∂r√∞ur, the Herring Era Museum offers an extensive, immersive glimpse into a fascinating period of Icelandic history. The museum has received numerous awards for its innovative curation and live exhibitions. It is, in fact, the only museum in the country to have won the European Museum Award. Unfortunately, it‚Äôs the main exhibition space that has flooded, and although firefighters have been running numerous pumps since Friday, they were still draining water away eight hours later, on Saturday morning. ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre using every available pump in the municipality,‚Äù said An√≠ta. She says it‚Äôs difficult to determine the extent of the damage to the collection at this time but hopes that staff will be able to start doing so early next week. ‚ÄúObviously, this is a great deal of water and it‚Äôs the exhibition space we‚Äôre talking about. There are artifacts and cultural relics. It‚Äôs hard to say right now‚ÄîI think we‚Äôll just have to wait until everything dries and we can walk through here [‚Ä¶] without getting our feet wet to assess the situation.‚Äù

headline: Orthopedist: Surgical Waiting Lists for Children ‚ÄúUnacceptable‚Äù
body: An orthopedist at Landsp√≠talinn hospital has told the Minister of Health that surgical waiting lists for children are unacceptable. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt get them into surgery within an acceptable time frame,‚Äù Sigurveig P√©tursd√≥ttir told Willum √û√≥r √û√≥rsson during an annual meeting of the Icelandic Medical Association in October. Sigurveig P√©tursd√≥ttir, 64, has been employed as a doctor for 38 years. She‚Äôs spent 30 years working with disabled children as a paediatric orthopedist. At an annual meeting of the Icelandic Medical Association, held on October 14, Sigurveig told Minister of Health Willum √û√≥r √û√≥rsson that the state of the hospital ‚Äúhas never been worse.‚Äù Read More: Mass Resignations at the University Hospital ‚ÄúI‚Äôve got children who‚Äôve waited a year,‚Äù she called out from the assembly hall, according to a transcript of the meeting published by the Icelandic Medical Journal: ‚ÄúA disabled child who walks with one leg crooked for an entire year because there‚Äôs no space in the operating room. And why is there no space? Well, because the staff has quit. It‚Äôs not a matter of not having the staff. They quit. The hospital‚Äôs a mess. It‚Äôs a mess right now. It‚Äôs not going to become a mess tomorrow. It didn‚Äôt happen yesterday.‚Äù Sigurveig preempted familiar bureaucratic talking points with the statement that all talk of analysis and assessment was unacceptable: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve heard it a hundred times, but the situation has never been worse than now,‚Äù she stated. ‚ÄúIt means nothing to me, being told that I did so well during the pandemic, not having missed a day of work.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm on my knees,‚Äù she continued. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm giving up, and I‚Äôm not the kind of person who gives up when things get rough. But no one will be able to walk in my shoes. No one!‚Äù Those present at the annual meeting urged the government to heed the will of the public and to increase healthcare funding. They also announced their disappointment in next year‚Äôs budget bill, urged healthcare institutions to ensure the safety of their staff, and called for actions to be taken to deal with the failing health of doctors and the growing number of healthcare professionals who are resigning from their jobs. In late October, sixteen middle managers employed at the National University Hospital of Iceland received letters of termination. The terminations stemmed from the adoption of a new organisational chart intended to improve the hospital‚Äôs operations. ‚ÄúThe main purpose is to get a handle on the hospital‚Äôs management and operations, to strengthen our clinical services, and to harmonise other key services,‚Äù Run√≥lfur remarked in an interview with R√öV.

headline: Custody of Domestic Terror Suspects Extended by Two Weeks
body: The two individuals suspected of planning a domestic terror attack will be held in custody for another two weeks, V√≠sir reports. A defence attorney has called the decision ‚Äúincomprehensible‚Äù in light of a psychiatric assessment that held that the men were neither a danger to themselves nor others. Four Icelandic men were arrested on September 21 suspected of ‚Äúterrorist plots‚Äù against state institutions and civilians. Two of the suspects were immediately released; the other two have remained in custody. According to the police, the suspects had hoarded numerous weapons ‚Äì including dozens of semi-automatic guns and 3D-printed components ‚Äì alongside a considerable amount of ammunition. The men, both of whom are in their twenties, had discussed carrying out attacks against political figures, among them Minister Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r √û√≥r√∞arson and Chairman of Efling, S√≥lveig Anna J√≥nsd√≥ttir. As noted by V√≠sir yesterday, the two men were initially placed in custody on the basis of investigative interests, but the current extension, as confirmed by the Reykjav√≠k District Court, was predicated on public interest, with the men believed to be a danger to the public. In an interview with V√≠sir yesterday, Sveinn Andri Sveinsson, defence attorney for one of the men, stated that the decision was founded on a threat analysis carried out by the National Police Department. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve criticised the fact that the threat assessment, which actually predated the psychiatric assessment, did not take the psychiatric assessment into account.‚Äù According to Sveinn, the psychiatrist who carried out the assessment at the behest of the police did not believe the men to be a threat to themselves or others. The District Court, however, did not take this assessment into account. Sveinn Andri added that his client would be appealing the District Court‚Äôs decision, which was a big disappointment, to the Court of Appeal. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs always disappointing for individuals who are in custody without good reason to have to remain in custody. But we‚Äôll simply have to deal with it and try to have the decision overturned in the Court of Appeals. That would be ideal.‚Äù In late October, Sveinn Andri Sveinsson dismissed private messages between the suspects as a ‚Äúfailed attempt at humour,‚Äù adding that he did not believe that either of the men would be charged with planning a terrorist attack.

headline: Optimism for Icelandic Language in the Digital Age
body: The integration of the Icelandic language into digital services and devices has improved rapidly over the last few months, with large leaps in speech recognition. Nana Bule, a representative for Microsoft, stated to R√öV: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been fortunate enough to have really high quality data sets on the Icelandic language, which means that we‚Äôve in very short time improved language recognition for Icelandic by 32%. Which may sound small, but is actually a very big improvement that would normally have taken 5 to 10 years.‚Äù Earlier this May, an Icelandic delegation including President Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson and Minister of Culture and Trade Lilja D. Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir met with American tech companies to discuss the further integration of the Icelandic language into digital services and devices. Following the May meetings, representatives from Microsoft have been visiting Iceland this week to report on progress made. Now, the meetings seem to be bearing fruit, with surprisingly fast improvements for the integration of Icelandic into digital services. Mrs. Bule stated that Icelanders will soon be able to speak Icelandic to their devices without a problem. Bule also stated with regard to speech recognition: ‚ÄúWe can already do that today, but my hope is that in the future, we will be able to do it much more fluently. In the future, an interview could be you asking me questions in Icelandic, me answering in English, but listeners could hear it in Icelandic hopefully because we‚Äôll be able to translate it in real time.‚Äù President Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson said with regard to the innovations that it will be essential for the future of the Icelandic language to have a place in the digital sphere as well.

headline: Buster Takes Over from Tindur
body: A new drug dog, Buster, will begin his duties in the Westfjords police force. The dog he will be replacing, named Tindur, will be retiring next year. Steinar Gunnarsson, a police officer in the Westfjords, was responsible for training Buster and handing him over to his new supervisors. Pictured are Tindur and Buster with their supervisors, √û√≥r Gu√∞mundsson and Mar√≠n Elvarsd√≥ttir. According to the announcement, Tindur has served with Westfjords police for many years, but is now in his senior years. In the announcement on Facebook, Westfjords police stated: ‚ÄúWe expect a lot from Buster and believe that he will be just as good as Tindur.‚Äù

headline: In Post-Ice Age First, Iceland Records 30m-Tall Tree
body: An Icelandic tree planted in 1949 near Kirkjub√¶jarklaustur was recently measured at 30.15m, making it the tallest recorded tree in Iceland since the Ice Age. The tree in question, a sitka spruce, was given the honorary title of ‚Äútree of the year‚Äù by the Icelandic Forest Service, an award given since 1989 to trees outstanding in their fields. Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir was present for the ceremony, and even helped with the triangulation of its height. In a speech at the ceremony, Katr√≠n spoke to the importance of Icelandic reforestation and the role that forests must play in Iceland‚Äôs climate goals. She additionally spoke to her own personal history with the forest at Kirkjub√¶jarklaustur, where she has several significant memories and experiences. In addition to the PM, several other officials were present for the ceremony, such as J√≥natan Gar√∞arsson, chairman of the Icelandic Forestry Association. ¬† ¬† ¬†

headline: Geysir‚Äôs Protected Status Confirmed in Signing Ceremony
body: Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir and Minister of Environment, Energy, and Climate Gu√∞laugur √û√≥r √û√≥r√∞arsson took part in a ceremony yesterday at Geysir, in which they confirmed the area‚Äôs management and protection plan. The namesake of all other geysers, Geysir is a well-known tourist attraction in Iceland and part of the ‚ÄúGolden Circle,‚Äù a popular drive near the capital area. However, many natural sites have been overwhelmed by increased tourism, leading to several sites including Sk√≥gafoss and Geysir being designated ‚Äúat risk‚Äù in recent years. The Geysir area was originally protected by law in 2020, but this status is just now being recognized in a signing ceremony. In addition to being a popular tourism destination, Geysir is home to many unique geological features, plant life, and microorganisms, meaning that the area is also important for scientific research. In addition to conserving the Geysir area, the new management plan hopes to place increased emphasis on education on Geysir‚Äôs significance. At the ceremony, Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir stated: ‚ÄúThe conservation of the Geysir area is an important step in nature conservation in Iceland, given its unique natural beauty. The conservation plan confirmed today ensures that future generations will be able to enjoy the area as we do today.‚Äù Minister Gu√∞laugur added: ‚ÄúThis management and protection plan presents ways to ensure that the objectives of conservation are achieved. When developing infrastructure, consideration should be given to local planning [‚Ä¶] Development should guide visitors around the area and ensure that its conservation value is maintained.‚Äù √û√≥rd√≠s Bj√∂rt Sig√æ√≥rsd√≥ttir, manager of conservation and planning at the Environmental Agency, was also present for the ceremony. She stated that this was a necessary step in nature conservation in Iceland, and one that most Icelanders agree with. Indeed, she notes that many Icelanders were surprised to learn that Geysir was not already a protected area. ¬†

headline: Earthquakes Near Gr√≠msey: Uncertainty Phase Declared
body: The National Commissioner of Police and the Chief of Police in Northeast Iceland declared an Uncertainty Phase on Friday due to ongoing seismic activity around the island of Gr√≠msey. R√öV reports that an earthquake measuring 4.9 was detected around the island at 4 AM on Thursday morning; since then, there have been roughly 2,600 earthquakes. At 1:20 PM on Friday, there was another large quake of 4.1 and several over a magnitude of 3.0 occurred after that. Per the Department of Civil Protection and Emergency Management, an Uncertainty Phase is ‚Äúis characterized by an event which has already started and could lead to a threat to people, properties,¬†communities or the environment. At this stage the collaboration and coordination between the Civil Protection Authorities and stakeholders begins. Monitoring, assessment, research and evaluation of the situation is increased. The event is defined and a hazard assessment is conducted regularly.‚Äù People who live in known earthquake areas in Northeast Iceland are advised to take appropriate measures to prepare for ongoing seismic activity. These include securing household items, such as flatscreen TVs and breakable d√©cor, taking down paintings or photos that can fall on people while sleeping, moving beds away from windows, and familiarizing oneself with the Duck ‚Äì Cover ‚Äì Hold procedure. More information on natural disaster preparedness can be found on the Department of Civil Protection and Emergency Management‚Äôs website, in English, here. Seismic activity is common in Northeast Iceland, and according to a natural disaster expert at the Met Office, there is currently no indication of a pending volcanic eruption.

headline: Alert Phase Revoked, Three Weeks after Eruption Ceases
body: The National Police Commissioner, in consultation with the Su√∞urnes Police, has decided to revoke the Alert Phase that has been in effect due to the volcanic eruption in the Reykjanes peninsula. Three weeks have elapsed since any volcanic activity was detected in the area. On July 30, an Uncertainty Phase was declared on Reykjanes after a swarm of earthquakes rocked the peninsula. Four days later, on August 3, a volcanic eruption began, as magma began spewing out of several-hundred-metre-long fissures in a lava field near Fagradalsfjall, which had been created by last year‚Äôs eruption in the same location. An Emergency Phase was subsequently declared, which was lowered to an Alert Phase in light of the relative smallness of the eruption. The eruption passed through several phases before all activity ceased on Saturday, August 20. Yesterday, the National Police Commissioner, in consultation with the Su√∞urnes Police, decided to revoke the Alert and Uncertainty Phases that had been in effect in the area, R√öV reports. Authorities will continue to monitor the area closely, the Department of Civil Protection and Emergency Management has announced. ‚ÄúWe can expect intrusion activity and earthquakes in Reykjanes over the coming weeks. Residents are encouraged to secure furniture and other household items to prevent injury and/or damages to their homes,‚Äù a press release from the Department of Civil Protection and Emergency Management reads. The press release also states that rangers will be positioned at the eruption site to monitor foot traffic. The presence of police and rescue workers will be gradually diminished in the area, although they will be dispatched if needed. Lastly, the Department of Civil Protection and Emergency Management underscores the hazard of venturing onto the lava, noting that craters and hot lava are protected by nature-preservation laws. ¬† ¬†

headline: M4.9 Earthquake Shakes the North Overnight
body: The Meteorological Office of Iceland reports that North Iceland was struck by a series of earthquakes last night. The announcement, seen below in a public Facebook post, states that the largest recorded quake in the string was registered at 4:01AM, September 8, at a magnitude of 4.9. The quake was centered approximately 12km east-northeast of Gr√≠msey, and was reported to be felt throughout the North. Some 300 smaller aftershocks were also reported. The Meteorological Office reports that such quakes are common in this region of Iceland, and that no signs of significant unrest have been detected.

headline: Foreign Fisherman Electrocuted by Eystri-Rang√° River
body: South Iceland‚Äôs police report that yeterday, September 6, a foreign fisherman was electrocuted while fishing in the Eystri-Rang√° river. The fisherman was taken to Hvolsv√∂llur for medical care, and has since been transferred to Reykjav√≠k. The man, reported to be in his 60‚Äôs, survived the incident with severe burns, but further details regarding his condition are not known at this time. The original police report can be seen below in a public Facebook post from the South Iceland police. The cause of the incident is attributed to longer-than average fishing gear, which is said to have hit a power line. The fisherman is said to be experienced, but was using a style of telescoping pole that can reach 8-10m in length. This style of rod is uncommon in Iceland, but relatively popular in Spain. As of this time, the origin of the fisherman is unclear. Such incidents are nearly-unheard of in Iceland. Nevertheless. R√öV reports that the power lines in questions may be buried next year to avoid such an incident.

headline: Reservoirs Swell, Leading to Possible Overflow for Several Hydroelectric Dams
body: In a recent report by Iceland‚Äôs national energy company, Landsvirkjun, reservoirs throughout Iceland are said to be reaching full capacity. The public report can be seen below in¬† Facebook post from Landsvirkjun.¬† According to Landsvirkjun, Bl√∂nduvirkjun power station, located along the Blanda river in North Iceland, began to overflow this past Thursday, September 1.¬† H√°lsl√≥n, one of the reservoirs for the K√°rahnj√∫kar hydroelectric dam, also began to overflow September 5, causing the 100m man-made waterfall known as Hverfandi to appear. Hverfandi, known literally as ‚Äúvanishing‚Äù or ‚Äúdisappearing,‚Äù is called this because it only flows when the reservoirs spills over. According to Landsvirkjun, it has been a good summer for energy production, with nearly all reservoirs nearing capacity. H√°g√∂ngul√≥n, a reservoir in the central highlands, and Keldu√°rl√≥n, a part of the K√°rahnj√∫kar system, were both full already in July. √û√≥risvatn remains the only other major reservoir to not reach its peak capacity. √û√≥risvatn is currently rising by some 3-4cm per day, but it is unclear if it will reach its overflow point this year. Last year, its highpoint was reached at 576m, 3m shy of its 579m capacity.

headline: Summer‚Äôs ‚ÄúFinally Here,‚Äù Meteorologist Declares
body: Speaking to¬†Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞ yesterday, meteorologist Sigur√∞ur √û. Ragnarsson announced the late arrival of the Icelandic summer. According to Sigur√∞ur, good weather is expected in Iceland over the coming days, and may even last a few weeks. ‚ÄúSummer‚Äôs finally here,‚Äù Sigur√∞ur √û. Ragnarsson, known more familiarly as Storm Siggi, declared in an interview with Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞ yesterday; notwithstanding warm weather in North Iceland last week, this year‚Äôs summer has generally received tepid reviews. According to Sigur√∞ur, however, the weather is expected to greatly improve over the coming weeks ‚Äì with warmth and stillness being the operative words. ‚ÄúWe see very warm air gathering in the upper atmosphere, especially to the north of the country, near eastern Greenland,‚Äù Sigur√∞ur told Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞. ‚ÄúThis is warm air that you usually don‚Äôt see this time of year. There‚Äôs also this pressure ridge building over the country, straddling the Atlantic, which would, if everything works out, push any low-pressure systems to the south. These two factors create warm, calm, and dry weather for the entire country, which could remain well into the middle of September ‚Äì or even longer,‚Äù Sigur√∞ur remarked.
