According to the Michelin Guide, √ìX ‚Äúoffers the best Icelandic produce in highly personalised dishes, which blend traditional flavours with a modern edge.‚Äù In a statement to R√öV, R√∫nar Pierre called the award the best possible advertisement for the Icelandic culinary scene but stated that it would not change much for him and his team, who will continue to work as they did before. Some 11 other restaurants throughout Scandinavia were honoured with their first Michelin Star at the event, alongside two other restaurants with a two-star rating.¬† Dill was also awarded a Michelin Green Star, a commendation for their commitment to sustainable gastronomy.

headline: Intact Walls from an 11th Century Turf House Found in Sey√∞isfj√∂r√∞ur
body: The undamaged walls of a manmade structure dating back to the 11th century have been found in an archaeological dig in Sey√∞isfj√∂r√∞ur, East Iceland. R√öV reports that the walls are in such good condition because they were buried by a landslide that occurred around 1150. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve uncovered a number of structures or houses that seem to be under the landslide from 1150,‚Äù explained archaeologist Ragnhei√∞ur Traustad√≥ttir. ‚ÄúSo it‚Äôs just really exciting, what we‚Äôre starting to see here.‚Äù Uncovering the ruins is an ongoing process, Ragnhei√∞ur said, ‚Äúbut we‚Äôve got some exciting weeks ahead.‚Äù There are plans in the works to build landslide barriers in Sey√∞isfj√∂r√∞ur to protect the town, which has been subjected to a number of devastating mud- and landslides in recent years. So this summer, as during the previous two, archaeologists have been working to uncover and preserve whatever artefacts they may find in advance of this construction. A number of smaller artefacts were found last summer, some of which dated back to the earliest settlement of Iceland. The landslide from 1150 was discovered last autumn, and beneath it, four pagan graves. Ragnhei√∞ur says this discovery changed the course of the dig, prompting the archaeologists to investigate the area under the landslide more closely. ‚ÄúWhat is perhaps the most interesting is that the landslide doesn‚Äôt appear to have damaged these houses,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMaybe it had lost all momentum by the time it had made it down here, to the settlement, and so just piled up along the turf walls and hills and so now we‚Äôre digging out unusually intact turf walls.‚Äù Ragnhei√∞ur told Iceland Review that researchers are just beginning to uncover the structures at this time, but expect to eventually find even older artefacts, dating back to the time of settlement (9th century). The dig will continue until mid-August.

headline: Simple Stories for Icelandic Learners ‚Äì Sequel to √Årst√≠√∞ir Released
body: Author Kar√≠tas Hrundar P√°lsd√≥ttur has released her second book of short stories for Icelandic learners in Reykjav√≠k. Titled Dagatal ‚Äì s√∂gur √° einf√∂ldu m√°li (Calendar ‚Äì Stories in Easy Language), the book is intended to help adult Icelandic learners by exposing them to everyday situations in Iceland in a straightforward and engaging way. Dagatal is a follow-up of sorts to Kar√≠tas‚Äô first book √Årst√≠√∞ir (Seasons). In addition to being a helpful tool in the language learning process, Kar√≠tas says she hopes the book‚Äôs stories reflect the values of equality and diversity. ‚ÄúI felt there was a need for more books in simple language, based on my own language learning experiences and also as a teacher of Icelandic as a second language,‚Äù Kar√≠tas told Iceland Review. When I started teaching and met more people that were learning Icelandic, I began to see what sort of material was missing.‚Äù Dagatal is not a continuation of √Årst√≠√∞ir per se. While Kar√≠tas‚Äô first book provides stories at the A2-B1 language levels according to the European framework, the stories in Dagatal have a slightly broader range of difficulty: A2-B2. The level is determined based on factors including vocabulary, grammar, and content. Kar√≠tas says that while Icelandic language education in Iceland has made great strides in recent years, a lot more could be done. ‚ÄúI feel the development has been good, all things considered, but we‚Äôre behind compared to the Nordic countries in terms of teaching the national language to immigrants. Then, of course, it would be good to see more funding from the government and employers because immigrants don‚Äôt always have the time or money to learn Icelandic.‚Äù In addition to being a language-learning tool, Kar√≠tas worked to ensure that Dagatal reflects the values of diversity and equality. ‚ÄúIn the stories, I try to challenge the idea of ‚Äòwomen‚Äôs‚Äô and ‚Äòmen‚Äôs‚Äô jobs, for example. I depict all kinds of families and relationships, including same-sex partnerships and blended families with stepparents. One of the characters uses the gender-neutral pronoun h√°n (they). The aim was to show the breadth of society: what Iceland has achieved and where it is headed.‚Äù The publication received a grant from Jafnr√©ttisstj√≥√∞ur √çslands (The Icelandic Equality Fund).

headline: Statues, Shows, Sand, and Street Theatre: Reykjav√≠k Arts Festival Begins Today
body: An indoor, black sand beach, statues in Medieval suits of armour, drag shows, and street theatre are just a few examples of the many sights at this year‚Äôs Reykjav√≠k Arts Festival, which kicks off today. Between June 1 and 19, visitors and residents of Reykjav√≠k will be regaled with exhibitions, performances, concerts, and more, many of which are free. The festival has already made itself visible in the city centre: in front of the iconic Hallgr√≠mskirkja, a collection of six statues by Steinunn √û√≥rarinsd√≥ttir have been installed, three featuring reconstructions of Medieval armour from the Met collection. Musical highlights of the festival include performances by drag artist Taylor Mac and conductor and singer Barbara Hannigan, this Thursday to Saturday. On Saturday and Sunday, the Sun and Sea exhibition will take over Reykjav√≠k Art Museum, filling the museum‚Äôs courtyard with black sand from Iceland‚Äôs beaches. The exhibition was awarded the Golden Lion at the 2019 Venice Biennale. The Arts Festival‚Äôs opening party will take place at I√∞n√≥ this Friday evening, featuring stand-up comedy by Madame Tourette, live music from Latin American music group Los Bomboneros, and DJ Kraftgalli. All Reykjav√≠k Arts Festival events at I√∞n√≥ are free to attend. The full festival program is available on the festival website.

headline: Unpublished Poem by Dav√≠√∞ Stef√°nsson Discovered
body: A 19-verse poem by celebrated poet Dav√≠√∞ Stef√°nsson has been discovered. The piece could be among the very first poems that Dav√≠√∞ composed. Last weekend, Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞ reported that a previously unpublished poem by the popular Icelandic poet and novelist Dav√≠√∞ Stef√°nsson (who is best known for his volumes of poetry) had likely been discovered; the style of the poem and the handwriting offer a strong indication of its origin. ‚ÄúWe believe that Dav√≠√∞ composed the poem during his school years,‚Äù Haraldur √û√≥r Egilsson, curator of the Akureyri Museum, told Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞. ‚ÄúIt was probably written before Svartar fja√∞rir (Black Feathers) was published.‚Äù (Svartar Fja√∞rir, Black Feathers, was Dav√≠√∞ Stef√°nsson‚Äôs first book of poetry, published in 1919. As noted on the website of the Akureyri Museum, the book was ‚Äúaccorded immediate acclaim and established the young author‚Äôs reputation. His poems captured the feelings and longings of the general public in crisp, clear and picturesque writing.‚Äù) The recently discovered poem is entitled A Brief Story and is addressed to Dav√≠√∞‚Äôs childhood friend, Helga Gunnlaugsd√≥ttir of Ytri Reistar√°, to whom the poet was very close. Having allowed experts to inspect the poem, Haraldur believes that there is no doubt that it was composed by Dav√≠√∞. ‚ÄúIt smacks of a poem written by a novice, but there‚Äôs a wistfulness to it, the experts say, that evokes the spirit of Dav√≠√∞,‚Äù Haraldur noted. The poem was in the possession of Helga‚Äôs son, Stef√°n L√°rus √Årnason, for many years before Stef√°n‚Äôs daughters, five in all, gifted the poem to the Dav√≠√∞ Stef√°nsson Museum in Akureyri earlier this month. ‚ÄúThe poem isn‚Äôt perfect, and perhaps he wouldn‚Äôt have published it himself without having perfected it,‚Äù Haraldur continued in his interview with Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞. He then went on to encourage anyone in possession of a similar work to share it with the museum. ‚ÄúIf anyone is sitting on a poem, which they believe may have been written by Dav√≠√∞, then they can, of course, turn to us; Dav√≠√∞ was known to send poems to friends and acquaintances for comment, so who knows if the original versions of some of his poems, e.g. Black Feathers, remain in possession of some of their relatives.‚Äù ¬†

headline: Viking-Era Cave System Larger, Older Than Previously Thought
body: Ongoing excavations of Viking-era, man-made caves near Oddi in South Iceland have revealed an extensive system of interconnected structures that is not only much larger than originally thought, but also much older. Mbl.is reports that excavations, substantiated by tephra layers, show that the caves at Oddi were first dug out in the middle of the 10th century. ‚ÄúThere really are no words to describe it,‚Äù archeologist Kristborg √û√≥rsd√≥ttir said of the experience of standing in what is one of the best-preserved man-made structures of the Viking era. Kristborg is leading the current interdisciplinary study on the caves, which has been ongoing since 2020. ‚ÄúThe size of these structures is just so vast, there hasn‚Äôt been a study of such large structures, and definitely not from this time period in Iceland.‚Äù An important medieval cultural and political centre The first intact, man-made cave at Oddi was discovered in 2018, which was a remarkable discovery in and of itself. But further investigation of the site revealed a much larger cave connected to the first. It is this cave that is currently being excavated by Kristborg and her team. The historic site of a church, farm, and vicarage, Oddi was once one of Iceland‚Äôs most important cultural and political seats and home to a powerful clan known as the Oddverjar. The current study has been ongoing for two years, with the primary aim of shedding light on the writing culture that was there during the 11th and 12th centuries, when the Oddverjar were at the height of their powers. S√¶mundur fr√≥√∞i (S√¶mundur the Learned, 1056-1133) was the most famous member of the clan. He studied in France and wrote one of the earliest histories of the Norwegian kings, although that manuscript was lost. S√¶mundur‚Äôs grandson, J√≥n Loftsson, was a powerful chieftain who fostered Snorri Sturluson, the renowned historian, poet, and lawspeaker who is thought to have authored or partially authored major medieval works such as the Prose Edda (known as Snorri‚Äôs Edda in Icelandic), the most significant extant source on Norse mythology, as well as the Heimskringla, a saga of the Norwegian kings that was likely based on S√¶mundur fr√≥√∞i‚Äôs lost manuscript. A race against time  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve just partially opened up the large, collapsed cave that our little cave is connected to,‚Äù explained Kristborg. ‚ÄúWe still have deeper to dig; we‚Äôre just working on making conditions safe. It‚Äôs gotten very deep and the rock isn‚Äôt sound. So it‚Äôs taken some time.‚Äù Kristborg notes that the excavation is unique in terms of how demanding on-site conditions are. The caves are not only at a significant depth, which is dangerous for the archaeologists involved in digging them out, but also built into sandstone. ‚ÄúThe rock is so porous that it just crumbles before our eyes.‚Äù It‚Äôs thought that the caves were not used for very long because they are so prone to disintegration. Resources for the archeologists also remain limited. ‚ÄúWe only have limited funds and time and you never know what‚Äôs going to happen next year. Maybe we can continue, maybe not. And information is always lost from year to year, preservation gets worse.‚Äù A long and complex history, waiting to be uncovered Kristborg says that the cave currently being excavated may possibly be Nautahellir, Bull Cave, which is mentioned in Jarteinab√≥k √ûorl√°ks Biskups (Bishop √ûorl√°kur‚Äôs Legends of Saints), which dates back to 1210 ‚Äì 1250. The manuscript relates how Nautahellir collapsed with 12 bulls in it. One was then rescued from the rubble. ‚ÄúAlthough it‚Äôs older than that, it‚Äôs likely that [the cave] was used for livestock,‚Äù explained Kristborg. ‚ÄúWhether it was for that specific bull, we don‚Äôt know. But the history of its use obviously goes back further than we‚Äôve managed to trace yet.‚Äù The caves at Oddi have a complex and fascinating story to tell, says Kristborg, but the scope of the current investigation is such that she and her team need to keep their focus narrow. ‚ÄúThese are huge structures and an unbelievably large system of caves that we‚Äôre only just starting to come to grips with. [‚Ä¶] We‚Äôd need to undertake a much, much larger study with a much bigger crew in order to get to the bottom of this and trace this history in full, the history of these caves‚Äô use.‚Äù

headline: Microsoft, Google, and Amazon Welcomed Icelandic Delegation
body: A delegation of Icelanders, including President Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson and Minister of Culture and Trade Lilja Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir, met with representatives of tech giants Microsoft, Google, and Amazon in the US last week to discuss the incorporation of the Icelandic language into new technologies. In a television interview, Gu√∞ni stated that the meetings went well, with the corporations willing to increase collaboration with Icelandic language technology developers to ensure Icelandic could be used widely in the digital world. The Icelandic delegation met with Scott Guthrie, Executive Vice President of the Cloud and AI group in Microsoft. They expressed their thanks for Microsoft‚Äôs inclusion of the Icelandic language in their software, including Word, which is available in Icelandic. Guthrie revealed to the delegation that he is a big fan of Icelandic Nordic noir author Arnaldur Indri√∞ason and has read most of his books. President of Iceland Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson stated that in the future, speaking to devices will be our main way of interacting with them: ‚Äúand not just to ask our phone what time it is or what the capital of Costa Rica is, or something along those lines, rather this technology will be used in the healthcare sector, education, and so much more.‚Äù Read More: Improving the Icelandic Language on Devices The aim of the trip was to ensure that the technological developments that take place take the Icelandic language into account. The delegation was not on its knees, begging for that to happen, Gu√∞ni says, rather showed up armed with arguments and data about the importance of linguistic inclusion in the tech world. ‚ÄúWe went to these technology giants with that in our suitcase and said: we‚Äôre going to work together,‚Äù Gu√∞ni stated. ‚ÄúWe are going to invite you to cooperate and luckily we were well received everywhere.‚Äù Read more about the newest developments in Icelandic language technology.

headline: Millions Allocated in Local Publishing and International Translation Grants
body: The Icelandic Literature Center has announced its 2022 publishing grants as well as its biannual translation grants. Every year, the Icelandic Literature Center allocates publishing grants to local publishers to support the publication of new works in Icelandic. These grants are awarded with the intention of supporting works that have particular cultural and epistemological value. This year, the Center funded 54 works, for a total of ISK 28 million [$208,986; ‚Ç¨200,856] in funding. A total of 72 applications were received, requesting ISK 75 million [$559,743; ‚Ç¨537,806] in grant funding. The topics of this year‚Äôs grantees range significantly, from an 18th century murder case, architecture, the history of communism in Iceland, the kings of Iceland, contemporary LGBTQIA+ art and more. Growing Interest in Icelandic Literature Abroad The Icelandic Literature Center also allocates funding to foreign publishers to support the translation of Icelandic literature into other languages. Allocations for these grants are made twice a year, in February and September. In February, the Center allocated 54 grants for translations into 22 languages. Translated works included contemporary novels, poetry, children‚Äôs books, biographies, and medieval sagas. See Also: Impostor Poets Make Impressive International Debut ‚ÄúIt is notable that Icelandic books are now travelling abroad almost as soon as they are published in Iceland,‚Äù the announcement on the Center‚Äôs website reads. ‚ÄúFor example, Fr√≠√∞a √çsberg‚Äôs debut novel, Merking, which will¬†be published in English and German this year, and √öti by Ragnar J√≥nason will be out in English next fall.‚Äù The largest grants were given to The San Francisco Ballet, for their forthcoming publication of √ûorvaldur Kristinsson‚Äôs biography of Helgi T√≥masson, and for a German-language translation of J√≥n Kalman Stef√°nsson‚Äôs Fjarvera √æ√≠n er myrkur. The latter will also be published in Danish and Dutch soon. Fans of Icelandic crime fiction also have much to look forward to in the near future, with English translations forthcoming of authors Eva Bj√∂rg √Ügisd√≥ttir, Lilja Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir, S√≥lveig P√°lsd√≥ttir, and Ragnar J√≥nasson. See all of February‚Äôs translation grants here. ¬†

headline: Icelandic Film Quake Gets International Theatrical Release
body: Icelandic writer-director Tinna Hrafnsd√≥ttir‚Äôs film Quake will have a theatrical release in North America, Sweden, and the UK, Variety reports. The psychological drama is Tinna‚Äôs first feature-length film as a director; as an actor, she takes a supporting role in Quake, but has previously had starring roles in the popular TV series The Valhalla Murders and The Minister. ‚ÄúQuake‚Äù follows Saga (Anita Briem), a single mother in her late thirties, who has a grand mal seizure while walking in a public park with her six-year-old son. The event results in her total memory loss and afraid of being declared an unfit mother, Saga attempts to conceal her precarious state of mind while also dealing with suddenly surfacing memories of her childhood, which she‚Äôs long repressed. The film is an adaptation of the Icelandic Literary Prize-nominated novel Stj√≥ri skj√°lfi by Au√∞ur J√≥nsd√≥ttir, which was recently published by Dottir Press in the US under the title Quake (translated by Meg Matich). The film, which premiered in Iceland in March and was well-received at the Santa Barbara film festival the same month, sold to Juno Films in North America and the UK and Njuta Films in Sweden. Both companies are planning for a late 2022 release. Quake will also be presented at the upcoming Cannes March√© du Film.

headline: Members of Pussy Riot Currently in Iceland
body: Russian political activist and member of performance art group Pussy Riot Maria Alyokhina is currently in Iceland. Alyokhina fled Russia after the country‚Äôs authorities announced that her house arrest would be converted to a 21-day sentence in a penal colony. Alyokhina told the New York Times she hopes to return to Russia. Alyokhina is currently in Iceland along with other members of Pussy Riot, who are rehearsing for an upcoming European tour. Alyokhina herself first fled her home country for Belorussia, where her first two attempts to cross the border into Lithuania were unsuccessful. The Times reports that Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson played a part in securing a travel document from a European country for Alyokhina, which helped her successfully board a bus for Lithuania. Sveinn H. Gu√∞marsson, communications officer at Iceland‚Äôs Ministry of Foreign Affairs confirmed to R√öV that the band members are in Iceland as refugees, but declined to provide further information. The band plans to perform in Iceland this fall.

headline: S√≥ley and B√°ra Nominated for Nordic Council Music Prize
body: Icelandic musicians S√≥ley Stef√°nsd√≥ttir (above) and B√°ra G√≠slad√≥ttir (below) have been nominated for the 2022 Nordic Council Music Prize. This year‚Äôs nominees represent a wide range of genres from world music and opera to electronic music. S√≥ley has been nominated for her 2021 album Mother Melancholia. In their rationale, the jury describes the album as ‚Äúa work of the utmost originality, in reality one long meditation on the state of the world, gravitating between pretty and horrific.‚Äù In an interview with Iceland Review S√≥ley described Mother Melancholia as being about apocalypse. ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt really imagine what happens at the end of the world. It‚Äôs an abstract idea. Especially when you live here in Iceland and have your house and your computer and your day-to-day life. I‚Äôve been reading some dystopian Margret Atwood novels and thinking ‚Äòwow, maybe it‚Äôll be like this.‚Äô Maybe that‚Äôs the role of artists: to create, draw, paint, try to imagine it.‚Äù B√°ra G√≠slad√≥ttir is a double bassist and composer based in Copenhagen, Denmark. She was nominated for her piece V√çDDIR, written for nine flutes, percussion, double bass, and electric bass. The Nordic Council Music Prize jury called her compositions ‚Äúhighly creative and uncompromising,‚Äù calling V√çDDIR an ‚Äúenthralling‚Äù work where B√°ra ‚Äúshapes the sounds and structure of the music in an organic way with focus on textural and timbral progressions through various portals of possibilities of the instruments.‚Äù The winner of the Nordic Council Music Prize will be announced on November 1 in Helsinki, Finland.

headline: Iceland Qualifies for Eurovision Song Contest Grand Final
body: The Icelandic sisters Sigga, Beta, and El√≠n qualified for the Grand Final of the Eurovision Song Contest 2022 in the first leg of the semifinals in Torino yesterday. They were the 14th act out of 17 to take the stage and delivered a rousing performance of their song Me√∞ h√¶kkandi s√≥l. Ten countries‚Äô contributions from last night will go on to compete in the Grand Final next Saturday: Switzerland, Norway, Armenia, Greece, Iceland, Ukraine, Lithuania, Moldova, Portugal, and the Netherlands. Which ten songs will join them from the other semi-final events remains to be seen this Thursday. This is the third Eurovision Song Contest running that Iceland moves on from the semi-final, with memorable performances by bondage-themed anti-capitalist group¬†Hatari¬†and the irresistible six foot, nine inches tall pop sensation¬†Da√∞i Freyr with his band Gagnamagni√∞. The sisters, and their brother who is a part of Iceland‚Äôs delegation despite not joining his sisters onstage, were on the verge of tears when the news had been announced. In an interview with R√öV, they stated that they were lucky and grateful for all the support they had received. Beta jokingly stated that when the news was announced, she almost lost her voice from screaming. Let‚Äôs hope not as she‚Äôll need it on Saturday when the sisters will perform Me√∞ h√¶kkandi s√≥l in the 2022 Torino Eurovision Song Contest Grand Final. Icelanders will be glued to their tv screens next Saturday as following the Eurovision Grand Final, R√öV will broadcast the results of an election that‚Äôs almost as important, Iceland‚Äôs municipal elections.

headline: Iceland Performing in Eurovision Semi-final Tonight
body: Icelandic sisters Sigga, Beta, and El√≠n will perform in the first 2022 Eurovision Semi-final tonight. Iceland is performing 14th out of 17 acts this evening. Only 10 will qualify for the grand final on Saturday. Iceland‚Äôs competing song Me√∞ h√¶kkandi s√≥l (e. With the Rising Sun) is a folk-tinged anthem of hope composed by Lov√≠sa El√≠sabet Sigr√∫nard√≥ttir, known as Lay Low. Lov√≠sa has said the lyrics are influenced by 19th-century Icelandic poetry, including that of the poet Und√≠na (Helga Steinv√∂r Baldvinsd√≥ttir). An English translation of the lyrics is available on lyricstranslate.com. Tonight‚Äôs participants in order of performance are: Albania, Latvia, Lithuania, Switzerland, Slovenia, Ukraine, Bulgaria, Netherlands, Moldova, Portugal, Croatia, Denmark, Austria, Iceland, Greece, Norway, and Armenia. A second semi-final with 18 performances will take place on Thursday, followed by the grand final on Saturday night. Iceland‚Äôs representatives in 2021, Da√∞i & gagnamagni√∞, landed in fourth place in the competition, despite a COVID-19 infection that prevented the band from performing live. Iceland‚Äôs performance tonight is confirmed: the band and crew have tested negative for COVID-19.

headline: ‚ÄúWind Harp‚Äù Sculpture Unveiled at Harpa Concert Hall
body: Himingl√¶va is the name of a new stainless-steel sculpture by El√≠n Hansd√≥ttir that will be officially unveiled outside of Harpa Concert Hall tomorrow. It‚Äôs a work of art that is not only meant to be seen, but also heard. An ‚ÄúAeolian harp,‚Äù the sculpture is designed to produce sonic overtones as the wind travels through it. Its name comes from Norse mythology, and means ‚Äútransparent, shining, and small wave.‚Äù In Norse mythology, sailors who sensed the power of the wind and waves around them assumed that the mythical figure Himingl√¶va was embodying the water and propelling their vessels across the ocean. Alluding metaphorically to this legend, the harp is designed to attune the viewer to the natural forces around them. The shape is based on a Lissajous figure, representing the shape of light beams reflected through vibrating tuning forks. The sounds it produces change based on the force of the wind travelling through it. The sculpture has been a long time in the making: back in 2008, before Harpa was completed, a design competition was held for public art in the environs of the concert hall. Himingl√¶va was the winning entry. Funding priorities shifted following the banking collapse, but thanks to a monetary gift from the City of Reykjav√≠k and the state given to Harpa last year, the concert hall could finally fund the construction of El√≠n‚Äôs design. El√≠n‚Äôs work often involves visual distortions that heighten the viewer‚Äôs awareness of their own presence in relation to the artwork. Himingl√¶va plays with sonic distortions instead, exploring how a sculpture can filter the natural environment around it. Iceland‚Äôs Prime Minister Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir and Mayor of Reykjav√≠k Dagur B. Eggertsson will be present at the sculpture‚Äôs unveiling in front of Harpa at 4:00 PM tomorrow. El√≠n is currently completing a residency in Berlin, but will travel to Iceland for the unveiling of Himingl√¶va.

headline: EVE Fanfest Begins in Reykjav√≠k Tomorrow
body: Over 1,000 EVE Online players are on their way to Iceland for EVE Fanfest, which takes place tomorrow and Saturday, May 6-7, in Reykjav√≠k. The festival will include social events for players, presentations, and hangouts with the game‚Äôs developers. It‚Äôs been four years since the last fanfest was held. ‚ÄúThe city is starting to fill up with, well, some would call them nerds,‚Äù stated Eldar √Åst√æ√≥rsson somewhat cheekily in a R√öV interview earlier today. Eldar is the brand manager of CCP Games, the video game developer that created EVE Online, a massively multiplayer online role-playing game (MMORPG) renowned for its scale and complexity. The game currently boasts over 1 million players per month. Eldar says participants have come from all over the world. ‚Äú[Fanfest] is a festival, conference, and national assembly, because these are players in the EVE universe, which is huge, that come here to have fun and meet others, but also to talk about economic, historical, and political issues in the EVE universe.‚Äù EVE Online was first released in 2003, almost 20 years ago. ‚ÄúAt CCP, we‚Äôre really proud that this game has lived for so long, and we‚Äôre also very proud of EVE Fanfest and the concept around it. We were one of the first companies to invite our customers, the people who play the game, to this sort of party. So we‚Äôre very proud of this festival and it‚Äôs always really fun to do,‚Äù Eldar stated.

headline: Da√∞i Einarsson Wins BAFTA Award
body: Icelander Da√∞i Einarsson has won a BAFTA award for Special, Visual, and Graphic Effects in the Netflix show The Witcher. Da√∞i won the award alongside his colleagues Gavin Round, Aleksander Pejic, Oliver Cubbage, Stefano Pepin, and Jet Omoshebi. The Witcher also won in the category of Make-up and Hair Design at the annual awards last night, held by the British Academy of Film and Television Arts. Da√∞i is a visual effects supervisor known for his work on the films Everest (2015), Gravity (2013) and Adrift (2018). He was the executive visual effects supervisor for ten episodes of¬†Trapped¬†between 2015-2016. His credits also include two Harry Potter movies, where he worked as an animator and visual effects supervisor. Da√∞i is not the first Icelander to win a BAFTA award. Musicians √ìlafur Arnalds and Hildur Gu√∞nad√≥ttir have both won BAFTAs, for their composing in the TV series Broadchurch¬†and the film¬†Joker, respectively.

headline: Hlynur P√°lmason‚Äôs Godland to Compete in Un Certain Regard at Cannes
body: Director and screenwriter Hlynur P√°lmason‚Äôs latest film Godland will be shown at the Cannes Film Festival as part of the Un Certain Regard competition, ScreenDaily reports. This will not be Hlynur‚Äôs first time at the prestigious film festival; in 2019 his film A White, White Day screened during Critics‚Äô Week and earned actor Ingvar Sigur√∞sson the rising star award. Set in the 19th century, Godland tells the story of a young Danish priest (Elliott Crosset Hove) who ‚Äútravels to a remote part of Iceland to build a church and photograph its people. But the deeper he goes into the unforgiving landscape, the more he strays from his purpose, his mission and morality.‚Äù It is a co-production between Denmark‚Äôs Snowglobe film production company and Iceland‚Äôs Join Motion Picture. See Also: Icelandic Film ‚ÄúLamb‚Äù Double-Nominated in Cannes Cannes‚Äô Un Certain Regard competition, which was ‚Äúrefocused‚Äù last year on ‚Äúthe discovery of emerging filmmakers,‚Äù has been part of Cannes since 1978. In addition to the main prize, which includes a ‚Ç¨30,000 purse, this competition also awards the Ensemble Prize, Prize of Courage, Prize of Originality, and a Special Mention. Last year, the Icelandic film Lamb, directed by Valdimar J√≥hannsson, written by Sj√≥n, and starring Noomi Rapace, won the competition‚Äôs Prize of Originality. In this year‚Äôs competition, Godland will screen alongside 14 other films, many of them their directors‚Äô first feature. Hlynur P√°lmason was born and raised in Iceland and then moved to Denmark to study filmmaking at the Danish National Film School. His debut film, Winter Brothers (2017), won four awards in the main competition of the Locarno Film Festival and went on to win 30 awards. Godland is his third feature film.

headline: Rokk √≠ Reyjav√≠k Turns 40
body: It‚Äôs been forty years since Fri√∞rik √û√≥r Fri√∞riksson‚Äôs seminal documentary Rokk √ç Reykjav√≠k (Rock in Reykjav√≠k) was first broadcast, R√öV reports. The film celebrates the vibrant punk and new wave scene of Iceland‚Äôs capital in the early 80s (it was shot in 1981) and features live performances and interviews with 19 bands and artists, most famously a 16-year-old Bj√∂rk, performing in her first serious band, Tappi T√≠karrass, as well as Bubbi Morthens in his band Eg√≥, and the all-women quartet Gr√Ωlunar, headed by Ragga G√≠slad√≥ttir. As part of this weekend‚Äôs Easter programming, the R√°s 2 radio program Rokkland will be dedicated to Rokk √≠ Reykjav√≠k on Easter Sunday. The channel‚Äôs Monday programming on the Easter Monday holiday will include interviews discussing the film‚Äôs impact and importance. You can listen to the full soundtrack on YouTube here.

headline: Scott Free Options Rights to J√≥nasson‚Äôs Thriller ‚ÄúOutside‚Äù
body: The production company Scott Free has optioned the rights to writer Ragnar J√≥nason‚Äôs latest thriller Outside. Danish director Henrik Hansen is in talks to direct the feature film. The independent film and television production company Scott Free has optioned the rights to the thriller Outside from Icelandic author Ragnar J√≥nasson for feature adaptation. The book relates the story of four friends who seek refuge from a lethal Icelandic snowstorm in an abandoned hunting lodge ‚Äì but¬†‚Äúnothing can prepare them for what‚Äôs inside.‚Äù As reported by R√öV, publisher Bjartur and Ver√∂ld released a press statement yesterday saying that Scott Free would be collaborating with the Icelandic production company True North on the project. Talks are underway with Danish director Henrik Hansen. Outside was published last year and will be released in English translation in the UK and the US this spring. The widely-acclaimed thriller¬†will subsequently be made available in other languages. Ragnar J√≥nasson has sold more than three million copies of his books in thirty-six countries. English director Ridley Scott founded Scott Free with his late brother Tony Scott in 1970. Ridley Scott ranks among Hollywood‚Äôs most renowned directors, having directed films such as Alien, Blade Runner, Gladiator, and Thelma & Louise. Scott has received numerous awards.

headline: The Northman Premieres in London
body: The Northman, a film written by Icelandic author Sj√≥n and Robert Eggers, premiered in London yesterday. A ‚ÄúViking revenge movie,‚Äù the film also features a few Icelanders, including a brief appearance by Bj√∂rk. The premiere was well-received, with one critic calling the film ‚Äúspectacular‚Äù and ‚Äúvisually stunning.‚Äù A star-studded cast graces the action-filled epic, including Willem Dafoe, Nicole Kidman, and Alexander Skarsg√•rd as Prince Amleth, the central character. Icelanders Ingvar E. Sigur√∞sson and Haf√æ√≥r J√∫l√≠us Bj√∂rnsson also make an appearance in the film. The film follows the life of Prince Amleth, who goes on a quest to avenge his father‚Äôs murder. The killer is none other than the prince‚Äôs uncle, who also kidnaps the boy‚Äôs mother. The script is based on the same Scandinavian folk tale that inspired Shakespeare‚Äôs Hamlet. The Northman premieres in Iceland on April 14.

headline: Iceland‚Äôs Winning Press Photos of 2021
body: The Journalists‚Äô Association of Iceland announced the 2021 Press Photo of the Year winners last Saturday at the 2021 Press Photo exhibition opening at Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs Museum of Photography. The winning photo, seen above, was taken by Vilhj√°lmur Gunnarson, and features, perhaps unsurprisingly, the Geldingadalir eruption, which began in March and lasted until September of 2021. The jury described the photo as ‚ÄúAn interesting, strong and original picture of one of the biggest news stories in a challenging year.‚Äù Vilhj√°lmur also won in the category of News Photo of the Year, for the above photo, titled ‚ÄúWhere is Svand√≠s?‚Äù The shot features Iceland‚Äôs new cabinet following the September 2021 parliamentary elections setting up for a group photo, with Minister of Food and Agriculture Svand√≠s Svavarsd√≥ttir nowhere to be found. The jury praised its humorous take on a classic subject. Kristinn Magn√∫sson won in the category of Sports Photo of the Year, for this capture of a tender moment where Deane William‚Äôs girlfriend comforts him after his team has lost a game, while the winning team celebrates in the background. This colourful shot by H√∂r√∞ur Sveinsson, featuring musician John Grant, was the winner in the Magazine Photo of the Year category. The jury praised its powerful colours and unusual shapes, which the photographer and subject clearly put a lot of effort into. Like the winning Photo of the Year, the winner in the Environment category, taken by Sigtryggur Ari J√≥hannsson, also features the Geldingadalir eruption, though in a different light. The jury noted how the image appears black and white, but a closer look reveals subtle colours. The shot shows fresh lava about to flow over earthen dams, built to direct the flow of the eruption.¬† Photographer Hei√∞a Helgad√≥ttir snapped a winner when she captured Una Margr√©t J√≥nsd√≥ttir and H√≥lmsteinn Ei√∞ur H√≥lmsteinsson, married for 20 years, using a special form of communication that has helped them discuss difficult issues throughout their relationships: letting imaginary ‚Äúfinger people‚Äù discuss the topics on their behalf. P√°ll Stef√°nsson won the Portrait of the Year category for his shot of artist Shu Yi at the opening of her exhibition at Mutt Gallery last year. The jury praised the photo for its stylistic purity and calm but strong energy. Hei√∞a Helgad√≥ttir shot this year‚Äôs winning series, which features P√©tur Gu√∞mann Gu√∞mannsson, one of Iceland‚Äôs two professional forensic pathologists. All the autopsies P√©tur carries out have the goal of determining the individual‚Äôs cause of death. The jury praised Hei√∞a for her well-thought-out approach, and for portraying difficult subject matter in a way that was tasteful and professional, while still striking. The exhibition features 102 photos in total, and can be seen at the Reykjav√≠k Museum of Photography until May 29, 2022. Interested readers can also browse the Press Photos of 2020 and Press Photos of 2019, in which Iceland Review photographer Golli was awarded.

headline: Icelandic Singer D√≠sella L√°rusd√≥ttir Wins Grammy
body: Classical singer D√≠sella L√°rusd√≥ttir was awarded a Grammy last night in the Best Opera Recording category. D√≠sella snagged the award for a live recording of Philip Glass‚Äô opera Akhnaten. The opera was written in 1983 and is about the life and religious convictions of Egyptian pharaoh Akhenaten. D√≠sella (b. 1977) is a critically-acclaimed soprano, who has performed in New York‚Äôs Metropolitan Opera as well as in Italy. The New York Times has used the words ‚Äúbeauty, ease, and artistry‚Äù to describe her singing, as well as calling it ‚Äúreliably breathtaking.‚Äù Icelandic musician √ìlafur Arnalds was also nominated for two Grammies this year, in the categories of Best Arrangement, Instrument and Vocals, and Best Dance/Electronic Recording.

headline: Impostor Syndrome: Fake Artists Posing as Icelandic Musicians on Spotify
body: Minister of Culture Lilja Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir will meet with the CEO of Spotify this week to discuss the proliferation of ‚Äúfake artists‚Äù posing as Icelandic musicians on the music streaming platform, R√öV reports. She says Spotify has thus far ignored requests to remove the impostors, which is costing real Icelandic artists a substantial amount of potential revenue. During the meeting, Lilja intends to discuss the seriousness of this matter with the streaming service and fight for real Icelandic musicians to get the exposure and revenue they deserve. ‚ÄúThe whole landscape has changed so much with streaming services and this can be a positive thing in some ways, but there are negative sides, too, and this is clearly one of them,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI believe our musicians deserve more for their efforts and I intend to say so. I understand that people think Iceland is cool, but this [appreciation] can‚Äôt be [performed] in such a way that our musicians‚Äô earnings go down. That‚Äôs out of the question, in my mind.‚Äù The Swedish Connection The phenomenon of so-called ‚Äòfake artists‚Äô on Spotify has caused considerable consternation within the international music scene for years. Fake artists are the inventions of a small number of individual music producers and/or record companies that create untraceable pseudonyms with little-to-no digital footprint, and then mass-produce songs that are added to Spotify‚Äôs popular playlists. Playlists encourage song play and Spotify revenues are, of course, paid according to the number of plays an artist receives. Therefore, fake artists funnel streaming profits to a select few entities and deprive actual working musicians of their already scant streaming royalties. A recent report by Swedish paper Dagens Nyheter discovered that Firefly Entertainment, a Swedish record label whose management appears to have close personal ties with a former Spotify executive, boasts a roster of over 800 fake artists, nearly 500 of whom are found on key Spotify playlists. Per Music Business Worldwide: ‚ÄúDN also discovered‚Äìvia the register of Swedish publishing body STIM‚Äìthat music from over 500 of these ‚Äúfake artists‚Äù have been created by just 20 songwriters. The publication says it even found one composer who is the creator of songs for no less than 62 fake artists on Spotify; his music is currently attracting 7.7 million listeners on the service each month.‚Äù (Read Music Business Worldwide‚Äôs latest reporting on this developing story, in English, here.) R√öV reports that a number of Firefly Entertainment‚Äôs fake artists are reputedly Icelandic. These Icelandic impostors then appear on a number of Iceland-themed playlists and thereby cash in on the country‚Äôs cachet as a nature- and music-lover‚Äôs paradise. Ekfat the Fake ‚ÄúIcelandic Beatmaker‚Äù One particularly egregious example of Firefly‚Äôs undercover antics is a fake artist going by the moniker Ekfat, whose song ‚ÄúPolar Circle‚Äù has generated over 3.52 million listens. According to the artist bio on Spotify, Ekfat is the pseudonym of ‚Äúupcoming Icelandic beatmaker‚Äù Gu√∞mundur Gunnarsson, who has been ‚Äúpart of the legendary Smekkleysa Lo-Fi Rockers crew since 2017.‚Äù But in reality, no such musician exists and neither does his ‚Äúlegendary crew,‚Äù although Smekkleysa Lo-Fi Rockers is undoubtedly a play on the real (and actually iconic) Smekkleysa SM, or Bad Taste Records, which launched Bj√∂rk‚Äôs career, among others. And yet, until recently, Ekfat could apparently be found on the Spotify-created playlist ‚ÄúLo-Fi House.‚Äù (At time of writing, Spotify showed that Ekfat was supposed to be featured on this playlist, but no song by the artist appears on the playlist anymore.) Real Icelandic Music from Real Icelandic Artists Luckily for Icelandic music enthusiasts, there‚Äôs an easy way to find and support real Icelandic musicians on Spotify. Iceland Music, an organization that promotes and exports music from Iceland, has created a number of playlists on both Spotify and Apple Music, all of which are populated with verified songs and musicians from Iceland. These include a playlist of new music from Iceland, which is updated on a weekly basis, as well as playlists of ‚Äòatmospheric‚Äô songs, contemporary classical music, music by Icelandic women, Icelandic hip hop, metal, electronic, and more. (Icelandic artists who want to have their music added to these verified playlists can request so here.) More on Icelandic musicians and streaming platforms in our latest issue.

headline: Sirkus Reopens in Reykjav√≠k After 15-Year Hiatus
body: Sirkus, the much-beloved and much-missed fixture of Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs nightlife scene, reopened on Friday night after a 15-year hiatus, V√≠sir reports. After closing the doors of its original location on Klapparst√≠gur in Reykjav√≠k, the club briefly opened an outpost in Sey√∞isfj√∂r√∞ur, East Iceland, and also inspired a doppelg√§nger in the Faroe Islands. In addition to being a music venue, as in the old days, Sirkus‚Äô new incarnation on L√¶kjargata also serves North Indian food and has darts and a pool table in the basement. Find out about upcoming DJ sets and shows on Sirkus‚Äô Instagram page, here.

headline: Accolades Evenly Distributed at the Icelandic Music Awards
body:
The Icelandic Music Awards were held in Reykjav√≠k yesterday. In what was an evening defined by a relatively even distribution of statues, singers Br√≠et and Anna Gr√©ta Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir, the bands Mono Town and FLOTT, and rapper Birnir took home two awards last night. Yesterday, the annual Icelandic Music Awards were held at the Harpa Music and Conference Hall in downtown Reykjav√≠k. The event was emceed by singer Valger√∞ur Gu√∞nad√≥ttir and actor Gu√∞mundur Felixson. The bands BS√ç and FLOTT performed on stage, and so did pianist Magn√∫s J√≥hann, rapper Birnir, and the Iceland Symphony Orchestra. Awards were presented by Minister of Culture and Business Affairs Lilja Alfre√∞sd√≥ttir, with President Gu√∞ni Th. J√≥hannesson giving away the statue for ‚Äúbrightest hope.‚Äù No one artist took home more than two awards: Birnir, FLOTT, Br√≠et, Mono Town, and Anna Gr√©ta Sigur√∞ard√≥ttir took home a pair of statues each. I believe that whoever lives in music need never be lonely, out of work, or without friends,‚Äù Anna Gu√∞n√Ω stated in her acceptance speech. 2022 Icelandic Music Awards Winners

headline: Iceland Airwaves Festival to Return Following Three-Year Pause
body: Iceland Airwaves music festival has announced the first 14 artists that will play the event this coming November. The festival is finally scheduled to return following a three-year hiatus due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Airwaves‚Äô programming has been shortened to three days and fewer passes will be offered than in previous years. The 14 acts announced by the festival are a mix of Icelandic and international artists, In alphabetical order: Amyl & the Sniffers, Arlo Parks, √Årn√Ω Margr√©t, Axel Fl√≥vent, Crack Cloud, Daughters of Reykjav√≠k, Eyd√≠s Evensen, FLOTT, gugusar, HAM, L√ìN, Metronomy, superserious, and Z√ñE. Both up and coming Icelandic artists (√Årn√Ω Margr√©t, gugusar) and establish favourites (HAM) are represented in the group. The artists can all be heard on a curated Spotify playlist. The festival is scheduled to take place November 3-5, 2022 (Thursday to Saturday). While programming has been shortened by one day, its organisers hope that ‚Äúfriends and partners will take the opportunity to put on their own shows and events on Wednesday to get things going and warm up for a three-day party like no other.‚Äù

headline: Two Additional Film Studios to Rise in Reykjav√≠k
body: Reykjav√≠k Studios Purchases a 4,000 square metre building in the Gufunes district of Reykjav√≠k yesterday in which the company plans to build two state-of-the-art film studios, R√öV reports. Director Baltasar Korm√°kur says that when renovations are completed, it will be possible to film blockbusters like Harry Potter in Iceland. The project is expected to cost around ISK 1 billion, [$7.7 million; ‚Ç¨7 million], and Baltasar hopes it will be completed by the end of the year. Baltasar‚Äôs production company Reykjav√≠k Studios has made a name for itself with many successful television series and films, including Trapped and Katla. The company already has a studio next door to the purchased building, where this year‚Äôs S√∂ngvakeppnin competition was filmed. That studio is one of the largest in Europe, and too big for certain projects, according to Baltasar, which is why the new building will be split into two smaller film studios. ‚ÄúThere will be a sound-proof wall between them, and there will be two smaller studios that will be more useful for the Icelandic film industry than [our other studio].‚Äù The new studios could also house concerts and events, Baltasar says, but there is much work to be done before that will be possible. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm hoping I can put it to use this year,‚Äù Baltasar stated. ‚ÄúWe are ready to go all-in into construction.‚Äù The studio‚Äôs success depends on the government fulfilling its promises regarding reimbursement of film production costs. The current government policy provides a 25% reimbursement of all filming production costs incurred in Iceland, both for local and international production companies.

headline: Iceland‚Äôs First Lady Meets Jill Biden in Washington Today
body: Iceland‚Äôs First Lady Eliza Reid will be a guest at the White House in Washington today, where she will have a private meeting with First Lady of the United States Jill Biden. The occasion is a special event marking Equal Pay Day, a day meant to raise awareness of and help eradicate the gender pay gap. Eliza will also take part in the Taste of Iceland Festival in Washington later this week. Eliza is a fitting guest for Equal Pay Day, having recently published a book on gender equality and feminism in Iceland called Secrets of the Sprakkar, about ‚Äúa small island nation, the women who live there, and how they are changing the world,‚Äù according to the book‚Äôs subtitle. Eliza spoke to Iceland Review about feminism and the book in our latest issue.

headline: Icelandic Produce is Getting a New Logo
body: Islenskt, Iceland‚Äôs horticulturists‚Äô sales organisation, unveiled a new origin marker for Icelandic produce today, V√≠sir reports. Several markings have been used over the years to state the origin of various Icelandic products, but Islenskt will roll out the new label out across all packaging in the coming months. The goal of the initiative is to create consistency and certainty in a time when consumers are more discerning about the origin of their food. Milk, meat, eggs, seafood and flowers that are produced and packaged 100% in Iceland can bear the new logo. Blended products like yoghurt and cheese can be labelled as Icelandic origin if no more than 25% of their ingredients are imported.

headline: Sigga, Beta, and El√≠n To Represent Iceland at the 2022 Eurovision Song Contest
body: Sisters Sigr√≠√∞ur Ey√æ√≥rsd√≥ttir, El√≠sabet Ey√æ√≥rsd√≥tti, and El√≠n Ey√æ√≥rsd√≥ttir will represent Iceland at the Eurovision Song Contest in Torino in May, performing their song Me√∞ h√¶kkandi s√≥l. Their performance proved the most popular of the five finalists competing in the S√∂ngvakeppning Eurovision final in Iceland, broadcast live on R√öV. Ten songs were vying for the chance to become Iceland‚Äôs entry to the Eurovision song contest. Following a semi-final in two parts, five songs moved on to the finals ‚Äì √ûa√∞an af, performed by Katla, Lj√≥si√∞, performed by Stef√°n √ìli, Me√∞ h√¶kkandi s√≥l, performed by Sigga Beta and El√≠n, Turn This Around, performed by Daughters of Reykjav√≠k and Don‚Äôt You Know, performed by Amarosis. None of the performers had taken part in the competition before. The sisters‚Äô country-tinged Me√∞ h√¶kkandi s√≥l faced off against the Daughters of Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs energetic performance of Turn This Around in a superfinal and was declared the winner. They will represent Iceland at the Eurovision Song Contest in Torino in May.

headline: Damon Albarn Live in Reykjav√≠k Tonight ‚Äì Nice Way to Repay ‚Äúthe Generous Gift‚Äù of Citizenship
body: Musician Damon Albarn will be performing at the Harpa Music and Conference Hall in Reykjav√≠k tonight. In an interview published on R√öV this morning, Albarn observed that the concert ‚Äì his first in Iceland in 25 years ‚Äì was a nice way to pay back ‚Äúthe beautiful compliment‚Äù of having been granted Icelandic citizenship. Blur-frontman and Gorillaz founder Damon Albarn will be performing at the Harpa Music and Conference Hall tonight. The concert marks the last stop on the musician‚Äôs The Nearer the Fountain, More Pure the Stream Flows tour. It‚Äôs been over two decades since Albarn last performed in Iceland, or since stepping on stage with Blur in 1996. Speaking to radio host √ìlafur P√°ll Gunnarsson on R√°s 2 this morning, Albarn stated: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs my first gig in 25 years in Iceland. And on this trajectory, it could take another 25 years. I‚Äôll be in my late seventies then ‚Äì so you better come and see me now.‚Äù The musician subsequently admitted that the concert seemed long overdue, especially considering his new legal status in Iceland. ‚ÄúConsidering that I‚Äôm an Icelandic national, as well ‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs a chance for me to, sort of, you know, pay back that beautiful compliment and generous gift that I‚Äôve been given.‚Äù Albarn was granted citizenship last year. At tonight‚Äôs concert, Albarn will be performing the album The Nearer the Fountain, More Pure the Stream Flows in its entirety. As noted on Harpa‚Äôs website, Albarn has found musical inspiration in Iceland‚Äôs nature and landscapes since first coming to the country nearly three decades ago. ‚ÄúThis new piece ‚Äì inspired by Albarn‚Äôs long-time love for Iceland ‚Äì will see the musician perform this very personal piece with an ensemble in what will be his first concert in Iceland in 25 years. The Nearer the Fountain, More Pure the Stream Flows was written and composed entirely in Iceland. The title is taken from a John Clare poem entitled Love and Memory.‚Äù

headline: Titanic LEGO Master Builds Icelandair Replica, His ‚ÄòCoolest Model Yet‚Äô
body: Friends Brynjar Karl Birgisson and Mikael √û√≥r Arnarsson are building a 2m [6 ft] LEGO replica of an Icelandair Boeing MAX 9, a project that they‚Äôve been working on since summer 2021. R√öV reports that the pair is completing the model over the weekend at the Sm√°ralind shopping mall and will place the final brick on Sunday. This is not the first time Brynjar Karl, who has autism, has made headlines for a monumental LEGO project. In 2018, he completed an 8 m [26 ft] LEGO replica of the Titanic, using actual blueprints of the ill-fated ocean liner. It took Brynjar Karl, then 15, over 700 hours and 65,000 LEGOs to build. The replica is the largest LEGO model of the Titanic in the world and currently on display in the Titanic Museum in Pigeon Forge, TN. At the time Brynjar Karl credited the project with helping him ‚Äúout of my autistic fog,‚Äù saying, ‚ÄúI was totally unable to communicate when I started the project. Now I‚Äôm standing on stage and giving interviews.‚Äù Ever since, he‚Äôs used his Titanic-building experience and LEGO construction endeavors as a means of building awareness around autism; he gave a TED Talk in 2016 called ‚ÄúMy Autistic X Factor,‚Äù and a documentary, ‚ÄúHow the Titanic Became My Lifeboat,‚Äù was made about his experience. See Also: Icelandic Teen‚Äôs Giant Lego Titanic On Display in US While still very proud of his Titanic project, Brynjar Karl is even more excited about the Icelandair model. The pair have put a great deal of effort into making the model as precise and accurate as possible. ¬† ‚ÄúFrom my perspective, even though I made the Titanic, this here is the coolest [model] I‚Äôve made because of how it looks and also because I‚Äôm working with as brilliant a builder as my friend Mikael,‚Äù he said. Brynjar Karl and Mikael will complete the model at Sm√°ralind mall on Sunday. Check Brynjar Karl‚Äôs Facebook page for livestream videos and updates; or his website (in English) for more information about his autism advocacy work.

headline: Icelandic Artist Packs Up Exhibition in Russia
body: Contemporary Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson has put a stop to his exhibition Santa Barbara that was taking place in the newly-opened GEC-2 contemporary art museum in Moscow, Russia, R√öV reports. Kjartan says there was no question that packing up the exhibition was the right thing to do after Russia invaded Ukraine last Thursday. Ragnar is an internationally renowned artist, having exhibited at the Venice Biennale, the Tate Modern, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, among other places. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not possible to exhibit this piece when this horror has begun,‚Äù Ragnar stated. ‚ÄúThe piece is about the beginning of the Russia that came to be after the Soviet Union. And that Russia ended [last Thursday]. Now it‚Äôs just become a full-blown fascist state.‚Äù Ragnar‚Äôs piece Santa Barbara is named after the US soap opera that started being broadcast in Russia one week after the fall of the Soviet Union. The exhibition recreates the series one episode at a time under the direction of √Åsa Helga Hj√∂rleifsd√≥ttir. A team of crew and actors had recreated one episode from the show each day since the beginning of December, until the decision to stop was made last week. The exhibition was originally supposed to run for an additional two weeks.  Read More: Staging Reality Ragnar says Russian artists have told him of being censored or imprisoned due to their art. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just been an incredible experience to make art in this situation, where it‚Äôs almost like being in a thriller,‚Äù Ragnar stated. ‚ÄúYou meet all kinds of people that have been put in prison, experienced bomb threats, censorship and I don‚Äôt know what else.‚Äù A New York Times article from December describes Russian artist Maria V. Alyokhina‚Äôs criticism of the GEC-2 grand opening as ‚Äúhosting a feast during a plague,‚Äù a reference to a play by Alexander Pushkin. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really cool what they are doing, I really like it. It‚Äôs just, we have reality also, not only ‚ÄòSanta Barbara,‚Äô‚Äù Alyokhina said, implying the arts centre was ignoring Russia‚Äôs political reality. Ragnar is also quoted in the article as saying: ‚ÄúMany things can be criticized in this country, but we cannot look away from the fact that the Russian culture is completely awesome.‚Äù

headline: New Technology for Prawn Fishing Uses Light to Reduce Emissions
body: An Icelandic company has developed a technology for prawn fishing that uses light to herd prawn up from the sea floor. This allows the fishing equipment to remain off the sea floor, leading to less disturbance of the environment and lower emissions than conventional trawling. The technology is set to be put on the market soon. ‚ÄúWe are developing the next generation of fishing equipment. Fishing equipment that can fly close to the bottom without touching the bottom. Then we have a light that herds,‚Äù Halla J√≥nsd√≥ttir, founder of Optitog, told R√öV reporters. Optitog has named this patented light beam technology ‚ÄúVirtual Trawl‚Äù and has data that shows that it results in higher yields, compared to using the equipment with the light off. ‚ÄúWe have a special light that forms a sort of wall or line in the sea and we see that it works to herd [the prawn].‚Äù The prawn swims ahead of the light, up off the sea floor and into the nets. It‚Äôs possible to set the equipment so that it travels a consistent distance above the sea floor, for example 30 centimetres [11.8 inches]. Because Optitog‚Äôs equipment does not trawl along the sea floor, it encounters 30% less resistance than conventional trawling, meaning the method drastically reduces fuel consumption. By leaving the sea floor largely undisturbed, the new technology also reduces CO2 emissions caused by disturbing organic material on the bottom of the ocean. Halla says that a Norwegian party is working to put Optitog on the market as an environmentally-friendly fishing technology. Halla believes the technology could be applied to fishing other species.

headline: Iceland‚Äôs Interest Rates Pass Pre-Pandemic Heights
body: The Monetary Policy Committee of the Central Bank of Iceland has decided to raise the bank‚Äôs interest rates by 1%. The bank‚Äôs key interest rate is now 4.75%, higher than it has been since March 2019, when it stood at 4.5%. The hike continues a trend of rising rates, with the Central Bank citing inflation as a key factor. While the Central Bank reports that GDP growth was somewhat stronger in the first quarter of this year than assumed in their May forecast and domestic economic activity remains strong, it underlines that the global economic outlook is ‚Äúhighly uncertain.‚Äù Households‚Äô and businesses‚Äô expectations about economic developments have also grown ‚Äúmore tepid,‚Äù according to the MPC. Inflation rose to 7.6% in May, with house prices and other domestic cost items cited as ‚Äústrong drivers of inflation.‚Äù Price hikes are widespread and global oil and commodity prices have also risen sharply, the Central Bank notes. Inflation expectations have risen by most measures and are above target. See Also: Government Approves Measures to Counteract Inflation ‚ÄúThe MPC considers it likely that the monetary stance will have to be tightened even further so as to ensure that inflation eases back to target within an acceptable time frame,‚Äù the statement from the committee concludes. Iceland‚Äôs Central Bank lowered interest rates repeatedly throughout the COVID-19 pandemic with the stated aims of bolstering the economy and maintaining stability on the housing market. Rates reached a historic low of 0.75% in November 2020, but the Central Bank began raising rates steadily once more in early 2021.

headline: Business Booming for Online Alcohol Retailers, Even Though Online Sales Aren‚Äôt Legal
body: Al√æingi has yet to vote on whether private Icelandic retailers will be allowed to sell alcohol online, but R√öV reports that business is already booming for sellers willing to risk wading into this lucrative market before online sales are legalized. Starting July 1, craft breweries will be allowed to sell alcohol on their premises. Al√æingi voted in favour of this change on Wednesday. The bill to allow private retailers to sell alcohol online, however, was not voted on before the end of parliament‚Äôs session. But this hasn‚Äôt stopped El√≠as Bl√∂ndal Gu√∞j√≥nsson, co-owner of the online alcohol retailer Santewines SAS, from cashing in this holiday weekend. And not just this weekend, either: Like a small number of fellow sellers willing to take the risk before online sales are legalized, Santewines has been selling alcohol online for over a year and sales are increasing all the time. See Also: Local Distributor Flouts Prohibitions on Home Beer Delivery June 17th is Iceland‚Äôs National Day, so while people would normally be queuing in V√≠nb√∫√∞ locations around the country to stock up on bevvies for the weekend, such wasn‚Äôt possible on Friday, when all state-run liquor store locations were closed. So many of these would-be customers hopped over to El√≠as‚Äô website instead. El√≠as said he isn‚Äôt worried about his operation being shut down, even though online alcohol sales haven‚Äôt been legalized yet. ‚ÄúWe have all our ducks in a row and everything‚Äôs in order. We have a French company that is handling the online shop and legal products and we‚Äôre no more afraid than Amazon or EBay,‚Äù he remarked. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt actually think there are many people who have it out for the business,‚Äù El√≠as concluded. ‚ÄúMaybe √ÅTVR [the State Alcohol and Tobacco Company, which runs Iceland‚Äôs V√≠nb√∫√∞ stores], and maybe some Progressive Party MPs. [‚Ä¶] The police were actually out here the other day, but they were just picking up an order.‚Äù

headline: Less Cod, More Haddock To Be Fished Next Year
body: The Icelandic Marine and Freshwater Research Institute has suggested a 6% decrease in cod catch quotas for the next fishing season. A notice from the Institute states that the decline is due to a lower estimate of the reference biomass compared to previous years and the effect of the catch stabiliser in the harvest control rule. The Institute is hopeful for cod in Icelandic waters, stating: ‚ÄúThe reference biomass of cod is expected to increase slightly in the next two to three years when the 2019 and 2020 cohorts enter the reference biomass as they are estimated to be above average in terms of size.‚Äù Meanwhile, suggested catch quotas for haddock increase to 62,219 tonnes, up 23% from last year. MFRI Director √ûorsteinn Sigur√∞sson stated in an introductory meeting that several fish stocks, including tusk, ling, blue ling, beaked redfish, anglerfish, witch, megrim, and langoustine, have been experiencing poor recruitment in the past few years, Fiskifr√©ttir report. These fish stay in the warmer waters to the south and west coast of Iceland. ‚ÄúUnfortunately, there seems to be little change for the better. The reasons for this negative development are unknown, but the most likely explanation is that it‚Äôs due to changes in Iceland‚Äôs marine environment.‚Äù

headline: Craft Unions Call for More Spots in Vocational Schools
body: Around 2,000 craftspeople are needed in the labour market to fulfil promises on housing construction, R√öV reports. Approximately 700 students will be denied a place in Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs Technical College, Iceland‚Äôs largest vocational training institution. The Federation of Icelandic Industries and the Federation of Skilled Construction & Industrial Workers challenge authorities to take charge of the issue. Most municipality coalition agreements following the recent municipal elections emphasise the importance of increasing construction. 3500-4,000 apartments need to be constructed per year to keep up with the population increase. This year, that number will be less than 3,000. Chief Economist with the Federation of Icelandic Industries Ing√≥lfur Bender told R√öV that around 2,000 skilled craftsmen are needed to meet the building requirements. ‚ÄúAt the same time as there‚Äôs a shortage of skilled workers, we‚Äôre turning people away who want to start their vocational training. Last year around 700 were turned away, and it looks like that number will be even higher this year. This is very bad. The problem is not within the educational system because they have every intention to do better. What‚Äôs lacking is that the authorities divert funds to the system,‚Äù stated Ing√≥lfur. The Federation of Skilled Construction & Industrial Workers Chair Hilmar Har√∞arson agrees, stating: ‚Äúthis is a common problem of all craft unions that we need more seats in the training programmes. We need to build a new Technical College and maybe even another school yet in the Capital Area. Of course, we hope that Icelandic Craftsmen will construct all these new apartments. It‚Äôs hard to see that happening as the situation is now. It is becoming harder to get craftsmen from Poland and other countries, so we‚Äôre seeking staff in locations that we‚Äôre less familiar with. We‚Äôre producing half the craftspeople compared to other European countries.‚Äù Hilmar stated that elementary school students have priority when it comes to places in the schools. When asked if older students were less likely to get a seat in the vocational training programs, he replied: ‚ÄúYes, most of the 700 people who were turned away from the Technical College last year were older students.‚Äù

headline: New Designer Shopping and Dining Centre Hafnartorg Gallery to Open Downtown
body: Downtown is about to get another designer facelift. V√≠sir reports that 11 new shops and restaurants, all of which will be housed in the newly anointed Hafnartorg Gallery, are expected to open in the next five weeks. The gallery is located between Arnarh√≥ll and the Kolap√≥rti√∞ flea market and its opening signals the long-awaited conclusion to more than decade‚Äôs worth of development between the Harpa Concert Hall and L√¶kjartorg. See Also: Sizeable Hotel Rises Beside Harpa Downtown Reykjav√≠k has been under near-constant construction since ground was first broken on Harpa in 2007. (After the Icelandic economy collapsed in 2008, construction halted on Harpa‚Äîand in Iceland in general‚Äîuntil the government decided to step in and fund the building‚Äôs completion, making it the only active construction project in Iceland for several years following the crash.) In recent years, this harbourside district has added high-end apartment buildings, a luxury hotel, a pedestrian mall, and a variety of shops. And the end is finally in sight: after Hafnartorg Gallery opens, Landsbankinn‚Äôs new building is the area‚Äôs last major construction project. It‚Äôs set to be completed by the end of the year.¬† See Also: Iceland University of the Arts to Receive Permanent Home Finnur Bogi Hannesson, who works for the real estate firm Reginn and acts as Hafnartorg‚Äôs development manager, says the all-indoor gallery will be easily accessible in inclement weather from the 1,100-car underground garage, and will also have entrances on several surrounding streets. He says that most of the restaurants are on pace to open slightly ahead of the stores, but the goal is for everything to open by early July. The gallery will house the largest 66¬∞ North in Iceland, as well as the country‚Äôs first North Face location, the lifestyle store Casa, an 80-seat fine dining restaurant focused on contemporary Franco-Italian cooking, and seven smaller restaurants catering to a range of tastes. In the end, Hafartorg will be home to a total of 30 shops and restaurants.

headline: Iceland Tightens Regulations on Blood Mare Farms
body: Blood mare farming, the practice of extracting blood from pregnant mares for sale, will soon be subject to a licence in Iceland. This is one of several measures the Icelandic government is taking to tighten and clarify regulations on the controversial practice. The new regulations will be valid for three years, during which authorities will ‚Äúassess its future,‚Äù according to a government notice. Iceland‚Äôs blood mare farm industry made international headlines last winter after the Germany-based Animal Welfare Foundation posted a documentary on YouTube under the heading ‚ÄúIceland ‚Äì Land of the 5,000 Blood Mares.‚Äù The documentary contained footage showcasing ill treatment of horses on blood farms, including horses being shouted at and hit. Read More: Blood Farms Documentary Shocks the Nation Following the publication of the video, the Minister of Food, Agriculture, and Fisheries Svand√≠s Svavarsd√≥ttir appointed a working group to review the practice and whether it ensured the welfare of the animals involved. The working group‚Äôs report, published yesterday, concluded that existing regulations on the practice were ‚Äúvery vague and not acceptable, as they concern a fairly extensive and controversial activity.‚Äù In addition to implementing a licencing system for the practice, the group proposed tightening regulations on blood mare farming ‚Äúwith regard to the views of stakeholders and others with whom the working group spoke.‚Äù These include more detailed provisions on conditions and facilities at the farms, monitoring of horse health, grooming, and temperament assessment, as well as the working methods of blood collection and internal and external monitoring. The report‚Äôs authors proposed banning production systems based on mass production of mares‚Äô blood, as they could endanger the welfare of the animals. The working group consisted of representatives from the Ministry of Food, Agriculture, and Fisheries, the Food and Veterinary Authority (MAST), and the University of Iceland‚Äôs Centre for Ethics. The Animal Welfare Foundation and many other interest groups were consulted in the writing of the report. Since the 1980s, horse farmers in Iceland have been able to gain extra income by extracting the hormone Equine Chorionic Gonadotropin (eCG) from their pregnant mares. This hormone exists in pregnant mares‚Äô blood and can be removed and sold for hefty sums. To begin with, blood farming was a secondary practice on horse farms, but later, some farmers turned their focus to the practice, with data from 2019 indicating that 95 farmers supplied pregnant mare‚Äôs blood. Just one company, √çsteka, buys and processes blood harvested from mares in Iceland. The hormone extracted from pregnant mares is mainly used to boost fertility in other farm animals. Only a handful of countries operate blood farms besides Iceland: Russia, Mongolia, China, Uruguay, and Argentina.

headline: PLAY Reports ISK 1.5 Billion Loss in Q1, Maintains ‚ÄòStrong Balance Sheet and Healthy Cash Position‚Äô
body: Iceland‚Äôs newest discount airline, PLAY, reported a loss of ISK 1.5 billion [$11.5 million; ‚Ç¨10.78 million] in the first quarter of 2022. Per the Interim Report (January ‚Äì March 2022) issued by the company this week, this comes as no real surprise, and can largely be credited to global factors, namely, ‚Äú[t]he Omicron variant impacted revenue during the quarter, and the war in Ukraine resulted in higher fuel price towards the end of the quarter.‚Äù The negative EBIT (Earnings Before Interest and Taxes) was ‚Äúexpected,‚Äù writes CEO Birgir J√≥nsson, who remains optimistic about the airline‚Äôs prospects. Travellers are showing an increasing willingness to fly, and the airline‚Äôs ‚Äúfinancial position‚Ä¶continues to be strong, with a strong balance sheet and healthy cash position.‚Äù PLAY‚Äôs equity ratio stands at 22% ($56.5 million; ‚Ç¨52.7 million; ISK 7.3 billion) and it is maintaining a cash position of ISK 5.4 billion [$43 million; ‚Ç¨39.2]. Currency risk is a factor in the airline‚Äôs operations, ‚Äú‚Ä¶since a large part of its cash position is in the ISK, while PLAY‚Äôs operating currency is in USD. PLAY is therefore exposed to the fluctuation of the two currencies against each other.‚Äù Rapid network expansion  Between January and March 2022, PLAY carried 57,500 passengers, with a 20% jump in passenger numbers from February to March. The airline hired 45 pilots and over 100 new cabin crew members in Q1. PLAY is steadily expanding its network and plans to continue to do so in Q2. Service to Baltimore/Washington, D.C. began in April; service to Prague, Boston, Lisbon, Gothenburg, and Brussels began in May, with destinations Stavanger, Malaga, and Trondheim on the horizon before the end of the month. In early June, service to Palma de Mallorca and Bologna will commence, as will daily flights to New York in the US. Indeed, PLAY will be the first airline to operate international flights from New York Stewart International Airport (located about 75 mi; 120 km outside of New York City) post-pandemic. ‚ÄòStrong booking momentum‚Äô As part of its strategy to counter rising fuel prices that have resulted from the war in Ukraine, however, PLAY is adjusting its summer fleet plan and will not be offering three weekly flights to and from Orlando, Florida this fall as planned. Additional measures to counter rising fuel prices include a fuel hedging strategy, a fuel surcharge, and ongoing schedule adjustments ‚Äúto eliminate unprofitable flying.‚Äù Passenger hesitation in the wake of the Omicron variant and global unrest appears to be waning, and bookings are on the upswing. ‚ÄúIn February, [there were] 59% more sold seats compared to January, despite the war in Ukraine. This improvement in booking inflow has continued into the second quarter of 2022, with more than fourfold increase in sold seats in April compared to January. Because of this strong booking momentum,‚Äù concludes the report, ‚ÄúPLAY expects to report improved utilization in the coming months.‚Äù

headline: Value of Exported Goods Increases Significantly
body: The value of exported industrial, marine and agricultural products has increased significantly over the past three years, R√öV reports (referencing compiled statistics published in Fr√©ttabla√∞i√∞). During the first four months of 2022, goods have been exported for almost ISK 319 billion ($2.3 billion / ‚Ç¨2.3 billion), compared to ISK 197 billion (($1.5 billion / ‚Ç¨1.4 billion) during the same period in 2020. The value of exported marine products amounted to ISK 118 billion ($874 million / ‚Ç¨842 million) during the first four months of this year, compared to ISK 81 billion ($600 million / ‚Ç¨578 million) in 2020. The value of exported agricultural goods, including farmed fish, totalled ISK 20 billion ($148 million / ‚Ç¨143 million) during the first four months of 2022, compared to ISK 11 billion ($81 million / ‚Ç¨79 million) in 2020. Finally, the value of exported industrial products is up by 75% ‚Äì from ISK 99 billion ($733 million / ‚Ç¨707 million) to ISK 175 billion ($1.3 billion / ‚Ç¨1.2 billion) ‚Äì during the first four months of this year as compared to 2020. A significant factor in that regard is that exported aluminium‚Äôs value has doubled compared to two years ago.

headline: Central Bank Raises Interest Rates by 1%
body: The Central Bank of Iceland‚Äôs key interest rate will be raised to 3.75%, rising ever-closer to pre-pandemic figures. The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) announced a 1% interest rate hike this morning. The MPC says the economic outlook has deteriorated due to the impact of Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine. In March 2019, the Central Bank‚Äôs key interest rate stood at 4.5%. It was lowered repeatedly throughout the pandemic in efforts to bolster the economy and maintain stability on the housing market. Interest rates reached a¬†historic low¬†of 0.75% in November 2020, but the Central Bank has been steadily raising rates once more over the past year. Despite the worse outlook as compared to February‚Äôs forecast, the MPC says there are ‚Äúsigns of strong domestic economic activity‚Äù in Iceland, including a tightening labour market. GDP growth is forecast at 4.6% for the year 2022, and a growth rate of just under 3% in 2023 and 2024. Combating inflation continues to be a challenge, according to the MPC, which cites ‚Äúhouse prices and other domestic cost items‚Äù as strong drivers of inflation, as well as global oil and commodity prices. Underlying inflation currently measures 5%, with inflation in the month of April measuring 7.2%. The Central Bank predicts that inflation will rise above 8% in the third quarter of this year. The MPC expects interest rate hikes and ‚Äútighter borrower-based measures‚Äù to slow down house price inflation and domestic demand. The Committee states, however, that it is likely the monetary stance will have to be tightened even further in coming months to ease inflation. ‚ÄúDecisions taken at the corporate level, the labour market, and in public sector finances will be a major determinant of how high interest rates must rise,‚Äù the notice concludes.

headline: Inflation Rate Continues to Climb, Peak Expected in June
body: The annual inflation rate hit 7.2% yesterday, a 12-year high. Analysts at √çslandsbanki bank predict that the inflation rate will peak in June at 7.7%. Statistics Iceland updated its consumer price index (a proxy for inflation) yesterday. The latest figures indicate that the annual inflation rate has hit a 12-year high, or 7.2%, with the CPI having risen every month since last August. As noted by R√öV, the consumer price index increased by 1.25% last month: the largest one-month increase since February of 2013. The biggest driver for this increase is a 2.4% rise in the price of housing and utilities, the single most significant category in the calculation of the CPI (29.3% of total weight), accounting for a rise of 0.45%. ‚ÄúHousing and utilities are by far the most important driver of inflation in Iceland, first and foremost rent (cost of housing),‚Äù Erna Bj√∂rg Sverrisd√≥ttir, Chief Economist at Arion Bank, stated in an interview with Mbl.is yesterday. ‚ÄúOf course, the war in Ukraine is beginning to affect inflation,‚Äù she continued. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve seen gas prices rise and the price of imported goods, as well. This trend, the gradual increase in inflation among our main trading partners, had begun before the war, but the war has exacerbated these effects,‚Äù (As noted by Kjarninn, the CPI would be approximately 3% lower if housing and utilities had remained unchanged over the past 12 months.) Another increase that affected the CPI was a rise in the cost of food and non-alcoholic beverages, which increased by 1.4% between months. (Food and non-alcoholic beverages account for 14.7% of the CPI‚Äôs total weight). The rise in the cost of dairy products also contributed to inflation, raising the consumer price index by 0.2%. Airfares likewise increased by 22.9%, causing a 0.37% rise in the index. The current inflation rate exceeds predictions made by the Central Bank: In early February, the Central Bank forecast an annual inflation rate of 5.8% during the first quarter of 2022 and 5.6% during the second quarter.
