Since then it has been detected in many other salmon farming nations, including Canada (1996), Scotland (1998), the Faroe Islands (2000), the USA (2001), Chile (2001), and Ireland (2002). ‚ÄúThe diagnosis of the virus emphasises the importance of monitoring and infection control in order to maintain good disease status in Iceland and prevent diseases such as ISA emerge and get a foothold in salmon farms,‚Äù the MAST statement concludes.

headline: MAST Reviewing Footage of Mistreated Mares in Youtube Doc
body: The Icelandic Food and Veterinary Authority is currently reviewing footage from a Youtube documentary that features clips of Icelandic mares being mistreated during blood-collection procedures. The conditions and conduct caught on camera are ‚Äúutterly unacceptable,‚Äù says the Chairman of the Horse Breeders Association of Iceland. On November 19, Tierschutzbund Z√ºrich (TSB, Switzerland) and the Animal Welfare Foundation (AWF, Germany) posted¬†a documentary to Youtube¬†under the heading ‚ÄúIceland ‚Äì Land of the 5,000 Blood Mares.‚Äù The documentary reports on the activities within so-called ‚Äúblood farms‚Äù in Iceland, where blood is drawn from mares in early pregnancy to extract¬†ECG¬†(previously known as pregnant mare‚Äôs serum gonadotropin or PMSG): a hormone commonly used in concert with progestogens to induce ovulation in livestock prior to artificial insemination. The documentary features footage from hidden cameras showing workers beating and shouting at horses. The filmmakers claim to have discovered ‚Äúwidespread animal-welfare violations‚Äù in Iceland, which run counter to claims made by pharmaceutical companies on the nature of blood-collection procedures in the country. As noted by MAST, the extraction of ECG from pregnant mares is a growing industry in Iceland; blood from almost 5,400 mares, on 119 farms, has been drawn in 2021. Following coverage of the documentary in the media, various parties connected to blood-collection farms in Iceland have commented publicly. In a press release on Sunday,¬†√çsteka¬†‚Äì which manufactures pharmaceuticals from the blood of mares ‚Äì denounced the treatment of the animals in the documentary: ‚Äú√çsteka disapproves strongly of sourcing practices that do not comply with the high animal welfare standards we work by and that we recommend to our customers and colleagues. We have immediately started an internal supplier review to investigate the allegations and cannot comment any further on this at this time.‚Äù In¬†an interview with V√≠sir, farmer S√¶unn √û√≥rarinsd√≥ttir criticized the footage recorded on her property on the grounds that it lacked context. ‚ÄúNone of my operations have anything to do with what is seen in that video,‚Äù she stated.¬† S√¶unn further alleged that the documentarians misrepresented reality on several occasions. (Early on in the video, for example, the documentarians say that they‚Äôre being followed by a veterinarian driving a grey jeep. ‚ÄúThe veterinarian in question was simply on his way home,‚Äù S√¶unn told V√≠sir.) ‚ÄúThe footage is horrible to watch and not at all an accurate depiction of our operations. We have a complete ban on violence; I would personally beat anyone who laid a finger on my horses,‚Äù S√¶unn remarked. In¬†a public statement released yesterday, the Icelandic Food and Veterinary Authority (MAST) announced that it was reviewing the footage seen in the documentary. ‚ÄúThe procedures caught on film appear to violate operational conditions, which stipulate the horses‚Äô welfare be ensured.‚Äù In the statement, MAST stressed that the supervision of blood-collection procedures is a priority. ‚ÄúSince the regulation on the welfare of horses came into effect in 2014, MAST has established clear conditions for blood-extraction procedures performed on pregnant mares, and we have gradually ramped up supervision.‚Äù According to the statement, MAST inspectors pay annual visits to a fifth of blood-collecting farms in Iceland during the time that procedures are being performed. ‚ÄúIf, during inspections, serious deviations from protocol are noted, operations are stopped; the operations of five facilities has been halted since 2014.‚Äù In¬†an interview with the radio station R√°s 2 this morning, Sveinn Steinarsson, Chairman of¬†the Horse Breeders Association of Iceland, stated that it was clear that the horses in the video had been mistreated: blood-collection is a sensitive procedure that demands great care. ‚ÄúThe extraction of blood from pregnant mares has been practiced for almost 40 years and the fact that the operating conditions are, after all this time ‚Äì and given especially how extensive these operations have become ‚Äì so unsatisfactory is utterly unacceptable,‚Äù Sveinn remarked in the interview. While he condemned the mistreatment of mares in the documentary, Sveinn warned against generalization: ‚ÄúI expect that conditions are acceptable in most places, but, as it stands, our discussion is beginning with the lowest-common denominator.‚Äù Sveinn concluded by stating that those who were charged with the supervision of blood-collection procedures in Iceland had many questions to answer. ‚ÄúAs far as what is depicted in the documentary, I expect no stone to be left unturned.‚Äù This article was updated at 15:17.

headline: Sara Bj√∂rk Wins European Championship
body: Icelandic football player Sara Bj√∂rk Gunnarsd√≥ttir has won the 2020 UEFA Champions League alongside her team Olympique Lyonnais. In the finals last Saturday, Sara became the first Icelander to score a goal in a European championship match. Lyon snatched the title with a 3-1 victory against Sara‚Äôs former club Wolfsburg. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just coming back down to Earth and realising that I‚Äôve become a European champion,‚Äù the midfielder said in an interview with V√≠sir yesterday. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a dream and a goal for a really long time. It‚Äôs unbelievably sweet to have the title in your hands.‚Äù Lyon, which has often been called the strongest women‚Äôs team in the world, acquired Sara just this year. The club is defending champion of Division 1 F√©minine, having won the league for 14 consecutive seasons, a world record in any sport. This is its seventh Champions League title. Sara thanked her well-wishers in an Instagram post this morning, saying she was ‚Äúproud to be an Icelander.‚Äù She dedicated her title to the girls and boys who dream of making a career in football. ‚ÄúThere are no limits.‚Äù   VaÃÅ takk fyrir allar fallegu kve√∞junar!‚ù§Ô∏èLitla IÃÅsland segja √æeirü§∑üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è √ûessi er titill er me√∞al annars tileinka√∞ur til allra foÃÅtboltastelpna og straÃÅka sem eiga seÃÅr √æann draum um a√∞ komast eins langt og √æeim dreymir um! √ûa√∞ eru engin takmoÃàrk! ‚ù§Ô∏èüí™üèºüî• Stolt a√∞ vera IÃÅslendingur üáÆüá∏ A post shared by  Sara BjoÃàrk GunnarsdoÃÅttir (@sarabjork90) on Sep 1, 2020 at 3:11am PDT

headline: ‚ÄòWorking Quarantine‚Äô for Icelandic Football Teams
body: Icelandic club football teams that travel to Europe to play in international matches may undergo a ‚Äòworking quarantine,‚Äô V√≠sir reports. This means they are allowed to practice together during the mandatory five-day quarantine between COVID-19 tests. This was confirmed on Thursday by V√≠√∞ir Reynisson, Chief Superintendent of Civil Protection in Iceland. Football teams must apply in advance to do a working quarantine after their return from matches abroad, so it is unclear if the KR football team will be allowed to practice together over the coming days. KR returned to Iceland on Tuesday night after playing a match against Celtic in Glasgow, Scotland. The team Brei√∞ablik has applied for permission to do a working quarantine after returning from a match in Noway next week, and V√≠kingur R. intends to do the same in advance of their trip to Slovenia. The fact that teams are allowed to train together while in working quarantine doesn‚Äôt change anything where match play against other local teams is concerned. There will still be no league matches during the five-day quarantine period. The working quarantine regulations may also allow for FC Valur to host a qualifying match for to European Championships, scheduled to take place in October. Valur has applied for permission to do so. FH will be playing a match against a Slovakian team in Hafnafj√∂r√∞ur next week; according to V√≠√∞ir, the Slovakian team will be allowed to arrive in Iceland the day before their match. Similarly, national teams‚Äîsuch as Iceland‚Äôs men‚Äôs national team and that of England, who will play against one another at Laugardalsv√∂llur on September 5, will be allowed to enter the country right before match day and will not be subject to the five-day quarantine and double COVID test regulations. ‚ÄúThere are different regulations for this,‚Äù V√≠√∞ir explained. ‚ÄúThey are entering this ‚Äòbubble,‚Äô you could call it, which is created around these UEFA matches. Such that teams enter it while abroad‚Äîundergo screening abroad before they arrive in Iceland and are basically in quarantine before they get here. So they are tested here at the border and are allowed to train and play matches within the five-day timeframe if necessary.‚Äù

headline: Spectators Allowed at Sporting Events Starting Friday
body: As of Friday, contact sports will be allowed to resume in Iceland and spectators will be allowed to attend matches and sporting events, V√≠sir reports. See Also: Most Current Gathering and Distancing Regulations Extended Even though spectators will be allowed, the National Olympic and Sports Association of Iceland (√çS√ç) was tasked with setting more specific safety regulations for its associations and teams. In order to observe the current gathering limits, for instance, spectators will be divided into sections of no more than 100 people. People within these sections will be required to maintain a two-metre distance from one another and no moving between sections will be allowed. Each section will have its own designated restroom facilities and its own concessions area, if food is to be sold at the event. Children born in 2005 or later are exempt from gathering limits and distancing regulations.

headline: Inga Birna √Års√¶lsd√≥ttir First Icelandic Woman to Earn Black Belt in Jiu-Jitsu
body: Inga Birna √Års√¶lsd√≥ttir has become the first Icelandic woman to earn a black belt in Brazilian jiu-jitsu, MMA Fr√©ttir reports. Inga has been recognised as one of the best female fighters in the country in recent years. Two other jiujiteiros, Bjarki √û√≥r P√°lsson and Magn√∫s Ingi Ingvarsson, also received black belts at the ceremony, which was presided over by Gunnar Nelson, Iceland‚Äôs most famous MMA fighter, at RVK MMA gym earlier this week. Two purple and three blue belts were also granted. Only 20 Icelanders have earned black belts in Brazilian jiu-jitsu.

headline: Iceland Reveals New National Football Crest in Dramatic Video
body: The Football Association of Iceland has revealed the new national team crest in a video directed by National Men‚Äôs Team goalkeeper Hannes Halld√≥rsson. Designed by advertising agency Brandenburg, the crest is a composite of four v√¶ttir, or supernatural beings ‚Äì a bull, eagle, dragon, and giant ‚Äì described in the video as ‚Äúprotectors‚Äù that ‚Äúfrom the dawn of time [‚Ä¶] have watched over the land [‚Ä¶] and repel every invasion.‚Äù Featuring drone footage of Icelandic glaciers and volcanic eruptions and narration by Icelandic actress Hera Hilmar, the video revealing the crest is not short on drama. That seemed to appeal to many fans of Icelandic football around the world. ‚ÄúLove the mythology, love the voice-over. Bravo all around!‚Äù commented one Twitter user. ‚ÄúEverything, and I mean everything, is perfect in this video,‚Äù stated another. Our new national team crest. pic.twitter.com/6Bk17WeO5u ‚Äî Knattspyrnusambandi√∞ (@footballiceland) July 1, 2020  The praise for the video was not unanimous, however, with some criticising its imagery as divisive and even fascist. ‚ÄúYuck to this type of image of Iceland that emphasises isolation, exclusion, and uses aesthetics that refer to the fascist tradition,‚Äù one critic tweeted in Icelandic. Icelandic artist and art professor Gu√∞mundur Oddur Magn√∫sson, known as Goddur, did not have high praise for the video, stating it was ‚Äúnot a testimony of virtues, it‚Äôs just chauvinism, jingoism [‚Ä¶] This is the peak of stupidity, to release something like this.‚Äù Regarding the crest itself, he commented: ‚ÄúI have nothing against the crest and it can stand as an ornamental crest, but I find it a little peculiar that it makes no reference to football.‚Äù

headline: Icelandic CrossFitters Criticize CEO‚Äôs Reponse to Protests
body: Following CrossFit‚Äôs controversial response to protests surrounding the death of George Floyd, Icelandic CrossFitters have taken to social media to criticize company leadership. The Icelandic gym CrossFit Reykjav√≠k has also threatened to drop their affiliation with CrossFit unless ‚Äúdrastic changes are made.‚Äù CrossFit is a branded fitness regimen and competitive sport founded by Greg Glassman and Lauren Jenai in 2000. Since its founding, CrossFit has enjoyed increasing popularity around the world. In 2005, the company was affiliated with 13 gyms. Today, it is estimated that CrossFit is practised by members of over 13,000 gyms worldwide. There are several CrossFit affiliated gyms in Iceland. Following protests centring around the death of American citizen George Floyd at the hands of police officer Derek Chauvin, CrossFit CEO Greg Glassman came under fire for a series of controversial tweets. On June 6, after the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (a public health body) stated that racism was a public health issue on Twitter, Glassman responded by tweeting: ‚ÄúFLOYD-19.‚Äù Three days earlier, Alyssa Royse ‚Äì the owner of Rocket CrossFit, a nine-year affiliate gym ‚Äì announced her intention of changing Rocket CrossFit‚Äôs name to Rocket Community Fitness and disaffiliating from CrossFit when it was time to renew. Among the reasons for her decision, was CrossFit‚Äôs failure to take a stand. ‚ÄúThe George Floyd murder threw our country into massive unrest. CrossFit is the only major brand I can think of that has failed to take a stand, make a statement, show support for social justice in general and Black lives in specific,‚Äù Royse wrote. Glassman‚Äôs reply, later shared by Royse, stated that he sincerely believed that the quarantine had ‚Äúadversely impacted‚Äù her mental health. The email went on to call Royse ‚Äúdelusional‚Äù and a ‚Äúshitty person.‚Äù On June 7, Reebok announced that it would not be extending its contract as the sponsor for the CrossFit Games. That same day, sports scientist and performance director Mike Young published an article on Medium alleging that Glassman had repeatedly stated, ‚ÄúI do not mourn George Floyd,‚Äù to a Minneapolis CrossFit gym owner on a group video conference call. Glassman later issued an apology on Twitter: ‚ÄúI, CrossFit HQ, and the CrossFit community will not stand for racism. I made a mistake by the words I chose yesterday. My heart is deeply saddened by the pain it has caused. It was a mistake, not racist but a mistake. Floyd is a hero in the black community and not just a victim. I should have been sensitive to that and wasn‚Äôt. I apologize for that.‚Äù In response to the scandal, Iceland CrossFit athletes have taken to social media and a few CrossFit gyms in Iceland, including CrossFit Reykjav√≠k, are considering dropping their affiliation. Writing on Instagram yesterday, Annie Mist √û√≥risd√≥ttir ‚Äì winner of the CrossFit Games in 2011 and 2012 ‚Äì criticized the company‚Äôs response to the protests: ‚ÄúI have ALWAYS been true to myself on social media ‚Äì and I will continue to be. CrossFit is the community NOT just the brand. CrossFit much more than just ONE individual. CrossFit is ALL of US. CrossFit is universally scaleable, CrossFit has room for everyone regardless of colour, gender, or sexual orientation.‚Äù  A post shared by Annie Thorisdottir (@anniethorisdottir) on Jun 7, 2020 at 3:26pm PDT  In a similar message on Instagram on the same day, Katr√≠n Tanja Dav√≠√∞sd√≥ttir ‚Äì who followed in her compatriot‚Äôs footsteps by placing first in the CrossFit Games in 2015 and 2016 ‚Äì said that she was ‚Äúashamed, disappointed, and angry.‚Äù Referencing Glassman‚Äôs ‚ÄúFloyd-19‚Äù comment and his reply to Alyssa Royse, Katr√≠n Tanja stated: ‚ÄúThis is something that I DO NOT STAND FOR. This is not leadership. This is not good human nature.‚Äù   . A post shared by  Katr√≠n Tanja Dav√≠√∞sd√≥ttir (@katrintanja) on Jun 7, 2020 at 10:29am PDT  Ragnhei√∞ur Sara Sigmundsd√≥ttir ‚Äì who placed third in the CrossFit Games in 2015 and 2016 ‚Äì also took to Instagram last night, stating that equality has always been central to her morality: ‚ÄúFortunately, our community is MUCH stronger than the words of one man. His words do not represent us, and you can be sure that I will stand up for what is right with our community.‚Äù   Equality is, has and always will be my biggest value therefore I have been struggling to put into words what is going through my mind after what just happened this weekend. ‚Å£ ‚Å£ When you walk into a Crossfit gym it does not matter what gender you are, what the color of your skin is, what your background is or how athletic you are. Everybody is accepted and respected and that is exactly what I have always stood for and will always stand for.‚Å£ ‚Å£ Fortunately our community is MUCH stronger than the words of one man. His words do not represent us and you can be sure that I will stand up for what is right with our community.‚Å£ ‚Å£ üññüèªüññüèºüññüèΩüññüèæüññüèø‚Å£ ‚Å£ ‚Å£ #livingiseasywitheyesclosed A post shared by  Sara SigmundsdoÃÅttir (@sarasigmunds) on Jun 8, 2020 at 6:39am PDT

headline: Iceland‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Mountain‚Äù Breaks World Record for Deadlift
body: Icelander Haf√æ√≥r J√∫l√≠us Bj√∂rnsson set a new world record for deadlift on May 2 when he lifted 501 kilograms (1,104.5 pounds). Haf√æ√≥r is a professional strongman and actor, best known for his portrayal of Gregor ‚ÄúThe Mountain‚Äù Clegane in HBO series Game of Thrones. Haf√æ√≥r surpassed Eddie Hall‚Äôs previous strongman deadlift record of 500kg (1,102.3lbs) set in 2016. Haf√æ√≥r is the first person to have won the Arnold Strongman Classic, Europe‚Äôs Strongest Man and World‚Äôs Strongest Man in the same calendar year. He has been the defending champion of the Arnold Strongman Classic three years running. Haf√æ√≥r‚Äôs record-setting was little reported on in Iceland, where he is a controversial figure. In 2017, two Icelandic companies reconsidered their promotional contracts with the strongman when several of his ex-girlfriends came forward with allegations of domestic abuse. One of them, Thelma Bj√∂rk Steimann, also the mother of Haf√æ√≥r‚Äôs child, described years of sexual violence she was subjected to by Haf√æ√≥r in an interview that same year. Haf√æ√≥r has denied all the accusations.

headline: Farewell, Gu√∞j√≥n Valur: Iceland‚Äôs All-Time Top Scorer Retires
body: Icelandic handball player Gu√∞j√≥n Valur Sigur√∞sson has announced his retirement from the sport. Gu√∞j√≥n Valur, who will turn 41 this fall, concludes his career with Paris Saint Germain. A long and illustrious career Gu√∞j√≥n Valur Sigur√∞sson was born on August 8, 1979. He began his career with Gr√≥tta in Seltjarnarnes, before moving north to Akureyri and joining KA. He played his first match with the national handball team in December 1999. Gu√∞j√≥n Valur went on to play for seven clubs in four countries, among them Rhein-Neckar L√∂wen, AG K√∏benhavn, and FC Barcelona Lassa. He won his first Champions League title in 2015 with Barcelona. He joined Paris Saint-Germain in 2019. For over three decades, Gu√∞j√≥n Valur has enjoyed a remarkable career with Iceland‚Äôs national team. He has participated in ten Euros, eight World Cups, and three Olympics. He won a silver medal at the 2008 Olympics and a bronze medal at the 2010 EHF Euro. Yesterday, Gu√∞j√≥n Valur announced his retirement on Instagram: ‚ÄúWell, it‚Äôs come to that time in my career that all athletes reach eventually. After 25 years at the senior level and 21 years in the national team, I‚Äôve decided to retire ‚Ä¶ I would like to thank all those who have stood by me through thick and thin.‚Äù All-time top scorer Gu√∞j√≥n Valur is Iceland‚Äôs all-time top scorer. He scored a total of 1,879 goals in 365 games, which also makes him highest-scoring handball player in the history of international competition. Gu√∞j√≥n Valur is also the EHF‚Äôs Euro‚Äôs all-time top scorer. He was the highest-scoring player at the 2007 World Cup, as well. ‚ÄúOne just wants to be a good person‚Äù Iceland Review spoke to Gu√∞j√≥n Valur earlier this year, in the lead-up to the 2020 European Men‚Äôs Handball Championship. Asked to speculate upon his legacy, Gu√∞j√≥n Valur told IR that it was for others to judge: ‚ÄúI just hope that I leave as few people disappointed as possible. As time goes by, one just wants to be a good person. To make good decisions. I don‚Äôt worry about the handball so much; so long as one works hard, it‚Äôll be fine.‚Äù

headline: Icelanders Run Around the World, From Home
body: A new website allows participants to participate in a virtual relay race around the world. The website Hlaupum kringum hn√∂tt¬≠inn, or ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs Run Around the World,‚Äô was started by a group of Icelanders looking to do ‚Äúsomething constructive to lift our moods during the epidemic.‚Äù Participants are encouraged to log the kilometres they jog every day and take part in a virtual trip around the globe‚Äî‚Äù with a distance of two metres between runners,‚Äù of course. The race kicked off on Monday this week, and at time of writing, 771 participants had run 6,033 km or 13% of the way around the world. The route started in Reykjav√≠k before making its next stops in √û√≥rsh√∂fn, Glasgow, London, Paris, Florence, and Athens. Next up are Adis Ababa, Nairobi, Johannesburg, and the South Pole. Each participant has run an average of 7.8 km a day thus far. √û√≥rlindur Kjartansson, one of the site‚Äôs founders, says that a project like this is all the more necessary while the gathering ban is in effect and people need to be prioritizing both their physical and mental health. The group doesn‚Äôt yet know how the race will continue after the round-the-world goal has been reached, but plans to keep the site up and running until Iceland is no longer in a state of emergency due to COVID-19.

headline: Two Cross-Country Skiers Rescued in North Iceland
body: The Dalbj√∂rg Search and Rescue squad in Eyjafj√∂r√∞ur in North Iceland came to the aid of two skiers who got stranded while trying to cross the highlands. R√öV reports that the skiers had registered a detailed travel plan at safetravel.is which greatly aided rescuers in locating them and bringing them to safety. The skiers intended to cross the highlands from north to south. However, on Thursday, one of them got wet and very cold during the expedition, which prevented the pair from either going back the way they came or continuing on their journey. They sent word to a contact in Canada, who in turn, got in touch with Icelandic authorities to request assistance on their behalf. The information that ICE-SAR received from this third party was unclear, but happily, the skiers had registered a detailed itinerary on that made it possible for rescuers to pinpoint their location without difficulty. Two ICE-SAR volunteers on snowmobiles left from Eyjafj√∂r√∞ur on Thursday afternoon to find the skiers, who were taking shelter in a tent east of Ur√∞arvatn lake. At the time of writing, a rescue vehicle was on the way to transport the skiers back to Akureyri. ¬†

headline: Northern Lights Run in Downtown Reykjav√≠k Tonight
body: The Northern Lights ‚Äòfun run‚Äô (or walk) will take place in Reykjav√≠k tonight, Saturday, February 8. Starting at 7pm, brightly clad participants will set out from the Reykjav√≠k Art Museum on a 5 km trot through downtown, which will be illuminated for the occasion. Runners will all get their very own light-up gear as well, making them ‚Äúpart of the entire show from start to finish.‚Äù The Northern Lights Run is part of the Reykjav√≠k Winter Lights Festival, which has been part of the city‚Äôs event calendar for the last 18 years. Billed as an event dedicated to ‚Äúfeeling healthy, having fun, and spending an amazing night out with friends and/or family,‚Äù the run isn‚Äôt timed but is expected to take anywhere between 20 and 70 minutes. The course runs past Harpa, through Hallgr√≠mskirkja, past Hlj√≥msk√°linn by Tj√∂rnin pond, through City Hall, and ends back at the Reykjav√≠k Art Museum on Tryggvagata. DJs will be set up at ‚Äúfun stations‚Äù along the route and there will be a dance party at the art museum at the end of the event. The route will be closed to traffic throughout the event. All participants must register for the event and are reminded to dress for the weather in bright, reflective colours so that they can easily be seen in the dark. Runners and walkers may not bring their dogs, but prams and strollers are acceptable, as long as they are fitted with reflectors or lights. Walkers are asked to stay to the right so that people moving faster can pass on the left. Find more information on the Northern Lights Run website, here.

headline: John Snorri Cancels K2 Climb
body: Icelandic mountaineer John Snorri Sigurj√≥nsson has cancelled his planned climb of K2, the world‚Äôs second-highest mountain. John was hoping to be the first person ever to climb the mountain during winter. The decision to cancel the ascent was made after two members of John‚Äôs team expressed they did not feel fully prepared for the expedition. ‚ÄúSummiting K2 in winter is a formidable task that necessitates all team members being fully prepared, both mentally and physically, to face the challenge,‚Äù John Snorri wrote in a Facebook post yesterday announcing the decision. ‚ÄúTeam members Mingma G of Nepal and Ga Li of China have both expressed that they don‚Äôt feel fully prepared to make the scheduled attempt of personal reason [sic]. Taking this into consideration and after much deliberation, it has been decided that the mission will not go forward.‚Äù In an interview with mbl.is, John‚Äôs wife L√≠na M√≥ey Bj√∂rnsd√≥ttir stated that John had been ready to go ahead with the expedition, despite two members of the team dropping out. The decision to cancel the trip was made when the five other team members did not trust themselves to continue under the changed circumstances. ‚ÄúThere have to be more of them,‚Äù L√≠na explained. ‚ÄúThe ice on the mountain, as he described it to me, is like safety glass. You have to kick it four to five times with crampons and the ice axe to get a grip. They would quickly get very tired and would have to always be taking turns and doing it together. They could have never done it just three.‚Äù L√≠na said John Snorri was already on his way to Islamabad, the Pakistani capital, and would be home in Iceland after the weekend. ‚ÄúIt was a big disappointment for him to have to cancel the trip,‚Äù she stated.

headline: Icelanders Disappoint the Danes at 2020 Euro
body: The Hungarian national handball team defeated Iceland in the teams‚Äô final game of the 2020 Euro group stages. As a result of the Icelanders‚Äô loss, the Danish national team was eliminated from the competition. The Danish press expressed its disappointment following the Danish exit, V√≠sir reports. Following a six-goal loss against Hungary yesterday, the Icelandic national handball team advances to the main round of the 2020 Euro (with zero points). As noted by the Danish Jyllands-Posten, ‚Äúwhat Hungary and Iceland have in common is that they will play their first game of the main rounds on Friday. Denmark will not.‚Äù The Danish press has criticised the performance of the Danish national team ever since its loss against Iceland last Saturday. The criticism continued yesterday. The Danes did, however, secure a consolation victory against Russia yesterday ‚Äì in a game that, as far as the competition went, meant nothing. ‚ÄúNo help: Danes exit the Euro,‚Äù a headline from Ekstra Bladet reads. Other observations include, ‚ÄúIceland couldn‚Äôt help the Danes‚Äù and ‚Äúthe Danes needed the Icelanders‚Äô help to advance to the main round, but no such thing happened.‚Äù Claus M√∏ller Jakobsen, a commentator with TV 2 Sport, agrees that there is no other word for the Danes‚Äô performance than ‚Äúfiasco.‚Äù ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no doubt that this is a fiasco. Denmark has, in two games, not displayed the quality the team possesses.‚Äù Iceland will face off against Slovenia tomorrow at 3 pm in the team‚Äôs first match in the main rounds.

headline: National Handball Team Advances to Euro Main Round
body: The Icelandic National Handball Team advanced to the main round of the 2020 EHF European Men‚Äôs Handball Championship yesterday. Iceland beat Russia 34:23 and sits atop Group E with four points. The Icelandic National Handball Team played its second match of the EHF European Men‚Äôs Handball Championship against Russia yesterday. Iceland had the upper hand for the entire game, enjoying a seven-goal lead during half time. The team played well during the second half, beating the Russians by 11 goals. The final score was 34:23. As Iceland won its opening match against Denmark on Saturday, the team has secured four points after two rounds. Shortly after Iceland‚Äôs match against Russia, Olympic Champions Denmark faced off against Hungary ‚Äì desperately needing a win; Denmark had zero points after a first-round loss against Iceland. Hungary, on the other hand, had secured two points following a narrow win against Russia. Securing an early advantage, Hungary maintained their lead for almost the entire match. With only a few minutes remaining of the game, the Hungarians were leading by two goals (23:21). The Danes mustered a comeback, scoring three goals in quick succession (23:24). In the final moments of the game, Hungarian Zoltan Szita equalised. Danish captain Mikkel Hansen had the opportunity of securing a Danish win, but goalkeeper Roland Mikler rebuffed his attempt. Final score 24:24. Denmark‚Äôs loss means that Iceland sits atop Group E with four points, Hungary has three points, Denmark has one point and Russia zero points. Iceland is, therefore, the only team in Group E that has advanced to the main round. The final round of the group stages will take place next Wednesday, January 15.

headline: Iceland Beats Denmark in European Handball Championships
body: Icelanders rejoiced last Saturday as the National Handball Team beat Denmark in their first 2020 European Championships match in Malm√∂, Sweden. As 2016 Olympic champions, Denmark was the clear favourite going into the match, but what made the victory even sweeter was that Iceland‚Äôs coach, Gu√∞mundur Gu√∞mundsson, is the one who coached Denmark to that Olympic win. The teams were neck and neck throughout the match. While Denmark appeared to have a slight advantage in the first half, the second half started 15-15. With 92 seconds to go, Icelandic captain Gu√∞j√≥n Valur Sigur√∞sson secured a two-goal lead of 31-29. The Danes nevertheless brought that score to 31-30 ‚Äì and had a chance to equalise with a penalty throw at the very end of the match. The throw was saved by Icelandic veteran goalkeeper Bj√∂rgvin P√°ll G√∫stavsson, giving Iceland the win with a final score of 31-30. The final review of the night covers the shock result in Malm√∂, where @HSI_Iceland üáÆüá∏ beat reigning world and Olympic champions @dhf_haandbold üá©üá∞ in a knife-edge match!#ehfeuro2020 #dreamwinrememberhttps://t.co/a9jt60l5bj ‚Äî EHF EURO (@EHFEURO) January 11, 2020  The Icelandic team plays Russia this afternoon at 5.15pm.

headline: Icelander Breaks World Record in Sand Drag
body: Kristj√°n Stef√°nson, a driver for Kvartm√≠lukl√∫bburinn (The Quarter Mile Club), has set a world record in sand drag, R√öV reports. Kristj√°n set the record last September but it was not confirmed until this week when it was officially registered by World Sand Drag News. Kristj√°n competes in the A/SPort Modified division where drivers compete over a distance of 100 metres in the sand. Last September, at Sandspyrnuglj√∫fri√∞, Kristj√°n crossed the finish line in a record 3.794 seconds. He reached speeds of 87.41 miles per hour (roughly 140 km per hour), which is also a record. The Motor Racing Association of Iceland broke the news earlier today. Kvartm√≠lukl√∫bburinn was founded on July 6, 1975. The inaugural meeting was held at Hotel Loftlei√∞ir. That same year the club best hosting car shows and sand drag competitions.

headline: Men‚Äôs National Handball Team Prepares for Euro 2020
body: The Men‚Äôs National Handball team will play its opening match at the 2020 EHF European Men‚Äôs Handball Championship against Denmark next Saturday, January 11. Team captain Gu√∞j√≥n Valur Sigur√∞sson, who turned 40 last summer, will be competing at the EURO for the eleventh time. In an interview yesterday, Gu√∞j√≥n Valur expressed his gratitude for still being able to compete at the highest level. The 2020 EHF European Men‚Äôs Handball Championship will take place between January 9 to January 26. It will be the first time that competition is co-hosted in three countries, Austria, Norway and Sweden. Iceland was drawn into Group E alongside Denmark, Hungary, and Russia. At a press conference held at Alvogen headquarters in Reykjav√≠k yesterday afternoon, Iceland Review spoke to captain Gu√∞j√≥n Valur Sigur√∞sson. He will be competing at the EURO for the eleventh time. No other Icelandic handball player has participated in the competition as often. Gu√∞j√≥n Valur admitted that a lot had changed in his roughly twenty-year career with the national team. ‚ÄúYou learn from the mistakes you‚Äôve made; from the coaches and the teams you‚Äôve played with; from the poor performances; from that meal you ate too close to game time. As you grow older, you begin focusing more on sleep, diet, mental health. Everything. Whether that‚Äôs experience speaking or just me getting older and more emotional ‚Äì I can‚Äôt say. Hopefully, you grow wiser, smarter, and more crafty as you grow older. It would be a shame if I were making the same mistakes today as when I was twenty.‚Äù Gu√∞j√≥n Valur played his first match with the national team in December 1999. No other outfield player has played as many matches for the national team. Gu√∞j√≥n Valur is also the highest-scoring handball player in the history of the national team. ‚ÄúI have learned a lot from having spent my entire life as a handball player.‚Äù When asked about the biggest change, in terms of stepping onto the court today as compared to 20 years ago, Gu√∞j√≥n Valur spoke of gratitude. ‚ÄúToday, I‚Äôm just grateful for being able to do this. I don‚Äôt take it for granted anymore. When one is 20, 25 years old, everything is a piece of cake. One stays up later, sleeps less, and can eat hamburgers and hot-dogs every meal. When one reaches one‚Äôs forties, however, sleep becomes more important. So does spending time with family.‚Äù

headline: Mountaineer John Snorri‚Äôs Marathon K2 Preparation Hike Cut Short
body: Mountaineer John Snorri Sigurj√≥nsson completed 8 of planned 14 trips up and down Esja mountain, V√≠sir reports. The ambitious hike is a fundraising venture for his planned trip up K2, the world‚Äôs second-highest mountain. John Snorri plans to be the first to top the mountain in winter. He had planned to make the 14 trips in 28 hours, but an injury stopped him short. None the less, 8 trips up and down the Esja mountain in 18 hours is no small feat. The combined length of the 14 Esja climbs is slightly longer than what John Snorri will have to traverse to climb K2, which is 8,611 metres (28,251 feet) high. He invited friends and supporters to join him for one or more of the 14 hikes. Among his company on the first trip up was Dean Carriere, who climbed Manasla with John Snorri this fall: the world‚Äôs eighth-highest peak. John Snorri plans to start his K2 climb in January. When asked why he was setting out on the challenge, Snorri stated ‚ÄúBecause I know I can do it and I want to see the Icelandic flag on the top of K2 in the winter. The first flag in the world, for it to be Icelandic. No one can take that away. It will always be the first flag that stood on K2 in wintertime.‚Äù John stopped the hike due to an inflammation in his right knee. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs no major issue but since there are only two weeks until I leave for Pakistan I thought it was sensible to not risk any further injuries. These sprints up and down the Esjan were mainly thought as both practice and for fundraising, but not to jeopardize the project,‚Äù John said in an announcement. John‚Äôs K2 trip is expected to cost between ISK 22-24 million ($180,000-196,000/‚Ç¨161,000-176,000). Locals who would like to support the journey can make a bank transfer to the account 549-26-52, kennitala (social security number) 200673-5499. Esjan Esjan is 914 metres high, looking over Reykjav√≠k 10 kilometres from the north. It is a popular pastime to climb the mountain in both summer and wintertime. Esjan is a volcanic range of mountains rather than a single mountain, but is still spoken of as one mountain. John Snorri climbed up towards Steinn rock in the Esjan mountain, which is approximately a 6.6 kilometre hike from the starting point as well a climb of 597 metres.

headline: Moldovan Choir Steals Show at Men‚Äôs Football Game
body: The Icelandic men‚Äôs football team played their final match at the UEFA Euro 2020 qualifiers yesterday evening. Among the evening‚Äôs highlights was the performance of Iceland‚Äôs national anthem, L√∂fs√∂ngur, by a Moldovan choir. The Icelandic men‚Äôs football team competed against Moldova at the Zimbru Stadium in Chi»ôinƒÉu, Moldova, yesterday. Iceland beat Moldova 2-1 with goals from captain Gylfi Sigur√∞sson and Birkir Bjarnason (Nicolae Milinceanu scored Moldova‚Äôs only goal). Despite winning the match, Iceland failed to directly qualify for the Euro 2020 Championship. Iceland placed third in Group H with 19 points (Iceland can still qualify through play-offs in March). Prior to the match, a choir comprised of approximately 30 women, dressed in white robes, sang the Icelandic national anthem, L√∂fs√∂ngur (see below). As a journalist for V√≠sir insinuated, the performance was a pleasant contrast to the boos of Turkish supporters during Iceland‚Äôs penultimate match in Turkey last Thursday.

headline: Men‚Äôs Football Team Takes on Turkey in Clutch Match
body: The Men‚Äôs National Football Team will compete against Turkey this afternoon in a crucial match for the UEFA Euro 2020 qualifiers. Two rounds are left of the Euro 2020 qualifiers. Turkey sits at the top of Group H with 19 points (level with France) and will advance to the UEFA European Championship if it manages a tie against Iceland. Iceland, on the other hand, is in third place with 15 points and must win the next two matches to advance (while also hoping that Turkey loses points against Andorra on Sunday). In the event that Iceland loses against Turkey, the team may still qualify via play-offs next March. It remains unclear what teams will advance through to the play-off round. It will not be determined until after the qualifiers. Iceland will play without team captain Aron Gunnarsson (Al-Arabi) and fellow midfielder J√≥hann Berg Gu√∞mundsson (Burnley), both of whom are injured. Turkey will be without forward Cenk Tosun (Everton) who is injured. Team captain, Emre Bel√∂zoƒülu (Fenerbah√ße), remains a doubt.  The match will begin at 17:00 and it will be played at the T√ºrk Telekom Stadium in Istanbul (home stadium of Galtasaray S.K.). The match will be broadcast live on R√öV. Iceland qualified for the UEFA European Championship for the first time in 2016. The team advanced through the group stages and secured a 2-1 victory against England in the round of 16. The lost 2-5 against France in the quarter-finals.

headline: What Iceland Has to Do to Qualify for European Championships
body: Chances for the Icelandic men‚Äôs national football team to qualify for the UEFA European Championships next year appear quite slim. In order to make it to the 2020 tournament, the team needs to win their upcoming matches against Turkey and Moldova, as well as see favourable outcomes from other matches in Group H.¬†¬†The team lost 0-1 to France last Friday, however it won 2-0 against Andorra yesterday evening. The Icelandic men‚Äôs national football team stands in third place¬†in their group so far with 15 points overall. Turkey and France stand in first and second with 19 points each. Iceland would need to win both its upcoming matches to ensure qualification, which would additionally depend on Turkey losing its match against Andorra. Since Andorra has only won a single match in the qualifiers so far, that result is unlikely. Icelandic football fans still have reason to hope, however, thanks to the UEFA Nations League, which offers Iceland a secondary route to qualify for the tournament.

headline: Men‚Äôs Football Team Takes on France in Crucial Match
body: The Men‚Äôs National Football Team will compete against France tonight in a crucial match for the UEFA Euro 2020 qualifiers. France will be hoping to overtake group-leader Turkey (the two teams are level on points although Turkey has conceded fewer goals). Meanwhile, Iceland is also challenging for the top two places (Iceland is three points behind Turkey and France). The top two teams in each group qualify. Iceland and France have gone head-to-head a total of 14 times. Les Bleus have been victorious ten times, with four matches resulting in a draw (France leads 41-12 on aggregate).¬†During the two teams‚Äô first match in 1957, during the World Cup qualifiers, France embarrassed Iceland with an 8-0 rout. In March, the two teams faced off in Paris for their first match in the qualifiers. France beat Iceland 4-0. Both teams will play without their team captains: Icelandic midfielder Aron Gunnarsson (Al-Arabi) and French goalkeeper Hugo Lloris (Tottenham) have both been ruled out with injuries. Iceland will also have to do without H√∂r√∞ur Bj√∂rgvin Magn√∫sson (CSKA Moscow), while Les Bleus will be without Paul Pogba (Manchester United) and Kylian Mbapp√© (PSG). As R√öV reports, however, France will field a strong team. Antoine Grizemann (Barcelona); Raphael Varane (Real Madrid); N‚ÄôGolo Kant√© and Olivier Giroud (Chelsea); Kingsley Coman, Lucas Hern√°ndez, Benjamin Pavard and Corentin Tolisso (Bayern Munich) are all expected to play. Italian Gianluca Rocchi will officiate. The match ‚Äì which is long since sold out ‚Äì will begin at 18:45 at Laugardalsv√∂llur stadium in Reykjav√≠k tonight.

headline: Women‚Äôs National Football Team Wins First Euro ‚Äô21 Qualifier
body: Iceland‚Äôs national women‚Äôs football team won their first qualifying match for the 2021 European Championships against Hungary, R√öV reports, with a final score of 4-1. Hopes were high for the squad when the game began at Laugardalsv√∂llur stadium on Thursday night. Energy was high from kickoff and the Icelandic team had many good opportunities early on. El√≠n Metta Jensen gave the team their first goal in the 9th minute after a cross from Hallbera G√≠slad√≥ttir. The Hungarian squad evened the score with a goal in the 41st minute, but the Icelandic team came back fighting after half time. Hl√≠n Eir√≠ksd√≥ttir scored again in the 59th minute, followed by Dagn√Ω Brynjarsd√≥ttir in the 64th. El√≠n Metta then capped off an excellent game by scoring again in extra time. The Iceland women‚Äôs national team will match up against Slovakia on September 2, and then France on October 4.

headline: Parking Lot Becomes Harbourside Park
body: Mi√∞bakkinn, a former parking lot along the Reykjav√≠k waterfront that has been converted into a public space for families, was opened during a public ceremony on Friday, V√≠sir reports. Mi√∞bakkinn includes a children‚Äôs cycling area, a skate park, and a basketball court. Its skate park was designed in collaboration with Steinar Fjeldsted, a skateboarder and graffiti artist who runs a skateboarding school in Reykjav√≠k, and Sesselja Traustad√≥ttir, a cycling educator and activist, designed the cycling area. Young artists were commissioned to paint the ground murals, which feature a giant crab, fish, and a sailor‚Äôs knot. Friday‚Äôs celebration featured musical performances and food trucks, both of which will return for Iceland‚Äôs first street fair, which will take place at Mi√∞bakkinn from July 19 ‚Äì 21. The fair will also have pop-up shops, coffee stalls, and scheduled entertainment. ‚ÄúI think this will be a very lively and fun area which was, of course, a parking lot, but has now become part of city residents‚Äô public space‚Äù remarked Sigurborg √ìsk Haraldsd√≥ttir, the chair of the City of Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs planning committee. ‚ÄúBecause it‚Äôs not going to go back to being a parking lot‚Ä¶the idea is that, over time, it will have permanent facilities for these kinds of sports and other kinds of harbourside activities.‚Äù

headline: Icelandic Cricket Association Offers Indian Cricket Star to Play for Iceland
body:
The Icelandic Cricket Association raised attention online yesterday when it invited Indian cricket start Ambati Rayudu to Iceland to play for the Icelandic team. Rayudu was snubbed for a call up to the Indian cricket team for the ongoing ICC Cricket World Cup in England.  The offer was made tongue-in-cheek by the Icelandic Cricket Association via Twitter, where the team has raised attention online recently. Rayudu had officially retired from cricket this Wednesday, so who knows if he will pick up the bat once again to play for Iceland. The Indian star was both snubbed for the original 15 man squad as well as two other players being selected ahead of him as injury replacements. The Icelandic Cricket Association thus offered Rayudu to apply for permanent residency in the country in order to play for the national team. The matter has received due attention in India, where news outlets such as India Today, Indian Times, Indian Express, and CNN-News 18 have covered it. Agarwal has three professional wickets at 72.33 so at least @RayuduAmbati can put away his 3D glasses now. He will only need normal glasses to read the document we have prepared for him. Come join us Ambati. We love the Rayudu things. #BANvIND #INDvBAN #CWC19 pic.twitter.com/L6XAefKWHw ‚Äî Iceland Cricket (@icelandcricket) July 1, 2019  ‚ÄúThe offer was mostly made as a joke,‚Äù said Jakob Wayne Robertson, the spokesperson and ex-president of the Icelandic Cricket Association. ‚ÄúOf course we‚Äôd happily accept Rayudu, but we wouldn‚Äôt be able to pay him any wages. He‚Äôs a professional.‚Äù Cricket up North
The Icelandic Cricket Association was formed in 2000, with the first official match of the national team taking place the same year. There are no cricket-specific stadia or training grounds in the country for the 35 players who play the sport. The association even claims that the sport was founded by Icelandic Vikings in the year 911. The team‚Äôs history online certainly proves a good read: https://www.krikket.is/history.
The team is not part of the official International Cricket Council but plays friendly matches against other nations both home and abroad. The team‚Äôs vice-captain is Delhi born Abhishek Raj Chauhan, who holds Icelandic citizenship and works as a bartender. The association has been flooded with messages asking to join the team since the tweet went out, leading the Icelandic Cricket Association to ask people to stop sending them e-mails. Guys we love you very much but please stop sending us emails asking if we can get you a visa to play for Iceland. We‚Äôre a national board. We select our players from residents of Iceland. We suggest you try the English county cricket system, they‚Äôll take anyone. ‚Äî Iceland Cricket (@icelandcricket) July 2, 2019  Follow the Icelandic Cricket Association on Twitter: https://twitter.com/icelandcricket

headline: CrossFit Athlete Receives Second Drug-Related Suspension
body: CrossFit athlete Hinrik Ingi √ìskarsson has received a four-year ban from the organization CrossFit, Inc. for failing a drug test at the Reykjav√≠k CrossFit Championship in May, R√öV reports. This is his second drug-related suspension in three years. Hinrik Ingi‚Äôs suspension was announced (along with that of American CrossFit athlete Elly Kabboord) on crossfit.com, which explained that ‚Äú[t]he sample [he] provided on May 4, 2019 at the Reykjav√≠k CrossFit Championship tested positive for ostarine and RAD-140. Ostarine and RAD-140 are classified as anabolic agents.‚Äù Both substances are prohibited in CrossFit competitions. The drug test at the Reykjav√≠k CrossFit Championship was conducted by a representative from the IcelandicAnti-Doping Organization after Hinrik Ingi came in second place, threeby securing himself a spot at the international CrossFit Games. Per barbend.com, Hinrik Ingi‚Äôs first suspension occurred in 2016 when ‚Äú‚Ä¶he was asked to submit a drug test after finishing in first place at the Nike Iceland Throwdown.‚Äù He refused, however, ‚Äú‚Ä¶to submit the sample [and] was banned from competition for two years.‚Äù At the time, Hinrik Ingi accused CrossFit Iceland of unfairly targeting him and had been out to get him from the beginning. When asked directly whether he‚Äôd been taking steroids, he told R√öV that ‚ÄúI have never taken steroids and in all likeliness, never will.‚Äù Hinrik Ingi appealed the drug test results in May, but his appeal was denied. He will, therefore, not be eligible to compete in any official CrossFit competitions until May 4, 2023.

headline: Iceland Beats Turkey 2-1 in Euro Qualifier
body: The Iceland men‚Äôs national football team beat Turkey 2-1 in a Euro qualifying match at Reykjav√≠k‚Äôs Laugardalsv√∂llur stadium last night. Centre back Ragnar Sigur√∞sson scored both of the team‚Äôs goals. Iceland started the game strong, scoring their first goal only 21 minutes in. The second goal came only ten minutes later, giving Iceland a 2-0 lead. Turkish midfielder Dorukhan Tok√∂z did not let that score stand for long, scoring for his team at 40 minutes into the game for a final result of 2-1 for Iceland‚Äôs team. France currently holds first place in Group H, Turkey second place, and Iceland third, followed by Albania, Moldova, and Andorra. Only the top two teams from each group will qualify for the UEFA Euro final tournament.

headline: Turkey Denounces ‚ÄúDisrespectful‚Äù Treatment of Football Team at Airport
body: The Turkish government has issued a diplomatic note to Iceland denouncing what it is calling ‚Äúdisrespectful‚Äù and ‚Äúviolent‚Äù behaviour against the country‚Äôs men‚Äôs national football team, aa.com reports. The football team arrived in Keflav√≠k airport on Sunday night in advance of their Euro 2020 qualifying match against Iceland on Tuesday. They claim that they were then subjected to excessive search and security measures at passport control and were held for around three hours before being allowed to leave the airport. A representative from Isavia, the company that owns and manages the Keflav√≠k airport, told¬†R√öV that per international regulations, airport employees were obliged to conduct a security check on the team and that it was more intensive because the flight on which the team arrived departed from an airport that is not part of the One Stop Security area whose security protocols apply to all airports in the EEA. Isavia maintains that as such, all of the passengers on the flight were subjected to the same security checks ‚Äì including Icelanders. Isavia also says that the security checks took an unusually long time on Sunday night because passengers were traveling with a high number of electronic devices and liquids in their luggage, all of which needed to be individually screened. Isavia contests Turkey‚Äôs claims that players were held for three hours, however: they say that the security wait was 80 minutes from the time that the aircraft arrived. The flight arrived at 7.40pm, representatives say, and the last passenger went through customs at roughly 9.00pm. Feelings are running particularly high in the wake of the event, with some players on the Icelandic squad and Icelandic sports journalists even receiving threats over the matter. It‚Äôs likely that tensions were exacerbated during an interview that Turkish midfielder Emre Belozoglu gave after going through security; an individual who has since been identified and is presumed to be a Belgian national stuck a dishwashing brush in the player‚Äôs face like a microphone while he was being interviewed by reporters. Turkey and Iceland do not maintain embassies in each other‚Äôs countries, but Fazli Corman, Turkey‚Äôs ambassador in Norway, is apparently on his way to Iceland to follow up on the situation. Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu also posted about the incident on Twitter, saying ‚ÄúThe treatment towards our national team at the Iceland airport is not acceptable in terms of both diplomatic and humanitarian practices.‚Äù

headline: Iceland Wins Euro Qualifier Against Albania, 1-0
body: The Icelandic National Men‚Äôs football team won its Euro 2020 qualifying match against Albania on Saturday, with a final score of 1-0, mbl.is reports. Iceland earned three points as a result of the win. Although J√≥hann Berg Gu√∞mundsson, who scored the winning goal during the 22‚Äô minute, admitted to V√≠sir that the game ‚Äúwasn‚Äôt pretty,‚Äù he and his teammates were thrilled with the result, which brought Iceland up to six points in the group. Albanian coach Edoardo Reja didn‚Äôt mince words when asked about the final score, however, saying that Iceland‚Äôs win was ‚Äúundeserved,‚Äù and that it was the kind of match in which the team that scored first was likely to come out the victor. ‚ÄúAs I‚Äôve said many times, Icelanders are very strong physically ‚Äì particularly in the air ‚Äì and as such, Albania kept the ball mostly on its own half of the pitch and tried to find a hole in Iceland‚Äôs defense. That would have been possible if the game had evolved differently. But then we made terrible mistakes in our defense, such that three players were like bowling pins ‚Äì just stood there and did nothing but make horrible mistakes. It was that kind of game ‚Äì where the team that scored first was more likely to come out victorious.‚Äù The match was a scrappy one, with Iceland on the receiving end of more fouls than Albania. When asked if his team had played a rough game, Reja replied that it was ‚Äú‚Ä¶a hard game, but football is a hard game‚Äù and moreover that he thought that Iceland‚Äôs players had a tendency to dive rather easily. Regardless of how elegant the match was (or wasn‚Äôt), Johann Berg reiterated that it was an important one for Iceland to win, both in terms of the points earned and the expectations it sets for Iceland in the long term. ‚ÄúEveryone‚Äôs been saying that we‚Äôre old, tired, and the game wasn‚Äôt sold out, which is unusual for us. We were determined to win the match.‚Äù Iceland is currently in third place in their qualifying group, on six points. Turkey is in first place with nine and France is in second with six. The team‚Äôs next match will be against Turkey on June 11.

headline: Three Icelanders Summit Everest
body: Bjarni √Årmannsson, Leif¬≠ur √ñrn Svavars¬≠son, and L√Ω√∞ur Gu√∞munds¬≠son reached the top of Nepal‚Äôs Mt. Everest, the tallest mountain in the world, on Thursday. Mbl.is reports that Bjarni arrived in the morning, while the other two Icelanders arrived in the evening. As of today, then, nine Icelanders have now accomplished this feat. This is the second time that Leif¬≠ur √ñrn has summited Everest. He previously did so in 2013, when he took the North Route to the top of the mountain, which is considered more difficult. He is the only Icelander to have ever completed that route and is also the only Icelander to have ever climbed the mountain twice. L√Ω√∞ur is the third Icelander to complete what is known as the Adventure Grand Slam, which involves the climber reaching the top of the highest mountain on every continent, as well as reaching the North and South Poles. Only two other Icelanders have completed the Grand Slam: L√Ω√∞ur‚Äôs Everest-summiting comrade Leifur √ñrn, and Haraldur √ñrn √ìlafsson. Bjarni is the former CEO of Glitnir Bank and the current CEO of Iceland Seafood. A picture showing the summit at the time of Bjarni‚Äôs arrival was published on the Facebook page Mount Everest 8848M. ‚ÄúMt Everest witnessed a traffic jam near the balcony area after more than 200 climbers attempted to reach the summit point this morning,‚Äù read the caption. Bj√∂rn √ìlafsson, Einar K. Stef√°nsson, and Hallgr√≠mur Magn√∫sson became the first Icelanders to reach the top of Mt. Everest on May 21, 1997. After that, Haraldur √ñrn √ìlafsson reached the summit on May 16, 2002. Ing√≥lfur Geir Gissurarson reached the peak on May 21, 2013 at the age of fifty; Leifur √ñrn Svavarsson reached the summit (his first time) two days later. Vilborg Arna Gissurard√≥ttir became the first Icelandic woman to summit Everest on May 21, 2017.

headline: World‚Äôs Northernmost Cricket Ground to Open in Iceland
body: Iceland Cricket will open the world‚Äôs northernmost cricket field this month in Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur. At a latitude of 64.07¬∞N, the field will break the record currently held in Ume√•, Sweden (63.84¬∞N) by 25km (15.5mi). It will be officially inaugurated on May 26 by Prime Minister of Iceland Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir. The even will feature an exhibition match between a Prime Minister‚Äôs XI, captained by Katr√≠n, and a British Ambassador‚Äôs XI, captained by Michael Nevin. Modern Icelandic cricket was founded by Ragnar Kristinsson, who¬†watched the famous world cup semi-final between Australia and South Africa while¬†on holiday in Cyprus in 1999. The first practice sessions took place at¬†Elli√∞a√°rdalur and the first local teams competed in 2000. Today, Iceland has cricket clubs in Reykjav√≠k, K√≥pavogur, Gar√∞ab√¶r, Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur and Seltjarnarnes. Iceland even boasts a national cricket team, which played its first international game last summer, beating Switzerland 330 to 115. Kit Harris, who runs marketing and advertising for Iceland Cricket, says that Iceland‚Äôs cricket history goes much further back. Along with historian Tom Holland, he believes there is evidence that the Viking game ‚Äúknattleikr,‚Äù as described in Egil‚Äôs Saga and several other sagas, is the ancestor of the modern game of cricket. The exhibition match on opening day starts at 1.00pm and is free and open to the public. As is customary at cricket matches, English tea and cakes will be served. Update May 20, 2019: A previous version of this article stated the cricket ground would be officially inaugurated on May 24 by the President of Iceland. The correct day is May 26, and the inauguration will be led by Prime Minister of Iceland Katr√≠n Jakobsd√≥ttir.

headline: Iceland Loses to France in Euro Qualifiers
body: The Iceland men‚Äôs national football team lost to France last night in a UEFA Euro 2020 qualifying match. The French team won a confident 4-0 victory against the Icelanders at their home stadium in Paris. Centre-back Samuel Umtiti put the French team ahead early on with a goal in the 12th minute. It was the only goal of the first half, which ended 1-0 for France. The team added three goals late in the game, with Giroud, Mbapp√©, and Griezmann scoring in the 68th, 78th, and 84th minutes. Iceland won their first match of the qualifiers, against Andorra last Friday, with a solid 2-0 victory. The team‚Äôs next qualifying match will be a home match against Albania on June 8. The Icelandic men‚Äôs team has yet to win a match against France. The countries‚Äô last meeting, a friendly in October 2018, ended with a promising 2-2 draw. While the French team is currently ranked second in the world, Iceland sits in 38th place.

headline: First Icelander to Run 10K in Under 30 Minutes
body: Hlynur Andr√©sson became the first Icelander to run a 10k street race in under 30 minutes yesterday when he finished the Parelloop race in the Netherlands with a time of 29:49. Hlynur landed in 27th place in the run. Ugandan Mande Buschendich took first place in the race with a time of 27:56.¬†R√öV reported first. The previous Icelandic record in the category was set in 1983 when J√≥n Di√∞riksson ran 10k in 30:11 minutes in Germany. Hlynur also holds the Icelandic records for 10,000m track run, which he set in April 2018 in Charlottesville, USA with a time of 29:20.91. Hlynur has set four Icelandic records in running overall.

headline: Iceland Wins First Euro 2020 Qualifying Match
body: Iceland‚Äôs national men‚Äôs football team won its first UEFA EURO 2020 qualifying match against Andorra on Friday, R√öV reports. It is the team‚Äôs first victory under new coach Eirik Hamr√©n, following the departure of Coach Heimir Hallgr√≠msson, who led the team to their historic World Cup debut in 2018. Much as expected, Iceland took control of the game from the start and Birkir Bjarnason took the first shot on goal only eight minutes into the match. Minutes later, Ari Freyr Sk√∫lason made a great cross to Alfre√∞ Finnbogason in the goal area, but surprisingly, Alfre√∞‚Äôs shot went right over the goal. Andorra had five corner kicks in the first 20 minutes of the game, but didn‚Äôt manage to make anything of these opportunities. In the 22nd minute, Iceland got its first corner. Gylfi √û√≥r Sigur√∞sson directed the ball to Ragnar Sigur√∞sson, who headed it into the far post. Birkir Bjarnason was quick to take a rebound shot, which finally found its target. The score was 1 ‚Äì 0 at the half. The second half got off to a slower start, with very little action for the first 15 minutes of play. R√∫nar M√°r Sigurj√≥nsson then came in for captain Aron Einar Gunnarsson. Aron, who underwent knee surgery in April 2018 after sustaining an injury while playing for Cardiff City F.C., immediately had to ice his knee after coming off the field, but is expected to be in good shape to play Iceland‚Äôs next qualifying match against France in Paris on Monday evening. Vi√∞ar √ñrn Kjartansson came in for Alfre√∞ Finnbogason in the 70th minute and ten minutes later, he received a right cross from Birkir M√°r S√¶varsson and scored the second and final goal of the match. This was Vi√∞ar √ñrn‚Äôs third goal with the national team.

headline: Sara Bj√∂rk and Gylfi √û√≥r Named Footballers of the Year
body: The Football Association of Iceland (KS√ç) has named Sara Bj√∂rk Gunnarsd√≥ttir and Gylfi √û√≥r Sigur√∞sson Footballers of the Year, R√öV reports. Sara Bj√∂rk is a midfielder for the German club VfL Wolfsburg, which won both the German division and Cup titles this year, as well as playing in the Women‚Äôs Champion League final against Lyon. Sara Bj√∂rk is also the captain of Iceland‚Äôs National Women‚Äôs football team. Gylfi √û√≥r is a midfielder for the Premier League club Everton. He has scored seven goals this season and made two assists over the course of 17 matches. Gylfi √û√≥r is also a key player on Iceland‚Äôs National Men‚Äôs team and played in all three Iceland matches during the 2018 World Cup. He scored one goal during the competition, during their final group match against Croatia. KS√ç ranked Augsberg‚Äôs Alfre√∞ Finnbogason and Kristianstad‚Äôs Sif Atlad√≥ttir in second place this year. Burnley‚Äôs J√≥hann Berg and Roseng√•rd‚Äôs Gl√≥d√≠s Perla Vigg√≥sd√≥ttir came in third.

headline: Women‚Äôs Football Team Maintains Top 25 Ranking
body: The Icelandic women‚Äôs national football team has maintained its top 25 ranking among national women‚Äôs teams worldwide,¬†R√öV¬†reports. headline: Icelander Wins Gold in Youth Olympics
body: Icelander Gu√∞bj√∂rg J√≥na Bjarnad√≥ttir won gold in the Buenos Aires 2018 Summer Youth Olympic Games on Tuesday,¬†V√≠sir¬†reports. Gu√∞bj√∂rg won Iceland‚Äôs first medal in the competition for the Women‚Äôs 200 metre run. Gu√∞bj√∂rg‚Äôs total time was 47.02 seconds, 0.67 seconds less than second place winner Dalia Kaddari of Italy. The 16-year-old has had a standout year, breaking Iceland‚Äôs previous record for the 200-metre run three times since June. Gu√∞bj√∂rg also took home gold in the 100 metre run and bronze in the 200 metre run at the European Athletics U18 Championships in Hungary this July. ‚ÄúShe is both big and strong and has all the means to go far in the adult category later,‚Äù stated¬†athletics specialist¬†Sigurbj√∂rn √Årni Arngr√≠msson. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs realistic to aim for the Olympic games in Tokyo in 2020.‚Äù

headline: Iceland Manages Draw Versus World Champions France
body: France snatched a draw from the Icelandic men‚Äôs national football team yesterday,¬†R√öV reports.¬†The friendly match took place in Stade de Roudourou in Guingamp. Iceland led 0-2 before succumbing to heavy pressure from France. The Icelandic team led 0-1 going into half-time after a goal from midfielder Birkir Bjarnason. Defender K√°ri √Årnason scored a header from a corner kick early in the second half to bring Iceland‚Äôs lead to two goals. After having a goal disallowed due to offside, Mbappe‚Äôs shot forced defender H√≥lmar √ñrn Eyj√≥lfsson to score an own goal, before drawing France level from the penalty spot in additional time. The match is the 18th ever between the two teams, who last met on the pitch in 2016 during the quarter finals of the UEFA Euros. headline: Iceland Faces France in Friendly Today
body: The Icelandic men‚Äôs national football team faces France in a friendly match this evening.¬†R√öV¬†reported first. The match is the 18th ever between the two teams, who last met on the pitch in 2016 during the quarter finals of the UEFA Euros. headline: Gylfi Scores Twice For Everton
body: Gylfi Sigur√∞sson more than made up for a missed second half penalty in Everton‚Äôs Saturday Premier League match at Goodison Park against Fulham,¬†V√≠sir¬†reports. The midfielder, who has played for Everton since 2017, hit the crossbar in his penalty shot but then scored two goals. The match was scoreless at half time. Gylfi scored in the 56th minute, and his teammate, substitute Cenk Tosun, followed with another goal ten minutes later. Gylfi‚Äôs second goal came right at the end of regulation time, in the 89th minute. This is¬†the first time¬†that Everton has won at Goodison Park, having lost there 23 times‚Äîthe last 22 in a row‚Äîand drawing in their four other matches there. Everton is currently ranked 11th in the Premier League, Fulham in 16th.

headline: Three Highline Over Dettifoss
body: Two Frenchmen and one British man performed a remarkable feat on Thursday when they ‚Äòhighlined‚Äô across Dettifoss waterfall,¬†R√öV¬†reports. Highlining is a sport¬†similar to tightrope walking or slacklining, in which participants ‚Äútraverse a narrow, springy band of rope suspended high above the ground.‚Äù In this instance, the three highliners walked a rope that spanned 270 meters [886 feet] and was roughly 100 meters [328 feet] above the waterfall, which has the greatest volume of water of any waterfall in Europe. The trio are part of a larger highlining team that travels around the world practicing their craft. When they first arrived at Dettifoss, they hadn‚Äôt decided on an exact location for their crossing. But when a rainbow appeared over the waterfall when they were scouting, they decided to base their crossing location on where they saw it. It seems only fitting, then, that several rainbows appeared in the same spot during their crossing on Thursday. ‚ÄúSome people were afraid,‚Äù said Bjarni Karls¬≠son, a park ranger at Vatnaj√∂kull National Park who himself¬†watched the crossing. ‚ÄúBut most people were interested and excited.‚Äù Highliner Daniel Laruelle says the sport is like a meditation. ‚ÄúIf you manage to stay calm then you enter a quasi-meditational state on the line. It works more often than not, but when there‚Äôs a lot of stimuli around you‚Äîlike, for instance, a giant waterfall or a bunch of rainbows, then it can be difficult to keep your focus,‚Äù he admitted. But the teammates insist that the practice is actually safer than it looks. ‚ÄúAs soon as I‚Äôve secured the safety,‚Äù said Daniel, ‚ÄúI can go out on the line and fall as often as I want.‚Äù His teammates Nicolas Pouchars and Theo Sanson agreed. ‚ÄúIt is actually more dangerous to drive a car around than it is to go out on the line,‚Äù said Theo. ‚ÄúAlthough your head says something else. We do this because it‚Äôs fantastic, but it‚Äôs also symbolic. We are all looking for balance in our lives, but it is a long process and takes us a lifetime.‚Äù See pictures of the three men‚Äôs remarkable, rainbow-embellished crossing on¬†R√öV¬†here. Bjarni Karlsson‚Äôs short video and photographs are viewable on¬†mbl.is.

headline: Two Icelanders Medal at Judo Competition for Juniors
body: Two Icelanders, √ölfur B√∂√∞varsson and √Årni Lund, medaled this year‚Äôs Swedish Open judo competition for Juniors and Cadets,¬†R√öV¬†reports. √ölfur won the gold medal in the Under 90 kg class, while √Årni earned a bronze medal in the Under 81 kg group. In addition to his gold medal, √ölfur received a special award at the end of the event for the best ippon, or one-shoulder throw, of the day. Another Icelander, Gr√≠mur √çvarsson competed in the same group as √ölfur and nearly took the bronze, but was just edged out by his final opponent.

headline: Golfer Loses Eye After Lava Accident
body: A golfer lost an eye following an accident at a Hafnarfj√∂r√∞ur golf course in South Iceland a few weeks ago,¬†V√≠sir¬†reports. The victim was a highly experienced Icelandic golfer in his sixties, who was taking part in an open tournament at the course. The accident took place when the golfer was on the fifth hole, along a section of the fairway appropriately called Hrauni√∞, or ‚ÄòThe Lava.‚Äô The man‚Äôs first shot saw the ball land in some lava that surrounds the course and so he decided to try and hit it back onto the green. On one of his attempts, the golf ball hit a a lava stone that was very close to the ball [about one metre, or three feet away] and which was protruding about ten centimetres [three inches] out of the ground. The ball ricocheted backwards off the rock and hit the man directly in the eye. According to course manager √ìlafur √û√≥r √Åg√∫stsson, the man hadn‚Äôt even seen the stone when he hit the ball. An ambulance was called to the scene and the golfer was taken into surgery soon after, but doctors were unable to save his eye. According to¬†V√≠sir‚Äôs sources, some consider him lucky, despite the horrible consequences of the accident; had the ball hit him in the temple, it could have killed him. Golf course manager √ìlafur √û√≥r √Åg√∫stsson said that the staff were shocked by the incident, but that luckily, these sorts of accidents are very uncommon. He did say, however, that balls do sometimes get hit into the rocks and/or lava surrounding the two different fairways and then ricochet off of them. ‚ÄúBut this is by far the most serious [incident] that we‚Äôve had happen at the course. There‚Äôs been nothing that compares to this. But people have been close to [having things happen]. In this sport, as in any other, accidents happen,‚Äù he said, and they can‚Äôt always be foreseen. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just horrifically bad luck.‚Äù The golf course‚Äôs management is now considering increasing the number of drop spots in areas with a lot of lava, which may decrease player risk along those sections of the course.

headline: Iceland‚Äôs World Cup Dream Over
body: The Icelandic women‚Äôs football team drew 1-1 against the Czech Republic today in a World Cup qualifier. Iceland was in pole position to qualify for the World Cup, which will take place in France next year, ahead of these last two matches in Group 5. After being down 0-1 for the majority of the match, an equalizer from Gl√≥d√≠s Perla Vigg√≥sd√≥ttir brought Iceland level in the 87th minute. Iceland had the perfect chance to snatch the win in additional time but Sara Bj√∂rk Gunnarsd√≥ttir missed a penalty which would have secured Iceland‚Äôs place in the play-offs. Iceland lost 0-2 against group leaders Germany where a win would have sealed Iceland‚Äôs qualification. A win today versus the Czech Republic might have sealed Iceland‚Äôs spot in the World Cup playoffs, provided results in other groups went Iceland‚Äôs way. The four best 2nd placed sides from the 7 European qualification groups advance to the play-offs. The Icelandic women‚Äôs team has previously gone to the final stage of the EURO competition three times. This would have been the first time Iceland competes at the World Cup finals. The team is currently ranked the 19th best team in the world, according to the FIFA world rankings.

headline: Iceland Loses World Cup Qualifier Against Germany
body: The Icelandic women‚Äôs football team lost their World Cup qualifying match against Germany on Saturday, with a final score of 2 ‚Äì 0,¬†R√öV¬†reports. If the team is going to have a shot at qualifying for their first World Cup ever, then, it‚Äôs imperative they win against the Czech Republic on Tuesday. Iceland¬†went into the match¬†at the top of Group 5, with 16 points. Germany was ranked second in the group with 15 points. Had Iceland won, they could have been certain of a direct qualification. Only the group winners will go directly through to the next round, while the four best-ranked teams from the European qualifiers will have to go through additional playoffs. Iceland started their sold-out homefield match looking strong, keeping the pressure on their opponents and preventing them from seeing much of the ball. As the first half progressed, Germany slowly won more possession but Iceland‚Äôs defense remained strong until the 42nd minute, when Svenja Huth scored. The first half ended 0 ‚Äì 1, Germany. Germany came out looking much stronger at the start of the second half, while Iceland had trouble keeping possession of the ball or making any goal opportunities for themselves. Svenja Huth then scored a second goal in the 74th minute. The final score was 0 ‚Äì 2, Germany. The result puts Germany in first place in Group 5, with 18 points, while Iceland falls to second place with 16. Germany‚Äôs last group match will be against the Faroe Islands, a game they¬†are expected to win¬†easily. As such, they will almost definitely go straight through to the next round. If Iceland wants a chance at the play-offs, then, they have to win against the Czech Republic on Tuesday.

headline: Iceland‚Äôs Women One Win from World Cup
body: Tickets for the Icelandic women‚Äôs national football team match against Germany are nearly sold out,¬†R√öV¬†reports. The match takes place this Saturday at Laugardalsv√∂llur in Reykjav√≠k. headline: Men‚Äôs Team Down 10 Spots in FIFA Rankings

headline: Hamr√©n Appointed Manager of Men‚Äôs National Team
body: The Swede Erik Hamr√©n was appointed as the manager of Iceland men‚Äôs national team earlier today,¬†KS√ç reports.¬†He will take over the reigns of the team from Heimir Hallgr√≠msson, who announced that he would part ways with the team after the World Cup in Russia this summer. The Icelandic team has enjoyed unprecedented success in recent years, qualifying for the EURO 2016 and the 2018 World Cup in recent years, a first for the men‚Äôs team. In doing so, Iceland became the smallest nation to ever qualify for the respective tournaments. Hamr√©n managed Sweden‚Äôs national team from 2010 until 2016, qualifying for both EURO 2012 and EURO 2016. He has previously won the Danish league with AaB as well as the Norwegian league with Rosenborg. Furthermore, he is a three-time cup winner in his native country Sweden. His first challenge will be facing off against Switzerland in the newly formed UEFA Nations League on the 8th of September.

headline: Katr√≠n Tanja Grabs Bronze at CrossFit Games
body: CrossFit athlete Katr√≠n Tanja Dav√≠√∞sd√≥ttir finished on the podium in the CrossFit Games,¬†V√≠sir reports.The Games reached their conclusions yesterday in Madison, Wisconsin. Katr√≠n Tanja was in third place before the final event, and managed to stave off a challenge from the 4th placed Kara Saunders, who was hot on her heels. The 25 year old Katr√≠n is a two time CrossFit Games champion, having won the event in 2015 and 2016. Among other Icelandic competitors was the two-time CrossFit Games champion Annie Mist √û√≥risd√≥ttir, who finished in 5th place this time around. The only Icelandic male competitor this time around was Bj√∂rgvin Karl Gu√∞mundsson also finished in fifth place.
